HEADLINE: IN THE NATION;
Turning the Tables

BYLINE: By Tom Wicker; A. M. Rosenthal is on vacation.

 BODY:
''The Republicans,'' Ronald Reagan once declared, ''are the party of July Fourth and the Democrats are the party of April 15.''
Knowing a profitable political message when he saw it, George Bush has continued to press the theme that the Democrats would raise taxes but he won't: ''Read my lips.''
It is with some poetic justice, therefore, that President Bush now must twist and turn to deal with the one response he neither expected nor can stonewall - an attractive Democratic plan to cut taxes.
The proposal by Daniel P. Moynihan of New York to repeal the most recent increase in the Social Security payroll tax appears to have been the Senator's own brainchild. It has deficiencies that ultimately may condemn it. But the idea is so nearly diabolical in the numerous political problems it poses for Mr. Bush and the Republicans that the White House rightly fears a ''stampede'' in its favor. 
Mr. Moynihan has proposed not just any old tax cut but one that would be of most immediate benefit to low- and middle-income workers - those who have just been hit with an increase, to 7.65 percent, in payroll taxes deducted from their earnings.
This would be a tax cut, moreover, in what can plausibly be termed - as it has been, repeatedly, in this space - the most regressive U.S. tax. All workers pay the same rate, whether they make $20,000 a year or $250,000; the earnings on which the tax can be imposed (now $51,300) are also the same. Someone making that much pays the same dollar amount as a person making $250,000. And all income other than wages is exempt.
Repealing the most recent rise in this onerous tax would benefit greatly those who have suffered most in the economy of the Reagan-Bush years: high school graduates and dropouts, most of whom are payroll workers. Peter Passell reported in The New York Times on Jan. 17 that from 1979 to 1987 their real earnings fell by 9 and 15 percent respectively; in the same years, the real earnings of college graduates rose by 9 percent.
A bird in the hand, moreover, is proverbially worth two in the bush (no pun intended). Higher retirement benefits for low-income workers, as well as the Federal earned-income tax credit for poor families, make up in some degree for the regressivity of the tax Mr. Moynihan wants to cut. But benefits are far in the future, and workers are suffering stiff payroll tax deductions now while trying to make ends meet.
Nor is it only to workers that a payroll tax cut would appeal, because Social Security deductions from a worker's wages have to be matched by his employer. That's a heavy cost of doing business, from which many an employer would like to be relieved -particularly small-business people who hire only a few workers.
Thus, a proposal appealing on its own terms, to workers and employers alike, also stands in stark contrast to one of George Bush's top priorities: a capital gains tax cut. No matter how he defends this scheme, it would be of no immediate relief to most low-income Americans and would yield its primary benefits to wealthy investors. Its trickle-down effect on employment and job creation would be speculative at best.
It's possible, in fact, that a sizable reduction in the Social Security payroll tax would produce at least as many new jobs and pay increases as would Mr. Bush's capital gains tax, and perhaps more. The benefits of a payroll tax cut, after all, would be spread across all levels of the economy, immediately. Not only might employers be enabled to hire more and pay better; millions of Americans would receive higher take-home pay to pour into the economy.
Besides, as Mr. Moynihan complains, the rising Social Security trust fund surplus - intended to pay benefits 30 and 40 years from now - is being used deceitfully to make the Federal deficit look smaller, and illicitly to finance other Government expenditures that ought to be paid for -if at all - out of general revenues. Thus, the payroll tax cut the Senator proposes, if achieved, would bring additional pressures on Mr. Bush for the general tax increase he is sworn to oppose.
Depending on its substance and purpose, such a tax increase might or might not be a good thing. Cutting the payroll tax now would raise the question whether future Social Security benefits would be sufficiently guaranteed. Other questions remain to be answered, but for now Mr. Moynihan has neatly turned the political tables on President Bush and the Republicans - in an election year, at that.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: L.I. Baymen Resist Shellfishing Ban

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Jan. 17

 BODY:
A battle between state officials and the baymen of eastern Long Island over closing rich shellfishing waters has erupted. The issue is not polluted seas, but the number of state inspectors available to test the waters.
Under a Federal public health program, baymen can legally harvest clams, mussels and other shellfish only from waters approved by the New York State Department of Environmental Conservation. In a race to test 900,000 acres of coastal waters for bacteria by the deadline, Tuesday, state officials ran out of time before they could inspect 56,000 acres in Suffolk County. 
Facing Federal sanctions against shellfish exported from New York, state officials said they had no choice but to close the waters until they could be analyzed and the safety of shellfish guaranteed.
Outraged baymen and officials from the two towns most affected, East Hampton and Southampton, argued that the state's foulup threatened to ruin their livelihoods and give the whole region a black eye. Shellfish dealers on the South Fork say clam sales have plummeted since the proposed ban was publicized last week.
 
Productive Waters Affected
The town officials took the matter to court, and on Tuesday Justice Kenneth K. Rohl of State Supreme Court in Hauppauge, a bayman himself, temporarily blocked the state from enforcing the ban in East Hampton and Southampton, pending a hearing scheduled for Jan. 24. The closures took effect in other parts of the county.
The ban would forbid shellfishing within 500 yards of shore from Eatons Neck east to Orient Point and Fishers Island along the North Shore, and from Fire Island Inlet to Montauk Point on the Shore Shore. In addition, rich clamming areas in the Peconic Bay system like Northwest Creek and parts of Accabonac Harbor, both in East Hampton waters, would be closed.
About 5,000 acres of the 56,000 untested acres are considered highly productive shellfishing waters, the commissioner of the state environmental agency, Thomas C. Jorling, said.
The ban is the latest blow to the baymen, a dwindling breed who for 300 years have relied on the sea for their living. In recent years, their ranks have fallen to about 35 from 150 in East Hampton alone as higher-paying jobs on the mainland lured away some men while a mysterious brown tide that wiped out the region's famous bay scallop industry discouraged others.
 
Accelerated Testing Ordered
The South Fork's tourism industry is still recovering from the effects of beach pollution in 1988 that scared away thousands of visitors from Long Island's shores.
''We cannot and will not allow the arbitrary, reckless and irresponsible actions of a state regulatory agency to jeopardize the economic foundation of our commercial-fishing industry and our tourist-related businesses,'' said Tony Bullock, the town supervisor of East Hampton.
In response to Suffolk officials, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo last Friday ordered state inspectors to speed the testing in the most productive areas, including about 250 acres in Accabonac Harbor and Northwest Creek. Until the testing is completed, Mr. Jorling said, the agency would appeal Justice Rohl's injunction for those specific waters, based on preliminary evidence that suggests that the waters are contaminated.
The state is following the National Shellfish Sanitation Program, a voluntary agreement between Federal, state and industry officials established in 1925.
 
Original Deadline Missed
With only five full-time inspectors and a handful of water samplers and laboratory technicians to cover more than 900,000 acres of bay and coastal waters, the state has relied on county and town agencies for help in collecting and analyzing samples, said Pieter VanVolkenburgh, chief of the state's shellfisheries bureau.
The program requires the state to gather at least five samples a year from each of the 1,000 test sites. To measure the worst potential for contamination, the samples must be collected shortly after heavy rains, when the likelihood of runoff from sewage-treatment plants, storm sewers or other sources of pollution is greatest.
Based on that information, the state approves or closes the waters for shellfishing. About 485,000 acres of state waters are considered productive shellfishing areas, and about two-thirds of those have been approved so far, Mr. VanVolkenburgh said.
The state missed its testing deadline of a year ago and was granted an extension until July. It missed that deadline and faced closing any waters not inspected as of Tuesday. ''The Federal Government issued a directive that said unless we could show the waters were not polluted, they were considered polluted,'' Mr. Jorling said.
Clean or not, the mere threat of a ban has frightened customers and endangered the Island's $18 million hard-shell clamming industry. ''They're really trying to destroy the industry,'' said Thomas Lester, a 49-year-old bayman from Springs. ''As soon as the public hears they're closing down the waters because of pollution, they stop buying.''
Mr. Lester said the price of hard clams dropped to $24 a bushel from $100 a bushel in the last week.

HEADLINE: The Budget As Politics

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH KOLBERT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, Jan. 17

 BODY:
At first blush, it does not look like an election-year budget.
It calls for almost $800 million in new taxes and rescinds the last phase of a popular income-tax cut. It cuts beloved programs for education and the arts. And it contains few new initiatives that can be used to embellish campaign literature. 
But given the options, the $31 billion budget Gov. Mario M. Cuomo presented to the State Legislature on Tuesday is probably as politically popular a proposal as the Governor could have come up with. Consider the alternatives. 'Unusual Election-Year Budget'
Mr. Cuomo could have proposed no new taxes and maintained the last phase of the income-tax cut. But then he would have had to come up with more than $1 billion in spending cuts.
Or Mr. Cuomo could have raised taxes further to avoid spending cuts altogether. But that might have meant increasing the income or sales tax, which is dangerous in an election year.
A third choice would have been for Mr. Cuomo to rely even more heavily than he already is on the state's reserve funds. But a likely consequence of that move would have been to lower the state's credit rating, even now considered precarious, and to risk plunging the state into a fiscal crisis.
''The Governor's budget is a very unusual election-year budget,'' said Mel Miller, the Assembly Speaker and Brooklyn Democrat. ''It violates all the taboos. It proposes to raise taxes, and in return, it isn't going to give you very much. But I don't think he had any options.''
 
'Tell Them the Truth'
Mr. Cuomo, who is expected to run for a third term in November, said today that he was not concerned about abandoning the conventional wisdom on election-year budgets. Indeed, he insisted, political considerations played no part in his budget plans.
''A lot of us politicians have it all wrong,'' he said, adding that voters ''don't want you to tell them everything is going to be wonderful even if it's not.''
''I think the best thing you can do is tell them the truth,'' he said.
But despite Mr. Cuomo's protestations, his budget reveals a political motive: To avoid the kind of criticism he encountered last year when he proposed a budget that retained the income-tax cut, but at the expense, many of his traditional liberal supporters said, of the state's poorest residents.
''Last year what happened is he really left his base, or his perceived base - the unions, the day-care advocates, the affordable-housing advocates,'' Mr. Miller said. ''One year you can walk away from your constituency. But you can't do that again.'' Little Obvious Impact for Some Mr. Miller, a vocal critic of Mr. Cuomo's budget last year, has voiced reserved support for his proposal this year.
A close look at the budget proposal also shows why, despite immediate denunciations, it might encounter less criticism than might seem likely.
On the revenue side, while the budget calls for $800 million in new taxes and fees, most of those levies would have little obvious impact on the average New Yorker. One new fee, for example, would raise the cost of vanity license plates to $25, from $15. Another would impose a new $15 charge on applying for a pistol permit. A third would impose a 2 percent tax on ''S corporations,'' which pay personal income taxes rather than corporate taxes.
One of the few tax changes the Governor has proposed that will affect virtually every taxpayer is the suspension of the income-tax cut. That proposal is likely to be the focus of protracted protest this spring.
 
'Austerity' at 9.3 Percent
But even the suspension of the income-tax cut is not the kind of issue that necessarily seizes voters' imaginations. As Mr. Cuomo noted rather insistently, he is not proposing to raise taxes, just not to lower them. And as Mr. Cuomo also likes to note, many taxpayers do not even know the state's current income-tax rate.
On the expenditure side, the Governor's budget, while lean, is hardly spartan. Many programs received no increase over inflation, and many others suffered cuts. But the budget still contains big spending increases for prison construction, for foster care, for Medicaid and for drug treatment. It eliminates no major programs and calls for few layoffs. And while by one measure it increases spending by only 4.5 percent, by another equally acceptable measure it raises expenditures by a substantial 9.3 percent.
''To me the most perplexing thing is that the budget is up 9.3 percent and everyone is calling it austerity,'' one Republican legislative official said.
A sign that the budget is indeed an election-year proposal is its heavy reliance on nonrecurring, or one-shot, revenues, like reserve funds. The Cuomo administration has acknowledged its reliance on almost $1 billion in one shots, but many financial analysts suspect that tucked in the 800-page budget book are many million dollars more.
 
'A Lot of Question Marks'
''There are a lot of question marks in this budget,'' said Hyman Grossman, a managing director of Standard & Poor's. ''One of them is how many of these so-called one shots they can afford.''
Although somber, Mr. Cuomo's revenue estimates also reveal what some analysts say is a degree of optimism explicable only as an election-year gamble.
''This is a time that projections should be based only on the most conservative estimates,'' said Cynthia Green, a senior analyst for the Citizens Budget Commission, a watchdog group. ''But that's not what's being used. Because if it were, you would have to spend less money or raise more taxes. And then someone would have to lose.''

He was joined at a news conference in Albany by Thomas Constantine, left, the State Police Superintendent, Joseph Dominelli, right, president of the New York State Chiefs of Police Association, and Sarah Brady, whose husband, James, was seriously wounded in the attempted assassination of President Ronald Reagan. HEADLINE: Negotiators for Owners and Players Ready to Zero In on Numbers

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS

 BODY:
In 1981, the players struck the baseball season in June. In 1985, the players struck in August. In 1990, the owners are prepared to stage a pre-emptive strike of their own.
Only a month away from the scheduled start of spring training, labor negotiators for the owners and the players resumed bargaining yesterday in Manhattan for a new basic agreement. The session centered on noncritical nonsalary issues. 
At their meeting today, the negotiators are scheduled to return to the most critical issue, the one that is expected to determine whether camps will open as scheduled on Feb. 16. The issue is the owners' proposed revenue-sharing plan with its accompanying pay-for-performance salary scale for players in their first six years in the major leagues and a payroll cap that could affect the signing of free agents.
 
Batting for Dollars
Under pay-for-performance, a player would be paid according to his years of service on a statistics-based pay scale. Although no details are known, it would mean a player who hit .250 would be paid a certain amount and one who hit .260 would be paid a certain amount more.
If the players do not indicate a willingness to accept some form of the owners' proposal, the owners will very likely learn at a meeting Feb. 9 that they will not be opening spring camps.
It could be that simple because the owners have planned for a possible lockout for more than a year. Last week the owners were told not to proceed with plans for spring training pending instructions from the Player Relations Committee. They appear to favor the lockout strategy because this time they want to have their finger on the trigger.
''In August 1985,'' Charles O'Connor, the owners' chief negotiator, said, alluding to the last strike, ''the players had 85 percent of their pay, but the clubs didn't have 80 percent of their television money.''
In other words, if these talks are to produce a work stoppage, the owners prefer that they be the ones who say when the work stops, or doesn't start.
 
Delay Not Unlikely
Certainly, enough time remains before Feb. 16 to produce an agreement of some sort. The players, though, don't seem prepared to accept pay-for-performance, and the owners seem reluctant to open camps without such acceptance. Thus, barring a change of thinking on either side, a delay seems to be a very possible development.
The two sides have not progressed very far into their negotiations. The owners' labor representatives have talked about their revolutionary - for baseball - revenue-sharing concept since last July, but only last Wednesday did they move it across the table in the form of a proposal.
The owners offered to give the players 48 percent of what they estimate is approximately 80 percent of their revenue, the part that comes from ticket sales and national and local broadcasting income. The 48 percent share would pay for players' salaries, guaranteed pay owed released players and the players' benefits plan. The players have studied the proposal for the last week and will ask questions and seek additional information today.
In 1988, the latest year for which figures are available, the costs the owners are talking about covering with their proposed fixed percentage totaled approximately $402 million. A 48 percent share of the 80 percent pool the owners would draw on would have come to $411 million. But the players have noted that 1988 player payroll costs were depressed by the owners' collusion against free agents. Based on pre-collusion percentages, those costs could have amounted to about $477 million.
The players are not opposed philosophically to revenue sharing - a practice begun in the National Basketball Association, where the players get 53 percent of the revenue - but they have shown no great hunger for pay-for-performance or any type of payroll cap.
The owners, for their part, have no desire to share their revenue without gaining the other elements inherent in their proposal or some alternative that would meet their desire to know in advance what their player costs will be.
Why do the owners want to change the system? The players say the owners have not explained why they see a need for a change. The method of dollar distribution to the players has nothing to do with revenue sharing, Donald Fehr, the union chief, said. Revenue, the players say, flows to the clubs in great abundance, particularly the nearly $1.5 billion baseball will receive in national television revenue the next four years.
 
Owners Don't Like Surprises
The owners, however, want to create what they call cost certainty. They don't like the kind of surprises arbitrators spring in salary arbitration. They don't like the George Steinbrenners and the Gene Autrys, fellow owners though they may be, lavishing $2 million or $3 million a year on a player to whom no one else will give more than $1 million.
Pay-for-performance would eliminate salary arbitration, multiyear contracts, guaranteed salaries, the maximum-salary-cut rule and agents for two-thirds of the players. The owners especially detest salary arbitration and agents.
When players reach the six-year level under the owners' proposal, they could become free agents and be signed by any team to any salary the team could afford under the payroll cap. Such caps would prevent the Steinbrenners and the Autrys from signing other teams' free agents if they had already exceeded the maximum payroll level. The clubs have not defined that level.
But the players are certain to resist any plan that would put a ceiling on what they can earn. The players are not without their own bargaining goals. They are concerned about roster problems, the clubs' economic treatment of younger players and collusion.
They want clubs to return to 25-man rosters during the season (clubs have carried 24 players the last few years) and they want a player to be able to become a free agent if he is removed from a club's 40-man roster and sent to the minor leagues.
They want the minimum salary raised from $68,000 to somewhere between $100,000 and $125,000, though closer to the higher level, and they seek to lower the major league service time required for salary arbitration.
They want a collusion-proof agreement, assuring that clubs will not repeat the free-agent practices for which arbitrators found them guilty.
The players also want improvements in the pension and benefits plan, citing the increase in revenue from the national television package.

HEADLINE: Review/Art;
Black Images of the Past: Servile, Subhuman

BYLINE: By MICHAEL KIMMELMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12

 BODY:
''Facing History: The Black Image in American Art, 1710-1940'' is an exhibition that no thinking person can walk through without feeling a measure of both sorrow and anger. The 100 or so paintings, sculptures and drawings gathered at the Corcoran Gallery of Art testify to a racism so ingrained in the American consciousness that artists - the overwhelming number of whom were white, but some of whom were black - thought nothing about stereotyping blacks as ''grotesque buffoons, servile menials, comic entertainers or threatening subhumans,'' writes Guy C. McElroy, the show's curator, in the exhibition catalogue.
It is the casualness of the cruelty that leaves the deepest impression on a viewer. Sometimes the methods of expression are sophisticated, the prejudices subtly masked. Yet to see in the context of this exhibition Thomas Eakins's depiction of a hunter and his guide, ''Will Schuster and Blackman Going Shooting,'' is to be reminded that the artist has evoked not simply a life of leisure but another kind of life entirely. 
The nameless, barefooted black man who steers Schuster's boat may be more sympathetically portrayed by Eakins than most of the blacks painted by American artists in the 19th century. Nonetheless, Eakins was inescapably a man of his time, and he took for granted the social and economic gulf that separated whites from blacks.
The image of Schuster and his guide is not the only well-known painting that Mr. McElroy has managed to cast in an unfamiliar light. Whatever may be the allegory behind John Singleton Copley's famous ''Watson and the Shark,'' it is hereafter impossible to overlook the central role given to the standing figure of a black man holding a rope.
''Facing History,'' in other words, puts before the viewer a variety of images that have been either ignored by art historians or thought about largely in terms other than race, and it insists that these works be reconsidered. Exhibitions have in the past dealt with portrayals of blacks in 19th-century American popular prints and cartoons. Mr. McElroy's show is the first to survey paintings and sculptures, and to underscore the fact that so-called high art was by no means above expressing the lowest of society's inclinations.
All of which is not to say, however, that ''Facing History'' can be counted a success. There are too many questions that Mr. McElroy leaves unanswered, many points that probably did not need making in the first place, and others that needed to be made far more forcefully.
For every work by Copley and Eakins and Homer that the curator has assembled, there are a dozen minor paintings by forgotten artists whose racism comes as no revelation. It is depressing to learn that the painter of ''Uncle Tom and Little Eva'' was Robert Scott Duncanson, a black artist. But to discover that a white painter named Charles Deas depicted blacks in the 1830's as either cowering weaklings or monstrous creatures, or that a work from the same period attributed to a white artist called Charles Winter represents a minstrel show in which blacks are made to seem like animals, is really to learn nothing unexpected.
Arguing, as Mr. McElroy apparently does, that better artists, like Copley, Homer and William Sidney Mount, relied less on crude caricature and predictable formulas than a Deas or a Winter is only another way of claiming that Mount and Homer and Copley were better painters. That is to say, ''Facing History'' mostly tells us what we already knew, or at least what we suspected.
What it does not tell us - and what presumably should be of fundamental importance to a social art historian like Mr. McElroy - is about patronage and provenance. Who bought these paintings? Where did they hang? What, if anything, was written about them? ''Facing History'' obviously has as one of its underlying themes the notion that these paintings and sculptures should be thought about not simply in esthetic terms but also on political and economic grounds. Yet viewers are often left uninformed about the financial history of these works.
That is not always the case. Among the most interesting paintings in the exhibition are the two or three commissioned by middle-class black families and black politicians, and one very moving silhouette of a slave from 1796. A portrait of a black man by Joshua Johnson, the first black artist to achieve prominence in America, is one of the few unqualifiedly dignified images in the show, as is the staid but respectful portrait of William Whipper by William Matthew Prior, an early 19th-century painter and writer on behalf of abolitionist causes.
The silhouette of Flora, a slave, accompanied her bill of sale in 1796 in Connecticut, and while never intended as a work of art, it has a poignance that is nowhere else to be found in this exhibition. There could be no better metaphor for the attitude of whites toward blacks than this spectral profile of Flora's head made by tracing her shadow.
But it would have been useful to know as much about other works in this exhibition. And it would have been very good to see more of the popular images on which these paintings were, directly and indirectly, based. Seeing in some depth how painters and sculptors transformed the banalities of printmakers and cartoonists would arguably have been a more valuable contribution by Mr. McElroy than the overview of 230 years of artistic activity he provides.
When arriving at the 20th century, ''Facing History'' can give only the sketchiest outline of how blacks were portrayed in art before World War II. There are a few works by Ben Shahn, Thomas Hart Benton and Reginald Marsh and a hint of what the Harlem Renaissance fostered, but these paintings almost seem to belong to another exhibition, so different are they in tone and subject from most of the other images in the show.
The catalogue reproduces several prints and cartoons that are not displayed on the walls, and it includes an essay by Henry Louis Gates Jr. that focuses largely on the portrayal of blacks in American literature.
Works in the exhibition were borrowed from several dozen public and private collections. One university declined to lend a painting to the show, contending there was no value in displaying derogatory images of blacks. Given the uproar it provoked last year after canceling an exhibition of photographs by Robert Mapplethorpe, the museum is obviously cautious about displaying any works that can be considered inflammatory. It is not surprising, therefore, that the Corcoran has included an unusual number of lengthy wall texts, many of which condemn in the clearest possible terms the racist nature of the paintings and sculptures.
''Facing History: The Black Image in American Art, 1710-1940,'' which is at the Corcoran Gallery of Art through March 25, will be on view at the Brooklyn Museum from April 20 to June 25.

GRAPHIC: Photo: ''Head of a Negro,'' by John Singleton Copley, is in ''Facing History: The Black Image in American Art, 1710-1940'' at the Corcoran Gallery.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Review

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

ECONOMY
 
U.S. oil production suffered its biggest single-year decline in 1989, falling by more than half a million barrels a day, the American Petroleum Institute reported. Imports surged to make up for the drop in domestic oil production. As a result, the nation's dependence on imported oil rose to a near-record 46 percent of demand, the highest level in more than a decade. [Page A1.] 
 
Federal authorities charged three men in California with engaging in a widespread pattern of breaking into telephone company and Government computers and obtaining classified information from a military computer. [A1.]
 
The nation's trade deficit grew in November by $10.5 billion, the biggest monthly increase of 1989. [D1.]
 
Industrial production rose 0.4 percent in December, bolstered by abnormally cold weather and the end of the Boeing strike. The operating rate at factories, mines and utilities rose 0.2 percent, to 83.3 percent. [D5.]
 
COMPANIES
 
Ending a difficult year on a disappointing note, I.B.M.'s net fell 74.8 percent in the fourth quarter. The decline reflected a $2.4 billion charge the company took in December to cover the cost of reducing its staff, shutting some operations and other changes. [D1.]
 
AMR's earnings fell 66.7 percent in the fourth quarter. The owner of American Airlines blamed rising fuel costs. [D4.]
 
Campeau's American retailing operations paid more than $3.74 million in legal and accounting fees as part of their preparations for a bankruptcy filing, court papers show. [D1.]
 
Conrail said it would spend $1.3 billion to buy back more than a third of its outstanding shares as a defense against takeovers. [D1.]
 
Partners of Ernst & Whinney will take home roughly 65 percent of all profits that they earn jointly with Arthur Young for the next three years, while Arthur Young's partners will share the rest, according to a confidential document. [D2.]
 
Southmark filed a reorganization plan in Federal Bankruptcy Court that would allow it to keep its troubled San Jacinto Savings Association in Houston. [D4.]
 
Levi Strauss will close three sewing plants in San Antonio and lay off 1,100 workers. [D4.]
 
INTERNATIONAL
 
Arkansas, Louisiana and Mississippi asked Japan for low-interest loans. Japan's Export-Import Bank is thinking it over. [D1.]
 
A Japanese economic nationalist crossed swords in Washington with a Congressman from Detroit. [D8.]
 
MARKETS
 
Stocks fell broadly after disappointing earnings reports and some futures-related trading. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 33.49 points, or 1.24 percent, to 2,659.13. [D8.]
 
Resolution Funding will sell $5 billion of 40-year bonds next week, the longest maturity on a security sold by the Government since 1960. [D15.] Yields fell on tax-exempt and taxable money market funds for the week ended yesterday. [D7.]
 
Oil and gasoline futures prices fell after a report showed an increase in U.S. stocks of petroleum products after several weeks of declining supplies. [D16.] The dollar finished mixed as the widening trade deficit unsettled foreign-exchange trading. [D16.]
 
TODAY'S COLUMNS
 
An East German maker of printing presses has bought the Long Island company that was its distributor. Talking Deals. [D2.]
 
The Great Northern Nekoosa battle with Georgia-Pacific continues to play in the companies' board rooms. Market Place. [D8.]
 
Outboard Marine has turned to feelings, rather than features, to sell its Johnson outboard motors. Advertising. [D19.]

HEADLINE: Trade Gap Widened in November

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17

 BODY:
The nation's trade deficit grew in November to $10.5 billion, the biggest monthly gap of 1989, the Commerce Department reported today.
Imports declined, but so did exports, and the trade imbalance worsened for the second straight month.
Although a strike at the Boeing Company, one of the biggest American exporters, accounted for nearly $1 billion of the November deficit, many analysts considered the results somewhat disappointing both for now and in the near future. Combined with other economic data, it appears that imported goods are beginning to pile up in inventories, while sales of American goods abroad are no higher than they were last spring. 
''Exports just are not going anywhere,'' said Richard S. Peterson, chief economist at the Continental Bank in Chicago.
 
Deficit 2.4% Larger
The trade deficit, the difference between imports and exports, was 2.4 percent higher in November than in October.
At $30.2 billion, exports were $800 million below the October level, and non-Government analysts said they took little comfort in the fact that November's trade decline could be largely attributed to the Boeing strike. The 45-day strike by 58,000 Boeing machinists, which ended Nov. 21, shut down production of commercial aircraft. Normal production has since resumed.
Imports during November totaled $40.7 billion, down $600 million from October, but still the second biggest level on record.
The nation's bill for imported oil remained at $4.4 billion. In both October and November, imported oil accounted for about 42 percent of the deficit in merchandise trade.
 
Oil Imports Fall Slightly
Volumes of imported oil decreased slightly in November, but that was offset in value by a 24-cent-a-barrel rise, to $17.33, in the average price.
Separately, the American Petroleum Institute today announced a 500,000 barrel-a-day drop in domestic oil production for 1989, the biggest one-year decline on record. This suggests the United States will have to spend increasingly more for imported oil.
The decline in exports in November is particularly worrisome to many economists because surging exports were a main force driving the general American economy during 1987 and 1988.
But the Government also reported today that industrial production rose four-tenths of 1 percent in December, prompting little consensus among economists on what the two figures together implied for the 1990 economy.
Mr. Peterson said that despite the decline in exports, he had ''less and less concern about recession,'' but Stuart G. Hoffman of the PNC Financial Corporation in Pittsburgh said he saw ''more signs of weakness than strength.''
Another Pittsburgh analyst, Norman Robertson of the Mellon Bank, said the trend in trade had turned unfavorable, contributing to a ''sputtering'' economy.
 
Fewer Japanese Cars Bought
Today's report also showed a sharp decline in the American trade deficit with Japan, which had jumped nearly 20 percent in October. In November, it fell 18 percent, to $4 billion, from $4.9 billion. Contributing to that decline, imports of Japanese cars fell to $1.6 billion, from $1.9 billion in November, apparently reflecting the broad weakness in the United States car demand.
There was an even sharper drop in the United States deficit with the newly industrialized countries of the Far East. The combined deficit with Taiwan, South Korea, Hong Kong and Singapore fell 25 percent, to $2.1 billion from $2.8 billion, with each showing a smaller surplus. The surpluses have been a source of trade friction with the United States.
Analysts cautioned, however, that these country figures are subject to wide month-to-month swings and that they are also not adjusted for seasonal variation.
At the same time, the American deficit widened by about $100 million each with West Germany, France and Britain and by about $400 million with Canada, the United States' biggest trading partner.
For the first 11 months of 1989, the trade deficit eased by $6 billion, to $101.7 billion, compared with the corresponding period in 1988, a result that Commerce Secretary Robert Mosbacher called fundamentally ''in line with our expectations of continued moderate improvement'' in 1990.
 
Exports Tapering Off
But exports have tapered off since early in the year, while imports have leaped to record levels. Even had there been no Boeing strike, November exports would have been less than in June, analysts said.
Over all, the November export change reflected a $1 billion decline in capital goods, like electrical machinery, sent overseas by United States companies and a $200 million decline in industrial supplies. There were small increases in exports of consumer goods, foods and other merchandise.
In imports, the value of industrial supplies brought into this country fell $800 million, while capital goods climbed $500 million.
For manufactured goods alone, which include plastics, furniture and motorcycle parts and is a category that is not adjusted for normal seasonal fluctuations, exports fell $1.9 billion, to $22.5 billion, while imports fell $2.2 billion, to $32.8 billion, from October levels, the report showed. In agriculture, exports rose $300 million, while imports were about unchanged, to produce a trading surplus of $1.8 billion.
In today's report, the $10.2 billion deficit initially reported for October, previously the highest of 1989, was revised upward, by about $50 million. Imports, which were at a record level, rose slightly to $41.3 billion, and exports also were revised higher.

HEADLINE: Conrail Sets $1.3 Billion Buyback

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS

 BODY:
For months, takeover talk has been driving up the stock price of the Consolidated Rail Corporation. Yesterday, the railroad company, known as Conrail, moved to defend itself by announcing plans to spend about $1.3 billion to buy back more than a third of its outstanding shares.
The plan was announced after trading closed yesterday. Conrail's stock finished at $46.125, off 37.5 cents a share, on the New York Stock Exchange.
Conrail said it was offering to buy 21 million, or 30 percent, of its 67.1 million outstanding common shares for no more than $53 a share, but no less than $43. 
The offer, valued at about $1 billion, will begin today and expire at midnight on Feb. 14. The company also said it would establish an employee stock ownership plan worth $300 million.
 
Became Public in 1987
Conrail evolved from six bankrupt Northeastern railroads that had been taken over by the Government in 1976. About $3.3 billion was pumped in to modernize the tracks, locomotives, freight cars and other equipment. The company was sold to the public in 1987.
Although Conrail, which carries only freight, has had some problems recently as traffic has declined, the Philadelphia-based company has been profitable since becoming public. Some investors think the company's stock price does not reflect the true value of Conrail's assets and earning potential. Graeme Anne Lidgerwood, the railroad analyst for the First Boston Corporation, valued the company at about $60 a share.
When Conrail was sold to the public, one provision prohibited any investor from accumulating more than 10 percent of its stock. But that provision is due to expire on April 2.
As a result, the carrier's stock has experienced a lot of activity. ''They have been vulnerable,'' Ms. Lidgerwood said.
She said the company had more than $600 million in cash and could generate substantial amounts of money, so a raider could use its assets to help finance a takeover.
Ms. Lidgerwood said she expected the company to use much of its cash on the offer announced yesterday and then increase its debt to raise the rest of the money, making it much less attractive as a takeover candidate.
James A. Hagen, Conrail's president and chief executive, said the stock buyback ''represents an attractive investment for the company, provides all shareholders with the opportunity to receive a significant immediate cash payment for at least a portion of their shares, and provides flexibility for both those shareholders seeking to continue as shareholders and those who wish to sell all or a portion of their shares.''
The railroad is largely the creation of L. Stanley Crane, who took over Conrail in 1981 shortly after retiring as chairman of the Southern Railway Company. He worked to to wean Conrail from Government support.
Mr. Crane, who retired early last year, cut staff, phased out unprofitable routes and brought in the modern technology to help run Conrail efficiently.
By the time the company was sold to the public, it was profitable.
 
Feeling the Pinch
But this year Conrail, which serves mostly the Northeast, began to feel the economic downturn in the region.
Mr. Hagen has moved to cut costs, cutting hundreds of jobs, combining trains and consolidating operations.
As a result, Conrail took a special charge in the fourth quarter of last year, and reported a loss of $81 million, compared with earnings of $78 million, or $1.13 a share, in the corresponding period in 1988.
For the year, the carrier reported earnings of $148 million, or $2.17 a share, down by 51 percent from $306 million, or $4.44 a share, in 1988. Its revenues for 1989 totaled $3.41 billion, down by 2.2 percent from $3.49 billion in 1988.
Conrail has 13,100 miles of track concentrated in the Northeast but also also runs to such points as Chicago, Charleston, W.Va., and Hagerstown, Md.
The railroad's work force numbers about 13,000. Conrail has 2,340 locomotives and 75,500 rail cars.

HEADLINE: Japan Foreign-Aid Program May Finance U.S. Projects

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Jan. 17

 BODY:
The Government-owned Export-Import Bank of Japan, whose principal mission is to help heavily indebted third world countries build their economies with low-interest loans, is contemplating its first loans to an industrialized country: the United States.
The Governors of three Southern states - Arkansas, Louisiana and Mississippi - raised the idea with Japanese officials a little more than a year ago, and the bank is now giving serious consideration to providing what could be billions of dollars of subsidized loans to underdeveloped regions in several states, said a bank official, who spoke on condition that he not be identified. Bank officials have also met with representatives from New York and California. 
The loans would probably be used for projects like roads, ports or other developments that would aid economic growth, the official said, confirming a report in the Japanese press.
So far, the bank officials have looked at dozens of potential projects, with a total estimated value of more than $3 billion. Most proposals involve industrial parks, with the bank lending money for the buildings, roads and supporting services. The completed projects, the bank official said, could then be used by the states to attract Japanese companies that want to set up manufacturing operations in the United States.
The Japanese official said the idea was born in September 1988, when the three Governors visited Japan and asked for help in financing projects that neither their states nor the Federal Government could afford.
The bank official said the loans would be so-called untied loans, that is, the recipient would not be required to use Japanese contractors or Japanese companies to build the projects or provide services.
Europe is also being considered for such loans, the officials said.
 
Recycling the Wealth
The proposal, which is being hotly debated in Japanese Government circles and is still far from approval, is another reflection of the growing wealth of Japan and its need to find new ways to recycle its financial surpluses abroad now that Japanese companies no longer need help. The proposal also underscores how far some American states are going in their search for financing.
The Export-Import Bank was founded in the early 1950's to subsidize Japanese industrial exports. But most Japanese companies no longer need Government help, and the bank began its recycling program in 1986. Japan has promised to recycle $65 billion, mostly to countries like Colombia, Mexico and Indonesia.
The Japanese bank's proposed low-cost loans to American states are viewed by some Tokyo officials as a way to help ease anti-Japanese sentiment in the United States and halt growing protectionist pressures in Congress. Yet the loans, if they go through, might produce a backlash of resentment in the United States from people already worried about the amount of Japanese money coming into the nation.
''I think that the loans would be perceived as about 60 or 70 percent positive and maybe 30 or 40 percent negative'' in the United States, the official said.
The official acknowledged that the proposal had met criticism from some in the Japanese Government. One criticism is that the Government has no business providing subsidies for one of the world's wealthiest nations. Others in the Parliament and the Ministry of Finance have said that a Government-owned institution should not be involved if such loans could be provided by the private sector, particularly Japanese banks.

HEADLINE: Talking Deals;
East Germany As Capitalist

BYLINE: By John Holusha

 BODY:
A EUROPEAN manufacturer of printing presses and auxiliary equipment was unhappy with the performance of its American sales and service agent. So it decided to buy the distributor to gain direct control of its operations in the United States.
That would be a standard enough transaction, except for the nature of the acquiring company, a state-owned monopoly from a Communist country, East Germany. Nevertheless, Polygraph Export-Import of Leipzig took control of Royal Zenith Inc. of Great Neck, L.I., last week and renamed it Planeta North America Inc. 
According to the Commerce Department, this was the first acquisition of an American company by an East German enterprise.
Polygraph is the sole exporter and importer of graphic arts equipment in East Germany. American lawyers say it is somewhere between a holding company and a sales agent in structure, an unknown entity in the West. This unusual structure, along with doubts about the creditworthiness of East German institutions, the fall of the Berlin wall and the political upheaval in Eastern Europe all complicated the deal. But they did not block it.
Polygraph sells the output of five East German factories, the largest of which is Planeta, a $50 million producer of sheet-fed offset printing machines. Planeta's presses, which are often used to print designs and instructions on cardboard cartons, have been sold in Western countries for more than 30 years and are among East Germany's most successful exports, said Alan Malachuk, the president of Plantea North America. For most of the postwar period, Polygraph was represented in the United States by Royal Zenith, which was owned by the Dyson-Kissner-Moran Corporation, a privately held holding company. But, Mr. Malachuk said, ''the relationship between the supplier and management had broken down.''
Talks about acquiring Royal Zenith began early last year, and quickly encountered complications. For example, there is no tax treaty between the United States and East Germany, and most Western banks have no experience in evaluating the credit of quasi-government organizations in the East bloc. Eventually, the Bayerische Hypotheken und Wechsel Bank of West Germany put up $25 million toward the undisclosed purchase price.
Hans Freidl, head of the bank's international department, said it had advanced the funds because it was accustomed to lending in East Germany and because of Polygraph's success as an exporter. ''We have a half-billion-mark exposure in East Germany,'' he said. ''We concluded that $25 million here is a reasonable risk.'' A key factor, he added, was that part of the credit was guaranteed by East Germany's foreign trade bank.
Robert B. Robbins, a partner in the Washington law firm of Shaw, Pittman, Potts & Trowbridge, which advised Polygraph, commented: ''We originally tried to get credit based on the transaction alone, but it would have been very expensive. With the export bank taking on responsibility, we were able to get credit on terms that would be extended to a very creditworthy borrower.''
A West German engineering concern, C. Illies & Company, and Mr. Malachuk were minority investors in the transaction, participants said.
Thomas Schneider, the president of Polygraph, sounded like a Western businessman when he said the acquisition had been made because Polygraph ''needs opportunities to grow profit-wise.''
''My colleagues at home are watching this project,'' he said. ''If it is successful, they will want to imitate it.''
The political turmoil in East Germany threatened to stall the talks, since Polygraph is an arm of the Government, participants said. ''It was hard to know the chain of authority that would have to approve the transaction and the financing,'' Mr. Robbins said. ''The people involved wondered from day to day what their position would be.''
Nevertheless, both East and West German officials said they expected economic links between the East and West to grow rapidly. Heino Ackert, an East German lawyer and consultant who was a participant in the Polygraph deal, noted that East Germany had recently changed its joint venture law to allow direct foreign investments.
Mr. Freidl said that East Germany was currently considered the best credit risk in the East and could be expected to flourish as central planning was loosened. ''We will support American and West Germany investments in East Germany,'' he said.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
First Interstate Sets Changes at the Top

BYLINE: By Richard W. Stevenson

 BODY:
First Interstate Bancorp said yesterday that Edward M. Carson, its president, would become chairman and chief executive. He will assume the position on June 1, after the retirement at age 65 of Joseph J. Pinola, who has led the Los Angeles-based banking company for 12 years.
The company said William B. Siart would succeed Mr. Carson as president of the parent company and would retain his posts as chairman and chief executive of the First Interstate Bank of California, the company's largest operating unit. 
Analysts said the appointment of the 60-year-old Mr. Carson to the top posts was not surprising, although there had been some speculation that First Interstate's board might bypass a generation of management and select Mr. Siart, who is 43.
Mr. Pinola, who is perhaps best known for his unsuccessful attempt to acquire the much-larger BankAmerica Corporation three years ago, is stepping down at a time when strong performances by most units of the company are being overshadowed by troubles in its Texas and Arizona subsidiaries.
The devastation of the real estate markets in those states has forced the First Interstate Bank of Texas and the First Interstate Bank of Arizona to establish large reserves for loan losses, causing losses for the company and dragging down its stock. The company reported a loss for the third quarter of 1989 of $15.5 million, compared with a loss of $214.4 million in the third quarter of 1988. The company is also expected to report a loss for the fourth quarter.
When he engineered the company's entry into Texas two years ago with the acquisition of Allied Bancshares of Houston, Mr. Pinola was gambling that the state's oil-based economy would rebound and that the real estate problems could be kept under control.
Mr. Pinola said in an interview that the company had tried ''to put the known problems in Texas behind us'' by taking the loss reserves, but acknowledged that shareholders had been angered by the problems there.
''All of whatever else we accomplished here is now being subordinated in large measure to that one problem,'' Mr. Pinola said, referring to the losses from Texas. ''I'm suffering for it, but I did it and I have to live with it.''
First Interstate has assets of $58 billion and operates 28 banks in 14 states, mostly in the West. The company also franchises its name in 11 other states.
Mr. Carson, who has been president of the parent company since 1985, came up through the ranks of the Arizona subsidiary, which he joined in 1951 after graduating from the University of Arizona. Analysts said he had a reputation as a methodical, low-key manager who had proved adept at cost-cutting.
''My expectation is that Ed will be more operationally focused than Joe was, and more internally focused,'' said Donald K. Crowley, an analyst at Keefe, Bruyette & Woods in San Francisco. ''They have an excellent franchise, but it continues to underperform.''
Mr. Siart is given credit by analysts for improving the performance of First Interstate Bank of California in a highly competitive market. He received a degree in finance from the University of Santa Clara and an M.B.A. from the University of California at Berkeley. He joined First Interstate in 1978 after spending nine years at the Bank of America.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Ford Strike Vote

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: LONDON, Jan. 17

 BODY:
Union leaders rejected a two-year pay offer from the Ford Motor Company Ltd. and called a strike vote for next week. Ford's latest offer was a 10.2 percent pay increase in the first year and a choice between 8 percent, or the inflation rate plus 2.5 percent in the second year. It was rejected during talks at the company's London offices. If the union votes Tuesday to reject the proposal, union members will begin an all-out strike beginning with the final shift Jan. 26, officials said. About 9,000 employees were already off the job today, some for a 24-hour strike and some continuing indefinite strikes begun Monday. Ford said it had responded by laying off more than 10,500 employees. It employs 32,000 workers at 22 British plants. Levi Strauss Closing Plant DALLAS, Jan. 17 - Levi Strauss & Company said today that it would close one of three sewing plants in San Antonio in April and lay off 1,100 workers. 
The large privately held maker of jeans and casual clothing said it had decided to use less expensive contract labor in the Caribbean trade zone for the production of the men's slacks made at the South Zarzamora Street plant in San Antonio.
Levi Strauss said in a statement that competitive forces in the industry had dictated the closing of the plant, which the company had owned since 1981.
The Dockers brand pants that were made at the plant are one of the company's most successful new products. Sales have grown to an estimated $400 million since the product was introduced in 1985, a company spokeswoman, Sydney Kapchan, said.
The company said it had made an effort to maintain its production in the United States.
 
''More than 90 percent of
Levi jeans and more than 75 percent of all Levi's products sold in the United States are still made in the United States.'' said Peter L. Thigpen, senior vice president of operations for Levi.

HEADLINE: Production Climbed 0.4% In December

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17

 BODY:
Industrial production rose a strong four-tenths of a percent in December, bolstered by abnormally cold weather and the end of a strike at the Boeing Company, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
In another report, the Fed said the operating rate at factories, mines and utilities rose two-tenths of a percentage point in December, to 83.3 percent, reflecting the increase in the production rate. The operating rate measures not only output but also changes in productivity levels. 
Analysts said the outlook for the near future was for slow growth in industrial output, but with enough strength to enable the economy to avoid a recession in the early part of this year.
 
Flirting With Recession
''The U.S. economy continues to flirt with some sort of a recession, but it is not quite there in the industrial production data,'' said Allen Sinai, chief economist for the Boston Company The Fed said the December increase in industrial output followed a gain of three-tenths of a percent in November after declines of four-tenths of a percent in October and one-tenth in September.
Michael K. Evans of Evans Economics Inc., a Washington forecasting concern, noted that the initial reports on production in September, October and November each had been revised upward by two-tenths of a percent.
''It changes the whole fabric of the industrial production report,'' Mr. Evans said. ''Instead of having a decline, it was flat. That doesn't signal a recession.''
 
Some Special Factors
Record cold weather over much of the nation lifted utility output by 6.3 percent in November, while the settlement of the Boeing strike late in the month returned production there to normal the following month.
''If you discount Boeing and the cold weather, industrial production basically was flat, and that's the way it's been the past few months,'' said Thomas Runiewicz, an economist with the WEFA Group, a forecasting organization, based in Bala-Cynwyd, Pa.
Much of the December rise in the operating rate was attributed to the cold weather, which caused ''a surge of five percentage points in the operating rate for utilities, which was the largest in the 23-year history of this series,'' the Fed said. The increase placed the utility rate at the 86.3 percent level.
''Elsewhere, utilization in manufacturing edged down one-tenth of a percentage point, while the rate for mining fell nearly a percentage point,'' the Fed said.
 
No Growth in Industry
Factory use had remained unchanged at 83.1 percent from October to November. The rate posted 10-year highs of 84.3 percent in December 1988 and January 1989.
The operating report is watched as a barometer of future inflation. The closer the nation's industry gets to full operating capacity, the greater difficulty it has producing enough to meet demand, leading to shortages and price increases.
Analysts generally consider an operating rate of 85 percent or above as an indication of inflationary pressures.
The output report continued to reflect softness in the manufacturing sector, which rose a weak two-tenths of a percent in December.

HEADLINE: Alcoa Profit Falls 24.7%

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: PITTSBURGH, Jan. 17

 BODY:
Hurt by the slowdown in the nation's industrial economy, the Aluminum Company of America said today that its fourth-quarter earnings fell 24.7 percent, and the report sent its stock tumbling.
Pittsburgh-based Alcoa, North America's biggest aluminum producer, said fourth-quarter profits fell to $164.7 million, or $1.88 a share, from $218.7 million, or $2.47 a share, in the 1988 period. Revenues rose 1.5 percent, to $2.69 billion from $2.65 billion.
Disappointment with the report sent Alcoa's shares skidding $5.875, to $66.875, on the New York Stock Exchange, where the stock's decline of 8.1 percent was the seventh largest today.
Despite the fourth-quarter weakness, Alcoa's full-year earnings were up 9.7 percent, rising to a record $944.9 million, or $10.67 a share, from $861.4 million, or $9.74 a share, in 1988, the previous record year. Full-year sales rose 11.3 percent, to $10.91 billion, from $9.8 billion in 1988.
The Reynolds Metals Company, the continent's third-largest aluminum producer, reported today that its fourth-quarter profit fell 4.4 percent, to $133.8 million, or $2.26 a share, from $139.9 million, or $2.61 a share. Revenues rose 4.7 percent, to $1.54 billion from $1.46 billion.
For the year, Reynolds's earnings rose 10.5 percent, to a record $532.7 million, or $9.20 a share, from the prior record of $482.0 million, or $9.01 a share, in 1988. Revenues grew 11 percent, to $6.21 billion.
Reynolds shares lost $1.75, to $52.50, today on the New York Stock Exchange.

HEADLINE: Meeting Narrows Gap Between U.S. and Japan

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17

 BODY:
Shintaro Ishihara, the Japanese economic nationalist who argues that the resentment in a declining America of his country's growing economic success is largely rooted in racism, crossed swords here today with a Congressman from Detroit.
But Mr. Ishihara, a former cabinet minister and author of a briskly selling book, ''The Japan That Can Say No,'' and the lawmaker, Representative Sander M. Levin, a Michigan Democrat who has been one of the leading critics of Japan on Capitol Hill, did agree on their diagnosis of some of the ills of both countries.
For example, they concluded - at what both said was an amicable lunch - that the United States had to strengthen its industrial base and become more export-oriented and that Japan should become more consumer and import-oriented and play a more active role internationally. 
 
Political Ambitions
They met privately and later provided reporters with an account of the meeting. Mr. Ishihara, who hopes to be Prime Minister of Japan, is here to meet fellow politicians and also seek publicity for a future English-language version of his book.
The principal point of difference, Representative Levin said, related to Mr. Ishihara's charges about American racism.
''I told him that his comments about American racial superiority were very much misunderstood,'' he said, ''that my constituents were motivated by the imbalance that exists in trade and what that means for jobs.''
In his book, which has sold more than 500,000 copies in Japan, Mr. Ishihara contends that Americans are proud that ''whites, including Americans, have built the modern era,'' but wonders whether ''historical pride has gone to the length of inerasable arrogance.''
''Right now,'' he adds, ''the modern civilization built by whites is coming close to a period of practical end, and I feel that is adding to the irritation of Americans as the postwar representative of whites.''
 
Morita Is Co-author
Listed as co-author is Akio Morita, chairman of the Sony Corporation, who wrote less controversial parts of the book. Although the book has not yet been published in the United States, an unauthorized English version has been distributed here and entered into The Congressional Record.
Mr. Ishihara also argued at the meeting today that the American work ethic and technological performance had declined markedly and that this, more than Japanese protectionism, was why his countrymen were reluctant to buy anything American.
But Mr. Levin responded by saying, ''There are good American auto parts,'' adding that the Japanese are not even ''buying American spark plugs, and we make good spark plugs.''

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Ends the Day Mixed After Trade Deficit Report

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar finished mixed yesterday as an unexpected widening of the nation's trade deficit had an unsettling effect on foreign-exchange trading.
Gold prices rose in New York. On the Commodity Exchange, gold rose by $1.70 an ounce, to $412.50. 
Foreign-exchange dealers said investors were concerned because the poor trade performance in November partly resulted from a drop in exports. Some analysts said the decline indicated a further slowing of the American economy.
The Commerce Department said the trade deficit grew in November to $10.5 billion, its worst showing in 11 months. Imports declined by $593 million, to $40.69 billion, and exports dropped $843 million, to $30.19 billion.
The Government attributed about $1 billion of the increase to a strike at the Boeing Company in Seattle, which severely cut into exports of expensive commercial airliners. But private economists still expressed disappointment with the figure.
Ronald Holzer, the chief foreign-exchange dealer with the Harris Trust and Company in Chicago, said any possible upward moves by the dollar were being limited by traders' skeptical view of the economy.
Although the trade news pushed the dollar lower against some currencies, the exchange traders largely focused on the West German mark and other currencies, Mr. Holzer said.
The dealers overseas said continuing tensions in the Soviet Union and in Eastern Europe gave the dollar some underlying support.
In New York, the dollar rose to 145.40 yen, from 145.30 yen late on Tuesday. The dollar also rose against the British pound, which was quoted at $1.65235, down from $1.6585 late on Tuesday.
Other late-dollar rates in New York, compared with those of late on Tuesday, included: 1.6873 West German marks, down from 1.6950; 1.5055 Swiss francs, down from 1.5116; 5.7325 French francs, down from 5.7630; 1,256.50 Italian lire, down from 1,262.25, and 1.16515 Canadian dollars, up from 1.16375.
On the Commodity Exchange, silver rose 2.6 cents an ounce to close at $5.256.

HEADLINE: Moynihan's Right, but. . .

BYLINE: By Henry J. Aaron and Charles L. Schultze; Henry J. Aaron and Charles L. Schultze are senior fellows at the Brookings Institution.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan recently advanced a proposal to reduce Social Security payroll taxes by $55 billion in 1991 and corresponding amounts in later years, thereby moving the Social Security system closer to pay-as-you-go financing. Such a change of policy, however, would damage the economy. Congress should reject this proposal. 
Senator Moynihan, Democrat of New York, has raised a serious issue - the fact that large additions to Social Security reserves, financed by the payroll tax, are now masking the true size of the Federal budget deficit. He is justifiably angry that a regressive tax on wages is being used increasingly to pay for ordinary operations of the Government.
Such a tax is defensible if the additions to Social Security reserves are used to increase national saving and productive capacity, thereby helping future generations shoulder the costs of providing retirement benefits for the growing number of retirees.
But the Government is not using the proceeds of the payroll tax that way. It is now borrowing the additions to Social Security reserves to pay for the current operations of the Government. Exclusive of Social Security, the Federal Government budget deficit is huge and is projected to rise in the future.
We can well understand Senator Moynihan's frustration with this budgetary hoax, and perhaps his proposal is merely a tactical device to focus the public's attention on this outrage. But if enacted, the proposal would do serious harm to the economy.
The immediate effect of the $55 billion cut in payroll taxes for 1991 that Senator Moynihan proposes would be to worsen the Federal deficit by an equivalent amount. To offset the potentially inflationary effects of an enlarged budget deficit, the Federal Reserve would have to raise interest rates, penalizing investment generally and long-term investments particularly. The higher budget deficit and increased interest rates would force the U.S. either to reduce investment at home or to increase borrowing from abroad. In either case, the already slow growth in American living standards would be further eroded. In short, cutting payroll taxes (or any other major tax cut) is the opposite of what is needed under current economic and budgetary conditions.
Although Senator Moynihan did not suggest it, the payroll tax cut could be made revenue neutral if it were linked to offsetting increases in income or excise taxes. Such a proposal would not add to the deficit. But it would wreck whatever chance now exists of successfully reducing the deficit through a compromise package of expenditure cuts and tax increases. If Congress were to use an income tax increase to offset the revenue loss from a payroll tax cut, it would become even harder than it now is to fashion a centrist political compromise that would combine spending cuts with income tax increases.
Simply cutting payroll taxes should be put off-limits because a payroll tax cut would worsen the budget deficit and thereby reduce still further the nation's already abysmally low saving rate. And combining such cuts with increases in other taxes is premature as long as any hope survives of fashioning a deficit reduction compromise. The best hope is that Senator Moynihan's proposal will provoke a review of the nation's currently absurd budgetary proposals. The worst fear is that it might actually be enacted.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: U.S. AGENTS ARREST WASHINGTON MAYOR ON DRUG CHARGES

BYLINE: By B. DRUMMOND AYRES Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18

 BODY:
Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr., who over the past several years has repeatedly denied allegations that he used drugs, was arrested tonight at a downtown hotel on a narcotics charge by local and Federal law officers, the United States Attorney's office said.
The authorities would provide few details of the arrest other than to say that it was the result of an undercover operation and had occurred shortly after 8 P.M. on the seventh floor of the Vista International Hotel, a few blocks northeast of the White House.
One person in Federal law enforcement said the charge against Mr. Barry involved cocaine. But a statement about the arrest issued by the office of the United States Attorney for the District of Columbia said only that a narcotics violation was involved.
 
No Comment From Mayor
About midnight, the 53-year-old Mayor was taken by van from the headquarters of the Federal Bureau of Investigation to his home in Southeast Washington. He flashed a wan smile as he ducked through the gate leading to his front door and refused to answer the shouted questions of reporters. 
Mr. Barry, who had planned to announce his bid for re-election to a fourth term this weekend, is scheduled to be arraigned before a Federal magistrate on Friday.
Recent polls had indicated that Mr. Barry faced an uphill race, because of politically embarrassing factors like a grand jury investigation into accusations of cocaine use and a report in The Los Angeles Times in which he mocked the political aspirations of the Rev. Jesse Jackson, a possible opponent for Mayor.
 
Drug Speech at a School
Most polls have shown that Mr. Jackson, who recently moved to Washington from Chicago, would decisively defeat Mr. Barry. The Mayor has been campaigning hard in recent weeks, making public appearances and trying to raise money.
Tonight's arrest came only hours after Mr. Barry had made an anti-drug speech at a local high school and only two days after he had boasted at a press conference that the city was winning its war on one of the worst drug epidemics in the country.
The United States Attorney's statement tonight said the F.B.I., working with the internal affairs division of the District of Columbia Police Department, had taken Mr. Barry into custody ''as part of an ongoing public corruption probe under the supervision of the U.S. Attorney for the District of Columbia.''
One law-enforcement official described the arrest as ''a very carefully planned operation.'' He said parts of it were secretly videotaped ''just to make sure it all sticks in court.''
Mr. Barry's arrest came a day before the scheduled sentencing of his longtime friend, Charles Lewis, who pleaded guilty to one count of conspiracy to distribute cocaine in Washington. Mr. Lewis, a native of the Virgin Islands, was conviced last year of drug dealing on St. Thomas.
Mr. Lewis said in open court last fall that he had provided cocaine to the Mayor on ''more than one occasion.''
Mr. Barry countered by calling Mr. Lewis a ''convicted felon'' and said, ''He'll say anything in court, trying to save his own hide.''
Mr. Barry was visiting Mr. Lewis's room in the Ramada Inn in Washington in December 1988 at the same time that city police officers were on their way to the room to investigate a report that Mr. Lewis was offering drugs for sale. When the officers found that Mr. Barry was present, they abandoned their mission in an episode that has not yet been fully explained.
The Ramada Inn is a block from the Vista International, where Mr. Barry was arrested tonight.
Although the Vista is a luxury hotel, it is in a troubled neighborhood that borders a high-crime area. Employees and guests were unaware the raid was taking place until it was over. ''We had no idea it was going to take place here,'' said Mark Phillips, a hotel manager.
The arrest sent a political shock wave through the city and its governmental hierarchy.
''It is a truly tragic time in our city,'' said Dave A. Clarke, the president of the City Council and a candidate for mayor.
Another member of the Council, Hilda Mason, said she was ''in shock'' and unable to immediately assess the impact of the arrest. ''I'm praying for the Mayor,'' she added.
The recent opinion polls were not the only bad news for the Mayor. In recent months some top aides, including Washington's health commissioner, prison chief and legal adviser, have resignd.
There have also been allegations, all denied, that the mayor used cocaine with Mr. Lewis while on a visit to the Virgin Islands a few years ago.
In the mid-1980's, there were allegations, again denied, that Mr. Barry had used drugs in the District with a woman. A Federal grand jury investigated those allegations at length but handed up no indictment.
Grand juries, reporters and political enemies have delved deeply into the life of Mr. Barry, who has chafed at running the city from behind a big desk and has preferred to visit its neighborhoods, often at night, shaking hands, exchanging quips and dropping in on bars and clubs to hear grievances.
And while the inquiries hurt the Mayor in the polls, until last night's arrest at the Vista International Hotel, no formal action had been taken against him.
 
Denied Earlier Allegations
As Mayor, Mr. Barry oversees a bureaucracy of 33,000 people and a budget of $2 billion in a city with a population of 650,000.
He was born into a family of sharecroppers in the rural community of Itta Bena, Miss. His mother worked as a domestic to support him and his seven younger sisters.
He graduated with a degree in chemistry from LeMoyne College in Memphis in 1958 and earned a master's degree at Fisk University in Nashville in 1960.
His involvement in the civil rights movement began while a sophomore at LeMoyne and continued at Fisk, where in 1960 he organized the first lunch counter sit-ins in Nashville. That same year he and other student leaders met with the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., at Shaw College, in Raleigh, N.C. The students, along with Dr. King, established the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee, which made Atlanta its base and chose Mr. Barry as its first national chairman.
In January 1967, he resigned as head of S.N.C.C.'s Washington office, declaring that ''the civil rights direction of protest is dead.''
''Now we must concentrate on control - economic and political power,'' he said.
After designing a successful program to aid Washington's poor blacks, Youth Pride, Inc, he won election to the city's Board of Education and served two terms as its president, in 1972 and 1974.
 
Elected to City Council
After easily winning election to the City Council in 1974, he became a full-time politician, reaching out not only to blacks but also to other minority groups. He worked, for example, with the Gay Activists' Alliance to develop one of the strongest municipal ordinances in the nation for protecting the civil rights of homosexuals.
His service on the Council almost cost him his life when Hanafi Muslims shot him in the chest during their seizure of the District Building on March 9, 1977. The bullet just missed his heart, and he was back at work by the end of the month.
A year later he successfully ran for Mayor.
In his early years as Mayor, he was frequently cited as one of the nation's leading elected blacks. But then began the series of controversies about his personal conduct, including not just allegations of drug usage but also allegations of marital indfidelity and allegations that he had surrounded himself with corrupt aides. He repeatedly denied the latter two charges, too.
