HEADLINE: Fight Over Tax Cut Heats Up As Bush and Moynihan Dig In

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18

 BODY:
An emerging battle over whether to cut Social Security taxes heated up today with President Bush sharply criticizing the proposed cut while the author of the proposal, Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, said he would not budge.
Their statements indicated that Mr. Moynihan's proposal could trigger a fierce political and legislative battle over a sensitive issue.
Mr. Bush called the Senator's proposal to cut Social Security taxes a ''charade'' that would lead to a tax increase or lower retirement benefits. Mr. Moynihan, in his first interview on the subject since he made the proposal three weeks ago, insisted that he intended neither a political trap nor a gambit to force other taxes to be raised. He also strongly rejected the suggestion that he wanted to lower retirement payments. 
Mr. Moynihan, a New York Democrat, last month proposed repealing the Jan. 1 increase in the Social Security payroll tax, calling it regressive and unfair. He also assailed the Bush Administration for using the $52 billion surplus in the Social Security Trust Fund to finance the Federal deficit.
 
Quayle Exhorts Party on Issue
At the White House today, President Bush repeated the charges his aides have been making for days. ''It's an effort to get me to raise taxes on the American people by the charade of cutting them, or cut benefits,'' the President said of the Moynihan proposal, ''and I'm not going to do it to the older people of the country.''
With both sides jockeying for political advantage, Vice President Quayle also weighed in on what has become one of the hottest topics of an especially slow period in Washington.
In an interview with The Associated Press, the Vice President said: ''Let me tell you something. Cut these taxes the way Moynihan is talking about, you have to cut benefits at some time, and the President and the Republican Party now have an opportunity to show the American people, once and for all, that the Republicans are as committed to the integrity of this Social Security trust fund as anybody.''
 
Moynihan Sees No Budget Link
Senator Moynihan was interviewed by in a telephone call to Jerusalem, where he is winding up a trip for the Foreign Relations Committee to Africa and the Middle East.
''No, no, no,'' the Senator said when asked whether his proposal was a trap to force an increase in the income tax or some other tax. ''It is not fair to say I want to raise taxes to offset the Social Security tax cut.''
The Social Security system, he continued, ''edges on the sacred, and to see its revenues debauched this way is an independent question that stands apart from the budget deficit, a tax increase or any other question.''
 
How It's Being Paid
As of Jan. 1, workers and their employers are each paying a 7.65 percent payroll tax, 6.2 percent for retirement under Social Security and 1.45 percent for Medicare, the health insurance program for the elderly and disabled. The Social Security rate rose from 6.06 percent last year and the overall rate from 7.51 percent.
The tax is paid on the first $51,300 of wages. The maximum tax this year is $3,924.45.
Mr. Moynihan would repeal this year's increase and reduce the Social Security portion of the tax to 5.1 percent next year, saving workers and their employers as much as $560 apiece.
 
Social Security and Income Tax
He argued that in the Reagan and Bush years the Social Security tax had been increased to balance a cut in income taxes. That is ''inequitable,'' he said, because the poor and the middle class are affected more by the Social Security tax and less by the income tax.
Income tax rates increase the more a taxpayer earns from all sources. Social Security taxes are paid at the same rate by all workers, they are assessed only on wages and not on interest, dividends or capital gains, and they are not paid at all on wages above $51,300.
''We now have the most regressive tax system in the Western world,'' Mr. Moynihan said.
Congress has been in recess since Mr. Moynihan offered his proposal just before New Year's Day. Democrats have reveled in the political discomfort it has caused President Bush and his Republican allies, but no Democrat has yet endorsed the Moynihan plan. The only support Mr. Moynihan has gained has come from a few conservative Republican lawmakers.
The view of most Democrats is that Mr. Moynihan should be applauded for underscoring the inequities of the tax system and the extent to which Social Security revenue is being used to mask the size of the Government's budget deficit. But the Democrats, and most moderate Republicans, also believe that the country cannot afford a tax cut of any kind.
 
Schumer Sees Economic Danger
Reflecting that conviction, Representative Charles E. Schumer, a Brooklyn Democrat who is on the Banking and Budget committees, said a tax cut would drive up the deficit, cause more Government borrowing, soak up private savings and damage long-term economic growth.
Senator Moynihan said he hoped that the President and Congress could get together and agree on ways to reduce the budget deficit, by cutting spending or increasing some other tax. But even without that, he said, the Social Security tax should be lowered. ''If the deficit is increased, that would be bad,'' he said. ''But if we have to go through a small crisis to straighten things out, fine, let's do it.''
Mr. Moynihan observed that he had long supported an increased gasoline tax, but he said he would not stick his neck out and suggest any tax increase now unless Mr. Bush did likewise.
The issue is being driven by partisan politics. Senator Moynihan has embarrassed Republicans by proposing a tax cut. It is the same kind of proposal that helped Republicans win the last three Presidential elections.
 
Help to All Workers Seen
Mr. Moynihan said that a reduction in the Social Security tax would help all workers, while the Bush plan to lower the capital gains tax rate would largely help the wealthy.
The rejoinder today from Mr. Bush and Mr. Quayle - that Mr. Moynihan's plan would lead to a cut in Social Security benefits - was similarly a move to capture a Democratic stronghold, the party's long-time advocacy of higher retirement payments.
Mr. Moynihan maintains that the money raised today through Social Security taxes affects future benefits only indirectly. He said he planned nothing that would lower those benefits.

HEADLINE: China Reports Release of 573 Held in Revolt

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BEIJING, Jan. 18

 BODY:
The Government said today that it recently released 573 people who had been imprisoned for taking part in the democracy movement last year.
It was the first official announcement since a Government order at the end of June that banned the publicizing of information on arrests and punishments.
The action seemed to be part of an effort by the Chinese authorities to improve their image before the United States Congress reconvenes next week and considers sanctions against Beijing. 
The lifting of martial law in the capital last week was also widely seen as an attempt to improve China's international image and reduce the possibility of new sanctions.
 
Flurry of Arrests and Executions
The official New China News Agency said the lawbreakers had been released ''because during investigations, they pleaded guilty and showed repentance.''
The brief report quoted an unidentified police spokesman as saying, ''Our policy is to educate anyone who can be educated and temper punishment with leniency.''
The report said the spokesman ''hoped that those who took part in the turmoil and counterrevolutionary riots, broke the law and obstinately stuck to the wrong course would understand the situation, repent immediately and plead guilty for leniency.''
The authorities detained thousands of students, workers and intellectuals in June and July, after the military crackdown in early June.
There was never an announcement on how many were arrested, but most estimates started at 10,000 and some were far higher.
After an initial flurry of arrests and executions were reported on television and led to an international outcry, the Chinese leadership circulated an internal document ordering that information about detentions and punishments no longer be publicized.
Since then there have been very infrequent reports, mostly in provincial Chinese newspapers, of arrests or executions.
 
Mistreatment of Prisoners
Some of those arrested were released in the late summer and early fall, and a significant number of students and intellectuals were released beginning in December, say dissidents who maintain an unofficial network among themselves.
The announcement today appeared to refer to those released beginning in December. Most of those released were not beaten by the jailors, and in some cases the guards showed a measure of admiration or respect for the political prisoners, friends say.
But some prisoners are said to have been mistreated in other ways.
One intellectual, for example, was kept in handcuffs constantly for the first 35 days of his imprisonment, a close friend said.
The intellectual had to rely on other prisoners to help him eat, dress and use the toilet.
After his release, his former employer refused to take him back, and no other concern would hire him. Since employers provide housing, the dissident had no place to live, no money to live on and no prospects for a career.
It is not clear how many people are still imprisoned for their role in the democracy movement, but nearly all estimates are in the high hundreds and probably the thousands.
The most prominent prisoners, like Wang Dan, a student leader; Ren Wanding, an essayist, and Liu Xiaobo, a literary theorist, all remain behind bars and nothing certain is known of their condition or treatment.
Almost all that is known about prisoners concerns intellectuals and students.
Very little is known about the many workers who played important roles in the movement, because they and their families were not part of a dissident network that could help them and spread the word about their circumstances.

HEADLINE: Panama-Latin Ties Linked to a Pullout

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18

 BODY:
Although President Bush and Vice President Dan Quayle are opening a round of diplomacy to bolster the Panamanian Government, Administration officials said today that it was unrealistic to expect formal recognition by major countries in the region until the United States invasion force is withdrawn.
The financially strapped and politically mistrustful governments of Latin America are also unlikely to offer much money to Panama, despite Washington's plans to try to enlist their help in economic aid programs, the Administration officials and Latin American diplomats said.
As a result, they said, the Administration's strategy in Latin America is based primarily on the calculation that pragmatism will eventually replace resentment and that regional leaders will begin to support the new Panamanian Government.
 
Too Soon to Visit
In keeping with this approach, officials said the Administration had decided not to press Mexico and Venezuela to receive Mr. Quayle after the two countries said it was too soon after the Panama invasion for him to visit. 
''Time will hopefully bring them around,'' one offical said. ''Gestures like the Andean summit on drugs that Bush will attend in February and Quayle's trips over the next weeks are designed to demonstrate continuity, to put Panama behind and try to get back to what we were doing with Latin America before.''
A Latin American diplomat said: ''The realpolitik of power will take over after a while. And then the Government of Panama, if it manages to produce some sense of economic restoration, will be in business.''
The diplomat suggested that governments in the region were waiting for the United States to take a significant first step to make the new Panamanian Government independent, including withdrawal of its extra troops from Panama and the presentation of an economic aid package for that country.
 
Aid Program Planned
Recognizing this need, Administration officials said they hoped to be able to give Mr. Quayle the outlines of an aid program before he leaves on Jan. 27 for Honduras, Panama and Jamaica, the first leg of his Latin American mission.
Meanwhile, the unwillingness of Mexico and Venezuela to accept a visit by Mr. Quayle has underscored the way in which Mr. Bush has so far failed to rally public support for his Panama policy in the region, even if he has achieved the military objectives he set for the invasion.
About two dozen countries have formally recognized the Panamanian Government of President Guillermo Endara, including most American allies outside the Western Hemisphere. But none of the major Latin American governments are on the list and some, including Peru, continue to maintain that Mr. Endara's Government is illegitimate.
''I think that recognition will accelerate once the departure of U.S. troops accelerates,'' an Administration official said. ''That has been a big sticking point.''
 
Business Goes On
Some Administration officials say that formal recognition is largely symbolic since about 30 governments, including Mexico, are doing business with Panama despite the lack of recognition.
But Government officials, Latin American diplomats and others involved in regional politics said the Panama invasion had derailed Mr. Bush's early efforts to build good will in the region by stressing a commitment to multilateral diplomacy and simply paying more attention to its leaders.
''Latin American governments have always complained that the United States neglects them,'' an Administration official said. ''With all the attention focusing on Eastern Europe lately, and then the invasion of Panama, that feeling has become more acute.''
The Panama invasion has also landed the Bush Administration in the midst of a tangled political situation in the region.
One thread is the historical distrust of North American power ''The fact is that the Latinos are going to be very leary for quite a while as to whether the United States is really going to do what we say,'' said Sol M. Linowitz, who negotiated the Panama Canal Treaties in 1977. ''The President has wisely sought to suggest that Panama was not a precedent for unilateral action, but they are going to be guarded and uncertain until we prove through action that this is not rhetoric.''
 
'The Only Safe Course'
Administration officials said some Latin American leaders had privately welcomed the ouster of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega. But many are under intense domestic political pressures, particularly from the left, and cannot be seen to be endorsing what some perceive as an act of Yankee imperialism.
''The question for the Latins now is how to react in the face of the obvious joy of the Panamanian people at what happened to Noriega,'' a Latin American diplomat said. ''They are struggling to put together a policy, and the only safe course in the meantime is to be cold to the United States.''
The diplomat said the Panama invasion had also provoked ''a terrible soul searching'' at the Organization of American States, whose political efforts to dislodge General Noriega failed.
''The two guiding principles of the organization - nonintervention and the promotion of dissent and democracy -collided in Panama,'' he said.
A United States official said, ''It is painful for the Latin Americans to accept an American invasion, but it is equally frustrating to know that they were not able to accomplish the same thing through the O.A.S.''

SECTION: Section A; Page 20, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 1802 words

HEADLINE: Approval of Bush, Bolstered by Panama, Soars in Poll

BYLINE: By MICHAEL ORESKES

 BODY:
As he completes his first year in office, George Bush, helped by overwhelming support for the invasion of Panama, stands higher in the public's approval than any President has at an equivalent point in his administration since John F. Kennedy, the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll shows.
Three out of four Americans say they approve of the job Mr. Bush is doing. This 76 percent approval is a level only rarely achieved by Presidents since World War II, and one particularly rare since the crises of political confidence that were brought on by the Vietnam War and the Watergate scandal.
In the Jan. 13-15 poll, 13 percent of Americans expressed disapproval of the job Mr. Bush is doing. The margin of sampling error was plus or minus three percentage points. 
Not since Presidents Kennedy and Dwight D. Eisenhower has an elected President been able to achieve such widespread approval after having been in office for one year. The approval rating for President Kennedy was 79 percent and for President Eisenhower it was 70 percent.
 
Satisfied by Foreign Policy
Neither Ronald Reagan nor Richard Nixon ever achieved this level of approval. In a Gallup Poll in the early months of Jimmy Carter's Presidency, he achieved approval ratings rivaling Mr. Bush's now, but went fairly steadily down after that.
Lyndon Johnson received similar support in the year after he succeeded the slain President Kennedy. But after his landslide election victory over Barry Goldwater, his public approval, too, quickly began to erode.
Tempering the generally positive view of Mr. Bush was a further finding of the poll: When asked whether he or President Reagan had accomplished more during his first year in office, 37 percent said Mr. Bush had and 43 percent said Mr. Reagan.
The view of Mr. Bush among the 1,557 randomly selected American who were surveyed by telephone is bolstered by general satisfaction with his handling of foreign policy (73 percent approve) and, in particular, by strong support for the United States invasion of Panama (74 percent said it was justified) and by the return of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega to the United States for trial (54 percent approve).
Approval of Mr. Bush's handling of foreign policy overwhelmed various domestic doubts about the President and the state of the nation.
Jitters about the economy have increased considerably since Mr. Bush's election, the survey found, with 36 percent of Americans saying they think the economy will get worse. That is an increase of 11 percentage points from November 1988. Only 8 percent said it would get better, the most pessimistic outlook on that question since January 1981, shortly before the start of the worst recession in postwar history. Mr. Bush himself got mixed reviews for his handling of the economy, with half approving but 4 in 10 disapproving.
 
Mixed View of Drug War
On several other domestic issues -improving education, protecting the environment and sheltering the homeless - a majority of Americans said Mr. Bush was mainly just talking about the problem or not doing enough.
On the issue of greatest concern to Americans, drugs, slightly more than half said Mr. Bush has made progress. That view was presumably influenced by the capture of General Noriega, who faces Federal drug trafficking charges. But there was also considerable skepticism, with 41 percent saying they believed Mr. Bush had mainly just talked about dealing with the drug problem.
There is long-term political danger for Mr. Bush in Americans' uneasiness about domestic matters. In identifying the biggest problems facing the nation, only 7 percent cited the area of the President's greatest strength, foreign policy. But one in three cited drugs and two in five identified the economy and other domestic issues.
Mr. Bush's political advisers are delighted about the President's standing in this poll and other recent surveys with similar findings, and they are looking for ways to capitalize on it. At the same time, they recognize the soft spots, so to counter those and to pressure Congress, Mr. Bush has begun talking about what he terms Washington's unfinished agenda.
In a recent speech, he accused Congress of not acting on items he has been pressing for, like a clean air bill and a cut in the tax on capital gains. Democrats on Capitol Hill reject this criticism, but Mr. Bush is likely to continue the theme in his State of the Union Message Jan. 31, senior Republican officials said.
 
Unusual Rise in First Year
Mr. Bush's approval rating has actually risen during his first year, the reverse of the recent trend for Presidents. In the early months of the Administration, about 61 percent of the public expressed approval in several surveys. That rose to 70 percent around the time of local elections in November and then slipped amid criticism that Mr. Bush was passive in the face of upheaval around the world and problems at home. But the slide has reversed in the last two months as Mr. Bush met at Malta with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union, helped President Corazon C. Aquino fend off a coup in the Philippines and then sent troops into Panama.
Mr. Bush's support spread broadly in the latest survey. Even 64 percent of Democrats and a remarkable 70 percent of blacks said they approved of the job he is doing.
As various other polls in recent days have also found Mr. Bush winning historically high levels of approval, Democrats have been arguing that the support is, in the words of Ronald H. Brown, the party chairman, ''a mile wide and an inch deep.''
The Times/CBS News survey suggests that part of Mr. Bush's success is that he has given people few reasons to be against him. By this point in Ronald Reagan's Presidency, nearly one voter in five was able to cite proposed budget cuts or the handling of the economy and the budget deficit when asked what Mr. Reagan's principal shortcoming was.
But when asked for Mr. Bush's failing, the only issue that drew strong reaction was the invasion of Panama, with 7 percent saying the United States should not have taken such action.
 
Criticism Is Diffuse
While 14 percent cited some domestic problem as a failing, these views were spread across many different issues, suggesting that the criticism was diffuse rather than focused. The same phenomenon occurred when people were asked to describe Mr. Bush's greatest success. One in four cited the Panama invasion, but after that, support was spread across a wide range of issues.
''George Bush nibbles around the edges rather than throwing ideological bombs,'' Representative Newt Gingrich of Georgia, the Republican whip in the House, said yesterday. ''This is a marginal Administration. It incrementally moves forward on 70 fronts.''
The Panama invasion was by far the most powerful moment in defining the Bush Presidency, the poll suggests. Three-fourths of those surveyed said the invasion was justified.
But they also said Panama was a special case. Half said the United States should stay out of the affairs of other countries rather than try to overthrow a dictatorship. And most said they believe Mr. Bush shared this view, with 57 percent saying it was not likely Mr. Bush would send American troops into other countries to overthrow dictators like General Noriega.
Past presidents have benefited the way Mr. Bush is now from what they call the ''rally round the flag phenomenon.'' This is the surge of public support that typically accompanies foriegn actions, whether military or diplomatic.
Even failed adventures can produce the effect. President Kennedy reached the pinnacle of public approval for a modern President, 83 percent in the Gallup Poll, shortly after the disastrous Bay of Pigs invasion of Cuba.
 
Nuclear War Fear Subsiding
While Americans remain reluctant to declare the Cold War over, the highest percentage ever recorded by the Times/CBS News Poll, 46 percent, now say it very unlikely that the United States will get into a nuclear war in the next 10 years.
The poll shows that while Americans tend to give Mr. Gorbachev more credit than Mr. Bush for the changes sweeping Eastern Europe, a majority say Mr. Bush deserves at least some credit for them.
Mr. Bush's approval rating has the potential for influencing much of American politics this year. Richard Brody, professor of political science at Stanford University, noted that President Kennedy's high standing helped insulate Democrats from the Congressional losses that the party in control of the White House normally suffers in an off-year election.
Indeed, Mr. Gingrich predicted yesterday that the Republicans might actually gain seats this year. At a breakfast, Mr. Gingrich was also asked what President Bush would do about Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan's proposal to cut Social Security payroll taxes.
''If the President's popularity is at 80 percent,'' Mr. Gingrich replied, citing the figure of a recent Gallup Poll in the first week of January, ''I think the President can do whatever he wants.''
In another survey, conducted in the second week of January by by The Washington Post and ABC News, the President registered 79 percent approval.
 
How the Poll Was Conducted
The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted Jan. 13 to Jan. 15 with 1,557 adults around the United States, excluding Alaska and Hawaii.
The sample of telephone exchanges called was selected by a computer from a complete list of exchanges in the country. The exchanges were chosen so as to assure that each region of the country was represented in proportion to its population. For each exchange, the telephone numbers were formed by random digits, thus permitting access to both listed and unlisted numbers. The numbers were then screened to limit calls to residences.
The results have been weighted to take account of household size and number of residential telephone lines and to adjust for variations in the sample relating to region, race, sex, age, and education.
In theory, in 19 cases out of 20, the results based on such samples will differ by no more than three percentage points in either direction from what would have been obtained by seeking out all American adults.
The percentages reported are the particular results most likely to match what would be obtained by seeking out all adult Americans. Other possible percentages are progressively less likely the more they differ from the reported results.
The potential sampling error for smaller subgroups is larger. For example, for either Republicans or Democrats in the sample it is plus or minus four percentage points.
In addition to sampling error, the practical difficulties of conducting any survey of public opinion may introduce other sources of error into the poll.

HEADLINE: Grand Juries Can Defend Rights of the Accused

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Sol Wachtler, Chief Judge of New York State and author of ''Grand Juries: Wasteful and Pointless'' (Op-Ed, Jan. 6), knows that the state, through its police force and offices of the district attorneys, has replaced the king as the abusive force against which the grand jury must stand as the protector of the rights of a defendant charged with a serious felony.
While the prosecutor conducts the presentation of a case before a grand jury, a defendant may choose to testify, and may ask the grand jury to call witnesses on his or her behalf and to consider evidence not put before it by the prosecutor. In the Bronx, where I have practiced as a criminal defense lawyer for the Legal Aid Society for three years, approximately two-thirds of those cases in which our clients choose to testify are dismissed outright by the grand jury, or the charges are reduced to less serious misdemeanors. 
Experience teaches that grand juries, composed of ordinary citizens, are capable of evaluating the testimony of defendants, complaining witnesses and police officers with far less cynicism than judges or prosecutors. Hailing from the very communities where the crimes charged are alleged to have taken place, these citizens can see through charges instituted for personal revenge, blackmail or as a result of human error.
And, subject to a police force no less racist than the police in Boston (who were ready to arrest a person of color without scrutinizing the evidence that pointed to the culpability of a white man in the Charles Stuart affair), they are able to balance the credibility of defendants against that of police officers who often will stretch the truth, when they are not lying outright, to justify an arrest motivated by racial or economic prejudice, or by the simple arrogance of law-enforcement personnel toward the average citizen of Bronx County.
Indeed, it is my opinion that more defendants would exercise their right to testify before the grand jury were their lawyers more willing to take the time to present their cases (they do not because, in the Bronx, the Office of the District Attorney maintains an archaic and inefficient grand jury system that can tie up witnesses and defense counsel for hours, if not days), and were they not faced with the threat that unrelated previous criminal records would be brought to the attention of the grand jury by prosecutors more interested in obtaining an indictment than in seeing justice done.
Nor would replacing the grand jury system with preliminary hearings presided over by those same cynical judges (often former prosecutors) preserve the rights of defendants. Faced with conflicting police and defendant testimony in suppression hearings conducted every day in the Criminal and Supreme Courts of New York State, these judges in the vast majority of cases find police testimony to be credible.
Judge Wachtler recently saw his request for an increase in judicial salaries and for hiring of more judges turned down by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's administration. Now he apparently wishes for a transfer of funds by eliminating the grand jury system. It would be a gross injustice to those facing indictment to pare their first line of defense, while increasing the funds of the very system against which their need for defense is so self-evident.
 
BILL MANTLO
 New York, Jan. 6, 1990

HEADLINE: Ex-Danbury Mayor's Trial: Extortion Tale Unfolds

BYLINE: By NICK RAVO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEW HAVEN, Jan. 18

 BODY:
When a former mayor of Danbury, James E. Dyer, was indicted on extortion and racketeering charges last year, few believed that his trial would include testimony as titillating as allegations of payoffs in restaurant restrooms, cash hidden between the pages of The Wall Street Journal and illegal deals cut over coffee in City Hall.
For the last two weeks, however, such accusations have become almost commonplace here in Federal District Court, where Mr. Dyer is on trial.
''This is going to be a great book,'' Mr. Dyer said today, after testimony that he received $30,000 in 1984 and 1985 from the former president of the Danbury Savings and Loan in exchange for not blocking several condominium developments that the bank was building.
Mr. Dyer, who was defeated trying for a fifth two-year term in 1987, was indicted in March and in September by a Federal grand jury on charges of racketeering, two counts of extortion and four counts of filing false Federal tax returns. 
The charges stemmed from Mr. Dyer's role in receiving $120,000 in exchange for helping developers receive city approval for several projects that fueled the explosive growth in this northern Fairfield County city in the mid-1980's. If convicted on all counts, he faces a possible 72-year prison sentence and $1.6 million in fines.
 
Three-Year Investigation
''I have not extorted money from anyone - period,'' Mr. Dyer said after testimony on Tuesday.
The indictments came after a three-year investigation of corruption in the fast-growing and mostly Democratic city of high-tech corporations, condominiums and 70,000 residents tucked in the Berkshire foothills, about 75 miles from New York City.
Mr. Dyer, who is 43 years old, was indicted in September on charges of using his office to extort $60,000 from the developer of the Danbury Fair Mall, Wilmorite Inc. of Rochester.
Among the allegations is that he received $1,000-a-month payments for more than four years. The first payment, a $10,000 stack of hundred-dollar bills, were delivered in an envelope tucked between pages 34 and 35 of The Wall Street Journal, according to testimony last week. Other payments, which were approved by the company, were delivered in Danbury area restrooms, hotel rooms, City Hall stairwells, the Westchester County Airport in Harrison and, once, at a local news conference trumpeting the new mall, witnesses said.
A Wilmorite senior vice president, Alfred Friedrich, testified last week that Mr. Dyer complained in 1982 that everyone was going to be making money on the mall except him. He also asked for $38,000 to help make the down payment for a house, Mr. Friedrich said.
Another part of the September indictment alleges that Mr. Dyer agreed to accept $100,000 from a Waterbury developer, John Errichetti, who was in charge of a $20 million downtown revitalization project that began in 1984.
 
A Means of Thanks
In March, Mr. Dyer, once a rising political star in the state, was indicted on charges that he extorted $30,000 from the Danbury Savings and Loan Association.
In testimony relating to that indictment, Charles Bruno, president of Danbury Savings and Loan, said on Tuesday that he visited Mr. Dyer in his fourth-floor City Hall office on a weekday in March 1984. Mr. Bruno said that he wanted to thank him for his aid in untangling some municipal red tape that had ensnared one of the bank's condominium developments.
 
Figure Scribbled on Paper
In his testimony, Mr. Bruno said that during the meeting, Mr. Dyer was modest. Then, Mr. Bruno said, the mayor pushed a piece of paper across his desk.
Mr. Bruno scribbled ''$30,000'' on the paper and slid it back.
''What do you want me to do for this?'' Mr. Dyer asked.
''I am just thanking you,'' Mr. Bruno said. ''And maybe it's not what you do, but what you don't do.''
The money, which was paid to Mr. Dyer in seven installments over the next year, came from a fund Mr. Bruno had created by inflating a real-estate commission paid by the bank, he said in his testimony. He retired from Danbury Savings and Loan last year. He has also pleaded guilty to a tax fraud charge in connection with the transactions with Mr. Dyer.

SECTION: Section C; Page 2, Column 3; Weekend Desk

LENGTH: 1104 words

HEADLINE: On Stage

BYLINE: By Enid Nemy

 BODY:

The Right Space
Theaters, theaters everywhere, and not a one to play in? Yes and no, at least on Broadway. At the moment, two major shows scheduled for March openings have not yet found or decided on a theater.
''Cat on a Hot Tin Roof,'' starring Kathleen Turner, is to begin its New York run on March 14, but where? No one is saying. Ideally, the show, which is selling out on the road (Wilmington, Pittsburgh, Boston and Philadelphia), would be booked into ''a 1,100-to-1,200-seat theater with an intimate feel,'' said Fran Weissler, the co-producer. It was originally scheduled for a Jujamcyn house, but the five Jujamcyn theaters are currently occupied or booked. The Nederlander organization has several large theaters available - including the Marquis (1,600 seats), which was to house the ill-fated ''Annie 2'' - but all are generally considered more suitable for musicals. However, the organization's Brooks Atkinson Theater (1,100 seats) is also free and is apparently under consideration, as are several Shubert theaters. 
''Lettice and Lovage,'' the English production starring Maggie Smith and Margaret Tyzack, scheduled to open here March 25, is being co-produced by the Shubert Organization. Bernard Jacobs, the Shubert president, said that no decision had been made yet, but that there would be no problem housing the show - it would go into a 1,100-seat, one-balcony theater ''like the Plymouth, Royale or Ethel Barrymore,'' all currently occupied.
 
Miss Margarida Returns
One of the smallest Broadway houses, the 499-seat Helen Hayes Theater, will house an unexpected arrival early next month. Estelle Parsons is returning in a revival of ''Miss Margarida's Way'' for a limited run of four to eight weeks. The almost one-woman show about a capricious, unpredictable schoolteacher (the audience participates as the class, and there is one other character who walks onstage but does not speak), opened at the Public Theater in 1977, moved to Broadway two months later and earned Miss Parsons a Tony nomination. The drama about political tyranny, by Roberto Athayde, then toured the United States, Europe and Australia, and another tour is planned after Broadway. Bernard Nussbaum, a lawyer, is making his debut as a Broadway producer.
 
Kline as Director
Kevin Kline will not only play the Prince of Denmark when ''Hamlet'' opens at the Public Theater in April; he will also direct the production.
''He had hinted before that he wanted to direct something,'' Joseph Papp said. ''And then he called and said he wanted to direct his own 'Hamlet.' '' (Mr. Kline played Hamlet at the Public in 1986 in a production directed by Liviu Ciulei.) Mr. Papp said he had informed Steven Berkoff, who was scheduled to direct, of Mr. Kline's request. Mr. Berkoff is in London, where he played the role of Herod and directed the National Theater production of ''Salome,'' which is moving to a West End theater this month. He also staged the critically acclaimed ''Coriolanus'' at the Public Theater in 1988. Mr. Papp described him as ''a first-rate director,'' but he added that with Mr. Berkoff's London commitment, ''it would have been a complicated situation.''
 
Nichols Off the Board
On another front, the Public Theater is temporarily short one board member. Mike Nichols, who has been on the board for slightly more than two years, resigned last week.
''There is a certain obligation of board members to raise money - we need to raise $2.5 million -and I spelled out a definite quota this year,'' Mr. Papp said. ''Mike felt that he was not a money-raiser in that way. He'll continue to contribute in his own way, and he'll still be chairman of the 35th-anniversary celebration April 23.''
 
Bete Drole
Stuart Ostrow, the co-producer of ''M. Butterfly,'' has a new show in the wings. ''La Bete: A Comedy of Manners,'' by David Hirson, is scheduled to go into rehearsal at the end of the year and arrive on Broadway in March 1991.
Mr. Ostrow described the three-act show, set in 17th-century France, as having ''a comic-opera feel, although there is no singing; it will be performed in an absurdly high comic style, and the pace is frantic.'' The 10 roles include two major ones for men, and Mr. Ostrow said he is determined to cast American performers. He also plans to add music to the show, as he did with ''M. Butterfly.''
Mr. Hirson, a 31-year-old Yale graduate with a doctorate from Oxford, will be making his Broadway debut as a playwright. Richard Jones, who staged ''Too Clever by Half'' at the Old Vic in London, will direct.
 
An Actor Who Works
John Curless thinks of himself as ''a jobbing actor,'' which he defines as ''an actor who works but has not necessarily made a major television series or become well known.''
After almost a decade in the United States, the English-born-and-trained actor, now appearing in ''Progress'' at the Hudson Guild Theater, said he feels ''part of the American theater, not the British theater in exile.''
And a small part of that feeling is accepting the fact that a job outside the theater (''but I've never waited on tables'') is occasionally necessary. When that happens, he reminds himself of something he was told at drama school: ''They said if you don't like being unemployed, this isn't the profession for you.''
Temporary unemployment and not moving ahead as quickly as one might like were not sufficient reasons to give up the profession, he said. ''The only reason for giving it up is when you stop enjoying it, and that hasn't happened to me.''
 
Sequel for a Black Musical
One of the longest-running black musicals in theater history, ''Mama, I Want to Sing,'' has naturally inspired a sequel, which has been given the same name with ''Part II'' added. The new musical, a contemporary love story, was created by Vy Higginsen and Ken Wydro, the husband-and-wife team who wrote, directed and produced the original, and includes 18 songs composed by Wesley Naylor. It will play in repertory with Part I and a third show, ''Let the Music Play Gospel,'' on weekends beginning Feb. 2. The address is the Heckscher Theater, 1230 Fifth Avenue, at 104th Street. Telephone: 534-2804.
 
In the Wings
Jon Polito and Priscilla Lopez go into ''Other People's Money'' on Sunday, replacing Kevin Conway and Mercedes Ruehl. . . . Hinton Battle and Christine Andreas will join Betty Buckley in ''Stardust,'' the $2.5 million musical opening on Broadway in April and featuring the songs of Mitchell Parish and composers like Hoagy Carmichael and Duke Ellington. . . . ''The Lisbon Traviata'' will close on Jan. 28.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Economy
Consumer prices climbed 0.4 percent last month, the same as in November. For 1989 as a whole, inflation as measured by the Consumer Price Index was 4.6 percent, the steepest since 1981, when it was 8.9 percent. [Page D1.] The White House said economic conditions justified lower interest rates, in an unusual public comment for this Administration on Federal Reserve policy. [D6.] 
Housing construction slumped in 1989 to its lowest level since the 1982 recession, the Government said. [D6.]
The Government's announcement that a man had obtained classified military data from a computer drew skeptical reactions from some computer security experts. [A19.] A man on trial for creating a rogue program said he was paralyzed with fear when his program jammed a nationwide network. [A19.]
 
 
 
Companies
First Boston removed William E. Mayer as chief executive, in a move that reflects troubles emanating from its financial exposure to Campeau's retailing operations. [D1.]
Rorer Group signed a pact to merge with Rhone-Poulenc and said the deal valued its stock at $73 a share, or $3.14 billion. [D1.]
Despite an $80 billion backlog of orders, Boeing said its factory work force had grown too large and would be reduced by 5,000 production workers. [D1.]
The nation's top health official expressed outrage at R. J. Reynolds's test-marketing of a cigarette aimed at blacks. [A1.]
Stephen Rubin was named Doubleday's president and publisher, replacing Nancy Evans, who resigned. [D1] The publisher at Bantam, Mr. Rubin is not shy about his rapid rise. [D16.]
Campeau faces potential problems with bank loans on which Canadian real estate is collateral. [D5.]
Texaco's fourth-quarter earnings fell 3 percent, partly because of a $355 million charge for environmental improvement. [D12.]

HEADLINE: Consumer Prices Up 4.6% in '89

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18

 BODY:
Consumer prices climbed four-tenths of 1 percent last month, the same as in November, the Labor Department reported today. Increases quickened for fuel oil and natural gas, while food prices and medical care rose more slowly than in the previous month.
For 1989 as a whole, inflation as measured by the Consumer Price Index was 4.6 percent, slightly higher than the 4.4 percent rise in 1987 and 1988 but the steepest since 1981, when it was 8.9 percent.
At the White House, the Presidential spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, took the occasion to declare that ''inflation is low and under control,'' suggesting that this meant the Federal Reserve could afford to relax monetary policy further to prevent a wavering economy from slipping into recession. [Page D6.] 'These Numbers Are Low' 
''We are hopeful that they will take a look at this morning's indicators and understand that these numbers are low,'' which would mean ''lower interest rates are justified,'' Mr. Fitzwater said in response to a question at the daily briefing for reporters.
Besides the inflation data, the Government reported today that housing starts fell 8 percent last month. Mr. Fitzwater said that was ''not good news,'' but non-Government economic specialists tended to dismiss it as probably reflecting unusually severe weather. [Page D6.] Mr. Fitzwater's comments came after two Fed governors were described in an article today in The Wall Street Journal as disinclined to reduce interest rates further without stronger evidence that the economy was really deteriorating. The Fed governors' remarks were largely blamed by people in the credit markets for a sharp drop in prices of Treasury securities and a jump in long-term interest rates to their highest levels in more than six months. [Page D12.] G.N.P. Data Due Next Friday, the Commerce Department will make its first estimate of gross national product for the fourth quarter of 1989. General expectations are for a small increase, but few experts are ruling out a possible small decline.
While today's inflation report was no worse than expected, economists said they were considerably less encouraged by it than the White House. They said gasoline posted a somewhat surprising decline that offset big jumps in household fuels. And the effects of freezing weather on Southern citrus and vegetable crops came too late to affect December prices. This suggests that consumer prices in January could jump perhaps seven-tenths of 1 percent before probably easing late in the winter.
Some analysts said they were sobered by the price acceleration in 1989, and while it was not large, they noted that it was driven significantly by factors that could generate a bigger increase this year.
''Inflation is creeping up, boosted primarily by labor costs,'' asserted David W. Berson, chief economist for the Federal National Mortgage Association. And he said that if the dollar falls, as appears fairly likely, American employers would be even better positioned to pass along these costs - which have been rising substantially, especially for fringe benefits - to consumers because of less rigorous foreign competition. Mr. Berson predicted that consumer prices would rise by just under 5 percent this year.
 
Less Volatile Figure
But Patrick C. Jackman, a senior Labor Department official, said he was optimistic that inflation would remain moderate, pointing out that when the gyration-prone food and energy components are taken out, the Consumer Price Index rose 4.1 percent last year, substantially less than the figure of 4.7 percent in 1988 excluding these components.
Referring to the argument being made by Mr. Berson and others, including Joel Popkin, a former Labor Department associate price commissioner, Mr. Jackman said, ''It appears the lag between rising wages and rising prices is longer than most of those people thought.''
The tally of inflation at the retail level in December was typical of recent months - though higher than during the summer - and consistent with last Friday's report that prices received by American producers of finished goods climbed seven-tenths of 1 percent for the month. Because of special factors, that report was widely thought to overstate inflation for these goods at the stage just before reaching consumers.
The two gauges do not closely parallel each other, because it takes many months for most producer prices to feed fully into retail prices and because the Producer Price Index includes no directly measured services or imported goods.
 
Food and Shelter Up
In 1989, inflation in the important shelter and food components rose somewhat more than in 1988, but most of the acceleration was caused by sharp increases in the first half of the year in petroleum-based energy, today's report showed. Nonetheless, food prices climbed 5.6 percent, the most rapid clip since 1980, with a number of items posting huge increases: dairy products rose 10.3 percent; eggs, 35.4 percent; fuel oil, 15.5 percent, and tobacco products, 14.7 percent.
Prices declined by small amounts for used cars, house furnishings and women's and infants' apparel.
In December, food inflation slowed to four-tenths of 1 percent, as fruits and vegetables fell 1.3 percent after rising sharply in October and November, while the other important grocery store food groups posted bigger increases than in the month before. Dairy products surged another 2.2 percent, and the index for meats, poultry, fish and eggs rose 1 percent.
Housing prices advanced five-tenths of 1 percent, the same as in November, with fuel oil up 3.8 percent, natural gas up 2.1 percent and electricity rising eight-tenths of 1 percent. Cable television and refuse collection also rose substantially, but telephone charges fell.
 
Decline in Gasoline
Transportation prices edged up a scant one-tenth of 1 percent. A 2 percent decline for gasoline, the sixth decline in seven months, nearly offset the higher cost of buying a new car.
Apparel prices fell seven-tenths of 1 percent, reflecting larger than usual late-season reductions, and this cut the full-year increase for clothing down to seven-tenths of 1 percent.
Medical care rose five-tenths of 1 percent in December, and the 12-month increase, at 8.5 percent, was the highest of any important category.
The category of ''other'' goods and services, which includes tobacco and tuitions, rose nine-tenths of 1 percent last month.
Excluding food and energy, the December increase was four-tenths of 1 percent, the same as in November.
 
Regional Measures
For the five metropolitan areas for which a monthly Consumer Price Index is calculated, there were increases for the year of 5.8 percent for New York, 5.2 percent for Los Angeles, 4.3 percent for Chicago, 3.9 percent for San Francisco and 3.4 percent for Philadelphia.
The Consumer Price Index, which covers all urban consumers, now stands at 126.1, compared with its 1982-1984 base of 100. Before rounding, the December increase was 0.3974563.
Another version of the index, covering only urban wage earners, rose three-tenths of 1 percent last month, also the same as in November, and 4.5 percent during 1989.

HEADLINE: Celebrity Twist to Savings Failure

BYLINE: By THOMAS C. HAYES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DENVER, Jan. 13

 BODY:
In the current savings industry crisis, the collapse of Colorado's Silverado Banking, Savings and Loan Association would stand out even if one of its former directors were not Neil M. Bush, a son of the President.
The Federal bailout of Silverado is likely to be one of the troubled industry's most expensive, costing taxpayers up to $1 billion to cover mounting losses from the savings and loan's risky investments in ''junk bonds,'' land, office buildings and housing developments.
The precipitious fall of Silverado was partly the result of poor business judgment. When the oil-dependent Denver economy slumped in the mid-1980's, lowering real estate prices, many of the region's savings and loans tightened their belts and curbed their lending for property. But Silverado plunged ahead, investing in speculative ventures in the midst of a declining market. 
 
Ties With Developers
But Silverado's demise also illustrates the kind of close - and sometimes questionable - links between savings institutions and developers that kept risky loans flowing and worsened the industry's troubles. The links between Silverado board members, including Neil Bush, and local developers are being scrutinized by platoons of Government investigators.
The Federal regulators are examining several issues, but the essential question is whether Silverado's directors and local developers were engaged in self-dealing - shuffling loans and investments to make Silverado appear more financially healthy than it really was. [On Thursday, the Office of Thrift Supervision held a closed-door meeting with Neil Bush in Washington, to consider whether he had committed any improprieties during the three years he was a Silverado director. The office's commissioners met into the evening and were not expected to announce their conclusions until later.] Earlier this month, three former senior executives of Silverado, including its former chairman and chief executive, Michael R. Wise, signed orders by the Office of Thrift Supervision that permanently barred them from holding jobs in the industry.
The Justice Department and the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation are also investigating the Silverado case.
 
No Sign of Great Wealth
Neil Bush, one of four sons of the President, is a 34-year-old Denver oilman and fledgling entrepreneur, whose modest style of living shows no evidence of significant personal wealth. By all accounts, he is close to his father and has served as a popular and effective fund-raiser in the Republican Party in Colorado.
Neil Bush was invited to join the Silverado board in 1985 and resigned on Aug. 30, 1988, two weeks after his father received the Republican Presidential nomination.
Neil Bush did not respond to repeated requests for an interview. In a recent interview with The Denver Post, he denied doing anything wrong during his period at Silverado. He also denied that he had sought lenient treatment from regulators for the savings association.
''I'm cooperating in every way that I can,'' Mr. Bush said in the interview, referring to the various Government inquiries. ''I have absolutely nothing to hide.''
During his three years as a director, the Silverado board and executives dismissed one auditing firm and approved questionable loans that helped to gild Silverado's weak capital base, keeping regulators at bay.
The institution was finally seized by Federal regulators in December 1988. The Government sold Silverado's healthy operations to the First Nationwide Financial Corporation, a unit of the Ford Motor Company. Those operations are now part of Columbia Savings, the largest savings institution in Colorado, with more than $5 billion in assets.
 
Ties to a Wealthy Borrower
For Neil Bush, the most potentially troublesome issue now under review is his financial ties to a former investor and frequent borrower at Silverado, Bill L. Walters.
Mr. Walters, a high-profile Denver developer whose personal net worth was estimated as high as $200 million a few years ago, was chairman of the Greater Denver Chamber of Commerce in 1987-88. He obtained more than $200 million in loans from Silverado, and purchased $20 million in Silverado securities in 1986, The Denver Post reported. Between 1984 and 1988, he bought $43 million in Silverado securities, the newspaper said.
In 1983, Mr. Walters contributed $150,000 to the formation of a an energy partnership, JNB Exploration, with Neil Bush as one of its partners, according to state records. By contrast, Mr. Bush invested just $100. One of three banks owned by Mr. Walters, the Cherry Creek National Bank, later established a $1.2 million credit line for JNB Exploration.
According to state records, Mr. Walters sold his interest in JNB Exploration in 1986. Neil Bush, who was a general partner of JNB, and James Judd, another general partner, withdrew from those positions last year. Neil Bush has not been associated with JNB Exploration since last May. He founded a new business, the Bush Energy Company, in March 1989.
One key issue, regulators say, was whether Neil Bush approved any transactions between Silverado and Mr. Walters while the President's son was a Silverado director, which would have been improper. He could have retained his seat on the board, but would have had to excuse himself from discussions regarding loans to investors in his energy business.
David L. Paul, the Colorado regulator of savings institutions, declined to confirm details of the loan and stock-purchase transactions between Silverado and Mr. Walters. The transactions were covered in past examinations by regulators, he said, but under state law the results of the examinations may not be publicly released.
Those transactions and others involving large borrowers and senior officers at Silverado have drawn the attention of Government investigators, several industry analysts and consultants said. The Office of Thrift Supervision said last week that it had ''grave concerns'' about some of Silverado's deals.
Industry consultants and executives said the investments in Silverado by Mr. Walters and other large borrowers could have kept the institution's capital above minimum levels required by regulators at a time when earnings from its loans were falling below expectations.
New capital provided by Mr. Walters and others would have permitted Silverado to maintain its active lending practices, which were important to its ability to post profits.
 
Role of Federal Home Loan Bank
Kermit Mowbray, former president of the Topeka, Kan., branch of the Federal Home Loan Bank, said detailed loan examinations conducted by auditors from his bank resulted in Silverado's posting of a huge loss, of more than $200 million, in 1988.
A former staff analyst who worked at the Topeka bank for six months in 1986, James Moroney, said in an interview that regulators under Mr. Mowbray had delayed taking action against Silverado when the questionable transactions and other unusual activities came to light in 1986.
He said an executive under Mr. Mowbray cited Neil Bush's position as a Silverado director as a reason for not cracking down on Silverado management. ''If anything, Neil Bush was victimized,'' Mr. Moroney said. ''He may have thought we were regulators doing our job.''
In an interview, Mr. Mowbray, who left the Topeka home loan bank after Silverado was closed at the end of 1988, denied that Neil Bush's presence at Silverado resulted in regulatory soft-pedaling that kept Silverado open two more years.
''It certainly had nothing to do with my actions,'' he said. ''In retrospect, we probably should have thrown the management out. But nobody had suggested that.''
 
'We Went Too Far'
For his part, Mr. Wise, Silverado's former chief executive, has insisted that the savings and loan made business mistakes but that it did nothing that violated the law. ''It's obvious we went too far,'' he has said. ''But we did nothing illegal or immoral.''

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Behind the 80's Takeover Spree

BYLINE: By Leonard Silk

 BODY:
THE bankruptcy filing this week by Federated Department Stores and Allied Stores, the American retailing operations of the Campeau Corporation of Canada, has raised anxieties about what will happen to the economy if the wave of debt-financed takeovers, leveraged buyouts and managerial buybacks of the 1980's should crash in the 1990's.
Champions of the takeover wave have argued that it will bring tremendous benefits to the American economy, as managers, driven by the need to service and pay off debts, employ corporate assets more efficiently, or sell them to those who will. The proponents contend that the run-up in the stock prices of the acquired corporations offer proof of these economic benefits to come. A case like Campeau, whose stores listed $7.5 billion in debts when they filed for bankruptcy Monday, is just the exception that proves the rule, they say. 
But if the proponents of debt-driven acquisitions and leveraged buyouts are right, why wasn't this wonderful discovery made until the 1980's? As Margaret Mendenhall Blair, a research associate at the Brookings Institution, writes in a forthcoming book, ''Debt, Taxes, and Corporate Restructuring,'' the main theories offered by economists do not explain why ''leverage mania'' struck in the 1980's.
One common theory is that the leveraged buyouts are based on the tax advantage of corporate debt over equity. However, she notes, that advantage of debt over equity has been a feature of the tax code for decades, and, if anything, was reduced by the Reagan-era cuts in the corporate tax rate. She also notes, in an article in the new Brookings Review, that other theories, like the disciplining role of debt on management, the excess of corporate cash flow over worthwhile internal investment opportunities, and alleged financial innovations like high-yield ''junk bonds'' existed well before the 1980's. To explain the mystery, Ms. Blair presents a new theory that shows what was different about the 80's and why such explanations as managerial incentives for buyouts or buybacks and tax advantages of debt over suddenly became important in the last decade. The core of her explanation is the upsurge of real (inflation-adjusted) interest rates at the start of the 1980's to levels three to four times as high as any since World War II. That surge coincided with a deep decline in the rate of return on physical assets, especially in manufacturing.
High real interest rates sharply cut the number of investment projects by raising the ''hurdle rate'' over which qualified projects had to jump. So corporations found themselves with more cash flow than they could profitably invest internally.
The high real interest rates also generated stockholder dissatisfaction and stepped up pressures on corporate managers to increase the payout to shareholders. In earlier decades, shareholders were much more willing to leave their money with corporations as retained earnings, thereby avoiding taxes on dividends and instead acquiring capital gains subject to lower tax rates. ''The elimination of the tax advantage of capital gains,'' says Ms. Blair, ''also removed a major incentive shareholders had for encouraging firms to retain and reinvest profits.''
The idea behind her theory, she said in an interview this week, came to her from a remark in a seminar by T. Boone Pickens, the corporate raider who is chairman of Mesa Petroleum. Mr. Pickens said he was on the hunt for companies because shareholders invest for the greatest after-tax yield and he could not give them enough internal growth.
Other business executives find this explanation of the takeover wave satisfying, though academic economists are waiting for econometric models and more rigorous proofs. According to the Blair thesis, however, the earlier postwar decades when shareholders, seeking their greatest post-tax returns, would let corporations hold and reinvest their money gave way to the 1980's when shareholders preferred to have corporations disgorge cash, buy back equities and leverage up the value of their assets. Companies that resisted such pressures often became the targets of hostile takeovers whose object was to break up the company, Ms. Blair found.
The high interest rates, she concludes, led corporate executives to ''opt for more debt in their capital structure, especially if those high interest rates are not accompanied by rapid growth, technological change or other developments that would make the marginal return on new investment for the firms even higher.'' And she sees the corporate restructuring and rush to leverage as another symptom of the shift in the United States economy of the 1980's away from savings and toward debt-financed consumption.
What should policy makers do about this now? Trying to regulate or stifle leveraged buyouts, she believes, might do more harm than good. In any case, the market is now curbing takeovers by marking down or wiping out the junkier junk bonds, emitting alarms of dangers and sending companies like Federated and Allied into bankruptcy.
The most important way to improve real investment incentives, Ms. Blair suggests, is to lower the real rate of interest and thereby bring down the ''hurdle rate'' for new investments. The best way to get real interest rates down, without sparking inflation or relying on a deep recession, would be to bring down budget deficits and encourage private savings.

HEADLINE: BankAmerica Broke $1 Billion Profit Mark in '89

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
BankAmerica's fourth-quarter profit of $270 million, or $1.21 a share, was slightly higher than the $265 million, or $1.36 a share, of a year ago. Because profits in late 1988 were swollen by the collection of two years' worth of interest on loans to Brazil and other special items, analysts noted that the latest earnings showed that BankAmerica was continuing to recover strongly from its woes of the mid-1980's.
For all of last year, BankAmerica earned $1.10 billion, or $5.19 a share, up 52 percent from $726 million, or $3.79 a share, a year ago. The bank said growth in consumer loans and residential mortgage lending had been especially strong last year, and losses in those lending activities had been low. 
 
Chemical Banking
At Chemical Banking, the nation's sixth-largest banking company, fourth-quarter profits of $95.9 million, or $1.04 a share, were down 66.8 percent from $288.5 million, or $4.66 a share, a year ago. The fourth-quarter earnings for 1989 were raised by $51.6 million to reflect profits from the sale of bond investments, while the fourth quarter of 1988 was raised by two years' worth of interest on Brazilian loans totaling $205.4 million.
Because Chemical added $600 million to its reserves in the third quarter for loans to developing countires and $300 million for loans at its Texas Commerce Bank subsidiary, it lost $482.2 million for all of 1989, or $8.29 a share. In 1988, earnings were $753.6 million, or $12.02 a share.
 
NCNB
Earnings at NCNB were sharply higher from a year ago, as the company more than doubled in size after it acquired the First Republicbank Corporation of Dallas, which has been renamed NCNB Texas. In the fourth quarter, profits were $136.2 million, or $1.25 a share, more than double the $64.3 million, or 68 cents a share, of a year ago. For all of 1989, earnings were $447.1 million, or $4.44 a share, up 77 percent from $252.5 million, or $2.87 a share.
Despite slowing economic activity in the Southeast, NCNB avoided a big increase in problem loans. Its reserve for loan losses totaled $465.5 million at the end of the year, or 1.35 percent of total loans, up from 1.22 percent a year earlier. Delinquent loans, totaled $446.1 million, or 73-hundredths of 1 percent of up from 72-hundredths of 1 percent a year ago.
 
Bank of New York
Profits at the Bank of New York, the 11th-largest banking company in the country, were $106.6 million in the fourth quarter, or $1.43 a share, up 94.9 percent from $54.7 million, or $1.10 a share, a year ago. Most of the gain was from the hostile acquisiton of the Irving Bank Corporation in November 1988.
For all last year, Bank of New York earned only $50.7 million, or 27 cents a share, down 76.2 percent from $213 million, or $5.12 a share, in 1988. The decline was caused by a $600 million increase in the third quarter in its reserve for losses on loans to third world countries. Since adding that reserve, Bank of New York has aggressively sold its loans to those countries, reducing its holdings by about a third, or $634 million during the fourth quarter.
Dennis F. Shea, a banking analyst at Morgan Stanley & Company, noted that earnings at Bank of New York and NCNB showed ''lackluster growth in revenues and little loan growth.''
 
Bank of Boston
At the Bank of Boston, profits in the fourth quarter fell to $9 million, or 8 cents a share, from 83 million, or $1.13 a share, a year ago. The company, which is the largest banking firm in New England and the 15th largest in the nation, had previously announced that problems with real estate loans caused it to add $280 million to its reserves for loan losses in fourth quarter. For all of 1989, when its earnings totaled $70 million, the company added $722 million to its loan-loss reserves. Profits in 1989 amounted to 80 cents a share, and were down 78.3 percent from $322 million, or $4.43 a share, in 1988.

HEADLINE: 2d Thoughts On Bank Deal

 BODY:
Bank of New York Company executives are hinting that they are reconsidering the previously agreed-to acquisition of the Northeast Bancorp, a Shelton, Conn., company.
Northeast Bancorp surprised Bank of New York executives earlier this week when it announced a big increase in troubled loans that cut 1989 profits to $632,000, from $34.6 million in 1988. 
In 1983, when the two companies agreed to merge as soon as Connecticut allows acquisitions by out-of-state banks, Northeast's banking market was thriving. But yesterday, J. Carter Bacot, Bank of New York's chairman, said in an interview with reporters that the weakening trend in the New England economy suggested that the Connecticut company faced difficult times.
A December examination of the books at the $3.5 billion-asset Connecticut bank ''suggests that considerably higher reserves may be necessary,'' Mr. Bacot said.
George R. Kabureck, president of Northeast, said he knew ''of no reason'' why the merger should not occur. He said that Northeast would be able to meet the financial standards set in the 1983 agreement, but he declined to comment on whether Bank of New York could back out.
In 1983, the New York company agreed to pay 2.5 times Northeast's book value, or capital.

HEADLINE: U.S. Growth Forecast

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
The United States economy will grow by 2.5 percent to 3 percent in 1990, with one-third of the gain fueled by exports, according to study released Wednesday by the Conference Board. ''Although relying on exports to foreign markets is something new for the United States, it will become a permanent feature of the 1990's,'' said Gail Fosler, chief economist of the New York-based business research group. While growth in the global economy has cooled in recent months, demand in leading foreign countries is growing faster than it is in the United States, the study said.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Vice Chairman to Head International Data Unit

BYLINE: By DANIEL F. CUFF

 BODY:
Although the computer industry goes into a slump now and then and companies fold up or cut back, Axel Leblois thinks the world is still at the beginning of the computer revolution.
''The industry has its ups and downs,'' he said this week, ''but the number of people using computers worldwide is booming.'' This year, that number stands at 200 million, and by the end of the decade it will pass a billion, he said. 
Mr. Leblois's business is providing information about the information technology industry. He is vice chairman of the International Data Group, based in Framingham, Mass., and former president of its publishing division, which issues 120 computer-related newspapers and magazines throughout the world.
Earlier this week, the company announced that he would wear an additional hat, chairman and chief executive of another International Data Group subsidiary, a market research and analysis company called the International Data Corporation.
Mr. Leblois, 41, will succeed Thomas E. Swithenbank, who has resigned to become president of Harte-Hanks Data Technology in Billerica, Mass. Mr. Leblois will continue as vice chairman.
Mr. Leblois, who joined International Data in its French subsidiary, headed the publishing unit from 1986 to 1989. ''During those four years revenues doubled through internal growth,'' he said. ''We entered a lot of new markets throughout the world, in Taiwan, Japan and the U.S.S.R.''
The company's Soviet computer publishing venture has put out five issues of a magazine. ''It's doing O.K.,'' Mr. Leblois said. ''We had some production problems from a shortage of paper, but it's back on track now. Local production costs are low, and it's been profitable since Day One.''
The International Data Group is a privately held company founded by Patrick J. McGovern, who is chairman. Its annual revenues are $500 million, and along with its publishing and market research businesses it operates a unit that produces exhibitions and conferences on information technology.
Mr. Leblois, who grew up in Paris, went to business school there and attended the University of Paris, majoring in economics and philosophy. The latter subject was ''for my personal fun,'' he said.

HEADLINE: Stocks Mixed Despite Rally In Blue Chips

BYLINE: By PHILLIP H. WIGGINS

 BODY:
Blue-chip stocks rallied in the final half-hour of trading yesterday, but the overall market finished the day mixed.
After vacillating throughout most of the session, the Dow Jones industrial average closed 7.25 points higher, at 2,666.38. It was down as many as 25 points shortly before noon.
But the broader market fared much worse than the glamour equities, with inflation worries and continuing reports of lower earnings pulling down most stock prices throughout the session. 
Declines on the New York Stock Exchange outnumbered advances by about 3 to 2, with 899 issues lower in price and only 584 higher.
Inflation fears were rekindled by the Government's report of a four-tenths of 1 percent increase in the Consumer Price Index for December, which was unchanged from November. This brought the total rise for the year to 4.6 percent.
 
Drop in Housing Starts
At the same time, housing starts showed an 8 percent drop for December. Traders said that the mixed economic picture indicated that the Federal Reserve Board would not move soon to lower interest rates. A report that Fed officials saw no need to ease also played a role in the fall, which sent interest rates sharply higher.
Indicative of the weak earnings outlook, Digital Equipment plunged 5 7/8, to 82, after reporting weaker-than-expected results for its second fiscal quarter ended in December. The computer maker reported net income of $1.25 a share, down from $2.20 a share a year earlier and sharply below the $1.66 a share that Wall Street consensus had estimated.
Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, which slipped 1/8, to 2 7/8, was the most active stock on a volume of 4.9 million shares. The publishing company said that it expected operating profit and cash flow for 1990 to be significantly higher than in 1989.
Monsanto was off 2 points, to 111 1/4. Analysts attributed the decline to investor nervousness over the scheduled release Monday of the company's fourth-quarter earnings.
 
Volume Was Higher
In the broader market, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index edged up 0.79, to 338.19, while the New York Stock Exchange composite index tacked on 0.21, to 187.07.
Volume on the Big Board expanded to 178.6 million shares, from 170.5 million on Wednesday.
Secondary stocks did not benefit as much from the late rally. On the American Stock Exchange, the Amex market value index declined 1.89 points, to 366.17, its lowest close since last July 11. In over-the-counter trading, the Nasdaq composite index fell 1.16 points, to 437.52.
Union Pacific Resources rose 1 1/4, to 77 1/8. The company said that it had cut the price it would pay for domestic crude by 75 cents, to $21 a barrel.
Bank of New York dropped 1/2, to 37 5/8. J. Carter Bacot, the bank's chairman, said that after preliminary examination of Northeast Bancorp, he was less positive about buying that bank. Bank of New York agreed in 1983 to buy Northeast subject to certain conditions, but Mr. Bacot said it appeared that Northeast might have to raise its loan-loss reserves in order to meet those conditions. Northeast plummeted 5 3/4, to 40 1/4, after falling 9 1/2 points on Wednesday.
 
Biggest Percentage Loser
The ailing Bank of New England was the biggest percentage loser, plunging 1 5/8, or nearly 28 percent, to 4 1/4. The bank has been unsuccessful in its search for buyers, and there were reports that an effort to sell some assets was being blocked by regulators.
USAir fell 2 points, to 28 3/4, after the company's chairman said that it might report a loss for 1990 if the trends of high fuel costs and weak revenues continued.
Active blue chips included Citicorp, up 1/8, to 26 1/2; A.T.& T., off 1/8, to 42 3/8; Philip Morris, up 7/8, to 39 3/8, and Alcoa, off 3/8, to 66 1/2.

HEADLINE: Starts of Housing at Lowest Level Since '82

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18

 BODY:
Housing construction slumped in 1989 to its lowest level since the 1982 recession, the Government said today, but many analysts said further decreases in mortgage rates should improve the situation slightly in 1990.
''The drop in December housing starts is primarily due to severe weather in most of the nation last month,'' said John A. Tuccillo, the chief economist for the National Association of Realtors. The extreme cold caused an 8 percent decline in housing starts in December, bringing them to their lowest monthly level since October 1982. 
For all of 1989 starts fell to 1.37 million units, the lowest since 1.06 million units in 1982. The 1988 total was 1.49 million units.
The housing industry had been sluggish through much of last year as the Federal Reserve pushed up interest rates to slow the economy and curtail inflation. But as concerns grew that the economy might be slowing too much, the Fed allowed interest rates to fall gradually in recent months.
 
Interest Rate Predictions
Richard Peach, an economist with the Mortgage Bankers Association, which looks for 1.45 million starts this year, said the forecast ''is predicated on our belief that rates are headed down.''
David Seiders, the chief economist for the National Association of Home Builders, is also counting on a moderate decline in interest rates early in the year to sustain his organization's forecast for 1.38 million starts in 1990.
On the other hand, David Berson, the chief economist for the Federal National Mortgage Association, looks for interest rates to edge up for much of the year and for housing construction to fall slightly.
The report said new houses and apartments were built at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.24 million in December, down from a revised 1.34 million in November and 1.42 million in October.
 
Single-Family Houses
Construction of single-family houses plummeted 10 percent, to an annual rate of 904,000 units, after a 2 percent decline in November. That was the lowest since 862,000 units in December 1982 as the economy began emerging from the recession. But Mr. Berson said that had it not been for the weather, single-family starts would have gone up.
Apartment construction fell 2.4 percent, to an annual rate of 331,000 units, compared with a 15.3 percent decline in November. Analysts said overbuilding in recent years would keep this sector weak.
The overall declines were biggest east of the Rockies, where severe weather was widespread last month. Starts were down 23.3 percent in the Northeast, to 138,000 units; down 10 percent in the South, to 439,000 units, and down 9.8 percent in the Midwest, to 268,000 units. The West recorded the only rise, gaining 3.4 percent, to 390,000 units.
Applications for building permits, an indicator of future activity, edged down four-tenths of a percent in December. During all of 1989, 1.34 million permits were issued, the lowest since one million in 1982.
