HEADLINE: White House Says a Drop In Interest Rates Is Justified

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11

 BODY:
In an unusual public comment for the Bush Administration on Federal Reserve policy, the White House said today that current economic conditions justified lower interest rates.
''We are hopeful,'' said Marlin Fitzwater, President Bush's press secretary, that the Fed policy makers ''will take a look at this morning's indicators and understand that these numbers are low, and that indicates inflation has remained very steady over the last seven or eight years and that lower interest rates are justified.''
The spokesman was referring to statistics released this morning showing that the inflation rate for 1989, as measured by the Consumer Price Index, was 4.6 percent and that housing starts fell by 8 percent last month. 
Mild as it was, Mr. Fitzwater's remark was noteworthy because Bush Administration officials have maintained a general policy of not criticizing the Federal Reserve. Previous Administrations have regularly attacked the Fed when the economy slowed down.
 
Improving Economy Seen
Mr. Fitzwater was responding to a question about an article in The Wall Street Journal this morning in which two governors of the Federal Reserve Board, Manuel H. Johnson and Wayne D. Angell, were quoted as having said in interviews that they saw evidence the economy was improving. The Journal interpreted that to mean that the two would not support a further easing of credit.
Mr. Johnson and Mr. Angell have been among the Fed governors who have pushed for somewhat lower interest rates in the last seven months.
On Wall Street, prices of Treasury securities fell today and interest rates rose. Traders said the market was responding in large part to the article.
 
Course Reversed in June
After driving rates higher since early 1987, the central bank reversed course last June. Since then, the Federal funds rate has fallen in six stages by about 1.5 percentage points, to about 8.25 percent. The Federal funds rate, which is controlled directly by the Fed, is the rate banks charge one another for overnight loans.
A natural tension exists between any Administration and the central bank. Elected officials generally emphasize economic growth, especially in an election year, and that often implies lower interest rates. The Federal Reserve, on the other hand, believes it has a mandate to restrain inflation, and that often means keeping credit tight.
Officials in the Reagan Administration often attacked Fed policy. But the current Federal Reserve Board chairman, Alan Greenspan, has cultivated warm relations with the Bush Administration. Not only has the Administration not criticized the Fed directly, but comments about monetary policy have been rare.
The strongest Bush Administration statement about the Fed came last summer when Richard G. Darman, the budget director, said that if the country fell into a recession, it would be because the central bank ''erred on the side of caution.'' Mr. Darman subsequently said he had not meant to be so blunt, and he has not spoken out since.
The White House has no direct control over the central bank's actions, but students of the Federal Reserve have observed for years that its officials respond to political pressure.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Issues Decline Sharply

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities fell sharply and long-term interest rates rose to their highest levels in more than six months yesterday in a selloff that traders said was largely spurred by comments from two Federal Reserve Board governors that suggested the Fed was not about to ease monetary policy again any time soon.
The comments by Wayne D. Angell and Manuel H. Johnson, the Fed's vice chairman, appeared in an article in The Wall Street Journal yesterday.
The comments merely confirmed the view of many money market analysts, who have stressed repeatedly in recent weeks that a weather-induced rise in key inflation indexes is making it difficult for the Fed to ease policy again soon.
Given the market's bearish tone of late, however, the article prompted a new wave of selling. 
 
'The Sentiment Is Terrible'
''The story in The Journal set this thing off,'' one Government bond trader said. ''But the bottom line remains that the Street still has a fair amount of inventory and there are no buyers. The sentiment is terrible.''
Commenting on the market's reaction to The Journal article, Norman Robertson, chief economist at Pittsburgh's Mellon National Bank, said, ''It is one thing when someone like me says the Fed won't ease,'' adding, ''But it is quite another when officials say it.''
Still, Mr. Robertson said: ''Once again the markets have overreacted and distorted the outlook for inflation and the economy. Indeed, the run-up in interest rates over the last month is likely to have a further dampening effect on the economy.''
The Fed officials' remarks also generated a comment from the White House. Marlin Fitzwater, the President's press secretary, told reporters in Washington that recent economic reports, including the data released yesterday on housing starts and consumer prices, argued for an easier credit policy.
In addition to the comments from the Fed governors, market participants were forced yesterday to contend with another big jump in long-term Japanese interest rates, which have risen by more than a percentage point since the start of the year. The Japanese rate rise further narrowed the differential between yen-denominated securities and those denominated in dollars. That makes it more attractive for Japanese investors to keep money at home rather than invest in the United States.
Yields on the Japanese Government's 10-year bonds rose 19.50 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, to 6.87 percent. On Jan. 2, the yield on the bellwether Japanese issue was 5.79 percent.
''We are seeing the development of a two-tier international economy,'' said David Hale, chief economist at Kemper Financial Services in Chicago.
''Growth in the big creditor countries, Japan and West Germany, is going like gangbusters,'' he said. ''At the same time, there is a slowing in the Anglo-Saxon economies. And rising interest rates in Japan and West Germany will delay improvement in the Anglo-Saxon countries, including the United States.''
The selloff in the the secondary market for Treasury securities yesterday pushed yields on the 8 1/8 percent bonds of 2019 to their highest levels since late June. In late trading, the bonds were offered at a price of 97 3/4, down 30/32, to yield 8.33 percent, up from 8.25 percent on Wednesday.
Prices of note issues also tumbled, and short-term Treasury bill rates soared. By late in the day, the 7 7/8 percent 10-year Treasury notes were offered at 97 6/32, down 22/32, to yield 8.29 percent. And the 7 5/8 percent two-year notes were offered at 98 30/32, down a quarter of a point, to yield 8.22 percent.
In the Treasury bill market, three-month bill rates rose by 13 basis points, to a late offered discount rate of 7.77 percent. Six-month bills were offered in late trading at 7.64 percent, up 12 basis points. And one-year bill rates rose by 14 basis points, to a late offered rate of 7.47 percent.
The sharp drop in Treasury prices had a negative impact on price movements in the markets for investment-grade corporate and tax-exempt municipal bonds. Corporate bond traders said that prices of most actively traded issues fell by five-eighths to three-quarters of a point.
Only one corporation, Comdisco Inc., chose to price a new debt offering yesterday.
Through an underwriting syndicate led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets, Comdisco priced $200 million of 9.75 percent seven-year notes. The notes, which mature Jan. 15, 1997, were priced at 99.743, to yield 9.80 percent, 1.50 percentage points more than the prevailing yield on the 8 percent seven-year Treasury notes at the time of pricing. The issue is rated Baa-2 by Moody's Investors Service and BBB+ by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
In the secondary municipal bond market, prices generally slipped by half to five-eights of a point, traders said. Even larger declines were recorded by New York State and New York City issues. Traders said that prices of New York issues fell by from five-eights to three-quarters of a point.
The drop in New York City issues was partly caused by an announcement from Mayor David N. Dinkins and Comptroller Elizabeth Holtzman that early next month the city would sell $250 million to $300 million of new general obligation bonds.
In other developments, the Federal Reserve Board reported yesterday that all three measures of the nation's money supply declined in the week ended Jan. 8. The report had no impact on the credit markets.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar's Value Up Sharply As Rates Appear to Be Firm

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar rose sharply yesterday against key foreign currencies in active trading as the market appeared more confident the Federal Reserve would not cut interest rates any time soon.
Firm interest rates tend to support the dollar.
Gold prices declined after gaining overseas. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold bullion for current delivery closed at $410.20 a troy ounce, down $2.30 from Wednesday. 
Currency dealers said the dollar was bolstered by a report in yesterday's Wall Street Journal in which comments by two Fed officials suggested they would not support a cut in short-term interest rates unless economic conditions changed.
Both the officials, Manuel Johnson, the Fed vice chairman, and Wayne Angell, a Fed governor, had been in the forefront of a move toward lower interest rates in recent months.
 
White House Comments
Those statements were in contrast with sentiment from the White House, which broke yesterday with its usual practice of not commenting on Fed policy by suggesting that current economic conditions justified rate cuts.
Still, said Ronald H. Holzer, a vice president at the Harris Trust and Company in Chicago, ''With the inflation picture looking as bad as it does, the market was anticipating that the Fed had stopped easing.'' The statements by Mr. Johnson and Mr. Angell, he said, ''confirmed it and brought out good buying for the dollar.''
Some dealers said the Fed had tried to thwart the dollar's rise yesterday by selling dollars for yen, but the market ignored that intervention.
In New York trading, the dollar closed up nearly a yen, at 146.35 yen, from 145.40.
Against the West German currency, the dollar rose nearly 3 pfennigs, to 1.7150 marks, from 1.6873.
The dollar was also stronger against the British pound. Sterling bought $1.6435 in New York, down from Wednesday's $1.65235.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Wednesday's quotes, included: 1.5245 Swiss francs, up from 1.5055; 5.8275 French francs, up from 5.7325; 1,276.75 Italian lire, up from 1,256.50, and 1.17135 Canadian dollars, up from 1.16515.
Gold rose in London to $413.75 an ounce, from $409.75 Wednesday. The late bid in Zurich was $413 an ounce, up from $409.75.
Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold closed at $413.95 an ounce, up from $410.35.
Silver prices were mixed. On New York's Comex, silver bullion for current delivery settled at $5.190 a troy ounce, down 6.6 cents. Silver rose in London to $5.26 an ounce, from $5.23.

HEADLINE: Profit Outlook At Times Co.

 BODY:
The New York Times Company said yesterday that it expected to report earnings of 83 cents to 88 cents a share from continuing operations in 1989. In 1988 the company reported earnings from continuing operations of $2 a share. 
The company said the expected decline largely reflected weakness in the New York region's economy, which affected advertising linage at The New York Times, as well as several other factors the company had previously reported.
These include a charge against earnings that reflected the lower value placed on the company's investment in its Forest Products Group; costs associated with voluntary staff reductions at The Times; organizational changes at McCall's, Golf World (U.S.) and Sailing World magazines, and a charge from a settlement of litigation with home delivery dealers.
Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, the chairman and chief executive, said that because of continued weakness in the regional economy and the costs of a new printing plant in Edison, N.J., the company expected 1990 earnings from continuing operations to be only moderately above the 1989 range of 83 to 88 cents a share.
The Times Company said it expected record earnings of $3.35 to $3.40 a share for 1989, including a gain of $2.46 a share from the sale of its cable televison system. The earnings will be reported early next month.

HEADLINE: Arthur J. Goldberg Dies at 81; Ex-Justice and Envoy to U.N.

BYLINE: By ERIC PACE

 BODY:
Arthur J. Goldberg, who rose from humble beginnings in Chicago to become Secretary of Labor, an Associate Justice of the Supreme Court and then United States representative to the United Nations, was found dead yesterday morning in his apartment in Washington. He was 81 years old.
Dr. Michael Newman, Mr. Goldberg's physician, said the former Justice died late Thursday or early Friday of cardiac arrest from coronary artery disease. A maid found his body lying on a sofa.
Prof. Alan M. Dershowitz of Harvard Law School, who clerked for Justice Goldberg and was a longtime associate, said Mr. Goldberg had been active until his death on project to form a committee to monitor human rights developments in Eastern Europe and China. 
 
Turning Point in Life
Associate Justice William J. Brennan, a fellow liberal who served with Justice Goldberg, said yesterday: ''The nation suffered a grevous loss in the death of Justice Goldberg. He served his nation brillantly as Secretary of Labor, Ambassador to the United Nations and Justice of the Supreme Court. Another great contribution was his work as a lawyer in bringing together the major labor organizations of the country.''
Warren E. Burger, the retired Chief Justice of the United States, said, ''As a Justice of the Supreme Court, he was a balanced and thoughtful jurist.''
A wrenching decision that was a turning point in his life occurred in 1965, when Mr. Goldberg gave up his lifetime appointment to the Supreme Court at President Lyndon B. Johnson's urging to assume the U.N. post. It was a decision he later said he regretted.
On the one hand, as Mr. Goldberg said years later, he believed that as U.N. representative he could reverse the Johnson Administration's Vietnam policy and bring about peace negotiations. On the other hand, it meant giving up a judicial position in which Mr. Goldberg's admirers believed he would have made a greater mark on American history.
''In all candor,'' Mr. Goldberg said on the day he was named to the United Nations post, ''I would rather the President had not asked me to undertake this duty.''
Mr. Dershowitz said the Justice had told him, ''Although I would love nothing more than to live out my years on the Supreme Court, America has been too good to me for me to turn down its President.''
Three years later he resigned, citing frustrations and disappointments, including ''the limitations of the scope of my office'' in regard to getting the United Nations involved in a Vietnam peace effort.
In 1970 Mr. Goldberg entered the race for Governor of New York as the Liberal-Democratic candidate, but he was soundly defeated by the Republican incumbent, Nelson A. Rockefeller.
Mr. Goldberg was an owlish, unimposing figure with remarkable energy and legal, judicial and negotiating skills. Johnson praised him in his memoirs as ''a skilled arbiter and a fair-minded man.''
It was in 1961 that the Chicago-born lawyer, then general counsel of the United Steelworkers of America, was named Secretary of Labor by President John F. Kennedy. In 1962, Kennedy named him to the Supreme Court.
 
A Mover in Historic Merger
The self-made son of an immigrant carter, Mr. Goldberg did much, as a union lawyer, to bring about the historic merger in 1955 of the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations.
His legal work plunged him repeatedly into important decisions involving labor and management. Admirers recalled him as the leading labor lawyer of that day. When he was named general counsel of the Congress of Industrial Organizations in 1948, he became the chief of the staff of lawyers working for its vast membership.
He was involved on behalf of labor in various court cases testing the Taft-Hartley Labor Act, which empowered the Government to obtain an 80-day injunction against strikes that endangered national health or safety. He was also the victor in an important 1949 court ruling affirming that pension issues were a proper subject for collective bargaining.
After the A.F.L.-C.I.O. was formed, he became the main figure to draft rules on ethics. In 1959, he represented the steelworkers in negotiations during a strike that lasted more than 100 days and that led to a contract that was widely seen as a major gain for labor.
As Labor Secretary, Mr. Goldberg was energetic in striving to settle labor disputes. He played a role in the Kennedy Administration's celebrated confrontation with the steel industry. Early in 1962 he helped bring about a noninflationary settlement between the steelworkers and the industry. He prodded the two sides by warning that a strike could seriously upset the nation's economy.
But 10 days later the United States Steel Corporation decided on a price increase, angering Mr. Goldberg and Kennedy. Other steel concerns followed suit. Then, with Mr. Goldberg working behind the scenes, the Administration successfully applied pressure to get steel executives to back down on the price rise. He met with Roger M. Blough, chairman of U.S. Steel, on a day when another steel company revoked its own price increase, and soon U.S. Steel also yielded.
Afterward, on the Supreme Court, Mr. Goldberg quickly became influential as an innovative judicial thinker whose arrival, to replace the more conservative Felix Frankfurter, tilted the Court toward liberal activism.
Authorities have offered different explanations of why Johnson chose Mr. Goldberg for the U.N. The President emphasized his desire to name a distinguished public figure to the post previously held by Adlai E. Stevenson. Others noted Johnson's wish to name his friend Abe Fortas to the Court. Mr Fortas was named to the seat after Mr. Goldberg stepped down.
 
A Reluctant Farewell
Mr. Goldberg said he was reluctant to leave the judiciary for the uncertain world of diplomacy. In making the shift, he became one of the few Supreme Court Justices to quit for reasons other than retirement. Professor Dershowitz said Johnson strongly appealed to Mr. Goldberg's patriotism. ''My President has told me that I can save American soldiers' lives'' by helping to work out a Vietnam peace arrangement, the Justice told his former clerk.
He did make a contribution, largely through dextrous negotiations with Soviet diplomats. But he achieved far less than he had hoped, which was to have a major role in ending the Vietnam War.
After he left the United Nations, he served as president of the American Jewish Committee, the nationwide human rights organization, in 1968 and 1969, and became a member of the Manhattan law firm of Paul, Weiss, Goldberg, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison.
In 1970, after opinion polls suggested that he would be a strong candidate, he entered the race for Governor of New York. But he proved to be a lackluster campaigner and he was easily defeated by Mr. Rockefeller, a long-entrenched power in state politics.
In 1971, Mr. Goldberg returned to Washington, where he resumed his career. He was called in on international arbitration cases and served in 1977 and 1978 in the Carter Administration as a United States Ambassador-at-large.
In that role he was chairman of the United States delegation to a follow-up conference, in 1977 in Belgrade, on the 1975 Helsinki agreements on human rights. At the 35-nation gathering, he voiced vigorous criticism of Eastern bloc nations on human rights.
That advocacy echoed the lusty assertiveness of his early years, as Labor Secretary, when the Federal Government played an interventionist role in some labor-management matters. Mr. Goldberg felt the Government had an obligation to affirm the importance to the nation of resolving crucial labor-management contract talks with implications for the state of the economy.
With Kennedy's support he acted on his own conviction that the Government itself should be vigorous in trying to settle labor-management conflicts that jeopardize national interests.
Early in his tenure as Labor Secretary, he helped resolve a New York harbor tugboat strike. He also intervened, and became a successful arbitrator, in a dispute between the Metropolitan Opera and orchestra members.
The arrival of Mr. Goldberg - a liberal, though not a rigid one - on the Supreme Court, then led by Earl Warren, proved to be a watershed. It led, in the opinion of most constitutional experts at the time, to a change in the course of the Court's rulings.
While Frankfurter was still on the Court, he was the leader of a five-Justice majority that favored judicial restraint, including respect for states' rights and deference to Capitol Hill.
But as an Associate Justice Mr. Goldberg became a member of a group, usually constituting a cohesive majority of the nine Justices, that extended the Court's writ into what had been deemed the spheres of the states or of Congress. This majority group was often termed activist or liberal.
As a Justice, Mr. Goldberg was also innovative. In 1964, in perhaps his most notable opinion, he wrote for the Court's majority in the case of Escobedo v. Illinois, striking down a conviction in a murder case in which the defendant had been denied the right to confer with his lawyer after his arrest.
Similar decisions ensued, and so did reappraisals of much of the nation's criminal justice system. Many police executives and prosecutors complained that the rulings had placed excessive restrictions on them.
Despite Mr. Goldberg's misgivings about leaving the Court for the United Nations, he had some successes as the United States representative there. Some admirers felt his most significant achievement was his role in drafting Security Council Resolution 242, which was passed in November 1967 after the Middle East war that year.
The resolution calls for ''a just and lasting peace in the Middle East,'' including ''withdrawal of Israeli armed forces from territories of recent conflict'' and respect for the right of ''every state in the area to live in peace within secure and recognized boundaries.'' The measure has been a cornerstone ever since in diplomatic efforts to bring peace to the Middle East.
But he did not succeed in getting the United Nations involved in an attempt to bring about an acceptable end to the confrontation in Vietnam. In addition, behind the scenes, Mr. Goldberg had grave differences with Johnson over Vietnam policies.
 
Exit From Vietnam
But Mr. Goldberg did figure modestly in the history of how the United States came to get out of Vietnam. In mid-March 1968, a time when, as Mr. Johnson put it in his book ''The Vantage Point,'' ''our total situation in Vietnam was under comprehensive review,'' Mr. Goldberg sent Johnson a memorandum. It suggested that the United States stop ''the aerial and naval bombardment of North Vietnam for the limited time necessary to determine whether Hanoi will negotiate in good faith'' in peace talks.
''I read the memo carefully,'' Johnson wrote. ''Goldberg made a strong case for a total bombing halt, but not strong enough. I could not take the risk of such a move at that time. I continued to believe that the North Vietnamese would interpret it as a clear sign of weakness - an indication that we wanted to stop fighting and come home.''
On March 20, 1968, Mr. Goldberg pressed his proposal at a meeting with Johnson and Presidential advisers. He did so at a time when there was much talk within the Administration of how to foster Vietnam peace talks. His suggestion was not acted on at the time, but 11 days later Johnson announced an unconditional and sweeping, but less than total, cutback in the bombing. Talks between the United States and North Vietnam ensued in Paris, and Johnson eventually stopped all bombing of the north.
 
Blind Horse and Wagon
The roles that Mr. Goldberg played in Presidential policy making and international affairs were remote from the world of his boyhood. Arthur Joseph Goldberg's was born Aug. 8, 1908, in Chicago, the youngest of eight children of Joseph and Rebecca Goldberg, both of whom were born in Russia. The elder Mr. Goldberg, a former peddler, owned a blind horse and a wagon and delivered produce to hotels.
After studying at Crane Junior College and De Paul University, Arthur Goldberg entered Northwestern University Law School, graduating at the head of its class of 1929 and earning a doctorate, summa cum laude, in 1930.
He went on to practice labor law in Chicago until 1948, with time out for war service from 1942 to 1944, serving with with the Office of Strategic Services and as an Army officer.
From 1948 to 1961, Mr. Goldberg was the Washington-based general counsel of the United Steelworkers and was active in negotiations toward settling major strikes in the steel industry.
He was also general counsel of the Congress of Industrial Organizations from 1948 to 1955 and in that capacity worked toward its merger with the American Federation of Labor, He was special counsel to the industrial union department of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. from 1955 until 1961.
Mr. Goldberg was married in 1931 to Dorothy Kurgans. She died in 1988.
He is survived by a daughter, Barbara Cramer of Chicago; a son, Robert, of Anchorage, and six grandchildren.
Funeral arrangements are incomplete, but Ralph DeStefano, director of Gawler's Funeral Home, said Mr. Goldberg would be buried in Arlington National Cemetery.

HEADLINE: Upheaval in the East: U.S. Policy;
A Worried Washington Is Keeping Its Distance

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18

 BODY:
Soviet experts in the Bush Administration were scrambling late today for information on the fighting in Baku between the Soviet Army and Azerbaijanis, which Administration experts said seemed the inevitable next step in the drama in the Caucasus.
''Gorbachev's show of force was not working,'' a senior Administration Soviet expert said. ''He had to go to another level of force to maintain order, but who knows if even this will be enough. In principle, we are still understanding of his need to restore order, but we don't know exactly what is going on down there yet.'' 
Since the start of the ethnic turmoil in the Caucasus between Armenians and Azerbaijanis, Bush Administration officials have regarded Mr. Gorbachev's situation with a mix of helplessness and deep concern.
Officials said their concern was born of a perception that Mr. Gorbachev looks like a man who has been adjusting the dials on his system only to have them all come off in his hands.
There is a growing feeling in the Administration that the Soviet leader may be approaching a point where he has so many things going wrong at once, or where he becomes so preoccupied with his own survival, that he will prefer to avoid tough decisions on the United States-Soviet agenda that might alienate constituencies or require heavy expenditures of political capital.
 
Virtually No Way to Help
The Administration's fatalism, officials explain, is rooted in several factors. The first is a keen awareness that there is virtually nothing the United States can do to help Mr. Gorbachev out of his present predicament, even if it wanted to. A second factor is an intelligence assessment that while Mr. Gorbachev's power base may be eroding, it remains substantial and there are no immediate rivals to his authority.
The third element is a conclusion that events in the Soviet Union are not likely to create any reversals in Soviet foreign policy and may actually encourage Moscow to make concessions on the central agenda of United States-Soviet relations - arms control.
''The general character of what is happening in the Soviet Union now was not unanticipated here,'' a senior Pentagon official said. ''The major purpose of the Malta summit was to send a signal, before what we expected would be rocky times, that we wanted to see Gorbachev succeed. It is true that some hard-liners have been reminding people that this guy's future is nothing to take out an insurance policy on. But that is just a statement of realism, not policy. The policy is still to take advantage of the opportunities he offers and insure against the downside.''
Administration officials say there is little that they can do to help Mr. Gorbachev, since what he needs most is a theory and practice of federalism that will allow him to loosen the reins of power enough for economic development to flourish while also not unleashing pent-up nationalist and ethnic tensions. Nevertheless, they are taking small steps on the margins to promote American interests and help buttress the Soviet leader.
 
Critical Months Under Way
Administration experts say Mr. Gorbachev's power base in the Politburo and the Supreme Soviet remains solid. He remains relatively weak in the Communist Party Central Committee. Mr. Gorbachev, as Administration experts see it, is planning to use the Communist Party Congress in October to seek to rid the Central Committee of rivals. That makes what happens between now and October ''doubly important,'' said one analyst.
''We are not going to make concessions to get a Start treaty just to help him,'' said one senior State Department expert, referring to the Strategic Arms Reduction Talks, ''but if we are able to work out a mutually advantageous treaty in time for this summer's summit with Bush, then it's obviously going to help Gorbachev.''
''A more stable international environment and a more positive U.S.-Soviet relationship can offset some of his domestic woes,'' the official said, adding that Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d will go to Moscow for talks with Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze on Feb. 6 with his bags ''full of proposals.''
At the same time, the American Embassy in Moscow, which maintains regular contacts with officials from Latvia, Lithuania and Estonia, has let it be known that Washington would much prefer that they take up Mr. Gorbachev's recent offer of gradually negotiating a process of secession after the Supreme Soviet passes a law governing such actions instead of pressing for immediate independence.
 
'Why Put Him in a Corner?'
One senior official said: ''What we are trying to get across is the fact that since Gorbachev is moving in the direction that the Balts want, why turn it into a test of manhood? Why put him in a corner? He is letting the Balts go, but he needs an explanation and a process that will allow it to happen.''
Another reason for the Administration's relative aplomb about the situation is a feeling that even if Mr. Gorbachev were to be replaced tomorrow, his successor would probably have to pursue a very similar foreign policy.
''Something that is not going to change whether Gorbachev stays or goes is the basic weakness of the Soviet Union right now - the problems of its economy, military and Warsaw Pact allies,'' said the Pentagon official. ''The threat from any policy reversal is much more in domestic policy than in foreign policy.''
Officials said today that Bruce S. Gelb, the Director of the United States Information Agency, would become the first senior Bush aide to talk with the new Government in Rumania next week. He will also visit Czechoslovakia and East Germany.

HEADLINE: Upheval in the East;
State Dept. Team Finds Nations in Afghan Conflict Flexible on Future Rule

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEW DELHI, Jan. 19

 BODY:
A State Department delegation exploring ways to end the war in Afghanistan completed a weeklong visit to the region today, convinced that the nations involved in the conflict are more amenable to a compromise that would not leave one party or leader in a dominant position.
The delegation, led by Robert M. Kimmitt, Under Secretary of State for Political Affairs, exchanged views with Saudi, Pakistani and Indian leaders as well as Afghan guerrillas armed and supported by the United States.
A United States official said tonight that the American delegation was impressed by the Saudis' apparent willingness to play a larger role in the region. Saudi Arabia has been a substantial backer of the Afghan guerrillas, supplying not only arms but a range of support services and nonmilitary aid along the Pakistan-Afghanistan border. Its religious ties to the Islamic Afghan rebels are strong. 
The delegation's visit precedes a planned trip to Moscow next month by Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d, and another this week by Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar of the United Nations.
 
Moscow Is Less Concerned
Officials say that although the Soviet Union has stopped short of saying that President Najibullah will be replaced, Moscow appears to be less concerned about what individual ultimately leads a government in Kabul.
Early last year, as the Soviet Union finished the pullout of its troops from Afghanistan after a 10-year stay, American officials predicted that the Najibullah Government would crumble within a few months. But nearly a year later, the American-backed guerrillas seem no closer to military victory.
Mr. Kimmitt said in Islamabad on Thursday that warmer relations between Moscow and Washington had raised American hopes that the Soviet leadership was prepared to reopen negotiations on the future of Afghanistan.
A year ago, the Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, came to Pakistan but failed to win concessions from the guerrillas. He also could not dissuade Pakistan from continuing support for the rebels and rejecting plans for a compromise that would have incorporated Kabul's current leaders in a new government.
This week, the Americans met Pakistan's Prime Minister, Benazir Bhutto, as well as President Ghulam Ishaq Khan and the Army Chief, Mirza Aslam Beg. In India, Mr. Kimmitt met Prime Minister V. P. Singh, who took office in December, and spent several hours with foreign policymakers including I. K. Gujral, the Foreign Minister, and S. K. Singh, permanent head of the Ministry of External Affairs.
 
Discussions on Relations
Indian and American officials also discussed general ways to strengthen relations between the two nations. An Indian Government spokesman said they touched on specific issues like technology transfers, the spread of missiles, the threat of trade sanctions against India because of its limited access to outside participation in certain economic sectors, and the problems of militancy in Kashmir and Punjab.
The Americans found the new Indian Government willing to acknowledge that Pakistan was not the cause of New Delhi's separatist problems, although some Pakistani politicians may be capitalizing on the issue in public statements. Some Indian politicians and the press routinely blame Islamabad for the unrest.
The American team included Michael E. Malinowski, former United States Consul in Peshawar, Pakistan; A. Peter Burleigh, Deputy Assistant Secretary of State for Intelligence and Research, and William J. Burns, deputy director of the State Department's policy planning staff. The group briefed Indian officials at length today on Washington's position.
There are hopes in Washington that India, which has been a strong backer of the Soviet-installed Kabul Government, may be persuaded to relax its inflexible position and act as intermediary in Afghanistan, particularly if Moscow moves toward a political solution.
 
U.S. Ability Overestimated
The official implied that the United States, the Soviet Union and Pakistan have all more or less abandoned the backing of individual candidates for leadership in Kabul.
The offical added that many people had in any case overestimated the ability of the United States to pick and choose among guerrilla groups.
The official said Gulbudin Hekmatyar, who had until recently been getting a major share of American arms, has more or less isolated himself from the rest of the Pakistan-based guerrilla organizations through his persistent disagreements with the rebel alliance's leadership.
On the other side, Moscow is also apparently prepared to withdraw support for the Afghan President, Maj. Gen. Najibullah, if he were to stand in the way of the establishment of a nonaligned Government that did not threaten Soviet interests and allowed the Soviet Union to cut back its costs in Kabul. $300 Million a Month for Moscow Moscow is reported to be spending about $300 million a month, or up to $3.7 billion a year, on military and other aid to the Najibullah Government. Although the United States does not disclose the cost of its support for the Afghan guerrillas, the total annual figure is thought to be about $600 million.
Diplomats in the region believe that the Soviet Union cannot afford to spend sums like these indefinitely if it intends to revamp its economy.
Moscow is also preoccuppied with ethnic unrest within its own borders. But American officials do not appear to believe that the Islamic factor in the civil conflict in Azerbaijan is linked in Soviet thinking to the Muslim rebels in Afghanistan.
Uncertainty still clouds the position of the Iranians, who can intensify Moscow's problems in Azerbaijan and whose intentions in Afghanistan are a concern to not only the Soviet Union but also Saudi Arabia, a rival for leadership of the Islamic world, and the United States.
About 2 million Afghan exiles live in Iran, and their leaders have been unable to form an alliance with the Pakistani-based rebels.

HEADLINE: Upheaval in the East: Reporter's Notebook;
Beret Meets Gold Braid: Generals Out of the Cold

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: VIENNA, Jan. 18

 BODY:
It had neither the drama of the crumbling of the Berlin wall nor the setting of the maritime summit meeting in Malta. But the cloakroom in the Hofburg Palace this week may well merit a place among images that chart the waning of the cold war.
While the generals, admirals and air marshals who run NATO and the Warsaw Pact discussed military affairs in a nearby hall, their hats, heavy in gold braid and authority, were piled on top of each other in what only months ago would have seemed indecent intimacy.
Along with tall French kepis, there were berets in green, blue and black, caps in khaki, white and blue, forage caps of the foldable variety and round-topped Alpine hats with cheerful feathers. Scattered among them were the wide-brimmed caps of senior Soviet officers. 
When the military brass of East and West emerged twice a day from their closed-door sessions, men trained to view each other as enemies jostled and joked as they searched for the hats and heavy coats that would proclaim their rank and protect them from the cold outside.
 
Historic Elbow-Rubbing
The meeting, everyone agreed, was unusual. The United States called it ''an unprecedented gathering.'' Britain said it was ''a remarkable and historic seminar.'' France described it as ''une grande premiere.'' A Soviet general even offered that it was a first ''in the history of mankind.''
The original idea was that the chiefs of staff of 35 NATO, Warsaw Pact and neutral countries - all of Europe plus the United States and Canada - would debate military doctrine. Predictably, in their statements, all said that their armed forces were equipped, trained and structured entirely for defensive purposes.
But the political transformation of Eastern Europe turned the meeting into the stuff of hyperbole. This first gathering of military leaders of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and Warsaw Pact came as both sides are scrambling to rethink defense premises that have served them well for more than 40 years.
Apart from the meeting itself, which will last another two weeks, the informal conversations over coffee, lunch and dinner are also giving senior officers from East and West the chance to get to know each other, which some delegates consider the most useful part of this exercise in confidence-building.
Competition still exists, though, if only for the credit of proposing the meeting. Gen. Mikhail A. Moiseyev, Chief of the Soviet General Staff, said the seminar was an ''important and timely initiative'' of the Warsaw Pact. NATO members insisted they suggested it last March. On this, the two sides agreed to disagree.
 
Fewer Echoes of Moscow
The setting for the seminar is appropriately historic. In 1815, the rambling Hofburg Palace was the site of the Congress of Vienna, in which the map of Europe was redrawn after Naopoleon's defeat and Austria became the ruler of an empire that included Germans, Hungarians, Italians and Slavs.
Today, East and West insist that while their objective is to end the division of Europe, the borders defined after World War II will not be altered. Yet the changing ideological map of Europe was more than apparent here this week as non-Soviet Warsaw Pact members spoke in voices that no longer echoed Moscow.
If negotiations under way here on the reduction of conventional forces in Europe are completed on schedule, the Hofburg Palace may be the site of a still more important meeting this year. Washington is thinking of a summit meeting of the 16 NATO and the 7 Warsaw Pact nations. Moscow has called for a 35-nation summit conference that would also include the rest of Europe.
 
Sophisticated Neutralists
Among the countries sending observers to the current seminar on military doctrine are lesser powers like Liechtenstein, San Marino and the Vatican. But the meeting has also served as a reminder that many neutral and non-aligned countries have highly sophisticated defense strategies of their own.
These countries - Austria, Sweden, Finland and Switzerland among them - may seem Western enough when it comes to their market economies and democratic systems. But they sit on the fence between NATO and the Warsaw Pact, and they say they are willing to fight for their right to remain there.
Noting that Sweden has 800,000 trained reservists, 10 percent of its population, the Supreme Commander of the Armed Forces, Gen. Bengt Gustafsson, said that his country's goals were to dissuade any would-be aggressor and to defend its neutrality in case of war in its vicinity.
Austria said it would defend its neutrality by mobilizing its forces to deny any foreign power the use of its territory or airspace, while Finland's military chief, Vice Adm. Jan Klenberg, said simply that ''all parts of Finland will be defended.''
Even tiny Malta, the site of the meeting between President Bush and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, sought to emphasize its neutrality. It welcomed moves toward greater disarmament, but said the interests of NATO and the Warsaw Pact should not ''push aside or overshadow completely the concern of states that are outside these alliances.''

HEADLINE: For Mayor Barry, Hope and Promise Crumble Under Weight of Charges

BYLINE: By B. DRUMMOND AYRES Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19

 BODY:
There was a time when Marion S. Barry Jr. was a symbol of hope, living proof that the great American dream could come true, that the son of a black Mississippi sharecropper could rise to the top of the heap, could go beyond chopping cotton and waiting tables and delivering papers to being Mayor of the capital city of the United States.
But that was before the rumors started about drugs and infidelity and corruption. That was before the police undercover operation Thursday night at the Vista International Hotel. That was before the Mayor of that capital city was arrested, like any other common suspect, on charges that he had bought and smoked crack supplied by undercover agents who were waiting for him in Room 727.
Mr. Barry remains innocent until proved guilty, and not just of the drug charge but of all other allegations and rumors. 
Still, no single finding of innocence is ever likely to restore the sheen of hope and promise that he gave off a dozen years ago when he first moved into the executive plushness of the Mayor's office on the fifth floor of City Hall, a one-time black militant who had challenged the system, changed it and made it work for him and his people.
 
Too Many Questions Remain
Any finding of innocence would leave too many other questions still hanging, where they have been hanging for years, not just months or weeks.
There are questions about Mr. Barry's nocturnal visits to bars and clubs at a time when the city is all but sinking under the weight of problems with drugs, crime, housing, health and finance; questions about his real estate dealings and the businessmen involved in them; questions about his friendship with convicted drug dealers. There are questions about unexplained hospitalizations, questions about close aides who have gone to prison on various charges of governmental corruption, questions and more questions that he has repeatedly been asked to answer but thus far has not, at least not well enough to keep them from being asked still again.
The day that Mr. Barry became Mayor was a day of triumph for black Americans, especially those who saw political power as the ultimate civil rights goal, and he had hardly been sworn in before he was being mentioned as a possible Vice Presidential candidate at some point, or perhaps a Senator should the District of Columbia become a state.
Today was, in the view of many long-time Barry supporters, as well as many of his critics, a day of genuine tragedy, perhaps even the end, of a public career that had been on the skids for some time.
''This is a very trying time for those of us who have worked for and supported Marion Barry,'' said Jeffrey N. Gildenhorn, a leading Washington businessman who is one of the Mayor's main advisers and fund-raisers. ''When you have put your trust in someone and something this serious comes along, it's just shattering, a tragedy of just the worst sort. It pains to see the city and its people hurt, the Mayor hurt, his family hurt.''
Mr. Barry, 53 years old, arrived in Washington in early 1965, a scarred veteran of the civil rights movement in the Deep South. There he had helped found the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee, the organization that supplied the movement with youthful shock troops for registering black voters.
He had emerged from a life of poverty that took him from his birth in Itta Bena, Miss., to Memphis, where his widowed mother worked as a domestic. Through pluck and hard work, he become a good student, an Eagle Scout and a graduate of Le Moyne College in Memphis. Later, he earned a master's degree in chemistry from Fisk University in Nashville. It was in his college years that Mr. Barry began to take part in the civil rights movement.
Gregarious, ebullient, impatient, driven by the memory of what it was like to be poor, he immediately struck both friends and foes as a man with a mission.
''He was totally political, totally committed to empowering the people, to getting people elected, not just getting them equality at the lunch counter,'' said Lawrence T. Guyot, a veteran of S.N.C.C. who now lives in Washington, serving as a neighborhood adviser for City Hall.
Mr. Barry, a Democrat in a city of 630,000 people who are mostly black, mostly Democratic, put the political and organizing skills he had honed in the Deep South to good use in Washington. He formed a group to push for home rule for the District of Columbia, set up a job training program for unemployed young people, worked to improve the black community's relations with the police. Then, in 1971, he ran for a seat on the city school board, and won easily.
He remained on the school board for three years, serving as its president at one point. In 1974 he won an at-large seat on the City Council, and in 1976 won re-election with a lopsided 78 percent of the vote.
 
Opposed by Black Establishment
That margin helped convince him that he could be elected Mayor, and in 1978 he announced his intention to run for that job. The city's heavily black political establishment was largely against him in the primary, but that all but insured that he would get a hefty white vote and he won the nomination. That victory, in turn, was tantamount to victory in the general election, since the city has so few Republicans.
No sooner was he in City Hall than Mr. Barry began to solidify his support among the city's blacks, steering housing projects, job programs and other governmental benefits in their direction. At the same time, he began adding to the city's work force, courting labor organizations and senior citizens and saw to it, through zoning and development decisions, that the big money in the city's business community stayed with him.
The result of these moves was the formulation of a solid political core that gained Mr. Barry easy re-election to a second, and then a third, term. People began to refer to him as ''Mayor for Life.''
But despite all this, trouble was building for Mr. Barry, much of it of his own making.
The Mayor, never one to sit behind a desk and ponder programs when there might be hands to shake or backs to clap out on the street, began to spend more and more time cruising about the city in his blue limousine.
''In one sense,'' said his old S.N.C.C. friend, Mr. Guyot, ''Marion is a lot like Lyndon Johnson. He needs to be pressing the flesh all the time, to have constant approval, to be out among the people.''
 
Nightclub Visit, Then Rumors
One night in the early 1980's, the Mayor dropped by a nightclub. The next day there were rumors that he used some drugs while there, an allegation he immediately denied.
That was but the first of a series of drug allegations that began to whittle away at the Mayor's credibility and also led to at least two inconclusive grand jury investigations.
In late 1988 Mr. Barry was involved in an incident at a Washington hotel in which a drug raid on one of the hotel's rooms was called off by police when they learned at the last moment that the Mayor was in the room with the suspect, Charles Lewis, an old Barry friend. Mr. Barry said he had known nothing of any raid in advance, and was only paying a social visit on an longtime acquaintance.
Subsequently the police charged Mr. Lewis with selling drugs in the hotel to people other than the Mayor. At his trial, Mr. Lewis said he had also sold cocaine to Mr. Barry.
The Mayor's strong denials wilted in the face of continuing rumors and accusations. His city, the national capital, was caught up in perhaps the worst drug epidemic in the country, and at times it sounded as if he was part of the problem.
But Mr. Barry was determined. He talked more and more of running for a fourth four-year term. He not only talked about running, he said he would formally announce his campaign this Sunday.
Now, after what happened Thursday night in room 727, that is all on hold.
But whether he runs or does not run is not the ultimate issue, says John Wilson, a member of the City Council who also worked with Mr. Barry back in the days of the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee.
''You've got to remember what they used to say about those of us who worked in the field for 'S.N.C.C.,' '' Mr. Wilson said. ''It was the kind of work that took a special thirst for life, a yen to live fully, to experience. They said we'd never be able to govern as well as we fought.''

HEADLINE: Beyond the Kill in Arthur Kill

 BODY:
Disaster is a timely teacher. The oil spill that has raised havoc at the nature sanctuary around Pralls Island in the Arthur Kill presents a costly lesson in ways to prevent and deal with such destruction. Beyond that it carries a lesson about ways to deal with nature - and the ways nature deals with itself. 
New Yorkers, disheartened by the bungling and the oil-soaked bird carcasses, were also surprised to discover, in the middle of a huge industrial complex, a wildlife preserve where egrets and herons and ibises had been living and breeding as comfortably as they would in a mangrove swamp or an isolated barrier beach.
Mostly, this has been nature's doing. Years ago, when some disruptive dredging stopped and environmental laws started to have effect, the Pralls Island area began to restore itself. Marsh grass grew, sponging up toxic waste from the polluted water and, though often dying in the process, always renewing itself. Wild cherry and other weedy trees sprouted and by the 1970's when the branches were big enough, herons and egrets began to build nests in them, finding plenty of food for their young in the surrounding mud flats and marshes.
Nature had, in effect, already created its own wildlife sanctuary. Then, in the 1980's, the New York City Parks Department came in to acquire and protect the island and it has gone on since, with the New York City Audubon Society and the Trust for Public Land, to make the whole area an official preserve.
Wildlife, as a matter of fact, makes itself at home almost anywhere in the city. Central Park is the major stopping place for migrating birds. Jamaica Bay harbors wild fowl by the thousands and hawks build nests on skyscraper ledges.
To encourage this, environmentalists have been concentrating on saving bits and pieces of city land from development and turning them into urban preserves. There are potential Pralls Islands jammed into unlikely spots all around the city - a small peninsula in the Rockaways, a pristine marsh right off Flatbush Avenue, a fresh water creek at the edge of a huge housing development. Saving them requires money and stubborn attention but nature can do much of the rest.
The oil spill is a heavy setback for nature's careful rebuilding at Pralls Island. But whether recovery takes months or years, the lesson is plain: Give me a fair chance, nature keeps telling us, and then get out of my way. It's worth listening to her.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: Builders of Eurotunnel Have Had No Incentive to Control Costs

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your report on the progress and pitfalls of the English Channel tunnel (news article, Dec. 18) misses the mark on an important issue.
The 10 British and French contractors that bid for and were awarded the construction contract were motivated primarily by their desire to design and build the tunnel. Eurotunnel was then set up as a separate company that would own and operate this major transportation facility. The tunnel would be financed by raising equity (1 billion so far) and commitments from banks in the form of loans (5 billion). 
This sequence of events has resulted in an immense problem. The tunnel is behind schedule and substantially over budget. Close to 2 billion has been spent on a project that is estimated to cost 7 billion to 11.2 billion. The problem has been that the builders have had little incentive to control costs. The future owner-operator had no opportunity to enforce competition between contractors at the bidding stage. The cost overruns on materials and construction are now subject to negotiations between parties who have to split the burden or consider having to back out of the project entirely.
Consider an alternative course. A true owner-entrepreneur is chosen among competing bidders interested in the tunnel project. After examining the project's economic and financial feasibility, he decides on the most efficient design from a list of options and solicits competitive bids for the contracts. As owner and operator, he would have strong economic incentives to keep costs down and complete the project on or ahead of schedule.
Choosing owner-operators as the starting point is similar to the situation in Virginia, where the state turned to the private sector to build, own and operate the first private toll road in the United States since the late 1800's (news article, Nov. 20). The state found itself an entrepreneur in Ralph Stanley, former head of the Urban Mass Transportation Administration.
The lessons should not be lost on Californians, who are proposing that private entities design, build and operate toll facilities such as bridges, tunnels, roads and rail all over the state. Although the state would own the facilities, the private operator would have the right to charge tolls for their use. The traveling public is then given a choice between free routes that are congested and uncongested (or at least less congested) toll routes. Among the projects considered is another bridge crossing San Francisco Bay.
 
YUVAL COHEN
 Ossining, Jan. 2, 1990
 
The writer is an economist with a consulting firm in New York City.

HEADLINE: Bush Warns Senate on Changes to Clean Air Bill

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHABECOFF, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19

 BODY:
President Bush wrote to leaders of the Senate today warning that he would oppose amendments to strengthen the Clean Air Act if the costs to the economy exceeded ''the already considerable costs'' of the legislation he proposed last year.
Administration officials estimate that the legislation the Senate plans to take up Tuesday would cost industry and consumers $40 billion a year by the year 2000. The President's bill, they said, would achieve almost the same reduction in airborne pollutants at a cost of $19 billion a year.
The President's letter raises the level of an argument that has erupted among policy makers and lobbyists here over the costs and benefits of cracking down on air pollution. Changes in the Clean Air Act are expected to be among the most important and contentious issues Congress will handle this year. 
The Senate bill would require major new programs to curb urban smog, acid rain and toxic air pollution as well as programs that would begin to address the global warming problem. The President's bill would have similar programs, but would not go quite as far as the Senate proposals, whose costs would rise each year as increasingly stringent pollution limits go into effect.
Late this week, White House and Environmental Protection Agency officials circulated estimates that put the cost of the Senate bill at $40 billion a year by the year 2000.
 
'Minimum Tests of Balance'
Mr. Bush said in his letter that the only bill he would accept is one that meets ''minimum tests of balance and reasonableness.'' Among those tests, he wrote, were that the bill maintain the same environmental protection and cost levels of his Administration's bill; that it have controls to lower pollution ''for the least cost per ton of reduced pollutant,'' and that it avoid new taxes.
''The bill,'' the President said, ''should not impose aggregate costs on the economy that exceed the already considerable costs embodied in the Administration's bill.''
But the President's letter did not mention a possible veto of any legislation that did not meet all his standards. Congressional staff aides said today that they doubted that Mr. Bush would veto a clean air bill this year in the face of what is widely perceived as strong public support for such legislation.
Senate aides who drafted the legislation said the Administration estimate of $40 billion miscalculated the cost of new controls. Among other things, they said, the figures overestimated the costs of lowering car pollution.
Public health and environmental groups, meanwhile, contend that reducing air pollution will save the country far more money than it will cost to achieve such reductions.
 
Benefits to Health, Some Argue
A report today by the American Lung Association concludes that the benefits of improved public health would significantly outweigh the costs.
The lung association report was based on a survey of dozens of studies of medical expenses, lost days of employment and premature deaths attributed to exposure to polluted air. It said these costs amounted to tens of billions of dollars a year.
James S. Cannon, the author of the lung association's report, said a range of $40 billion to $50 billion a year for medical costs from all forms of air pollution seemed most reasonable, although one survey cited in the report found that pollution from automobiles alone resulted in health costs to the nation of nearly $100 billion a year.
On Thursday the Business Roundtable issued a report on the legislation coming before the Senate, saying the costs could be as much as $104 billion a year and that the best estimate of the costs of legislation pending before Congress is $54 billion.
The roundtable, an association of executives of big corporations who seek to influence policy making, warned that the higher costs estimated for the Senate bill ''could result in a shutdown or significantly reduced production in United States industries whose total revenues exceed $100 billion annually.''

HEADLINE: Tomisaburo Hashimoto Dies at 88

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: TOKYO, Jan. 19

 BODY:
Tomisaburo Hashimoto, a powerful official who was convicted in the bribery scandal that swept the Government in the mid-1970's, died of pneumonia today, a hospital official said. He was 88 years old. 
Mr. Hashimoto served in such posts as secretary general of the governing Liberal Democratic Party, Construction Minister and Transport Minister.
In 1976, while Transport Minister, he was arrested on charges of accepting $34,000 for promoting sales of Lockheed aircraft to a Japanese airline.
 
Appealed to Supreme Court
The Tokyo District Court later sentenced him to a two-and-a-half-year jail term. Mr. Hashimoto, who denied the bribery charges, took his case to the Supreme Court, but the court had not issued a ruling by the time of his death.
The Lockheed scandal broke in 1976 when the American aircraft maker acknowledged that it had bribed Japanese officials to influence their decisions on purchases. The scandal caused a split in the Liberal Democrats that took several years to repair.
Mr. Hashimoto, a native of Ibaraki prefecture, northeast of Tokyo, joined Asahi Shimbun, a major Japanese newspaper, in 1927 after graduating from the department of politics and economics at Waseda University.
 
Many Years in Parliament
He quit the newspaper company after World War II and won his first election to the lower house of Parliament in 1949. He returned to Parliament 12 times before losing in general elections in 1980.
He served in the Cabinets of Prime Ministers Hayato Ikeda, Eisaku Sato and Kakuei Tanaka. Mr. Tanaka, who was also implicated in the Lockheed scandal, is still appealing his case to the Supreme Court.

HEADLINE: Bank Sees $1.2 Billion In Losses

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
The Bank of New England Corporation said yesterday that its real estate losses were far greater than had been expected and that it would report a deficit of $1.2 billion for the fourth quarter.
In an effort to survive without Government assistance, the banking company, the second largest in New England after the Bank of Boston and 18th biggest in the country, disclosed details of a plan to sell more than a fifth of its assets, about $6 billion worth. It is also seeking buyers for its loss-ridden banking units. Analysts said the independence of the company might depend on its ability to continue to borrow money from institutions and hold on to its consumer deposits. 
''A Federal takeover is entirely possible,'' said Virginia Adair, a banking analyst at Drexel Burnham Lambert. ''And the problem with trying to sell the banks is that nobody wants to buy them without assistance from the regulators.''
 
'Final Nail in the Coffin'
 Gerard S. Cassidy, first vice president at Tucker Anthony Inc., a securities firm, said, ''The final nail in the coffin of most troubled banks is a funding crisis.'' To hold consumer deposits, he said that the Bank of New England was offering interest rates as much as a percentage point higher than neighboring banks in some markets.
In addition to the fourth-quarter loss, the Bank of New England, which is based in Boston, said it would have a $1.05 billion loss for all of 1989. Those losses will reduce the company's shareholders' capital to less than $500 million.
The remaining capital is far below the standard of 3 percent of assets set by Federal regulators for banks. It is a precariously small cushion to absorb any additional losses on the company's $29 billion of loans and other assets.
 
Deposits Are Insured
 But so far, banking regulators who asked not to be identified said there were no immediate plans to close or take over the bank. The banking company is regulated by the Comptroller of the Currency and the Federal Reserve, and its deposits are insured by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation. The Comptroller's office and the Federal Reserve have each had 50 or more examiners at various offices of the Bank of New England in recent weeks, studying thousands of loan documents to decide how bad the losses are.
One result of those examinations has been the expanding estimates of the company's losses that have stunned Wall Street analysts. Nonperforming loans, or loans on which interest is at least 90 days past due, are now estimated at $2.25 billion, up from $1.6 billion in mid-December and $900 million on Sept. 30, 1989.
Losses at the company have resulted mostly from lending for real estate projects. A glut of construction in New England in the last few years, combined with a slowing of the region's economic growth, has caused real estate prices to fall.
While bank regulators have not moved to close or take over the Bank of New England, they are working out details of an agreement that would require the company to raise more capital and improve its management. A few weeks ago, the Bank of New England announced that its chief executive, Walter J. Connolly Jr., had agreed to step aside when a successor was found.
 
Not Borrowing From the Fed
 According to data published by the Federal Reserve, there has not been a sharp increase in loans by Federal Reserve Banks to troubled financial institutions. The Fed loans to troubled institutions averaged only $22 million in the week ended Jan. 17, suggesting that the Bank of New England has not had to turn to the Fed for assistance.
''The fact that they are allowing the company to sell $6 billion of assets suggests that the Federal regulators are prepared to give the company time to come back to health,'' Ms. Merenyi said. If the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation had decided that the company's financial condition was hopeless, she said, it would want the $6 billion of assets to remain at the company, so that the Government agency would be less vulnerable to losses.
Bank of New England stock fell $1.50 yesterday, to $2.75 a share, on the New York Stock Exchange, down sharply from its high in the last year of $24.875. Early this week the stock was trading above $7 a share, but its price fell rapidly on reports that losses were rising and that Federal regulators had intervened to prevent the Fleet/Norstar Corporation from buying a large part of Bank of New England. Officials at Bank of New England and Fleet/Norstar declined to comment yesterday on any aspect of talks between the two concerns.
The Bank of New England said Lazard Freres & Company ''is actively pursuing written indications of interest'' concerning mergers and sales of various banking subsidiaries. The company has subsidiary banks in Massachusetts, Connecticut, New Hampshire, Maine and Rhode Island. As the company's problems mounted, it announced plans last year to sell 53 branches and cut 800 jobs.
The financial plan described yesterday also calls for the sale of $1 billion of leases, $450 million of which have already been committed to GE Capital, a financial unit of General Electric, for an undisclosed amount. Another $670 million of credit-card loans are to be sold, at a price that analysts estimated would be about 20 percent higher than the outstanding loans. The company also plans to sell 95 percent of its home-equity loans, or $1.3 billion, and $3 billion of various kinds of commercial loans. It also plans to sell $500 million of its $1.8 billion of residential mortgages, and $125 million of car loans.

HEADLINE: Bush Urges A Mortgage Rate Drop

BYLINE: By THOMAS C. HAYES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ATLANTA, Jan. 19

 BODY:
In an address to the nation's home builders, President Bush today hailed the broad decline in home mortgage rates in the 1980's and suggested that rates should be lowered further.
Although the President's message drew loud applause from members of the National Association of Home Builders, many developers expressed concern about savings industry regulations approved by the Administration and Congress last year. Those rules threaten the vitality of the home building industry, and in turn the nation's economy, they said.
In comments to reporters, Shirley McVey Wiseman, president of the home builders' association, called on the President and Congress to alter a new rule quickly that bars a savings institution from lending more than 15 percent of its capital to a single borrower. 
 
Small Builders Scale Back
 That rule and related restrictions have caused many small builders to scale back operations because they lack enough financing to continue projects under development and to begin new ones.
In his speech, which opened the home builders' convention at the Omni Coliseum, Mr. Bush linked the call for lower interest rates on loans to his campaign for a reduction in the tax on capital gains, which he has set as a priority for the 1990 Congressional session, just as he did last year without success.
''A capital gains tax cut will help every American who holds a job or owns a home,'' Mr. Bush said. ''Also vital to home buyer and home builder alike are low and stable rates of interest.''
Mr. Bush, whose Administration has carefully avoided the kind of criticism of Federal Reserve policy that has been typical of other Administrations when the economy slowed, did not mention the Federal Reserve in today's speech.
On Thursday, the White House spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, said he hoped Fed policy makers would reassess the economy's peformance and conclude ''that lower interest rates are justified.''
The President echoed that theme in his speech to the home builders.
''A 1 percent increase in the interest rate knocks millions of families out of the market,'' he said. ''In the last few years, millions of families could afford a new home because mortgage interest rates have dropped from 18 percent in the early 1980's to less than 10 percent today.''
''And I want to see them come down even more,'' he declared to loud applause from the audience.
Builders attending the convention indicated that the impact of lending cutbacks at savings institutions, largely the result of new rules imposed on the industry, varied widely by region. In California, they indicated, construction financing is abundant from many sources, but builders in the Southwest said lenders had largely shut off loans for real estate development.
Despite the tightening spigot for loans to developers, builders and economists said financing for home buyers remained plentiful. Indeed, many savings institutions have re-emphasized mortgage lending on single-family homes.
The Commerce Department reported Thursday that new home construction declined in 1989 by 8 percent, to 1.37 million units, including single-family homes and apartments, the lowest level since 1982. David Seiders, chief economist of the builders' association, said the total was likely to rise slightly this year, to about 1.45 million units.
But with interest rates rising, making buyers' financing costs more expensive, Ms. Wiseman asserted that the added burden of inadequate capital for construction would ''plunge'' the housing industry into a recession if the lending limit for savings institutions was not raised.
 
Effect of Tighter Restrictions
 Some economists who spoke before the convention said the tougher lending restrictions would eventually force many small builders out of business because savings institutions were their main source of capital for acquiring land and developing homes.
Before the change, which was ordered to force more conservative lending practices at savings institutions, executives in the savings industry were permitted to lend up to 100 percent of capital to any borrower.
Most of the nation's home builders construct fewer than 10 homes a year. The industry, once a leading indicator of the economy's health, marched more in step with the overall economy after adjustable-rate mortgages became widely used in the early 1980's.
Its activity level remains an important part of the economy. For every 100,000 new homes under construction, the industry generates $280 billion, including $38 billion in wages, $1.6 billion in taxes and 1.6 million jobs.
Mr. Bush's speech to the convention was largely upbeat, saying the home building industry would benefit from his economic policies, including a capital gains tax cut.
''The truth is,'' he said, ''there's one housing policy, and one sales strategy, that's better than all others combined - a healthy growing economy with low long-term interest rates.''
