HEADLINE: Trustee at Work in Stores' Case

BYLINE: By ISADORE BARMASH

 BODY:
Creditors' committees are expected to be named next week in the Chapter 11 bankruptcy proceedings of Federated Stores Inc. after a scrutiny of all claims, said Conrad Morganstern, the United States Trustee who is overseeing the case and will designate the committee members.
The formation of the committees from among the 20 to 30 largest of the company's 50,000 creditors is an important step in the bankruptcy process, since all matters proposed under the bankruptcy are subject to the approval of such committees and the bankruptcy judge.
In a telephone interview from Cleveland, Mr. Morganstern said there would be at least two committees representing ''all the creditor constituencies.'' He said he was also considering forming a committee for non-trade creditors, which are mostly banks and investment bankers. 
 
Working Under Pressure
 Mr. Morganstern said his responsibilities in the bankruptcy were ''to supervise it and make sure it fits the laws,'' adding that his office had a huge amount of work to do before Judge J. Vincent Aug Jr., the Federal bankruptcy judge, opens the first hearing, which is scheduled for Thursday.
There were 67 Federated entities that filed for court protection under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code on Monday. The company has 260 stores, 100,000 employees and about 300,000 suppliers.
''We will have to determine the nature and amount of all claims,'' Mr. Morganstern said, ''and make sure there aren't duplications and wrong addresses.''
He said he would soon schedule a debtors' conference, in which there will be questioning of and testimony taken from the top executives of Federated Department Stores and Allied Stores, the two American retailers bought by the Campeau Corporation and now operated as Federated Stores Inc.
 
Looking for 'Brush Fires'
 ''We will find out what the financial conditions of the company are,'' Mr. Morganstern said, ''whether there are any brush fires or raging infernos that we must quickly put out.''
He said large creditors, government officials and the press would be allowed to attend the session, which will be held in Cincinnati, Federated's home base.
Campeau borrowed heavily to purchase Allied Stores in 1986 for $3.6 billion and then to buy Federated Department Stores for $6.6 billion in 1988. Together the retailers operate nine chains: Bloomingdale's, Abraham & Straus and Stern's, which are based in the New York area; Jordan Marsh, in New England; Burdines and Maas/Jordan Marsh, in Florida; Rich's/Goldsmith's in Atlanta; Lazarus, in Cincinnati, and the Bon Marche, in Seattle.
The heavy debt load eventually led to a cash crisis and the filing for voluntary bankruptcy last Monday. Just before the filing, the retailing operations, once known as Campeau Corporation (U.S.), were transferred by the parent Campeau Corporation to a group of trustees, yet to be named.
 
Sources of Money
 The two retailing groups told major suppliers yesterday that there would be sufficient money, from store operations and other sources, to support all store operations. In a letter to suppliers, James M. Zimmerman, president of the Federated and Allied units, said, ''The availability of funds is due to cash on hand, future cash from operations and our substantial working capital, and debtor-in-possession financing.''
Debtor in possession financing is made up of court-approved loans intended to provide money to keep a business operating during bankruptcy reorganization. Campeau had earlier said that it had arranged debtor-in-possession loans of $400 million from Citibank for Federated and $300 million from Chemical Bank for Allied.
Yesterday, company officials said that the Federated unit had a current cash balance of $220 million and does not anticipate drawing from the debtor financing until March. Allied, which has a beginning cash balance of $117 million, would also not need to draw on the financing until March.
The financing arrangements are, however, still awaiting approval from Judge Aug. Federated-Allied lawyers are expected to file the financing arrangements next week, the company said, and the court will then hold hearings.
 
Offering Reassurance
 Trying to reassure suppliers on shipments, Mr. Zimmerman said that any vendor who ships after the bankruptcy filing ''will automatically receive priority status for payments and will receive payments in full.''
''There is no further threat of being frozen, as there was before the bankruptcy petition was filed,'' he said. ''Given the fact that our companies will not be paying interest on most of our debt, this is the most rock-solid time and situation into which to ship.''
In Cincinnati, Carol Sanger, vice president for public relations at Federated Stores, said that both Liz Claiborne Inc. and Leslie Fay Inc., two major suppliers of apparel, had said they would resume shipping on normal terms. Executives of both companies could not be reached for comment.
But some division heads in the store operations said yesterday that they had only about 15 percent to 20 percent of January needs on hand. Many suppliers had canceled shipments when it became clear that the retail operations would be filing for bankruptcy.
 
Congressional Inquiry
 WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (AP) -The House Judiciary Committee will investigate the bankruptcy filings by the Campeau Corporation's American retail divisions and look into the consequences of leveraged buyouts, Representative Jack Brooks, the committee chairman, said today.
Mr. Brooks, Democrat of Texas, said the Subcommittee on Economic and Commercial Law would hold hearings on the court-supervised reorganization of Federated Stores Inc., the renamed holding company of the Campeau operations, and the potential for more bankruptcies resulting from the debt-financed takeovers of recent years.
''The gold rush is over now, and the time for reassessment has arrived,'' Mr. Brooks said. ''I intend to move quickly in the upcoming session of Congress to consider the lessons of the Campeau bankruptcy, and how LBO bankruptcies will affect consumers, suppliers, creditors and the American economy.''

CORRECTION-DATE: February 2, 1990, Friday, Late Edition - Final

 CORRECTION:
Four recent articles in Business Day about the bankruptcy filing of Federated Stores Inc. - one on Jan. 20, one on Jan. 23 and two on Tuesday - misidentified the United States trustee who is overseeing the proceedings. He is Conrad Morgenstern.

HEADLINE: Treasury Issues Post Best Gain of '90

BYLINE: By H. J. MAIDENBERG

 BODY:
Treasury bond prices yesterday posted their best gain of 1990 in a rally that began overnight in Tokyo and continued in the London and New York markets. Dealers said the recovery was sustained by domestic retail investors and professional traders who were covering short positions.
In late dealings in New York, the Treasury's benchmark long bonds, the 8 1/8 percent issue maturing in 2019, were offered at 98 14/32, up 20/ 32 on the day. This dropped the yield to 8.26 percent, from 8.33 percent on Thursday, but the yield remains substantially higher than the 8.17 percent of a week earlier. 
The rise in the price of the long bond came after the issue fell to an intraday low of 97 10/32 in Tokyo before rebounding there to close at 97 24/32. This attracted buyers in London, where the Treasury's long bond closed at 98.
''With yields at their best levels in many months, it was inevitable that retail buyers would materialize,'' said William V. Sullivan Jr., a senior vice president at Dean Witter Reynolds. ''What was perhaps a bit of a surprise was that the retail demand first surfaced in Tokyo and then in London before our market opened.''
Those waiting for lower interest rates may have to wait, Mr. Sullivan said, ''because the Fed cannot, and is unlikely to, show any public response to any political pressures to change its policy.''
President Bush again called on the Federal Reserve to lower interest rates yesterday, in a speech to the National Association of Home Builders in Atlanta. In recent days, White House spokesmen have linked current interest rates to signs of a weakening economy.
The Fed's only response yesterday was to drain reserves from the banking system through weekend matched sales. The key Federal funds rate, which banks charge each other for temporary loans, traded at 8 3/16 percent at the time and later declined to 8 1/8 percent. While the Fed's action was linked to technical factors, the decline in the funds rate reflected continued weak demand for credit.
Because of the heavy flow of individual and corporate tax payments early this week, the Treasury's deposits at the Federal Reserve swelled to nearly $7 billion on Wednesday from roughly $4 billion the day before. But Mr. Sullivan expects the Fed to recycle these deposits quickly into the banking system.
Interest continued to grow in the Treasury's auction on Tuesday of $5 billion of 40-year bonds for the Resolution Funding Corporation, known as Refco. The bonds, which are being sold to raise funds to pay debts of the many defunct savings and loan institutions, traded on a when-issued basis to yield 8.47 percent.
Although the Refco bonds would be the first Treasury offering of a straight 40-year issue since 1955, the maturity poses no problem, Mr. Sullivan noted, ''because the 'strippers' have already presold much of the issue.''
In stripping bonds, financial houses offer the bonds' coupons to investors seeking income and the principal to those seeking long-term price appreciation.
On Wednesday, the Treasury plans to auction $10 billion of new two-year notes, which traded to yield 8.14 percent on a when-issued basis. The outstanding 7 5/8 percent notes of 1991 rose 3/32, to 99 20/32, for a yield of 8.15 percent.
Among other representative Treasury issues, the 7 5/8 percent issue of 1993 climbed 8/32, or a quarter-point, to 98 7/32, and a yield of 8.16 percent; the 8 percent issue of 1997 soared 10/ 32, to 98 30/32, for a yield of 8.20 percent; the long notes, the 7 7/8's of 1999, advanced 15/32, to 97 21/32, for a yield of 8.22 percent, compared with 8.09 percent a week earlier.
At the short end of the Trasury market, the discount rate on the 90-day bills fell 6 basis points, to 7.73 percent; the six-month bills lost 4 basis points, at 7.60 percent, and the one-year bills fell 5 basis points, to 7.44 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
Dealers said they failed to see any significant flight to quality into Treasury bills following the heavy loss reported by the Bank of New England.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Copper Prices Fall Sharply On Fears of Slack Demand

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Copper futures prices fell sharply yesterday on New York's Commodity Exchange, reflecting fears of an economic slowdown, which would reduce demand for the metal.
Copper futures finished 1.7 cents to 3.05 cents lower, with the contract for delivery in January at $1.01 a pound. The more heavily traded March contract settled at 99.30 cents a pound. 
The selloff extended Thursday's more moderate decline and resulted from growing perceptions that copper demand is slackening after more than two years of strong consumption, analysts said.
''What really highlighted the fact that demand is likely to weaken is the recent stock market weakness,'' said James Steel, a metals analyst with the futures brokerage Refco Inc. ''With the U.S. stock market going down and the London and Japanese markets going down also, that's a clear indication that as we go into 1990, demand will be soft.''
Copper demand is closely tied to the nation's economic health, especially to the construction industry, which accounts for more than 40 percent of copper use.
 
Petroleum Contracts Gain
 Petroleum futures climbed sharply on the New York Mercantile Exchange, led by the February crude oil contract, which expires on Monday.
The buying of crude mainly resulted from concerns about a possible squeeze in supplies of crude for delivery against the February contract, analysts said.
Heating oil rallied and gasoline followed, as temperatures fell in the Northeast after several days of springlike conditions.
West Texas Intermediate crude oil settled 25 to 91 cents higher, with February at $23.67 a barrel; heating oil was 0.26 cent to 1.82 cents higher, with February at 63.66 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was 0.12 cent lower to 0.91 cent higher, with February at 61.62 cents a gallon.
Wheat and soybean futures fell on the Chicago Board of Trade, dropping sharply near the close, on selling linked to slack export demand and improved growing conditions for winter wheat and South American soybeans.
Wheat futures sank to their lowest levels in almost four months, extending a decline that began Thursday when large amounts of snow and rain began falling on wheat fields from the Texas panhandle to southern Kansas.
But yesterday's pattern of steep losses only in the March and May wheat contracts indicated the selling was inspired more by slack export demand than by the weather.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Moves Downward; Gold Prices Finish Lower

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The American dollar was mostly lower against other leading currencies yesterday in trading dominated by the Canadian dollar. Gold prices declined.
Analysts reported quiet trading in the United States dollar. Ronald Holzer, chief dealer with Harris Trust and Company in Chicago, said the foreign exchange markets focused on the Canadian dollar, which had fallen through the week in response to a decision by the Bank of Canada to ease monetary policy and allow interest rates to decline. 
At the close of trading in New York, the American dollar was worth 1.1836 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1713 late Thursday and 1.1573 a week earlier. In European trading, the United States dollar closed at 1.1786 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1713 late Thursday.
 
Falling Canadian Rates Cited
 ''Interest rates in Canada are starting to ease, while rates in the rest of the world are continuing to move up,'' said Ken Foxcroft, senior vice president at the Toronto-Dominion Bank. ''So a lot of the attraction of investing in Canada is disappearing.''
Analysts attributed some of the American dollar's declines to profit taking before the weekend.
The dollar fell against the British pound. In London, a British pound cost $1.6475 late yesterday, more expensive for buyers than Thursday's late $1.6445. In later New York trading, a pound cost $1.6470, compared with $1.6435 late Thursday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Thursday's rates, included: 1.7105 West German marks, down from 1.7150; 1.5205 Swiss francs, down from 1.5245; 5.8130 French francs, down from 5.8275, and 1,274.12 Italian lire, down from 1,276.25.
 
Late Dollar Rates in Europe
 Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with Thursday's prices, included: 1.5140 Swiss francs, down from 1.5185; 5.6955 French francs, down from 5.8090; 1.9310 Dutch guilders, up from 1.9130; 1,269.25 lire, down from 1,272, and 1.1786 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1713.
In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 146.33 Japanese yen, up from 145.66 yen. In late London trading, the dollar closed at 145.60 yen. In New York, the dollar fell to 145.93 yen, from 146.35 yen late Thursday.
In New York, gold fell 20 cents, to $410 an ounce, on the Commodity Exchange. The Republic National Bank of New York later quoted a bid of $410, down 80 cents from late Thursday.

HEADLINE: U.S. Officials Suspect Israelis Sent Ethiopia Cluster Bombs

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20

 BODY:
Administration officials said today they strongly suspected that Israel has sent cluster bombs to Ethiopia. They said there were unconfirmed reports that the Soviet-backed Marxist Government in Addis Ababa has already used the weapons against rebels in the northern part of the country.
The officials, who are from the State and Defense Departments, did not say when Israel might have sent the weapons, how many were involved or whether the bombs were American-made or Israeli-made.
''People have described attacks and the consequences of attacks that sound like cluster bombs have been used on more than one occasion,'' an Administration official said, adding that no physical evidence had been recovered. Nor were any casualty figures available. 
Since Ethiopia restored diplomatic relations with Israel in October after a break of 16 years, the United States has repeatedly expressed concern to Israel over that country's intentions to send military hardware to Ethiopia, American and Israeli officials said. Israel is thought to be eager to establish a strong relationship with the Ethiopian Government because it wants its cooperation in allowing remaining Ethiopian Jews to emigrate to Israel.
 
A Variety of Allegations
Several weeks ago, after what Administration officials called ''allegations from different sources'' that cluster bombs or a similarly destructive weapon had been used against rebels, the United States sent a message to Israel asking for clarification on whether it had provided the weapons to Ethiopia.
Israel denied that it was sending cluster bombs, but was less definitive about what it had done in the recent past, an Administration official said. ''There was a little wiggle room on what they have done in the past,'' the official said.
Ethiopian diplomats in Washington were not available for comment today.
The cluster bomb is a canister packed with hundreds of bomblets. After the bomb is dropped from an aircraft, a small explosion opens the canister in midair, and the bomblets are spread over an area that is usually several hundred feet in diameter.
Israel has developed its own version of the cluster bomb, but the United States contends that Israel cannot export the weapon without approval in advance because it was developed using American technology and is therefore subject to American export restrictions.
 
Own Weapons, Israel Says
Israel, however, says that its cluster bomb is based on its own technology and not subject to American regulations.
The United States suspended deliveries of cluster bombs to Israel after they were used against civilian areas during the Israeli invasion of Lebanon in 1982. No new cluster bombs have been delivered to Israel since then, although the ban was lifted in the last months of the Reagan Administration.
Administration and Israeli officials said the United States has raised the issue of military help to Ethiopia, including allegations about the shipment of cluster bombs, several times and at high levels since the beginning of November. Israeli officials said, for example, that the American Ambassador to Israel, William A. Brown, has discussed the matter with a number of Israeli Cabinet ministers.
Ruth Yaron, a spokeswoman at the Israeli Embassy in Washington, denied that Israel is sending them to Ethiopia. ''Israel does not sell or give cluster bombs to Ethiopia,'' she said.
 
At Carter's Initiative
The subject first came to light last month in a speech and news conference by former President Jimmy Carter after a trip to Ethiopia; Mr. Carter was trying to mediate an end to the long civil war between the Ethiopian Government and rebels of the Eritrean People's Liberation Front. The State Department said today that it does not have recent or reliable figures for the number of people who have died in that civil strife. Deaths in great numbers have occurred both in fighting and from famine exacerbated by the confict.
Mr. Carter, speaking in Atlanta at a ceremony honoring Palestinian and Israeli human rights workers, said, ''In Addis Ababa, I was told that there was new hope that the war could soon be ended, because the Ethiopian Air Force had recently acquired cluster bombs from one of our Middle East allies to be used against rebel villages.''
He added that although the United States had sold cluster bombs to ''one or two countries'' to be used only as defensive weapons in case of invasion, ''those allies are manufacturing cluster bombs to be sold in the third world, without further constraint on their use.'' Mr. Carter did not say which countries he was referring to.
In a later news conference, Mr. Carter said he received the information on the cluster bombs from Bush Administration officials. ''It was American officials who said that the Ethiopian Government was quite happy that they had finally acquired cluster bombs, and they thought they could end the war quickly because of the devastating effect of those cluster bombs being dropped on the villages in the north,'' Mr. Carter said. Area of Carter's Sensitivity Mr. Carter's remarks went largely unnoticed at the time. Asked about Mr. Carter's speech the day after it was delivered, Richard Boucher, the deputy State Department spokesman, said, ''I don't have anything on that subject.''
Asked about the issue this week, however, a number of officials said that they would not disagree with what the former President said.
Carrie Harmon, a spokeswoman for the Carter Presidential Center in Atlanta, said Mr. Carter stands by his public statements but would have no further comment on the issue. Mr. Carter might be reluctant to comment further since he probably received the information in classified briefings, Administration officials said.
In addition, Mr. Carter is extremely sensitive about the issue of cluster bombs since it was he who originally approved their sale to Israel, a former aide to Mr. Carter said.
 
Emigration Rights
After Israel and Ethiopia re-established diplomatic relations, Israel agreed in principle to send military hardware to Addis Ababa, including captured Soviet ammunition and spare parts, Administration officials said. In return, the Government of President Mengistu Haile Mariam promised to allow more Ethiopian Jews to emigrate, they said.
There are about 18,000 Jews remaining in Ethiopia, Miss Yaron of the Israeli Embassy said. In 1985, Israeli officials in a secret airlift brought thousands of the black Jews to Israel, using more than $60 million raised abroad.
But Israeli officials have since assured the United States that the military agreement is very modest and that they would not provide Ethiopia with advanced military hardware.
Ethiopia is among several African nations to have recently restored relations with Israel as the Government in Jerusalem sought to end its diplomatic isolation from Africa and establish economic and military relationships.

HEADLINE: WHY PLANE TRAVEL ISN'T ALWAYS FAST

BYLINE: By ERIC WEINER

 BODY:
USAir Flight 188 from Washington to Cleveland had a perfect record in November. It was never on time.
The flight, with delays averaging 42 minutes from its scheduled arrival time, was the most notorious of the 59 appearing in the latest monthly Federal report on flights that arrive late at least 80 percent of the time, a report that Department of Transportation employees call the list of shame.
USAir, which has taken several steps to correct the delays on Flight 188 and on other flights, had some unique problems. But Flight 188's troubles also illustrate the more common reasons for a sharp increase in air traffic delays last year, despite efforts by airlines and the Federal Aviation Administration to improve performance. 
The Government reported last week that the number of delays - defined as planes delayed by air traffic controllers for 15 minutes or more - rose 14 percent last year, to 393,000.
For airlines, the late flights are costly because of added fuel and labor expenses and the more intangible expense of lost consumer confidence. For passengers, the cost is exacted in frustration.
 
Rolling With the Punches
''I've learned to sit back and roll with the punches,'' said Edward J. Sowinski, a Cleveland businessman who flies to Washington twice a month. He said that Flight 188 had never left on time for him, and that delays sometimes lasted an hour and a half.
Mr. Sowinski said he had considered switching to a different airline but is a member of USAir's frequent-flier program and does not want to lose those benefits.
The airlines say the delays are mainly caused by an air traffic control system with outdated equipment and a shortage of controllers. To try to solve the problems, they are taking steps like rerouting planes and adjusting departure times.
For instance, USAir recently rescheduled Flight 188's departure time to early afternoon, when there is less congestion, and changed the plane's itinerary before it reaches Washington. Now the flight arrives on time 77 percent of the time, said Jim Tabor, the USAir executive charged with getting the airline's schedule back on track.
But consumer groups argue that the airlines are not working hard enough. They say that the late flights are a result of unrealistic scheduling, and that airlines tend to accept the problem as a part of doing business. They have called for tougher action against carriers with consistently tardy flights.
Two bills have been introduced in Congress relating to airline service. One bill by Representative Pete Stark, Democrat of California, would require airlines to tell passengers why a flight is delayed before they board and compensate passengers if a flight is canceled. A similar bill sponsored by Senator Howard M. Metzenbaum, Democrat of Ohio, would prohibit airlines from canceling flights with less than 24 hours' notice unless they provide alternative service.
USAir flights have been so late so often that the airline could face fines from the Department of Transportation if it does not improve its record soon, a department official said.
USAir accounted for 41 of the 59 flights that appeared on the Transportation Department's list in November, the most recent period for which statistics are available. The airline has been ranked last in on-time performance among the nation's largest airlines for the past four months, with only 64 percent of its flights arriving on time in November.
The Transportation Department official, Marty Langelan, an economist, said the department gives an airline three months to remedy a chronically late flight before taking action. Under coaxing from the Government, airlines have managed to keep particular flights from reappearing on the list of shame. Still, each month, dozens of new flights appear, but no airline has ever been fined.
Despite its poor on-time record, USAir's financial performance has made it well regarded on Wall Street. ''Financially, it's one of the strongest carriers,'' said Raymond Neidl, an analyst with Dillon, Read.
USAir executives said they are attempting to improve on-time performance for all their flights, even those to small cities in the East, where they often have a monopoly on the route. ''We don't have any throwaway flights,'' said Thomas G. Kephart, vice president of operations services.
 
Special Problems
To be sure, USAir has problems that are unique in the industry. With nearly 3,000 daily departures, USAir has more flights than any airline in the world except Aeroflot, the Soviet carrier. Many routes are in the Northeast, where bad weather and congestion can cause frequent delays. Also, USAir planes must fly as many as eight segments, or flight legs, each day, exposing the airline to more chances for delays.
The airline is also still reeling from its merger with Piedmont Airlines in August, after having swallowed Pacific Southwest Airlines in 1987. For several months, labor contracts prohibited the airline from mixing pilots and flight attendants from USAir and Piedmont, complicating the already knotty art of crew scheduling.
But many of USAir's problems are common to the industry. With fleets expanding, with air traffic on the rise and with only one new airport slated to be built this decade (in Denver), experts warn that all airlines face increasing delays.
While the Government said severe weather accounted for more than half the delays last year, experts also cited a shortage of air traffic controllers, occasional computer failures and the growth of hub airports where flights are concentrated. At such airports, the bunching of flights at certain convenient times frequently leads to delays.
 
Crowded Schedules
Flight 188, for example, was scheduled for several months to leave Washington at about the same time as six other USAir flights, as well as many other flights.
Airlines try to use their planes as much as possible, and when the planes are scheduled so that they stop in many cities, a small delay at the beginning of the day can snowball. For instance, before flying to Washington, the DC-9 that would become Flight 188 flew from Chicago to Philadelphia and then Buffalo, on to Toronto and back to Buffalo before finally arriving in Washington. As a result, it often arrived late in Washington, said Mr. Tabor, the USAir executive.
Ms. Langelan at the Transportation Department said the airlines could help guard against late flights by spacing departure times and lengthening the time planes spend on the ground between flights, especially at hub airports.
In what Mr. Tabor called ''a bow to reality,'' USAir did just that. It revised its entire schedule last month to improve its performance, adding a total of 120 hours daily to its published flight times.
To remedy Flight 188's dismal performance, USAir moved the departure time from 3:35 P.M. to 2:20, when fewer flights are scheduled to leave Washington National, one of the nation's busiest airports. The airline also increased the plane's turnaround time - the time on the ground at Washington - to 39 minutes from 31 and added eight minutes to the scheduled flight time to compensate for stronger headwinds.
Finally, it changed the plane's itinerary earlier in the day, routing it clear of congested airports so that it was more likely to arrive in Washington on time. Instead of flying to cities like Chicago and Philadelphia, the plane is routed through cities like Norfolk, Va., before flying on to Washington.
 
A Tug of War
Mr. Tabor pointed out that within an airline, a tug-of-war is often waged between the marketing and operations departments. ''They want to sell seats, and we're trying to run the airline on time,'' Mr. Tabor said. ''There's a lot of give-and-take.''
More often than not, the marketing department wins. Flights are then bunched during prime hours, creating gridlock in the morning and evening. For instance, American Airlines has 41 departures scheduled within a half-hour in Dallas.
Daniel Smith, director of industry and government affairs for the International Airline Passengers Association, said that although the airlines have begun to space their departure times, they are reluctant to give up popular departure slots. ''The operating expense of running 45 minutes late is well offset by the fact that they have filled up the airplane,'' he said.
 
What People Want
But Stephen Hayes, a spokesman for the Air Transport Association, the industry trade group, said the airlines are simply giving passengers what they want. ''People want to leave at 5, 6 and 7 in the evening,'' he said. ''We're responding to market demands.'' Mr. Hayes said the solution lies in expanding and modernizing the air traffic system, not in juggling airline schedules.
Still, hub airports seem especially vulnerable to delays, which can ripple throughout an airline's route system. At least one airline has tried to contain the delays caused by a congested hub by changing the way it schedules flights to help reduce the effect of a troublesome hub airport. To reduce the domino effect, American Airlines has routed its planes from Chicago so that they return directly to that city rather than flying on to a third city.
''We accept that Chicago isn't going to be an on-time hub for quite a while,'' said Dan Knerman, manager of systems operations control for American Airlines. ''At least we can allow the other hubs to run on time.''
United Airlines, the largest carrier at Chicago, has staggered its departure times there and scheduled its flights earlier, said Thomas Lagow, senior vice president for planning. ''We've definitely spread the day out more,'' he said. ''A flight that used to leave at 7 now leaves at 6:45.''
But some people are still not satisfied. Wayne Dimmic, who publishes a newsletter and software program that tracks the most delayed flights and airports in the country, questioned the airlines' commitment to eliminating their chronically late flights.
''The airlines will adjust these flights just enough to get the public off their backs,'' he said. ''If nothing else, they'll change the flight numbers.''

HEADLINE: The City of Mayor Barry: Achievement and Decay

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20

 BODY:
On Friday afternoon, David A. Clarke, the chairman of the City Council here, said with evident anxiety, ''The most important thing I want to project to the people of Washington and across the nation is that this city is under control.''
That's not the picture people have been getting. When they think of Washington, many people think no more of the elegant city that Pierre L'Enfant laid out, with its white marble monuments evoking the splendor of ancient Greece and Rome, nor of Presidents and senators and judges.
They think of a febrile city of fear and violence. They call it the national capital of murder and cocaine, this place where the homeless lie disconsolately on heat grates a block from the White House. And now they can talk about a capital city whose Mayor was busted. 
Tonight, close political associates of Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. were said to be pressing him not to seek re-election, to resign or at least to seek medical treatment for his own good and that of the city. There were reports that he would announce Sunday morning that he would seek treatment.
 
No Fourth Term, Lawyer Urges
His lawyer, R. Kenneth Mundy, said Mr. Barry should not seek a fourth term because a campaign would interfere with his legal defense. ''Under those circumstances,'' Mr. Mundy said on WJLA television, ''I believe trying to run a campaign and do the things he must as an accused person would be incompatible with one another.''
The Rev. Jesse Jackson said on an NBC News broadcast that Mr. Barry appeared to have committed a ''moral felony.'' He added that Mr. Barry in private was ''not resisting admitting that a problem exists'' with his legal situation and his political future.
The arrest of Mayor Barry on cocaine charges Thursday night, compounding years of negative television and newspaper images, has solidified for Washington a reputation as unsavory as Chicago's 60 years ago in the era of submachine guns and bootleggers. It has sapped the confidence of people, great and small, who live in this city. For many of the Mayor's supporters in the core of Washington, it left a trail of confusion, anger and hurt. [Page 26.] Home Rule Seen in Jeopardy It has derailed the effort, already going uphill, to win statehood for the District of Columbia, and some worry that it might erode support for the 16-year-old home-rule legislation that ended the era of total Congressional control in Washington. Coincidentally, it was the excesses of another leader -Alexander (Boss) Shepherd, the city's corrupt second territorial governor, appointed in 1874 - that led to a century of rule by Congressional committees here.
Yet in his dozen years in office, Mr. Barry helped preside over Washington's coming of age - its emergence as a world-class center for the arts, an important business headquarters, a city with restaurants of national repute. Pennsylvania Avenue was rebuilt; so was the old downtown area, where hotels and office buildings, clad in the fashionable postmodern idiom, replaced porno shops and pawnbrokers.
Real estate values soared in largely white residential Northwest Washington, which retained some of the leafy calm and civility of small-town life. But there were alarms, too.
Once confined to areas that lawyers and lobbyists seldom visited, the violence began creeping, in the last couple of years, into the Dupont Circle area and toward the luxurious enclaves of Georgetown and Cleveland Park.
Drugs are sold and people are murdered these days eight or ten blocks from multimillion-dollar houses owned by C. Boyden Gray, one of President Bush's advisers, and Benjamin C. Bradlee, the executive editor of The Washington Post, and Pamela Harriman, the philanthropist and Democratic Party figure.
For some of the city's black residents, who constitute more than three-quarters of the population, the Democratic Mayor's ability to speak their language, to identify himself with their troubles, to win the allegiance of their clergymen and to take on the white news media with seeming impunity, was enough, even when he was accused, again and again, of infidelity and drug use.
Others came to consider him an embarrassment even before this week's stunning denouement. One of these was Delicia Jackson, a 24-year-old secretary who said his arrest made her ''as happy as the Fourth of July.''
Barry supporters insisted that he ran the city as well as anyone could in a tough era for cities. Streets were cleared promptly after early-winter snowfalls last year, they noted, in contrast to 1986, when a huge storm paralyzed Washington for three days while Mayor Barry went to the Super Bowl.
''He's managed to provide general services in a reasonable way,'' said Edward C. Sylvester Jr., staff director of the House District Committee.
''I think this city has come back a lot'' since the riots of 1968, said Frank Shaforth, Director of Federal Relations for the National League of Cities.
But others, like Clifford L. Alexander Jr., a lawyer and former Secretary of the Army who ran unsuccessfully for Mayor 15 years ago, before Mr. Barry's time, vehemently disagreed.
''He's been an awful Mayor,'' said Mr. Alexander, who lives on Capitol Hill. ''Those of us who live here are suffering from more murders per day than we'd ever had. We're suffering from failed city services. We're suffering from the fact that people can't hold their heads up as city employees.''
''The issue for most people is renewing their driver's license, potholes, collecting garbage, health care, jobs and equity in the job market,'' Mr. Alexander added. ''If you had a progressive mayor and a person of vision and excitement, he would have turned the city around. He didn't at all. The city has shown economic progress. The haves have done well. The have-nots are ignored more and more.''
Roger W. Wilkins, Clarence J. Robinson professor of American history and culture at George Mason University, added: ''You want good government. You want your taxes to be well spent. You don't want the wheels on your automobile continually pounded to bits with potholes, and you want, when you go to face your city government, you want efficiency and good manners. That's the bare minimum, and we weren't getting the bare minimum.''
It is not that the ''haves'' escape taxation to provide money for the common weal. According to a recent study by the District's own Department of Finance and Revenue, Washington's tax burden was higher than those in any of the Virginia and Maryland suburban jurisdictions around it and higher than that in 50 other large cities. A family of four earning $25,000 a year paid $2,514 in taxes in 1989, as against an average of $2,085 in the 51 cities studied.
While reports of phantom inspection services and disintegrating, vermin-ridden public housing provide staple reading in the local press, the city's work force has increased by 10,000 people in the past six years. With almost 50,000 workers for a population of about 620,000, it has one of the highest ratios of employees to residents of any city in the country.
 
The Backlog of Neglect
The headline in the Washington Monthly magazine a year ago offered a searing indictment - ''The Worst City Government in America'' - and the accompanying article offered a tour of a squalid landscape of inefficiency and neglect over several years of Mr. Barry's 11-year tenure as Mayor: 2,700 backlogged maintenance requests on public housing, although there are 80 percent more maintenance men on the payroll per apartment than the Housing and Urban Development Department recommends; an eight-year wait for a woman trying to get into public housing and subsisting on a $359 monthly disability check; a patient at the city's largest nursing home dying of exposure 50 feet from her dormitory; ambulances losing their way while heart attack victims died.
Most stark, perhaps, is the way people die in the District, which has not only the highest murder rate in the country but the highest infant mortality rate of the nation's top 20 cities. In 1986, Washington had 21.1 deaths for every 1,000 live births. For the first six months of 1989, the figure was 23.8.
''The public health system isn't capable of coping with the need,'' said Joseph Liu, of the Children's Defense Fund, pointing out that severe financing cutbacks forced most prenatal clinics to cut back their hours. ''In other cities there has been a very serious investment in prenatal care and infant mortality rates. They've kept it as a higher priority than Washington has.''
As in other large cities, the failures of the government of the District of Columbia are felt most acutely by the poor, the elderly and the homeless, who need the most help. The big winners, in Marion Barry's Washington, have been the developers.
''The business community under Marion Barry has done better than it's ever done in its life,'' said Mr. Sylvester of the District Committee.
Those who built the buildings grew rich and many gave the money that enabled Mr. Barry to run effective campaigns.
The city's budget fell out of balance two years ago, and some much-criticized bookkeeping legerdemain was required to get it into balance for this year.
Nonetheless, the city and its Mayor have become ''a focus of national ridicule,'' as Norman Ornstein, a resident scholar at the American Enterprise Institute, said the other day. That galls blacks like Roger Wilkins.
''I was returning from a speaking engagement in Reno the other day,'' the writer and longtime civil rights worker said. ''I was five miles above southern Utah and I opened The Reno Journal-Gazette and there's an editorial cartoon showing the Mayor as a clown. It makes you cringe. You cringe because the Mayor had become not a symbol of leadership for black people anymore but a symbol for white people of black incompetence and self-indulgence.
''It was a symbol that ranked right up there with all of the symbols that people used to discredit Reconstruction governments in the South a hundred years ago.''
That symbolism, he says, has postponed the day when Washington gets full self-government and made it harder than ever to deal with the drug epidemic that is causing what he called ''catastrophic destruction of black youngsters.'' Instead of giving people here hope, Mr. Wilkins said bitterly, Marion Barry ''turned them cynical.''

An article last Sunday about Washington and its Mayor, Marion S. Barry Jr., misstated the percentage of blacks in the city. It is about 70 percent.

HEADLINE: Report Warns of Pollution in Eastern Europe

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20

 BODY:
While efforts to restore clean air to the United States have met with partial success, there is a far greater ecological disaster brewing in Eastern Europe, a report on worldwide air pollution said today.
The report, issued by the Worldwatch Institute, a Washington-based environmental group, warned that gains in the West are quickly being negated by the unrestricted burning of high-sulfur brown coal and diesel fuel that is blackening cities across Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union.
''Fishless lakes and streams, dying forests, and faceless ancient sculptures all provide sad testimony to the destruction that industrialization has wrought,'' wrote Hilary F. French, a researcher at the Worldwatch Institute and author of the report, ''Clearing the Air: A Global Agenda.'' The notion that ''pollution is the price of progress'' has become antiquated, she said. 
Hasty industrialization in the East after World War II, powered by the region's abundance of brown coal, has resulted in air quality reminiscent of London at its Dickensian worst, Ms. French wrote.
The city of Olkosz, Poland, reports one of the highest levels of lead and cadmium in the soil in the world, the report said, and acid rain has turned the panoramic mountains along the East German and Czechoslovakian border into a vast expanse of dead trees.
''The lack of market forces kept these countries from realizing the impressive gains in energy efficiency registered in the West after the oil shocks of the Seventies, and their weak economies still preclude major investments in pollution control,'' the report said.
Richard Mott, director of the atmospheric-pollution program at the Environmental Law Institute in Washington, agreed that air pollution in Eastern Europe is some of the worst in the world. The problem is the price of fixing it.
''The technologies are extremely expensive even by Western standards,'' Mr. Mott said in a recent interview. ''It's a technological luxury we've been able to afford. It's not realistic to think those technologies are going to spring up in the East themselves, despite the enormous need for them there.''
To begin tackling pollution in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union, these countries will need Western know-how as well as domestic reform, the report said. ''Now that air pollution and its damaging health and ecological effects have proliferated around the globe, crossing borders with winds, international cooperation is critical,'' it said. ''Nations that receive the bulk of their pollution from other countries have an obvious interest in sharing and financing the technical means to reduce that pollution.''
While the United States has been slow to deal with air pollution on a global scale, European nations have begun to help their neighbors in the East with pollution-control devices.
The report said West Germany is donating $163 million to East Germany for pollution control. Sweden announced it is spending $45 million in Poland over the next three years, mostly to cut airborne pollutants.
Increasing pressure on Eastern countries to improve their air should not hinder domestic reform, argued C. Fred Bergsten, director of the Institute for International Economics in Washington. Any investment will create jobs and orders for new products, and it can just as well be for environmentally safe ends, he added.
''If you do it right, you can simultanously pursue environmental and economic objectives,'' Mr. Bergsten said. ''Starting from scratch makes it even easier to accomplish environmentally sound objectives.''
 
Not a Simple Switch
Ms. French warned that Western industrial countries must not simply transfer their pollution-control methods to the East and the third world. She argued that the ''technological Band-Aids prescribed by the regulatory intervention'' cannot deliver their promises of clean air.
Instead, she said, traditional efforts need to be supported by policies that encourage energy efficiency and develop alternative sources that spew out fewer toxic wastes.

HEADLINE: Delaware Tries to Erase Image of Its Poor Health

BYLINE: By MICHAEL deCOURCY HINDS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WILMINGTON, Del., Jan. 19

 BODY:
Gov. Michael N. Castle has a problem: scientific studies saying that people who live in Delaware are among the least healthy in the nation.
The solution he is offering presents a case study in how government officials must deal with both a problem and the image created by that problem.
''It's a perception problem,'' Governor Castle said in an interview Thursday. ''But perception can become reality if you don't combat it. Frankly, a lot of people here believe that the health problems are not as severe as stated in the studies.'' 
Health is a new concern in Delaware, becoming a major issue with the publication of the scientific data last year. The Governor says, and health experts back him up, that there is nothing within Delaware - no special pollution problem or industry waste sites - that make it an especially unhealthy place. The problem, as elsewhere in the country, involves access to medical care, the quality of that care and the choices that people make in their diets and behavior.
 
He Wants a Solid Message
But he is afraid that the qualified message will not come through to those who hear only casual reports about the studies. One is a report from the Centers for Disease Control that ranks the state first in breast cancer and sixth over all in chronic but largely preventable diseases. The second is a study by the Northwestern National Insurance Company ranking the state last over all in 16 areas dealing with health and related risk factors like smoking and alcohol consumption.
The Governor's concern is that people will hear about the state's ranking and immediately think about the state's chemical and automobile factories that are polluting the environment. Delaware companies release more than 200 million pounds of pollutants a year into the environment, a considerable amount for so small a state, but there are not enough environmental health standards to judge what impact these pollutants have on health. There are only a half dozen Federal air quality standards, and the state has, with few exceptions, always met them.
The Governor, a Republican elected in 1984 and again in 1988, has addressed the issue of health care in speeches over the last month, including his State of the State Message last week. His $1.23 billion budget request for 1991 includes $250 million for health and social services, a 10 percent increase over spending in the current fiscal year, which ends in July.
 
A Mobile Mammography Lab
This month he announced a comprehensive Cancer Control Plan that will have the State Department of Health identify where cancers are most prevalent in the state, assess environmental and behavioral risk factors and establish programs for prevention and early detection. New programs will include a mobile mammography laboratory for use in inner-city neighborhoods and expansion of experimenal programs like health clinics in public schools.
He has also called on Delaware residents to ''abandon their deadly habits,'' adding that of every 100 residents an estimated 28 smoke, 10 abuse alcohol, 60 do not wear seat belts, 50 have high cholesterol levels, 26 are obese and 24 have high blood pressure.
As part of the Governor's public relations campaign to change people's way of living, he said he will ask his Cabinet members to take fitness tests, improve their diets and start exercise programs. ''Three or four won't be happy,'' he said. ''They are not in great shape.''
Experts in both health and communications say Governor Castle is right to confront the state's health problem rather than dodge it. But they add that even if the programs he has announced help reduce mortality rates, the stigma brought on by the state's current low standing in health surveys could have a far-reaching and long-lasting negative social and economic impact.
As a prime example, they say New Jersey and its residents have long suffered from the state's reputation as ''Cancer Alley'' even though statistics have not supported that branding for decades. ''Cancer Alley doesn't exist anymore, but the perception lingers,'' said Dr. Michael Greenberg, professor of public health and a cancer epidemiologist at Rutgers University.
 
Chronic Disease Death Rates
Studies indicated that Delaware has a relatively high mortality rate for several chronic diseases. It has the highest mortality rate for breast cancer and diabetes, the sixth-highest for heart disease and the eighth-highest for cirrhosis, according to a study of 1986 mortality rates published this week in the Morbidity and Mortality Weekly Report of the Federal Centers for Disease Control in Atlanta.
The state ranked sixth in the nation, based on its overall mortality rate for nine chronic diseases that were surveyed because they are considered to be largely preventable through early detection or changes in diet and behavior. The nine diseases were stroke, coronary heart disease, diabetes, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, lung cancer, breast cancer, cervical cancer, colon-rectal cancer and cirrhosis.
The low ranking in the Federal study was not news to Governor Castle, who received a preview copy of the study in November. But he had already been put on the defensive by the study by Northwestern National Life Insurance of Minneapolis.
That study ranked Delaware last among states based upon 16 health factors and related behavior. The health factors included the incidence of chronic diseases, overall mortality rates, infant mortality rates, life expectancy and access to health care.
 
'Low Across the Board'
The style-of-life factors included prevalence of smoking, alcohol consumption, exercise and missed days at school or work. ''Delaware ranked low across the board,'' said David Ordos, Northwestern's manager of research.
Thomas P. Eichler, Secretary of Delaware's Department of Health and Social Services, found fault with the research techniques used in the insurance study. ''We could quibble over statistics and whether or not Delaware is the unhealthiest state,'' he said. ''But the point is we know we have some health problems and we are trying to address them.''
Health officials in nine other states that had high mortality rates in the Federal study also expressed concern about their ranking, but, unlike Delaware officials, most had been aware of their state's problems for many years.
Business groups are already concerned about the impact of Delaware's health problems. ''From a chamber of commerce point of view, it's a real negative when you're trying to relocate businesses and people into the state,'' said Jack A. Nylund, president of the Southern Delaware Chamber of Commerce. ''One of the first questions we always get is, 'How good is your medical care community?' If this label, 'the least healthy state,' sticks, it will have long-range impact.''

HEADLINE: REPUBLICANS SHOW GAINS IN LOYALTY

BYLINE: By MICHAEL ORESKES

 BODY:
The Republican Party enjoyed virtual parity in 1989 with the Democrats in the loyalty of Americans for the first time since just after World War II ended.
Forty-four percent of Americans identified themselves as Republicans or said they leaned that way in 1989, and 46 percent said they were Democrats or leaning so. The figures are based on data from 8,719 interviews in seven New York Times/CBS News Polls conducted through the year. The margin of sampling error is plus or minus one percentage point. 
The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll, taken Jan. 13 to 15 of this year, shows that the closeness between the parties is persisting into the 1990's, with 45 percent calling themselves Democrats or leaning toward the party and 44 percent siding with the Republicans.
The percentages show the continuation of a trend that raised hopes among Republicans and concern among Democrats throughout the last decade.
 
Peaks After Elections
In 1980, the Republicans were clearly a minority party, with 34 percent of Americans identifying themselves as Republicans or leaning toward the Republicans, while 53 percent said they were Democrats or leaning toward the Democrats.
The responses in the polls represent the partisan sense Americans have of themselves, not how they are registered or how they voted in any election. Data for the 1980's showed Republican strength peaking in the year after the Presidential elections: 1981, 1985 and 1989. After 1981 and 1985, the Democrats regained some but not all of the ground they lost, only to fall back again after the next Presidential race.
Since modern public opinion polling made such measurement of partisan mood possible in the 1930's, the Republican have been this close to the Democrats only once. That was in 1946, amid the economic upheavals of military demobilization, when 40 percent identified themselves in The Gallup Poll with the Republicans and 39 percent with the Democrats. The Republicans won control of both houses of Congress that year.
But after that, the Democrats opened a large advantage, which persisted into the 1980's.
 
Republicans Attract the Young
Some political analysts have argued that a significant, if gradual, realignment of party loyalties is under way, although others have suggested that as parties have become weaker, party identification is less and less important.
Republicans continued to be strongest among the youngest voters. Times/ CBS News Polls showed that among Americans 18 to 29 years old, 51 percent identified themselves last year as Republicans or leaning that way, while 40 percent sided with the Democrats. In the January poll, the margin was narrower.
Democrats still enjoyed a modest advantage among core partisans in 1989. Excluding the independents who said they leaned to one party or the other, 36 percent of the Times/CBS News Poll respondents in 1989 identified themselves as Democrats, and 32 percent picked the Republicans. This was a dramatic narrowing of the gap from 1980, when 41 percent identified themselves as Democrats and 23 percent said they were Republicans.
It was when the 28 percent who initially described themselves as independent were pressed to choose the party closest to them, a common survey technique, that the Democratic advantage closed to the 46-to-44 margin.
The two parties continue to have distinctly different constituents in the January poll. Fifty-five percent of those surveyed with incomes of more than $50,000 indentified themselves as Republicans, while 39 percent said they were Democrats. At the same time, 53 percent of those with incomes of less than $15,000 said they were Democrats, and 30 percent said they were Republicans.

HEADLINE: Longshoremen Strike in Baltimore, Idling Port, After Internal Dispute

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: BALTIMORE, Jan. 20

 BODY:
The Port of Baltimore was idled today when dockworkers went on strike. About 2,000 members of the International Longshoremen's Association put up picket lines at the port, where 13 ships were scheduled to call this weekend.
Port managers and elected officials warned that a strike of more than two weeks could prompt shipping companies to take their business to competing East Coast ports, dealing the city an economic blow. 
The strike was a result of a dispute between two of the port's five union locals over allocation of jobs under a tentative contract agreement. The rank and file was to have voted on the contract Friday. Economic issues had already been settled; the longshoremen are paid $18 an hour.
 
'So Many Families'
William J. Detweiler, president of Steamship Trade Association of Baltimore, an employers' group, said a prolonged strike would mean ''we're going to lose business, some irretrievably.''
Representative Helen Delich Bentley, a Maryland Republican, said as many as 30,000 people could suffer direct or indirect loss of income because of the strike. ''Unfortunately, so many people are going to be hurt, so many families,'' she said. ''Efforts to improve Baltimore's name will be put way back for a long time.''
Most of the ships due at the port were expected to be diverted to other harbors. About 2,500 ships call at Baltimore each year, but the number has been declining as shippers move to competing ports.
Baltimore has lost 29 steamship lines in the last five years to the port of Hampton Roads, Va. Virginia ports have lured away much of the cargo that moved by rail between Baltimore and the Midwest.
Gov. William Donald Schaefer has said in recent weeks that the state would take over the port's operations if there is a strike, but he declined to comment on the walkout Saturday.
The longshoremen's union in Baltimore is alone in the nation in having failed to reach an agreement on local work rules. The agreement that was to be voted by workers Friday would have eliminated what management says is one of the port's worst problems: rules allowing the union to decide when crews stop work for bad weather.
But the tentative accord prompted a dispute between two union locals, one representing clerks and the other cargo handlers. The agreement would have reduced the number of clerks and increased the number of handlers.

HEADLINE: Police Pension Fund Will Invest in Loans Guaranteed by U.S.

BYLINE: By LEONARD BUDER

 BODY:
For the first time, a New York City employees' pension fund will invest in federally guaranteed bank loans as part of a city effort to promote greater economic growth by making more loan funds available for small businesses.
Under a program announced last week by City Comptroller Elizabeth Holtzman, the Police Pension Fund will purchase $50 million in loans backed by the Federal Small Business Administration that are to be offered by five lending institutions. The banks will use the money they get from the pension fund to make additional loans backed by the S.B.A.
With Harrison J. Goldin, the former Comptroller, joining in the announcement, Ms. Holtzman described the development as ''an example of a win- win'' in which every participant would benefit - the city, the pension fund, the banks and the borrowers, many of which will be minority-owned businesses. 
She said the program, which was set in motion before Mr. Goldin left office on Dec. 31, would create additional jobs by helping small businesses and, ''best of all, potentially generate new revenues for the city.''
 
Lenders in Program
The five lenders taking part in the program are the Chase Manhattan Bank, Chemical Bank, the Freedom National Bank, the Capital National Bank and the Business Loan Center. Until now, Ms. Holtzman said, those institutions have not for the most part offered such loans.
The portion of the loans guaranteed by the S. B. A. - generally 85 percent of the loan, up to $750,000 - will be put into securities, which the Police Pension Fund will buy for its investment portfolio.
James Gebhardt, the president of the Lieutenants' Benevolent Association and a trustee of the Police Pension Fund, said the fund would receive on its investment ''a rate of return that will be higher than a comparable government note or bond with the same maturity and guarantee.''
Loans to qualified borrowers can range from $25,000 to $1 million and run from 5 to 25 years.

HEADLINE: SUSPECT ARRESTED IN RAZOR ATTACKS

BYLINE: By DONATELLA LORCH

 BODY:
After a weeklong search that took detectives to Miami Beach, a Brooklyn teen-ager was arrested yesterday in the razor-slashings of two people, including the actress Viveca Lindfors, as they walked in Greenwich Village on Jan. 13. The police said the suspect was high on LSD and alcohol during the attacks.
The suspect, Peter Bedford, 18 years old, of 543 Third Street in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn, was arrested at 4:45 A.M. in a friend's home on Sixth Street, where he had been hiding, said Ronald Fenrich, chief of Manhattan detectives. 
Mr. Bedford was charged with two counts of assault and one count of criminal possession of a dangerous weapon. The police said he is unemployed and was planning to go to college next year. They said he does not have a police record.
The police said Mr. Bedford slashed the two people with a single-edge razor blade in separate attacks on Jan. 13 about 1:30 A.M.
 
'Under the Influence'
''He was high; he was under the influence. He was running down the street acting wildly, and for no reason he slashed the two people without any confrontation, no provocation,'' Chief Fenrich said.
Ms. Lindfors, 69, was attacked in front of the Archives, an apartment building at 666 Greenwich Street. She received 28 stiches on her left ear. Five minutes earlier and three blocks away, 36-year-old Dennis Beal of Manhattan was slashed from his right ear to his chin. Forty stitiches were needed to close his wound.
Chief Fenrich said that before the attacks Mr. Bedford and seven friends had been asked to leave Tek Billiards at Chrisopher Street and Seventh Avenue after a dispute with other customers.
The police said that after the assault Mr. Bedford returned to Brooklyn alone by taxi; obtained money from his home, where he lives with his mother and two siblings, and then flew to Miami Beach with a friend, whom the police did not identify and whom they said was not part of the group at the billiards parlor.
The police said two anonymous phone calls helped identify Mr. Bedford as the assailant. Detectives tracked him to a Miami Beach hotel, only to find he had returned to Brooklyn. The detectives traced telephone calls from Mr. Bedford's hotel to a house in Brooklyn, where they arrested him.

HEADLINE: S. Fannie Simon, Teacher, 88

 BODY:
S. Fannie Simon, a retired teacher and labor leader, died of a ruptured appendix Wednesday at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center in Manhattan. She was 88 years old and lived in Manhattan.
Miss Simon, who came to the United States from Poland in 1913, taught economics at James Monroe High School in the Bronx for 30 years before retiring in 1962.
She was a founder of the Teachers Guild, the United Federation of Teachers and the Retired Teachers Chapter of the federation.
Miss Simon, a 1923 graduate of Cornell University, received a master's from Columbia University.
She is survived by her sister, Diana S. Granof of Bethesda, Md.

HEADLINE: City Environmental Agency Will Move to Queens

BYLINE: By JOSEPH P. FRIED

 BODY:
In a major step to disperse part of New York City's bureaucracy outside Manhattan, the Department of Environmental Protection will shift its headquarters and half of its 5,000 employees to Queens next fall.
City officials say the planned move to Corona - which will make the department the only mayoral agency besides the Fire Department to have its central offices outside Manhattan -will lower the city's leasing costs and increase the agency's efficiency. They also say it is in line with a policy of bolstering neighborhoods across the city with government workers to fill vacant office space and patronize local shops.
But agency employees who oppose the switch say that it will introduce new inefficiencies. And they warn that the longer commute for many of them will cause some of the department's most experienced and valued professionals to quit. 
The planned move - to the Long Island Expressway and Junction Boulevard - illustrates the economic and morale considerations that municipal managers must juggle in determining the benefits of such shifts. In this case, officials said, the pluses outweigh the minuses.
The officials noted that the main offices of the environmental department's bureaus were now scattered in a half dozen locations in lower and midtown Manhattan. They said this often made it time-consuming and cumbersome for the staff to do business.
The decision to unite in another borough - in two adjacent buildings owned by the Lefrak Organization -was made because ''it was too costly to consolidate in Manhattan,'' said Alan Schoor, first assistant commissioner of the Department of General Services, which arranges quarters for city agencies.
William Cusick, another General Services official, said that besides trying to avoid the high costs of Manhattan rents, city officials now pursue ''the more equitable distribution of city facilities in the five boroughs.''
But Louis Albano, president of the Civil Service Technical Guild - which represents 1,200 engineers, chemists and other professionals in the environmental agency - reported that many of his union members ''have said they would quit if the move was made.'' He said that commuting time for many to the new offices ''will be quite extensive,'' up to two hours each way for those living in Westchester and New Jersey. There is subway service on the E, F, G and R lines within a few blocks of the offices.
He added that replacing such specialists would be difficult ''because the city doesn't offer enough.''
Mr. Cusick of General Services said, ''Anytime an agency makes a decision to move, some employees are going to be unhappy.'' Martha Holstein, a spokeswoman for the environmental agency, said that ''some people say they look forward to the move, it may be closer to where they live.''
A department employee who asked not to be identified held that the efficiencies from consolidating the agency would be negated because of the time lost when her colleagues would have to travel to Manhattan for meetings. Ms. Holstein said the benefits of the move would still predominate.
Employees also said that in one of the Manhattan buildings being vacated, the city spent several million dollars for extensive renovations to enable the environmental agency to move in only two years ago. Mr. Schoor of General Services said other city agencies could use the space in the future.
Much of the Lefrak space became vacant when the Federal Social Security Administration moved a year ago to Jamaica. Mr. Schoor said that the city's base annual rent to Lefrak for a half million square feet would be $9.45 per square foot to start, rising to $13.43 in the 11th through 20th years of the lease. Mr. Cusick said that those figures ''compare very favorably with what's available in the market'' in Queens.
City officials said that campaign contributions to former Mayor Edward I. Koch by members of the LeFrak family played no role in the selection of its buildings. A LeFrak spokesman, Howard J. Rubenstein, said such contributions totaled $3,000 from 1985 to 1989.

HEADLINE: Campus Lief: Wellesley;
Shadow Program Aims to Illumine Life After Degree

DATELINE: WELLESLEY, Mass.

 BODY:
January means winter term and almost no one is on the campus, but more than 150 Wellesley College students are getting some education about life after graduation. The students are participating in the annual Shadow Program, which enables a woman to follow an alumna in the field of her choice for a day in January. Organized by the college's Career Center, the program takes place in seven major cities.
The fields are varied and include working with the editor of Woman's Day in New York and following around the general manager of the Los Angeles Philharmonic or a deputy district attorney who prosecutes homicide cases in Los Angeles. 
Nora Manella, chief of criminal appeals for the United States Attorney's Office for the Central District of California, has held that job for two years and been a Federal prosecutor for seven. ''I thought I had an interesting enough job,'' Ms. Manella said, and she wanted to show her ''shadow'' something besides civil and corporate law.
Her shadow, Brooke Frewing, a Wellesley junior majoring in economics and minoring in math, from La Canada, Calif., saw the sentencing of a convicted kingpin of a major cocaine ring. In addition, the two toured the chambers of a Federal judge. Having already spent time in a corporate law office, Miss Frewing wanted to see ''the contrast between private law practices and working for the Federal Government.''
 
'A Wonderful Field'
Ms. Manella explained that in high school she participated in a similar program, which enabled her to sit next to a judge on the bench for a full day. This experience, she said, ''left a vivid impression.'' In addition, she said, although a ''rigorous academic curriculum like that provided at Wellesley'' is the best training for later life, ''you obviously don't get exposure to various careers, and the program provides a unique opportunity to pop somebody into an environment that they would not otherwise have access to.''
Nancy Bell Coe, general manager for the Los Angeles Philharmonic, said she volunteered to be in the shadow program because she thought she worked in ''a wonderful field, and I want everyone to know about it.'' In addition, she said, ''Any networking we can do is all to our benefit.''
Her shadow, Margaret Lo, a senior from Anaheim, Calif., majoring in English with a computer-science minor, has been playing the piano since she was 6 years old and has participated in concerts at Wellesley as well as helped arrange them. But she said, ''I had never really thought about all the behind-the-scenes work involved.''
Ms. Lo spent the day with Ms. Coe as she dealt with logistics and the coming concert series and its repertory. She also attended a rehearsal and a meeting with conductor Andre Previn, and she saw a concert in the evening. Ms. Lo said that while taking music courses and working in the music department office, she ''had been pointed in the direction of arts management.'' But she had thought that that would be very far down the road, after getting an M.B.A. ''But now I'm becoming very interested in this, and it may come sooner,'' she said.
 
Two Types of Students
Callie Crossley, a 1973 graduate who produces the Dr. Timothy Johnson medical segments for the ABC News program ''20/20,'' shows students the studio in New York and, depending on the day, the student may see her editing, researching, meeting with the director or seeing the taping of the program. ''It's supposed to be a workaday day, and that's what I provide,'' said Ms. Crossley, who has been involved in the shadow program since it began four years ago.
Ms. Crossley said she has seen two types of students: those very interested in a field and those who are still in the exploratory stages, ''crystallizing'' the various possibilities open to them. ''I feel very strongly about this kind of opportunity, and if I had that, I would have taken advantage of it,'' she said.
Aniella Gonzalez, a first-year student from Kearny, N.J., who followed Ms. Crossley, said she learned ''it is a plus to be computer-literate because not too many people are,'' noting that a lot of time was spent trying to retrieve a piece that was ''lost in the computer.''
Marcie Schorr Hirsch, who is director of the Career Center and who started the program after she had seen similar ones at other schools, said, ''We all have fantasies about careers, but very few of us actually know what they are really like.''
The students, she said, ''get to go into a day in the life of, and they get not only the cognitive piece of the job, they get the whole thing.'' The alumnae, she said, ''are not at entry level, but people who are a little further along'' and this gives students ''a look into their future.''

HEADLINE: Pastimes;
Stamps

BYLINE: By Barth Healey

 BODY:
The basic idea is interesting enough: Here was a United States postal rate that had endured with only minor interruptions for almost a century, through wars and a vast national expansion.
But research into this modest area yielded glimpses of spectacular inflation, the debasement of paper money and a tax on the better educated.
The rate in question is the 1-cent fee charged for ''drop letters,'' which were left at post offices to be picked up by the addressees. The rate was first established in 1794 when unified postal services finally supplanted the colonial potpourri; it was last ratified by the post office in 1885. 
The rate was low because almost no service was required. It was enough that postal employees retrieve the letters from the drop slot and keep them in a safe place.
But in reviewing the period just before the 1794 reorganization, one is struck by the sharp rate increases that the Government decreed after Independence. According to rate tables, gathered for the first time in Linn's Stamp Almanac, the last British colonial rates were, for example, 8 pence to carry a single letter sheet 60 to 100 miles from its destination. The first ''American'' postal rates lowered the British fees by 20 percent.
Then the inflationary roller coaster started: In 1777, postal rates were raised 50 percent. In April 1779, they were set at double the 1775 rates. In December that year, they were raised again, to 20 times the 1775 rates. Six months later, in May 1780, the rates were doubled again, to 40 times the original basic rate.
One reason for rocketing rates was a lack of faith in paper money, which was being issued by a variety of institutions in various states of financial health. This phenomenon was duly noted in December 1780, when postal rates returned to half what they had been in 1775 - if paid in coin. When rates finally stabilized, the fee to send a letter sheet from 60 to 100 miles was 10 cents; the top rate, for distances over 450 miles, it was 25 cents.
What accounted for such rates, during a period when 25 cents might be a day's wage and a good meal could be had for a few pennies? Mostly it was the high cost of maintaining a mail network to deliver very few letters. Literacy was not high, and commerce was narrowly based.In part, fees constituted a kind of tax on the literate.
With the drop rate pegged at 1 cent, postal history took a new twist: bootleg letters. If it cost 10 times more to mail a letter from Philadelphia to New York, for example, than to just drop it in a box in New York for pick up, it was worth finding someone travelling to New York to carry a letter.
The drop rate endured. There was a 50 percent surcharge, to 1 1/2 cent, in 1815-16 to raise money for the War of 1812, then the fee returned to 1 cent. As mail delivery became more efficient and growing volume reduced per-letter costs, routine first-class rates came down, to 5 cents a half ounce (up to 300 miles) in 1845; at the same time, the drop-letter rate was raised to 2 cents.
Examples of bootleg mail after 1845 are harder to find, but it still cost 40 cents to send a letter from coast to coast, and commercial mailers sometimes found it more efficient to send couriers.
In 1851, the drop-letter rate fell back to 1 cent, but the half-ounce rate was also reduced, to 3 cents for up to 3,000 miles, and to only 6 cents beyond 3,000 miles. Stamps were also being introduced, replacing the hand-written notations of fees paid.
The drop-letter rate changed once more, rising to 2 cents in 1863-65, to help pay for the costs of the Civil War. A black stamp showing Gen. Stonewall Jackson paid the rate. These stamps, known as Black Jacks, form a popular collecting study.
Hobbyists who want to know more about drop letters can write to The American Philatelist for reprints of a profusely illustrated article by Dr. James W. Milgram in September 1980. The address: Box 8000, State College, Pa. 16803. Linn's Stamp Almanac is available from Amos Press, Sidney, Ohio 45365.
A footnote: The basic letter rate of 1851 fell further, from 3 cents a half ounce to 2 cents in 1883, then 2 cents an ounce in 1885. It rose to 3 cents in 1917, and was not raised to 4 cents until 1958 - another long-lived rate, another column, someday. Rather than being taxed, business mailers today get deep discounts: if a company does the postal sorting chores itself, a 1-ounce letter can be sent 6,000 miles from Boston to Honolulu for 11 1/2 cents.

CORRECTION-DATE: January 28, 1990, Sunday, Late Edition - Final

 CORRECTION:
The Stamps column last week misidentified the man on the 2-cent ''Black Jack'' that paid the drop-letter rate in 1863-65. It was President Andrew Jackson, not Gen. Stonewall Jackson.
