HEADLINE: THEATER;
Driving 'Miss Daisy' From Here to There and Back

BYLINE: By MARILYN STASIO; Marilyn Stasio, the author of the Crime column for The New York Times Book Review, is a former theater critic.

 BODY:
After 15 months on the road, the national touring company of ''Driving Miss Daisy,'' starring Julie Harris and Brock Peters and featuring Stephen Root, closes today in New Haven. Charlie Willard, the company manager, will take down the photos in the theater lobby, settle up at the box office, check the company's travel arrangements and head for his cabin in the Adirondacks. He is trying to be philosophical.
''There's a peculiar romance about living under the pull and tug of the road-show moon,'' said Mr. Willard, whose job it was to supervise the administrative details at every stop along the 27-city cross-country tour. ''Its odd glow creates this illusion of intimacy, when you're separated from the realities of your own life. The show defines your identity and becomes your whole reason for being. Whatever town you're in, you never take off your logo showjacket.'' 
As the official representative of the show's producer, the company manager is the person who keeps the production on its feet and moving from city to city. From his catbird seat, Mr. Willard has watched the traditional road change, from a few central arteries on which shows once left New York to cross the country, into a network of local and national routes with more intersections than the old Erie-Lackawanna railroad line. His is also a job built for day-to-day crises, like the one that struck the 17-member ''Daisy'' company in San Francisco, when the death of Brock Peters's wife and the birth of Stephen Root's son disoriented the troupe and left Miss Harris performing in Alfred Uhry's three-character play with two understudies. ''That was the week that was,'' recalled Mr. Willard. ''The life force nipping at us from both ends.''
The 46-year-old company manager, who sports a well-chewed mustache and usually conducts business in a broad-brimmed leather hat, has stared down other life-and-death situations on the road - during tours of ''A Chorus Line,'' ''Company,'' ''The Belle of Amherst'' with Miss Harris and ''Gypsy'' with Angela Lansbury - and kept these and other shows rolling across the country without missing a date. But he had not done it in a long while; not since he left the road in 1981 to become an assistant professor in the drama department of Carnegie-Mellon University in Pittsburgh. He was coaxed away from academe for one more shot at the road by Miss Harris, whom he calls ''that rara avis - a genuine theater star,'' and for whom he has a deep affection. Besides, after spending almost a decade on high ground, he was curious about the changes he might find on the road.
''The main thing I discovered,'' said Mr. Willard in one of a series of interviews over the last six months, ''was that nobody is doing the traditional tour anymore.'' National tours used to spin off from original Broadway productions. Although somewhat scaled down for travel, they were produced by the same New York management, financed from profits of the Broadway production, supervised by the original creative team and often featured members of the Broadway cast.
First-class touring companies would play only major theaters in major cities. But in the case of a big hit, management often licensed independent producers to send out additional bus-and-truck companies. Socalled for their original mode of travel, these secondary but fully unionized tours would service smaller cities with productions trim enough to travel quickly on one-night stands and split-week engagements.
''Nowadays, national companies of the big musical hits don't really tour anymore,'' Mr. Willard said. ''They travel to a few big cities, like Los Angeles and Boston, and sit down. Elephantine road shows like 'Les Miz' and 'Phantom' - which are elaborate technical duplications of their originals - are no longer built to move in that swift, old-fashioned, road-show style. I remember a conversation with the company manager of 'Les Miz,' about the old split weeks we used to play. 'Split weeks?' he said, 'We're playing split years.' ''
Mr. Willard was more agreeably surprised to find that smaller cities he was seeing again for the first time in years - Bloomington, Ind., Kansas City, Mo., Wilmington, Del., Louisville, Ky. - had not lost their uniqueness. But he was saddened by the thinning ranks of ''mom and pop'' theater promoters, seasoned box-office treasurers and those colorful advance men producers once sent ahead to beat the drums for a new show coming to town. Though their functions are becoming obsolete because of newer, streamlined business procedures, in some cases, Mr. Willard said, local theatrical entrepreneurs are being ''pushed aside by the big monopolies.'' These large companies now produce most of the road attractions, which collectively earned an impressive $256 million in the 1988-89 season, according to Variety.
The source for these and other changes, Mr. Willard said, can be found in the larger economics of the theater industry. Broadway is producing less ''product'' for export, he noted, which invites longer runs of what is already out there. At the same time, new shows with the legs to travel take so long to recoup their original, multi-million-dollar investments on Broadway that producers are unable to stockpile the significant financing it takes to send out a national company. Rather than wait the years it may take to generate that kind of profit, management often prefers to license the touring rights to one of several large independent outfits like American Theater Productions, PACE Management Corporation and the Nederlander Organization. These producing managements may have no connections to the original shows, but they have considerable knowledge about how the new road works.
''Meanwhile,'' said Mr. Willard, ''as the major national companies get bigger and less mobile, the bus-and-trucks have taken over their one- and two-week cities. That leaves nonunion companies free to move into the old split-week tracks abandoned by the legitimate bus-and-trucks.'' To complicate matters further, noncommercial theater companies of diverse professional quality are often in residence at the same road-stop cities.
For the ''Daisy'' company, these tricky road tracks translated into some awkward logistics: They could not book Chicago or Atlanta, because smaller local companies had been licensed to do the play; and San Diego was out because a major resident theater production was scheduled.
Of more concern to Mr. Willard was the fact that local promoters are much less involved with the shows they present. ''That trend began,'' he said, ''when the traditional touring contract - a 75-25 split of the box-office income between the producer and the local promoter - gave way to the guarantee system, whereby the local promoter pays the producer a fixed amount, regardless of boxoffice proceeds.
''In order to meet these stiff guarantees, the promoter is under pressure to fuel his huge subscription series, which has become his money machine. The producer hides behind the guarantee, the presenter cowers behind his subscriptions, and nobody goes near the show.''
There are still many people on national road stops who love the theater, Mr. Willard said, and who take the time and care to tend shows properly. Among those ''steely independents,'' as he calls them, he mentioned local promoters in Baltimore and Boston who personally welcomed the ''Daisy'' company, worked on the show's local publicity and watched some performances. But for a number of reasons - computerized box offices, season subscriptions and the overall tendency toward centralization - many of the new faces that Mr. Willard met on the ''Daisy'' tour were buried up to their noses in computer printouts.
''The road,'' he said, ''is a much more polished and orderly place for this new breed of promoter, with their subscription lists and fax machines. Some of the old promoters - you used to have to meet them in a phone booth. But for all their marketing skills, many of these new people are not authentic theater animals. Like my old mentor, Jack Schlissel, was fond of saying, 'Some of these guys might as well be in lingerie.' ''
One happy surprise was the new generation of young professionals he discovered working in his own field. ''There is much more camaraderie today among road-show managers,'' Mr. Willard said, in part because of the apprentice program administered by their union, the Association of Theater Producers and Managers. ''The apprentices I've taught over the years are now full-fledged managers and criss-crossing all over the country,'' he said proudly. On the late-night phone network, their trade talk ranges from a hot tip about a tax scam being pulled by a theater out west to the information that a breakfast cereal called Birchermusli has appeared on a room-service menu in Grand Rapids.
Mr. Willard's main fear about going back on the road - that regions of the country would appear homogenous to him, after a decade's absence - proved unfounded. ''I was really heartened,'' he said, ''to see the different audience reactions to 'Daisy,' even among small cities in close proximity to one another.'' After watching the distress of elderly audiences in St. Petersburg, Fla., when Miss Daisy ended her days in a nursing home, he prevailed on his producers to allow Julie Harris to make a reassuring final bow without her makeup and gray wig.
''No matter how this country might appear to the traveler who stops at generic Holiday Inns and fast-food restaurants on the Interstate,'' he said, ''there are genuine regional and social differences out there, and a touring show must be sensitive to them.''
There are also thrills and chills. ''It still stirs the soul,'' he said, ''to arrive in a cold, empty theater at 8 A.M. and to be proudly flying your own little flag in that same space by 8 P.M. Seeing the scenery go up, watching the lights being focused, always brings back that primal sensation that you are, after all, putting on a show.
''And for all the changes that have come to pass under the road-show moon, there is still that one and only rock-solid and completely dependable rule in the commercial theater: sooner or later, the show always closes.''
 
GOODNIGHT, SWEET BOX OFFICE
 Charlie Willard, a company manager for many road tours, discovered some changes along the old routes when he took out the national company of ''Driving Miss Daisy'' 15 months ago. He also found that some of the familiar signposts were down.
 
 ''What I miss most of all on the road are box offices. And box office treasurers. And tickets - I mean, actual hard tickets that you can hold in your hand.
''There are no box offices on the road anymore. Oh, to be sure, there are still dimly lit rooms connected in some way to the lobbies of theaters. But they are closed up tight all day and apparently no one would think of actually buying a ticket there.
''These rooms flicker to some dim life about 7:00 every evening when a team of people arrive breathlessly trailing sheafs of computer printouts and a handful of computer-type tickets which they spread out on a table. Someone else arrives with a shoe box of 'will call' seats and sets up on a card table at the opposite end of the lobby.
''If you ask to see the 'deadwood' [tickets for unsold seats] for the performance, you are regarded with a look that dates you in some prehistoric era. For the fact is, deadwood is no more. Without those dead seats in your fist - capacity less remaining dead seats in hand equals tickets sold, is how it went - there is a terrible feeling of loss of control.
''The entire matter of selling and managing tickets to a show - once a finely practiced skill, if not an art - is just one more computer printout. Even the managers have gone from out front to backstage, where there is enough voltage to support their computers.
''Box offices were where you hung out, got a cup of coffee in the morning, picked up your mail, made your phone calls and read the papers. No point in being out front anymore if there are no box offices to hang out in.''

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
Want a Seat? They're Going For a Song

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris

 BODY:
Anybody want to buy a house? Or a seat? With share prices weakening last week as interest rates rose and housing starts hit a six-year low, the most depressing news at the New York Stock Exchange may have been the year's first sale of a seat in that august body. The price: $390,000, the lowest tab since 1985.
The record price of $1.15 million was paid on Sept. 21, 1987 - just ahead of the crash - when the Dow Jones industrial average was 2,492.82. Last week, after a bumpy ride, the Dow ended down 11.31, at 2,677.90. While many smaller stocks had rougher times - the American Stock Exchange market value index fell to a six-month low - the fact stock prices generally are high while seat prices are low shows that customers can do well even if brokers are being squeezed. And squeezed they are, trading fewer shares for smaller commissions. 
Rising interest rates from London to Tokyo also account for some of the depression on the Street. In this country, the yield on 30-year Treasury bonds, below 8 percent as 1989 ended, was up to 8.27 percent by Friday, when President Bush, speaking to the National Association of Homebuilders, declared he was for lower rates. Any other message would have been unthinkable in that forum, but it was nonetheless viewed as a broad hint to the Federal Reserve to back off and stop worrying so much about inflation.
The day before President Bush spoke, the Government reported that housing starts in 1989 fell to the lowest level since 1982, with an especially rapid drop in the Northeast as the year ended. Part of that may be weather-related, but another part reflects the tide of red ink at real estate lenders. Shares in the Bank of New England, by far the worst hit, fell $4.50 last week, to $2.875, amid rumors of more bad news. Whether the Fed can do much about that slump is another question. Interest rates could drop to zero without any new condos being built in much of Connecticut.
Maybe, just maybe, none of that is very important. Various real estate markets have run into trouble at different times in the past decade, without causing much alarm on Wall Street. Now, however, home prices are falling around New York and Boston, where many money managers live. ''Perspective is always toughest when the pain hits a little too close to home,'' said Stephen S. Roach, an economist at Morgan Stanley & Company. Nationwide, ''the housing market is not caving in,'' he said, adding that a better-balanced economy may result from ''the elimination of excesses in residential real estate markets.''
Builders will be forgiven if they see a lot of excesses as having vanished long ago. In 1982, when interest rates were sky-high and there was a recession, builders put up 320,000 apartments in buildings with five or more units. Last year, with rates much lower and no recession, the total came to 317,000.
Just how low would the figure go if we did get a recession, or if the recent rise in rates continued? The White House clearly would rather not find out. Fed-bashing season, it would appear, has arrived.

HEADLINE: World Markets;
Will Tokyo's Slide Snowball?

BYLINE: By Jonathan Fuerbringer

 BODY:
It is becoming a regular reflex to check the Nikkei 225 - Tokyo's closely watched stock index - early in the evening in New York. Since the beginning of the year, it has been plunging with regularity and has helped bring down many other major markets.
It seems fairly certain that if the declines continue in Tokyo they will continue elsewhere. But what is still open to debate is whether this Tokyo slide will be just a sharp correction or will snowball into a crash. 
One way to examine the question is to look at the bond market, whose sudden drop in Tokyo helped touch off the equity slump. Slumping bond markets elsewhere, including in Britain and France, are also contributing to the January chill in the markets.
This is the third time since 1985 that a global bond market slump has been set off by a sudden and sharp jump in Japanese interest rates.
The first time was in the fall of 1985, after the United States and its economic allies decided in the Plaza accord to force down the exchange value of the dollar, which was at record highs. In about four weeks, from mid-October to mid-November, interest rates on three-month yen deposits in Europe went from 6.5 percent to 8.12 percent while the yield on the 10-year Japanese Government bond, on a semi-annual compound basis, zipped up from 5.8 percent to 7.15 percent.
The move to tighten by the Bank of Japan came when the dollar, after dropping initially after the Plaza accord was announced, began to rise against the yen. But in about a month, with the yen again gaining on the dollar, interest rates had fallen and the bond market reversed. And there was no significant decline in the stock market.
The next jump in rates was, yes indeed, the one that preceded the October 1987 crash on Wall Street. It started in August, when the Bank of Japan was worried about inflation. Looking back, Nicholas Sargen, director of bond market research at Salomon Brothers, said there was no measurable sign of inflation in the price indexes. The Bank of Japan, however, focused on the rise in Japanese land prices and the ''speculative bubble in equities,'' in Mr. Sargen's words. Interest rates went from 3.94 percent to 4.95 percent on three-month yen deposits in Europe and from 4.44 percent to 7.16 percent on the 10-year Government bond from the end of August to Oct. 16. By the end of November, rates had fallen back to about where they had been, after the Bank of Japan eased up following the crash.
The third rate jump began in the middle of last month with three-month yen deposits at 6.5 percent and the 10-year bond at 5.37 percent. By Friday, three-month deposits had risen to 7 percent while the 10-year bond was at 6.4 percent. There have been stronger signs of inflation now than in 1987, although it may be subsiding a bit. Mr. Sargen again believes that the Bank of Japan has based its tightening move on rising land prices and the high stock prices in Tokyo. The bank's aim, he said, is to curb ''future inflation.'' In addition, the central bank is worried about the very weak yen, which was the problem in 1985.
The unknown is how long it will take for this rate increase to unwind and how much damage will be done to stocks in the interim.
Mr. Sargen said that the big difference between this episode and the one in 1987 is that there is not - at least now - international disagreement over policy, as there was among the United States, Japan and West Germany in the year of the crash.
Still, Mr. Sargen said it could be April or later before the Bank of Japan sees enough reassuring numbers on inflation to cause it to let interest rates come down some. And the weak yen could even prompt another ratcheting up in interest rates.
This means the pressure on the stock market could last much longer and the cumulative impact - both in Tokyo and abroad - could be significant.
The Nikkei is now at 36,836.54, having posted a rise Friday for the first time in five trading days. While the Nikkei 225 is down 5.3 percent for the year, Friday's level still implies that investors expect the interest rate jump to unwind quickly, limiting damage to the stock market. But if interest rates remain at this level for some time, the risk is that the Nikkei could fall much more.

HEADLINE: Mutual Funds;
Reassessing Eastern Europe

BYLINE: By Carole Gould

 BODY:
When the Iron Curtain ripped open, investment managers rushed through, seeking profits in the chaos of Eastern Europe. Shares in Hungary and Germany funds have been sold and plans are in the works for Poland and Berlin funds.
''With the outlook in Europe so bullish, everyone's trying to get in the door at the same time,'' said Thomas J. Herzfeld, a Miami-based investment adviser who said he had been contacted earlier this month by three international investment managers interested in setting up German funds. West Germany is widely viewed as a proxy for direct investment in the Eastern bloc. 
But even as some fund managers are trying to capitalize on Eastern Europe's social and economic upheaval, money managers say most investors would be better off moving carefully until some of the dust settles. For them, the best bets at the moment, advisers say, are international mutual funds that have European holdings.
Speculative investors and people interested in filling the high-risk part of their portfolio are likely investors in the new, closed-end funds. But such direct investment would be risky for most others, investment strategists say.
Eastern Europe opened for investment so recently that no one is sure what will happen, and investment managers are still experimenting with ways to tap into opportunities there. And, they say, don't expect quick returns from a region whose infrastructure has languished since World War II and whose experience with a free market economy is rusty at best.
''Direct investment would be a mistake now,'' said John Storkerson, a securities analyst with Putnam International Advisors in London, part of the Boston-based Putnam Companies.
Further, advisers say, the share prices of closed-end single-country funds are likely to drop as more funds are started up. Prices on these funds, which trade on listed exchanges like common stock, are set by supply and demand, and fund shares trade at a premium or discount to the value of the securities in their portfolios.
For example, the Germany Fund is trading at an 85 percent premium to its net asset value. At that rate, investors ''are buying guaranteed underperformance over the long term,'' Mr. Herzfeld said.
Returns on the fund, which is publicly traded, took a nose dive early this month when its sponsor, Deutsche Bank, unveiled plans for a second Germany fund. The price recovered, but investment returns may drop again as the field becomes more crowded.
Assessing other new funds is more difficult. Bear Stearns & Company, which handled the underwriting for the First Hungary Fund, raised $180 million for the closed-end mutual fund through a private placement that closed last October. But the fund is not publicly traded and performance data is not available. So far, there have been no resales, said Brian V. Murray, a managing director at Bear Stearns.
The Berlin Fund, sponsored by Masterfund Inc., a private investors' group in New York City, filed registration papers with the Securities and Exchange Commission in mid-January. Norberto Mehl, the fund's president, called it a closed-end mutual fund for long-term investors, but would not elaborate.
Sponsors of the Poland Fund, Alliance Capital Management, in New York City, would disclose even less about their plans. The name has been registered with the S.E.C., but Linda Finnerty, a spokewoman, would not say when the fund will be launched.
Given all the uncertainties with the single-country funds, money managers say investors interested in Eastern Europe should consider mutual funds that focus on European companies. Some of them, with their 1989 performance, as gauged by Lipper Analytical Services, are: the G.T. Europe Growth Fund, part of the G.T. Global Growth Series, which returned 40.71 percent; the Fidelity Europe Fund, which returned 32.33 percent, and Merrill Lynch EuroFund A, which returned 25.48 percent, and its EuroFund B, which returned 24.23 percent. Lipper's international fund average, which includes 79 international funds, returned 22.25 percent over the same period.
Another way to bet on the Eastern bloc is through European companies. Companies with a track record doing business behind the Iron Curtain are best positioned to profit from the pent-up demand there. One company Mr. Storkerson likes is Fiat, the Italian car maker.
Hakan Castegren, investment manager for the Ivy International Fund, in Boston, likes smaller companies positioned to fill moderate-sized capital goods orders. In Scandinavia, he favors Atlas Copco, producers of compressors and mining equipment, and Ericsson, a telecommunications company.

HEADLINE: Forging a Global Empire in a Sluggish Market

BYLINE: By LESLIE WAYNE

 BODY:
These are not the easiest of days for the Marriott Corporation, the largest hotel company in the world. The company's chairman, J. W. Marriott Jr., is recuperating from open-heart surgery. The Marriott hotel in Panama endured a harrowing seige during the United States invasion last month. Business at some of the company's lodging properties has been so sluggish that the company last month announced a $150 million write-down. And the company's stock has been flat for several years.
But these generally unrelated events pale against the new task that Marriott has set for itself. As part of a massive corporate restructuring, the company announced last month that it would lop off about $1 billion worth of businesses unrelated to hotels to concentrate on expanding its core lodging business.
Specifically, Marriott plans to expand into a far-flung global empire with hotels dotted across Europe and the Pacific Rim. It is stepping up its push into the budget segment by increasing construction of a variety of lower-priced motels. And it talks grandly about snapping up hotels that have faltered in the current soft real estate market and slapping the Marriott name on them. It is also setting up a beachhead in the ''senior life'' market with new, extended-care residences that combine apartment living with nursing home care. 
''When I think about the lodging business, I see a $50 billion industry and we are approaching about $4 billion,'' said William R. Tiefel, the president of Marriott Hotels and Resorts. ''So we have a rather modest representation in the total industry. I'd like to see numbers twice that and I think there's opportunity.''
Marriott recorded $7.4 billion in revenues in 1988, almost half of it in lodging, and was running at about the same pace last year. With some 451 properties and 118,000 rooms in the United States and 26 countries, it is the world's largest hotel operator. Over the last decade, it has been one of the most aggressive developers of hotels, due in large part to its practice of selling its properties as soon as they are built to investors, who pay Marriott a one-time development fee and an annual fee to manage the hotel. The technique frees up cash for Marriott to build and sell again.
But the strategy may not work so well in the current real estate slump. The hotel market is already severely overbuilt. Tax benefits in the mid-1980's for real estate investments led to free-wheeling lending to hotel developers by savings and loan institutions. Although demand for lodging climbed throughout the 1980's, the number of available hotel rooms increased even more dramatically, to 2.9 million today, according to Laventhol & Horwath, a Philadelphia-based consulting firm. As a result, industrywide occupancy rates fell steadily through the decade, to 63 percent, down from an average of 68 percent at the beginning of the 80's. Many weak properties have gone under, and with real estate investments less attractive under the 1986 tax reforms, the hotel boom came to a crashing halt.
Today, real estate financing is harder to come by. And that could also make it difficult for Marriott to sell off properties to raise the $1.5 billion a year it says it needs to build new hotels. ''To the extent they cannot sell off hotel properties on a consistent basis, it may mean that they end up owning them,'' said Michael G. Mueller, an analyst with Montgomery Securities in San Francisco. ''That means less capital for future expansion, which means they will have to lower their growth rate and their earnings could suffer.''
Marriott, however, argues that its properties have performed better than most, making them more attractive to investors. So far, the company's sales efforts have not been hampered. Over the last 12 months, Marriott has sold some $1 billion in hotels, about equal to previous years' sales. But in the last year or two, it has been forced to look for new investors to replace traditional ones like insurance companies and tax shelter investors. One promising new source is overseas investors, particularly the Japanese. Last November, Marriott sold four all-suite hotels for $100 million to a group of Japanese investors, and last September it entered into a joint venture with a different Japanese group to develop and sell $400 million worth of hotels in Europe. It is negotiating with yet another Japanese group for the sale of its $300 million convention center in San Francisco.
To Marriott's delight, the Japanese have been willing to forgo immediate cash returns for a greater stake in a hotel's later capital appreciation. But other investors have not been so willing.
So Marriott has had to structure its deals in different ways. For instance, it now accepts lower management fees, taking more of its return in tax benefits, so that investors can receive more of the cash flow from a property. While this does not affect Marriott's total return on a deal, it does reduce the company's reported net income in a given year.
In addition, some investors now demand that Marriott guarantee returns, particularly in the early years of a project. To cover any shortfalls between what it promises investors and what a hotel actually returns, Marriott sets aside more funds in reserve, thereby reducing the money it has to devote to new construction.
''We're not concerned about finding people to buy hotels. For us, it's a matter of how you structure the deal,'' said William J. Shaw, Marriott's chief financial officer. ''For instance, we didn't used to have to guarantee returns. But now, investors are concerned about getting guarantees for the first two or three years and we're providing them.''
But that is also why Marriott is taking write-offs against fourth-quarter 1989 earnings. Many of those $150 million in reductions stem from lower-than-expected occupancy rates at some properties, which, in turn, forced the company to live up to its guarantees or to loan investors money to cover their debt service on the properties with banks.
And Marriott's exposure to the vicissitudes of the real estate market are only going to increase. Under the recently announcecd restructuring, Marriott will sell its In-Flite Services, the airline catering group, to a management group for $570 million. And its 600-unit Roy Rogers fast food franchises and 434-unit family restaurant division, which includes Bob's Big Boy, Howard Johnson's and other brands, are also on the auction block. Marriott hopes to use the proceeds to pay down its $3 billion in debt.
But dependence on lodging will increase. ''My concern is with the economy,'' said John J. Rohs, an analyst with Wertheim Schroder & Company. ''Unless someone has repealed the law of cyclicality as it relates to lodging, their overall corporate business might be vulnerable to a slowdown.''
Marriott executives, however, argue that the restructuring rids the company of low-growth areas. The company would be left with only lodging, which in 1988 accounted for $3.1 billion of sales, and the $3.2 billion contract services group, which focuses on institutional food programs for hospitals, schools and corporations, and also includes Host International airport restaurants, toll-plaza restaurants and the new senior living retirement communities.
''By restructuring and spinning off 20 percent of our busineses, it's fair to say that we'll be able to spend more top management time on the areas that have high growth potential,'' said A. Bradford Bryan Jr., a Marriott executive vice president.
 
QUICK! HIDE IN THE WASHING MACHINE
It was 3:30 A.M. on Dec. 20, when Roger Conner, Marriott's public relations executive, was awakened from a sound sleep by the telephone. The United States had invaded Panama, said the caller, from the security desk. ''Our hotel there was front-and-center in some way,'' recalled Mr. Conner.
For a company not accustomed to being caught in a war zone, this was the start of a gruelling round-the-clock crisis. Mr. Conner and the other executive involved in handling the crisis, William R. Tiefel, Marriott's president of hotels, arrived at work within the hour find that the company couldn't get a phone line through to the hotel. According to news reports, 40 guests from the Panama hotel had been taken and released in an initial wave of hostage taking.
As American Telephon and Telegraph worked to get an open line through to the hotel, Marriott executives with Washington contacts placed frantic calls to the State Department and the Pentagon urging that the United States military in Panama get to the hotel and secure it.
At about 9:30 A.M., some of the Dignity Battalions loyal to Panama General Manuel Noriega burst into the hotel and demanded that Daniel Sarria, its manager, hand over the keys to the rooms of the 27 American guests. When Mr. Sarria refused, he was taken away, along with two journalists.
By about noon, an open phone link had been established and Mr. Sarria, who had escaped from his captors and returned to the hotel, began to hide the Americans, mostly journalists or flight crews from Eastern Air Lines. Spanish-speaking Americans were put into employee uniforms, others were hidden in laundry hampers and washing machines.
Through the day, Dignity Battalions showed up at the hotel, but never took control.
Meanwhile, Mr. Conner and his staff fielded some 200 calls from the press and friends and families of the hotel guests. ''We kept a speaker-phone in Daniel's office and every half hour or 15 minutes, he'd give us updates on where the Americans were, which we relayed to the family,'' Mr. Conner said.
Some of the calls were quite unexpected. Mr. Conner was startled by the large number of callers claiming to be paramilitary operators who had organized troops that could storm the hotel for Marriott.
Then, night fell. ''We'd hear gunfire through the speaker-phone and not know what was going on,'' Mr. Conner said. By midnight, the American troops arrived. The next day, as American soldiers stood guard, 36 Marriott employees and 27 Americans scrambled aboard two Marriott food service trucks, which whisked them to safety. The 13 other guests had already left.

HEADLINE: Raise 'User Fees' on Alcohol To Reduce Drinking-Related Problems

 BODY:
To the Editor:
''The King of Beers Raises the Ante'' (Dec. 24), describing Anheuser-Busch conveyed the beer giant's marketing muscle. Tactfully omitted, though, was the enormous human and economic toll related to drinking - 100,000 deaths and $135 billion each year. 
Anheuser-Busch dominates more than the beer market. According to our analysis of industry data, it accounts for 23 percent of all the alcohol Americans consume. Surely the King of Beers must share the blame for these tens of thousands of preventable deaths.
The enormous death toll linked to alcoholic beverages has spurred former Surgeon General C. Everett Koop, as well as dozens of health, consumer and parent groups, as well as elected officials, to support public policies that would reduce drinking-related problems. One key policy change would be to increase Federal ''user fees'' on alcohol (the Federal tax on beer - less than 3 cents a can - has not been raised since Harry Truman was President).
August A. Busch 3d might be bullish about his company's future, but growing citizen outrage, state and Federal budget deficits and a population with fewer people in the heavy-drinking college-age group all suggest that the sluggish beer market will be a shrinking one in the years ahead.
 
MICHAEL F. JACOBSON, PH.D.
Center for Science in the Public Interest Washington, Jan. 9

HEADLINE: Another Challenge of the 90's: Managing Information Technology

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Conspicuously missing among the challenges of the 1990's addressed by the three deans (''Shifting the Focus at B-Schools,'' Dec. 31.) is management of information technologies.
We are considered an ''information society'' characterized by rapid technological changes. The problems and tasks of the country revolve around planning, organizing, and managing the complex information flows emanating from the operations of business, government and social institutions worldwide. The success of an organization will depend on how well it mobilizes information technology to improve its overall performance in a competitive marketplace with fast-blurring national boundaries.
We have high regard for students. But their best-made career plans go awry when they are confronted with the rapidly changing situation in the job market, particularly since the supply often overshoots the demand. The time lag between their choice and the reality of the business world often works to their disadvantage. A more fundamental reason for not simply being demand-driven is that business schools must be on the forefront of analyzing the needs of society with a longer horizon. It is by anticipation, innovation and adaptation that we will offer the needed leadership in the wake of newer technologies in the 1990's.
 
SHASHI K. SHAH
Associate Professor, Computing
And Decision Sciences
School of Business
Seton Hall University
South Orange, N.J.
 
SUMITRA SHAH
Assistant Professor, Economics
St. Vincent's College
St. John's University
Jamaica, N.Y., Jan. 5

HEADLINE: Business Diary: January 14-19

BYLINE: By Allen R. Myerson

 BODY:

COMPANIES
 
Jumping In Where A.T.& T. Fell Down
Where telecommunications software engineers stumble, ad men rush in. The American Telephone and Telegraph Company's competitors moved quickly to exploit last Monday's breakdown in A.T.& T.'s long-distance network. ''An important message to everyone whose telephone is the lifeline of their business,'' said a full-page ad from the U.S. Sprint Communications Corporation. ''Always have two lifelines.'' Other advertisements featured the Sprint access code that A.T.& T. operators initially refused to provide. The MCI Communications Corporation took a lower-key approach. ''The facts speak for themselves,'' said Kevin Sharer, MCI's executive vice president. ''Large companies need more than one long-distance company.'' But MCI and Sprint also depend on complex computer programs, similar to those that failed at A.T.& T. A.T.& T., for its part, hopes to make amends with a Valentine's Day discount.
 
Reorganizing the Campeau Empire
The affairs of the Campeau Corporation's American retailing divisions are now under the direction of a Cincinnati bankruptcy judge and a former Federal Reserve chairman. A Monday bankruptcy filing will keep 260 Federated and Allied stores open while the company reorganizes. Campeau named G. William Miller chairman and chief executive of the retailing operations Tuesday. He has been president, chairman or secretary of nearly everything - the Federal Reserve Board, the Treasury Department, Textron Inc., his own merchant banking firm - except a major retailer. At Federated Department Stores and Campeau, he has been a director. 
* Most Bloomingdale's shoppers might scarcely notice the effects of Campeau's bankruptcy filing, but Wall Street's financiers will. The First Boston Corporation, with hundreds of millions of dollars at risk from financing Campeau's deals, removed William E. Mayer as its chief executive. Many of Campeau's junk bonds are worth a fraction of their original value, leaving several other investment firms with heavy losses.
 
Spinning Off, Close to Home
Tele-Communications Inc. plans to spin off its cable programming operations, but not spin them very far. The nation's largest cable company said Friday that both companies would remain under the command of John C. Malone, T.C.I.'s tough president. The move was a hit on Wall Street, where T.C.I. stock rose 2 5/8 to close at 17 3/8. The reaction in Washington is another question. Members of Congress who have cited T.C.I.'s size as a strong argument for tighter cable regulation might ask whether two T.C.I.'s are any less of a threat than one.
 
Singing the Fourth-Quarter Dirge
The chorus of fourth-quarter earnings reports last week sounded like a dirge: International Business Machines, down 75 percent to $591 million; Digital Equipment, down 45 percent to $155 million; Texaco Inc., down 3 percent to $287 million, and the AMR Corporation, down 67 percent to $39 million. David M. Jones, chief economist at Aubrey G. Lanston & Company, called corporate earnings ''one of the victims of a soft landing.
 
Layoffs and Buybacks
* Merrill Lynch & Company began laying off more than 3,000 people Thursday. Several top executives and investment bankers are being dismissed.
* The Consolidated Rail Corporation plans to buy back more than a third of its shares for about $1.3 billion, or $43 to $53 a share. Conrail's stock price has risen on takeover talk.
 
Bank Blues in the Northeast
The Bank of New England lost $1.2 billion in the fourth quarter, the worst in a series of weak performances by major banks. Citicorp also had deep losses, while earnings at the Chase Manhattan Corporation and J.P. Morgan sharply declined. The Bank of New England, buffeted by real estate problems, hopes to rescue itself by selling nearly a fifth of the company. Outside the Northeast, several banks, including BankAmerica and NCNB, reported surprisingly strong gains.
 
ECONOMY
 
Two Views on Inflation
The White House and the Federal Reserve do read the same economic reports, don't they? Last Thursday's news that the Consumer Price Index rose four-tenths of 1 percent in December prompted a Presidential spokesman to declare inflation under control. He advised the Federal Reserve to stoke the economy by lowering interest rates. In a speech Friday, President Bush called for lower interest rates. But the Federal Reserve seemed more concerned about fighting inflation than providing further stimulus. For the year, the C.P.I. climbed 4.6 percent - the highest rise since 1981. Economists say higher food and fuel prices resulting from December's cold weather will be evident in January.
 
Trade and Other Weaknesses
The trade deficit continues to worsen. November's $10.5 billion gap was the largest in 1989. Economists see little hope for improvement. ''I think it reflects a serous problem in competitiveness,'' said Lawrence Chimerine, senior economic advisor for the WEFA Group.
* Other figures from last week tended to point to weakness: 1989 housing starts of 1.39 million, the lowest since 1982; industrial production up four-tenths of 1 percent in December despite higher, winter-time electrical output and the end of the Boeing Company strike. But car sales for Jan. 1-10 rose a healthy 29.8 percent over a year ago.
 
Well, OPEC Must Be Happy
The United States is bound to depend more than ever on imported oil. As domestic production suffered a record annual drop last year, imports surged to 46 percent of the nation's needs - second only to the 47.7 percent total in 1977. Oil prices are too low to encourage drilling, and supplies in the United States are becoming harder to find. The nation's thirst for foreign oil is likely to aggravate the trade imbalance. Oil imports cost about $49 billion last year, about 44 percent of the deficit. Energy efficiency has been improving, but lower energy prices have weakened the drive for conservation. And the stronger the seller's market for oil, the easier the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries finds it to avoid divisiveness and limit production.
 
INTERNATIONAL
 
%U.S. Coming Apart in Chips
Woe to America's motorists if OPEC members ever learn to cooperate like the Japanese chip producers. The collapse of U.S. Memories, a joint American venture to make computer chips, leaves Japanese manufacturers as unified as ever. The major Japanese producers announced plans to cut back the supply of memory chips used in personal computers and appliances. A glut of these chips has lowered prices. The glut also convinced American chip-makers that their consortium couldn't recover its investment. But the Japanese took the fate of U.S. Memories as another bit of evidence that American businesses were too short-sighted to successfully compete.
 
A Merger, and New Money
* Rhone-Poulenc S.A., a chemical company owned by the French Government, agreed Thursday to buy the Rorer Group Inc. for $3.14 billion, or $73 a share. Rorer is to be merged with Rhone-Poulenc's pharmaceutical operations, creating a company with combined sales of of $3 billion in 1989.
* The Japanese Export-Import Bank, which has aided underdeveloped nations, is considering low-interest loans to help three underdeveloped American states. The Governors of Arkansas, Louisiana and Mississippi have discussed loans that probably would be used for roads, ports and business parks. The loans would be the first in an industrialized nation.
 
La Scala on the Amazon
Nashville has a replica Parthenon; Tokyo has its own Eiffel Tower. Now Manaus, Brazil, is trying to lure tourists 1,000 miles up the Amazon by restoring its 1896 copy of Milan's La Scala opera house. The Teatro Amazonas is a rain-forest apparition, a monument as vulnerable to termites and decay as the Manaus economy was to a plunge in the price of rubber. The American monuments of the 1980's - corporate headquarters, mansions, museums - may prove more durable than the junk-bond boom that that helped build many of them. But the rise, the near-fall and the revival of Manaus and its opera house offer a reminder of the force of economic cycles.

HEADLINE: Currency;
Drawing Strength From the Fed

 BODY:
It turned out to be an up week for the American dollar. While it was buffeted by news of the jump in the November trade deficit, the dollar was pushed higher by the growing belief that the Federal Reserve, concerned about inflation, would not be lowering interest rates any time soon. Firm interest rates tend to support the dollar. More support came from continued indications that the Bundesbank would not push interest rates any higher in West Germany, where the mark is felt to be strong enough. Meanwhile, the Canadian dollar was heading down, down, down. The Bank of Canada gave its first signal that it would let high interest rates there start to drop. In response, the Canadian dollar fell 2.3 percent against the American dollar, to 84.48 cents, from 86.40.

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
In Washington, It's the Year for Clean Air

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHABECOFF

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
UPON its return this week, the Senate will immediately face the moment of truth on strengthening the Clean Air Act, a goal that has eluded Congress for a decade.
Failure to act soon, the advocates of strong legislation warn, would condemn the nation to widespread deterioration of air quality.
Some describe the stakes as even higher. The Senate majority leader, George J. Mitchell, said Congress's ability to enact clean-air legislation this year is ''a test of our ability as a society to come to grips with problems that are part of what is now the most dangerous threat to our nation and our species.''
Each year since 1980, legislators have tried to amend the law. Each year they have failed in the face of conflicting regional interests; powerful, well-financed opposition by industry and, during the Reagan years, a hostile White House. 
But President Bush, far from hostile, put forth his own broad proposal last year. Industry is still spending large amounts of money to fight specific proposals, but corporate leaders are taking pains to voice support for a stronger law. And while some Midwestern states that would bear a substantial economic burden continue to voice opposition, they are isolated politically.
If, given the active encouragement of the President, the enthusiastic support of the majority leader and the Speaker of the House, the demands of the public for cleaner air and an industry that gives at least lip service to a more stringent law, Congress cannot pass strong legislation this year, it is hard to see how it could at any time in the foreseeable future.
''Who is going to vote for dirty air?'' asked Senator Max Baucus, Democrat of Montana and chairman of the Senate's environmental protection subcommittee.
But there will be some obstacles. One is a dispute over costs and benefits that has already erupted here. On Friday, Mr. Bush sent a letter to Senate leaders warning that he could not accept a bill whose costs exceed those in his legislation. Administration officials said the cost of the Senate bill to industry and consumers would be about $40 billion a year by 2000. The President's bill, they contended, would achieve virtually the same goals for about half the cost.
The House of Representatives must also approve legislation this year, and a House subcommittee has reached a compromise that removes one longstanding obstacle to action on auto emissions.
The existing law has produced modest improvements in air quality and has held in check the clouds of pollution that would otherwise have been spewed into the atmosphere. But the statute, passed in 1970 and last amended in 1977, left some major pollution problems unaddressed and proved inadequate to deal with others.
The Senate bill, like the President's legislation and a bill pending in the House of Representatives, would address several forms of pollution: Acid Rain The 1970 law required industry to clean up pollution in the immediate vicinity of its source. Many polluters, particularly big, coal-fired power plants, did so by sending emissions through tall smokestacks, which dispersed the pollutants over a wide area. Sulfur and nitrogen oxides are transformed chemically in the atmosphere and return to earth as acidic rain, snow and dust. This pollution, much of it emanating from the Midwest, has been found to damage freshwater life and buildings in the Northeast and Canada, and it may be detrimental to human health.
The Senate bill and the Bush legislation would require that by 2000, 107 big power plants in the Midwest reduce sulfur emissions by 10 million tons a year, or about half the amount they are now releasing. After that, total sulfur emissions could not exceed the levels of 1980. It would also require that nitrogen oxide emissions be reduced by 2 million tons by 2000, a somewhat deeper cut than envisioned by the Administration's proposal. The legislation would give utilities credits for reducing pollution below required limits, and these credits could be sold or traded to other polluters.
 
Smog
Volatile chemical vapors from auto exhaust and similar pollution from industrial and commercial sources, reacting with sunlight, create the smog that chokes many urban and suburban areas. Smog was limited by the law's requirements that car manufacturers install devices to reduce tailpipe emissions. But with a rapidly growing number of cars on the road each driving more miles, the requirements have proved inadequate. More than 100 major cities now exceed the maximum permissible smog levels at some point during the year.
Under the Senate bill, car makers would have until 1995 to reduce their vehicles' hydrocarbon and nitrogen oxide emissions to levels currently required by California. They would have to make a second round of emissions cuts by 2000. The Administration called for only the first round of reductions but also proposed requiring auto makers to produce a certain number of cars that run on fuels that pollute less than gasoline.
 
Toxic Chemicals
The 1970 law called on the Environmental Protection Agency to regulate hundreds of dangerous chemicals such as benzene and butadiene. The agency has taken action on only eight chemicals, however, in part because the law's mandate is ambiguous and agency officials have been unable to devise an effective regulatory approach.
The Senate bill would require polluters to install the ''maximum available control technology'' to reduce emissions of the 187 chemicals deemed most dangerous to health over the next seven years, twice the number of chemicals proposed by the Administration.
 
Global Pollution
The Senate bill would reduce carbon dioxide emissions by imposing stricter fuel efficiency standards on motor vehicles. Carbon dioxide is the most important of the industrial gases that scientists believe are causing long-term warming of the globe by trapping heat from the sun. The bill would also ban all emissions of chlorofluorocarbons, chemicals that deplete the protective ozone layer in the upper atmosphere and contribute to the greenhouse effect.
These provisions would add up to major progress in cleansing the skies. They also would cost a lot more than the $35 billion a year the country is currently spending to improve air quality.
Corporate spokesmen and some Administration officials are saying the cost of the Senate bill would hurt industry's ability to compete in international markets.
''I don't want to be harsh, but that is a lot of nonsense,'' replied Senator John H. Chafee, Republican of Rhode Island and co-sponsor of the legislation. ''We will be able to keep a lot of people healthy by cleaning up the air and spend a lot less money on medical bills.''
The American Lung Association issued a report on Friday that concluded that the health costs associated with air pollution are now $40 to $50 billion a year, more than the cost of the Senate bill. The association's estimate does not include the costs of damage to buildings, crops and forests.
But the costs of the new requirements would fall unequally on different areas of the country and different industries. The brunt of the acid rain costs, for example, would fall on a handful of Midwestern states. The changes could cost jobs in states like West Virginia that produce high-sulfur coal. These states ask that the costs be shared by the whole country. States that have already reduced pollution demur, saying they should not have to pay for cleaning up a second time.
Such issues will produce spirited debate. Some Senators have threatened to filibuster. It seems unlikely, however, that, after 10 years of spinning in place, Congress will fail to act on clean air now that all the political signs are in proper alignment.
''If Congress doesn't succeed this time, I don't know what it will take for them to succeed in the future,'' said S. William Becker, executive director of the State and Territorial Air Pollution Control Officers. ''All that is left for them to do now is political posturing and horse trading.''
 
A FEW ADJUSTMENTS ARE CALLED FOR
If the Clean Air Act amendments now being taken up by the Senate become law, the effects would soon be visible in the lives of most Americans. Many proposals involve motor vehicles, which cause much of the nation's air pollution. Here are some likely repercussions:
* Electric bills for many customers in the Midwest would rise as public utilities are forced to install expensive scrubbers or shift from high-sulfur coal to more costly low-sulfur grades. There is some dispute over how much electric bills would go up, but in some cases the increase would be 20 percent or more.
* The price of automobiles would go up as new equipment required by the amendments to cut exhaust emissions and to recover gasoline vapors during refueling is installed. Estimates of the costs vary, but they would probably be about $250 per car by 2000, or, as a Senate staff aide noted, about the cost of one power window.
* Service stations would be required to install special suction devices on pumps, also to catch gasoline fumes.
* Cities that do not meet the standards on air quality would be required to set aside car pool lanes on the biggest commuter arteries. Employers would also be required to set up car pools.
* Large cities not in compliance with the air standards would have to switch their bus fleets to fuels like methanol or natural gas that pollute less than gasoline. The change would have to be accomplished by 1994.
* To reduce the carbon dioxide pollution that is contributing to the greenhouse effect, manufacturers would have to build cars that require less gasoline per mile driven. Each car-maker would have to achieve an average of 33 miles a gallon by 1996 and 40 miles a gallon by 2000. Auto fleets now average about 28 miles a gallon.

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
Senator Dole's Jackpot Question On Foreign Aid Stirs Up Congress

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
SENATOR BOB DOLE set off a stormy debate on foreign aid last week by saying aloud something that has only been whispered on Capitol Hill: Given the limited resources the United States has for foreign aid, wouldn't it make sense to cut by a mere 5 percent the grants made to Israel and the four other largest aid recipients, reallocating that money to Eastern European countries and Panama?
Why did such a furor result from a suggestion that only involved $330 million out of a foreign aid budget of $14.6 billion? Because the proposal was not just about this year's international assistance budget.
It was also about who should have the right to determine where foreign aid goes - Congress or the Administration. In addition, it was about Israel, and whether the $3 billion it has been receiving annually as the largest American aid recipient should be re-examined. And finally, it raised the issue of how the United States is going to help the nations of Eastern Europe from a foreign aid pie that does not seem able to grow larger. 
Ever since 1985 and the imposition of the Gramm-Rudman deficit spending ceiling, the foreign aid budget has remained largely fixed. It would be nice if the budget could be enlarged, said Mark L. Edelman, Deputy Administrator of the Agency for International Development. ''But that just isn't going to happen,'' he said. ''If we want to increase one country, we are going to have to take it from another.''
That means the Administration faces nearly impossible choices. ''We're now forced to decide which women and children get to be in the lifeboat,'' said Mr. Edelman. ''Who knows what will happen next year. Will Albania ask for aid? Will Outer Mongolia? Will Cuba? Who would have guessed Eastern Europe this year?'' He continued, ''We now have a foreign aid crisis and my hope is that because of it, Congress will re-examine the constraints and limitations it has imposed on foreign aid allocations.''
This raises another of Mr. Dole's points. What complicates life for the Administration is not simply that so many new countries are deserving of foreign aid, but that Congress each year insists on choosing which countries will get aid and how much they'll get, leaving the Administration with little discretion or flexibility when the world suddenly changes.
The process of putting the bill together begins each year in January when the President submits his budget to Congress; then, various Government agencies suggest where they think the money should be spent. A season of horse trading then begins among the Administration, Congress and various lobbies, ''earmarking'' exactly who will get what. By the end of the year, a spending bill is worked out.
 
'Where Was Bob Dole?'
Mr. Dole suggested that the President exercise his authority within the foreign aid legislation to override some designations and reallocate funds to make more aid available to Eastern Europe. That authority is only to be used in exceptional cases. The Administration hailed the proposal, which it had discussed with Mr. Dole ahead of time. But few in Congress are ready to give the Administration such freedom.
''Where was Bob Dole when the earmarking was going on?'' asked Representative David R. Obey, the Wisconsin Democrat who leads the House subcommittee on Foreign Operations, which oversees foreign aid. ''When the foreign aid bill was in conference I was fighting mightily to resist Senate earmarks. I don't remember one minority member raising his voice in that conference against earmarks. I would suggest that Mr. Dole ought to get involved in the process beforehand rather than sneaking around afterwards and trying to change the arrangements.''
Mr. Dole's proposal was viewed in some pro-Israel quarters as a veiled attack on their lobby. Many Congressmen think Israel's annual $3 billion allocation has become an entitlement program Jerusalem takes for granted, and they quietly cheered Mr. Dole's suggestion to do something about it.
But this argument ignores the fact that foreign aid in general is unpopular, and that specific constituencies are needed to push the whole program through. ''Aid to Israel is the locomotive that drives the whole foreign aid train,'' said Douglas M. Bloomfield, a former lobbyist for the American Israel Public Affairs Committee. ''If you take the locomotive off the tracks, what happens to the rest of the train? When it comes time to actually get the foreign aid bill passed, if you stood outside the door of the conference room and took away the friends of Israel, you would be awfully lonely.''
This may be true, some Congressional experts say, but if aid to Israel were reduced slightly and the difference spread around Eastern Europe, would Israel's allies stop lobbying for aid?
Mr. Dole's suggestion may also have had a diplomatic objective.
His proposal surfaced only days after Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d ''hit the ceiling,'' according to an official, after reading comments attributed to an aide to Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir of Israel suggesting that Mr. Baker was not serious about advancing the Middle East peace process. Mr. Baker, who has devoted a great deal of time trying to advance Mr. Shamir's proposal for Palestinian elections in the West Bank, had his department issue a statement the next day saying that ''there are many other areas in the world clamoring for his attention'' and that unless he sees ''the kind of impulse that will produce change in the Middle East'' he may not have much time any more to devote to that part of the world. Mr. Shamir got the message and came out the next day to express appreciation for Mr. Baker's efforts.
Nevertheless, the observation by the State Department spokeswoman, Margaret D. Tutwiler, that Senator Dole's proposal was ''well worth looking at'' may be seen, in part, as a reminder from the Bush Administration to Israel that if it does not get more serious about its own peace plan, not only the Administration's energies - but also some resources - may be directed elsewhere.

LENGTH: 1451 words

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
Prof. Moynihan Wakes the Class With Truth About Taxes

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
DANIEL PATRICK MOYNIHAN, Ph.D., was a professor before he became a Senator. Although his recent proposal to cut Social Security taxes has turned out to be a clever political stroke that has embarrassed President Bush, it was meant mostly as a teaching device. Angry and frustrated that no one seemed to be listening to his economics lessons, the New York Democrat chose a sharp political instrument to make these blunt points about economics:
* Despite Republican claims, Federal taxes overall were not cut in the Reagan-Bush years. What happened was the burden of taxation was shifted from the income tax to the Social Security tax. Counting their employers' share, nearly three-quarters of all Americans now pay more in Social Security taxes than they do in income taxes.
* One result is that the expenses of Government are financed more by a tax on the poor and the middle class and less by a tax on the wealthy. Another result is that surplus revenues in the Social Security system are being used to mask the deficit in the Government's operating budget instead of being used as they were intended, to guarantee pension benefits for today's workers when they retire. 
Those are facts, but most taxpayers seem not to have grasped them. A New York Times/CBS News poll found that 64 percent of adults believe that they and their families pay more in income taxes than in Social Security taxes and that 78 percent would prefer a cut in the income tax to a cut in the Social Security tax. The telephone poll, conducted Jan. 13 to 15 with 1,557 adults nationwide, has a margin of error of plus or minus three percentage points.
Mr. Moynihan's proposal to reduce the Social Security tax by more than $60 billion over the next two years is not likely to become law. But even if he loses that battle, he seems to have won his personal war by calling attention to the way the system works. His proposal created such political waves that it has gained an inordinate amount of attention in recent weeks.
Ronald Reagan and George Bush were elected in large part because of their opposition to tax increases. But Federal tax revenues now stand at just under 20 percent of the gross national product, the same as at the beginning of the 1980's.
Income taxes were indeed sharply lowered. The top rate for individuals is 28 percent now, down from 70 percent at the beginning of the 1980's. The corporate rate also dropped substantially. As a share of Federal revenue, personal income taxes fell by 6 percent during the Reagan years and corporate income taxes fell by 23 percent.
At the same time, the share of Federal revenue coming from Social Security taxes rose 23 percent. As of Jan. 1, workers and their employers each pay 7.65 percent on payday, 6.2 percent for retirement under Social Security and 1.45 percent for Medicare, the health insurance program for the elderly and disabled. The tax is paid on the first $51,300 of wages. At the beginning of the last decade, the total payroll rate was 6.13 percent on the first $29,700 of wages.
Economists agree that if employers did not have to contribute their share, workers could demand and generally receive most if not all of that money in higher wages. Thus, they maintain, the payroll tax rate now is effectively 15.3 percent.
Unlike income taxes, which are levied at higher rates as a taxpayer's earnings increase, Social Security taxes are not only cut off at $51,300 but are also paid at the same rate by all workers and apply only to wages - not to interest, dividends, capital gains, rental receipts and other forms of income that are enjoyed largely by the well-to-do. This year, the maximum payroll tax will total $3,924.45.
What that means is that a husband and wife earning $30,000 each, say a pair of schoolteachers, pay more in Social Security taxes than a single person who earns 10 times that much. That person would not pay any Social Security tax at all if the income is from investments rather than a salary.
The other notion that Senator Moynihan is trying to drive home is that the growing surplus of Social Security revenue, $65 billion this year and a projected $200 billion or more by the turn of the century, is being used to mask the size of the deficit in the Government's operating budget. The main reason why the overall Federal budget deficit has decreased in the last few years is not so much because of reduced spending as it is because of increased Social Security revenues. And they will increase further; in 1993, the Government will collect about $100 billion more in Social Security taxes than it will pay out in benefits.
Using today's Social Security revenue to pay for everything from jet fighters to thumbtacks is, in Mr. Moynihan's view, a perversion of the reason given in 1983 for scheduling periodic increases in the payroll tax. That was done primarily to guarantee benefits for the generation of workers that will retire early in the next century. The Senator was a member of the Presidential commission that established the new rates.
The way the Social Security system works is complicated and often misunderstood. The idea that workers' payroll taxes are placed in a trust fund to pay for their own retirement is a fiction. Social Security has always been a pay-as-you-go system. Each generation of workers pays Social Security taxes to finance the older generation's retirement.
When more money is received in Social Security taxes than is needed for benefits, as is the case now, the surplus is used to buy Treasury bonds. If there were no deficit in the Government's day-to-day operating budget, all the surplus could be used to buy Treasury securities held by private lenders. Those lenders' money would then be invested in plants, equipment and other productive private enterprises, stimulating growth in the entire economy.
 
Stoking the Economy
The theory behind the payroll tax increases that began in 1983 was to allow more money to be invested in productive ventures so that the economy would grow, making it easier for the children of baby boomers to meet the huge cost of pension payments. The Government will have to tax or borrow enough in the next century to meet retirement obligations in any case, but the stronger the economy is, the easier that task will be.
President Bush, embarrassed by having been one-upped on a tax issue, charged last week that Senator Moynihan's proposal for a payroll tax cut was a ''charade'' that would lead to a tax increase elsewhere or lower retirement benefits. The Senator strongly opposes reduced pensions, but said he would accept an increased income tax or a higher gasoline tax if the President would go along.
Other Democrats, while delighting in the discomfort the proposal has caused the President, have declined to sign on to the Moynihan plan. They say that a cut in Social Security taxes, like any other tax cut, would force the Government to borrow even more than it already does, draining private savings and seriously damaging the economy.
Mr. Moynihan agrees with the economics of that analysis. But he added in an interview, ''If we have to go through a small crisis to straighten things out, fine, let's do it.''
 
A CRUTCH FOR THE BUDGET
The surplus funds collected by Social Security are being used to offset a significant share of the budget deficit.

SECTION: Section 4; Page 20, Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 430 words

HEADLINE: Why So Rigid on Eastern Europe?

 BODY:
Eastern Europe's courageous effort to leap from controlled to market economies creates a desperate need for Western help. It would be tragic if ideological rigidity blocked that aid.
The question is whether the West should lend money for public as well as private investment projects. It should. But at a recent East-West meeting to create an Eastern European development bank, the U.S. and Britain reportedly said no. This is no time for pointless intransigence. It can only jeopardize fragile political and economic reforms. 
The insinuation of market forces into centrally controlled economies will be painful. Consumers and producers must be weaned from government subsidies. Prices will soar; bankruptcies and unemployment will become commonplace. The West can't eliminate this pain. But it can dull the hurt.
A wise way to help was outlined in October by President Francois Mitterrand of France. The West could create a development bank that would extend loans in exchange for democratic reforms. The bulk of the loans, all agree, should go to the private sector. The disagreement is whether loans should also go to governments - for highways, dams and other public investments.
The Bush Administration evidently fears that public investments will inevitably overwhelm the new development bank's limited resources. It also fears a repeat of the 1970's, when Eastern Europe squandered Western loans.
But there has now been a dizzying set of economic and political changes. The 1970's are a poor guide to the 1990's. Private enterprise cannot emerge without suitable public infrastructure. Investments in both sectors are necessary. And Eastern Europe cannot do it alone.
Making wise loans will not be easy. With only primitive markets to guide the way, investors will be unable to discriminate productive from wasteful proposals. The absence of suitable copyright, patent and other legal protections compounds the problem. That is why a development bank to negotiate safeguards makes good sense.
To ease its task, the bank should be saddled with few rules. The West can rightfully insist that assistance be conditioned on democratic political reforms and viable economic policies. That means eventually creating workable price systems and convertible currencies.
Beyond these basic requirements, the bank's directors will have to appraise private and public projects on a case-by-case basis. But to eliminate public projects arbitrarily is to impose an ideological litmus test that makes no sense when the larger goal is to preserve budding democratic reforms.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: Q and A

BYLINE: By CARL SOMMERS

 BODY:

Entry to East Germany
Q. Now that travel between the two Germanys is unrestricted for German citizens, what are the requirements for foreigners traveling to and in East Germany? Will I still have to exchange a certain amount of money for each day I am there? - V. H., Putnam Valley, N.Y.
A. East Germany has dropped the requirement that foreigners entering the country convert to East German marks the equivalent of about $15 for each day in the country. Otherwise, East Germany has retained its entry requirements.
Those traveling to East Germany must first book hotel accommodations through an American travel agent. Those staying at private residences must apply for permission through a travel agent or the East German Embassy (Embassy of the German Democratic Republic, 1717 Massachusetts Avenue, N.W., Washington, D.C. 20036; 202-232-3134). Hotel bookings can take 10 days to several weeks; approval for a stay at a private residence takes up to eight weeks. When travelers enter East Germany and show vouchers confirming their arrangments for accommodations, they will be given a visa, cost about $8. Visas are good for one entry only. Travel inside East Germany is not restricted, except that travelers must stay in the hotels or private residences listed on their visa applications. 
Despite the numerous new crossing points along the East Berlin-West Berlin border, Americans still must enter East Berlin at Checkpoint Charlie or the Friedrichstrasse subway station. On showing their passports, Americans get a permit for a day trip. Americans traveling by car or train through East Germany en route to West Berlin get transit visas at the border. Such drivers must stay on special routes marked ''transit.'' Those flying into West Berlin do not need visas.
 
Carry-On Bag Dimensions
Q. I need to have a case constructed for the photo gear I take along on my travels. What is the largest size permissible for carry-on luggage? - M. M., Pinellas Park, Fla.
A. It is difficult to specify dimensions if you will be storing your case in the overhead compartment, as there are at least 15 types of aircraft used by the major airlines, and the overhead compartments of each are a different size. But airlines require that heavy items like camera cases be stored under the seat, for the safety of passengers. The size of the space under seats is standard: the total of the measurements of the length, width and depth of a bag must not exceed 45 inches; but bear in mind that the space under airline seats usually is not more than 9 inches.
 
Ice-Skating in Europe
Q. I will be living in Europe this winter and spring and would like to attend some ice-skating competitions. Could you tell me about events coming up? - E. S., New York, N.Y.
A. Listed below are the major competitions coming up in Europe. Whenever possible, where to get tickets and their prices are included. National figure skating associations are provided in other cases; they will be helpful in providing ticket information. Telephone numbers include country and city codes for calls from the United States.
The European Figure Skating Championships will take place Jan. 30 to Feb. 4 in Leningrad. U.S.S.R. Skating Federation, 8 Lazhnetskaia, Moscow 119871; telephone, 7-095-201-0854.
The Nordic Figure Skating Championships will be held Feb. 10 and 11 in the Helsinki Ice Stadium (Helsingin Jaahalli), at 11-13 Nordenskioldinkatu; 35-80-418122. Tickets, $9 to $13, will be sold at the stadium.
The Sofia Press Cup competition takes place Feb. 16 to 18 in Sofia, Bulgaria, with ladies' and men's figure skating and ice dancing. Bulgarian Skating Federation, 18 Tolbukhin, 1000 Sofia; 359-2-8651. The Basler Cup, an international ice-dancing competition, will be held Feb. 17 and 18 in Basel, Switzerland. The events will be at Margarethen Park, telephone 41-61-35.95.95. Tickets are $6.70 a day, $15 for both days.
A junior ladies' figure skating competition will take place in Brassanone, Italy March 30 and 31. Italian Ice Skating Federation, 44/B Via Piranesi, 1-20137, Milan; 39-2-76110261.
In Gdansk, Poland, an international senior ice-dancing competition March 30 to April 1 also includes junior ladies' and men's pair skating and juniors' ice dancing. Polish Figure Skating Association, 6A Lazienkowska, 00-449 Warsaw; 48-22-289806.
In Grenoble, France, a senior ice-dancing competition will be held April 5 to 8. Tickets, $13 to $21, are available, starting next month, from Serge Bouquet, 40 Boulevard Clemenceau,38000 Grenoble, France; 33-76-54.67.80, as of February 1990. Credit card payments will be accepted by telephone.
 
Argentine Money Exchange
Q. I am getting conflicting messages about the best method of changing money in Buenos Aires and whether to take money in cash or traveler's checks. - W.G.S., Westport, Conn.
A. Since Dec. 15, the exchange rate has been freed in Argentina. This means the rate may vary greatly from day to day, but there should not be much difference among the various exchange offices and banks. Since banks in Argentina are notoriously slow and bureaucratic, one of the exchange houses in the financial district around San Martin and Corrientes Streets is probably the best bet. Most big hotels have an exchange window offering a competitive rate. There is also an exchange window on the right as you leave customs in the Buenos Aires airport. Buying australs, the national currency, before leaving the United States is not recommended because the rate changes so rapidly.
It is a good general rule for the sake of security to use traveler's checks, but many travelers to Argentina find it convenient to bring American cash, in a variety of denominations, 1-, 5-, 10- and 20-dollar bills. Many merchants still prefer dollars, and some goods, such as and the silver and old jewelry in Buenos Aires's antiques markets, are priced in American dollars. The singles can be used for tips.
Another bit of advice: take enough money to cover all your expected expenses and don't count on being able to use credit cards in Argentina; many establishments do not accept them when inflation soars. Moreover, it may not be a good idea to use them, because you will not know the exchange rate at which you will be billed when the transactions are calculated; the exception is major hotels, many of which which set rates in dollars.
