SECTION: Section 7; Page 15, Column 1; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 1700 words

HEADLINE: IN THE GRIP OF THE NAZI PAST

BYLINE: By ALAN BRINKLEY; Alan Brinkley is a professor of history at the Graduate School of the City University of New York.

 BODY:

20TH CENTURY JOURNEY
A Memoir of a Life and the Times.
Volume Three: A Native's Return, 1945-1988.
By William L. Shirer.
Illustrated. 484 pp. Boston:
Little, Brown & Company. $24.95.
In 1985, at the age of 81, weakened by heart trouble and with fading vision, William L. Shirer returned to Berlin for the first time in nearly four decades. It was the occasion of President Ronald Reagan's controversial visit to a World War II cemetery in Bitburg, West Germany, where German soldiers, including members of the SS, were buried. Mr. Shirer had accepted an invitation from his former employer, CBS, ''to comment on German reaction . . . and see how the Germans were faring forty years after the end of Hitler.'' He left the country profoundly depressed. He was alarmed that Mr. Reagan had chosen to excuse the Nazi war dead as ''victims'' of the evil of ''one man,'' when in reality, Mr. Shirer had always believed, the German nation was deeply complicit in Hitler's crimes. But Mr. Shirer was far more disturbed by what he took to be the attitude of the German people, by what he considered their eagerness to forget, even in some cases to forgive, the Nazi past. (He will not, one assumes, be much encouraged by the present enthusiasm for German reunification.) For Mr. Shirer, facing the German past is not only a moral necessity, it is a thread that has run through his entire adult life. That is nowhere clearer than in ''A Native's Return,'' the third and final volume of his lengthy memoirs, ''20th Century Journey.'' He writes of his experiences since 1945, virtually all of them in the United States. But even here, his thoughts seldom stray far from the Germany that he covered in the 1930's and 40's as a radio correspondent for CBS and that he chronicled in 1941 in his first book, ''Berlin Diary.'' Much of this new memoir consists of meditations on the great evil he had witnessed in his youth, the enormity of which he still cannot fully comprehend. Much of it consists of recapitulations of pieces of Nazi history, which he has spent much of his adulthood reconstructing. And much of it consists of an account of the writing and reception of his celebrated 1960 book, ''The Rise and Fall of the Third Reich,'' which remains the cornerstone of his large reputation.
Wading through this sprawling autobiography makes clear, however, that Mr. Shirer's preoccupation with Germany is not just a reflection of his fascination with the Nazi past. It is also a reflection of his own difficulties in coming to terms with the America he encountered when he returned home in 1945. Above all, perhaps, it reflects his enduring bitterness at having been dismissed by CBS in 1947 and blacklisted throughout the broadcasting industry for the next 15 years - an experience that shattered his professional life, his financial security and many of his personal relationships and that ultimately helped push him toward the writing of his most famous and successful books.
Mr. Shirer's account of the CBS incident is the most original and important section of this shapeless but intermittently interesting book. Like his colleague and close friend Edward R. Murrow, Mr. Shirer returned to New York after the war as one of the most honored figures in broadcast journalism. For several years he was a popular, successful and well-paid radio commentator and newspaper columnist, much in demand on the lecture circuit. Then suddenly he found himself removed from the air and, in effect, fired by CBS. He has, he claims, never understood why. A clue to Mr. Shirer's plight, although he himself does not identify it as such, may be his relatively benign view of the postwar Soviet Union. Mr. Shirer opposed containment and many of the other cold war policies the United States was embracing in 1946 and 1947, and he spoke openly of his scorn for what he considered hysterical fears of Russian militarism and domestic subversion. Nothing in his past and nothing in his public statements suggested that he had ever been a Communist, a fellow traveler or even a serious dissident. But in the superheated atmosphere of the late 40's, being simultaneously an important public figure and a critic of cold war orthodoxy was, apparently, enough to destroy his career.
Mr. Shirer's recounting of Edward R. Murrow's role in his demise at CBS may come as a shock to those who revere Murrow as the saintly patriarch of broadcast journalism. Murrow, a vice president of CBS at the time, clearly acquiesced in Mr. Shirer's ouster, probably in response to pressures from nervous sponsors and William Paley, the head of the network. But Murrow also, apparently, made vigorous efforts to defend himself and the network from criticism by actively blackening the reputation of a man who had been a close friend for more than a decade. ''What had they done to Ed Murrow up on the nineteenth floor amid the nineteen vice presidents?'' Mr. Shirer asks. ''I was appalled by his disregard for the truth.'' Years later, after Murrow himself had been eased out of CBS in the wake of his own belated attack on McCarthyism, he offered Mr. Shirer a muted apology. And as he died of cancer in the 60's, he attempted to effect a reconciliation. But while Mr. Shirer is generous in his assessment of Murrow's many accomplishments, his stark account of the CBS imbroglio is harsh and unforgiving.
Nothing in Mr. Shirer's account of his subsequent life matches the passion and vividness of his story of the events of 1947. He describes in almost gruesome detail his long struggle to make a living by writing books, lecturing and pursuing other consistently unsuccessful moneymaking schemes. He discusses the inception of each of his books, recapitulates something of their contents and then offers an exhaustive and tedious commentary on virtually all his reviews, domestic and foreign (a commentary suffused with resentment toward academic historians, who have generally held his work in light regard). He gives a somewhat embarrassing description of his extramarital affairs and a painful account of the breakup of his long marriage (although he seems to draw only a faint connection between the two). He meditates on the world around him, not (as in the previous volumes of his memoirs) as a journalist who was actively involved in events, but as a solitary writer living mainly in the Berkshire Hills of Massachusetts and forming impressions by reading newspapers and watching television.
Here, as in the earlier memoirs, Mr. Shirer is generally reticent about revealing much of his own inner life. In the reportorial tradition, he prefers to comment on the behavior of others and keep himself in the background. But this is by necessity the most personal of his books, and even if inadvertently it conveys a sense of the character and values that have shaped his career. In many ways, Mr. Shirer has remained throughout his life what he was in his youth: a small-town Midwesterner with a straightforward, vaguely populist view of the world; a man who has never had much patience with the pessimism and ambiguity that suffuse Eastern intellectual life; a writer who has never offered much of an interpretation of the great events he has described, but has viewed them through the prism of his own basic decency and apparent innocence. He has responded to the great evils he has witnessed in the 20th century with a simple and in many ways appealing bewilderment, as things to be carefully and patiently chronicled but never to be truly understood. Even his own less epochal travails in the 40's and 50's he views with seeming incomprehension; there can be no rational explanation, he appears to believe, for intelligent people behaving so badly.
''Whatever happens now, and whenever,'' Mr. Shirer writes at the close of this book, contemplating the end of his long and eventful life, ''I am glad to have lived through the turbulent, tumultuous twentieth century.'' The millions of readers who have found in his many books a compelling picture (even if seldom a compelling explanation) of some of the century's great events have reason to be glad of that as well.
 
FEAR OF REUNIFICATION
 Even William L. Shirer, who has kept Europe under a magnifying glass for 60 years, admits to surprise at the suddenness with which the nations in what used to be the Soviet bloc ''have freed themselves from 40 years of Communism.''
But Mr. Shirer - who concludes ''A Native's Return, 1945-1988,'' the third volume of his memoirs, ''20th Century Journey,'' with two visits to the Soviet Union - is wary, he said in a recent telephone conversation during a vacation in Sarasota, Fla. The revolts in Eastern Europe, he said, ''have exposed the bankruptcy of Communism, which could not feed its people, could not clothe them properly or find them homes. But it is going to be terribly difficult for them to change themselves into market economies and political democracies. In the next year or two they are going to face terrible economic problems, especially Poland and Rumania.''
The Germanys pose special problems. ''The first problem will be the eruption of pro-Nazi interests in East Germany,'' he said. Reunification may be inevitable, he added, ''but our so-called Western allies are much more against it than they are saying publicly.'' Why? ''They're frightened. West Germany is already the strongest economic power in Europe, and combined with East Germany, it would be the strongest military power. The Warsaw Pact is dead. Germany would no longer have to rely on Washington or seek our advice.''
Mr. Shirer, a radio journalist, came late to writing: CBS let him go when a sponsor withdrew its support during the so-called Red menace blacklists of the late 1940's.
But despite his 85 years, his weak heart, poor eyesight and failing hearing, Mr. Shirer maintains momentum: Bantam Books has bought his next work, ''The Last Days of Tolstoi.'' He expressed annoyance that Little, Brown, the publisher of ''A Native's Return,'' turned down ''Tolstoi.'' But then he chuckled: Little, Brown had also refused ''The Rise and Fall of the Third Reich,'' the best seller on which his reputation rests.
 
BARTH HEALEY

LENGTH: 1479 words

HEADLINE: PERSPECTIVES: The Dunbar Apartments;
Switching to the Rental Track in Harlem

BYLINE: By ALAN S. OSER

 BODY:
THE best news for the Dunbar Apartments in Central Harlem may be the city-sponsored rehabilitation activity around it, which gives a lift to the area's rental market and helps secure the Dunbar's future.
The Dunbar's future is no new concern. This is a full square block of 536 apartments in six red-brick, walk-up buildings that John D. Rockefeller Jr. developed to wide acclaim in the 20's. It was the first large cooperative project in the country built for occupancy by blacks, although it became a rental in the Depression. Manhattan's first large garden-apartment complex, it was named for Paul Laurence Dunbar, a black poet who lived from 1872 to 1906.
The Landmarks Preservation Commission was eloquent about its significance to black social history in 1970 when it was designated a landmark. A list of its tenants reads like a Black Who's Who, the commission said: Countee Cullen, poet; W. E. B. DuBois, editor; A. Philip Randolph, labor leader; Paul Robeson, singer, actor and athlete; Bill (Bojangles) Robinson, dancer, and Matthew A. Henson, North Pole explorer. 
Ira Kellman, a lawyer with property interests elsewhere in Manhattan, bought the Dunbar two years ago this month from another entrepreneur who had acquired it from the Goldome Bank for Savings.
Goldome had failed in its efforts to bring about a co-op conversion, which a tenant committee fought. The property was sold after $11.8 million in building improvements paid for by the bank.
Dunbar Associates - with Mr. Kellman, Gary L. Nave, a real estate owner and manager, and Lawrence Bernstein, an accountant, as general partners - bought the property for $5.65 million, or $10,500 an apartment, of which $3 million was cash. After two years, operations are about breaking even, Mr. Kellman said.
For Harlem, the Dunbar saga has become a test of whether, in the hackneyed catchwords of housing parlance, market forces can turn around a troubled property. Will the Dunbar ever return to co-op status as the housing reformers of John D. Rockefeller Jr.'s day advocated?
The Dunbar is bounded by 149th Street and 150th Street, and by Adam Clayton Powell Jr. Boulevard (Seventh Avenue) and Frederick Douglass Boulevard (Eighth Avenue). The side streets around it are filled with buildings undergoing rehabilitation under the city's 10-year housing plan, a plus for the neighborhood's ability to attract wage-earning new tenants.
Long years of stable rents put the complex in dire straits when the inflation of the 70's struck. The downward spiral never led to abandonment, but deferred maintenance caused other problems. So did the lack of an adequate security system, and the innumerable doors off the central courts.
To build such apartments today on free land would cost perhaps seven times what Dunbar Associates paid for them. Preservation is a civic concern, but previous efforts to stabilize the Dunbar's future in the 80's ended in disappointment.
AT one point, an $11.8 million rehabilitation was undertaken by the city and the mortgagee, the Goldome Bank for Savings. But tenants resisted a plan to convert the building to a co-op, which would have increased their monthly costs.
Subsequently another owner, Edward I. Penson, head of a management firm that also managed the Vandeveer apartments in central Brooklyn, tried to run the development as a rental. But he had trouble raising financing and decided eventually to sell.
Vacancies had been accumulated for years in hope of a conversion. Dunbar Associates also has conversion as a longterm goal, but it has spent money to put the vacancies in shape and rented them out at market levels.
Mr. Kellman said he is hopeful that the development can also be run successfully as a rental. With improved rent collections, evictions of long-delinquent tenants and rentals of vacancies, the monthly income has greatly improved.
Some 1,200 building violations have been dealt with, he said, and a system for handling maintenance complaints has gone into effect.
But at best, it is hard to run the Dunbar apartments successfully as a rental. In 1988 the 140 rent-controlled apartments were renting for an average of $40 a room a month, and the 340 occupied rent-stabilized apartments rented at an average of $80 a room. At $40 a room, a controlled tenant in a five-room apartment would be paying $200 a month.
Housing managers estimate that it costs about $90 a room a month - or about $360 a month for a four-room apartment - just to operate and maintain a building, without either taxes or debt service. No privately owned building can be expected to run long without financing, or debt. The Dunbar pays low taxes because the rehabiliation work done in the 80's qualified for abatements under the J-51 program.
For the new owner, the hope lay in vacancies, and what they could command on the market. There were 56 vacancies when Dunbar Associates bought the property. There have been 70 more since, through turnover and court action against long-term rent delinquents.
Now, with the renting program, there are 120 new tenants in the upgraded apartments, paying close to $160 a room per month, or roughly $650 for a four-room apartment and $750 to $800 for a five-room. Incoming tenants typically earn $25,000 to $40,000. If there is normal turnover, new vacancies should average about 25 a year, Mr. Kellman said.
THE ability of the Dunbar to attract tenants able to afford those rents encourages the owner to think that a conversion is possible. They would be better off, he claims, devoting $60 or $70 a month of their housing budget to mortgage payments, building a stake in their housing, rather than pouring it all into rent.
Meanwhile, Dunbar Associates investors have yet to see any return on their money, he said, although $500,000 was returned to them at the time of the refinancing.
They have gotten a $9 million mortgage on the property from the Ensign Savings Bank, however. The loan included money usable only for certain building improvements. One has already been done: $220,000 was spent to remove 2,400 linear feet of asbestos.
There is $1.3 million left for landscaping and window replacement. The Dunbar has 4,200 old windows. There also is a problem with the landmarks agency. To meet the strict specifications of its window code, the Dunbar would have to spend $1.2 million for custom-extruded windows. Robert Ecker, vice president of Ecker Manufacturing Corporation of Mount Vernon, N.Y., a leading manufacturer and installer of replacement windows, said that only smaller buildings, typically in prestigious neighborhoods with higher-income tenants, have been buying new windows that meet the Landmarks Commission's standards.
''The metal frames must match the rolls and curves of the old wood frame beneath it,'' Mr. Ecker said. ''We've done it at 39 Fifth Avenue and in a dozen buildings in Brooklyn Heights.''
To do it at the Dunbar Apartments would result in costs that the tenants can ill afford, Mr. Kellman said. The most he is willing to pay for window replacement is $800,000, or about $185 a window. The owner is still negotiating with the commission's staff, which only in recent months has shown a disposition to compromise. But the two sides are still apart. Meanwhile, many tenants have drafty windows.
Most of the rest of the budget for improvements is to be used for landscaping in the rundown central garden court, the pride of the development in the early days. Brochures from the 1930's show it as a verdant vista through an arch off Seventh Avenue.
Among those looking forward to the work is Leon Campbell, the 52-year-old manager of the Dunbar for the last five years, who has 22 years of building management experience.
''Tenants here have been through a lot,'' he said. ''They were very mistrustful. But they believe what they see. We just completed a laundry room - that helps. You've got to have patience and perseverance, you've got to keep your word and provide service. And if you can't, you've got to tell them why.''
He said he doubted that any conversion to a co-op could be undertaken successfully in less than five or six years.
The improvement program and the new management apparently havesucceeded, at least for the time being, in stabilizing relations with tenants, strained during the 80's. The management says that active tenant organizing has ceased. ''Things are peaceful now,'' said William K. DeFoussett, a 69-year-old retired State Department security guard, whose parents brought him to the Dunbar in 1927, when he was 7 years old. He and his wife have lived in it continuously since 1947.
As a rent-controlled tenant paying a rent he would not disclose, Mr. DeFoussett is not among the most likely purchasers in any new conversion. But asked if he would ever consider buying his apartment, Mr. DeFoussett replied, ''I might buy for my son.''

PUB-DATE: January 21, 1990

SECTION: Section 10; Page 15, Column 1; Real Estate Desk

LENGTH: 1427 words

HEADLINE: COMMERCIAL PROPERTY: As-of-Right Construction;
Kalikow Opts for a 58-Story Lower Manhattan Hotel

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP

 BODY:
PETER S. KALIKOW did not want to spend any more time going through the complex approval process necessary to build a 29-story office building in lower Manhattan. So he decided to go the easier route and build a 58-story hotel instead.
Because the hotel is being developed as of right, with much less space than the office project, it was subject to less municipal scrutiny. But the slender, glass-sheathed shaft is sure to have a greater esthetic impact on its surroundings, including St. Paul's Chapel, the 18th-century landmark where President Washington worshiped.
The 584-room hotel, across from the World Trade Center, is to be 588 feet high, making it one of the tallest in New York City. Mr. Kalikow, the developer, who publishes The New York Post, expects that it will cost about $85 million and be finished by the end of 1991. It will occupy an L-shaped site bounded by Fulton, Church and Dey Streets and by the former headquarters of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company at 195 Broadway, which Mr. Kalikow also owns. 
Designed by Eli Attia Architects of Manhattan, the Kalikow hotel will have a curtain wall of gray glass and about 380,000 square feet of space. The lot is zoned for a floor-area ratio of 15, with a bonus of up to 20 percent for the creation of open space.
''It shouldn't be a surprise that a 15 F.A.R. zone can produce a large building,'' said Con Howe, executive director of the City Planning Department. ''It is across the street from the world's second and third tallest buildings. And it was never raised as an issue that the site was inappropriately zoned.''
Mr. Kalikow bought the whole block from A. T. & T. in 1983 for $93 million. The next year, the telephone company moved to its new headquarters at 550 Madison Avenue, between 55th and 56th Streets, and Mr. Kalikow undertook a restoration and renovation of the older structure, a project supervised by Mr. Attia. Two small buildings on the west side of the block were demolished.
The old A. T. & T. headquarters, girdled by layer after layer of colossal Ionic columns, was designed by William Welles Bosworth and built in three phases from 1912 to 1923. At first, the Kalikow team planned a floor-by-floor expansion of the 195 Broadway building - in effect, a late fourth phase.
Then the plan changed. ''The natural use for that site is a combination office building and hotel,'' Mr. Kalikow said. ''We felt five years ago that the downtown market needed at least one or two more hotels.'' But marketing studies and hotel-chain executives disagreed. ''The consensus was that a hotel would never make it,'' Mr. Kalikow said.
With that, the plan changed again and an office project returned to the table, meaning an enlargement of the building. Although a dozen hotel rooms could fit in floors of 6,000 or 7,000 square feet, that would not be enough space for a large financial-district commercial tenant. What was needed were floors closer to 18,000 square feet.
At the time, however, city planners were talking about treating the entire block as a single zoning lot, since the tax lots were under common ownership at the time of the 1961 Zoning Resolution. On a single zoning lot, the bulk of 195 Broadway - vastly overbuilt by modern rules - would have effectively foreclosed any development on Church Street, to say nothing of such large floors.
One proposal to get around this limit was to close Dey Street and rebuild it as a pedestrian passage, at Mr. Kalikow's expense. The developer would have owned the north half of the street and been able to use the air rights from the street for his new structure.
BUT Mr. Howe, of the planning agency, said planners ''thought that it was a terrible precedent to de-map a street that would continue to feel, look and act like a public street.'' Mr. Attia recalled that water-supply officials objected to having high-pressure lines under private property.
The next tack was to buy 154,000 square feet of air rights from St. Paul's Chapel of Trinity Parish, directly across Fulton Street. With them, Mr. Kalikow would have constructed a 29-story building, with floors of about 17,000 square feet, matching 195 Broadway in height and bulk, but not in materials. Mr. Attia proposed textured and colored glass to emulate the basic three-story grid of the original building.
''We felt that we should express the architecture through means that are contemporary,'' he told the Landmarks Preservation Commission in 1987. ''Adding a building to line up with and echo 195 Broadway will also reinforce the independence of the church, providing a soft, neutral background.''
Commission members, who were reviewing the air-rights transfer because of St. Paul's landmark status, objected that the facade of the new building was merely a glass curtain wall. The architect then deepened the facade and included painted aluminum among the materials. But the commission still balked. With that, the plan changed again and the hotel was reborn. Mr. Kalikow, who believed that the demand for a downtown hotel had grown since he first envisioned one, asked Mr. Attia to sketch an as-of-right building. (City planners had determined that the block could be treated as separate zoning lots - meaning that the west parcel would not be penalized for the bulk of 195 Broadway.) ''We decided to make a statement that had nothing to do with 195,'' Mr. Kalikow said. ''I said to Eli, 'Let's stop trying to blend in.' And he said: 'You remember the monolith in ''2001?'' That's what I see there.' ''
Mr. Attia acknowledged that the new design bears no relationship to 195 Broadway and makes no attempt to create a sympathetic setting or background for St. Paul's Chapel. ''An as-of-right building assumes certain detachments from those concerns,'' he said, adding that ''as-of-right buildings are part of the fabric of Manhattan.''
Because the project does not require special permits or variances, Community Board 1 took no formal position, although there were objections to the tower's height and proportions. Brian Principe, a partner of Mr. Attia, described the meeting: ''They asked, 'Is there anything we can do about it?' We said, 'No, this is as-of-right and we're here only as a courtesy.' So they asked, 'Well, then, what are you charging for parking spaces?' ''
WITHOUT the air-rights transfer, the project was no longer subject to review by the Landmarks Commission. ''I was rather startled that he didn't come back with a revised design,'' said David F. M. Todd, the commission chairman, ''because the ground on which we found ourselves unable to give a complete, supportive report really had more to do with material choices than with form, composition or the disposition of elements.''
But that was just the point for the developer. ''Eli and I, through the 1980's, were the leading advocates of glass buildings,'' Mr. Kalikow said. ''I cannot stand new stone buildings. I hate them. One Ninety-five is different. That's a Greek temple. But I can't build a building like that today.''
With construction now under way, Mr. Kalikow has turned to the details of the hotel, where the basic rate will probably be close to $210 a night.
On the eighth floor of 101 Park Avenue, the skyscraper in which the developer has his offices, is a full-scale mockup of two rooms, all the way down to flowers on the table and extra pillows and blankets.
Mr. Kalikow has studied the rooms as if he might have to stay in one.
''I've got to be able to do this,'' he said, sitting in a bedside chair, propping his feet up on the bed and turning his gaze toward the television cabinet across the room. And speaking of the chairs, he said, ''I'm unhappy with the size.'' He ran his hand over the sharp edges of the bedside bureau and said, ''These are going to be rounded.'' He confessed one disappointment: He could not get glass doors for the showers and had to settle for curtains.
Mr. Kalikow may operate the hotel himself. ''I'm not aiming for that, but if I have to, I will,'' he said, smiling as he added, ''I know more about hotels than I know about newspapers.'' A big operator might be a liability, he said, because ''you're judged by the worst hotel in the chain.'' He mentioned a hotel in Atlanta and its presidential suite, saying: ''If I had a rent-controlled apartment in the Bronx that was like that, I'd be in jail.''
Asked why he lavished such attention on so many fine points in room decor, Mr. Kalikow answered: ''I'm going to build 600 of these. I only have to get one right. The other 599 will follow.''

HEADLINE: LONG ISLAND OPINION;
Teen-Agers and the Trap of Affluence

BYLINE: By Roger Keizerstein; Roger Keizerstein, a clinical social worker who specializes in the treatment of children, lives in East Setauket.

 BODY:
I SIT in the back row of the Seaport deli, that twilight hub of East Setauket, alternately reading a newspaper, picking at a plate of fried seafood and surveying the comings and goings of teen-agers who casually drift in and out.
These teen-agers are casualness in motion. They enter the deli barefooted or in tennis sneakers, wearing long baggy shorts or pants rolled up to their knees. Their shirts, usually seeksucker or flannel, hang loosely below their waists. Their hair is styled in uneven new-wave cuts that have a peculiar symmetry. They are never encumbered by pocketbooks or wallets, carrying their cash and car keys in hand. 
The girls are pretty and the boys are handsome, in that clean-looking, rosy-cheeked, well-cared-for way. When they speak they stretch their vowels slightly and their tone is never definitive, even when ordering food. They never talk about intense subjects that arouse emotions, like politics or romance. They are mostly quiet and patient. After receiving their food, they pull away from the deli in Saabs, Volvos and BMW's.
I believe the casualness comes from affluence and stability. Their lives haven't been touched by urban crime and poverty or the economic fretfulness and congestion of old suburbia. Within two square miles of the seaport is a harbor full of boats and sails, a forest of ancient towering trees, farms with horses, cows and chickens, and nurseries filled with row upon row of colorful flowers. In this bucolic paradise, who wouldn't be casual and carefree?
I wonder, though, if these teen-agers understand the vast differences between the world in which their parents came up and the world they face beyond the cozy confines of their small, countrified world. Do they know that the house that they're living in today cost approximately eight times the price their parents paid for it 20 years ago? Do they know that the average American car costs $12,000? Do they know that the price of borrowed money is twice as much as it was in their parents' day?
I suspect not. I suspect that they go on weeklong school ski trips to Utah and Colorado, and participate in summer enrichment programs in France and Italy, with the same casualness with which they get in and out of their shiny new cars. Maybe they should go skiing in the western Rockies, visit the Eiffel Tower and view the frescoes of Michaelangelo in the Sistine Chapel. These are surely enriching experiences, or at least they could be. They might even serve to make some of these teen-agers better people.
But I wonder if these young people aren't being misled, set up for a big fall. How many of them will be able to continue this kind of life style, independent of their parents, after graduating from college or professional school? How many will even be able to afford their own apartment and car? What the economy giveth to one generation, from another it sometimes taketh away.
If I were a parent of a teen-ager in an affluent town, I'd be ambivalent about how high a lifestyle I'd want my children to lead, although I might be tempted to raise them in a luxurious fashion for psychological reasons that might not be very sound. Many parents overindulge their children to compensate for what they didn't have as children and to compete with other families. The motivation behind these reasons is a recipe for trouble.
We are living in a society in which many of our ills are the result of having too much, as opposed to too little. It is very hard for young people who have been given so much and have high material expectations to face a life in which the flow of milk and honey is temporarily discontinued, or even halted.
So many young adults are returning home after completing their education and competing briefly in the job market, and staying home into their middle and late 20's because they can't tolerate giving up the life style to which they'd become accustomed. Living at home at this stage is damaging to one's self-esteem and may lead to overdependency.
That's why when it comes to raising children, I fall on the side of modesty and restraint, although one parent's modesty and restraint is often another's extravagance and overindulgence. Nonetheless, I believe it's better to be pleasantly surprised by getting more than you expected than bitterly disappointed by getting much less than what you were brought up to so casually receive.

LENGTH: 1708 words

HEADLINE: Enrollment Slips at Many Private Schools

BYLINE: By PRISCILLA VAN TASSEL

 BODY:
PRIVATE elementary and secondary schools in New Jersey have experienced some slippage in enrollments as they try to cope with a declining school-age population and a slowdown in the economy.
A recent survey by the New Jersey Association of Independent Schools, an organization of some of the state's most prestigious private schools, shows that nearly two-thirds of its 58 member schools are enrolling fewer students this academic year than last.
Although overall enrollments for association members decreased only 1.3 percent and most schools have lost just a handful of students, the downturn represents a departure from other years, when growth occurred even though the number of school-age children was declining in the overall population. In general, schools in or around urban areas were hardest hit. ''We've been feeling pretty flush in New Jersey in recent years because the economy has been booming,'' said Edward Lingenheld, president of the association and headmaster of the Rutgers Preparatory School in Somerset. ''But people are paying tuitions with discretionary income, and on their list of priorities, tuition for their children's school might be on the list of touchables.'' 
To bolster their enrollments, many schools have begun aggressive new marketing campaigns and established contact with real-estate agents and relocation companies. Some schools are focusing on improving relations with alumni in the hope of attracting their children and extra donations while others are turning to parents of enrolled students as recruiters.
Tuition plans that permit parents to make payments monthly rather than twice a year are becoming more common, and enlarged scholarship funds are also becoming more common, as schools try to cushion the cost of a private education.
With the median tuition approaching $9,000 for a private day high school and $14,000 for a boarding school, a number of educators are concerned about the pessimistic economic forecast.
''Am I worried about it?'' said Arlene Gibson, headmistress of the Kent Place School, a girls' day school in Summit. ''Sure, everybody's worried about it. You watch it very carefully, and especially you watch, because of where we are, what is happening on Wall Street, at A. T. & T. and the drug companies.''
Last spring, Kent Place, with a tuition of $8,700 for the upper grades, was facing 24 vacancies for this academic year, mostly in its upper school. The mood on campus was somber as faculty members pondered how they could continue offering, as part of the school's rigorous curriculum, advanced placement classes with as few as four or five students taking part.
But by the fall, Kent Place was able to open with a balanced budget, thanks to some late acceptances and a new admissions director, who over the summer followed up all inquiries and got in touch with real-estate offices and corporations that were relocating families to the area. School officials say they did not lower standards to meet their goal. ''The board decided that rather than changing the type of student we were looking for, we'd just tighten our belt a little,'' Mrs. Gibson said. ''If you change the tenor of a school, I don't think you ever get that back.''
Nationally, girls' schools have had a particularly hard time maintaining enrollments, as an increasing number of students opt for a coeducational setting. Even with a student body of 447 this year, Kent Place is still substantially below its peak enrollment of 501 students in 1983. But instead of sweeping its identity under the mat, Kent Place has decided to aggressively market its single-sex status.
''Instead of acting as if we're incidentally a girls' school, we're letting people understand why that is important to them,'' said Mrs. Gibson, who has organized a group of girls' day schools at the national level to publicize the advantages of girls' schools.
One private school that has opted for coeducation in part to ease its enrollment difficulties is the Admiral Farragut Academy in Pine Beach, the nation's first preparatory school to focus on naval training. The $11,500-a-year boarding school officially opened its door to women this month, although none are expected to enroll in the program until the fall.
''Demographics was a consideration,'' said Capt. Robert Matthies, the superintendent of the 170-cadet academy. ''If you take the pie and take the small sliver that wants a quasi-military program and then divide that in half because you're only talking about boys, then you're down to a very small segment of the market.''
Because of the academy's specialized nature, school officials are not counting on the shift to coeducation to totally solve their enrollment difficulties - there was a drop of 53 cadets this year alone - so they have begun to market themselves in areas as far away as the Bahamas and South America. Their efforts are not dissimilar to those of most boarding schools, which are casting their nets wider and wider around the country to draw quality candidates with diversified backgrounds.
 
Wider Geographic Pool
''There is no question that we're doing more traveling than we used to,'' said Philip Pratt, director of admissions and a mathematics teacher at the Lawrenceville School. ''All of the boarding schools are.''
Enrollment at Lawrenceville, at 761 students this year, has never been higher, in part because of the school's decision three years ago to become coeducational.
Day schools are also drawing from a wider geographic pool. The 652 students at the Dwight-Englewood School in Englewood commute from 69 communities as far north as Rockland County and as far south as Union City and Hoboken.
The school, which has shown enrollment increases, has begun emphasizing a multicultural curriculum to reflect the area's changing population. More than one in four Dwight-Englewood students are members of minorities, with the largest growth occurring among Asian-Americans.
''One of the reasons our numbers are increasing slightly is that I would think and hope our school would be perceived as welcoming a diverse population,'' said Dr. James Van Amburg, the school's headmaster.
 
Shorter Waiting Lists
An increase in interest in private education among Asian-Americans also helped the Newark Academy in Livingston to fill vacancies last August. For the school, whose enrollment is still slightly off from a high of 495 five years ago, changing demographics has meant shorter waiting lists for many classes.
''We're aware that the pool of candidates is lower now than it used to be,'' said Dr. Allan Strand, the Newark Academy's headmaster.
Shorter waiting lists are not surprising, considering that New Jersey's school-age population has declined 28 percent since 1972. Private school officials hope that an increase in the birth rate, which is already affecting public elementary schools throughout the state, will ease enrollment shortfalls in private high schools by 1992.
Whether the increase in the general population will result in increased private school enrollment is unclear, however, especially since more than half of the elementary schools belonging to the New Jersey Association of Independent Schools have reported declines in enrollment.
One way private schools assess the impact of the economy is through their re-enrollment statistics.
 
Study Yields Surprises
''If there is softness in the economy, the tendency is for a considerable increase in attrition from currently enrolled students,'' Mr. Lingenheld of the Rutgers Preparatory School said. ''We haven't seen that; knock wood.'' Enrollment at Rutgers Prep has climbed back to its peak level of 1982.
Several years ago, when enrollments were slipping, Rutgers and two other private schools in the area shared the cost of a $50,000 market survey on independent education and how their schools in particular were perceived. The study resulted in few surprises, but it did lead to a renewed commitment to reduce attrition and convert inquiries into applications.
Rutgers Prep also sought to ease the financial strain of its $8,300 tuition by tripling its scholarship fund for middle-income students and seeking corporate scholarships for disadvantaged students.
 
Stricter Standards Pay Off
Other schools are using parents as their selling agents. At Gill/St. Bernard's School in Gladstone, volunteer parents conduct biweekly telephone drives to recruit new students and identify concerns of parents of already enrolled students. The school has also raised its admissions standards, imposed a dress code and emphasized good citizenship.
The stricter standards are apparently paying off. This year Gill's enrollment rose by 45 students to a total student body of 357, the largest increase of any school in New Jersey. A dramatic drop in the attrition rate of students from a high of 48 percent four years ago to 14 percent was largely responsible for the growth.
''When you are in an economic crunch and things are not going well, the tendency is to lower standards,'' said Christine Gorham, Gill's headmistress. ''That may be a short-term solution, but in the long term you'll be in trouble. People send their children to independent schools because they want to get something special for it.''
Gill's dramatic comeback is still more the exception than the rule. At the Mount St. Mary Academy in Plainfield, where enrollment is down 20 students this year, school officials are toying with the idea of offering a seventh and eighth grade or becoming a seven-day boarding school, instead of a five-day institution.
In Montclair, officials of the Montclair Kimberley Academy cite an increasingly transient business community and a growing popularity of public schools as prime reasons for their 52-student enrollment decline in the last three years. At the Neumann Preparatory School in Wayne, where enrollment had been as high as 300, there are now 172 students, despite a change to coeducation several years ago.
In the end, no marketing effort or internal reorganization could save the Atlantic Friends School in Brigantine. Faced with a faltering Atlantic City economy and a dwindling student body, the 89-year-old school shut its doors for good last year.

LENGTH: 1076 words

HEADLINE: NEW JERSEY OPINION;
Why Be Surprised At the Budget Crisis?

BYLINE: By Richard A. Zimmer; State Senator Richard A. Zimmer, Republican of Delaware Township, is on the Senate Revenue, Finance and Appropriations Committee.

 BODY:
IN the words of New Jersey's Yogi Berra, it's deja vu all over again. A newly elected governor, who had predicted on the campaign trail that he could balance the state budget without a tax increase, is dropping hints that higher taxes might be necessary after all. He says he has discovered new information that was unavailable to him before the election.
Time will tell whether Jim Florio, like his two predecessors, will become a proponent of higher taxes early in his term. But there is no doubt that New Jersey faces an enormous budget shortfall for the coming fiscal year. This shortfall wasn't caused by an unexpected post-election decline in tax revenues. It was preordained by decisions made when the current budget was adopted last July 1 and confirmed by data publicly available long before Election Day. 
The state is in its current cash bind because the budget for fiscal year 1990 (which began last July 1 and ends this June 30) was based on unrealistic revenue estimates of the Treasury Department's Office of Management and Budget. These projections were roughly $200 million higher than those of the nonpartisan Office of Legislative Services.
Some of us on the Senate Appropriations Committee argued unsuccessfully last spring that even the Office of Legislative Services estimates were too optimistic because they did not fully take into account New Jersey's economic slowdown, which was already under way.
We were soon proved correct. Revenue from almost every major tax came in below expectations from the very beginning of fiscal 1990. By Election Day, publicly available figures from the Office of Management and Budget and the Office of Legislative Services showed the shortfall at more than $100 million for the first four months of the fiscal year.
Even with the recently imposed emergency budget measures, there is grave doubt as to whether we will see anything close to the $250 million budget surplus with which we were supposed to end fiscal year 1990. That means there will be less to roll over into the budget for fiscal year 1991, a budget that is already guaranteed to be a fiscal nightmare.
Last year we finally exhausted the huge budget surpluses that had fueled explosive state spending growth since the mid-1980's. To avoid election-year tax increases and layoffs, this year's $12 billion budget was balanced with one-shot fiscal gimmicks that in many cases actually pulled revenue out of future budgets. They include:
* $110 million from accelerated sales tax collections on leased property.
* $65 million from increased income tax withholding.
* $77 million from accelerated collection of insurance premium taxes.
* $246 million from the ''Rainy Day Fund,'' supposed to be used to balance the budget in a recession.
* $100 million from the Unemployment Compensation Fund.
* $120 million from court-ordered windfall profits taxes.
* $45 million from an urban property insurance fund.
Besides coming up with new money to replace this one-shot revenue, next year's budget must also address these mandated state spending increases, among others:
* $550 million to fully finance the school aid formula.
* $160 million for new public employee salary contracts.
* $120 million for pensions, Social Security, health insurance and other fringe benefits.
* $120 million for correctional facilities.
* $140 million for medical assistance.
* $25 million in property rentals.
* $25 million for programs for the developmentally disabled.
* $15 million in debt service.
* $10 million for the Division of Youth and Family Services.
To these obligations could be added $628 million in capital spending urged by the Capital Budget and Planning Commission. (Virtually all capital spending was suspended by the fiscal year 1990 budget.) None of these projected spending obligations are surprises; they were all identified by the Office of Legislative Services last May. As a result of last year's fiscal legerdemain, we now must come up with several hundreds of millions of dollars in tax increases or spending cuts before we can spend one dime to deal with a softer economy, school financing obligations expected to be imposed by the State Supreme Court, property tax relief or urban aid, not to mention a host of campaign promises.
During the budget debate, I warned my colleagues that we were only pushing our fiscal problems into future years. But a year is an eternity in politics, especially when an election is imminent.
Now that the future is here, what should we do about it? The most obvious answer is to raise taxes. The better though more difficult course is finally to address the spending side of the fiscal equation.
We should begin as Jim Florio has proposed, with an in-depth audit of state government. Even after a period of relative austerity, there is still a lot of nonessential state spending that an aggressive audit can identify. We should get rid of ''perks'' like the personal use of state cars, not just for the money they cost, but for the message they convey, that resources are plentiful enough to cover wants as well as needs.
But, to effect major economies, the new administration must cut more than perks. It must eliminate popular but nonessential programs.
In the long run, neither tax increases nor program cuts will result in long-term fiscal equilibrium unless we restrain so-called ''formula driven'' spending - like education aid, pensions and medical assistance - that grows faster than revenue.
Ultimately, we need permanent institutional constraints against government profligacy. We must cap state spending increases and payroll growth. We need a permanent ''Rainy Day Fund'' to keep us from having to increase taxes during a recession, as well as a ''Sunny Day Fund'' to return a share of unanticipated surpluses to the taxpayers.
All these reforms have long been pending in the Legislature under the sponsorship of leaders of both parties, but they will not be realized without Jim Florio's leadership. They would be salutary if enacted as statutes, but would be most valuable as constitutional amendments impervious to repeal by later legislatures.
Thomas Jefferson was right when he said that, instead of depending on the good intentions of politicians, we should ''bind them down from mischief by the chains of the Constitution.'' That is the most reliable protection against future budget ''surprises.''

HEADLINE: Questions on Closing A Dental School

 BODY:
The recent article on the closing of the Fairleigh S. Dickinson Jr. College of Dental Medicine raises some fundamental questions about the responsibility of a state for encouraging and maintaining private institutions for the benefit of its residents.
Although technically not state-related, all private institutions in New Jersey, except a handful exempted by a discriminatory grandfather clause, are state-controlled in the sense that they must have their offerings approved by the Department of Higher Education. They all depend for a major part of their budget upon tuition grants for New Jersey students and upon specific grants from the department for various projects. 
In addition to this, Fairleigh Dickinson had received special funds that enabled it to maintain its dental school and to train dentists there at considerably lower cost than it will cost to train them at the University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey. Over the years, this state relationship maintained a high-quality program that benefited our faculty, staff and students as well as the residents of Bergen County. The vast majority of all these categories were New Jerseyans. Why junk all of this?
The excuse given was that the state was producing too many dentists. This argument, of course, assumes that dentists produced in New Jersey all set up practice in the state and that no one trained elsewhere could move into the state, a dubious premise at best. The real reason was that Fairleigh Dickinson's nonstate operation was competing with the University of Medicine and Dentistry for a diminishing pool of students, that there was a short-term fiscal crisis in Trenton, and that the Department of Higher Education could now afford to expand its dental program since the passing of a new bond issue.
Gov. Thomas H. Kean and Chancellor T. Edward Hollander had worked long and hard to upgrade state institutions. If one of the two dental schools had to go, they had no hesitation as to which one it would be. Fairleigh Dickinson was given an ultimatum: no more money to continue a quality program, but should you decide to close, we'll be happy to bankroll that operation.
What is the responsibility of the Governor and the Chancellor toward private institutions? In upgrading the facilities, equipment and faculty salaries of state colleges while keeping the tax-subsidized tuition artificially low, a great service has been done to the state. But a great many difficulties have also been visited upon private institutions, already hard hit by a soft economy and a shrinking student pool.
In addition to what would be normally a difficult situation, more and more corporate dollars have also been siphoned into state institutions.
A $27 million fund-raising campaign for the University of Medicine and Dentistry overlapped our own $12 million effort.
One needs to remember that the good health of both private and public education is deeply affected by public policy. Aside from Princeton, no New Jersey institution of higher learning can stand alone. To take the attitude that what happens to private institutions, to their students staff and faculty, is of no concern to the state is to forget that all the foregoing are residents, voters and taxpayers. One can only trust that Mr. Kean will appreciate more the value of private institutions as he takes up his new duties as president of one of them, even though it is one of those few excepted from the authority of the Department of Higher Education.
A merger or affiliation of some kind between the two dental schools not only would have been a kinder and gentler solution, but also, in the long run, would have saved tax dollars and preserved a program of quality and of national prominence.
 
R. THOMAS MCDONALD
 President, Fairleigh Dickinson Council of A.A.U.P. Chapters
 
 (American Association of University Professors)
 South Hackensack

HEADLINE: What Shapes a New Apartment House?

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON

 BODY:
THE 13-STORY St. Andrew Hotel guarded the northwest corner of Broadway at its intersection with Amsterdam Avenue and 72d Street for half a century until it was pulled down during the Great Depression to make way for a two-story retail development that, in those hard days, paid a better return than old hotels.
Over the years, the complex became just another ''taxpayer,'' a building just big enough to carry the property taxes until something better came along.
Now the stores are gone and the Alexandria, a 202-unit condominium scheduled for completion in September, is rising on the spot. As the latest of a new generation of condominiums to rise along Broadway between Columbus Circle and 96th Street in the last seven years, the project is also a kind of map to the minds of today's apartment-house developers, a textbook on the Manhattan real estate market and a guide to how new buildings are shaped by economics, profit potentials, housing needs and zoning.
The developers for the $100 million project are William Zeckendorf Jr., for the Zeckendorf Company, and Peter Malkin and his W & M Properties, along with Arthur G. Cohen, a well-known real estate investor, and a partner or investor group the other principals identify only as SCC 72nd Street Association. 
Every new apartment project is built on a set of developer's assumptions worked out before the first concrete is poured. But as private partnerships, builders are under no obligation to reveal their secrets, and most discuss the internal affairs of a project only in the expectation of publicity.
Thus a willingness by the Alexandria's developers to share their thinking, up to a point, offers a chance to explore a process that produces, for most buyers, a fait accompli - this big, that view, so many dollars, take it or leave it.
The partners believe that the Alexandria - the name reflects the faintly Egyptian design elements of the building's multicolored brick and decorative ironwork - represents a third generation of Upper West Side apartment buildings. The first was made up of the big, multibedroom prewar buildings that dominate the neighborhood and give it its distinctive character. The second emerged after World War II as the boxy, glass and brick buildings filled with studios and one-bedroom apartments for singles and young couples. Now, in the third, bigger apartments are needed for an aging cohort of baby-boomers with children who are stretching for more space.
To reach this conclusion, the developers surveyed the market performance of the 2,000 other new condominiums in the Upper West Side, including Zeckendorf's own Columbia, Princeton House, Copley and Park Belvedere, and decided that the neighborhood was ready for more two-, three- and four-bedroom aprtments.
''We know all the buildings we've done and from looking at the Manhattan market which units have been doing well in primary sales and in resales and which untis have not performed well,'' said William Lie Zeckendorf, William Jr.'s 31-year-old son, who is running the day-to-day operations on the project, with Anthony Malkin, 27, who is Peter's son.
''If you look at the apartments that have been built on Broadway in the last seven years, 80 percent of them are studios and ones'' and the rest are twos,'' he said, referring to the number of bedrooms. ''Threes and fours are virtually nonexistent.''
The Alexandria, designed by David Childs of the architectural firm of Skidmore, Owings & Merrill, will in contrast be 47 percent two-, three-and four-bedroom aprtments, 44 percent standard studios and one-bedroom untis and 9 percent one-bedroom duplexes.
''The traditional base for the Upper West Side was the larger prewar apartments, so this type has tended to be underbuilt since the war,'' the younger Mr. Zeckendor said. ''We believe there is a significant market for the trade-up buyer in this area, and our design reflects that.''
But no one should believe that the big prewar apartments like those along Riverside Drive and West End Avenue are making a comeback. Their big dining rooms are a thing of the past in today's eat-and-run world, and the space they took has been given to more bathrooms - one per bedroom is the rule at Alexandria - and closet space.
Only one apartment, the 24th-floor penthouse, will contain a maid's room - another emblem of Upper West Side gentility. it will be tiny, as tradition dictates. But unlike the airshaft view that the maid's rooms in the old Riverside Drive co-ops offer, the one in the Alexandria will have the best view in the building, south down Broadway.
A health spa, including a 50-foot pool in the ''lower level'' - basement is a world not found in the New York developer's lexicon - will be open to owners only, a departure from many other buildings, whose developers sell memberships to outsiders to help carry the extra cost. A small, landscaped interior courtyard will be accessible from a workout room on the street level above the pool.
The services will be provided by 24-hour doormen, a daytime concierge, to receive deliveries, a resident superintendent and a staff of four or five porters, according to current plans. Mail will be left in lobby mailboxes, and each floor will have a garbage-compactor chute.
The partners paid $21.5 million for the 17,000-square-foot site. That is close to $1,300 a square foot and therefore at the middle to high end - the range is typically between $1,000 nd $1,500 a foot - for prime locations offering a combination of retail and residential development, brokers said.
The location, a major factor in values and apartment pirces, is rated as good, even very good, but not prime like Central Park West or Fifth Avenue. It offers views down Broadway and Amsterdam Avenue toward Lincoln Center and midtown from its south and east sides, and to West End Avenue, Riverside Drive and the Hudson River, from upper floors on its west side.
The intersection has the IRT subway station a hundred paces across 72d Street, crosstown bus service, Central Park two blocks to the east, Riverside Park two blocks to the west and an absence of high-rise contruction to block sunlight and sky on all sides.
Immediately across Broadway are Sherman Square and Verdi Park, a sliver better known a few decades ago as ''needle park,'' a notorious drug bazaar. The developers contributed a third of the $150,000 cost of fencing, planting and lighting it in hopes of erasing that memory from the minds of potential buyers. On a recent rainy day, one bedraggled idler still haunted the sidewalk beside the composer's diminutive statue, hissing: ''Smoke, smoke.''
The partners hope the archeitectural environment around their building will also be a marketing draw. Across Broadway and Amsterdam stand the Van Dyck and the Severn, two venerable co-ops. On the northeast corner of 71st and Broadway is the Dorilton, a landmarked 1902 Second Empire-style apartment building.
Directly to the north along Broadway stands the immense stony bulk of the Ansonia, a Broadway landmark whose twin turrets the Alexandria will respectfully salute with a lighted octagonal cupola of its own.
''One of the most interesting things about that area is the development that was done at the time of the Egyptian revival,'' said Mr. Childs, the archeitect. ''And that became the basis for the motif of the building, not only in the column decorations, but in the doors and in the grillwork, the entrance, the lighting fixtures and up to that lantern at the top of the building.''
Following Mr. Child's design, the owners have taken some pains to match the florid oranameted styles of their neighbors by including subtle lotus leaf ornamentation and $1 million in ironwork on the columns and multicolored brickwork of the project.
The Alexandria site, with a zoned floor-area ratio of 10, would not allow the developers the bulk they wanted to build their big apartments (floor-area ratio is the number of square feet in a building allowed for each square foot of lot size). So they bought air rights from five adjoining walk-ups on the 72d Street site and transferred them to the project.
The partners refused to disclose how much the development air rights cost them, citing the confidentiality of the sellers. Brokers estimate that such rights would sell for $30 to $50 a square foot, or $6.7 million for the 168,000 feet of development rights, assuming the price was about $40 a foot.
The building will thus contain 297,000 square feet, giving the site an effective F.A.R. of slightly more the 17, with setbacks starting at the 16th floor.
The purchase of the air rights brought another advantage to the partners - the right to put windows in the projects's western lot-line walls with views to the west that they afford, greatly increasing the appeal of the apartments.
The corner site, given its central location at a major intersecton, is important to the developers for reasons other than the convenience to transportaton for the new tenants. It is also a prime retail location, in keeping with the practice of the Zeckendorfs and other developers of putting retail space along the ground floors of residential buildings to sweeten the economic mix.
Real estate experts like to regard ground-floor retail space as a way of subsidizing land costs. It is not unusal for developers who retain ownership of street-level retail space, as the Alexandria partners will, to sell the space later, after values rise, to an investor.
Assuming that the Alexandria's 12,700 square feet of street-level retail space rents for a net price of $100 a square foot, said Albert Bialek, a major commercial real estate broker in Manhattan, the annual rent roll would amount to $1.2 million for the street-level space alone, while 7,800 square feet of second-floor retail space might fetch $400,000 a year net, brokers estimated, and 9,000 feet of basement retail and storage space an additional $300,000 a year.
An investor would buy that space on the bais of a 9 percent rate of return on the purchase price, Mr. Bialek explained, or $14.1 million, while on the same basis, the upper level and basement space might sell for an additional $7 million.
Mr. Bialek, whose company is Albert Bialek Associates, pointed out that many residential buildings are being developed in good commerical areas where high rents can be had for retail space. ''Without the stores,'' he said, ''these buildings wouldn't work.''
The younger Zeckendorf, when presented with this analysis, said only, ''I would not argue with that,'' but added that he thought he could get better than a 9 percent basis on the retail space. He added that the partners expected to retain ownership of the store space in the Alexandria, but noted that the retail space in the Copley and the Columbia had in fact been sold to investors.
As for an Alexandria retail tenant, the word among other brokers is that HMV Records, a British company, has contracted to rent the entire retail space, putting a huge record, tape and video store just a few blocks north of the big Tower Records store at 66th Street.
But the partners insist that no agreement has been reached among several retailers they said were interested in the space.
''There is no other large block of modern retail space on the Upper West Side,'' side Peter Malkin, whose W & M Properties is the lead leasing agent for the space. ''The size of the retail space was one of the considerations in designing the lobby entrance on 72d Street, keeping the retail and the residential as separate as possible, because when you get over to the lobby you are in a very quiet residential neighborhood.'' (The address will be 201 West 72d Street.) Besides the ground-level space, the stores will have 7,800 square feet of second-story space on a kind of mezzanine that will be visible from the street, and 4,500 square feet of basement retail space.
Finally, an additional 4,000 square feet of basement space will be divided into storage space for condominium owners to rent.
As for buyers of apartments, the market on the Upper West Side is as varied as anywhere in New York, the younger Mr. Zeckendorf said. It includes first-time buyers seeking small apartments, trade-up buyers looking for more room, expanding families needing several bedrooms, empty-nesters moving from large apartments to a smaller one, and investors who buy to rent.
Sales prices have not yet been determined, the partners said, but they estimated that apartments would go for $375 to $475 a square foot, slightly higher than prevailing prices in other condominiums in the area. Sales are scheduled to begin in April.
Assuming that the low end iscloser to $425 a square foot, since prices tend to creep up during construction, that translates into $250,000 Studios, $370,00 for a one-bedroom duplex, $450,000 for the smallest two-bedroom, two-bath unit, $830,000 for three-bedroom corner units and $1 million for a 2,000-square-foot, four-bedroom apartment with 80 feet of a yard-wide terrace overlooking the intersection of Broadway and 72d Street.
In the midtown condominium market, foreign investors have become major players, as the ownership lists of many buildings in that area show. American investors have been discouraged from such investments because losses on the carrying charges of the apartments can no longer be deducted from income from other sources unless the investor can demonstrate an active, day-to-day role in managing the property.
William Lie Zeckendorf said that the Alexandria would not have a special marketing program in Japan, where most of the city's condominium-investors live, or elsewhere overseas. However, he said, ''people in Japan will be aware of this building.''
The buyers will have 10-year tax abatements on their condominium, thanks to the developers' purchase of 202 tax-abatement certificates from a low-income project on Staten Island, called Davidson Court, under the city's 421a program. The abatements cost $25,00 each, with the money used to pay for building low-income housing. The developers will make it back on the builing during construction and by being able to ask for higher prices for the under-taxed units.
To buy the $450,000 two-bedroom apartment with a 20 percent, $90,000down payment and a 10 percent fixed-rate, 30-year mortgage would require a minimum annual income of about $136,000, assuming that the lenders hold to their rule of not allowing a borrower's mortgage and interest costs to exceed 28 percent of gross income. A still higher income, to allow for taxes, would be needed once the building's 421a tax abatement is fully removed after 10 years.
The people who buy these expensive apartments often wonder how much the developers will pocket for their labors. Although all developers set profits targets when going into a project, the developers of the Alexandria declined to be specific about their hoped-for return. The accuracy of any estimated profit figures arrived at by outsiders would above all depend on how long the apartments take to sell, since short-term constructions loans are expensive and each month debt eats into profit.
The project is being built with a five-year construction loan of $107 million for Chemical Realty Group, a subsidiary of Chemical Bank, under a participating mortgage deal that guarantees the lender a share of the profits.
Some numbers are known, and if others are assumed to be in line with development costs at similar sites, an estimate of the project's profitability can be made. The developer puts the land cost at $21.5 million and the construction costs at $200 a square foot, with ''hard'' costs of concrete, labor and the like at about $120 a square foot and ''soft'' costs of interest, commissions and marketing at $80 a foot.
The developers have also put in the 421a tax abatements at $25,000 per apartment, for 202 apartments.
Adding in the assumed cost of $40 a foot for air rights from the adjoining low-rise buildings brings the total development cost to $92.7 million. With a 3 percent fudge factor typically included for such projects, the total cost would be $95.5 million.
On the other side, the developers will sell their 206,000 square feet of net residential space an estimated average of $425. That would produce $87.5 million, plus approximately $20 million for the retail space once it is fully leased, assuming the partners decide to sell it, for a total of $107 million in total potential revenues.
That warks out to a profit of about $11 million, very close to the $50 a square foot thatmany developers set as their target when they start a project. In rough terms, profits at that level wold represent a gain of $29,000 onthe smallest studio apartment, depending on whether the project's soft costs include brokers' fees, and $100,000 on the big four-bedroom corner apartments.

HEADLINE: FORUM;
Those Awful Shuttle Fares

BYLINE: By DONALD L. PEVSNER; Donald L. Pevsner is an attorney, consumer advocate and travel industry entrepreneur based in Miami. He was assistant general counsel of Air Florida.

 BODY:
On Wednesday morning, Jan. 3, weekday Shuttle passengers on the Washington-New York and New York-Boston routes received a nasty New Year's present from the glitzy self-promoter Donald J. Trump. His Trump Shuttle raised its one-way weekday fares by an unprecedented 20 percent, to $119 from $99, thereby exacerbating the already excessive unrestricted air fare gouge that presently afflicts most of the nation's business (and many other) travelers. Its principal competitor on these busy routes, Pan American World Airways Inc., promptly matched the Trump Shuttle's increases.
Airline economics are complex, but understandable - so it's worthwhile taking a close look at the economics of the two shuttle routes. 
Pan Am's systemwide domestic costs for the second quarter of 1989 (the most recent figures available) were 8.1 cents a mile, meaning that it cost Pan Am 8.1 cents on average to fly each seat, filled or empty, one mile throughout its domestic system. On the airline's shuttle routes (191 miles New York-Boston; 215 miles New York-Washington), with their short length and extra costs for standby airplanes and crews, knowledgeable sources estimate that the costs rise to about 20 cents a mile.
Figures for the Trump Shuttle are not available, partly because Mr. Trump's acquisition of the Eastern Airlines Shuttle operation is relatively recent, and partly because the carrier has asked the Department of Transportation for a waiver that would permit it to keep its mandatory quarterly financial reporting confidential. Trump officials argued that a waiver was necessary to avoid ''severe competitive disadvantage,'' should Pan Am discover its rival's costs. But I submit that the real danger for Mr. Trump lies in the traveling public's discovery of the magnitude of his company's fare-gouging if the data become available.
With these airlines charging $119 for one-way weekday fares, I estimate that both the Trump Shuttle and Pan Am realize weekday yields of 52.8 cents a mile for the New York-Boston flight and 46.9 cents a mile for the New York-Washington run. These figures are arrived at after subtracting from gross revenues offsets of 8 percent for the Federal transportation tax and a further 10 percent for an aggregate of travel-agent commissions, minor weekday-fare dilution from the carriage of corporate employees enjoying secret bulk-fare deals, and - on Pan Am only - carriage of Federal civilian and military employees for a ''sweetheart'' $49 fare. Given the aforesaid 20 cents a mile estimated operating costs, both of these carriers should break even with load factors - percentage of seats filled - of only a minuscule 37.9 percent on the New York-Boston route and 42.6 percent on the New York-Washington route.
But weekday shuttle load factors average about 55 percent. Simple arithmetic therefore reveals that break-even air fares on the two routes are $69.45 to Boston and $78.18 to Washington. Even allowing for the lower - $79 - weekend fares, there is still no excuse for charging weekday passengers fares that produce unconscionably high gross profit margins of 31.1 percent to Boston and 22.5 percent to Washington.
The fact that, in my estimate, Mr. Trump overpaid by about $100 million (of a total $365 million acquisition price) when he bought the shuttle and its assets should not justify these high prices, particularly since the premium mainly bought him the ancillary benefits of participating in a rank, anticompetitive duopoly whose very existence is against the public interest.
How do both greedy carriers get away with the gouging? There are no more takeoff or landing slots available at either La Guardia in New York or Washington National Airport, so no new competition can enter that shuttle route. The insidious Airline Deregulation Act of 1978 removed all Government controls on domestic air fares on Jan. 1, 1985, thereby eliminating the sound Federal oversight that mandated ''just and reasonable'' fares. Gates at La Guardia, National and in Boston are impossible to secure for any new entrant into the market. And there is a pervasive mind-set in the airline industry that non-discretionary, mostly business, travelers are victims ready for skinning, under the argument that they have to travel and they don't pay for their own tickets anyway.
The only equitable remedy for airline fare-gouging, nationwide, is long-overdue Congressional restoration of Section 404(a)(1) Federal Aviation Act authority over domestic air fares, and the prompt imposition of equitable fare caps to limit the appetites of the major-airline oligopoly. The Department of Transportation continues to exercise such control over unrestricted economy-class international air fares - and what is good for the international passenger is equally good for that passenger's beleaguered domestic counterpart.
Although the Department of Transportation remains firmly opposed to capping domestic air fares, even in the most egregious cases, the agency will have to do what Congress directs. In the meantime, I strongly urge this agency to issue quarterly press releases describing, in readable form, the actual costs and yield breakdowns of the nation's major carriers. This information is public record now and should be available to the general public - not just to those airline industry executives whose employers can afford to pay $1,130 a year to subscribe to Aviation Daily, a trade publication where the data are published.
In the interim, prospective shuttle passengers can vote with their feet for Northeast Corridor transportation relief. Amtrak costs as little as one-third as it takes to get there by air shuttle.
An old Wall Street maxim applies, to both Trump and Pan Am: ''You can be a bull or a bear - but you shouldn't be a pig.'' Congress should eliminate the ''pig factor'' and impose fare caps quickly.

HEADLINE: NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Houlton, Me.;
Historic Square In a Comeback

BYLINE: By LYN RIDDLE

 BODY:
MORE than $2.5 million from public and private sources has been spent in the last few years to fix up Market Square, the downtown area of this northern Maine town of 6,700 people. The area is listed on the National Register of Historic Places as a fine example of turn-of-the-century commercial architecture, said Charles Upton, the town's Director of Community Development.
But it is the configuration that makes Houlton's downtown especially distinctive. The buildings encircle the square, setting off the downtown from other parts of the town and preserving a small-town flavor. The major highways through town, Routes 1 and 2A, bypass the square. 
Market Square was built by the military in the 1800's. Perched on a hill some 45 feet above the Meduxnekeag River, it was where troops were mustered for the Civil War. Later, as the lumber and potato industries developed in the area, Houlton became a center for commerce, and handsome three- and four-story buildings were built around the square.
Around 1900, this bustling community was thought to have had more millionaires per capita than any town except Averill, Mass., Mr. Upton said. Millionaires Row, a section of fine, wood-frame homes near the square, was built around that time. But the downtown declined in the 70's, as did the potato industry, and many businessmen closed their shops in the square. By 1979, when the town began planning a downtown revitalization, 50 percent of the floor space was vacant. Work began in earnest in 1986.
The town received $725,000 from the state and raised $1.4 million more through bonds to replace all the storm drains, sidewalks and streetlights. It also planted trees along the streets.
As was the hope of town leaders, the public improvements spurred private investment. About $400,000 has been spent to renovate a third of the buildings, and many are now historically accurate. Town leaders hope all the buildings will be renovated before long. They also are encouraged by the number of new businesses moving into the storefronts and upper-floor offices. Little ground-level space is vacant now.
Mr. Upton said more than 30 percent of the new businesses have been started by young people able to pay the $3 to $5 a square foot rent downtown, but not the $6 or $7 plus maintenance and snow plowing in a strip-shopping center on Route 1.
The homes on Millionaires Row also are still standing and most are in fine shape. Residential property values here have increased, but still seem a bargain compared with southern Maine. Brokers here say houses on the market range in price from $25,000 to $125,000.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Part of the renovated Market Square in Houlton, Me. (The New York Times/Lyn Riddle)
