HEADLINE: FORUM;
The New Organized Crime

BYLINE: By BENJAMIN J. STEIN; Benjamin J. Stein, is a lawyer, writer and economist living in Los Angeles. He was a speechwriter for Presidents Richard M. Nixon and Gerald R. Ford.

 BODY:
John Gotti, you poor, obsolete loser. You've missed the boat. You forgot Willie Sutton's lesson - go where the money is. Just before Christmas, when I was in New York, I saw on the local news a story about the police in Queens ''busting'' a gambling ''bank.'' A veritable army of police cruisers were outside a pitiful-looking building next to a bakery. Inside, a few equally pitiful-looking men and women in polyester and T-shirts sat on ratty couches while a policeman showed the camera stacks of $20's the gambling bank allegedly had taken in recently.
Breathlessly, the announcer talked about how the take was in the tens of thousands of dollars, and how the raid marked a major coup in the war on organized crime in New York City. 
If it's true, it's a joke. ''Organized crime?'' Next to a bakery in Queens? With guys in T-shirts running it? With a take of tens of thousands? From betting on football games?
Forget it. That's a heartbreakingly small joke. The real organized crime, the riskless kind that pays off in the hundreds of millions and billions, is across the river, in lower Manhattan, on Broad Street, on Wall Street. It's across the continent, in a gleaming marble cube on Rodeo Drive.
The only truly meaningful kind of taking of other people's property, the kind that adds up to enough to support an army - of lawyers - is being done by the American financial establishment, at least the tawdriest part of it, and the American stock company establishment at its saddest. It's so big, so perfectly safe, that it has redefined ''organization'' and ''crime'' in the Western world.
Example: the sale of fraudulent bonds. This has been done in a small way in the whole history of the Republic. But in the last decade, it has been lifted to unheard-of levels.
What, after all, were the bonds of Campeau, issued for hundreds of millions of dollars within the last two years, with many of them now close to worthless? What were the hundreds of millions of Merv Griffin and Resorts International bonds that were issued within the last 12 months and are already in default? Or the bonds for Seaman Furniture or SCI Television or Gillett Holdings?
Of course, the most astute buyers in the world, who might have read every word of the prospectus, who may have studied law at Harvard or accounting at Wharton, might not have been fooled by those bonds. But those bonds weren't sold to eagle-eyed financial types. No, they were sold to savings and loans and to insurance companies, to banks - and basically to the stockholders of those companies. Those stockholders did not know, and often still do not know, that their money was used to buy those bonds. Worse yet, they were sold to the taxpayers who support Federal deposit insurance for the savings and loans that went broke because of their collapsed ''junk-bond'' holdings. In every meaningful sense, phony bonds were sold to people without a clue to what they were buying.
Unethical? You bet. But the sellers got 4 percent. The lawyers who drew up all the indentures got $400 an hour and a bonus for quick work. The executives of the banks and savings and loan institutions got promotions and favors. But no one goes to jail when the savings and loans go down the tubes. No one gets rubbed out in a clam bar in Little Italy over the fallout.
Then there are the executives of public companies who simply give themselves multimillion-dollar wages even as their companies are falling into insolvency. Look at the losses of failed savings and loans. Read about the salaries of the men who got institutions like Centrust Bank, Imperial Savings and Loan and Silverado Savings and Loan into trouble. Those men (and a few women) were paying themselves some of the highest salaries in America even as, it is alleged, their companies were being wildly mismanaged.
John Gotti, you poor devil, those savings and loan guys and others like them at some entertainment companies know the score. Just consider Steve Ross, chairman of Warner Communications Inc., who is paying himself about $200 million over the next five years.
Why bother to sell numbers or drugs or prostitution? Just write out a check with the stockholders' money, made payable to yourself. Have your lawyers certify that it's fine. That's American business today, John, and you missed out.
Or buy your company away from your stockholders at less than its real value. Use the stockholders' money to hire the lawyers and bankers to help you take away their money. Go ahead. It's cool. It happens every day. No one gets shot.
Or buy a piece of your company. Or award yourself a control block of preferred shares. Or use your company's working capital to buy bonds and get tips on takeovers in return, as many of Drexel Burnham Lambert's players are alleged to have done.
That's modern organization. That's modern crime. The Securities and Exchange Commission won't bother you. There will be a private plaintiffs' suit, but it will get settled - with the money of the stockholders - and you get away clean and rich.
And you don't have to give a thing in return for all that money in this new world. The old-style organized criminal had at least to deliver gin or prostitution. But the new way, the Wall Street way, means you don't deliver a thing. You run the company into the ground, you take from the stockholders unreasonably. You sell a worthless bond, and nobody lays a hand on you.
It is a lesson for you, John Gotti. If you have young relatives, don't teach them the fish wholesaling business, and forget linen supply. If you want to do someone a favor, try corporate finance at a big-name school. Try calling in some favors in Vegas to get them started in mergers and acquisitions at a big firm in Beverly Hills or New York. The world has changed. Be in finance. Be in management of a public company. They learned from you and now you can learn from them.

PUB-DATE: January 21, 1990
Correction Appended

SECTION: Section 6; Page 17, Column 1; Magazine Desk

HEADLINE: Aspen: The Call of the Wild

BYLINE: By Jon Bowermaster: Jon Bowermaster is co-author, with Will Steger, of ''Saving the Earth: A Citizen's Guide to Environmental Action,'' to be published by Knopf in April.

 BODY:
THE SUN FIRST PEEKS OVER the Continental Divide just after 6 on New Year's Day, and particularly at this hour, it seems there could be no more beautiful place on earth than the Roaring Fork Valley - red-tinged clay, bright white snow and a pure blue in the sky that only high altitudes can produce. Below, the narrow streets of Aspen, Colo., are empty, yielding no signs of the previous night's parties. Instead of whoops of frivolity there is only the squawking of jays and nutcrackers. 
Still, the morning tranquillity can barely disguise the tremors of celebration that have rocked the town all week long. Sleeping soundly under goose-down Duvets in multimillion-dollar ranches and $2,000-a-night hotel suites is the biggest concentration of rich and famous people in perhaps the world. They gathered here, in this small town in the Rocky Mountains, to witness the end of the 80's. The glitz contingent has become part and parcel of every story and conversation about Aspen. And every season it grows larger. Whether recited alphabetically (Irving Azoff, Ed Bradley, Cher, Michael Douglas, Chris Evert, Jane Fonda, Melanie Griffith, etc.) or by genre -movie stars (Nicholson, Hawn, Schwarzenegger); moguls (Tisch, Walton, Murdoch); socialites (Bass, Guest, Hunt); media (Ziff, Walters, Steinem); musicians (Simon, Henley, Van Halen, Buffett); models (Paulina, Christie) - the list of regulars leaves the same impression. That this community of 6,000 year-round residents has become the wintertime place to be. ''I get to work out, ski, meet a lot of beautiful women, go to great restaurants and hang out with my friends,'' says the Hollywood producer Don Simpson. ''Every day is a party.''
The rich and famous make their most concentrated ascendance between Christmas and New Year's, when the population of the normally peaceful end-of-the-valley triples, and the roar of private jets breaks the stillness with regularity. And this year's scene, by all previous standards, was unmatched. Marvin Davis flew in an entourage of 40, including Gregory Peck and Sidney Poitier; Dustin Hoffman and Calvin Klein brought their families. Barbara Walters, Lee Iacocca, Don Johnson, Adnan Khashoggi - they came to drink in the natural beauty of the place, and to get drunk on the scene. Nouveau riche groupies, starlet wannabes and assorted hangers-on roamed the downtown mall in high heels, furs and diamonds. Nonskiers sported $2,000 ski suits. Press agents called the local papers to announce the comings and goings of their ''clients.'' (One L.A. p.r. man worked the phones the day before New Year's Eve desperately trying to find a party for a couple of his rich-but-nobody clients. ''They're in Aspen and it's not happening for them,'' he moaned.) Over all, such intermittent invasions take up just a few weeks each year, but their effect - on both the world's opinion of the place and the town's own state of mind - lasts year long. The result has been a predomination of acquisition over preservation. Hundred-year-old Victorian houses have been bought, torn down and replaced by modern mansions that cover every inch of quarter-acre lots. Houses built on spec are furnished right down to the towels and the books. One-bedroom condos go for $500,000, to commodity brokers from Los Angeles or bankers from New York; there were some 50,000 landings last year at Aspen's tiny airport, more than half of them by private planes. And Range Rovers - at $40,000 each - are so ubiquitous that a serviceman flies in once or twice a week from Denver to do warranty work. Accompanying all this are the accouterments of money and leisure - caterers, florists, expensive restaurants and boutiques, and security guards.
YET DESPITE THE KNOCKOUT aura of the place and the quiet beginning to this new decade, things are hardly peaceful. Scratch the surface of the glitz and you uncover a small town - albeit a rich, high-profile one - wrangling very publicly toward the 21st century, trying its damnedest to maintain the beauty, diversity and hipness that made it a world-class community in the first-place. Led by a four-term mayor some call a dictator, Aspen has banned smoking and neon and will soon vote on becoming the first town in the world, perhaps, to ban the sale of fur coats. A local newspaper columnist has suggested a ban on bans.
In the meantime, real-estate prices have doubled in the last three years. Affordable housing is virtually nonexistent. (Last year, single-family homes in the United States cost on average $111,755; in Aspen, $937,000.) Traffic jams snarl the two-lane highway that leads into town. Air pollution is increasing. Minimum wage is about $8 an hour, yet ''help wanted'' ads are plentiful.
As a result, the one-time hippie haven is becoming increasingly homogenized, more conservative; more a place for the haves and less a place for the have-nots, whose ranks include schoolteachers, lawyers and other members of the middle class. The classic ski bum has all but disappeared. ''I want my plumber to live in Aspen,'' says George S. Stranahan, tavern owner and founder of the Aspen Center for Physics. Indeed, locals are scared that the town will soon become the exclusive hangout for the fabulously rich and that their end of the valley may be nothing but an opulent ghost town during much of the year, with the million-dollar second homes shuttered, the streets quiet and lifeless.
While insisting that ''spirited public debate'' has always been a part of Aspen's charm, Mayor Bill Stirling says that lately it's turned vicious. A shrill faction of longtime locals - joined by a handful of newcomers who would like to close the gate behind them - rages constantly against new growth, furious that their home has become known as a ''salt lick for celebrities,'' ''a petting zoo for the rich and famous.'' Hopeful developers from out of town are harassed by threats of injunctions, lawsuits, gossip, even violence. The nearly nonstop contentiousness has the outgoing city manager advising applicants for his post to think twice.
But maybe the most eloquent expression of Aspen's current state surfaced soon after the 90's had begun. The pizza maker at the ultrachic Mezzaluna restaurant announced in broken English that he was soon leaving town for Beverly Hills. ''It's just gotten too expensive here,'' he said.
ASPEN HAS ALWAYS BEEN A special place. The Ute Indians called it ''The Valley of the Thunder River,'' and used it for a summer camp. The first miners-to-be crossed the 12,000-foot Independence Pass on snowshoes in the winter of 1879, dubbing their new home Ute City, then Aspen, after the wispy, white-barked trees that climb the steep rock canyon. By the 1890's - thanks largely to a Macy's department store partner, Jerome B. Wheeler - Aspen was home to literary clubs, polo matches and skiing, on barrel staves. The grand opening of his Hotel Jerome, on Thanksgiving eve 1889, was attended by society from around the globe and Aspen became known worldwide as the Silver Capital.
In the late 1800's, the silver market, thus Aspen, collapsed. The town sat abandoned, its buildings crumbling, until the late 1940's, when the Chicago industrialist Walter Paepcke set out to revitalize it. Paepcke's vision was of another kind of boom town, a mecca for 20th-century thinkers and outdoors lovers, sort of a winter and summer camp for the elite. He financed a ski resort, and started the Aspen Institute for the Humanities and the Music Associates of Aspen, local institutions that today boast international reputations.
The creeping problems affecting Aspen today have surfaced over the last two decades. Many locals blame the ''Freak Power'' political movement of the early 1970's - highlighted by a much-publicized run for sheriff by the renegade journalist Hunter S. Thompson - which encouraged successive administrations of staunch no-growthers. They adopted stringent zoning laws, effectively throttling development. But, ironically, by clamping down on new building, the new rules essentially closed the valley and drove real-estate prices sky high, thus setting the stage for creating the nouveau riche boom that now threatens to swallow the town.
During the nationwide recession of the early 1980's, the City Council loosened its chokehold, and new building erupted. Councilman Stephen S. Crockett blames much of the current overdevelopment on that loosening of strictures. ''It didn't work, and they essentially gave away the ranch,'' Crockett says. ''We could stop granting all construction here tomorrow, and there would be enough permits left to allow building for another two and a half years.''
Perhaps the growth wouldn't rankle so much if it wasn't so ostentatious. Take Frederick (Ted) and Suzanne Field - he's the Marshall Field's department-store heir - and their $16.3 million house on Aspen Mountain, for example. Reached by a freestanding 50-foot elevator, it boasts 8 bedrooms, 9 baths and 27 televisions (including one in the sauna). Cross-valley on Red Mountain, Leslie Wexner, owner of the Limited, has built a $26 million, 25,000-square-foot manse. Not one to be topped, Prince Bandar Bin Sultan Bin Abdul Aziz, the Saudi Ambassador to the United States, is constructing a 55,000-square-foot palace in nearby Starwood. Producer-actor Michael Douglas and partners are soon to start developing 6,400 acres six miles out of town.
Marvin Davis, (Continued on Page 28) the oilman who runs the movie studio 20th Century-Fox and whose family owns almost half the Aspen Skiing Company, takes the town's approach to growth in stride. (Though he's owned the company since 1981, this Christmas was his first visit to Aspen.) ''Look,'' he says by speaker phone from Los Angeles, ''everybody's got a bit of heaven they'd like to protect from the outside world, but they just can't protect Aspen anymore. I don't think the town can hold back the growth; it's going to expand in spite of itself.
''I can't believe what people are paying for real estate. And there's no reason or rhyme, other than there's this desire to be in Aspen.''
Among year-rounders, however, there is no such thing as a pro-development stance in Aspen. Everyone is antigrowth - in varying stages from slow- to no- .
Dick Butera represents one faction of no-growther - the kind that has already gotten a piece of the rock and wouldn't mind seeing the gate to the valley closed to new development. Onetime president of the Hilton Head Company in South Carolina, he moved to Aspen in 1981 and now owns a fitness club and a real-estate company. His wife, Julie Anthony, who manages their Aspen Club, once explained to Psychology Today why they settled in the Rockies: ''In Aspen clothing stores, the sizes are smaller because the men have narrower waists and the women have better figures. My husband and I were here two weeks before we saw a fat person or a pimple.''
Butera admits there are people in town - ''oldtimers,'' he calls them - who are being passed up by the current boom. But he wonders if the town isn't really better for the changes. ''We've got three fabulous health clubs, a first-class hotel, the gondola, high-speed lifts, bike paths all over. The town is cleaner, all the electric wires are buried, the bus service is extensive and free, public swimming pools are fabulous. The school system is better, Alcoholics Anyonymous is packed full, so are the churches. I don't know what else a society is supposed to do.''
He also insists it is just a small minority who think Aspen's vaunted ''sense of community'' is threatened by the influx of the superrich. ''Out of the 10 public officials in office in Aspen now, 8 of them were hippies,'' he says. ''As a result, we've had a lot of looney stuff going on, which was part of our character. Our past two mayors posed nude in calendars. But the town is changing. Not for good, not for bad, it is simply changing.''
Councilman Crockett represents the more virulent strain of Aspen's no-growthers. He says: ''The ski culture, the quality-of-life culture, is being eroded by people capitalizing on the real-estate boom - people who think with their wallets and are motivated by a different set of values than those who gave this town its original character and substance.''
A 20-year-resident, Crocket was elected last May, running on the ''Endangered Species'' ticket, and his vision of Aspen's future is bleak. ''The melting-pot aspect of this community is one thing that made it so unique,'' Crockett says. ''The new money has no desire to integrate into the community. They want to be waited on and catered to, they don't even want to shovel their own walks. It's the opposite of when in Rome do what the Romans do - it's more like, buy Rome, and make the Romans wait on you.''
THE BATTLE THAT best exemplifies the struggle for the soul of Aspen is the fight over a five-star hotel to be built at the foot of Aspen Mountain. The subject has dominated public meetings and barrooms for nearly a decade, and a hotel is still nowhere near to being built, despite the fact that there is a gaping, blocklong hole in the ground where it is supposed to be. Every weapon - referendum, lawsuits, populist coalitions, even a recent bomb threat - has been used to combat the project and no end is in sight. The current developer, Washington-based Mohamed Hadid (in conjunction with Ritz-Carlton), is back in court to get construction approved.
Two previous developers went bankrupt. The property was bypassed by some of the country's biggest developers, reportedly scared off by the town's reputation for ''spirited public debate.'' Hadid swept the property out from underneath the feet of Donald Trump in 1987, paying $42.9 million for a package that includes 80 valuable acres scattered around town. (Trump had bid $17.5 million for the hotel site alone.) But typically, Trump has not conceded. He's still in litigation with Hadid, arguing he has first claim on the land.
Hadid's real-estate portfolio comprises mostly D.C.-area office buildings and he is a partner in three other Ritz hotels. So far the Aspen purchase has been nothing but a drain on his pocketbook at a time when it has been reported that his office-building empire is crumbling. He bought the land after just a couple visits to town.
''He fell in love with the beauty of the place without understanding the process,'' says Mayor Stirling. ''He's the kind of guy who just wants to be noticed.''
Hadid made himself highly visible in town, buying a big house, throwing lavish parties and touring the streets in his Bentley convertible. But his efforts to get a 292-room Ritz-Carlton built have been stymied at every step by the City Council, which is now putting the issue back to the people. One of the issues on a Feb. 13 special ballot will be whether Hadid should be allowed to build the hotel as planned, or one 25 percent smaller. Hadid insists that he won't build a smaller hotel and has asked the courts to grant him construction approval. He says he's bent over backward to appease the town and its planners, going through hundreds of meetings, a handful of redesigns and promising plenty of ''bribes,'' including building a public ice rink. ''I'm tired of spending and I'm tired of giving,'' said a worn-sounding Hadid on New Year's Eve, two days after his suit against the city was announced. ''I've already spent $13 million. The problem is that they don't rule by long- term plans, they rule by emotion.''
Dick Butera offers one reason why there has been so much opposition to Hadid. ''The untold story is the 21,000-square-foot convention center that is in that hotel,'' Butera says. ''I don't want to sound elitist here, but that spells Shriners with hats and beer cans up and down the streets.'' Butera, for one, would actually prefer that if anybody were to build a hotel in Aspen it be Trump.
''I'd build something much more in keeping with the town,'' says Trump, who has visited Aspen several times, though he doesn't yet own any property there. ''And they'd love to have me. I've been sort of an Aspenite, as much as you can be an Aspenite. I go there with my family every, uh, every chance. I'm out there a lot.''
In the next breath, Trump admits he would ''make more in one day in Atlantic City than I can make in 10 years in Aspen.'' Then why Aspen? ''Because it's a place I go to. Because I'm there, that's the only reason.'' That's exactly the kind of attitude that frightens longtime Aspenites. Hadid laughs at Trump's insistence that he will be Aspen's newest hotelier and adds that no matter what happens with the Ritz-Carlton project he's in Aspen for the long run. The pair of superegos bumped into each other during the recent holiday week and had a brief, smiling conversation. ''He asked me when I was going to finish that hole in the ground,'' relates Hadid. ''I said, 'Donald, at least I have a hole.' ''
THE 800-POUND GORILLA in the midst of all this is the Aspen Skiing Company, founded in 1946. Composed today of three of the valley's four skiing hills (Aspen Mountain, Snowmass and Buttermilk) and two hotels (the Little Nell and 50 percent of the Snowmass Club), it is the community's biggest employer (2,000 during peak season) and cash generator (1.2 million skier visits in 1988-89, times an average $30 per lift ticket). No matter how contentious things get, no one ever forgets that 60 percent of the town's revenues are generated during the five-month ski season and that skiing is still the main reason people come to town. Many locals think the ski company is most to blame for fostering the image of a glitzy, elitist Aspen.
''It's easy to beat up on the ski company,'' says Bob Maynard, its fourth president in the last decade. ''In people's minds it's 'The Company,' the bad guy. It's like being mad at the Government.''
The latest chapter in the Aspen Skiing Company history began when Marvin Davis bought 20th Century-Fox in 1981; the movie studio had purchased it for $48.6 million in 1978, an invasion that in itself made some locals uncomfortable. It made others very rich. Fox agreed to pay $45 per share to stockholders at a time when the stock was selling for $24.
When Davis (and his then-partner Marc Rich, the oil-trader-cum-tax-fugitive) bought the movie company for $722 million, the package included two high-profile resorts, Pebble Beach and Aspen. The paper chase that followed is a classic example of how Davis has become a billionaire - by bringing in partners to help pay off leveraged debt, and using profits from the sale of various assets to buy down his own risk. Soon after he bought Fox, he spun off the stock or assets of Pebble Beach, Aspen, Coca-Cola Bottling Midwest, Hoyt Theaters (an Australian chain) and the real estate under the movie-company lot into a joint venture with Urban Diversified Properties Inc., a subsidiary of Aetna Life & Casualty. The bottler and the movie theater chain were then sold off.
In December 1983, Davis took on more partners - three real-estate cronies from Chicago and Denver - and the limited partnership, dubbed Miller-Klutznick-Davis-Gray , bought out Aetna's half-interest in Aspen, Pebble Beach and the Century City land operations. Then they bought out Fox's half-interest. Chicagoan Tom Klutznick was named to oversee the resorts. In 1985, in a final move to raise money and distribute risk, the partners sold half of the Aspen Skiing Company to the Crown family of Chicago. When he first became involved, says Klutznick, ''it was the biggest disaster I'd ever seen at a resort. This was a community that in a sense had made itself kind of a private club and was using the facilities to serve its own interests. They wanted a little utopia and did not really want tourists there, or even outsiders. So we got rid of a lot of employees and managers, and in 1987 brought in Bob Maynard. By then the table had been set - the company, the mountains and the company's position in the community had all been dramatically improved.'' (Continued on Page 42) It was just before May- nard's arrival that the company made its most disastrous public-relations gaffe, incurring the most serious community wrath, when it announced the nation's first $35 lift ticket and simultaneously doubled prices for resident passes. Local agitation was so high that Mayor Stirling flew to Washington to complain to Colorado's Congressional delegation.
Since then, the company has made several moves to ingratiate locals. Resident passes have returned to their original price. Plus, locals over 70 now ski free at Buttermilk, and college students home for the holidays get reduced lift-ticket prices. But the most visible change the company made was in the other direction, a high-gloss ad campaign, begun in 1988.
The $1.25 million print and radio campaign was a distinct move away from typical ski resort advertising, which, in print at least, tends to be dominated by red ski parkas, gleaming smiles and knee-deep powder. Created by Hal Riney, originator of well-known ads for Perrier and Bartles & Jaymes wine coolers, the campaign focuses on Aspen's natural beauty and brags up the valley's three mountains, 100 bars and restaurants, and 200 shops and boutiques. The ads are beautiful. They also border on the pretentious, leading critics to accuse the company of pandering to the rich.
Klutznick admits having second thoughts about the campaign. ''I was willing and supportive of taking the high road,'' he says, meaning a presentation of Aspen as ''a gentle, spiritual, warm environment.''
''But at the same time,'' he continues, ''part of our success in the winter stems from the people we've attracted. I can't apologize for the fact that we attract jet-setters and Hollywood stars. Should I tell Rupert Murdoch not to come next year? You want me to stop the direct flights from Los Angeles? Those people are part of the image of Aspen.''
Bob Maynard adds that while glitz is an inherent part of Aspen, it is a smaller part than most make it. ''If a writer comes into town for a day, that's what he writes about,'' Maynard says. ''It's easy. Skiing with Jack Nicholson - everyone's going to read that. In the long run, that probably helps us; I don't mind it. But some of us feel very strongly about pushing other aspects of Aspen, so that there's a balance. It's not that we're antiglitz, let's just not leave out the other parts. Some people actually come here because the fishing is good.''
ULTIMATELY WHAT'S GOT Aspen's civic leaders - if not yet its visitors - quaking in their ski boots is not the current glory days, but the years that stretch ahead. Several complicated roadblocks stand between the town and future serenity.
Lack of affordable housing may be the town's biggest headache of the 90's. It has made it extremely difficult for the booming boutiques, restaurants, hotels and even the ski company to attract help. The new $35 million Little Nell hotel - and other employers - are busing help from as far as 70 miles downvalley, from Silt and Parachute, Rifle and Basalt. (In a Robin Hood-meets-the-80's tale, some employees living in housing set aside for them have illegally rented bedrooms to tourists, a kind of take-from-the-rich, rent-to- the-rich parable.) Several plans are on the boards to build employee housing; the county has a goal of building 100 affordable units in 1990 and at least that many in 1991. Some want to see that doubled. At the same time, taxpayers are revolting at the idea of their dollars being spent for the benefit of the profitable businesses in town. And it's not just the minimum-wage employee who is suffering. The last director of the town's art museum, for example, left in part because she couldn't find a two-bedroom apartment for less than $2,000 a month. Transportation in and out of the valley - especially since so much of the town's employment base must now commute - is the other big concern. Highway 82 - known locally as ''Killer 82,'' for the myriad car wrecks that claim lives each winter - is a two-lane road that winds southeast for 40 miles from Glenwood Springs, alongside roaring rivers and between close canyon walls. Because of congestion, during a winter storm it can take two and a half hours to travel. Along its narrowest stretches, expansion to four lanes will cost an estimated $2 million per mile. Plus, the increased commuting is causing more air pollution and the county is wrestling with a clean air bill that could cost $500,000.
Forecasts for slowing growth are bleak: the Colorado Department of Highways Draft Environmental Impact Statement for Highway 82 predicts 34 percent commercial growth in Aspen by 2010, 80 percent commercial and population growth in Snowmass Village, and 56 percent more cars entering the valley. But perhaps the most immediate threat is that the nonprofit organizations that are the base of the town's cultural heritage are getting fed up. The International Design Conference in Aspen, Music Associates of Aspen (sponsors of the Aspen Music Festival) and the Aspen Institute have all considered moving to other communities, largely because the city has grown too expensive to house visitors, faculty and students. Last winter, the Aspen/Snowmass Repertory Theater had to cancel its season because no affordable lodging could be found for employees. (Included in the Feb. 13 referendum that will decide whether Hadid's hotel should be approved as designed, whether to ban fur sales and which Highway 82 segment should be expanded, is the fate of a bond issue that would fund student and faculty housing for several nonprofit groups.) David T. McLaughlin is president of the Aspen Institute, which sponsors international conferences on political philosophy and policy issues. Though its year-round base is in Queenstown, Md., it operates in Aspen from mid-June to Labor Day and holds a couple of seminars in January and March. This summer the institute celebrates its 40th anniversary with a major symposium to be attended by national and world leaders. ''It's a rather significant event and here we're sitting not knowing if we'll have facilities to house it,'' says McLaughlin. The institute's current residential facilities are worn, and badly in need of renovation. But that won't happen anytime soon because of the struggle between the City Council and Hadid. Hadid owns the land, but he's not going to put any money into renovation as long as his dispute with the town over the Ritz drags on.
McLaughlin insists the problem is one of priorities, that the Council has been so absorbed fighting developers that it has ignored the town's roots. ''It's not like any political process I've ever witnessed,'' he says. ''The Aspen Institute convenes leaders from all over the world. We discuss monumental problems like arms control. Yet we can't seem to use our convening power to get anything done in Aspen.'' He maintains that the institute, as well as the other not-for-profits, are committed to remaining where they are ''as long as we can have facilities there that meet our minimum requirements.'' But he adds: ''Are the facilities adequate today? No they are not.'' And without improvements, he says, ''we have a very limited future in Aspen.''
THERE IS SOME SENTIMENT that the town's very feistiness -at one time an attraction - is starting to wear thin. The endless battles have taken their toll. Longtime residents are moving on, newcomers growing increasingly agitated. And if the town didn't have enough squabbling on its plate, in early December a band of locals - under the banners of the Citizens Recall Coalition and the People's Rights Organization - began collecting signatures on petitions to recall Mayor Stirling and three of four councilmen. Tom Klutznick thinks if matters are left completely to the current crop of elected officials, things may take a grave turn. ''I think they would like to see a very formidable gate put up across Highway 82 entering the community,'' he says, ''with representatives of the extreme left as the gatekeepers, determining who can come in and cannot and under what circumstances. They would probably issue visas of very short-term duration.'' Councilman Crockett would no doubt supervise the construction of such a barricade. As added fuel for his political stance, the small downtown house he has rented for 17 years was recently sold to a couple from Los Angeles, for $500,000. He's not sure where he's going to move. ''You know, I get accused as a politician of trying to make war, not peace,'' Crockett says. ''That's because I don't think there is room for peace here. Go back in history. Ask the Apaches or the Utes how successful they were in protecting their culture by compromising, by making peace. Their advice today, I'm sure, would be, 'It's war. Kill.' ''

Because of an editing error, an article in The Times Magazine last Sunday about Aspen, Colo., misstated Marvin Davis's role in the 20th Century Fox Film Corporation. He sold his interest in 1985.

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: January 22, 1990

SECTION: Section A; Page 1, Column 2; National Desk

LENGTH: 1570 words

HEADLINE: A Tearful Mayor Barry Pledges To Seek Help for 'Weaknesses'

BYLINE: By B. DRUMMOND AYRES Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 21

 BODY:
His personal and political life shattered by a criminal charge that he smoked crack, a repentant Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. said today, in public and in tears, that he had ''weaknesses'' and would seek help for them.
''I'm going to find a way to begin to heal my body, mind and soul,'' the Mayor announced in a brief statement that, while legally and politically circumspect, seemed as much a personal confession and a catharsis as anything.
Mr. Barry did not actually say he had a drug or alcohol problem or disclose what kind of help he would seek or where he would seek it. In past grand jury testimony he has denied ever using drugs, and an open acknowledgment of a narcotics problem could leave him open to charges of perjury and weaken any claim he might make that he had been entrapped by the Federal agents and local police officers who arrested him.
 
Wife Says He Needs Help
But Mr. Barry's wife, Effi, standing beside him at St. Timothy's Episcopal Church, near their home, said somberly that her husband had a problem and that he needed help. 
The Mayor's press secretary, Lurma Rackley, said, ''The most serious problem involves alcoholism.'' She said she did not know if he had a drug problem.
Nor did Mr. Barry talk about his political plans, thrown into turmoil by his arrest Thursday night at a local hotel after undercover agents said they filmed him smoking crack.
The pressure on him to quit has intensified in the last day. Federal prosecutors say they have additional leverage now that Mr. Barry's old friend Charles Lewis has been sentenced to 15 months in prison on charges of distributing and possessing cocaine at a hotel here a year ago. In a plea bargain with prosecutors, Mr. Lewis said he had used drugs with the Mayor several times; Mr. Barry paid several visits to Mr. Lewis at the hotel but has insisted under oath that he neither bought nor used drugs there.
Aides and friends, many of them ministers who spent the weekend counseling the Mayor, said he was suffering from drug and alcohol abuse and would seek help. They said he had been talking to Dick Gregory, the former comedian who now is a health counselor, and was considering entering either the Betty Ford Center in Rancho Mirage, Calif., or a clinic in the Washington area.
The aides and friends also said that while Mr. Barry was under pressure to resign as part of a plea bargain with prosecutors, he might well refuse. He is a proud man, they said, intent on seeing out his full term. If he resigned he would be replaced by the chairman of the City Council, David A. Clarke, a political enemy.
 
Special Election Is Possible
If he does resign, a special election will be held on the first Tuesday 114 days after the formal resignation. No special election would be necessary if the Nov. 6 general election fell within the 114-day period.
Jay B. Stephens, the United States Attorney, has indicated that Mr. Lewis's cooperation with the authorities could lead to further charges against Mayor Barry, who is still the subject of a grand jury investigation. In an emotional statement at his sentencing Friday, Mr. Lewis said he had once felt ''that because I used drugs with other professionals, with others in government, with the Mayor of this city, that I should lie to protect them and myself.''
Mr. Stephens has suggested that as he considers how to proceed with the investigation, he would look favorably on a decision by Mr. Barry to resign.
While Mr. Barry remained ambivalent - tormented, some of his friends said - about the possibility of resigning, there was little doubt that he would forgo a bid for re-election for a fourth term as Mayor of Washington.
''I don't think he intends to step down,'' said Bishop H. Hartford Brookins, of the African Methodist Episcopal Church in Washington, a close adviser who said Mr. Barry's statement was prompted by dependence ''upon some kind of drugs and alcohol.''
''I think he will not run for mayor again,'' the bishop added. ''He wants to leave office with a measure of appreciation,''
 
Resign, Say 57% in Poll
In a Washington Post poll published today, 57 percent of the 661 Washingtonians polled by telephone the night after his arrest said Mr. Barry should resign and 76 percent said he should not seek re-election. The Post said the margin of sampling error was plus or minus about four percentage points.
At least four present or former members of the City Council, including Mr. Clarke, plan to run for the Mayor's job, whatever his plans. All are Democrats, and all are considered to have a chance of winning.
The winner of the primary is likely to face Maurice Turner, the former Police Chief, in the general election in November. He is one of the few Republicans given a chance in this overwhelmingly Democratic city.
There is one other important political factor. The Rev. Jesse Jackson moved to Washington from Chicago last year, leading to talk that he might be interested in running for mayor. He has said repeatedly that he would never run against Mr. Barry, an old ally in the civil rights movement, but there is heightened speculation now that his position may change.
He was unavailable for comment today, canceling a public appearance at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel in New York, where he had been scheduled to speak before the Council for the Advancement and Support of Education. An aide said he had laryngitis.
In the Post poll, 42 percent of the registered voters said they would vote for Mr. Jackson if he ran, far more than for any other potential candidate.
 
Administrator in Charge
Pending his trial on the drug charge, the Mayor has turned over most of his duties to the city manager, Carol B. Thompson. An experienced administrator, she has the authority to take over almost all government functions except signing legislation and executing some contracts.
Ms. Thompson, 38 years old, who graduated from Smith College and holds a master of arts in public administration from New York University, was formerly Deputy Mayor for economic development and before that served as Mr. Barry's chief of staff.
 
Past Denials Put Aside
Until this morning, Mr. Barry had always denied adamantly, often angrily, that he had any substance problem. But at 9:30 A.M., in a church Sunday school room across the street from his home, fixed in the glare of television lights and in the crowding presence of 100 or so reporters and old friends, he put aside those denials in a flood of tears and crushed hubris.
''How I wish I could trade this hour!'' he lamented.
The hour, perhaps the most humbling of all in a once shining, always proud public career that began 30 years ago on the civil rights battlegrounds of the Deep South, was brought on by the Mayor's arrest in a hotel in the heart of the capital, a city beset by one of the worst cocaine epidemics in the country. Undercover agents said they videotaped him there smoking cocaine given him by a model whom police described as a former girlfriend of the Mayor's. The agents said the model was cooperating with them.
 
Confession and Apology
Originally, the hour was to be used by Mr. Barry to announce that he would seek re-election to a fourth term. Instead, he found himself making a confession to the public and then making what seemed to be an apology to his wife. All in all, he said, nothing he had ever experienced, not even the poverty and racism of the Old South, had been as difficult.
''This time,'' he said, his cheeks glistening with tears, ''I've come face to face with my deepest human failures. I've had to look my human weaknesses straight in the eye - had to realize that God made Marion Barry the same as He made other people, a flesh and blood creation who rises and falls just like any other human being.''
''It's not Marion Barry, the Mayor, that counts,'' he went on. ''It's Marion Barry, the person.''
His confession out, the Mayor managed a smile and broke into the sing-song cadence often heard in black churches in the South. His friends scattered throughout the room responded with soft interjections.
''I realize I'm going to have to walk this journey by myself,'' Mr. Barry began. ''Amen!'' a friend intoned. ''It's going to take Marion Barry walking this journey.'' ''Tell it, brother.'' ''But I say to others who have pain and hurt as I am, 'Join me, brothers and sisters; we can make it.' '' ''Well!'' ''We can make it.'' ''Well!'' ''We will make it.'' ''Amen!'' 'Burden That Has Been Lifted'
The Mayor then turned to his wife, standing beside him, who had endured not only the slings and arrows of his political fortune but also the rumors of his narcotics addiction and womanizing.
''Effi has been with me almost 12 years now as my wife,'' he said, haltingly now.
''And she's just great,'' he added, leaning over to give her a kiss.
Mrs. Barry, who once described her husband as a ''street dude,'' took the podium. Until that point, she had been almost totally unanimated except for a brief moment when she stroked her husband's hand. But now she came alive, promising that she and their 9-year-old son, Christopher, would stay at his side.
''Marion,'' she said, ''for you to admit to the world that you have a problem, that you need to deal with your problem to make yourself whole again, is truly a burden that has been lifted from our souls. And I know that for our family this is just the beginning.''

HEADLINE: On-the-Air Diary of a Passage Toward Death

BYLINE: By JANE GROSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 21

 BODY:
Once a week here on the evening news, television viewers are making the acquaintance of a man with AIDS, hearing firsthand about his fears and frailties and watching his jaunty passage toward death.
Even in San Francisco, a city more sophisticated about AIDS than any other in the nation, ''Paul Wynne's Journal,'' as the segment is known, is stunning television, shocking for some viewers, illuminating for others and invigorating for its dying star, a broadcast journalist in years past.
''This is potent stuff,'' said Harry Fuller, the news director at KGO-TV, the local American Broadcasting Company affiliate, who was braced for a flurry of criticism from viewers that has not materialized. ''The first night, we watched in my office, and hardened news reporters were in tears.''
The first segment began with a tape of Mr. Wynne in his days as an husky, handsome entertainment reporter, before his 1987 diagnosis. Then the image switched suddenly to Mr. Wynne in the newsroom today, seated at a computer terminal. Slowly, he swiveled his chair and turned toward the audience, unrecognizably gaunt, his bright blue eyes deep in their sockets and his cheeks hollow. 
''This is the face of AIDS,'' Mr. Wynne said.
 
In Praise of Courage
Then he flipped through some recent snapshots of himself and wrinkled his nose in displeasure. ''The holiday photos I didn't send the folks,'' Mr. Wynne said.
The debut of the on-the-air diary, on Jan. 11, was greeted with rave reviews from Bay Area television critics and scores of telephone calls and letters, the vast majority praising the station for its courage and Mr. Wynne for sharing his ordeal with hundreds of thousands of strangers.
Like the journal itself, the reaction has been intensely personal. A reviewer wrote in The Oakland Tribune that he knew no one who had AIDS and had been ''personally insulated from this tragedy'' until now. A viewer from San Jose sent her telephone number, saying she was a ''stay-at-home with arthritis'' and suggesting Mr. Wynne ''call any time if you'd like someone to talk to.'' Another viewer mailed him a crocheted afghan.
''I wonder if any other market in the country would accept what I'm doing so graciously and warmly as the Bay Area,'' Mr. Wynne said.
 
The Viewers Can Choose
Mr. Fuller said he had no misgivings about putting Mr. Wynne on the air, although he designed the broadcast so viewers had a choice whether they wanted to watch it. The segment is introduced before a commercial, so people know exactly what is coming and have time to shut off their sets or send their children from the room.
''I don't believe in ambush news,'' Mr. Fuller said. The second segment of Mr. Wynne's journal, seen here on the Thursday edition of the 6 o'clock news, dealt with the bigotry that homosexuals encounter in the age of AIDS. Mr. Wynne tells the story of two friends, gay but not ill, who are consigned to the foot of the table at a fancy dinner party by a hostess who serves them off paper plates while the other guests eat off Limoges china.
''Did she think their silverware would contaminate her dishwasher?'' Mr. Wynne asked, surrounded by elegant props that he borrowed from Gump's department store.
The segment is more glib than painful, which Mr. Wynne said is true to his personality. ''One of the reasons this works is I know how to crack a smile, make a joke,'' he said. ''I'm someone people will let in their homes, on a subject they might not want in their homes. Let me make friends with them first, and then I'll move on to tougher issues.''
 
Hardships Are Chronicled
In the weeks and months to come, Mr. Wynne plans to show viewers the contents of his medicine cabinet, full of pills and potions since his diagnosis. He plans to describe what daily life is like for a 47-year-old man who is sometimes so weak that ''just stepping onto a curb is a major proposition.''
He plans to tell viewers about losing 55 pounds and the subsequent months when he hid in his apartment because ''I didn't want to be seen as another emaciated, pale AIDS person shuffling down the street.'' He plans to itemize the financial impact of his disease, which dissuades him from drawing a regular salary from KGO because it would jeopardize his government benefits.
He plans a list of the most undiplomatic things people have said to him, including his father's observation that he ''looked like a cadaver.'' He plans a critical evaluation of obituaries in the era of acquired immune deficiency syndrome. He plans to talk about friends who have died and those who have been ''widowed.'
He plans to remain on the air until he runs out of things to say or runs out of energy to say them. ''I may end up doing the last few from a hospital bed,'' Mr. Wynne said.
 
Help With a Legacy
Mr. Fuller said there are no specific plans for how the series will end. ''It's up to him and how he feels,'' the news director said. ''Paul wants to leave a legacy, and we want to help him.''
There is a paradox in Mr. Wynne's current success, which comes after five years of unemployment. He had been an entertainment reporter on three local television stations from 1972 until 1984, until a former news director at KGO chose not to renew his contract. Since then, he received no offers for on-the-air work, in large part, several local television executives said, because his frothy style was not much in demand.
The idea for the AIDS journal was tossing about in Mr. Wynne's mind recently when he was visited by a friend and former colleague, Lorne Morrison, a cameraman at KGO. Mr. Morrison approached Mr. Fuller, who jumped at the chance to break ground. Mr. Wynne said he has ''been walking on air ever since.''
All those involved in project were wary that viewer response might be hostile, even ugly. Mr. Wynne immediately got an unlisted phone number to avoid homophobic hate calls. ''I don't want some nut calling at 3 o'clock in the morning,'' he said.
 
Stereotypes Are Resisted
Mr. Wynne was also frightened to open a package that arrived at the station the other day, thinking it might be a bomb. Instead, swaddled in white tissue paper, he found the afghan.
The letters, too, have defied expectation, with only one unpleasant one in the first batch of 30. ''If he had lived his life according to God's word he would not be experiencing the results of sin,'' the offended viewer wrote. ''Whatsoever a man soweth he shall also reap.''
Mr. Wynne took account of religious fundamentalists in the opening segment, saying they would likely be infuriated by his presence on mainstream television. ''Good!'' he declared. ''That alone will keep me alive and kicking for another year.''
But among the letters to the station are several from people who identified themselves as fundamentalists and quarreled with Mr. Wynne's stereotype. ''The ones who hate you are not true Christians and only succeed in making the rest of us look ugly and bigoted,'' one such letter said.
Mr. Wynne's eyes brim when he considers the wondrous, unexpected things that are happening to him, the impact he is having on thousands of strangers and they on him.
''I feel smothered with love,'' he said. ''And I am so glad to have a reason to get up in the morning.''

HEADLINE: Haiti Deports Some Opposition Leaders

BYLINE: By JOSEPH B. TREASTER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MIAMI, Jan. 21

 BODY:
The military Government of Haiti has begun expelling political leaders and at least one presidential candidate was reported in hiding today, a day after the imposition of a state of siege.
The Haitian leader, Lieut. Gen. Prosper Avril, who seized power 16 months ago, said he ordered the state of siege late Saturday, curtailing a range of civil liberties, ''to protect democratic accomplishments against terrorism.''
But opposition leaders said General Avril was moving to take back a promise to hold free elections this year, beginning with municipal elections in April. In Washington, the State Department said General Avril's actions ''put at risk the democratic transition in Haiti.'' 
A State Department spokesman, Richard A. Boucher, said, ''Such actions undermine the confidence voters must have to participate in a credible electoral process as well as the confidence of the international community in Haiti's commitment to that process.''
 
'We're in Shock'
Opposition members in Port-au-Prince, the Haitian capital, said dozens of Haitian Government critics were rounded up and beaten Saturday night and this morning. The capital is apprehensive, they said in telephone interviews, and many people are staying home.
''We're in shock,'' said Jean-Claude Roy, the leader of a small opposition group called the Union of Haitian Constitutionalists. ''We don't know what to expect next.''
One of the exiled leaders, Dr. Louis Roy, who was a principal author of the country's latest Constitution in 1987 and who has campaigned for free elections, arrived in Miami at midday and was taken to the home of friends without speaking to reporters. Jean-Claude Roy, who is a nephew of Dr. Roy, said his 74-year-old uncle was taken away from his home in Port-au-Prince on Saturday night by three men wearing civilian clothes and armed with submachine guns. He said no explanation for the expulsion was given.
The first of the Haitian leaders forced into exile, Hubert de Ronceray, who was a presidential candidate in elections in November 1987 that ended in a massacre, and was expected to be a candidate this year, arrived in Miami on Saturday night. At a news conference here today, Mr. De Ronceray declared: ''There is no possibility of democracy with Mr. Avril. He's a dictator.''
 
Leader in Hiding
Another opposition leader, Silvio Claude, a Baptist minister who was a presidential candidate in 1987 and was expected to run again, fled from his house to a secret location when authorities knocked on his door Saturday night, associates said.
All three political leaders had fought the Duvalier family dictatorship that collapsed on Feb. 7, 1986, when President Jean-Claude Duvalier was forced to leave the country and went into exile in France. Mr. de Ronceray and Mr. Claude had been been arrested and harassed by Mr. Duvalier. Dr. Roy had been forced into exile in Canada by Jean-Claude's father, Francois Duvalier, early in the 30-year Duvalier rule.
General Avril served as a close aide to both Duvaliers and was an adviser to Lieut. Gen. Henri Namphy, who took power when Jean-Claude Duvalier fled. The general's rise to power was greeted with skepticism by many Haitians, but their fears that another dictatorship was taking shape were placated by repeated pledges that General Avril would lead the country to democracy.
The Associated Press reported tonight that six other political leaders have been expelled, including Max Bourjolly, the second in leadership of the Haitian Communist Party.
The Avril Government indicated in a statement on the Government radio station that the state of siege, which is to be in effect for 30 days, was prompted by the slaying of Col. Andre Neptune, his wife and a servant by unidentified assailants on Friday night. The bodies were found in Fontamara, a Port-au-Prince neighborhood, about 100 yards from Mr. de Ronceray's home. The colonel was a member of the 1,100-member Presidential Guard, which is General Avril's main power base and which defeated a coup attempt last April in a two-day battle with other army units.
 
Violence Is Common
Political killings and terrorist violence have become common in Haiti since the collapse of the Duvalier dictatorship. The violence is believed to be the work of Duvalier loyalists, including former and present members of the army, who oppose free elections. The country's political leaders say they believe General Avril is merely using the killing of the colonel as a pretext to move against them.
''He wants to spoil the elections,'' Jean-Claude Roy said. Jean-Claude Bajeux, a left-of-center political leader who has been prominently involved in human rights issues, told The Associated Press in an interview in San Juan that Haiti was witnessing steps calculated ''to keep Avril in power as dictator.''
''There will be elections, but they will be a farce, a nomination by the army,'' he said.
General Avril raised new doubts about his intentions on elections in an interview this month in the Government-run newspaper, L'Union, when he said that Haiti was ''undergoing one of the most severe economic crises in its history,'' and added that it was ''hardly desirable that elections take place.''
 
General Visits Taiwan
A week ago, General Avril returned to Haiti from Taiwan, his first trip outside the country as chief of state. At the airport, he fiercely criticized Dr. Roy and two other civic leaders who had cautioned the Taiwan Government in a telex message that the Haitian people were not aware of the reason for General Avril's visit and that any agreements with him would not be binding.
On the eve of the general's return to Haiti, huge piles of human excrement were found outside the offices of several political and labor organizations.

HEADLINE: Old and New Help Clear Hurricane-Felled Trees

BYLINE: By RONALD SMOTHERS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WITHERBEE, S.C., Jan. 20

 BODY:
Amid the shattered grandeur of the Francis Marion National Forest, Buddy, Prince, Duke and Joe took a break the other day from the logging operations that are clearing trees felled by Hurricane Hugo. It was lunchtime, and on the menu was a mixture of oats, corn and molasses.
The four are Percheron draft horses, pressed into service to help haul wind-snapped pines from thousands of acres of the national forest.
As the horses nibbled contentedly, the air was filled with the sounds of helicopters, saws and tractors. The reasons horses are being used along with advanced logging techniques have to do with the sometime conflicting demands of economics and conservation as man battles a calamity that will take nature decades to undo. 
Loggers operating tractor-like skidders, large cranes and lifters marveled at the sight of horses being used in a logging technique that had not been seen here in more than 50 years. #70% of Park's Trees Felled Four months after Hurricane Hugo, both the low-techlogging by horses and the high-tech logging by helicopter are being used to clear the 250,000-acre park, which lost about 70 percent of its trees. But the condition of the once-dense pine forest represents a small part of the devastation caused by the hurricane, said Jack Gould, South Carolina's head forester.
Mr. Gould said he and other foresters had determined that the hurricane, which hit Charleston, S.C., with winds of 135 miles an hour on Sept. 21, swept through a total of 4.4 million acres of privately and publicly owned timberland in the state.
''We estimate that we lost 6.7 billion board feet of timber throughout the state,'' he said. ''That's more timber than was lost in Hurricane Camille, the Yellowstone fires and the eruption of Mount St. Helens combined.''
The $4.3 billion logging industry is South Carolina's third largest business, Mr. Gould said, and employs 30,000 to 40,000 people. Reforestation will take 6 to 10 years, and it will be at least 50 more years before nature completes the restoration.
Mr. Gould and others said the logging industry is thriving now, with the work force swelled by farm workers idled by crop losses from the hurricane and by out-of-state loggers.
 
Forest Fire Danger Seen
''It's not instant death,'' said John Jamison, who operates the Umphleet Mill in McBeth, northeast of the national forest. ''It will be six months to two years before the real problems hit.''
Many fear that even before the economic impact is felt, wildfires feeding on the hurricane debris that litters the forest floor in piles up to 10 feet high will cause another disaster.
The area had 27 fires after the hurricane last fall, as against an average of 10 for that time of the year.
The timber salvage efforts have become that much more urgent, said Glenn Stapleton, the United States Forest Service ranger in charge of the eastern half of the Francis Marion forest. The peak fire season is mid-February to early April.
''If a wildfire gets into that, it could burn 50 or 60 miles inland, Mr. Stapleton said. ''And you aren't talking about days, but weeks before it stops.''
 
Longer and Hotter Fires
Dick Cox, director of fire management for the United States Forest Service's southern region, said such fires burn longer and hotter than those in forests with standing trees.
For this reason, the Forest Service quickly got bids from logging companies to harvest the fallen timber.
At the same time, Mr. Stapleton said, they tried to prevent damage to the soil from heavy equipment that would hamper natural regrowth in sensitive areas of the forest, including the nesting areas of certain species of birds. Among the 50 logging operations now going on in the national forest are those using ''low-impact'' techniques involving horses and helicopters.
Unlike tractors and skidders, horses do not leave ruts in the ground and do not damage trees that are still standing. And the helicopters lift the cut logs by a 250-foot cable, eliminating the need for heavy equipment on the ground.
John Reed, a wizened Tennessean, brought his Percherons into the forest to pull timber from an area that is the main habitat of the red-cockaded woodpecker, an endangered species.
''We're usually ridge-runners in the Great Smokies or up in Maine,'' Mr. Reed said, noting that logging by horses is more common in mountainous areas. ''But we can work on this flat land, too. It's a little slower, but I'll take these old horses over a machine any day.''
Mr. Reed and his crew of five men and four two-horse teams are logging prime, long-needle pine from an area that the Forest Service rarely allows to be logged. The mill that won the bid on this parcel with the promise of bringing in low-impact logging techniques is owned by Joe Cantley and specializes in heart-of-pine flooring, which uses dense, knot-free wood from the very center of the tree.
 
'It's Working Out Fine'
''People told me I was crazy when I told them I was going to bring horses in here,'' Mr. Cantley said. ''But it's working out fine, and other operations have come around offering Mr. Reed three times what I am paying him to get him on their parcels.''
Nearby, the Georgia-Pacific Corporation is using the more expensive method of logging by helicopter to pull fallen 85-year-old loblolly pines from an experimental forest area. Joe Watkins, the engineer on the project. said such costly techniques were more common in logging hardwood trees, which have a higher value than conifers.
But the Forest Service requirement that the operations on the experimental forest use low-impact methods and Georgia-Pacific's need to supply a nearby mill made it necessary to reach out to the Oregon-based Columbia Helicopter Company for a helicopter big enough to lift 28,000 pounds.
As the twin-rotor copter hovered noisily over the forest, loggers on the ground scurried about hooking cables to fallen logs, then hooking the cables to a hauling collar that dangled from another cable extending from the helicopter. The copter hauled the logs more than two miles to a loading area where they were put onto trucks.
Mr. Watkins said Georgia-Pacific would store some of the logs at its plant in nearby Russellville and send other logs to four other mills from Virginia to Florida. But it was the Russellville mill, which makes plywood and employs 90 people, that was most in need. He said devastation was so widespread there was a fear the company could not get enough raw material.
Similar logging operations are taking place on on state and private land as well as the national forest. Mr. Gould, the state's chief forester, said he hoped that 25 percent of the fallen timber could be salvaged statewide. But even so, he added, the loss to South Carolina's economy will run into the hundreds of millions.
But the loss for people like the Charleston novelist Josephine Humphreys and her 15-year-old son William, who are birdwatchers, is beyond dollars. Ms. Humphreys said she and her son often sought the serenity of the national forest for bird watching.
''My son just gets sort of depressed looking at all the snapped and snagged trees,'' she said. ''I try to tell him that he will now get to watch a more dynamic process of rebirth, but the fact that it will take years and years doesn't seem to move him very much.''

LENGTH: 541 words

HEADLINE: A Poor Way to Save

 BODY:
President Bush's misguided urge to cut the tax on capital gains finds a dubious companion in his ''family savings plan.'' Floated during the 1988 campaign and now being readied for submission to Congress, it shares at least two faults with the gains tax: it is weak medicine for America's low savings rate, and it would create new budget problems for the future.
The family savings plan is a slimmed-down Individual Retirement Account, the tax break for personal savings sharply curtailed by tax reform in 1986. The big difference is that I.R.A.'s offered an immediate tax break. The family savings plan offers less incentive to save because it offers a less certain break sometime in the future. 
Before reform, all taxpayers could take as much as $2,000 off their taxable income each year if they put it into an I.R.A. No tax was due on the deducted income until the savings were withdrawn, after retirement, and interest or dividends earned by the account accumulated tax-free until withdrawal. Since 1986, only taxpayers with limited incomes who are not covered by company pension plans have been eligible for an I.R.A.'s alluring up-front benefit.
The basic idea of the Bush plan is a long-term savings account on which the earnings accumulate tax-free and would not be taxed on withdrawal. Unlike an I.R.A., money placed in the account would not be deductible from current income. Mr. Bush is expected to limit his plan to savings for designated ''family'' purposes, like education or buying a home. And to avoid favoring the rich, he may make taxpayers with higher incomes ineligible. The idea of reviving the I.R.A. in some form already has strong backing in Congress. Lloyd Bentsen, the Texas Democrat who heads the Senate Finance Committee, has a plan for a new I.R.A. with an up-front benefit like the old one; he offers it as a tax break for the middle class, to balance the President's capital gains break for the well-to-do.
Representative Charles Schumer, Brooklyn Democrat, proposes a variation that would commit taxpayers to future saving, with an option for payroll deductions. And Senator William Roth of Delaware offers a version closer to the President's.
The Roth and Bush plans ask that taxpayers trust Congress not to change the law again before they get the promised benefit. That's trusting a lot. Five different tax incentives for savings have been written and rewritten in the past 16 years.
But the idea is flawed anyhow. Pre-1986 I.R.A.'s probably stimulated some savings, but it's uncertain how much was simply old savings transferred into a new shelter. The Bush plan, with its narrower focus, would presumably stimulate less.
Further, the tax exemption for interest and dividends earned would mean loss of future tax revenue. The Administration says these losses would be more than offset by increased tax collections generated by higher savings and investment and a more vigorous economy. That's debatable.
If Mr. Bush is serious about a tax incentive for savings, let him admit that it has a cost now, and not lay the cost off on future taxpayers. If he's not, let him at least acknowledge that the surest way to improve savings is still what it has been for years now: reduce the budget deficit.

HEADLINE: A United Europe Seems Closer Than Ever

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The Bush Administration has finally found its vision, and it is a good one. The vision, expounded by President Bush and Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d during and after the summit talks with Mikhail S. Gorbachev in Malta early in December, is of building a peace order for the industrial world by developing three concentric spheres of unity: the Europe of the Economic Community, where the Administration has renewed America's historic support for European federation; the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, where new joint political arrangements are needed, and the greater Europe of East and West, including the Soviet Union and the United States. 
This vision is practically identical to President Gorbachev's vision of a ''common European home.'' Now that Mr. Gorbachev has come out for NATO - and for a stronger political NATO that could become a substructure of the common home - East and West should be able to work together toward this goal.
This is an extraordinary political configuration. It means that the door is open to the realization of the hopes of international unity that were dashed after 1945. What is more, these hopes can be realized on a much higher and more mature basis, by encompassing institutions that have meanwhile been built up in the European Community and the Atlantic-Pacific system.
Even so, the vision will not take care of itself. Persistent diplomatic efforts, backed by Congress and the public, will be needed.
 
IRA L. STRAUS
Executive Director, Association
to Unite the Democracies
 Washington, Jan. 2, 1990

HEADLINE: ESSAY;
State Of the Drug War

BYLINE: By William Safire

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
In the past month, the U.S. Government's ''war on drugs'' won two victories.
In Panama, the dictator accused of facilitating the international movement of narcotics was overturned, cornered, arrested and is in jail.
In D.C., the Mayor long-suspected of being the nation's most celebrated crack smoker was entrapped, arrested and will enter treatment and Agnew-style plea bargaining.
Both victories followed invasions: one of a nation, the other of individual rights. 
In Manuel Noriega's case, the invasion was justified by his declaration of war and threat to U.S. lives.
In Marion Barry's case, the inability of a prosecutor to get a grand jury to indict was no justification for the sleaziest kind of entrapment.
A former girlfriend of the target was induced or coerced to set him up; the U.S. for the first time became a party to the sexual seduction of an elected official, creating the circumstances for the commission of a crime. In an act more familiar to K.G.B. blackmailers than F.B.I. agents, the misdemeanor was recorded by cameras hidden in the bedroom.
The publicity-grubbing U.S. Attorney goes on television to characterize the charge as ''corruption,'' as if it were a Federal offense to be a poor role model. (Good prosecutors persuade grand juries to make charges in an indictment and then shut up until trial or plea.) With that prosecutorial misfeasance noted (and where is the A.C.L.U.?) the fact remains that Marion Barry has been an embarrassment to drug fighters. In this city, the widespread assumption has been that the Mayor was a drug user; the message was that you could do drugs, deny it, ''handle it'' and get away with it.
Now that is reversed: every would-be drug bigshot on the streets knows that the fuzz busts bigshots, too.
The same convincing message has been sent by the Colombian Government to the Medellin cartel. Drug lords who declared war on the Government only six months ago are now suing for peace, offering to stop their killings if the Government will protect them from extradition to the stern U.S. Evidently the cartel believes it is losing; the Barco Government is making no deals.
All this is unmistakable progress in the ''war.'' A year ago, some liberals predicted defeat because the emphasis was on law enforcement rather than addict treatment. Some conservative economists joined in the defeatism, waving the white flag of legalization - a route that would put cheap, mind-destroying chemicals in millions of school knapsacks.
Drug czar William Bennett denounces the defeatists, is counterdenounced by academics, but plugs ahead on all fronts.
How do you measure progress, or lack of it, in a war? The casual use of cocaine has been declining, but the addictive use of the cheaper crack rages on. You could deduce from this that the rich get cleaner and the poor get more addicted, but tolerated casual use has often been the bridge to addiction.
Blowing coke may be down but crack-caused violence is up. Murders are increasing on the streets of Washington (we call our hometown Intifada West). Lawmen suggest this gangland turf warfare is caused by a tightening of the market, but put this area down as no progress.
Anti-drug spending is rising. Last year, we upped it by 50 percent; this year, Bill Bennett asked for 24 percent more and will get half that in the coming budget.
Is the money going in the right direction? The strategy, as I see it, is to spend the most on enforcement and prisons, limiting availability, raising prices and scaring addicts into treatment. This increased demand for treatment should create pressure for its supply - and greater local response.
Meanwhile, ''the war on drugs is not a metaphor,'' as the President told the Defense Secretary. Despite the flap about our warships off Colombia, we will see more of our military stopping drug-runners - especially at our Southwest border, formerly known as the Mexican border.
That escalation of the use of the military will be part of the second phase of the drug war strategy to be announced at the end of this month.
A computerized law enforcement intelligence center will be proposed to disseminate information that can be used in court, which the C.I.A. cannot do. The headline will be the death penalty for murderous kingpins. (Never put the story in the lead.) The war is far from won, and a lust for testing is a danger, but our doggedly optimistic drug czar has earned a vote of confidence. These early victories put us at ''the end of the beginning.''

HEADLINE: IN THE NATION;
Beyond The Jackpot

BYLINE: By Tom Wicker

 BODY:
If anybody doubted it, recent polls show that Lee Atwater, the Republican national chairman, was right as well as crass when he said the death and destruction of the Panama invasion had won President Bush a political ''jackpot.'' As poker players know, while the winners crack jokes, the losers can only say ''deal!''
The new polls show Mr. Bush's popularity rating higher than any President's since John F. Kennedy scored 83 percent, right after the Bay of Pigs fiasco. Earlier this month, Mr. Bush won the approval of 76 percent of respondents to a New York Times/ CBS News Poll, and 79 percent in a similar survey by The Washington Post and ABC News. 
The conquest of Panama and the capture of Manuel Noriega clearly were major elements in Mr. Bush's high ranking. Not only did 74 percent of respondents to the Times/CBS Poll term the invasion justified. They also were largely responsible for the President's strong approval rating -73 percent - in the general handling of foreign policy. That's an increase from just over 50 percent last November.
Since 54 percent of those queried reacted favorably to the return of General Noriega to the U.S. for trial, events in Panama appear also to have influenced public approval - by 54 points - of Mr. Bush's otherwise invisible progress in ''dealing with the drug problem.''
The rest of the Times/CBS Poll hardly gives Mr. Bush cause to crack jokes - or does it? Sixty percent believed he had made little progress toward the ''kinder, gentler'' nation he talked about in his campaign. Only 37 percent thought he had prevented new taxes, rather than just making promises.
Americans' confidence in his handling of the economy was shown to be shaky at best; 36 percent - up from only 25 in November - thought things would get worse against only 8 percent who looked for an economic upturn. Such pessimism had not been registered since 1981, just before the Reagan-Bush recession, the worst of the postwar period.
Mr. Bush got bad marks on environmental protection, with only 24 percent approving his minimal efforts, and on education, where all but an underwhelming 16 percent believed he had ''mainly just talked about'' improvements rather than accomplishing them. Even on the drug question, and even after the bagging of General Noriega, 41 percent of respondents said the President was mostly jawboning rather than getting things done.
What's behind this phenomenon of a highly popular President, so many of whose efforts in office the public low-rates? For one thing, as Lee Atwater knows, never underestimate the rally-round-the-flag effect that always bolsters a President who sends the troops into action abroad - never mind the reasons, the resulting casualties or the ultimate consequences. This national glorification of violence ought to give supposedly peace-loving Americans pause; but it never does.
The Times/CBS Poll tends to validate, moreover, some other unpalatable ideas about American politics. It suggests, for instance, that in judging their leaders American voters do not place a high priority on specific accomplishments - Mr. Bush is popular despite fears about the economy and doubts about his leadership on important domestic matters.
That reinforces a lesson too often ignored by Democrats who keep calling for ''a new party position'' or a ''return to the center,'' etc. In the electoral politics of this country, personality almost always counts more than issues.
It may be also that Americans have come to count on all Presidents to take care of foreign policy (where they give Mr. Bush high marks) but no longer believe that any President can accomplish much in the tangled underbrush of domestic affairs (where they rate Mr. Bush poorly). Given the long-term progress in the cold war that has happened on his watch, and his short-term success in Panama, Mr. Bush appears strong where American voters want their President to be in charge. As long as he meets that test, they demand little from him at home.
That's mostly what they've had from George Bush, which may be the most ominous implication of these polls. The more a President does or even tries to do in difficult domestic affairs, the more likely he is to outrage one or more powerful interests or constituencies; but the less he attempts, the less he risks rocking the boat or pulling down his approval rating - and the more his opponents are reduced to crying ''deal the cards!''
