LENGTH: 1333 words

HEADLINE: New Police Chief Brings a Sense of Loyalty That Left Rift in Houston

BYLINE: By LISA BELKIN

DATELINE: HOUSTON, Jan. 21

 BODY:
One of Lee P. Brown's last acts as police chief here, before starting work as the New York City Police Commissioner on Monday, was to dismiss four officers involved in two highly publicized and widely criticized shootings of civilians.
In dismissing the officers, Mr. Brown leaves Houston as he entered it - with the ill will of the officers under his command.
Since he accepted the New York job last month, Mr. Brown has stressed that ''New York is not Houston,'' and that he has no plans to transfer any policies from one city to the other. Mr. Brown, who declined to be interviewed for this article, has said his actions in Houston are not a blueprint for what he will do as head of the nation's largest police force.
But one thing he is likely to take is his loyalty to the mayor who hired him, even at the risk of angering his officers. During his seven years in Houston, which included some of the toughest economic times the city had ever seen, Mr. Brown did not take issue publicly with Mayor Kathryn J. Whitmire when she proposed staff and salary cuts. 
And when a study by his office last year found that the city needed 1,000 more officers, Mr. Brown was criticized for planning the release of that report just after the re-election of Mrs. Whitmire.
 
A Badge of Integrity
''The Mayor is the chief executive officer of the city,'' he said after his appointment was announced. ''We may disagree many times, about many things, but it serves no purpose for me to go out raising questions in public.''
Mr. Brown's supporters describe such loyalty as a badge of integrity. ''Lee Brown has a very strict sense of ethics for himself,'' said Tom G. Koby, an assistant chief of police under Mr. Brown. ''Good, bad or indifferent, that Mayor is his boss.'' Mr. Brown had sharp words with the Mayor about raising officers' salaries, but scrupulously kept those discussions private, Mr. Koby said.
''The officers really would have liked for him to get up there and beat on the table,'' Mr. Koby said. ''But Brown is never going to do that.''
Mr. Brown's critics, in turn, say such loyalty is misdirected. ''He was more concerned with posturing for his own benefit and the Mayor's benefit than for the men and women who were out on the street,'' said Mark R. Clark, the president of the Houston Police Officers Association, one of Houston's two police unions. ''He's no more than another politician.''
The tension between the chief and the rank and file dates back to his appointment by Mrs. Whitmire in 1981. Mr. Brown, then the Public Safety Commissioner in Atlanta, where he oversaw the investigation into a series of child murders, came to Houston as an outsider in a clubby department.
 
A Review of Department
He brought a reputation as a maestro of bureacracy, who played his plans close to his chest and often talked in police jargon so thick it baffled listeners. The Houston police, in turn, had a national reputation as a lawless, racist force, particularly after a Hispanic prisoner was beaten and drowned by several officers in 1978.
Mr. Brown's first act was to ask for a thorough review of the department -something he is likely to do in New York, too. He decided that the Houston police force was too insulated, and began sending both management and beat officers to seminars across the country for exposure to other departments' operations.
After several years of trying some modest changes, Mr. Brown tried to develop ''a philosophy of management,'' Mr. Koby said. As a result, police executives, managers and other guests addressed seminars about the future of the department.
''We had spent time and money on faster cars, newer computers, enhanced communications - but all this took us further and further away from the community,'' remembers Capt. Bill Young, a director of the Neighborhood Oriented Policing program, which grew out of those sessions.
 
Helping to Cut Crime
Such policing is not a new idea, but it was new to Houston. In theory it keeps overworked officers from becoming ''robots, responsible to a dispatcher, responding from call to call to call,'' Captain Young said. The policy, as it works in Houston, is meant to reserve a few hours in each officer's week for walking the streets, meeting people and making plans rather than just responding to calls. While the approach taxes resources, Captain Young said, in the long run it can help cut crime.
He gives as an example an apartment complex heavily used by crack dealers. Officers spent hours with the apartment managers, eventually persuading them to evict the dealers. Before the evictions, the police received 13 calls a day from the complex, he said. Now they get about three.
Critics call the program a good idea, poorly executed.
''On paper it's great,'' said Mike Howard, president of the Houston Police Patrolmen's Union, another union, ''and if we had the manpower and other resources to do it, it could be great. But we don't.''
 
Changed the Image
Local command stations were another outgrowth of Mr. Brown's brainstorming sessions. Houston has always had one command station. Located downtown, it is far away from many residents in this city, which spans 550 square miles.
The plan is to build five smaller command stations with separate dispatchers and jails. ''Under the old system,'' Captain Young said, ''if your kid gets picked up for shoplifting, you have to pick him up downtown. If your car is towed it's likely to be towed downtown. This way we put the services where the problems are.''
The first of the five stations, on the west side, has been open for two years. The second is under construction. The changes brought praise for Mr. Brown from Houston residents and law-enforcement groups nationwide. ''He made the policemen visible and accessible even when their numbers were way down,'' said State Representative Al Edwards, a Democrat. ''And he himself made a big effort to be out and around giving speeches to community groups and meeting with people all the time. He changed the image of the department very dramatically.''
But that newly burnished reputation was hurt recently by a rash of incidents. Last fall, two officers shot and killed motorists after traffic stops, two others were found guilty in rape cases, one was arrested for heroin possession, one was charged with coercing sex from a prostitute, one was reassigned amid charges of harassment and two officers' houses were searched as part of a drug investigation.
The two shootings brought the most public outcry, and on Wednesday Mr. Brown dismissed the officers involved. One, Alex Gonzales, had already been indicted. But two officers accused of standing by while Officer Gonzales pulled the trigger were not indicted. The case of a fourth officer accused in another shooting has not yet been presented to the grand jury.
Though the dismissals have brought praise from the Mayor and black residents here - both shooting victims were black while the officers were white or Hispanic - many officers expressed outrage that three police officers were dismissed even though they had not been indicted.
''I don't know why in the world when he's going to New York he took these eleventh-hour actions,'' said Mr. Clark, of the Police Officers Association. ''He felt like he needed to clear the slate out and it was easier for him to do the wrong thing than to do the right thing.''
Mr. Brown's call on Thursday for the establishment of a Civilian Review Board evoked similar anger.
Until that time he had opposed one on the ground that it would tie the hands of the police chief in disciplining officers. It was the one issue on which he openly clashed with Mrs. Whitmire. But he said the version he was endorsing would leave final authority in the hands of the police chief.
''It's almost like he's taking a few last shots at us as he's walking out the door,'' said Mr. Howard, of the Patrolmen's Union. ''Maybe he never really wanted to be here in the first place.''

HEADLINE: For Gov. O'Neill, Bitter 3d-Term Prospects

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Jan. 20

 BODY:
Gov. William A. O'Neill, whose popularity soared with the economic boom of the mid-1980's and sank as financial woes rocked the state government last year, will face the toughest battle of his career when he seeks re-election to a third term in November, supporters and opponents say.
In the cluster of northeastern states that were identified so strongly with the regional resurgence and so battered as the decade closed, Mr. O'Neill is so far the only incumbent Governor who has said he will seek re-election in what appears to be a new economic era.
In Massachusetts, Gov. Michael S. Dukakis, another once-popular Governor whose approval rating soured in part because of budget troubles, has said he will not run again. In New Jersey, former Gov. Thomas H. Kean, barred by the State Constitution from a third term, has left that state's deep financial problems to Gov. Jim Florio, who was inaugurated last week.
And in New York, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, struggling with what could be a $2 billion budget gap in the fiscal year beginning April 1, has declined to say whether he will run for a third term. 
 
Overshadowed by Other Governors
Mr. O'Neill, a former bar owner who has cultivated an image as an ordinary man, was consistently overshadowed through his nine years in office by the governors next door. But he said in a recent interview that he now believed his lack of grandise claims and grand ambitions for higher office in the boom years might be a blessing.
''We never talked about the miracle of Connecticut,'' he said, referring to the ''Massachusetts miracle,'' a claim of prosperity that haunted Mr. Dukakis after his failed bid for the Presidency in 1988. ''We talked about the 'land of steady habits,' and that's exactly what we are, very steady.''
Even Mr. O'Neill's staunchest supporters concede, however, that as a candidate, he will have to be far more than a steady incumbent at the helm to win re-election.
Since last June, when he signed into law the biggest one-year tax increase in state history to shore up a faltering state budget, his popularity has appeared to decline.
His opponents have attacked him as a doddering symbol of failure, heading an administration that should be left where it flourished, in the 1980's. Last month The Hartford Courant, the state's biggest newspaper, portrayed Mr. O'Neill on its editorial page as the recipient of an annual gift from the voters: this year it was a noose.
And his popularity might slip even more with the state facing a possible $125 million shortfall in the fiscal year that ends June 30 and a possible $400 million gap in the next fiscal year.
 
Challengers Are Encouraged
The daunting numbers have encouraged challengers in Mr. O'Neill's own Democratic Party, including Representative Bruce A. Morrison. Republicans, who have controlled the governor's office for only four years since 1955, say they believe 1990 will be their best chance in decades, especially if Mr. O'Neill stays on the ticket.
''He has well-defined high negatives,'' said the chairman of the State Republican Party, Dick Foley, using pollsters' jargon to describe the Governor's popularity problems. ''If I had my preference, I'd run against O'Neill.''
Mr. O'Neill, a 59-year-old former three-pack-a-day smoker who suffered a heart attack in his first term, has said repeatedly that only a decline in his health will forestall a re-election bid. And while he has promised in speeches to run again, he has yet to file the papers for his candidacy, a fact that has led some people, including Mr. Foley, to believe that Mr. O'Neill may still ultimately withdraw if he thinks he cannot win.
''About April 1 he's going to look at the polls again, and he's going to get sick,'' Mr. Foley said.
 
Fighting to the End
But Mr. O'Neill also seems to be going out of his way in recent weeks to demonstrate that he will not go down without a fight. Last month, for example, he forced a cross-border confrontation with New York - often politically popular in a small state dominated by larger neighbors - when he refused to allow fares on the Metro-North Commuter Railroad to be increased on the Connecticut side of the border.
After two weeks of threats and bluster between Mr. O'Neill and the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, which operates Metro-North, the Long Island Rail Road and the New York City bus and subway system, the authority agreed to keep the old fares in place for Connecticut and make up the revenue difference by postponing some improvements in service and scrapping an advertising campaign.
Earlier this month Mr. O'Neill went on the attack again, announcing a plan to put state police officers on drug patrols in Bridgeport, New Haven and Hartford, the state's three largest cities.
Arguing that drug crime was rampant and that the local police were unable to cope, Mr. O'Neill imposed the plan without getting any prior agreements from the local police unions about such sticky issues as jurisidiction, benefits and overtime. Hartford police officers picketed in protest last Thursday, giving Mr. O'Neill's plan wider news coverage across the state than the idea received when it was first announced.
 
Budget a Top Concern
Still, Mr. O'Neill's central problem, politicians and economists say, remains the state budget, which is sicker than Connecticut's overall economy. Although the housing market has slumped and there is fear of worse to come, the unemployment rate is still only 3.4 percent. And the state's tax rate, even with last year's increases, remains the sixth lowest in the country, according to a recent nationwide survey by Money magazine.
What has happened, budget experts say, is that states like Connecticut, New Jersey and New York, which expanded their budgets in the 1980's to compensate for the withdrawal of Federal aid under the Reagan Administration, have all become subject to greater budget fluctuations - and perhaps political turmoil - because their tax bases have shrunk.
In Connecticut, for example, the size of the state budget grew by about 275 percent in the O'Neill years - from $2.5 billion in 1980 to $6.9 billion this year. There have been huge increases in spending for health care, prisons and road and bridge rebuilding.
And because Mr. O'Neill has adamantly refused to consider an income tax and there is less Federal aid, Connecticut's bigger budgets have had to rely more and more on a particularly volatile revenue source: its 8 percent state sales tax, which can fluctuate wildly in revenue as consumers decide to spend money or not.
 
No New Taxes Planned
Mr. O'Neill, who is to open the General Assembly session on Feb. 7 with the presentation of his budget, has already said that it will not contain new taxes. For the Democratic-controlled Assembly, most of whose members are also facing election campaigns this fall, the session will thus concentrate on which state services to cut - and if state employees must be laid off, how many. Few legislators expect much good news to take back to their districts as campaign ammunition.
But Mr. O'Neill says he still believes that the tide, seemingly so strong against him, will turn. Sitting at his desk in the Capitol, he recently said that if he could still reach voters ''at the kitchen table,'' as he once did, he would prevail.
''They have to start thinking, and they will, sitting at the kitchen table or the breakfast table: 'Say, wait a minute. We know this guy. We know what he can do. He's been there in good days, and he's been there in bad.' ''

HEADLINE: Fate of Daily News Seen at Stake as Labor Talks Start

BYLINE: By ALEX S. JONES

 BODY:
After months of bitter verbal sparring, labor and management at the 70-year-old Daily News began the collective-bargaining process last week on negotiations that both sides say are apt to save the paper or sink it.
''It could be thumbs up or thumbs down on the future,'' James Hoge, the New York paper's publisher, wrote in a recent annual report sent to employees. Contracts for all 10 of The Daily News's labor unions expire at midnight March 30.
Company and union leaders say they do not want a strike, which could mean the end of the nation's largest metropolitan newspaper and cost New York City several thousand jobs and millions in taxes.
''We're ready to negotiate a contract,'' said George E. McDonald, president of the Allied Printing Trades Council, an umbrella organization that includes all the paper's unions. 
 
Seeking Radical Change
But Mr. Hoge is demanding radical change from what he characterizes as overmanning, featherbedding and rampant waste. He is underscoring his seriousness by preparing to produce a paper during a strike. Mr. Hoge has been saying for months that he is determined ''to regain management control of manufacturing and distribution operations'' - a dramatic shift in the balance of power toward management and a very different approach than was taken in past contracts.
For instance, the current contract defines precisely how many people must be assigned to a press, depending on such things as the number of pages. In the past, The News negotiated in that context, seeking to reduce the manning level required by the contract.
But not this time. John T. Sloan, who is acting as spokesman for The News during the negotiations, said last week that the company now would seek union acknowledgement of management's right to decide press staffing in all situations as well as a host of other things - like hiring and the right to take disciplinary actions - that are determined by the present contracts and long tradition.
Mr. Sloan declines to say how much The News hopes to reduce costs but says the goal is to change salary, overtime, benefits and other compensation expenses from about 50 percent of revenues to about 25 percent, the industry average for large papers. To accomplish this would require more than $100 million in annual savings. That would make The News highly profitable by industry standards.
Mr. Hoge says that, once ''management control'' is achieved, the Chicago-based Tribune Company, which owns The Daily News, will invest up to $500 million to build a modern color printing plant that both union and management agree is essential to the paper's long-term survival.
Last week, the process of exchanging contract proposals between the paper and the unions began, with negotiations to follow.
Mr. McDonald and other labor leaders say management's unusually harsh, confrontational approach to the negotiations suggests that the Tribune Company does not intend to own the paper for very long.
The unions were dismayed when The News hired King & Ballow, a Nashville law firm that specializes in tough labor negotiations and has a reputation among labor unions of being particularly aggressive.
 
Concessions and Profits
According to the union scenario, which Mr. Hoge vigorously denies, management intends to wring huge concessions from the unions to make the paper profitable and then sell it to a buyer who will operate it cheaply on existing equipment. Or, if there is a strike, union leaders fear the company will say labor killed the paper and close it with minimal shutdown liabilities.
In the early 1980's, the Tribune Company sought to sell The News but reversed itself and declared its commitment to continue publishing. But in negotiations throughout the 80's, the company has sought manning reductions, generally accompanied by buyout offers.
Union officials fear that in these negotiations the company will be very stingy with buyout offers and similar inducements. Many of the newspaper union leaders say they do not believe the Tribune Company will invest in a new printing plant, regardless of union concessions, because New York's economy is too uncertain. They note that The New York Times Company has postponed plans for color presses to print the daily paper, though The Times is proceeding with another plant to print some Sunday sections in color.
And the unions have not been persuaded by The News's recent acquisition of industrial sites in New Jersey and Long Island, which the paper has offered as evidence of its sincere intention to invest in new presses.
The paper's union leaders make no secret of their worry. Because the same unions represent workers at The Times and The New York Post, any substantial concessions at The News are apt to be sought by the other papers. The Times is already seeking changes in a six-year contract due to expire in 1993. Contracts at The Post, like The News, expire March 30, but no decisive action on The Post contracts is expected until settlements are reached at The News.
Though union leaders will not confirm it, they have apparently been working with the Kamber Group, a public relations concern, for the negotiations - an unusual step that reflects their anxiety. The News has hired John Scanlon, a public relations specialist.
 
Eager for Public Support
Both sides are eager to win the sympathy of the public, especially advertisers and city leaders, which could prove critical in a strike.
''We will not sign or ratify any contracts until everybody reports they are satisfied,'' Mr. McDonald said then.
Solidarity may well become an important issue as The Daily News has identified New York Newspaper Printing Pressmen's Union No. 2 and the Newspaper and Mail Deliverers Union - the pressmen and the drivers - as principal targets because they are responsible for a majority of what the paper says is unnecessary expense. A key aspect of The News's strategy seems to be to crack that solidarity.
The first concrete glimpse of The News's plan came Jan. 14, when the paper made its contract proposals to the deliverers union. The union, representing 688 of the paper's 2,466 unionized employees, is generally considered the paper's most powerful because in a strike, many say, The News could not be distributed without the drivers.
 
A One-Year Contract
The union's president, Michael J. Alvino, declined to give details of the proposal, except that The News was seeking a one-year contract, rather than the usual three-year agreement. A person associated with the unions, who said he had seen the proposal but asked not to be identified, described it as ''completely rewriting the contract.''
And Mr. Alvino confirmed that The News's proposal stated that the paper is seriously considering converting to independent contractors for delivery of papers sold by single copy, as opposed to home delivery. About 80 percent of The News's 1.2 million circulation is sold through racks or newsstands.
Under this plan, the drivers would be given the first option to buy the right to deliver papers along a particular route, transforming many of them from employees to entrepreneurs.
For the paper, such a change would greatly reduce the number of driver employees and also create a commodity - the routes - that could be offered to people willing to deliver the paper during a strike.
Mr. Alvino said selling routes was calculated to divide the union and would ''help some individuals but not the majority.''
While Mr. Alvino has said repeatedly that the drivers union would not make any separate deal with The News, his union has traditionally acted independently of the other unions and only joined the allied council last year.
Mr. Sloan, the News spokesman, declined to discuss the proposal.
 
Labor Practices
The News has sought to isolate the pressmen and driver unions by portraying them as engaging in more abusive and unreasonable labor practices than the other unions.
For instance, Mr. Sloan said that while the contract might require 15 men to run the presses on a given night, often only about 10 will show up, but they will sign in for the five others in what is called ''the buddy system.''
Though management has the right to make a worker roll-call, Mr. Sloan said any discipline of that sort results in work slowdowns.
Because fewer than 10 people are actually needed to operate the presses, Mr. Sloan said, it is customary for several pressmen to go home after a couple of hours, though they are paid for the full shift. And if there are problems and resulting overtime, all 15 signed-up workers are entitled to it.
''I think it's just a smokescreen,'' said John P. Kennedy, president of the pressmen's union. ''The manning levels have been in place ever since the equipment has been running.''
Mr. McDonald of the allied council noted that The News already has the power to insure that a full press crew is on hand, but has lacked the management will to enforce the existing rules.
The News also accuses some of its unions, especially the pressmen, of effectively shutting out minorities from jobs. Mr. Sloan said the 410 employees in the pressmen's union at The News include no women or blacks or Hispanic workers and no Asian-Americans or Native Americans.
Mr. Kennedy said he never heard of a woman seeking a job in the pressroom, which is particularly dirty work; he asserted that ''the door is open'' to minority workers.
 
Control Over Hiring
The News maintains that the problem with the pressmen and some other unions has been that the company does not control hiring for those jobs, as it does with unions like the Newspaper Guild, which covers such jobs as reporters.
One of the company's objectives is to assert control over all hiring, and Mr. Sloan said one outcome of that would be an increase in minority representation. In areas where management controls hiring, The News says that 27 percent of the work force are women and 21 percent are from minorities.
Newspaper analysts say the Tribune Company has decided that the time is ripe to force workplace efficiencies at The News that have become common at papers in other cities as newspaper unions have gradually lost ground over the last two decades.
The News says it has lost $115 million during the last decade. It says the paper had no profit on $420 million in revenues in 1989.
Some newspaper analysts say the Tribune Company needs to bring The News's operation in line with its other, quite profitable newspapers, such as The Chicago Tribune and The Orlando Sentinel in Florida. They say anything short of significant profits would be a drag on the company's overall earnings, which in turn would affect the price of Tribune stock.
''It's a critical issue for stockholders,'' said Lisa Donneson, an analyst at County NatWest Securities in Manhattan.
Mr. Hoge, the News publisher, said that even in a city that is generally considered the most pro-union in the nation, readers and advertisers will not support what he characterized as inefficiencies that no modern company could tolerate.
But newspaper union officials are casting the struggle as perhaps the crucial test of the New York labor movement and vow that the Tribune Company will learn just how strong a union town New York still is.
They argue that The News is trying to roll back on contracts and work practices that have been won through decades of collective bargaining.
''We are prepared to negotiate manning levels, but on new color equipment,'' said Mr. Kennedy of the pressmen's union. Mr. McDonald and other union leaders said the concessions The News appears to want must be accompanied by an ironclad guarantee to build a new plant and based on the high-tech equipment to be used there.
The company has insisted that it must first have the concessions on existing equipment in order to justify a huge new investment.

HEADLINE: Listing Shows Homeless Sites To Aid Census

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP

 BODY:
New York City has made its first concerted effort to list the places where homeless people spend their nights, in the hope of guiding the Census Bureau to those who live in shelters, subway stations, parks, doorways and abandoned buildings - and who would otherwise go uncounted.
The list, based on two surveys taken last year, has more than 2,100 sites. More than half are in Manhattan, although the borough has only 20 percent of the city's population.
On the list are 326 shelters, public and private, whose combined population or capacity is 29,612 people. In addition, there are as many as 1,687 locations, on and off and under city streets, where up to 5,783 people were counted - in the middle of the night -by police officers, transit workers and other government employees. 
 
'There Are Many, Many More'
''This is a very limited snapshot taken by non-enumerators in a limited amount of time,'' said Linda Goldsmith, deputy director of computer information services in the City Planning Department, which prepared the survey.
''If we found these people, we know there are many, many more,'' she said.
In March, the list is to be used by the Census Bureau when it sends out hundreds of enumerators to conduct a special and limited count of the homeless population.
''What we're not doing here is a census of the homeless,'' said Dr. Kenneth C. Meyer, the assistant regional census manager in New York.
Instead, he said, its importance is that ''this may give us the first handle - if not on the numbers - on the magnitude of the problem.''
The count will provide information that has never existed: for each census tract (typically 10 to 20 city blocks), there will be an enumeration of people living in shelters and on the street.
The special count will also add homeless people to the population tally for specific city blocks. There might be wide political implications, especially on the local level, when the census is used for redistricting.
There will be important economic implications, too, in the many instances in which government aid is apportioned by census figures.
Although the special count is a nationwide effort, in which every municipality was asked to devise a list of shelters and street locations for the Census Bureau, New York City's site inventory stands out because of its size, complexity, detail and scope.
And yet, as census officials and city planners acknowledge, thousands of people will go uncounted.
 
'A Moving Target'
For example, many New Yorkers go through episodic homelessness, having friends or relatives house them between periods on the street. If they happen to have found temporary lodging in March, they will be skipped. Also, many homeless people take great pains to obscure their condition. They might easily elude an enumerator's cursory glance.
''By its very nature, a site inventory is a moving target,'' said Roberta Lentz, program director in the city's 1990 Census Project.
The survey's limitations have raised suspicions and fears. Despite the government's disclaimer, advocates for homeless people worry that the count will be seen as a census, boiled down to a single, unrealistically low number.
If Census Bureau enumerators were to visit every site and find roughly the same number of people, and if they were to visit every shelter and find them all operating at stated capacity, they might count about 35,000 people. But the Coalition for the Homeless believes the true number may be at least twice that high.
 
'Cynical Politicians'
''The more New Yorkers who are homeless are counted, the better it is for all New Yorkers, homeless or otherwise,'' said Robert M. Hayes, chairman of the coalition.
''Our abiding anxiety,'' he said, ''is based on the near certainty that cynical politicians who want to ignore the massive scale of homelessness across the country will misuse this limited exercise,'' to diminish the problem.
And, he said, it is ''almost inevitable'' that the results of the count will be misrepresented and oversimplified in news accounts - that the count will be mistaken as a real measure of the homeless population.
That fear is heightened, in a way, by the evident effort and diligence that went into the site inventory, because the results appear authoritative and more comprehensive than they are.
 
List Shows 326 Shelters
As Mr. Hayes leafed through the 200-page list, he said, ''There are obvious places that were missed, but this was a bona fide effort.''
The list shows 326 shelters, in which as many as 29,612 people can be housed. There are 142 in Manhattan (with 14,132 people), 85 in Brooklyn (7,959 people), 48 in the Bronx (3,882 people), 45 in Queens (3,247 people) and 6 on Staten Island (392 people).
In addition, the city counted 1,775 people in 202 places throughout the transportation network.
No one was counted at Grand Central Terminal, which closes at 1:30 A.M., but 104 people were observed at the ferry terminal on Staten Island, 86 at the ferry terminal in Manhattan, 64 in Pennsylvania Station, 61 at the Port Authority Bus Terminal, 39 at La Guardia Airport, 29 at Kennedy International Airport and 20 in the George Washington Bridge Bus Terminal.
 
Homeless in the Subways
Some 20 homeless people were counted on A, E, F and No. 1 trains and in the Astor Place, Bedford Park Boulevard, Broadway-Lafayette, Broadway-Nassau, Delancey Street, Fifth Avenue, Grand Central, Second Avenue and Spring Street stations.
In addition, 1,547 homeless people were counted in 963 ''off-street locations,'' meaning parks, playgrounds, vacant lots, housing projects and even the steps of Federal Hall on Wall Street. Fifty people were counted in 26 spots throughout Central Park. Others spent their nights on bridges, railroad trestles and Hudson River piers.
The city prepared a list of 522 street locations, where 2,461 people were counted in doorways, sidewalks, heating grates and the seating areas in the median malls along upper Broadway.
Another list was prepared of 152 abandoned buildings, schools and theaters where homeless people are believed to be living.
 
Began Preparing the Inventory
''The whole effort is to make sure that the Census Bureau has some clue where to send enumerators,'' said Philip Wallick, director of computer information services in the City Planning Department.
Early last year, in response to the Census Bureau, planners began preparing the inventory. The survey ran from March 20 to 24 and was supplemented by a second canvass, from Oct. 30 to Nov. 3.
Survey takers were given forms to fill out the street name and house number or cross streets, as well as a box labeled ''Number of Homeless Persons Observed.'' The workers were to note homeless people that they came across in their rounds between midnight and 2 A.M., but not search for them.
The special census count is to begin at 6 P.M. on March 20, when teams of enumerators will go the shelters - armories, church basements, hotels, homes for runaways, lodging houses -to count and interview residents. That first phase runs until midnight.
From 2 to 4 A.M. on March 21, enumerators will go to the street and off-street locations on the list, take a count and note people's age, race and sex.
From 4 to 6:30 A.M., they will wait outside abandoned buildings that the city has identified as likely to house homeless people. For safety's sake, the enumerators will not go inside. But they are supposed to interview anyone entering or leaving the building.
Finally, from 8 to 11:30 A.M. that same morning, families who are living in shelters or being housed in hotels will be interviewed and counted.
Enumerators will not be allowed to leave predetermined sites, even if they spot homeless people nearby. As it is, there may not be enough time or money for the Census Bureau to visit every site identified by the city, Dr. Meyer said, and the point of the March exercise is neither to canvass the city nor count every homeless person.
''We will try to get to every shelter and hotel or motel,'' he said. ''The more people we can count in the shelters, rather than the streets, the better the count is going to be. We're encouraging governmental units to encourage as many homeless as possible to go into the shelters.''
But Ms. Lentz, of the city's census project, said: ''You just don't know what outreach might do. It might have a boomerang effect. People might not go to the shelters that night. How would they believe that this is an innocuous undertaking and that there is no one spying on them? We walk a very fine line there.''

HEADLINE: Ethnic and Disabled Actors Ask for a Chance

BYLINE: By WILLIAM H. HONAN

 BODY:
''For those of us living and working in this city,'' said the playwright Jules Feiffer, ''writing in the realistic or naturalistic mode for whites only has become unreal and unnatural.''
Mr. Feiffer was speaking at the beginning of the second conference of the Nontraditional Casting Project, a nonprofit organization that seeks to promote greater participation by ethnic minorities and the disabled in the theater.
His words were echoed - by turns with fist-shaking anger, sly wit and impassioned oratory - throughout the two-day conference that ended on Saturday. It was held at the Tisch School of the Arts at New York University. 
The conference attracted about 150 theater people, ranging from Colleen Dewhurst, the president of the Actors' Equity Association, and Bernard Jacobs, the president of the Shubert Organization, to Linda Bove, a deaf actress who is a regular performer on ''Sesame Street,'' and Cochise Anderson, an American Indian actor who traces his ancestry to the Chickasaw and Choctaw tribes.
 
What the Project Is Doing
Since the project's founding in 1986, the problems of blind, deaf and wheelchair-using performers have been added to its concerns. In the last few years, the project has held symposiums in various parts of the country, distributed a book and videotape, and developed a casting file of 3,000 actors representing ethnic minorities and the disabled.
Groups represented at last weekend's conference ranged from the Perseverance Theater of Douglas, Alaska, and the Mixed Blood Theater Company of Minneapolis to Theater by the Blind in New York and the Market Theater of Johannesburg.
Most of the actors, speaking at one of nine panels, simply asked for greater opportunities to appear in theatrical productions.
''Rarely does a Native American Indian woman get to play the roles written for her, and since she is not hired to play other roles she's mostly unemployed,'' said Donna Couteau Brooks of the Sac and Fox nation in Stroud, Okla. Ms. Brooks appeared in the movie ''Prizzi's Honor.''
 
Trying to Forestall Business
Michael Schwartz, a deaf amateur actor and practicing lawyer, drew laughter and applause when, after describing the equal-employment-opportunity provisions of the bill on disabled rights now before Congress, he said: ''Let's do it voluntarily. Let's not go to court and make people like myself rich.''
Some actors said it was especially galling not to be given a chance to portray the ethnic or disabled minorities they represent, and to see white or able-bodied actors get those roles.
Kitty Lunn, an actress who made numerous television commercials before a disabling fall in 1987, told of the distress she felt when she was rejected for the role of a disabled character and learned that it had gone to an able-bodied actress.
''They think I'll be too much trouble,'' she said with a laugh. ''In addition to two boards and a passion, I may need a ramp.''
 
A Conflict of Desires
A number of participants were troubled by a conflict between their desire to work in their own cultural tradition and their wish to play other roles.
Seret Scott, a black actress who has appeared on ''Miami Vice'' and ''The Equalizer'' and recently at Center Stage in Baltimore, was overcome with emotion as she described how upsetting it had been to accept the roles of Hispanic and American Indian characters ''when I knew that would deprive a Hispanic or Native American actor of a job.''
Mr. Anderson said, ''I want to be both an Indian actor and an actor who happens to be Indian.''
And Nestor Serrano, a Puerto Rican actor who is a regular cast member of the NBC series ''True Blue,'' said: ''I'm not embarrassed to play a Hispanic. I just don't want to be limited to playing Hispanics.''
 
A Caveat on Casting
Speaking about casting restrictions, Tisa Chang, the artistic producing director of the Pan-Asian Repertory Theater in Manhattan, said she would not wish to include a Caucasian actor with a group of Asian actors to represent a Japanese-American family. ''I simply do not see Japanese-American families being portrayed with an integrated cast,'' she said.
A number of conference participants offered hope for the future in several areas, including grants, nontraditional casting and new works featuring minorities.
Jessica Andrews, the new director of the theater program of the National Endowment for the Arts, said her goal was that 50 percent of the endowment's grant-making theater panel ''should be people of color.''
Ruth Mayleas, a program officer for the arts at the Ford Foundation, said the extent of cultural diversity on the staff and the board of a theater company had increasingly become a criterion for foundation grants.
 
A Playwright Surprises Himself
Mr. Feiffer said the lead in his new play, ''Elliot Loves,'' scheduled to open on Broadway in June, is a Hispanic woman. ''I didn't know I could write for a Hispanic,'' he said, ''but before that I didn't know I could write for a woman.''
Jean Schiffman, representing several theater groups in the San Francisco Bay Area, said the American Conservatory Theater had employed nontraditional casting in every one of its major productions this season.
And Lucia Puccia, a blind actress who has appeared in a number of Off Broadway productions, said, ''I hope I will have a successful career, but at worst perhaps I will be a role model for another blind actress who makes it.''
At the end of the conference, Sharon Jensen, the executive director of the project, said a consensus had been reached to pursue several objectives. These include the designation of regional representatives to work with a national office, the creation of a theater workshop to introduce directors to a company of talented ethnic and disabled actors, the establishment of a national research program to document critical and public response to nontraditional casting, and the search for other means to encourage cultural diversity throughout the theater.
 
Breaking Classical Barriers
As several participants pointed out, cultural diversity can be encouraged in the casting of the classics.
Chuck Smith, an associate director of the predominantly black Chicago Theater Company, said he had been repeatedly frustrated by casting directors in the Chicago area telling him that black actors were infrequently chosen for the classics ''because they can't handle the language.'' To ''disprove that myth,'' he said, he set up a daylong audition for minority actors to let them show how well they could handle scenes from Chekhov, Noel Coward and Shaw. Local directors were invited. ''We had at least 250 actors audition and about 100 casting directors showed up,'' he said. ''It was a historic day. I saw actors getting hired as they walked off the stage. We got rid of that myth about black actors.''
And Benny Sato Ambush, the artistic director of the predominantly black Oakland Ensemble Theater, said he was recently approached by an actor who uses a wheelchair who thought he should play the title role in Shakespeare's ''Julius Caesar.'' The actor said: ''Caesar was an old soldier with war wounds. Why not put someone in the part who really knows what war wounds are?''
Mr. Ambush said, ''You can bet I'm going to remember that.''

LENGTH: 1649 words

HEADLINE: Why the Fed Is Largely Uncriticized

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 21

 BODY:
President Bush and his spokesman last week broke his Administration's policy of keeping quiet about the policies of the Federal Reserve.
But the statements of the President and his press secretary, Marlin Fitzwater, about the need for lower interest rates were mild compared to the sharp attacks on the Fed by officials in previous administrations when the economy was flagging in an election year.
At the week's end, senior Administration officials said the Bush and Fitzwater remarks were not meant as a direct challenge to the central bank but as a reminder that the Bush Administration wants interest rates as low as is possible, consistent with restraining inflation.
 
Rates Remain High
Although the Fed has allowed interest rates to fall somewhat in the last seven months, they remain abnormally high in relation to the rate of inflation.
Until last week, the central bank had received unusually little criticism from the White House and Congress as an election year begins, given the weakness of the economy and the fact that interest rates are unusually high by historical standards. Three-month Treasury bills are paying about 7.75 percent and 30-year Treasury bonds are around 8.25 percent, while the inflation rate has held steady for years at about 4.5 percent. 
The reluctance of politicians to take on the Fed is in large part a result of the high regard they have for Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, and of their hope that Mr. Greenspan and his colleagues can perform the extraordinarily delicate feat of slowing the economy enough to avert high inflation without causing a recession.
 
No Political Pressure
The relative absence of criticism also reflects the acknowledgement in the White House and Congress that elected officials have let the budget deficit get out of hand and, for better or worse, have surrendered economic policy to the central bank.
Even legislators from states and districts that for all intents and purposes are in a recession say they are under no pressure from constituents or interest groups to take on the Fed.
The view of the Federal Reserve governors and top staff members is that a lack of political arm-twisting gives them freedom to fine-tune the economy that they would not otherwise enjoy.
But, gun-shy from past experience, they fear the statements by Mr. Bush and Mr. Fitzwater are the first signs that the truce flags are coming down.
''I enjoy the absence of Fed-bashing,'' one governor said a few days before the President spoke. But he added, perhaps prophetically, ''I don't think it's a long-term phenomenon.''
In his first public statement on the matter in almost a year, Mr. Bush told the National Association of Homebuilders in Atlanta on Friday that ''low and stable interest rates'' were essential to a growing economy. He did not specifically mention the Federal Reserve.
 
Fitzwater's Remarks
The day before, Mr. Fitzwater said the Administration hoped that new statistics showing a steady inflation rate and a faltering housing industry would persuade the Fed to loosen credit.
Some politicians suggested that Mr. Fitzwater's remarks laid the groundwork for the Administration to shift blame to the Fed if the economy slides into a recession. But top Administration officials disputed that view. One observed that Mr. Greenspan resented political pressure and would be less likely to loosen the reins on credit if the Administration kept speaking out.
In any case, the mood now is quite different from that in 1980 and 1982, the last times the economy was weak in an election year.
In 1980, a repeated theme of President Jimmy Carter's re-election campaign was his attacks on the Federal Reserve for its ''ill-advised'' policy of raising interest rates to retard inflation. Mr. Carter's Treasury Secretary, G. William Miller, himself a former Fed chairman, complained that the central bank was ''not communicating'' sufficiently with the Administration.
 
Reagan's Complaint
Similarly, in early 1982, President Ronald Reagan blamed the Fed for a monetary policy that caused capital investment to decline. Speaking of interest rates as the midterm election drew near, he told an audience, ''If that string hadn't been pulled for so long and so hard, we might not have had the depth of the recession that we've had.''
Reagan Administration officials like Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan and Beryl W. Sprinkel, chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, were even harsher in their criticism, and many lawmakers campaigned on platforms of seeking lower interest rates.
By contrast, President Bush and his top economic policy makers agreed early in the Administration not to attack the Fed in public, a senior official said. They have generally stuck to that agreement, even though most economists believe the economy is growing little, if at all.
Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady explained the reasoning behind not challenging the Fed. ''People in the United States and around the world generate a higher level of confidence, which leads to economic growth, if they don't feel that there's a big war going on between the economic authorities inside the United States,'' he said.
 
'Inflation Genie'
Michael J. Boskin, chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, said, ''The Administration realizes that while the goal is to maximize growth, letting the inflation genie out of the bottle is very costly later on.''
Once or twice before last week, the Administration's vow was broken. In his first week in office, President Bush told an interviewer, ''I don't want to see us move so strongly against fear of inflation that we impede growth.''
Even that mild comment raised eyebrows in the markets. ''There was a suspicion that this Administration, dominated by Texans and with all the Texas real estate and energy problems, would be less anti-inflation than Reagan,'' said Jerry L. Jordan, chief economist at First Interstate Bancorp in Los Angeles. ''People were waiting for signs that they would turn on the printing press.''
Then in August, Richard G. Darman, the budget director, pointedly criticized the Fed for keeping credit too tight. ''If we do have a recession,'' he said, ''I think it will be because they erred on the side of caution.''
 
Darman Pulls Back
That caused a stir for a few days. Mr. Darman said later he had not intended to use such strong words. He has not spoken out publicly on the subject since.
Asked in an interview today on the ABC News program, ''This Week,'' what policies the Fed should be following, Mr. Darman replied, ''I would like to stay out of that debate in the theory that they will do something wiser if I stay out of the swirl.''
This does not mean the Bush Administration and the Fed have not at times been at odds. Early last year, they disagreed over how to deal with the third world debt and the problems of the savings industry. Over the summer, one official said, Administration economists tried hard to convince Mr. Greenspan that signs of inflation were largely the result of one-time increases in oil and food prices and not a general overheating of the economy.
Then, in October, the Federal Open Market Committee, the policy-making arm of the central bank, decided not to lower interest rates immediately after the meeting of finance ministers of the seven leading industrial countries because Fed officials did not want to be perceived as succumbing to Administration pressure to drive down the value of the dollar.
 
Value of Socializing
Those differences were smoothed over in private. Mr. Greenspan knew many officials in the Administration from when they worked together for President Gerald R. Ford, and they continue to socialize together.
Mr. Greenspan and Mr. Brady meet nearly every week for breakfast, often joined by other officials. Mr. Boskin said staff relations between Administration economists and those at the Fed were smooth and cooperative.
''I do express my views to the chairman,'' Mr. Brady said. ''I do it forcefully and privately, and I intend to keep it that way.''
''I admire Alan Greenspan,'' he continued. ''That doesn't mean we don't have our differences; we do. The Fed has a special view about the containment of inflation, and at the same time it is not unmindful of the necessity for growth. We have a special feeling about growth, but we have a very strong eye on inflation. I would say the differences are between the 40-yard lines.''
 
Greenspan Is Careful
For his part, Mr. Greenspan has been careful not to criticize President Bush's policies in public, although, according to colleagues, he believes strong measures including tax increases are needed to lower the budget deficit.
In Congress, where lawmakers with strong interests in farming, small business and construction railed in years past against high interest rates, Mr. Greenspan is treated with respect bordering on reverence.
Representative Lee H. Hamilton, the Indiana Democrat who heads the Joint Economic Committee, has led the drive to make Federal Reserve procedures more accountable. But he precedes every discussion with strong praise of Mr. Greenspan and the current Fed policy.
And the Democrats who control Congress say they prefer to blame President Bush for the economic slowdown. They fear that too much talk about the Fed's role would give the President an escape hatch.
 
A Positive Influence
Many lawmakers also concede that Mr. Greenspan may be the only official in Washington with a positive influence on the economy, and they are grateful that times are not worse.
''Can you imagine, if it was the President or Congress who had control of monetary policy?'' asked Representative Charles E. Schumer, a Brooklyn Democrat who sits on the Banking and Budget Committees. ''Look at how Congress and the President have handled the budget deficit.''

HEADLINE: Tokyo's Wary Money Managers

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD

DATELINE: TOKYO, Jan. 21

 BODY:
It takes only one shout of, ''It's the Japanese; they're buying!'' in a Wall Street dealing room to throw traders into fits of nervous activity. It is easy to understand why.
The Japanese buyers are a group of money managers at Tokyo's big banks and insurance companies who control the largest pools of investment funds in the world today, multibillion-dollar symbols of Japan's economic strength.
Their buy or sell decisions can send financial markets gyrating in New York, London or Frankfurt. Every time the United States Treasury sells bonds to finance America's huge budget deficits, the anxious question in Washington and on Wall Street is whether the Japanese will buy. If they do not, interest rates are likely to rise. 
 
Widespread Influence
While their influence is greatest in the stock and bond markets, these conservative Japanese money managers are also large investors in American real estate, Western works of art and even such American finance houses as Shearson Lehman Hutton and Paine Webber.
These powerful money men have been called the ''gnomes of Tokyo,'' successors to the ''gnomes of Zurich,'' the Swiss bankers once believed to hold sway over world finance. Like those secretive Europeans, Tokyo's money managers are generally regarded on Wall Street with fear and envy because of their vast influence over the markets.
But in interviews with the tiny group of managers who make the international investment decisions for two of Japan's largest financial institutions, the Nippon Life Insurance Company and the Mitsubishi Trust and Banking Corporation, these corporate bureaucrats did not speak of their power. Rather, they talked of how they felt hamstrung by the very size of the funds they control.
''Bigness itself has become a problem,'' said Kozo Nogami, general manager of Nippon Life's international securities investments division.
Mr. Nogami and his counterparts at Mitsubishi Trust described how they can move the tens of billions of dollars they have already invested overseas only in tiny increments, because a large move could destabilize the markets, create a panic and end up causing them losses.
 
'It Would Be Suicide'
That concern is a sober counterpoint to people in Japan who have advocated that the Japanese money managers consider dumping their Treasury bonds to punish the United States when it threatens protectionist actions.
''Those remarks are ridiculous,'' Mr. Nogami said. ''It would be suicide because we would end up losing so much money.''
The risks are awesome. Nippon Life, the biggest insurer in the world, has $164.3 billion in assets, with more than $30 billion invested abroad. Mitsubishi Trust, the largest trust bank with $209 billion in total funds, has $14 billion in international investments.
The money managers acknowledge that they are in the midst of a major shift in their international investment strategies. First, they are putting less money into bonds - largely American - and more into foreign stocks. Second, they are buying more West German stocks, because Germany is expected to benefit from the opening of Eastern Europe and the European Community's move to a single barrier-free market in 1992.
Shinpei Ohashi, the 39-year-old chief manager of Mitsubishi Trust's treasury and securities division, said that as much as 20 percent of the new capital his group invests overseas goes to West Germany, compared with 5 percent a year ago. Similarly, Nippon Life will put more than half its new capital for overseas investment into West Germany.
 
Cautious Newcomers
Despite the vast sums they control, the money men themselves emerged in the interviews as a distinctively Japanese breed of cautious newcomers to the turbulent global markets, methodical and disciplined in their ways but disconcerted by the volatility of this new realm.
The Japanese also provided a telling contrast to their Western counterparts. In the United States, the financial markets are regarded as a bastion of individualism, a place where hot-handed money managers can lay down huge bets and reap part of the rewards if they are successful. They are business stars, highly paid and mobile.
The Tokyo managers are duty-bound bureaucrats in the traditional mold of the regimented Japanese ''salaryman.'' They are means by which the group expresses its will.
For the Japanese, there is no fast track. They can move only slowly, by seniority, up the corporate ladder of prestige and pay, rather than being rewarded in proportion to the returns they earn with their portfolios. A 45-year-old section chief overseeing the investment of $10 billion or so might earn $100,000 a year, at the most, compared with many hundreds of thousands of dollars for a successful American fund manager, who could be nearly 20 years younger.
 
Cadres of Generalists
An American money manager may dart from firm to firm, selling his specialized skills to the highest bidder. The Tokyo managers typically remain in their assignments only three or four years before getting shuffled to another department. This method develops cadres of strong generalists, but not the kind of specialists that some Japanese executives acknowledge are necessary in an area as tricky as international investment.
For instance, Makoto Toda, a chunky, amiable man who heads Nippon Life's international planning department, has a law degree from the University of Michigan and has built his career as an international expert.
But several years ago, he was suddenly appointed head of a provincial branch 60 miles west of Tokyo, managing 800 housewifes who sold insurance door to door. (Insurance is sold almost exclusively by women in Japan.) The job, he noted tersely, ''was not at my request.''
Although the Japanese managers put safety above all else and think of the long term, they acknowledge that they have inadvertently become some of the globe's largest risk-takers. They have a conservative buy-and-hold strategy but because their overseas holdings are so huge, they run enromous risks that swings in currency rates will undermine the value of their portfolios.
''We buy and hold and hope,'' said Shigeru Noma, a short, trim 38-year-old who heads the international stock department for Nippon Life.
 
Overnight Losses
Every night they go to bed with the prospect that if the dollar declines just one yen on currency markets while they sleep, they can suffer tens of millions of dollars in losses in their American investments before they sit down to their first cup of coffee. They have struggled without success to protect themselves from such swings.
The declines, to be sure, remain paper losses unless the securities are sold. But the concern in Tokyo is that the swings make the value of the overseas portfolios highly unpredictable.
For example, Japan's life insurance companies suffered combined paper losses on their foreign investments equivalent to an astounding $30 billion from 1985 through 1987 because the dollar lost about half its value against the yen.
''We are running out of examples to follow because we are the first investor in world history to have $30 billion of currency risk,'' said Keiji Tsuda, a slight, intense man who has a degree from Duke University and heads Nippon Life's international bond portfolio. ''There may be a system for handling that, but nobody has found it yet. I think it's impossible.''
 
Too Big for Most Markets
Another problem these investors face is that they are simply too big for most of the world's financial markets. Outside of New York, Frankfurt and London, the markets simply cannot absorb the capital the Japanese have to invest.
''Even if we put all the time needed into researching these other markets, we just couldn't invest enough to make it worth our while,'' said Yuya Saijo, a confident 34-year-old who manages a slice of the $14 billion that the Mitsubishi Trust invests abroad.
Mr. Tsuda added: ''We're like a big oil tanker. We can't change direction rapidly, and we can only work in the widest area of the sea.''
Nippon Life and Mitsubishi Trust are two primary repositories of the spectacular wealth that accumulated in Japan during the 1980's because of the country's huge trade surpluses.
In addition to collecting premiums from policyholders, Nippon Life manages corporate pensions. Mitsubishi Trust takes deposits, manages assets for both individuals and corportions, and also oversees corporate pension plans.
 
Largest Single Stock Owner
Huge as their assets are, the official figures understate the real value. Nippon Life, for instance, is Japan's largest single stock owner, holding 3 percent of all shares on the Tokyo Stock Exchange. That stake is worth about $125 billion - about three times the value at which the shares are carried on the insurer's books. The books show what Nippon Life paid for the shares.
It was hard to square the visions conjured up by the unprecedented wealth of these institutions with the scene in the large, open, conspicuously unadorned dealing rooms of Nippon Life and Mitsubishi Trust on several days recently.
In typical Japanese fashion, the senior executives sat at large metal desks, all the same, at the head of parallel rows of other metal desks facing each other under fluorescent lights. They were occupied almost exclusively by men in blue suits, almost all of them young; it was hard to spot a face that looked more than 45 years old and most seemed in their 20's. Women, who generally dressed in identical company outfits, did clerical work and fetched tea.
Japan's financial institutions are so new at international investing because during most of the postwar years the Government hoarded capital at home to rebuild and then modernize Japanese industry.
 
Markets Awash With Surpluses
Insurers and trust banks used most of their capital for making loans to industrial concerns. But with Japan's markets awash in surpluses during the 1980's, the Government liberalized its rules and the institutions began looking to foreign markets.
The executives conceded that they had been remarkably naive in their first big moves overseas.
''Theoretically, the logic was that we could reduce our overall risk by spreading out investments over many different countries,'' explained Tokuo Banba, chief manager of international investments for Mitsubishi Trust's pension fund division. ''But practically speaking, people just looked at the interest-rate differential and thought this was an easy way to get a higher return.''

LENGTH: 941 words

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Japanese Rate Surge Felt in U.S.

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
For the first time since Japan became a financial superpower, the market for its Government bonds is playing a critical role in the movement of interest rates in the United States.
Market participants in the United States began to monitor the Japanese market closely only about two weeks ago. Last week, daily increases in Japanese interest rates were followed by a rise in American rates. On Friday, a rally in Tokyo was followed by a rally in the United States. 
Over the last month, long-term interest rates have risen sharply in Japan. As a result, analysts say, the focus on Japan in the American credit markets is likely to remain intense, at least for the next several weeks, even though the market for Japanese Government bonds is only about half as large as the Treasury market. Turning Away From Treasuries? The reasons for the attention are more parochial than global. Because of the run-up in Japanese rates, fears are mounting that Japanese investors will lose their appetite for the new Treasury notes and bonds that will be sold at next month's quarterly refunding auctions.
''It becomes an iffy question about whether or not you buy Treasuries when spreads between Japanese and American interest rates get to the point where they are now,'' said William N. Griggs, a managing director at Griggs & Santow Inc., a financial consulting firm. ''I don't know what Japanese investors will do, but they very well may stay away from these auctions. The market has a legitimate thing to be worried about.''
Including the latest run-up, Japan has experienced three sharp increases in rates since 1985. The current one began in mid-December after an aggressive shift in monetary policy amid worries about inflation.
 
A Narrowing Spread
During the current run-up, yields on 10-year Japanese Government bonds have risen by more than a percentage point, to 6.73 percent on Friday. By comparison, late last week yields on the United States Treasury's 7 7/8 percent 10-year notes stood at 8.23 percent. At those levels, the spread, or difference, between the two issues is about as narrow as it has been in the last 10 years.
In an analysis published in the current issue of Salomon Brothers' weekly ''Comments on Credit,'' the firm's economists note that Japanese rates surged in the fall of 1985 and again in the fall of 1987. But the current rise is different.
''Do I recall a monetary tightening and a sell-off in the Japanese bond market having as dramatic an impact on other markets?'' asked Nicholas Sargen, an international economist at Salomon. ''No.''
Mr. Sargen said fears about inflation in Japan are overblown. Still, he said that further increases in Japanese rates are possible before a substantial downward correction occurs.
''This market has a history of big sell-offs that last for four to six weeks,'' he said. ''Those tend to correct over about the same amount of time.'' Mr. Sargen added that Japan's debt markets could remain unsettled until critical parliamentary elections are held in mid-February, and perhaps longer. 2 Reports Awaited Aside from developments in Japan, two economic reports to be released on Friday could alter the decidedly bearish mood in the credit markets.
Preliminary data on fourth-quarter economic growth and on durable goods orders during December are scheduled to be released. A number of analysts expect that the data may revive the notion that the economy is quite weak.
''I think that output was flat in the fourth quarter,'' said Donald J. Fine, chief market analyst at the Chase Manhattan Bank, ''and it would appear to me that the first quarter is not going to be any better than the fourth. And orders have slowed, and will slow in January as well.''
Despite the recent run-up in interest rates, Mr. Fine said, ''nothing has changed except the timing of the next easing move by the Federal Reserve Board.''
''I still think we will see the overnight Federal funds rate, currently at 8 1/4 percent, down to 8 percent within a month,'' he said.
Because of continued strong demand from retail investors and a light new-issue calendar, the drop in prices of Treasury issues in 1990 has had only a limited effect on tax-exempt municipal bond prices.
Indeed, prices of municipal issues have held up well, even though in the past eight months commercial banks have quietly sold more than $6 billion worth of bonds from their portfolios.
Banks, which have been largely prohibited from buying municipal bonds since the enactment of the Tax Reform Act of 1986, have been selling bonds as a way to shrink their balance sheets to shore up capital ratios, as well as taking profits to offset losses in other areas.
Since the bonds that have been sold have been readily absorbed, market analysts said the selling was not yet a source of concern.
 
'Should Be Watched'
Still, ''it is something that should be watched,'' said James F. Lynch, editor of the New York-based Lynch Municipal Bond Advisory, a newsletter that tracks developments in the industry.
''Most of the selling by the banks has been from institutions in the Northeast,'' he said. ''If the region's real estate problems continue to grow, more bonds may be sold, and could become a source of new supply that the market has not been anticipating.''
Still, since banks can deduct 80 percent of the interest costs on bonds they bought before 1986, analysts said there probably would not be much more liquidation of these securities.
''Most banks are holding on to what they have by their fingernails,'' said George D. Friedlander, manager of municipal bond research at Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL REPORT;
The Bundesbank's Partial Success

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
With its aggressive strategy to strengthen the mark, the Bundesbank of West Germany has shown again why it is considered the most skilled of the West's central banks and a primary player in the economic future of Europe. But not everything has gone according to plan.
The mark now stands at its highest level against the dollar in almost two years, thanks to the Bundesbank's interest rate increases all last year, capped by a 1 percent rise in October, and the central bank's surprising dollar-selling two weeks ago, an action that helped send the dollar down by more than four pfennigs. On Friday, the dollar fell to 1.7105 marks, from 1.7150 marks the previous day.
But the Bundesbank has failed so far in its central goal: strengthening the mark against other major European currencies. Even the Italian lira, which was devalued earlier this month, was down by less than 1 percent against the mark last week, and the French franc has appreciated. 
And the central bank's unexpected intervention the first week of the year may have backfired somewhat by being more disruptive than anticipated, analysts say.
 
Keeping the Pressure
Bundesbank officials have made it clear that they intend to keep the pressure on West Germany's European trading partners to devalue their currencies or to slow their economic growth by raising interest rates to maintain parity with the mark. Either move would help the West Germans shrink their record trade surplus with Europe.
The Bundesbank could also still move to raise interest rates another notch if it concluded that this would be useful in a parallel effort to curb the wage increases that will come out of the crucial labor negotiations with metal workers next month.
For the dollar, this strategy means even more downward pressure will be coming, against the mark and other European currencies. This could add to inflation in the United States, as imports become more expensive. And if the stronger mark, along with the promise of the economic opening of Eastern Europe, continues to divert foreign capital from the United States to West Germany and Europe, interest rates here could rise.
 
'Uncooperative Policy'
Some of the analysts contend the Bundesbank is being self-centered, refusing to account for the effect of its policy on the dollar, the United States, Japan and other economies, the European Monetary System or the goal of a single market in Europe.
''From an international point of view, it is a very uncooperative policy,'' said David Morrison, the chief international economist at Goldman,Sachs & Company in London. ''The Bundesbank decided to do what they wanted to, and the rest could lump it.''
But other analysts are less worried. They contend that for now, the strategy is helping the United States, whose Treasury has favored a weaker dollar to help lower the American trade deficit by making imports more expensive and exports more competitive. Norbert Walter, the senior economist at Deutsche Bank A.G. in Frankfurt, said, ''I haven't seen much complaint about the Bundesbank moves.''
The Bundesbank strategy is no secret. The central bank's president, Karl Otto Pohl, and members of the Bundesbank board have said they want the mark to be stronger.
 
Opening of Borders
In this effort they have been helped by the opening of Eastern Europe, which has lured investment to West Germany and helped strengthen the currency. The Bundesbank also took advantage of the lowering of interest rates in the United States and the resulting downward pressure on the dollar.
One reason for a stronger mark is the desire of West Germany to make its exports more expensive and thus reduce the trade surplus with its European trading partners. The surplus is growing annually and adding to global trade tensions.
A second reason is the Bundesbank's anti-inflation fight. A stronger mark, in this case against the dollar, makes many of the countries' imports, which are priced in dollars, less expensive.
And another reason is the critical labor talks ahead between industry and the 3.5 million metal workers represented by IG Metall. A new increase in interest rates would give a signal to industry that a generous contract will be more difficult to offset with profits because the economy will not be growing as fast.
 
Realigning the System
The Bundesbank contends that the best way to achieve its strategy is through realigning the European Monetary System, which could be forced by a strengthening mark. Such an adjustment would devalue the other currencies in the system, including the French franc.
But the Bundesbank has been frustrated in this goal because its trading partners, especially France, and members of the West German Government do not want a realignment. The French Government has been willing to push up interest rates along with the West Germans, keeping the franc in line with the mark and slowing the French economy to maintain its anti-inflation policy.
The West German Government does not like the idea of a realignment now because it could slow the movement toward monetary union and the fixed exchange rates that are possible after the economic unification of Europe begins in late 1992.
''A realignment of the E.M.S. is not on the agenda because the major players do not want it,'' Mr. Pohl acknowledged recently.
 
Higher Interest Rates
The next best alternative is to maintain pressure by raising interest rates and keeping the mark strong. When countries like France then follow by raising their rates, their economies will be slowed. With slower growth, the West German surplus could be curbed because fewer exports will be bought abroad.
The startling selling of dollars on Jan. 4 was also an effort to keep the mark strong by heading off the rapid appreciation of the dollar on Jan. 2 and 3 and by dampening the idea that the dollar would stage a January rally like it did in 1989. The dollar had risen to 1.7350 marks on Jan. 4, from 1.6910 marks at the end of last year.
The intervention came as the dollar was around 1.73 marks, well within the range of 1.70 marks to 1.90 marks believed to be set by the Group of Seven, which includes the United States, Japan, West Germany, Britain, France, Italy and Canada. This intervention is what made the move to push the dollar lower so surprising and raised questions about whether the Group of Seven was setting a new lower range for the dollar.
 
More Effect on Market
John Lipsky, the director of international bond research at Salomon Brothers Inc. in London, said the Bundesbank probably was trying to make sure the market did not think it was acquiescing in a higher dollar, and therefore, a weaker mark.
He said the bank's selling had much more effect on the market than intended because it coincided with large orders to sell dollars, which led to frenzied selling that pushed down the dollar to 1.6785 marks in late trading in New York on Jan 4, from 1.7224 marks on Jan. 3.
The sharp fall caused confusion in the market and more volatility than the Bundesbank would have wanted.
''When the Bundesbank intervened, people felt that it made sense,'' said one official who understands the bank's strategy. ''But you never know the reaction of the market. And, maybe if the Bundesbank had known how the market would react, the position might have been different.''
