HEADLINE: Market Place;
Super Bowl Nears And Theories Fly

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris

 BODY:
THERE are just five trading days until the Super Bowl is played, and unless share prices rise this week the outcome could be bad news for San Francisco and for stock buyers.
Or it will be if two Super Bowl indicators work this year, as they did in 1989. One uses the stock market to forecast the results of the football game. The other uses the results of the football game to forecast the stock market. 
There is absolutely no reason to think a football game should have anything to do with the stock market. But while there are thousands of market indicators, many of which make a lot more sense, few are better known on Wall Street than the Super Bowl theory. And it is hard to find one with a better record.
The idea of using the market to forecast the football game is more recent. First mentioned in this column a year ago, it prophesied that if the Dow Jones industrial average rises from the end of November until the game is played, the team whose city falls later in the alphabet will win.
Last year, it correctly predicted that the San Francisco 49ers would beat the Cincinnati Bengals. That gave the indicator a record of being right in 13 of the last 15 years, failing only in 1982 and 1986.
The Dow was at 2,706.27 at the end of November, 28.37 points higher than its close last week. Unless it manages to regain that lost ground this week, the market theory forecasts a win by the Denver Broncos over San Francisco.
The much more widely followed Super Bowl indicator holds that a 49ers victory would be a bullish market indicator, because the San Francisco franchise came out of the old National Football League. A Denver win, on the other hand, would provide a bearish signal, because that team used to be in the American Football League.
Such ideas are, of course, nonsense. Still, proponents of the theory note that in measuring market performance from Super Bowl to Super Bowl, the theory has failed after only 2 of the 23 Super Bowl games. Those failures came after the games in 1970, when a Kansas City (A.F.L.) win was nevertheless followed by a rising year for stocks, and after the 1987 win by the New York Giants, when the October market crash decimated stock prices.
It is, of course, a hallmark of the indicator invention game to change the indicator's rules to produce as good a record as possible. Both of the failures of the Super Bowl theory can be finessed away by a simple June rule. In each of the years it failed, it worked from the Super Bowl through the end of June. In 1970, the market was down 14 percent from Super Bowl time through June; in 1987, there was a 15 percent rise over that period.
So the newest version calls for following the indicator and cashing out at the end of June if it worked, while waiting for the next Super Bowl if the market is down as of June. If that does not work this year, no doubt someone will come up with another modification to prove that in retrospect it really worked again.
One reason for the popularity of the Super Bowl theory is that in recent years the old N.F.L. teams have dominated the game, having won 5 in a row coming into this week's showdown, and 12 of the last 15. For understandable reasons, Wall Street prefers bullish indicators that might persuade customers to buy stocks.
The good news for the bulls is that there are other indicators of a more conventional if less popular nature that may show prices are ready to bounce. By last Tuesday, options players were signaling a rarely seen sort of bearishness, said Bernard Schaeffer, a principal in the Investment Research Institute in Cincinnati, which has a service for traders called Market Intelligence Fax. The volume in put options, a way to bet on lower prices, exceeded 95 percent of the volume in calls, a bullish play, over three trading sessions ending Tuesday. Normally, far more calls are traded.
From the beginning of the 1982 bull market, Mr. Schaeffer said, options investors have been that negative only three times, on June 15, 1984; Sept. 13, 1985, and Dec. 4, 1987. Within a month of each of those dates, stock prices exploded upward.
''It's an extreme in negative sentiment by a group of traders who tend to be quite emotional and quite wrong at turning points,'' he said.
Not all sentiment indicators are that extreme, and there are indications that professional money managers, in contrast to options speculators, are talking a more negative game than they are playing. Just back from talks with West Coast money managers last week, a Morgan Stanley & Company strategist, Byron Wein, described the managers as ''apprehensive and kind of bearish on the market, but fully invested,'' and compared them to a person carrying a large cash deposit to the bank, fearful that a mugger lurks in every shadow.
Nonetheless, Mr. Wein remains among the shrinking band of bulls, arguing that the next surprise to hit Wall Street will be a realization that the economy is not as bad as many think, and that profits will be better.

HEADLINE: New Rules Forcing Cuts by Builders

BYLINE: By THOMAS C. HAYES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ATLANTA, Jan. 21

 BODY:
Most housing analysts concluded months ago that fewer first-time home buyers, a slowing economy and rising land and development costs would curb home construction this year and next. But builders in many regions are starting to slash operations even more deeply than they had planned, because of tough new lending policies Congress forced on savings and loan institutions in August.
The regulations came in response to past abuses and mismanagement in the savings industry, which has suffered hundreds of failures in recent years, prompting the Government to undertake a rescue that may ultimately cost $300 billion.
Analysts have said that much of the fraud-related losses stemmed from lending for land purchases and development of housing. 
As a result, a wave of caution has spread to hundreds of commercial banks. In several interviews here, where the National Association of Homebuilders is winding up its annual convention, developers glumly recounted stories of bankers reducing or halting new lending for land purchases and housing development.
By all accounts, the most turmoil has stemmed from a new rule that bars savings institutions from making loans equal to 15 percent or more of their capital to a single borrower. Before Congress approved the new laws, the limit was 100 percent of capital.
 
Limit Is 'Pretty Scary'
''The lending limit at the thrifts is pretty scary,'' said Alvin T. Schwartz, president of the Double S Companies, a home builder in northern Delaware. Mr. Schwartz said he will build 150 homes this year, compared with 200 in 1989.
In other changes, savings institutions must raise their capital to 6 percent of total deposits by 1993. Perhaps as many as 2,000 institutions expect to meet that standard, but many plan to do it by letting their deposits shrink and cutting back on new loans.
Savings and loans are also barred from investing any of their equity in real estate projects - a practice that became common in many areas after the Federal Government deregulated the industry in 1982.
That rule change has hit hardest in California, Oregon and Washington, where many large institutions with considerable capital often joined with builders to finance and develop home construction. The Western states are expected to show the strongest demand for new housing in the next two years, and considerable demand is also predicted in the Midwest, economists told the builders.
 
Congress Seen Moving Slowly
Despite the mounting complaints of home builders, Congress seems unlikely to move quickly to ease the new lending standards. Public opinion could, however, swing in favor of the builders after a few years if prices and apartment rents escalate, said Barbara Alexander, a managing director and housing analyst at Salomon Brothers.
A recession in the housing industry that could cut housing starts by 100,000 a year would either arrest price declines for existing homes or push prices higher in many parts of the country, Ms. Alexander said.
She said such a shift in prices would eventually be likely to persuade voters and Congress to heed the home builders' call for more liberal lending rules. But that would probably not occur for at least three years, she said.
In a speech to the builders, Ms. Alexander estimated that housing starts, including single-family homes and apartment buildings, will average 1.2 million a year through 1994, or 500,000 below what the industry would have produced without the lending constraints.
The Commerce Department reported on Thursday that housing starts fell 8 percent in 1989, to 1.37 million, the lowest level in seven years.
 
Lower Estimates Expected
Many economists had predicted that new starts would be flat to slightly higher in the next few years. But some economists told reporters at the convention that they were likely to lower their estimates because of recent rises in interest rates and the financing difficulties of builders.
Ms. Alexander said a large company typically needs to borrow $140 million to finance a 1,000-unit development with an average sale price of $200,000 for each home. Under the new rules, only about 15 savings institutions are large enough to be allowed to make a $50 million loan to a builder, she said.
''We are hearing increasing reports from builders, including some very large companies, that are having problems'' obtaining loans, she said. She said one California bank, which she did not name, will only make loans based on conservative appraisals set at 1987 prices. Her remark drew gasps from some in an audience of more than 200.
That approach means builders must put more equity into new projects to keep pace with land costs, fees imposed by local governments and other expenses that have risen sharply since 1987.
 
Builders' Thirst for Funds
William C. Apgar, head of the Joint Center for Housing Studies at Harvard University, said that in time the financial system would close the gap in meeting the builders' thirst for funds. He said nearly 12 million housing units would be constructed during the decade, down slightly from the 13 million of the 1980's.
With many private investors also wary of real estate financing, particularly in the Southwest and parts of the Northeast, some builders are looking to individuals and financial institutions in Japan, Britain, West Germany, France, Canada and elsewhere for loans and equity.
A survey conducted earlier this month by Ernst & Young, the big accounting firm, indicated that 30 of the nation's 100 largest home builders had borrowed recently from abroad. Patrick M. Schaefer, a partner in the firm's Dallas office, said developments in the mid-Atlantic states had obtained the most foreign money.
One builder in Southern California, Jim Deane, said four Japanese investors are backing his new housing development in Riverside, about 90 miles east of Los Angeles.
Mr. Deane cautioned builders that it took three years to cultivate his ties with the Japanese partners and that any land deals or projects requiring quick action were not part of the discussions.

HEADLINE: 3 Issues in This Week's Treasury Auctions

 BODY:
The Treasury's schedule of issues this week includes today's auction of three- and six-month bills and Wednesday's auction of two-year notes.
Tomorrow, the Resolution Funding Corporation plans to raise $5 billion through the sale of 40-year bonds for the Government's savings-and-loan rescue plan. The Treasury last sold 40-year bonds in 1955. 
By late Friday, the outstanding three-month bill was bid at 7.73 percent, while the six-month bill was bid at 7.60 percent. In when-issued trading, the two-year notes were offered at a price to yield 8.14 percent, while the Resolution Funding bonds were 8.47 percent.
The issues expected from Government agencies this week include a $3.1 billion financing by the Federal Farm Credit Banks Funding Corporation. The consolidated systemwide bonds, to be priced Wednesday, will be offered with maturities of three months, six months and one year.

HEADLINE: U.S. Set to Ease High-Tech Curb On Eastern Bloc

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22

 BODY:
Under intense pressure from American business and Western European allies to relax curbs on exports of high technology to Eastern Europe, the Bush Administration said today that it would work toward opening the door.
The change could open markets worth hundreds of millions of dollars to American companies, especially for those that make computers and telecommunications equipment.
The decision on a softer line was recommended Friday by a committee of the National Security Council, which has been debating the matter since the third week of December.
''Obviously, it's a reaction to changes in Eastern Europe, and obviously it's because we want to continue to support those changes,'' Marlin Fitzwater, the White House press secretary, said today. 
The relaxation announced today does not affect curbs against technology transfers to the Soviet Union. The American proposal includes safeguards, including spot inspections, intended to insure that the Eastern European countries do not ship the technology on to Moscow.
These countries would be offered roughly the same degree of freedom to acquire Western technology as now applies to China, a senior American official said.
The proposal will be the basis of the American negotiating position at a meeting in Paris next month of the 17-nation Coordinating Committee on Multilateral Export Controls, known as Cocom.
Some analysts said the American proposals for safeguards might draw objections from other Cocom members.
The Administration had been resisting calls for looser trade rules, as the American military warned that any relaxation could enable Moscow to divert technology to its military and become a stronger potential adversary.
The plan calls for the easing to take place in stages and to affect first Hungary and Poland, then East Germany and Czechoslovakia, and finally Rumania and Bulgaria, the senior Administration official said.
No details were disclosed, but American officials said the new approach would allow the sale of computers two and three times as powerful as those now approved for export to the East bloc.
 
Eased Military Threat
Noting an apparently eased military threat from the Soviet Union, Mr. Fitzwater called the decision ''a prudent change that will not jeopardize critical strategic interests.''
The decision has the blessing of President Bush, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d, Commerce Secretary Robert A. Mosbacher and Brent Scowcroft, the national security adviser, one top Administration official said.
A proposal before Cocom that is now likely to go forward is a bid by U S West, the regional telephone company based in Denver, to build a cellular telephone system in Hungary, one official said, Industry Is Glad An industry group that has been among the most ardent backers of easing the policy was encouraged by the Administration's decision. ''We're glad that they finally succumbed to Cocom pressure and put a significant proposal on the table,'' said Debra L. Waggoner, manager of international trade policy for the 3,500-member American Electronics Association.
In addition to computers and telecommunications equipment, rules on exports of machine tools would be loosened. Machine tools cut or shape metal parts used in an array of products, from appliances and vehicles to aircraft and construction materials.
Much of the additional business in machine tools is likely to go to West German, Italian and Japanese companies, which hold competitive advantages over American companies.
Britain's Secretary of State for Trade and Industry, Nicholas Ridley, in a conversation with a small group of reporters, said he was delighted that Cocom would soon discuss the proposed liberalization. Eventually, he said, Eastern European countries might be able to trade with the West ''the way Britain trades with the United States.''
 
Technology Trade Rules
Cocom, which was formed 41 years ago at the height of the cold war, includes all the Western European nations except Iceland, as well as Japan and Australia. It tries to adopt uniform rules covering transfers of technology to Communist countries.
Traditionally, the United States has been the most reluctant Cocom member on liberalizing trade. Its allies, led by West Germany, have warned that with democratization and market-based economics spreading in Eastern Europe, Cocom risks collapse if it does not show more flexibility.
At a meeting of senior officials in Paris in October, the United States was isolated, 16 to 1, in a Cocom vote on easing curbs on machine tools.
The relaxation announced today is linked to the ''establishment of proper safeguards for Western technology,'' said Dennis E. Kloske, Under Secretary of Commerce for Export Administration.
 
Coordinated Position
''We will have a coordinated position with Cocom allies which will assure that we have a common policy towards Eastern Europe,'' he added.
Under the new American approach, to qualify for the more advanced technology Eastern European countries will need to adopt legal and administrative frameworks for protection of the technology against diversion. The United States would seek to advise on the safeguards.
American officials said they would insist on spot-inspection certification by the governments of the users of the products.
But some analysts see these demands as possible sticking points at next month's Cocom meeting. ''The allies may consider these demands too onerous,'' said Paul Freedenberg, a former top Commerce Department export control official and now a trade lawyer in Washington.
On the other hand, what is said to be continued close linkage between military and security services of the Soviet Union and its Eastern European allies has raised questions about the effectiveness of efforts to keep the technology out of Soviet hands.
''There are people within these governments who will be actively subverting the assurances,'' said Frank J. Gaffney Jr., director of the Center for Security Policy, a Washington-based research group opposed to liberalization.

HEADLINE: A CORPORATE LAG IN RESEARCH FUNDS IS CAUSING WORRY

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF

 BODY:
For the first time in 14 years, spending on corporate research and development in the United States has not even kept pace with inflation, raising concerns that the nation is lagging in its efforts to hold a competitive edge in high technology.
Many economists and corporate research executives say the decline is particularly troubling because, at the same time, research money is increasingly being shifted from basic research to development of specific products, reducing the chances of fundamental breakthroughs.
What is more, they say, a smaller portion of research is being done in large laboratories, where resources can be pooled, limiting the opportunity for significant advances.
 
Report to Be Released
The decline will be reported in a survey by National Science Foundation economists to be released within a week. The report will show that although spending rose to $68.8 billion in 1989 from $66.5 billion in 1988, when adjusted for inflation the change represents a decline of nine-tenths of 1 percent, the first drop since 1975. 
Economists and corporate research directors say the portion of research money spent on basic research, as opposed to product development, has been falling from its historical level of approximately 10 percent in many industries.
The decline in United States corporate research spending, which follows several years of slowing growth, has been attributed to a variety of factors. They include higher interest rates, which have made it more expensive to raise money for research; an increasing focus by corporate managers on short-term profitability, and the cost-cutting that accompanies corporate restructurings, mergers and leveraged buyouts.
 
Effect of Takeover Era
The era of hostile takeovers has reshaped corporate thinking on research and development, said William J. Spencer, the Xerox Corporation's executive vice president for research and development. ''We've moved from research and development as being a corporate asset to where it's what a corporate raider looks for first,'' he said. ''They can make significant cuts and get cash flow. I haven't seen a takeover yet where they increased research and development activities.''
Research spending is crucial to assuring that corporations develop innovative products and bring them to market quickly. Since World War II American corporate research and development programs have created a remarkable variety of advanced products and technologies, including the transistor, drugs, lasers and advanced jet aircraft.
But now, ''Research and development is becoming less prominent in American companies exactly at the time when it should be becoming more prominent,'' said Charles F. Larson, executive director of the Industrial Research Institute, a Washington group that represents the research centers of major corporations. He said such spending should rise if the United States was to remain competitive with other nations.
 
Japanese Keep Spending
Experts say Japanese companies, flush with cash, keep increasing research spending at a brisk rate. As of 1987, the most recent year for which comparative figures are available, the growth of research and development spending among Japanese companies was more than three times that for United States companies, statistics from the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development show.
In this country, there is no general agreement that restructurings have been bad for research. Some scholars and corporate research managers argue that the decline may instead represent increasing efficiency by research laboratories. They say there is no definitive link between merger activity and the falloff in spending on research.
Economists say the experience of Xerox illustrates the problem of companies that find it difficult to translate spending on basic research into profits quickly.
Xerox, under pressure from its Japanese copier competitors and in danger of being acquired by a hostile bidder, has reduced its research in basic physical sciences by roughly a third. It has transferred scientists to work in systems and software - research areas that are likely to have an immediate product payoff. Previously, the money was going toward research in basic semiconductor physics; such research might have yielded advances toward denser, faster chips that could have run a new generation of computers.
Xerox's increased emphasis on product development reflects its frustration with basic research in the last two decades. Attempting to enter the computer industry during the 1970's and 1980's, Xerox pioneered basic computer science research at its research center in Palo Alto, Calif.
The research produced significant advances, including an experimental computer language, an easier-to-use computer interface and basic technology permitting computers to communicate with one another. But many of the scientists doing this basic research later left the company to start a wide range of businesses based on those developments at Xerox.
 
Expanding Xerox Ideas
Companies like Apple Computer, Adobe Systems and Grid Computer have all built sizable businesses based on ideas pioneered at Xerox. Meanwhile, Xerox itself could never successfully translate the fruits of its research into products to make it a significant force in the computer industry.
But not everyone at Xerox is happy about its shift away from basic research. ''The premier laboratories in the country are all under pressure,'' Dr. Spencer said. ''If this continues we won't have laboratories where a transistor, laser or superconductor can be invented any longer. Instead people will tend to get pulled into product development.''
The Eastman Kodak Company, long a leader in research, reorganized in 1986, shrinking its central laboratory and transferring its work into operating divisions. Previously, research had been organized by scientific disciplines, like physics and chemistry.
Now it is organized along product lines, like photography and data storage. And the company's research and development spending fell to $992 million in 1987 from $1.06 billion in 1986; it rose in 1988 because of the acquisition of Sterling Drug.
The downturn in corporate spending on research is even more alarming to some economists and researchers because of extensive cuts expected in military spending, which has historically provided the largest part of Federal financing for research. The integrated circuit, which controls all modern electronics products, was developed in the late 1960's as part of a military program to squeeze more electronics into the nose cone of the Minuteman missile.
 
Military Applications
And, like many companies, the Pentagon has shifted the money it still provides away from basic research and more toward work that can be directly related to military applications, research executives said.
''There's clearly a shift away from the kind of funding that resulted in great ideas in the 60's and 70's,'' said Samuel Fuller, who heads research and development at the Digital Equipment Corporation. He said entire lines of products, from the personal computer to the engineering work station, grew out of basic computer-science research financed by the Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency, a small Pentagon office.
As a consequence of the changes in Pentagon spending, he said, American universities, which have been expected to take up the slack in basic research as corporate researchers have moved toward product development, may increasingly find that they are starved for money.
Economists say that shifting money back to basic research from product development may be less profitable for a company but more useful for the nation as a whole. As one example, the discovery, during basic research at the International Business Machines Corporation, of materials that conduct electricity without resistance at higher temperatures may lead to important advances in energy transmission, computing and transportation. But it will not be immediately profitable to I.B.M.
 
'The Most Value'
''From the point of view of the country, basic research has the most value,'' said Kenneth Flamm, an economist at the Brookings Institution. ''But it's also the most difficult to turn into profits for an individual company.''
Economists say the downturn in research spending indicates that a steadily worsening national trend shows no sign of reversing. In the late 1970's and early 1980's, corporate research and development spending increased dramatically. Since rising at an average annual rate of 12.7 percent between 1976 and 1985, the growth rate has steadily declined.
''We ought to regard these statistics as warning flares,'' said Roland W. Schmitt, president of the Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute and formerly senior vice president for science and technology at the General Electric Company.
The trend may be only part of the problem. In recent years, as the emphasis has shifted to product development, many of the foremost research laboratories in the United States have lost some of their effectiveness. Some research managers are concerned that this will mean less basic research and therefore fewer breakthroughs.
 
Effect of Bell Breakup
For example, the breakup of the Bell System in 1984 has reduced the size and, some argue, changed the focus of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company's prestigious Bell Laboratories. Some economists argue that Bell Labs has cut back significantly on basic research as a result of the divestiture. But A.T.&T. officials dispute this charge, saying the laboratory has not lost its influence in the six years since the breakup.
The purchase of RCA by the General Electric Company has resulted in the scaling back of the David Sarnoff Laboratories, which did much pioneer research in television. The lab was donated to SRI International. At the same time, G.E. has cut spending on basic research and development, and company-financed research as a whole remained flat at $1.2 billion in 1987 and 1988, the latest years for which figures are available.
To be sure, some American companies, many of them in highly competitive industries, have continued to increase their research budgets.
At I.B.M., for example, research spending increased by about 10 percent last year, to about $5.5 billion, and at the Hewlett-Packard Company, such spending was up almost 20 percent.
But I.B.M.'s head of research and development, Dr. John Armstrong, said that as a result of increasing competition the company has been changing the way it does research to support product development more closely.
 
'Traditional View'
''The traditional academic view is that first you do basic research, then applied research, then product development, then give it to manufacturing,'' he said. But he said the Japanese had been so effective at rapidly translating research into successful commercial products that I.B.M. had been forced to try to generate new products more quickly.
Hewlett-Packard executives said their focus in research had shifted because the increasing speed of change in the computer and electronic equipment industries meant more money had to go into product development just to keep up.

HEADLINE: PLOT ON BUSH'S JET POSSIBLE, U.S. SAYS

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22

 BODY:
United States intelligence has picked up indications that Colombian drug traffickers may be planning to attack President Bush when he visits the city of Cartagena next month for a four-nation meeting on narcotics, Administration officials said tonight.
The officials confirmed the substance of a report by CBS News, which said there were ''growing reports'' that the Colombian cocaine cartels had obtained shoulder-fired antiaircraft missiles and were planning to use them in an attack on Air Force One.
Other Administration officials who were contacted tonight declined to confirm specifically whether the Soviet-made SAM-7 weapons were being smuggled into Colombia, as CBS reported. But they did not dispute the general accuracy of the broadcast. 
 
Available on Black Market
One official noted that such weapons were readily available on the black market.
Asked about the reports, Michael Skol, the senior State Department official in charge of relations with Colombia, said, ''I can't comment on that.''
Mr. Skol added: ''The President is going to Colombia. You can quote me on that.''
Mr. Bush is to visit Cartagena for several hours on Feb. 15 to discuss anti-narcotics efforts with the Presidents of Colombia and Bolivia and a representative of the Peruvian Government.
The Secret Service takes extensive precautions to protect the President as a matter of routine whenever he travels, and officials have said that these measures will be even more extraordinary for the Cartagena visit.
''The Service has assured us repeatedly that they are confident they can protect the President in Colombia,'' one official said tonight. ''They have checked out every report and gone over the arrangements repeatedly.''
CBS News said there had been ''a growing number of intelligence reports'' that SAM-7 missiles had been smuggled into Colombia ''for an attempt to shoot down Air Force One as it lands at Cartagena.''
 
Some Reports Dismissed
The network said some of the intelligence reports ''are dismissed by intelligence officers as attempts by informants to curry favor with law enforcement officials.''
CBS News quoted unidentified United States officials as saying they were confident they could thwart any effort to shoot down Air Force One, since the SAM-7 is a relatively unsophisticated weapon and Mr. Bush's plane is equipped with electronic devices intended to throw such missiles off course.
But it said the Secret Service was considering ''other ways of bringing the President into Colombia.'' It did not say what those methods were.
According to Administration officials, one early plan for the conference called for Mr. Bush to fly into a heavily guarded military airfield with military aircraft escorts and then to fly under equally heavy guard to an isolated Colombian naval station where the conference would take place.

HEADLINE: Cardinal Szoka Leaving Detroit for Vatican

 BODY:
Edmund Cardinal Szoka of Detroit announced yesterday that he would be resigning as the Roman Catholic Archbishop of Detroit to take up new duties in June, heading the Vatican's budget office.
At a news conference in Detroit, the Cardinal said he was acting at the request of Pope John Paul II, who is believed likely to name a successor for the Detroit archdiocese in the spring. It is the fifth largest archdiocese in the United States.
Cardinal Szoka ordered 30 parishes closed last year, but Detroit church officials deny that the action indicated that the archdiocese was in straits.
The Cardinal said the action was primarily due to shrinking congregations and low religious activity rather than insolvency.
He will be president of the Prefecture for the Economic Affairs of the Holy See, which compiles and oversees the budgets of all Vatican offices and agencies and investigates abuses.
The Prefecture exercises no direct authority over the Vatican Bank, but Cardinal Szoka is a member of a council of cardinals who supervise the bank.

HEADLINE: Final Score on Panama

 BODY:
President Garcia of Peru refuses to meet with President Bush on drug issues . . . Colombia discourages the U.S. Navy from patrolling its coasts . . . Mexican and Venezuelan leaders stiff-arm Vice President Quayle. Has the Bush Administration relieved its Noriega headache at the cost of paralyzing itself elsewhere in Latin America? Not necessarily. But recovering Latin good will will require renewed attention to the style and substance of several sensitive issues. 
Before the Panama invasion, the Bush Administration worked hard to smooth U.S.-Latin American relations. One big reward was cooperation on drugs, symbolized by next month's drug summit meeting in Bogota. Latin leaders sensed that Mr. Bush was prepared to help them stand up to the political consequences of confronting traffickers.
Then came Panama. The invasion was justifiable under the circumstances, but no occasion for preening or pride. The resort to force represented a failure of U.S. policy on several levels.
For years, assorted U.S. agencies put misplaced trust in General Noriega. Their folly made it easier for the general to entrench himself, sell protection to drug traffickers and thwart later U.S. efforts to dislodge him. Those efforts, under the Reagan and Bush Administrations, all misfired. Reluctantly, a cautious President approved a drastic course he knew carried major diplomatic costs.
Still, Latin leaders seemed to recognize Panama as a special case, not a return to the Bad Neighbor Policy of the past. The U.S. had first gone to the O.A.S., with disappointing results. Panama marked a failure of Latin diplomacy, too. Had Mr. Bush defined his goals narrowly, kept U.S. troops in a low profile and stressed a quick return of authority to Panamanian hands, regional relations might have quickly recovered. Instead, U.S. commanders have shown stunning diplomatic insensitivity. Then, the Navy was ordered to patrol Colombia's coast without formal Colombian approval.
Latin leaders face acute problems. Most have little taste for Yanqui-bashing. They'd rather cooperate with Washington on debt, drugs and problems of democratic transition. Mr. Bush would do well to promote such cooperation, in non-military ways: Argentina and Brazil need economic and political reinforcement as they attempt economic adjustments as drastic as any in Eastern Europe. Chile's new Government needs diplomatic backing as it tries to bring institutions under civil control. Peru faces perils as it holds a presidential election amid guerrilla and drug violence, death squads and hyperinflation. Colombia needs help sustaining its non-drug exports, like coffee, if it is to continue resisting truce offers from the Medellin cartel.
Panama was neither a famous U.S. victory nor a regional diplomatic disaster. The President's final score depends on what he does now about enduring questions in Latin America.

HEADLINE: Topics of The Times;
No Shortage of Ideas

 BODY:
In 1988, American workers dropped 1,010,889 ideas into their suggestion boxes, according to the National Association of Suggestion Systems. Their bosses adopted more than 293,000 of those ideas, roughly 29 percent, and thereby saved $2.2 billion. 
Impressive numbers? Not compared with Japan. The Human Relations Association there says Japanese companies with worker-suggestion programs average more than 2,000 ideas per 100 workers. In America, it's only 13 per 100. What's more, 80 percent of Japanese suggestions are adopted.
Japanese and U.S. statistics aren't directly comparable because the systems differ. Japan's employers actively encourage involvement; employee discussion groups are more common. Trifling suggestions are welcomed - and get trifling awards. American business focuses on ideas for big improvements, with big awards. Differences notwithstanding, there's a message: The greater the workers' involvement, the sharper the competitive edge.

HEADLINE: Out of the Welfare Roll and Into the Soup Kitchen, Albany Style

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Cesar A. Perales, New York State's Commissioner of Social Services, recently issued a press release celebrating a drop in the welfare rolls to their lowest levels since 1968. His department attributes this drop to a stronger economy and successful programs to get welfare recipients back to work.
Mr. Perales neglects to mention that this plunge in the welfare rolls has been accompanied by an explosion in emergency food program use. In 1980, it is estimated, there were 50 food pantries and soup kitchens statewide; today there are more than 2,500. Food pantries serve 400,000 families each month; 1 million meals are served in soup kitchens each month. 
Contrary to Mr. Perales's assertion, the Department of Social Services has no statistical evidence to demonstrate that welfare numbers are down because people are entering employment as a result of any of its job-training programs. Where studies of employment and training programs are done, the findings indicate only a slight difference in entry to employment between people who participate in the program and control groups who don't.
Furthermore, the department acknowledges that only one-third of what it has saved in welfare grants through its comprehensive employment program is accounted for by employment. A full two-thirds results from sanctions placed on clients who failed to comply with complicated, confusing program requirements. What the state saves means a reduction in the income of public assistance families, forcing them to rely on food pantries and soup kitchens to feed their children. Seventy percent of all people on public assistance are children.
A second problem is that many people who get a job still live below the poverty level. A woman with two children would have to earn nearly $5 an hour to keep her family at the poverty level. Yet the Department of Social Services makes no effort in its job-training programs to insure that the jobs people are trained for pay decent wages, offer medical benefits and provide job security. They will not allow recipients to get a college degree.
The department has no information on the rate of pay clients are receiving when they leave the welfare rolls, and it does not track them after they leave the rolls to find out how long they are able to stay off. Nearly half of all jobs created between 1979 and 1985 paid poverty-level wages. If welfare recipients are going into these jobs, they will also need a food pantry or soup kitchen to feed their family. The minute a medical problem or some other crisis arises, they will return to the welfare rolls.
Mr. Perales should not boast about lowering the rolls yet. His constitutional duty as the Commissioner of Social Services is to insure the provision of aid, care and support to the needy. The purpose of the aid to families with dependent children program is to provide financial assistance and care for children and to help their caretakers attain self-support. When Mr. Perales can demonstrate that he is meeting these needs, instead of shifting the cost of feeding people onto the food pantries and soup kitchens, we will be among the first to congratulate him.
 
HEIDI SIEGFRIED
Associate Director, Hunger Action
Network of New York State
 Albany, Jan. 2, 1990

HEADLINE: American Wheat Habit Was Killing Nigeria

 BODY:
To the Editor:
''Wheat Rift Splits Nigerians and U.S.'' (news article, Dec. 31) merits a bit of additional background information so that readers may better understand the dispute.
The countries of sub-Saharan Africa have been plagued with the slowest rates of economic growth of any area of the globe, and their economies are overburdened with international debt that they can never hope to repay in full. Their ability to purchase the vital capital inputs to keep their economies from slipping further backward is seriously restricted by their increasing difficulty in earning foreign exchange, and for years development economists have urged them not to squander it on unnecessary imported consumer goods. Politically, such reforms are difficult to implement, and when African leaders have occasionally undertaken to follow such advice, it has been at considerable risk. 
The Nigerian Government finally summoned up the courage to impose a ban on the importation of wheat, a commodity that does not thrive well in Nigeria, but has become a popular ingredient in the Nigerian diet because it has for many years been made available by the United States at attractive prices. As you point out, Nigeria had become the sixth largest market for American wheat imports, which were fast becoming a major absorber of Nigeria's scarce foreign exchange earnings.
The Nigerian population was becoming hooked on wheat, creating the specter of a permanent dependence on imports for its basic food staple by this largest of the African countries.
Not only were vitally necessary capital goods imports sacrificed, but Nigeria's efforts to build a measure of economic independence were also blatantly undermined by this increasing consumption of imported wheat. President Ibrahim Babangida's decision to demand that his people ''eat only what we can grow ourselves'' was a wise and courageous move, and we should offer our full moral support to him for making such a politically risky structural adjustment.
Instead, the Bush Administration is apparently threatening to retaliate against him in some manner. You suggest that the Administration is placing responsibility for its negative posture on Congress, arguing that Nigeria is discriminating against United States imports and is therefore in violation of American law. Although the facts are not all in, the Administration's case is not persuasive. The farm lobby will certainly be unhappy to lose these sales, but there is no basis for charging discrimination if the ban applies to all wheat imports, not just those from America.
Africa is suffering from a greater range of problems than any other area of the world, and its leadership is not always as farsighted as its friends would like it to be. Certainly we should applaud it when Africa makes the right decision, even if that imposes some inconvenience upon ourselves.
 
WALTER E. FAUNTROY
Chairman, House Subcommittee on Intl. Development, Finance,
Trade and Monetary Policy
 Washington, Jan. 5, 1990

HEADLINE: PUBLIC & PRIVATE;
Insufficient Funds

BYLINE: By Anna Quindlen

 BODY:
The building that was once B. Altman stands on Fifth Avenue, solid as a rock, pathetic as an abandoned house. Two women mount the steps and peer inside the glass doors. ''I was on their bridal registry,'' said one sadly.
There are plenty of lessons to be learned when a business fails, lessons about retailing and financing and cash flow. But what shoppers think when they pass the lifeless hulk of what was once one of New York's grand department stores may be something different, something less cerebral, more emotional. 
The sluggishness of the real estate market may illustrate something about interest rates, and the transformation of Bloomingdale's from Trend Central to Chapter 11 is a story of crushing corporate debt. But to those of us who come closest to reorganization when we consolidate our debt on our Visa cards, these things speak to a vulnerability that has been with us for some time. This is a land of diminishing economic expectation. The ground is not solid here. In other parts of the country this has been manifest for years, and not just when the family farms have failed or the oil boom in Texas went bust. In most American small cities and large towns, there was a store like Altman's, the anchor to the downtown, the center of commerce on Main Street. If your father made enough money, you had lunch in the tea room and bought a winter coat with a velvet collar and matching hat there. If you were poor, you dreamed of doing those things.
What you didn't dream was that some day you would come through town and see that big square building boarded up. It often had more to do with the ascendancy of the malls and the suburbs than the national economy, and yet it seemed to the people who lived in those towns as though a part of a prosperous past was gone, the part that believed in passbook savings accounts.
There is, among economists, an equation that determines when a recession exists: two back-to-back quarters of negative growth in the gross national product. One group of economists even has a committee that will sometimes meet for the sole purpose of declaring a recession.
A new New York Times/CBS News Poll shows that 36 percent of the respondents said the economy was getting worse, 11 percentage points more than a little over a year ago. Oddly enough, there's a big difference in pessimism between men and women; 43 percent of the women said things had gone downhill.
There could be several reasons for that. There's the ''last hired, first fired'' dictum which makes women especially vulnerable to layoffs. The fact that, on average, women workers are still making 70 cents for every dollar a man makes means they also feel inflation more keenly.
But perhaps it is also that women experience the economy on what you might call a reality level. We buy bread. A recession committee meets nearly every week in my neighborhood supermarket, and this is how it works. Someone puts everything on the black rubber treadmill, and when it's all toted up the bill is $20 higher than it was a year ago. At that point, a recession is declared, at least in the mind of one person.
Unscientific, but never forget that science has to share shelf space in all our minds with humanities. Much of our approach to life is anecdotal. When a pretty house down the block wears a sale sign for eight months, and when we hear that it finally sold for $30,000 less than the asking price, we feel, not that our neighbor has a problem, or our neighborhood, but that the economy does.
When he was running for President, Ronald Reagan asked Americans whether they were better off than they were four years before. That's not the question I would ask today. Ask 30-year-olds whether they are better off than their parents were at that age. For that small slice known as the upper middle class, the ones with second homes and interesting portfolios, the answer is probably yes.
But for all those young men and women who thought that $25,000 a year would buy a house and now know that it will barely buy a car, the answer is clearly no. That is based, not on economic formula, but on the way we feel about our lives. The people who stop for a minute to look at the facade of B. Altman, the people who still experience a twinge when they drive down Main Street and see the department store where their first suit was purchased now a shell, do not necessarily know the numbers. They know the feeling.

HEADLINE: Man Held in Beating Death of Homeless Man After Subway Fight

BYLINE: By DONATELLA LORCH

 BODY:
A 39-year-old unemployed plumber, punched and spat at by a homeless man while standing on a subway platform Sunday night with his 3-year-old son, beat the vagrant so badly that he died a few hours later, the transit police said.
The police charged the man, Rodney Sumter of 2991 Frederick Douglass Boulevard in Washington Heights, with first-degree manslaughter.
The homeless man was described as a black male, about 6 feet tall, in his late 50's, by a transit police officer, Randall Berry. Officer Berry said the man had a reputation for harassing and spitting at passers-by. The man was a ''regular'' at the subway station at Columbus Circle and 59th Street, where the incident took place, Albert O'Leary, a transit police spokesman said. 
The confrontation occurred at 11:30 P.M. as Mr. Sumter and his son, Patah, returning from seeing ''Back to the Future II,'' waited on the platform for the northbound A train.
 
The Man Pursued Him
Witnesses told the police that the homeless man approached Mr. Sumter and spat at him. When Mr. Sumter tried to move down the platform the homeless man pursued him and punched him above the left eye, Mr. O'Leary said. Mr. Sumter then punched the man, knocked him to the platform, kicking him and slamming his head onto the platform.
It was not clear whether the homeless man had continued to fight while down on the platform.
A train supervisor spotted the fight and alerted the transit police. They arrested Mr. Sumter on the platform, where he was comforting his son, who was crying. The homeless man was taken to Roosevelt Hospital and died shortly after midnight, Mr. O'Leary said. The medical examiner's office had not reviewed the case yet.
The boy was picked up at 1 A.M. at a transit police command post at the subway station by his mother, Michelle Sumter.
 
Provocation Studied
Colleen Roche, a spokeswoman for the Manhattan District Attorney, said the charge of first-degree manslaughter was based on the slamming of the homeless man's head onto the platform. She said her office was still investigating what provoked Mr. Sumter's reaction.
''Mr. Sumter is alleged to have taken John Doe by the face area and slammed his head to the platform and kicked John Doe on the side of his head while he was down,'' Ms. Roche said. ''That in and of itself constitutes manslaughter.''
Mr. Sumter was to be arraigned last night. The transit police said he had no prior arrest record.
The case could pose difficult questions in the judicial process. Robert Pitler, who teaches criminal law at the Brooklyn Law School, said Mr. Sumter's defense would depend on how easily he could prove that he responded with physical force in order to protect himself.
Physical force can be used against a person, Professor Pitler said, if he needs to protect or defend himself.
''If he was afraid that he was going to be punched again, he had the right to defend himself,'' he said.
But justification defenses are very difficult to prove in cases in which the action happens very quickly.
 
Makeshift Cardboard Tents
''It is difficult to determine what is reasonable and what is not reasonable when everything happens very quickly,'' he explained.
The Columbus Circle train station is a haven for many homeless people who gather in makeshift cardboard tents on its heat grates or huddle in its cavernous cement underground hallways, foraging through the garbage or panhandling on the platforms.
The station has one of the largest populations of homeless people in Manhattan, said George McDonald, the executive director of the Doe Fund, which provides legal help to the homeless.
Some passengers feel threatened, others are sympathetic, annoyed or even lend them assistance. Fights among homeless people over food and money are not uncommon, said Mr. O'Leary. Neither are instances of homeless people being harassed, particularly by groups of teen-agers.
''I don't punch someone in the face unless they deserve it,'' said one 18-year-old subway rider in the station last night, Louis Rivas, of Staten Island. Mr. Rivas said he is regularly harassed by homeless people. ''If someone spits in my face,'' he said, ''I'll beat him up.''

LENGTH: 896 words

HEADLINE: Troopers Bolstering Hartford Police

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Jan. 22

 BODY:
A state plan to help overworked local police departments combat street crime by sending in a little extra muscle from the state police has turned into a fight over jurisdiction, public perception and ruffled pride.
The pilot program, which began last week in a drug-plagued area near downtown Hartford called Frog Hollow, involves only five state troopers and a sergeant, who have been detached for 90 days for uniformed patrols.
But Hartford police union officials, who filed a lawsuit in Superior Court here last week to try to halt the patrols, said the small numbers mask a greater threat. The union officials argue in the lawsuit, which is supported by police unions in eight other towns and cities in Connecticut, that bringing in outside police service is illegal and is the first step in an effort to break the unions by subcontracting police protection. 
Some union officials also say sending for help is an insult to the department and sends a signal to residents that the local officers are not good enough.
 
'Undermines' Effectiveness
''The public perception is going to be that the Hartford police cannot do the job,'' said Stephen F. McEleney, a lawyer for the union. ''That undermines the Hartford police's effectiveness in the community.''
The debate over the plan has taken on political dimensions. For instance, the State Senate minority leader, Reginald J. Smith, a Republican who is running for governor, came out today in support of the police unions, urging that the plan be scrapped. He accused Gov. William A. O'Neill, a Democrat running for re-election, of using the police for ''political grandstanding.''
''This program insults Connecticut's finest,'' he said.
Hartford's Police Chief, Ronald J. Loranger, dismissed the objections to the plan as ''ridiculous.''
''It's just like an extra vitamin B shot, that's all,'' he said. ''We need it. We're just stemming the tide of narcotics in this city.''
Chief Loranger denied that any attempt was being made to break the union and said any damage to department morale or public perception would be caused by the union leaders' remarks, not by the additional officers.
''If they keep saying it, some people are going to start believing it,'' he said.
 
Two Reasons
State and local law-enforcement officials cited two reasons for sending in the state troopers. One is the large increase in drug crimes over the last few years in the state's largest cities. The other is the difficulty that many local police departments are having in recruiting officers in a state that has an unemployment rate of only 3.4 percent.
In 1985, the New Haven police made 573 narcotics arrests, but by 1988, the most recent year for which state figures are available, the number of arrests had increased to 2,365. In Hartford, total arrests increased between 1985 and 1988 from 13,656, to 22,290. Drug arrests rose from 2,360, to 3,241. A spokesman for the Hartford Police Department, Capt. Joe Croughwell, said keeping up with rising crime is only half the battle. Although the department has an authorized strength of 500 officers, it is barely able to keep up with attrition and has only 448 officers now, he said.
 
'Hurting for Officers'
''If you look at the problems we have filling existing vacancies, I really think citizens should be proud of the work we do,'' he said. ''We're hurting for officers.''
But Hartford police union officials said that they believed some vacancies were deliberate and that the department had delayed hiring new recruits to save money. ''If the state has additional money, give it to the municipalities and let them fill these holes,'' said Dennis M. O'Brien, the union president.
The state is paying the $250,000 cost of the trial program, which also began in New Haven last week and will start in Bridgeport soon. After 90 days, the cities and the state police will evaluate the program and determine whether it should be continued or expanded.
Union officials question how much the troopers can achieve in cities they may not know well. Although the 984-member state police force does some muncipal police work in towns too small to have their own police departments, much of the troopers' work is essentially highway patrol duty. Except for occasional undercover narcotics investigations, thet have no jurisdictions in any of the larger cities.
In both New Haven and Hartford, police officials said, the troopers are teamed one on one with regular officers familiar with the neighborhoods.
 
Effort Doubled
A New Haven police spokesman, Lieut. James V. Sorrentino, said the troopers there have all been assigned to a uniformed detail that until last week had only enough officers to cover one neighborhood at a time. The six additional officers doubled the effort, he said, to two neighborhoods at a time.
In Hartford, Chief Loranger said the troopers have been assigned to regular police patrols, working with officers who know the drug gangs and crime patterns in Frog Hollow. He said just getting more uniformed officers on the street - even if the uniforms are a little different - will make a difference in the crime rate.
But Mr. O'Brien of the police union said he believed that the troopers would be ineffective because of their lack of familiarity with the city. ''They don't know our streets and they don't know our criminals,'' he said.

HEADLINE: Supreme Court Says Strike By Lawyers Violated Law

BYLINE: By LINDA GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22

 BODY:
Rejecting free-speech arguments, the Supreme Court ruled today that a group of criminal defense lawyers here violated Federal antitrust law six years ago when the lawyers refused to accept more cases representing indigent defendants until the local government raised their pay.
The two-week strike by the Superior Court Trial Lawyers Association, a group of about 100 lawyers who represented most indigent criminal defendants in the District of Columbia's court system, received widespread publicity and accomplished its goal. The City Council voted to increase the lawyers' fees to $35 an hour, up from the $30 level that had been paid for nine years. 
The strike also attracted the attention of the Federal Trade Commission, which accused the organization and its officers of conspiring to fix prices and restrain trade.
Under the Sherman Antitrust Act, such a conspiracy is an automatic violation, regardless of motive or effect on the marketplace. The commission prohibited the lawyers' group from conducting another boycott.
The United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia overturned the commission, saying the strike was a form of political expression protected by the First Amendment.
The appeals court said that while the Constitution did not give the lawyers immunity under the antitrust laws, the usual rules of automatic liability could not apply. Instead, the appeals court said, the trade commission first had to prove that the lawyers' group had significant market power before it could find them guilty of illegal price-fixing.
Voting 6 to 3 today, the Supreme Court overturned that decision. The Court said the First Amendment elements of the lawyers' action did not entitle them to any special consideration under the antitrust laws.
Writing for the majority, Justice John Paul Stevens said that while ''reasonable lawyers may differ about the wisdom of this enforcement proceeding,'' nonetheless the ''social justifications'' for the lawyers' action ''do not make it any less unlawful.''
 
Creating a Gaping Hole
Justice Stevens said, ''Every concerted refusal to do business with a potential customer or supplier has an expressive component.'' He said a rule requiring special treatment for economic boycotts of that type ''would create a gaping hole in the fabric'' of the antitrust laws.
The majority opinion, Federal Trade Commission v. Superior Court Trial Lawyers, No. 88-1198, was joined by Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist and Justices Byron R. White, Sandra Day O'Connor, Antonin Scalia and Anthony M. Kennedy.
Justices William J. Brennan, Thurgood Marshall and Harry A. Blackmun, while joining portions of the majority opinion, dissented from the majority's conclusion that the First Amendment entitled the lawyers to no special treatment.
Justice Brennan said the majority decision was ''insensitive to the venerable tradition of expressive boycotts as an important means of political communication.''
 
A Central Role
Citing the American colonists' protests against the Stamp Act, as well as the civil rights boycott of the segregated buses in Montgomery, Ala., Justice Brennan said such actions ''have played a central role in our nation's political discourse.''
In his majority opinion, Justice Stevens noted that in 1982 the Court found that the First Amendment shielded black residents of Claiborne County, Miss., from liability for a boycott of white merchants.
He said the difference was that while the black citizens were seeking ''only the equal respect and equal treatment to which they were constituionally entitled,'' the lawyers were seeking economic advantage.
The decision was a substantial victory for the Federal Trade Commission. Lawyers' boycotts are very unusual, but the commission had been concerned that the appeals court's analysis might have for antitrust enforcement actions against doctors and other professionals.

HEADLINE: Dow Tumbles 77.45 to End at 2,600.45

BYLINE: By H. J. MAIDENBERG

 BODY:
The stock market yesterday posted its biggest loss since Oct. 13 as the Dow Jones industrial average plummeted 77.45 points, or 2.89 percent, to 2,600.45.
The Dow has not been below 2,600 since Nov. 7, three weeks after it plunged 190.58 points, or 6.91 percent, on Oct. 13.
But yesterday's selloff was marked by low volume as many individual investors left the field to index futures program traders. Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was 148.4 million, down from 185.6 million on Friday. Only 267 Big Board issues rose yesterday, compared with 1,336 that declined. The Big Board composite index fell 4.36 points, to 183.20. 
Analysts attributed much of the selling to the flow of poor fourth-quarter corporate profits, as well to the older lament that the Federal Reserve was keeping interest rates too high.
''The fact is simply that the market has finally gotten around to paying attention to fundamentals,'' said Hildegard M. Zagorski, a market analyst at Prudential-Bache Securities. ''While we think the selling was overdone, the fundamentals that provoked today's selloff included poor corporate profits, a toppy Tokyo stock market and, indeed, the belief that interest rates will remain high for sime time.''
Much action centered on program trading, involving the Standard & Poor's index of 500 blue chips and the spot March S.&P. 500 index futures.
At one time toward the close, the March futures were down 11.95, close to the 12-point limit that would have mandated a 15-minute halt in trading the contracts on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. But the March futures recovered to close down 10.80, at 331.50, avoiding the so-called circuit breaker mechanism.
Ms. Zagorski and other analysts were concerned that the spread between the March S.&P. 500 futures and the cash, or actual, index was abnormally close. The actual 500 index closed at 330.38, down 8.77 on the day.
Normally, futures should trade at a premium to the underlying instrument or commodity. How much of a premium depends on a number of factors, not the least of which is the remaining life of the contract futures. The spot S.&P. 500 futures will expire on March 16, when all that month's index futures and options and individual stock options expire in what is termed the ''triple witching hour.''
If the program traders and other arbitragers feel the futures are inexpensive relative to the cash market, they will buy the futures and sell the actual shares. Should the spread widen significantly in favor of the futures, they will do the reverse.
William M. LeFevre, a market strategist at Advest Inc., said the index futures changed little in the 15 minutes these contracts are traded after the close of the Big Board. ''You can be sure the program traders will be watching Tuesday morning to see whether the spread between the futures and cash indexes widens or narrows further,'' he said.
 
Japanese Market Up
Although the Tokyo Stock Exchange's 225-share Nikkei average closed up a strong 420.47 points, or 1.14 percent, at 37,257.01, fears grew that the Japanese equities market was wobbly and that any sustained decline there would influence sentiment in the market here.
Most individual investors, however,will continue to be more concerned with deteriorating corporate earnings, Mr. Lefevre said. ''What they see is more quality companies, such as Quaker Oats and Monsanto, reporting lower fourth-quarter profits and the prospects of still weaker earnings this quarter,'' Mr. Lefevre said.
Quaker Oats fell 2 points, to 51, and Monsanto lost 3 5/8, at 107 5/8. Among other blue chips, Du Pont fell 1 5/8, to 39 7/8. Some analysts said a 3-for-1 stock split of Du Pont, which is one of the 30 blue chips in the Dow, may have caused a bit more volatility in that average.
Among the most actively traded blue chips, Philip Morris fell 1 1/4, to 38, partly in response to a mounting campaign against smoking; A.T.& T. 1 5/8, to 40 1/2; General Electric 2, to 62 7/8; I.B.M. 2, to 96 5/8; Union Carbide 1 5/8, to 20 7/8, and Citicorp 7/8, at 24 5/8.
At the American Stock Exchange, the market-value index fell 5.20, to 360.88. In the over-the-counter market, the Nasdaq composite index plunged 8.94, to 431.94, its lowest level since last May 11, when it stood at 430.63.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Issues Are Down Again

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of most Treasury notes and bonds continued to slide in lethargic trading yesterday, as dealers focused on coming auctions of securities.
While the impending supply of new issues helped to push down prices of long-term issues, another big drop in equity prices had a steadying influence on short-term interest rates.
''The market is trading a little bit heavy again,'' one government bond trader said. ''With the Refcorp and two-year auctions this week, there is no buying, and no bonds are leaving the Street.'' 
This afternoon the Resolution Funding Corporation is expected to sell $40 billion of 40-year bonds. That auction will be followed tomorrow by the sale of $10 billion worth of two-year Treasury notes. And early next month dealers will be asked to bid on what could be as much as $30 billion of notes and bonds at the Treasury's quarterly refunding auctions.
 
No Japanese Influence
Unlike recent sessions, developments in the Japanese bond and equity markets had no influence on trading patterns once activity shifted to the United States.
''All of the ingredients for a good day were there,'' said William V. Sullivan Jr., a senior vice president at Dean Witter Reynolds. ''The Japanese bond market was stable, their stock market was better and the dollar improved. But nobody is moving off the sidelines to take down bonds at this juncture.''
Market participants also seemed to attach little significance to a decision by the Federal Reserve Board not to conduct open-market operations at a time when the overnight Federal funds rate was trading below the 8 1/4 percent level that is widely perceived by analysts as the Fed's target for the rate.
Funds were trading at around 8 3/ 16 percent at the time the Fed normally conducts open-market operations. The closely watched rate remained at that level for the remainder of the session.
Analysts at MMS International, an economic information service company, noted in their daily market commentary that the ''lack of intervention is a surprise, but is not policy-related,'' adding, ''The softness in the funds rate should only be temporary.''
The slightly lower funds rate did little to aid prices of short-term Treasury issues, even though those securities managed to outperform longer-term notes and bonds.
By late in the day, the 7 5/8 percent two-year notes were offered at a price of 99 3/32, up 1/32, to yield 8.13 percent.
At the Treasury's weekly auction of three- and six-month bills, three-month bills were sold at an average discount rate of 7.66 percent, down from an average rate of 7.68 percent at last week's sale. Six-month bills were sold at an average rate of 7.58 percent, up slightly from the average 7.54 percent rate on bills sold a week ago.
Among longer-term securities, the Treasury's 8 1/8 percent bonds of 2019 were offered at a price of 98 2/32 late yesterday, down 11/32, to yield 8.30 percent. And the 7 7/8 percent 10-year notes were offered at 97 14/32, down 6/32, to yield 8.25 percent.
 
Refcorp Yield at 8.50%
The Refcorp 40-year bonds to be sold today were offered on a when-issued basis late yesterday at a price to yield 8.50 percent. Dealers said that about half of the $5 billion issue had been pre-sold.
As the slump in Treasury prices entered its fifth week, dealers were not about to predict the yield levels it would take to spark buying interest. But some said that securities look attractive now.
''We recommend closing your eyes and buying securities at this point,'' said Mitchell Held, chief financial economist at Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company. Mr. Held added, however, that conditions might not improve until next month.
''You have to get beyond the fears of new supply in the refunding as well as the January producer price and consumer price numbers'' before market participants will feel more confident, he said. ''It's more a function of time than of price level.''
Activity in the secondary market for investment-grade corporate bonds was very sluggish, traders said. Prices of most issues were unchanged to down 1/8 of a point.
In the secondary market for tax-exempt municipal bonds, prices of most issues slipped by 1/8 of a point in thin trading.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Mark Selling Raises Dollar Despite a Plunge in Stocks

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar rose against most currencies yesterday, despite a steep slide in stock prices on Wall Street that would make dollar-denominated investments less attractive.
Gold prices ended lower. In New York, gold for current delivery fell by $2.80 an ounce, to $407.20, on the Commodity Exchange. The Republic National Bank of New York later quoted an ounce of gold at $408.20, down by $1.80 from late on Friday. 
The dollar benefited from sales of West German marks. Currency dealers sold marks as they weighed the implications of fighting in Azerbaijan in the Soviet Union and the rumors of unrest in Eastern Europe, said John McCarthy, the chief dealer at the New York office of the Amsterdam Rotterdam Bank.
But the dollar rally met resistance amid speculation about possible central bank intervention to curb the advance, he said.
Enthusiasm to buy dollars was also tempered in the afternoon as the stock market piled up losses.
''I'm quite surprised the dollar isn't lower, given that the stock market is down a ton,'' Mr. McCarthy said.
 
Average Falls 77.45
The Dow Jones industrial average fell by 77.45 points, to 2,600.45. The decline was the Dow's largest one-day point loss since it fell by 190.58 points on Oct. 13.
But a belief that the Federal Reserve Board is unlikely to ease its monetary policy, which the traders said contributed to Wall Street's selloff, fortified the dollar.
In late trading in New York, the dollar was quoted at 146.51 yen, up from 145.93 yen late on Friday. Against the West Germany currency, the dollar rose to 1.7242 marks, from 1.7105.
In London, the British pound fell to $1.6385, from $1.6475 late on Friday. In later New York trading, a pound cost $1.6370, compared with $1.6470 late on Friday.
Of the major currencies, only the Canadian dollar strengthed yesterday against the American dollar.
Other late-dollar rates late yesterday, compared those of late Friday, included: 1.5350 Swiss francs, up from 1.5205; 5.859 French francs, up from 5.8130; 1.18015 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1836, and 1,283.00 Italian lire, up from 1,274.12.
Gold prices eased while silver finished mixed. The late bid for gold in London was $405.25 an ounce, down from $410.25 late Friday, while silver for January delivery rose to $5.268 an ounce on the Commodity Exchange in New York.

HEADLINE: Patterns

BYLINE: By LEONARD SLOANE

 BODY:

Attention-Getter
It was good news, bad news at last week's annual meeting of the National Retail Merchants Association here. The good news was that the event finally grabbed the attention the organizers have always insisted it deserved. The bad news was why: on Monday the Campeau Corporation announced that the off-again, on-again bankruptcy filing of its Federated and Allied unitswas definitely on. 
Reporters flocked to interview such industry leaders as Harold E. Sells, the chairman of the Woolworth Corporation, or John M. Belk, the chairman of Belk Stores. But the questions were about Campeau, not about fashion trends.
Throughout a week that in the past has been devoted to glad-handing and cheerleading, ominous words were heard from the speakers' platform. Rosalind Wells, the association's chief economist, pointed out that population and new household growth will slow during the 90's. The result: ''Yearly gains in consumer purchases of department store merchandise will be lower than in past decades.''
The word from William R. Howell, chairman of the J. C. Penney Company, who was elected chairman of the association Wednesday, was worse: ''Today it is accepted that the general merchandiser is a dinosaur,'' he said at the opening session.
 
Service Bandwagon
Most of the retailers were from independent smaller stores rather than the giant chains. In the corridors, lobbies and dining rooms of the New York Hilton and the Sheraton Centre, when they weren't trading titillating Campeau gossip they commiserated about the industry's shared obsession: customer service.
''Everyone is trying to get on the service bandwagon right now,'' said Carmen Monaco, the vice president of Miller's Outpost, a chain of 300 apparel stores based in Ontario, Calif.
''I don't think anybody can get by without price competition,'' remarked Jeff Dahl, co-owner of the Dahl House, a group of 23 women's specialty stores with headquarters in Northfield, Minn. ''But customers shop in stores because they want to shop there. And the stores that do well year in and year out give customer service.''
Once again, electronic point-of-sales equipment and systems were billed as the panacea.
''When we installed POS equipment, it was good for the customer,'' said Allan Dukelsky of the 40-store Strawberry women's apparel chain. ''If we see merchandise that's not selling, we can mark it down and make it more attractive. And the more merchandise we have that is selling enables us to sell everything at cheaper prices.''
Electronics dominated the exibition spaces in both hotels; about half of the 300 exhibitors, a record number for the trade show, set up displays in this category. A retailer browsing through the four floors of exhibits could test out software for inventory control or customer profiling, bar code scanners, security systems and an array of personal computers.
Gone were many of the packaging booths. The hanger and garment bag manufacturers were banished far from the high-tech exhibitors.
 
A Merging of Identities
In any event, this 79th convention was the last for the National Retail Merchants Association.
During the week, the association and the American Retail Federation, another trade group based in Washington, voted to merge. The directors decided not to support two separate organizations with overlapping functions and individual overhead and staff.
So next January the seminars, speeches and trade show may be familiar, but they will be under the auspices of the National Retail Federation, the combination's new name.
