HEADLINE: Electronic Teacher: A Mississippi Experiment

BYLINE: By SUSAN CHIRA, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JACKSON, Miss, Jan. 19

 BODY:
Mississippi, where one of every three adults is functionally illiterate, is embarking on an ambitious experiment in electronic education: put an I.B.M. computer program in every kindergarten and first grade, and try to have every child reading and writing by the end of the first grade.
The experiment, the first effort to use one computer program throughout a state, is backed by two millionaires who put up money on the condition that the state buy computers from the International Business Machines Corporation and use an I.B.M. program called Writing to Read.
While Mississippi is overjoyed with the initial results, some educators say the arrangement raises questions about the economic and political forces at work in efforts to improve the educational system, the proper role of technology in education and the power of business leaders to impose their solutions on schools.
 
A $7 Million Contribution
Part of the money is coming from Richard Riordan, a California philanthropist who had given the same I.B.M. equipment and software to school districts elsewhere and was sold on the results. When an I.B.M. executive suggested that he donate computer programs to an entire state, Mr. Riordan turned to Mississippi and found a partner to share the cost. He and his partner, Richard Dowling, a New York City businessman, contributed a total of $7 million for a five-year program. The state agreed to put up $6 million. 
The gift was seen as manna from heaven by Mississippi, which trails most other states in education spending per pupil, teacher salaries and per capita income. For I.B.M., the gift was a business and publicity windfall. And for educators and computer specialists, it offered an intriguing case study: Are computers the best way to tackle illiteracy? Is I.B.M.'s phonetics-based approach, which teaches reading by sounding out words, the right one? Is it better to use one I.B.M. program statewide or to offer a range of other computer education programs?
Many Mississippians, from Gov. Ray Mabus to teachers and students, rave about the program. So far, 72 computer centers out of a total of 523 have been installed.
 
'They Know More Words'
''They are definitely further along this year,'' said Dorothy Jenkins, a kindergarten teacher at Boyd Elementary School in Jackson. ''They know more words. We've not had children at this stage writing stories before. I believe we're going to see a lot of improvement in this state.''
Advocates of electronic education say computers are infinitely patient, and they can tailor programs to the needs of each student. But educators say computers are no substitute for good teachers or group learning in a classroom.
''The problem with computers in education is that people expect the same kind of wonders that they see in other areas, like medical research,'' said Dr. M. D. Roblyer, author of a book evaluating research on computer-based teaching. ''If they're expecting miracles in Mississippi, they're going to have to try harder.''
 
A Question of Choice
Others question whether a businessman's vision was being imposed on the state because he had the means to make a gift with strings attached.
''It's too bad the teachers in Mississippi weren't given a choice,'' said LeRoy Finkel, coordinator of instructional technology in the San Mateo County Office of Education in California. ''What's just been said to Mississippi is there's only one way to do it.''
Schools may refuse the computers if they wish, but none have so far.
Governor Mabus and Dr. Tom Saterfiel, the interim State Superintendent of Education, said that they did not consider the Writing to Read program the only way to teach and that it was only part of broader educational changes being planned in Mississippi.
''We need to do something dramatic, and this is dramatic,'' the Governor said. ''But it's not the only thing we need to do. If something doesn't click in Writing to Read, you've got to catch them with another teacher, or more time in school.''
 
A Vast Potential Market
Computer education represents a vast potential market. In the 1987-88 academic year, elementary and high schools spent a total of $210 million on educational software, said Natasha Thomsen, an analyst at LINK Resources. She estimated that by the end of 1988 schools had installed 2.5 million computers.
The I.B.M. program is based on the idea that children come to school knowing many more words than they can read or write, and many more than most textbooks teach them in the early grades. By teaching children 42 ''phonemes,'' or letter-sound combinations, and encouraging them to spell words any way they hear them, the program seeks to have children write down words they can say and read what they write. In one-hour daily sessions, children rotate through a series of computers and learning stations.
At the Boyd School in Jackson the other day, Daisy Carter, a kindergarten pupil, put on a headset and began to study her words and sounds for that day. She saw the letters ''VAS'' flash on the computer screen, along with a picture of a vase and its proper spelling. As she heard a voice on the computer say each sound, she repeated it, typed it on the keyboard and then typed the whole word.
Next she moved to a low table, pressed a tape recorder and reviewed the computer lesson in a different way: a taped voice spoke the sounds and letters, and she wrote them down with a pencil in her workbook.
When she finished writing, Daisy walked to another row of computers, where she could write stories on any topic she pleased. After about 15 minutes she shifted again, moving to a ''listening library'' where she heard a tape recording of a book. She ended the session by making words with alphabet tiles.
The children move through the program at their own pace, staying with one set of words until they master it. To encourage the pupils to write without fear of corrections, teachers are told not to correct their unconventional spelling.
 
A Story About Turtles
Sabre Razeyeh, a kindergarten student at Boyd, hunched over the computer, typing intently. ''Wuns epone tim ther woor thre tutith,'' she wrote, beginning her story about three turtles in fairy tale fashion.
Her classmate, Jeffrey Schelver, thanked a college student for writing a poem about the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. ''Tu store wus grat,'' he typed. ''Thk yuw for rotn tu store to doctr mortn luth kig.''
Mississippi teachers say computers offer children something teachers cannot always provide.
''It reaches all learning styles,'' said Vicki Moore, a first-grade teacher at the West Lauderdale Regional Attendance Center, a rural school in Collinsville, near the Alabama border. ''If somebody learns better by hearing or touching or seeing, they can.''
The results have convinced many teachers and administrators, who concede that they began the school year worried that the program would cut into valuable classroom time.
 
Praise From a Principal
''I felt it was another gimmick,'' said Marvin S. Richardson, principal of the elementary school in Collinsville. ''I have made a complete change. This program is the best supplementary project I've been involved with, but nothing takes the place of a good teacher.''
There are some problems. While children like Sabre and Jeffrey write on the computer, some of their classmates merely play with the keys or write the letters of the alphabet over and over. Some children had a hard time at first understanding the Northern accent of the recorded computer voice. One teacher in Collinsville said several of her students at first thought the voice was saying ''take'' instead of ''type.''
Governor Mabus says he considers Writing to Read just one approach among many. The Governor, a longtime backer of educational change, has called for a $500 million commitment for further improvements. A week ago, however, the State Senate voted down an important source of money for the improvements: a proposed state lottery.
Much of the reaction to I.B.M.'s program depends on how people see the role of the computer in education.
''The most efficient way to do things is computers,'' said Mr. Riordan, a lawyer, investment banker and restaurateur who established the Riordan Foundation in 1969 to fight illiteracy.
 
'You Go In and Make Changes'
''The main thing is, whatever was being done before wasn't working,'' he said. ''If you have a sick company you go in and make changes. If you don't make any changes, it will go under and go bankrupt.''
Many specialists, including Idit Harel of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology's Media Laboratory, and Tom Snyder, a publisher of educational software, say children learn better when they make decisions on a computer and when they can work in groups.
For example, Ms. Harel has worked on a project that encourages children to learn about fractions by writing a computer program that introduces fractions to younger children. Mr. Snyder's software allows a teacher to divide the class into small groups, each at a computer terminal, and take a computer-simulated voyage around the world.
By contrast, the I.B.M. program presents a prescribed course, one that company officials say is necessary to make sure children learn certain concepts.
 
Faster Reading Progress Found
Several studies, including one conducted for I.B.M. by the Educational Testing Service, found that kindergarten and first-grade students who used the Writing to Read program progressed faster than the national norm on standardized reading tests.
Other educators remain unconvinced. They fault Writing to Read for its emphasis on phonics - learning to read by sounding out words - rather than learning phrases and words as a whole, as children do when they learn to speak.
''This forces students to work contrary to the way they learn language,'' said Daniel Hittleman, an associate professor at Queens College and former president of the New York State Reading Association. ''You will probably see dramatic short-term gains, but the question will be whether these are true gains, whether the results couldn't have been achieved more efficiently and effectively through some other means.''
Educators say the true test of the Mississippi experiment will come years from now: whether students do learn to read and write better, and whether the program endures or goes the way of other educational trends.

HEADLINE: WHITE HOUSE ASKS AN IRATE CONGRESS FOR CHINA SUPPORT

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23

 BODY:
The Bush Administration pressed returning members of Congress today to support the President's handling of relations with China, but the effort was greeted by a storm of opposition from both Democrats and Republicans.
The Administration's initiative was prompted by a pending vote in Congress over whether to override the President's Nov. 30 veto of a bill that would allow the 40,000 Chinese students in the United States to remain in the country after their visas expire.
Both houses of Congress overwhelmingly passed the legislation last year in response to Beijing's violent crackdown in June on democracy demonstrators, many of them students.
 
Loss of Congressional Confidence
While the matter at hand was Mr. Bush's veto, which he explained in part by saying that he could accomplish the bill's goals through administrative action, the real issue today was broader: Congress's apparent loss of confidence in President Bush's handling of relations with China and the Administration's attempt to win that confidence back before it loses control of the policy to legislators. 
''Republicans as well as Democrats are going to vote in the House to override the President's veto,'' Representative Mickey Edwards, Republican of Oklahoma, said at a ceremony with Chinese students outside the House today. ''The President has simply made a mistake, but the American Congress and the American people stand very strongly with those people in China who want to get those same rights of democracy and liberty that mean so much to us.''
The pending vote to override the veto has also taken on significance as an expression of Congressional sentiment after recent Administration gestures toward Beijing. These included a resumption of high-level contacts suspended after the crackdown and the lifting of some economic sanctions.
 
House Vote Imminent
A vote is expected on Wednesday in the House and Thursday in the Senate.
The White House Chief of Staff, John H. Sununu, and Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d met with Republican senators on Capitol Hill, while Mr. Bush telephoned others in an effort to secure the 34 votes needed to block the two-thirds majority required for an override in the Senate. Administration officials have all but conceded that the veto will be easily overridden in the House, where the original bill passed, 403 to 0, in November. The Senate adopted the bill without a recorded vote.
Senators and members of Congress from both parties seemed to return from their holiday vacation angry over the Administration's recent gestures toward Beijing. Some of the most controversial were revealed while they were on recess, including two trips to Beijing by the national security adviser, Brent Scowcroft, and Deputy Secretary of State Lawrence S. Eagleburger, and the lifting of several economic sanctions without any significant human rights concessions by the Chinese authorities.
The Administration said such high-level contacts were essential with a country as important as China, and pointed to Beijing's lifting of martial law on Jan. 10 as a vindication of its overtures. Many members of Congress sharply disagreed, saying that the lifting of martial law was an empty gesture.
 
A Beijing Facsimile
This morning, a group of leading Democrats and Republicans made it their first order of business to join with the Chinese students in dedicating outside the House of Representatives a plaster model of the Goddess of Freedom, similar to the one erected in Tiananmen Square in Beijing. At the ceremony, the Senate Democratic leader, George Mitchell of Maine, denounced the Administration for engaging ''in embarrassing kowtowing to an aging Chinese Communist leadership.''
The ceremony was followed by a special hearing of the Senate Judiciary subcommittee on immigration and refugee affairs, headed by Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts. The hearing was entirely devoted to policy toward China.
''The secret White House missions to China,'' Mr. Kennedy said, ''have dealt a serious blow to the confidence of Congress in the Administration's China policy, and to the confidence of the Chinese students that the Administration has their best interests at heart.''
Borrowing a remark frequently made by President Reagan in his dealings with the Soviet Union, Mr. Kennedy said: ''President Bush says, 'Trust me.' We say, 'Trust but verify.' ''
Technically, the debate between Congress and the Administration is focused on the President's veto of the Chinese Emergency Immigration Act, a bill passed with broad bipartisan support that would give Chinese students now studying in this country four more years to apply for new visas, or for permanent residence, while also waiving the requirement that they first return to China.
In an effort to provide the same safeguards without passing a law that would offend the Chinese authorities, the President accompanied his veto with an administrative directive to the Immigration and Naturalization Service that offers Chinese in the United States - students and non-students alike - much the same protection. The Administration argued that if the Congress overrides the President's veto, Beijing will choke off all student exchanges with the United States. Constitutional Infringement? The White House has also contended that such a law would be an infringement on the President's right to make foreign policy and only lead to a further isolation of China from the United States.
Supporters of the bill, which was initially put forward by Representative Nancy Pelosi, Democrat of California, have argued that legislation is necessary because the President's administrative order could be withdrawn at any time, because it might be challenged in court as illegal, and, most important, because it sent too mild a signal to Beijing.
Testifying at Senator Kennedy's hearing, Winston Lord, who served as Ambassador to China during the Reagan Addministration, said: ''Fairly or unfairly, the vote on this issue will be interpreted abroad and at home not just as a decision on how best to protect Chinese students in America, but more fundamentally as a referendum on our posture toward the current Chinese regime.''
After a lunch with Republican Senators, Mr. Baker said it was too early to predict whether the Administration would be able to stop an overriding of the veto.
 
Baker's Argument
''We're making the point,'' Mr. Baker said, ''that the President has done as much, or more, administratively as you get through the legislation. We're pointing out that things are at a very sensitive stage over there and what could happen if you override the President's veto is get a reaction over there that would, in effect, close off student exchanges.''
Nevertheless, Alan K. Simpson of Wyoming, the Senate minority whip, predicted that a veto override ''will pass like a dose of salts.''
''There won't be five of us who will vote'' for the President, he said.
Aides to the Senate minority leader, Robert Dole of Kansas, said he told Mr. Baker that he would tally the votes he can muster. If it appears that he is close to 34, Mr. Dole is expected to try to enlist everyone from past Presidents to China experts in an attempt to block an override. If the number is too small, Senator Dole is not expected to ''waste any time'' on the matter, aides said.

HEADLINE: Rome Journal;
Campuses Aflame Again: Just Tools of Industry?

BYLINE: By CLYDE HABERMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ROME, Jan. 23

 BODY:
From Palermo to Turin, and on more than a dozen campuses in between, Italian universities are being rocked by student protests that had all but disappeared in the passive, self-absorbed 1980's.
The principal issue is the quality of academic life, or, more commonly, the lack of it in a system that is universally denounced as obsolete, overcrowded, inefficient and at times dehumanizing.
Over the last few weeks thousands of students have demonstrated in at least 17 cities, forcing the wholesale cancellation of classes in many departments.
At La Sapienza, the main campus of the University of Rome, protesters have occupied eight buildings, denouncing the Government and demanding the ouster of the university rector. Reflecting the high-technology age in which these students were born, their symbol is not the bullhorn of earlier generations but rather the fax machine, which they use to follow developments elsewhere. 
 
Looking Back at '68
Perhaps inevitably, the Italian press has alluded frequently to 1968, that landmark year of ferment, when campuses exploded in Italy as elsewhere. But students resent the comparisons as glib attempts to trivialize their grievances as imitations of past activism.
Their immediate target is a proposed law, endorsed by the governing five-party coalition, which would give individual campuses more autonomy to set course requirements than they now have under a highly centralized system. They would also be able to sign research contracts and start other joint projects with private companies.
In theory, the changes would nudge Italy's 50 universities and 1.1 million students closer toward the United States model of privately run colleges. They amount to a Government acknowledgment that it has totally failed to correct decades-old inefficiencies.
''I don't believe that anyone can deny that the Italian university system needs reform,'' said Antonio Ruberti, the Government minister in charge of colleges and the architect of the new law.
 
What the Students Fear
On that score, no one disagrees. But students say they worry that big corporations may be given a free hand to reshape the country's schools to fit their own needs.
While the sciences and engineering are likely to get adequate financing, they argue, the liberal arts will fall by the wayside. Laboratory researchers, who joined the protests this week, fret that they will lose their independence and become tools of industry. Large companies, it is also argued, are more likely to invest in the well-developed Italian north, further widening the considerable gap with the relatively poor south. Not coincidentally, the campus protests first erupted in Palermo, where the unemployment rate is over 20 percent, three times that in Turin.
''Students don't count for anything now,'' said Francesco Bucci, a 22-year-old physics major at La Sapienza. ''They'll count for even less, if that's possible, in the hands of industry.''
Although the University of Rome rector, Giorgio Tecce, calls such concerns overwrought, Italian skepticism about industry's good intentions runs high, not only among students.
 
Dissatisfaction Is Widespread
Objections to the Ruberti plan reflect widespread cynicism about the concentration of economic and political power in the hands of a few industrialist titans like Giovanni Agnelli of Fiat, Carlo De Benedetti of Olivetti, Raul Gardini of the Ferruzzi-Montedison agrobusiness group, and Silvio Berlusconi, a television magnate. A recurring student theme dwells on perceived slights of their cause by the leading national newspapers, most of which are controlled by these men.
In their protest the students are supported by the dominant opposition force, the Communist Party, and judging from their slogans, most demonstrators seem to fall on the political left. But such characterizations are not especially meaningful, for dissatisfaction with Italian universities goes deep and cuts across political lines.
The basic issue is not the Ruberti plan so much as the system itself, which is little changed from 1968 or from 1977 - another milestone year of protest, when, unlike now, violence was epidemic. The litany of complaints is long, tending to focus on shabby equipment and overcrowding.
La Sapienza, Italy's largest campus, has 180,000 students, or 100,000 more than it should, Mr. Tecce said. If not for the fact that fewer than 30 percent show up for classes, the rector said, ''this place would look like a soccer stadium.'' Even so, an engineering major here says he must arrive an hour early for one of his courses to get a seat in the lecture hall. The University of Bologna's law department has only 40 teachers for 10,000 students.
 
Most Students Drop Out
At most colleges, libraries stay open only a few hours a day. Campus housing is meager, forcing most out-of-town students into apartments that are undersized and overpriced. A common lament is that professors are aloof.
One result is that most students give up, with two-thirds dropping out in the first two years. And as they do, Italians worry that the country will wind up academically ill equipped for Western Europe's economic integration in 1992.
''We will enter Europe,'' wrote Miriam Mafai, a commentator for the newspaper La Repubblica, ''with a backward scholastic system, like haughty ragamuffins, fatuously proud of the past but incapable of preparing for the future.''
That is why immediate change is critical, says Mr. Ruberti, who complains that protesting students, while well intentioned, overlook the need for quick action. The Government, he says, is prepared to modify his plan, but the basic framework will remain intact.
''No one is proposing alternatives to this law,'' he said. ''Sometimes, it seems as though there is no will among the students to reform.''

HEADLINE: Shamir and Sharon in Bitter Fight to Run Israel

BYLINE: By JOEL BRINKLEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, Jan. 23

 BODY:
Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir and his chief Likud party rival, Ariel Sharon, are deep into a bitter political war two weeks before a party meeting at which the future leadership of the nation, and the future of the Government's moribund peace initiative, may well be decided.
The party meeting, similar to one last summer, is an open contest of political strength between Mr. Shamir and Mr. Sharon. And on Monday Mr. Shamir warned, ''It is very clear that if the Likud Central Committee won't support me, I cannot remain the leader of the Likud or the Prime Minister.''
It is not clear how the voting at the party meeting Feb. 7 will be framed. But whatever the actual question put before the delegates, the real decision will be whether the Likud party wants Mr. Shamir or Mr. Sharon as its leader. The vote is likely to be close. Mr. Sharon and his allies disparaged the Prime Minister's resignation threat today. Mr. Sharon told supporters in Beersheba, where he was campaigning, that Mr. Shamir should abandon his proposal for Palestinian elections ''that would in fact bring about a Palestinian state, bloodshed and war.'' 
 
An Open Challenge
Many Israelis, Palestinians and Americans have already come to the view that the election plan is not likely to be carried out in any case, because of intransigence on the part of both Mr. Shamir and of leading Arabs.
But although the proposal is moribund, Mr. Sharon wants to see it dead. While he is a rival of Mr. Shamir's for power, he says the frequent charge that he is attacking Mr. Shamir's plan only for his own political gain is ''lies and utter nonsense.''
Mr. Sharon openly challenged Mr. Shamir over the elections proposal at a party meeting last summer. Before that meeting, too, Mr. Shamir threatened to resign if the party did not support him. Then, as now, the threat was in part a tactical inducement for support: If Mr. Shamir resigns, the Government will fall and there would be a chance that the Labor Party would take over control of the Government.
In the last few weeks, the Labor Party leader, Shimon Peres, has been actively trying to work out agreements with several smaller political parties to form a narrow coalition should the Labor-Likud Government fall.
 
Attacked at Every Turn
At the meeting last summer, Mr. Shamir compromised at the last minute - just as the Central Committee meeting was set to begin - and accepted several binding constraints on the elections proposal pushed on him by Mr. Sharon and his two allies, Housing Minister David Levy and Economics-Planning Minister Yitzhak Modai.
Since then, the three who offered the proposal have attacked Mr. Shamir at every turn, accusing him of betraying the right-wing promise to exclude the Palestine Liberation Organization from any role in peace negotiations. The United States Government, meanwhile, has repeatedly indicated that it did not think Mr. Shamir was being flexible enough.
And in the end the unrelenting pressure from both sides prompted Mr. Shamir to call for a party meeting to meet his political rivals head on.
Getting ready for that meeting, he addressed a group of Likud party members last week and, apparently trying to flaunt his right-wing credentials, told them he believed Israel should hold onto the West Bank and Gaza because the land would be needed to settle some of the Soviet Jews emigrating to Israel.
Predictably, that brought a protest from the United States, even though Mr. Shamir contended that he had been misunderstood. And today President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt, taking an unusual threatening tone, said Egypt would never accept it if Israel began settling Soviet immigrants on what he called ''Arab land.''
Mr. Sharon and Mr. Shamir are holding rallies around the country as the party meeting draws near. At his rally today, Mr. Sharon called Mr. Shamir's elections plan ''the greatest concession of Israel to the Arabs without anything any return.''

HEADLINE: Upheaval in the East: U.S. Policy;
Congress Starts Review Of U.S. Military Posture

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23

 BODY:
The Bush Administration and Congress began work today on what is likely to be a basic reshaping of American military strategy and spending in the wake of political and social upheavals in the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe.
Returning after a two-month recess during which the Rumanian Government was overthrown and new domestic turmoil erupted in the Soviet Union, the Senate Armed Services Committee opened hearings that its Democratic chairman said will question ''fundamental assumptions'' of Pentagon military and budget policies for the 1990's.
''We've seen the threat change on TV every night,'' said the chairman, Senator Sam Nunn of Georgia. ''We'll be looking at this changed threat as the foundation on which we build the budget which we will be asking the American people to pay for.'' 
Mr. Nunn, the leading Democratic expert on defense matters and a major force in setting the course of Pentagon spending, is expected to shape his party's response to the Bush Administration's proposed military budget for the 1991 fiscal year, which begins Oct. 1.
Defense Department officials already have said that they will propose cuts in military spending for fiscal 1991 of about 2 percent, after inflation is taken into account, because of the reduced threat of war with the Soviet Union.
 
Tallying the 'Peace Dividend'
Today, Mr. Nunn said those reductions could produce savings - a so-called ''peace dividend'' - of $8 billion to $15 billion in the next fiscal year. While substantial, the number is well below the estimated $60 billion that Congress must cut from the budget if it is to achieve spending targets set by the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings deficit reduction law, he noted.
Mr. Nunn said it will not be clear how spending cuts might be achieved until the month of hearings begun today produce a new ''threat assessment'' of the military perils facing the United States.
The ranking Republican on the Armed Services panel, Senator John Warner of Virginia said this afternoon, after the session, that he ''didn't hear any testimony today which would justify drastic revisions in the armed forces of the United States.''
While the Soviet Union's intentions appear to have changed, he said, ''we must wait a period of time in order to allow the arms control process to go forward, to allow the threat assessment to be predicated on solid facts of change rather than intentions.''
 
Changing Military Priorities
The public portion of today's hearings, which consisted of prepared statements from three senior intelligence officials, indicated that the Bush Administration may seek to shift some of the military's emphasis from conflict between the superpowers to other arenas, such as terrorism and other third world threats.
But they stressed that technological advances will make the Soviet Union's nuclear arsenal more advanced and powerful than ever in the next decade, even after reductions in the number of missiles and warheads that are contemplated as a result of arms control agreements still to be reached.
The first witness, William H. Webster, the Director of Central Intelligence, told the panel that the Soviet Union's political and conventional force threat to the United States and Western Europe is likely to ebb in this decade as its leaders struggle with the nation's ''mounting turmoil and economic distress.''
Mr. Webster told the committee that Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet President, ''and any successors will have an even more pressing need than in the past few years to reduce the burden of defense spending and to transfer resources to civilian production.''
 
Soviet Control in Bloc Fades
Two other Defense Department intelligence officials who appeared with Mr. Webster predicted that Moscow will continue to reduce its military presence gradually in the nations of Eastern Europe, and said some of those nations already are making military decisions independent of the Soviets.
The Warsaw Pact military alliance is likely to change radically, or even disappear, as a result of the past year's political upheavals, they said.
The head of the Defense Intelligence Agency, Lieut. Gen. Harry E. Soyster, said the disintegration of Eastern Europe's Communist bloc means the Soviet Union no longer can expect the automatic support of its old satellites' military forces in a conflict with the NATO alliance.
''In light of these developments,'' he said, ''I believe the Soviets would consider large-scale theater operations against NATO with only their own forces as highly risky, if not impractical.''
Both General Soyster and Mr. Webster said the Soviet Union has also reduced its military commitments in the Far East, potentially reducing the requirement for an American military presence there.
But Mr. Webster warned, as he has often in the last year, about the rising potential for chemical, biological and nuclear warfare among developing nations such as Iran, Iraq, Libya and Pakistan.
Increasingly Sophisticated Missiles Roughly 15 third world nations are developing missiles capable of delivering chemical, biological or nuclear warheads, Mr. Webster said in a March 1989 speech. While most of those missiles have a range of less than 625 miles, he predicted today that by the end of the decade at least six nations will have missiles with ranges exceeding 3,100 miles.
Four of the nations developing missiles already have or are close to acquiring nuclear weapons capabilities, he said. ''By the end of the decade,'' he said, ''four more countries could be added to the nuclear list.''
Mr. Webster's remarks went beyond what has previously been publicly disclosed about the nuclear and missile capabilities of third world nations. After meeting today with Mr. Webster and other intelligence leaders behind closed doors, Mr. Nunn and other members of the Armed Services Committee said they found the new estimates disturbing.
Mr. Nunn said the spread of long-range missiles and nuclear weapons among developing countries is causing ''a great deal of concern'' that the Soviet Union also shares.
Senator Warner said the issue of third-world missiles ''is a factor that must be considered as we re-examine our military aid programs.''

HEADLINE: Colombia Envoy Angry About U.S. Trade Policy

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23

 BODY:
Recent Bush Administration trade decisions are squeezing Colombia's earnings and making its war against cocaine trafficking more difficult, the country's Ambassador, Victor Mosquera Chaux, said today.
Three weeks before President Bush is to meet the Colombian President, Virgilio Barco Vargas, and other Andean leaders at a summit conference on drugs in Cartagena, Colombia, Mr. Mosquera held a news conference here to criticize American actions affecting Colombia's top legal exports: cut flowers and coffee.
He said the Administration's policies could cut Colombia's foreign earnings by hundreds of millions of dollars a year at a time when his country has had to ''earmark a good portion of national resources for that heroic fight'' against drug trafficking, ''which Colombia is waging on behalf of the whole of mankind.''
Mr. Mosquera said a move to impose a Federal import surcharge on Colombian flowers, after a finding that Colombia was ''dumping'' them in the United States at below fair market value, could put a serious dent in the country's $200 million-a-year trade in cut flowers. He also said that a decision by the United States to pull out of negotiations on a new coffee agreement, causing prices to plummet, will cost Colombia $500 million a year. 
 
Flowers Are Widely Distributed
The freshly cut flowers, airfreighted daily from Bogota in air-conditioned Boeing 747's, are sold in 35,000 American florist shops and 10,000 supermarkets.
A preliminary decision by the Commerce Department on Jan. 5 could mean that the surcharge, imposed retroactively on importers, would rise by 50 percent to $8 million, weakening the competitiveness of Colombian flowers. The decision, which could be overturned when the department makes a final determination in April, is based on an earlier finding that Colombia's dumping was harming domestic growers.
The breakdown in the International Coffee Agreement, signed by 74 producing and consuming countries to regulate coffee prices by controlling the quantity of exports, resulted from demands by the United States. Washington wanted greater imports of higher-quality coffees and elimination of discounting that it said was hurting American companies.
Its decision not to continue to negotiate caused a sharp drop in international coffee prices.
 
Coffee Price Drops by a Third
The agreement, which has maintained order in the world market for the past 27 years, aimed at supporting a base price for coffee beans of $1.20 a pound. After suspension of the quotas, the world price toppled to 85 cents, and remains around these levels today, coffee experts said.
Academic experts see the apparent contradictions of trying to help Colombia fight a drug war on the one hand and then penalizing it with trade actions on the other as the result of the fiercely competing tugs of domestic American interests.
''Obviously it doesn't sound like a very coordinated policy,'' said James R. Tybout, an economics professor and Latin American expert at Georgetown University. ''Since we're so driven by domestic lobbies, it's not surprising that our policy actions are not in concert.''
Administration officials insisted that the United States is in fact offering important trade assistance to Colombia, or as United States Trade Representative Carla A. Hills put it, ''trying to be a constructive force in many areas.''
 
Colombian Sugar Quota Raised
In coffee, she noted, American negotiators, under instructions from President Bush, are currently working with other nations to repair the agreement.
''There's nothing the United States can do on the coffee agreement without the big producers like Brazil and Colombia getting closer together,'' she said, adding that one of the problems is that Brazil, the world's biggest coffee producer, is between governments.
Mrs. Hills noted that as part of a reallocation, the United States recently increased Colombia's sugar quota.
On Colombia's complaints in the cut-flowers trade case, Eric I. Garfinkel, Assistant Secretary of Commerce for Import Administration, said the department is constrained by the anti-dumping law and judicial review provisions, which mandate that decisions be based on facts and supported by the record.
''If the department were to tilt its decisions because of foreign-policy considerations,'' he said, ''then the integrity of anti-dumping enforcement would be undermined.''

HEADLINE: Washington Talk;
'Umbrella' on Abortion Delays G.O.P. Decision

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23

 BODY:
Republicans have grown adept at pursuing two-track strategies, with the White House sending one message and party leaders another.
Democrats complained throughout 1989 that the Republicans were playing a sophisticated game of good cop, bad cop, with President Bush extending the hand of bipartisanship to Congressional Democrats, seeking deals on the budget and Central America, while his lieutenants pursued an unrelenting partisan war.
Now another multi-track strategy has emerged, around the issue of abortion: The President reiterates his opposition to abortion rights, easing the fears of the party's fervently anti-abortion wing, while other Republican leaders emphasize the party's tolerance of differing views. Consider Monday, the anniversary of the 1973 Supreme Court decision legalizing abortion, when tens of thousands of protesters descended on the city. 
Mr. Bush, following precedent set in the Reagan years, delivered a message to the anti-abortion rally, expressing his commitment to their cause. But Marlin Fitzwater, his press secretary, told reporters that morning that Mr. Bush's position ''is a personal choice of conscience,'' adding, ''We all feel there is room within the party for varying points of view.''
At the same time, Lee Atwater, the Republican national chairman, paused to say a few words to a group of Republicans who support abortion rights, who were rallying on the steps of their party's headquarters. Mr. Atwater, reiterating remarks he delivered to the Republican National Committee last week, a speech that met with White House approval, emphasized his commitment to an ''umbrella party'' with tolerance for people on both sides of the abortion issue.
It was a day, in short, that sent more than one message to more than one audience.
Even the President's message to the marchers was carefully calibrated, softer than the one he gave a year ago, before the Supreme Court reshaped the politics of abortion by giving states more power to restrict it. Moreover, several times in recent months, he has signaled his support for the ''umbrella party'' philosophy.
Republican leaders, ever vigilant about protecting the President's right flank, and ever sensitive about a President who has changed his position on abortion before, play down the significance of all this. An Administration official, speaking on condition that he not be identified, argued that ''we're not trying to fog it up'' or blur the party's identity as being firmly anti-abortion. But many others see a gradual change, like the turning of a battleship.
At the least, the party leadership has managed to hearten some of its people who support a more flexible approach to abortion, while avoiding open warfare with the anti-abortion wing. The question is how long the dual-track strategy can work.
There will come a time when the party must address the issue head on, when it rewrites its 1992 platform. Right now, the platform commits the party to a constitutional amendment that would overturn Roe v. Wade. Senator Bob Packwood, the Oregon Republican who has long supported abortion rights, says he believes it is ''almost inevitable'' that this anti-abortion plank will be pulled. The other side is equally determined to save it. The party will have to choose.
In the short term, Congressional Democrats who support abortion rights are eager to challenge the Republicans' two-track strategy. ''I think it's doomed to failure,'' asserted Representative Les AuCoin of Oregon, who played a key role in the abortion battles last fall. Mr. AuCoin said he and his allies intend to ask, again and again, why abortion is a matter of individual conscience for Republican politicians, but not for American women.
''That's the question we're going to put to the country,'' said Mr. AuCoin. ''We're going to win that argument.'' Moreover, Mr. AuCoin and other abortion rights supporters argue that it will be hard for the Republicans to soften their image on this issue if the President continues to veto legislation like the bill last fall to provide Federal financing for abortions for poor women who are victims of rape or incest.
Indeed, many analysts assert that such actions carry a heavy political cost for the party, especially with the baby-boom voters who lean Republican on economics but are more liberal on social issues. The Republicans know they need to keep those voters under their umbrella.

HEADLINE: Fiscal Crisis Could Open Door to the G.O.P. in Massachusetts

BYLINE: By FOX BUTTERFIELD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BOSTON, Jan. 21

 BODY:
The precipitous decline in Gov. Michael S. Dukakis's popularity and a budget crisis that has paralyzed state government have set the stage for a wide-open governor's race - so wide open that people are talking about the possibility that a Republican candidate could win for the first time in two decades.
''It could be a watershed year for Massachusetts, said Nick Mitropoulous, a former close aide to Mr. Dukakis who is now executive director of the Taubman Center for State and Local Government at Harvard University. ''Things are really up for grabs,'' ''There is a tremendous desire for change,'' said Thomas Kiley, a political consultant in Boston. ''It gives the Republicans a unique opportunity, one they haven't had in 20 years.'' But Mr. Kiley cautioned that it is far too early to make any predictions and that the Republicans in Massachusetts have ''kicked away their chances before by squabbling among themselves.'' 
 
Bitter Over Budget Mess
The outcome of the governor's race is particularly difficult to predict because in a state where the voters are overwhelmingly Democratic and tend to be more liberal than elsewhere in the nation, and people are angry over the budget mess, blaming Governor Dukakis and disparaging the Democratic leadership in the legislature. So heated is public feeling that a number of legislators have reported getting telephone calls threatening them with physical harm if they vote for tax increases to make up a $600 million deficit in the $12 billion state budget.
The leading Democratic candidates are Lieut. Gov. Evelyn Murphy, former Attorney General Francis X. Bellotti and John R. Silber, the president of Boston University. With Ms. Murphy laboring under her close ties to the unpopular Dukakis administration and Mr. Bellotti, at 66 years old, regarded by many as past his prime, Mr. Silber could emerge as a dark horse.
Their race for the Democratic primary in September could be further complicated if Mayor Raymond L. Flynn of Boston enters the race.
On the Republican side, the major contenders are William F. Weld, a patrician former United States Attorney in Boston, and Steven Pierce, the House minority leader. Mr. Weld has tried to depict himself as an outsider, and has adopted a modified position accepting abortion where Mr. Pierce is strongly against it.
Although former President Reagan carried the state in 1984, no Republican has won a statewide election in Massachusetts since 1972, and the last Republican to win the governor's office was Francis Sargent in 1970. Republicans make up only 14 percent of the state's registered voters. Mr. Dukakis, who is not running for re-election, has dominated Massachusetts in his three terms as Governor beginning in 1974.
 
Pledges of No New Taxes
All the candidates in both parties, in varying degrees, have pledged not to raise taxes, with Mr. Weld promising no new taxes for four years and declaring that he can balance the budget by cutting $1 billion out of the $12 billion total.
Regardless of who ultimately appeals to the voters in November, he will inherit a serious problem. In the latest indication of how severe the fiscal situation has become, the Democratic House speaker, George Keverian, withdrew a scaled-down tax package last Thursday that would have partly closed the revenue gap after failing to muster enough votes to pass it.
By law, the state's books need to be balanced by the end of the fiscal year on June 30. But some legislators are now suggesting that they may simply leave the problem until the next governor is elected.
''There is an absolute majority for no solution,'' said Nicholas Paleologos, a Democratic state representative from Woburn. ''There's an absolute majority for no taxes and an absolute majority for no cuts in the budget.''
''We are being eaten alive by indecisiveness,'' said James Howell, a consultant who was the former chief economist for The Bank of Boston. The state's basic problem, he said, is that while its revenue is growing 2 percent a year, its expenditures are shooting up 8 percent a year.
The situation could become even more confused this week, when Governor Dukakis is scheduled to make his budget plan public for the fiscal year 1991, which begins July 1. Although the Governor's office is keeping the details secret, officials have indicated the new budget will be based on the assumption that the legislature will not vote any tax increases and therefore there will have to be deep cuts in most state services.
 
'Draconian, Appalling'
L. Edward Lashman, the state's Secretary of Administration, described the spending plan as ''Draconian, appalling, disgraceful, hideous, frightening.''
Public outrage at politicians here grows from several sources. In part, it reflects disbelief that the state could have fallen on hard times so soon after the ''Massachusetts Miracle'' that Mr. Dukakis boasted of in his unsuccessful bid for the Presidency in 1988. In the middle and late 1980's, Massachusetts consistently had the lowest unemployment rate of any major industrial state, as low as 3 percent, and its high technology and financial services industries were booming.
But in 1988 and 1989 many businesses in the state suddenly faced falling profits, led by mini-computer makers like Wang Laboratories Inc. and the Digital Equipment Corporation and then by banks like the Bank of New England. On Friday, the Bank of New England said it would report a record loss of $1.05 billion for 1989 because of bad real estate loans in the Northeast.
It was this downturn in the economy that largely caused the drop in state revenue, economists say, a problem that hit other states in the region like New York and New Hampshire. But because, in the public's eye, the decline in state revenue showed up first, it was Governor Dukakis who was blamed, not business leaders.
Public anger at Mr. Dukakis was also fueled by the belief that he knew that the problems were coming but kept them hidden during his Presidential campaign, an idea some of his aides now privately concede is right.
 
Group Bashes the Incumbents
This anger has been given further voice by an unusual group that broadcasts for two hours every Tuesday afternoon on radio station WRKO-AM, bashing anyone in state government and deriding them as ''hacks.'' The three are Barbara Anderson, a housewife who has become head of a powerful anti-tax lobby, Howie Carr, a Boston Herald columnist, and Jerry Williams, a radio talk show host. On the show, Mr. Dukakis is referred to as ''Pee Wee,'' and the gospel is spread that Massachusetts has the highest taxes in the country.
In fact, according to the Census Bureau, Massachusetts now ranks near the bottom in terms of state and local taxes as a percentage of personal income, 42d out of the 50 states.

HEADLINE: How to Pay for Social Security

 BODY:
I thought I understood what Senator Moynihan had in mind with his proposal to cut the Social Security payroll tax. He wants to stop using a tax that bears hardest on the poor to reduce the Federal deficit. That sure sounds nice. But if we reduce the payroll tax, won't benefits be threatened for people who retire in the future? 
No. Regardless of what people say about creating a big fund to cover the baby boomers, Social Security surpluses do not pay future retirees. Future taxpayers do, tax cut or no tax cut.
Right now, payroll taxes are high enough to generate large surpluses. These surpluses are lent to the Treasury. When the expected bulge in retirements occurs around 2020, the Treasury will have to pay back the Social Security Administration. How? With money from taxpayers. Under the Moynihan plan, no surpluses would accumulate. Every year, the Treasury would have to turn over the necessary cash to the Social Security Administration. How? With money from taxpayers. Either way, future taxpayers pay the bill.
In other words, the Moynihan tax cut would be harmless?
Not really. Future taxpayers will pay, either way. But how much pain that causes them depends on how much the economy grows between now and then. Future taxpayers won't mind the tax burden if they feel well-off. The best way to guarantee that is for the nation to invest in education and capital equipment.
The big danger of the Moynihan tax-cut proposal is that it threatens such investment. Tax cuts drive up the deficit, siphoning private savings away from productive investment. The economy could shrivel, making future tax burdens unbearable.
O.K., tax cuts harm the economy. But isn't Senator Moynihan right about the unfairness? Isn't there some way to help the majority of Americans who now pay more in payroll taxes than in income taxes?
Yes. The flat-rate payroll tax that everybody pays up to $51,300 in earnings is a vestige of a powerful myth. Many people still think Social Security is an insurance system and that people only get back what they paid in. But in reality, most beneficiaries collect much more.
If Congress acts on the basis of that reality, it could readily fashion a tax system that spreads burdens fairly. The top marginal rate is now 28 percent. By raising it just a fraction of a percentage point, Mr. Moynihan could have his Social Security tax cut without worsening the deficit. Another remedy would be to make the payroll tax progressive, too.
Then why didn't he propose something like that?
Probably because he wants to make Congress face up to the hard choices. The worst outcome of all would be for Congress to pass the payroll tax cut and also the President's pernicious, sweeping cut in the capital gains tax. That would mean an even bigger deficit and more pain for the next generation.
A better outcome would be for Congress to redistribute unfair tax burdens away from the poor without raising the deficit. But the best outcome of all would be to protect lower-income people now and also reduce the deficit. That would insure higher incomes when the Social Security bills come due. If that happens, Senator Moynihan's ''hand grenade'' will have done enormous good.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: Elitist Visions Won't Feed China's Masses

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Li Lu, in his vitriolic and grossly exaggerated Op-Ed article, ''In China, I'd Be Dead'' (Dec. 24), uses all the cliches to elicit sympathy from Congress and the American people for the pro-democracy movement in China. If the movement fails, as I think it will at this time, it is precisely because it caters to United States emotions rather than to Chinese needs. When Li Lu writes that ''Our hopes in Tiananmen Square were built on the principles that frame the U.S. Constitution and Bill of Rights,'' he is talking about concepts that are as foreign to the Chinese people and their traditions as Confucianism might be to us. 
But he is not thinking about the Chinese masses. If he had his way, Li Lu would create an elitist democracy that would serve the daydreams of some intellectuals, with little regard for the immediate needs of the overwhelming proportion of the Chinese people. If his concern was for the workers and peasants, he and the other wielders of bullhorns in Tiananmen Square would have continued to combat corruption, inflation and the many other ills now plaguing China -for which they would have had the support of the population - rather than switching to unrealistic rhetoric about democracy and human rights, which play much better on American television but have little meaning for most Chinese.
To anyone who has watched China struggle through the Great Leap Forward and the Cultural Revolution finally to achieve the economic growth and political liberalization of the last 10 years, the unnecessary setback caused by unthinking and arrogant students is painful. Mr. Lu's article exemplifies this arrogance, and it too will only delay the changes we all desire to see in China.
 
LEO A. ORLEANS
Washington, Jan. 3, 1990
 The writer retired as China specialist with the Library of Congress.

LENGTH: 260 words

HEADLINE: Why There's No U.S. Market for Electric Cars

 BODY:
To the Editor:
''G.M. Displays the Impact, an Advanced Electric Car'' (Business Day, Jan. 4) reminds me, I am sorry to say, of similar recent events.
In the late 1970's, the General Motors Corporation announced, with great fanfare, it would produce 100,000 electric cars by 1984. This turned out to be somewhat misleading. I was then editor of EV Focus, the leading international newsletter on electric cars and trucks. Most of the electric vehicle companies I wrote about have gone bankrupt because few consumers will buy battery-powered vehicles when petroleum is available at a relatively low price.
No manufacturer will build an electric road car until a market exists for a limited-range, expensive vehicle. The only way to make the electric car competitive with vehicles in use today is to find a vastly improved electric storage medium. This is unlikely.
Lead-acid batteries, which have been around more than 100 years, have been improved only marginally despite enormous expenditures of time and money all over the world. Lead batteries are heavy, filled with corrosive acid, require slow charging and have power densities ridiculously small compared with gasoline.
Short-range electric trucks and buses make much greater economic sense than passenger vehicles. They can compete for stop-and-go runs of less than 50 miles a day. But they will come into being in the United States only when political leaders create markets for them - as is being done in a few, better managed parts of the world.
 
CYRUS A. ADLER
New York, Jan. 6, 1990

HEADLINE: Dinkins Appoints Advisers on Drugs And Top Positions

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
Mayor David N. Dinkins yesterday named Nicholas deB. Katzenbach, a former United States Attorney General, to head a study group to recommend a strategy for fighting drug abuse.
Mr. Dinkins also named Arthur L. Liman, the lawyer who was special counsel to the Senate select committee that investigated the Iran-Contra affair, to head a seven-member Committee on Appointments to screen nominees to certain city boards and committees.
''The objective is to provide a foundation for the city's anti-drug stratgey over the next four years,'' Mr. Dinkins said of Mr. Katzenbach's appointment. He said the study group would recommend treatment and education ideas and report back to him by May 1. The city will provide office space, but a private consortium has raised $150,000 for staff members and consultants. 
Mr. Dinkins has been under mounting pressure to fill about a dozen critical posts in his administration. But none of the vacant commissioners' jobs at agencies like the housing, welfare, correction and sanitation departments, and the Health and Hospitals Corporation, would be affected by the screening committee announced yesterday. Mr. Dinkins has said he hopes to fill those jobs as soon as possible.
''We have such a lot of work yet to do, as has been observed by some,'' he said with a smile, referring to criticism about the pace of appointments and complaints by some Hispanic supporters that he has not named enough Hispanic people to important jobs.
Mr. Dinkins had also been under pressure to name the Committee on Appointments, so it could screen nominees to bodies like the City Planning Commission, the Landmarks Preservation Commission and the Conflict of Interest Board, all of which require approval by the City Council.
Mayor Edward I. Koch issued an executive order establishing the committee, with five members, as a check against corruption in the wake of the munici-pal scandals several years ago. But all its members resigned effective Dec. 31, when Mr. Koch left office.
Mr. Dinkins issued a new executive order yesterday to continue the committee. Dinkins aides have said they had candidates for some of the boards but did not want to identify them because the appointments committee was not in place. Now the boards have vacancies, mixed with holdovers from the Koch administration - sometimes with tangible effects on decision-making.
On Monday, for example, the Planning Commission, which has two vacancies among its seven seats, failed to approve zoning changes sought by a private developer for a high-rise project proposed for the Brighton Beach section of Brooklyn. The commission voted 3 to 2 in favor of the changes, but that fell short of the four votes needed for approval.
Mr. Dinkins had not taken a position on the development. But he said yesterday that if the appointments committe had been in place, it ''already could have been considering names'' for such vacancies.
Under Mr. Koch, the panel was headed by the lawyer Floyd Abrams. It is modeled on the mayoral screening panel that recommends appointees for judgeships.
For each vacancy, the committee recommends at least three candidates for the Mayor's consideration. He agrees to pick one of the three, or to ask for additional nominees.
 
Hispanic Objections Addressed
Besides Mr. Liman, a partner in the law firm of Paul Weiss Rifkind Wharton & Garrison, the committee includes Victor Alicea, the president of Boricua College and a commissioner of the New York State Energy Research and Development Authority.
After the announcement at a news conference in the Blue Room of City Hall, a reporter asked Mr. Dinkins if Mr. Alicea would be his last Hispanic appointee. It was the harshest of several similar queries to the Mayor in recent days.
''I suppose others standing in my position would resent the question and suggest that you were being less than candid in the fashion in which you put it,'' Mr. Dinkins said. ''So I'll just answer the question you asked. The answer is no.''
On Monday Mr. Dinkins noted that he had named a Puerto Rican woman, Sally Hernandez-Pinero, as Deputy Mayor for Finance and Economic Development, and Carlos M. Rivera, also Puerto Rican, as Fire Commissioner.
The city's highest-ranking elected Hispanic official, Borough President Fernando Ferrer of the Bronx, said yesterday that people had expressed concern to him over the number of Hispanic appointees. But he said that some of the criticism had come from people who did not even support Mr. Dinkins and that the Mayor had not yet made all his appointments.
''The proof of the pudding is going to be at the end of the process,'' he said. ''So I don't think it's terribly productive to comment on numbers now.''
 
Investigation Chief Approved
Meantime yesterday the City Council approved unanimously without debate Mr. Dinkins's nomination of Susan E. Shepard as the city's Commissioner of Investigation. One of her first duties will be to appoint a special outside counsel to continue inquiries begun last year into Mr. Dinkins's handling of some of his financial activities while he was Manhattan Borough President, including a transfer of stock in a broadcasting company.
Mr. Dinkins said the executive director of the drug study group would be Dr. Lucy Friedman, who will take a leave from her job as head of the Victim Services Agency, a private, city-financed group that counsels crime victims. Herbert J. Sturz, a former Deputy Mayor and founding director of the Vera Institute of Justice, will be an adviser.
Mr. Katzenbach, who lives in Princeton, N.J., and is now in private law practice, said he expected the group to recommend a ''wide variety of things'' for the Mayor's consideration.
The Mayor's announcement said one issue the group would review was how to move step by step toward a system of drug treatment on demand at more treatment centers. But he said he could not give a timetable for when such treatment would be available or just how the city could afford it.
In addition to Mr. Liman and Mr. Alicea, the other members of the Committee on Appointments are:
 
Dr. June Jackson Christmas, professor, Columbia University's College of Physicians and Surgeons.
Ronald T. Gault, director for public finance, First Boston Corporation.
Nathan Leventhal, president, Lincoln Center.
Dr. Kenneth Ong, assistant director of AIDS center, St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center.
Martha T. Wallau, vice president of Eastdil Realty.

HEADLINE: EDUCATION;
Shortage of Ph.D.'s Imminent, Report Says

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23

 BODY:
A study by university deans predicts an intense tug of war among government, industry and academia for people with doctorate degrees.
As a result, the Association of American Universities said in a study released Sunday, the nation's competitive stature can only weaken in comparison with other industrialized countries.
''This nation faces a serious shortage of Ph.D.'s,'' the report said. ''A sharply increased demand will outstrip Ph.D. production before the turn of the century. Industry, government and universities will be pitted against each other in a battle for critical human capital.'' 
The report, ''The Ph.D. Shortage: The Federal Role,'' was prepared by a nine-member group, primarily graduate-school deans, for the association, an organization of 56 major research universities.
The report predicted that the nation would suffer an annual shortage of 7,500 natural science and engineering doctorates just a few years into the next century. Shortages of doctorate degrees in the humanities and social sciences would occur even sooner, it said.
 
Academia Is Losing Out
Faculty shortages have already appeared in engineering, business and other high-demand fields, the report said.
In 1985, an estimated 43 percent of all people with doctorates employed in the United States were working outside of higher education. Seventy percent of the people who received engineering doctorates in 1987 had commitments in nonacademic sectors, with 53 percent in industry and 17 percent in government and other sectors. About 65 percent of those who received doctorates in the physical sciences in 1987 had employment commitments in nonacademic sectors, with 50 percent in industry and 15 percent in other sectors.
Across all fields, 50 percent of the 1987 doctorate recipients had employment outside academia, the report said.
The report follows a study in September 1989 by the Mellon Foundation that estimated there will be only eight applicants for every 10 faculty jobs in liberal arts by the year 2000.
And last Friday, Education Secretary Lauro F. Cavazos called on colleges to increase by 25 percent the number of college graduates completing doctoral programs in the basic arts, mathematics, sciences, engineering and technological disciplines.
 
Masking of Shortages
''The current shortages have been somewhat masked by the heavy enrollment of foreign students in Ph.D. programs in science and engineering and by the desire of those students to spend at least some postdoctoral years in employment in this country,'' said Robert Rosenzweig, president of the American Association of Universities. ''We should be grateful for that fact, but as many observers have noted, it is a foolishly risky assumption for the future.''
The report recommended ''a significant expansion of Federal support'' for graduate education and a doubling of Federal fellowships and traineeships.
Mr. Rosenzweig said, ''The government has an essential role in assuring that the nation's intellectual life and economic vitality remain healthily fed by successive generations of talent trained to the highest levels of which our universities are capable.''

SECTION: Section C; Page 3, Column 1; Living Desk

LENGTH: 455 words

BYLINE: By ERIC N. BERG

DATELINE: Chicago

 BODY:
TO 46-year-old Ina Pinkney, this is the Decade of the Blobb.
Blobbs are an almost intoxicating blend of walnuts, peanuts, chocolate chips and sweetened and unsweetened chocolate, dense shapeless mounds, crisp on the outside, fudgy and chewy on the inside. At $1.25 each, they are the signature offering of Dessert Kitchen Limited, Mrs. Pinkney's bakery on Chicago's Near North Side. 
They have also made Mrs. Pinkney a hit among Chicago restaurateurs, who buy Blobbs by the hundred, and among individual chocolate addicts across the country, who send in orders by phone and mail.
''They are our way of thumbing our noses at gourmet cookies and gourmet brownies,'' Mrs. Pinkney said. ''Blobbs are the next-generation brownie, what you eat after you are tired of the gourmet brownie.''
Now in its 10th year, Dessert Kitchen is prospering. Blobbs have put Dessert Kitchen on the map, but they are a relatively recent addition to its line. The company turns out many other desserts - tarts, flourless chocolate cakes, cheesecakes and fruit breads. Although ''gourmet'' commercial bakeries are proliferating, Mrs. Pinkney thrives by focusing on freshness. She bakes to order and usually delivers only hours after a dessert emerges from the oven.
''We don't freeze desserts and we don't hold them,'' Mrs. Pinkney said. ''At most, something stays overnight before being delivered.''
Dessert Kitchen was born in 1979, Mrs. Pinkney said, after she and her husband, Bill, moved to Chicago from New York and could find no good bakeries. Working first out of her apartment, where she used a coat closet to store chocolate and a dining room for extra refrigerator space, Mrs. Pinkney began by baking surprise birthday cakes that unemployed actors and actresses in tuxedos delivered. When that business matured, Mrs. Pinkney expanded her product line and moved into her current location, a nondescript storefront in a largely residential district.
Dessert Kitchen remains a decidedly low-tech venture; there are two home ovens and conventional Pyrex measuring equipment. Everyone on the staff, which at peak seasons does not exceed a dozen, serves as baker, clerk and deliverer. Even Mrs. Pinkney delivers, using her van to shuttle warm Blobbs and cakes to customers each evening on her way home.
And at the end of the day, is she sick of chocolate? ''The answer is you never get tired of licking the bowl and tasting,'' Mrs. Pinkney said. ''When people ask when did I start the business, I say 43 pounds ago.''
Dessert Kitchen, 721 West Wrightwood Street, Chicago, Ill., 60614 (312-525-1116), is open Monday to Saturday, 8 A.M. to 4:30 P.M. It sells to order, or by mail or at the store. There is no minimum order.
ERIC N. BERG

HEADLINE: Capital Restaurants Born of Global Politics

BYLINE: By JOAN NATHAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23

 BODY:
Ten years ago Gabriel Aubouin, the private chef for the French Ambassador in Washington, decided to open a restaurant. ''A backer offered me $100,000,'' Mr. Aubouin, 43 years old, said. ''That was the opportunity I was waiting for.''
Today Mr. Aubouin and his partner, the former maitre d'hotel at the French Embassy, Raymond Campet, own La Brasserie, a popular French bistro on Capitol Hill. ''I wanted to stay here because the opportunity to open a restaurant was greater and more exciting than in France,'' Mr. Aubouin said. Mr. Aubouin's tale reflects a peculiar Washington tradition of embassy workers who leave their jobs to open restaurants. In the last few years, Alain Roussel, the chef at the French Embassy, opened La Ferme in Chevy Chase, Md., and Pierre Chauvet, chef at the Dutch Embassy, opened La Fourchette in Adams-Morgan, a Washington neighborhood with many ethnic restaurants. 
Sometimes new restaurants open out of political necessity rather than economic opportunity. After Governments changed in Iran and Ethiopia, for example, Iranian and Ethiopian restaurants opened around Washington, serving a ready market of political refugees who missed their families and their food. Restaurant watchers are now betting on when Panamanian and Eastern European restaurants will begin opening.
David Carliner, a Washington immigration lawyer, said people who seek asylum in the United States are permitted to work and to open their own businesses. Many are former embassy officials, and restaurants offer an excellent outlet for their diplomatic skills.
Eight Ethiopian restaurants opened in Washington in the 1980's. One of the oldest, the Red Sea, opened eight years ago in Adams-Morgan. ''We were students; one worked at the embassy,'' one of the three owners, Ghennet Gabre Medhin, said. ''We didn't want to go back to Ethiopia. The first year it was the three partners who did all the cooking. Now we are one step up. We have a cook.'' Most of the restaurants open outside the high-rent district of downtown Washington. Nguyen Van Thoi, who left Vietnam by boat in 1979, owns two Vietnamese restaurants in northern Virginia, including My An 2, a tiny restaurant in a shopping center in Falls Church that has several Vietnamese and Chinese restaurants. In Vietnam, Mr. Van Thoi was an administrator for the Agency for International Development. ''When I came here I studied aviation and then worked in a gas station,'' he said. ''If you are not a mechanic or technician, which I am not, a gas station is a terrible job. I worked hard and didn't make any money.''
Like Greek, Chinese and Jewish immigrants before him, Mr. Van Thoi employs members of his family. ''Your family can save you lots,'' he said. ''There is less waste and no stealing.''
''I know public relations and how to greet the people,'' he went on. ''I am one of the people most successful, but don't kid yourself, most of these restaurants fail.''
Not all the people fleeing political regimes arrive in the United States penniless. Across the street from the Red Sea is Meskerem, the fanciest of the Ethiopian restaurants, with brightly painted tiles decorated with Ethiopian motifs. ''My husband and I left Ethiopia and made some money in Saudi Arabia,'' Nafisa Said, 33, who runs the restaurant, said. ''When we came here we thought there was a market for Ethiopian food.''
When the Shah of Iran fell in 1979, Fatola Samiy was the educational counselor at the Iranian Embassy. He and his wife, Simin, had been collecting furniture to take back to their home in Teheran. With no possibility of returning to Iran, Mrs. Samiy went to work cooking. The antiques found a new home at the Caspian Tea Room, a restaurant the Samiys opened in a shopping center in the Spring Valley section of Washington, a residential area.
Like owners of many other ethnic restaurants, the Samiys learned that it was wise to have a menu with ethnic and American dishes. ''There are not many Iranians who live in this neighborhood,'' Mrs. Samiy said. ''We have to adjust our menu for our American and Iranian customers.''
If politics governs restaurant trends, what is next in the nation's capital? ''Washington will continue to be a magnet for emigres,'' said Joel Denker, author of ''Capitol Flavors,'' a portrait of Washington's ethnic restaurants. ''I see Somali cafes, Haitian Creole eateries, and even more Pakistani kebab shops.''
