LENGTH: 1133 words

HEADLINE: Wine Talk

BYLINE: By FRANK J. PRIAL

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 23

 BODY:
In 1989, for the third year in a row, Americans drank less wine than the year before. But as they have been doing regularly for more than a decade, they continued to drink more good wine: sales of premium wines, while they constitute only a tiny segment of the wine business, were up.
In a report published in Wines and Vines, a trade magazine, Jon Frederikson and Louis Gomberg, industry analysts here, estimated that the entire American wine market, including imports, was off about 8 percent last year. It was down to 511 million gallons, they said, or a little less than 3 gallons for each American age 21 and over. What's more, they predicted that the trend would continue and that the market would be down 5 percent more this year. 
The biggest drop was in wine coolers, a hybrid product made from wine, fruit juice and carbonated water that dominated the so-called pop wine category just a few years ago. Some 85 million gallons of wine coolers were produced last year, 21 percent less than the year before, the report said.
In dropping so precipitously, wine coolers are following the path of a variety of wine or wine-based novelties that gained wide acceptance and then dropped into insignificance. Among them were bottled sangria, cold duck and apple wine. Lambrusco, another enormous success a few years ago, has dropped back but still has substantial sales. White zinfandel is probably the favorite pop wine of the moment.
After wine coolers, the champagne category dropped the most: 9 percent. The category includes both imported and domestic sparkling wines. The report attributed much of the decline to the nationwide crackdown on drunken driving. ''Most sparkling wine is consumed away from home,'' Mr. Frederikson said in an interview last week, ''and people are very concerned about what and how much they drink when they're out.''
It was the fifth consecutive year of decline for the sparkling-wine category, which experienced dramatic increases in the late 1970's and early 1980's. In those years, dozens of California wineries began making sparkling wine, and big sparkling-wine producers in France and Spain built extensive wine-making centers in this country. Some of those wineries are just now coming into full production.
Table wine - the most popular category, at 330 million gallons - was off only 3 percent last year, mostly in lower-end jug wines.
What has happened to sparkling wine mirrors to some extent the experience of the entire wine industry.
After dramatic, often double-digit, expansion in the 1970's, the market began to cool off at the end of the decade and at the beginning of the 1980's. But there was enough momentum to sustain some growth until 1987, when for the first time, overall production was off, by 1 percent. In 1988, it fell 5 percent more.
If the Frederikson-Gomberg prediction of total 1990 production of 488 million gallons is accurate, production will have declined almost 100 million gallons in four years.
The report sees a further drop of 2 percent in table wine this year, a 6 percent decline in sparkling wine and a 15 percent falloff in wine coolers.
Two bright spots in the otherwise gloomy overview were a prediction of continued strength for premium wines and what the report called a ''bottoming out'' in sales of imported wines, which have been falling steadily for five years.
Premium wines are hardly high priced by most standards: they are defined by the industry as wines costing more than $3 for a 750-milliliter bottle. That seemingly covers the cheapest of wines, and yet represents only 5 percent of the American market.
The report predicted gains not only for French and Italian wines but for wines from Latin America and the newly active wine-producing Eastern bloc nations.
When the dollar began to slide in 1985 and imported wine prices began to climb, most pundits predicted a new golden age for American premium-wine producers. In some ways, the opposite has happened. The price increases posted by California wine makers recently have provided new incentives for foreign wine makers to fight for a share of this lucrative market. Spain, Italy, Chile and to some extent Australia have done just that.
In a separate report, Hambrecht & Quist Inc., a San Francisco investment company with a special interest in the wine industry, is cautiously optimistic about the wine market for the 1990's. John Fisher, the managing director, said there would be sustained growth, particularly in the super-premium and ultra-premium catgories, while jug wines and spirit sales would continue to fall.
Mr. Fisher defined premium wines as those costing $3 to $7 a bottle, super-premiums $7 to $13 and ultra-premiums $13 and up.
Hambrecht & Quist reported that important advances in grape growing and wine making in recent years have enabled big wineries - those producing 250,000 cases or more - to make and sell super-premium and ultra-premium wines that once were assumed to be the exclusive domain of the California boutique wineries.
The report cited as an example the barrel fermentation of chardonnay wine, in which the wine is actually fermented in small oak barrels rather than in huge stainless-steel tanks. Once limited to small wineries, barrel fermentation is now ''measured in the tens of thousands of barrels, not the hundreds,'' the report said.
''The boutique barrier to quality,'' it concluded, ''is forever broken.''
The economies of size and the marketing clout of the larger wineries will, as the Hambrecht & Quist report put it, intensify ''competitive pressures across all levels of the winery size spectrum.''
As the consumers who created the wine boom of the 1970's and early 1980's age, the report said, the ''emphasis on drinking lighter, better and more healthful beverages is felt throughout the market.''
''The premium-wine industry of the 90's will continue to benefit from the decline of spirits and jug wines driven by 'less but better' philosophy,'' it continued. ''Unfortunately, the same trends will drive some current wine drinkers to waters, seltzers and other nonalcoholic adult beverages.''
 
TASTINGS
Chateau Gloria 1986, Bordeaux, about $12.
 
Since Chateau Gloria was rocketed into prominence a decade or more ago by a magazine story about its owner, Henri Martin, the wine has consistently lived up to its high reputation. The wines of St.-Julien have always been the most accessible of the Medoc wines, which are usually considered the most austere of all Bordeaux wines. Chateau Gloria - which is ranked as a cru bourgeois, or bourgeois growth - may not display the depths of a Ducru-Beaucaillou or a Beychevelle, but it is invariably delicious and a good value. The 1986 vintage was particularly successful in St.-Julien, as this bottle will attest.

HEADLINE: Tim Curry Plunges Ahead Into the Past, Part IV

BYLINE: By MERVYN ROTHSTEIN

 BODY:
Sitting in the lobby of the Manhattan Theater Club, a smile on his face, is Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart, William Shakespeare, Tristan Tzara and William Hogarth. Or, to put it another way, sitting in the lobby of the Manhattan Theater Club, a smile on his face, is the English actor Tim Curry.
Playing historical figures has been something of a specialty for the 43-year-old Mr. Curry, and at one time or another he has portrayed all of the above. He was the original Mozart on Broadway in Peter Shaffer's ''Amadeus,'' and he got a 1981 Tony nomination for his work. He was Shakespeare on British television in the 1970's, in a series written by John Mortimer. He portrayed Tzara, the Dadaist and apostle of the irrational, in Tom Stoppard's ''Travesties'' on Broadway in 1975. And now he is playing Hogarth at the Manhattan Theater Club in ''The Art of Success,'' Nick Dear's bawdy and provocative tale of a day in the life of the 18th-century English artist.
 
Playing With the Facts
Mr. Curry says he does not approach his historical characters differently from the way he prepares for such roles as the dastardly Rooster Hannigan in the film version of ''Annie'' or the transsexual Transylvanian villain Frank 'n' Furter in the cult movie ''The Rocky Horror Picture Show.'' 
''It's much more a matter of playing the characters as they were written by the authors,'' Mr. Curry says, ''because of the liberties that have been taken with pretty much all of them. They've all been distorted in one way or another, because the authors have hardly stuck to the facts. When I was playing Mozart, I really read very little about him, because I thought what was really important was to play not only Peter Shaffer's Mozart but also the Mozart who's seen through the eyes of his enemy Salieri.
''I think that if you get too close to the character, if you do too much historical research, you may find yourself defending your view of a character against the author's view, and I think that's terribly dangerous.''
For Hogarth, Mr. Curry says, ''I just looked at the pictures.'' And in a sense, he says, there was little point in doing extensive historical research for ''The Art of Success,'' ''because it's really a very modern play.''
 
Purpose of 'Success'
In ''The Art of Success,'' Mr. Dear uses the politics and the sexuality of 18th-century London, as seen through Hogarth and his friend the playwright and novelist Henry Fielding, to reflect on the greed and success-at-any-price ethic he sees in 1980's England. Mr. Dear has condensed episodes from 10 years in Hogarth's life into a 24-hour period. They include his marriage to the daughter of the official royal painter and his encounters with a prostitute, a killer and Robert Walpole, the British Prime Minister. There are discussions of the relations between the sexes, the role and the purpose of the artist in society and the problems of governmental censorship as well as the censorship an artist may impose on himself in his attempt to get ahead.
''Hogarth has really been taken hostage to Nick Dear's view of Thatcher's England,'' Mr. Curry says. ''The sort of economic greed of the 80's, at the end of the Industrial Revolution, is very similar to the part of the 18th century shown in the play, which was the beginning of the Industrial Revolution and indeed of the British Empire.''
 
The Role of the Artist
The play, Mr. Curry says, is really about ''the moral responsibility of the artist - is there one, really? - and indeed the political responsibility of the artist.'' It's about making political compromises to succeed in your career, about the dilemma of the artist's position in society: to what degree the artist can be both a social critic and dependent on the state for a living.
''They're the kind of questions any artist in the 20th century would be asking himself,'' he says. ''Why am I doing this? Am I doing this for any kind of really valid reason? I think artists are driven by the engine of their own talent, but it's a question of what use they put it to.''
The play, he says, ''is also a discussion about how the wheels of censorship grind into motion and why it's important that they be stopped.''
''Reading the play, you couldn't help but think of the Mapplethorpe photographs,'' Mr. Curry says, referring to the decision last year by the Corcoran Gallery of Art in Washington to cancel an exhibition that included homoerotic photographs by Robert Mapplethorpe. The exhibition was partly paid for by the National Endowment for the Arts, and the Corcoran feared adverse Congressional reaction. ''Anything to strike a blow in Mapplethorpe's defense is well worth doing,'' Mr. Curry says. #200 Years of Censorship In ''The Art of Success,'' Walpole creates a theater licensing system, a form of censorship, to stop Fielding from criticizing him in his plays. The real Walpole also created such a system.
''I was in the first play in London to be done after the theater licensing act was repealed,'' Mr. Curry says. ''It was repealed the day before I started to work in 'Hair,' in 1968. So between the 1730's and 1968 there was more than 200 years of censorship in England.''
Mr. Curry was born, toward the end of those more than 200 years, in Cheshire, in the west central England. His interest in performing began early. ''I was a boy soprano,'' he says. ''I sang in church from the age of 6 or 7, which I guess started it really.'' He went to the University of Birmingham, which was one of the first universities in England to offer a drama degree, ''and at the time I wasn't really sure whether I wanted to be an actor or a singer; so I talked my way into 'Hair' and postponed the decision for another year or so.''
His indecision continued for many years. He would alternate stints of acting with making rock-and-roll records and touring with a band. After doing ''Travesties,'' ''The Rocky Horror Picture Show'' and the stage version, ''The Rocky Horror Show,'' in London and on Broadway, he quit acting and devoted himself to rock-and-roll. But then came ''Amadeus.''
 
The Return to Acting
''When I did 'Amadeus,' I hadn't done a play for five years,'' he says. ''And I was so happy doing it and felt so foolish that I hadn't done a play for such a long time that I wanted to go back and really kind of reach out for a classical career.''
So he went back to London and joined the National Theater for two seasons, where he performed in ''The Rivals'' by Sheridan, ''The Threepenny Opera'' - ''a dreadful, abortive production of a play I'd always wanted to do and then made a terrible pig's ear of'' - and the Tom Stoppard adaptation of Arthur Schnitzler's ''Dalliance.''
He made a couple of movies, including ''Legend,'' in which he played the Lord of Darkness, and ''Clue,'' in which he was the butler Wadsworth. He also played Bill Sikes in a television movie version of ''Oliver Twist.'' And he is in the coming ''Hunt for Red October.''
Recently, he spent a year touring the United States in the road company of ''Me and My Girl.'' There is a movie on the horizon for him after ''The Art of Success,'' he says, but it's not definite yet, so he isn't ready to talk about it.
One thing he will talk about is the fact that he has abandoned rock-and-roll. ''It really is a young man's game,'' he says.
These days, he says, he's ''pretty much concentrating on acting,'' and specifically on acting in movies. He has even sold his home in London and bought one in Los Angeles.
''I moved to L.A.,'' he says, ''because that's where they point cameras at you. And that's what I'd like them to do.''

HEADLINE: Japan Stakes Out Nearby Markets

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Jan. 23

 BODY:
From Taipei to Bangkok to Jakarta, Japan's largest securities firms are rushing to open new offices, beef up their staffs, set up new investment funds and start joint ventures in their own backyard - Asia.
The flurry of moves amounts to a reorientation of the global ambitions of the big Tokyo securities houses. It is partly an effort to cash in on the region's rapid economic growth, but the Asian push also reflects Japanese frustration with the meager profits and stiff competition encountered by their Wall Street operations. In Western Europe, they are worried that the planned economic unification of 1992 may block them from new opportunities in the European markets.
Japan's Big Four securities firms - Nomura, Daiwa, Nikko and Yamaichi - are staking out Asia's young but booming capital markets as, in effect, their own bloc. To be sure, the Tokyo firms stress that the United States and Europe will continue to be integral to their strategies, because of their size and because Japanese customers are still pouring huge amounts of capital into Western economies. But Asia will get far more attention in the pursuit of more profitable business. 
''For Daiwa, the United States is a kind of laboratory for new financial products,'' explained Tetsuo Yoshino, general manager of Daiwa's international planning department. ''But when we look at the dynamic Asian economies, we are looking at the 21st century.''
For American and European securities houses, which often moved earlier than their Japanese rivals into established East Asian financial markets like Hong Kong and Singapore, the Japanese assault is viewed as a formidable challenge.
''They have more capital and more patience than any other firms in the world,'' said Michael Dobbs-Higginson, chairman of Asia-Pacific operations of Merrill Lynch & Company. ''Belatedly, they are bound to become the most important firms in their own backyard, leapfrogging non-Japanese firms.''
For years, the Japanese firms merely sold Japanese stocks to wealthy Asian investors through their offices in the region. But with the area's rapid expansion and a trend among many Southeast Asian governments to dabble less in industry and rely more on private capital to fuel development, the stock markets of these nations seem on the verge of a growth boom.
To exploit that opportunity, the Japanese firms have started to move into ''higher quality'' business, underwriting securities and forming mutual funds - providing vehicles that allow the Japanese to invest in these markets and help Asian companies to acquire other companies.
''Now is the time, because this is when the markets in Asia are really growing and opening up,'' said Akiyoshi Ito, director of Yamaichi Securities' international division.
This shift by Japan's biggest securities houses marks the start of a new international offensive after the sobering problems they ran into in the United States during the 1980's.
Despite the commitment of hundreds of millions of dollars in capital and hundreds of staff members to their Wall Street offices, the Japanese firms failed either to build a substantial market share or to show a meaningful profit.
Hitoshi Tonomura, executive managing director in charge of international operations at Nomura, the world's largest securities firm, said that Nomura's Asian operations outside Japan, although less than a third as big as its American operations, are more profitable. The three other big firms have confronted similar problems in the United States.
 
Rethinking Strategies
Their experience on Wall Street has forced the Japanese firms to rethink their strategies. An early sign of the new direction emerged last year when Yoshihisa Tabuchi, chief executive of Nomura, said in a much quoted interview that ''Nomura's strength is our influence throughout Asia, not just in Japan.''
Mr. Tabuchi added that Asia was where Nomura had a competitive advantage and that the firm intended, finally, to exploit that edge. As is often the case in Japan, when the leader started to move, the other firms quickly followed suit.
With Japan as its anchor and smaller states expanding even faster, East Asia is the world's fastest-growing region. For example, the economies of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations - Brunei, Indonesia, Malaysia, the Philippines, Singapore and Thailand - grew 7.4 percent last year, compared with a 3.4 percent rate for the industrialized nations in the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development.
 
More Opportunity for Growth
''In Europe and the United States, you have more mature markets; the growth will be limited,'' said Takahira Ogawa, manager of Nikko's Asia and Oceania division. ''The growth possibilities in Asia are much, much greater, and will be for some time.''
These are among the steps taken by the Japanese firms in Asia:
* Last week, the four big firms said they had agreed to acquire small stakes, from 5 to 10 percent, in Taiwan brokerage houses. Although volatile, Taiwan's stock exchange is one of the hottest in Asia, with the value of shares traded there surpassing that of London. Wealthy Taiwanese are also increasingly looking for opportunities to invest in Japan and other foreign markets.
* Nomura was joint lead manager last November, along with the brokerage unit of the Bankers Trust Company, of the first Euromarket offering of its kind, a $100 million convertible bond issue for Yuen Foong Yu Paper Manufacturing of Taiwan. Japanese executives said the offering, which provided a rare opportunity for outsiders to buy Taiwanese securities directly, will be followed this year by at least a dozen more.
* Several of the firms have formed joint ventures in Jakarta to help build Indonesia's nascent securities market. There are only about two dozen listed companies now, but the Government is encouraging more companies to go public, which would provide new underwriting business and broader investment opportunities for Japanese firms.
* Several of the firms have opened representative offices in Thailand, and have begun, or expect to begin soon, Thai mutual funds.
* The firms are all substantially enlarging operations in the regional centers of Hong Kong and Singapore. For instance, Yamaichi wants to double its 70-member Hong Kong staff and 60-person Singapore staff ''as soon as possible,'' Mr. Ito said.
 
The China Question
The Asian push by Japanese securities firms is not across-the-board and not without pitfalls.The region's largest country, China, is still many, many years away from having active financial markets, the executives said. Some of the firms have made substantial investments in China -Nomura, for instance, has developed a hotel in Shanghai and an office building in Beijing - but expect no return soon.
The ties to China have also constrained the Japanese firms in Taiwan. Japan's Finance Ministry permitted the firms to invest in Taiwanese securities firms only recently, out of fear of upsetting China, and even then the approved investments were limited. They were also made indirectly, through Hong Kong subsidiaries of the brokerage houses.
''Frankly speaking, we do hope to open our own office eventually'' in Taiwan, said Mr. Yoshino of Daiwa. ''This is the best we can do for now.'' In addition, most of the markets in the region can absorb relatively small amounts of capital. Japanese institutions are often looking to invest tens of millions of dollars, sums that would swamp many of Southeast Asia's markets if pumped in too quickly.
''By our standards, these markets cannot take much capital efficiently,'' conceded Mr. Ogawa of Nikko.
 
Some Resentment Lingers
Not least, after Japan's brutal conquest of most of Southeast Asia in World War II, the Japanese are still resented in some countries. Nowhere is this more pronounced than in South Korea, where hostility toward Japanese companies can run high.
For their part, Asia's smaller economies still fear being dominated by Japan's financial powerhouses. ''Don't misunderstand, we are not invading them,'' said Mr. Yoshino of Daiwa, trying to tiptoe around the sensitive issue. ''This is a form of cooperation. We have the expertise and capital to help them develop.''
That, in fact, may be the Japanese firms' strong suit. They can help Asian financial markets mature and expand, bringing expertise in addition to capital and new investors -while building huge market shares.
''The point is that these economies don't yet have a financial infrastructure that links them to the major markets,'' Mr. Tonomura of Nomura said. ''That is what we are providing.''

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
U.S. Bond Auction Goes Poorly

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
The Federal Government's first auction of 40-year bonds since the mid-1950's went poorly yesterday, as investors demanded higher-than-expected interest rates on $5 billion worth of bonds issued by the Resolution Funding Corporation that will be used to finance the bailout of insolvent savings institutions.
The higher-than-expected interest rates will cost the Government more than $200 million over the life of the bonds.
Bids on the securities produced an average yield of 8.60 percent, about 10 basis points, or hundredths of a point, above where the bonds had been offered in when-issued trading earlier in the day.
And after the results were announced, the price of the bonds slipped further. By late in the day the securities were offered on a when-issued basis at a price to yield 8.66 percent. 
 
Other Signs of Weakness
The interest rates were not the only sign of weakness.
Demand was tepid, with $8.16 billion worth of bids received. By comparison, the last Treasury auction of 30-year bonds, in November, brought $20.4 billion in bids for the $10 billion in bonds that were sold.
And the Resolution Funding Corporation's first sale of $4.5 billion of 30-year bonds in October generated $12.9 billion in bids.
Moreover, the bids on yesterday's issue covered an unusually wide range.
Nearly 60 percent of the bids were at a price to yield 8.65 percent, while the low bids came in at a price to yield 8.55 percent. In most Treasury auctions, the difference between high and low bids is generally 1 to 2 basis points.
''This is a lot worse than expected,'' a trader who deals in Government agency issues said. ''It's very ugly.''
 
Officials Satisfied
Still, officials at Refcorp, as Resolution Funding is known in the credit markets, said they were satisifed.
''We shaved 12 basis points off the bonds sold in October,'' said William S. Jasien, a spokesman for the agency, which was established by Congress to oversee the savings bailout. ''That was our objective. Unfortunately, it happened at a time when the market was not hospitable.''
The auction results also produced a sharp selloff in the secondary market for Treasury notes and bonds. Prices of most issues, which had risen earlier in the day, plunged after the results were announced late in the day.
Ward McCarthy, a managing director at Stone & McCarthy Research Associates, a Princeton, N.J., firm that provides research and commentary on activity in the foreign exchange and fixed-income markets, said the high bids showed that ''a small percentage of dealers wanted to be darn sure they got these bonds,'' adding, ''As far as the rest of the investor community is concerned, they were not interested in bonds at these yield levels.''
 
Japanese Not Involved
The investors in the 40-year bonds apparently did not include the Japanese.
The Japanese ''prefer 30-year bonds,'' said William M. Brachfeld, an executive vice president at Daiwa Securities America Inc.
Mr. McCarthy and others said the lack of Japanese participation at the auction raised questions about whether Japanese investors would be active buyers at the Treasury's quarterly refinancing auctions in February.
But Mr. Brachfeld commented, ''I don't think it says anything about how the refunding auctions will go.''
The 8 1/8 percent Refcorp bonds sold in October were trading at a price to yield 8.77 percent late yesterday. The auction of the 40-year bonds marked the first time the Government has sold securities with such a long maturity since 1955.
 
Reduce Financing Costs
''One of the purposes of Refcorp is to reduce financing costs, and they accomplished that,'' Mr. McCarthy said. ''But you can safely say that the Treasury will not issue a 40-year bond to replace the 30-year bond.''
The price of the Treasury's outstanding 8 1/8 percent bond of 1919 pl,mmeted after the results of the auctiowewere annncnced.
In le e tradin t the clo 1/4,ly watched issue was offered at a price of 97 3/32, down nearly a full point, or almost $10 for each $1,000 face amount of securities, to yield 8.39 percent.
Treasury note issues also took a beating, especially intermediate- to long-term issues.
By late in the day, the 7 7/8 percent 10-year notes were offered at 96 30/ 32, down half a point, to yield 8.33 percent. And the 7 3/4 percent five-year notes were offered at 97 7/8, down 3/8 of a point, to yield 8.25 percent.
Interest rates on the $10 billion worth of two-year notes to be sold at auction today also rose.
The notes were offered on a when-issued basis at a price to yield 8.17 percent late yesterday, up from a late offered rate of 8.10 percent on Monday. Treasury bill rates inched higher. Three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 7.67 percent late yesterday, up 3 basis points. And six-month bills were offered at 7.59 percent, also up 3 basis points.
 
Kodak 'Step Down' Notes
In the corporate bond market, the Eastman Kodak Company priced $500 million worth of ''step down'' floating-rate notes through an underwriting syndicate led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.
The notes, which mature Jan. 20, 1993, carry their name because interest rates on the securities decline at specified times in the course of the loan.
The notes, which were priced at par, or $100, are noncallable for one year.
For the first year, rates on the notes will be the one-month commercial paper rate plus 30 basis points. In the second year the spread, or difference, over one-month commercial paper shrinks to 25 basis points. And in the third year the spread over one-month commercial paper falls to 20 basis points.
The commercial paper rate is set the third Wednesday of each month, with the first rate set on Jan. 29.
The issue is rated A-2 by Moody's Investors Service and A-minus by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
Investors in the tax-exempt municipal bond market snapped up an $837 million issue of general revenue bonds from the Massachusetts Water Resources Authority.
The negotiated issue consists of serial and term bonds. Coupons on the serial bonds range from 6 percent on bonds maturing in 1991 to 7.50 percent on bonds that mature in 2004.
Merrill Lynch Capital Markets acted as lead manager for the transaction, which is rated A by Moody's and A-minus by Standard & Poor's.

HEADLINE: Most Employers Coveting Frequent-Flier Bonus Miles

BYLINE: By PHILIP S. GUTIS

 BODY:
Corporations are increasingly wrestling with their employees to claim frequent-flier bonuses from airlines as travel costs soar and the economy slows.
Frequent-flier programs, which were introduced 11 years ago, typically offer free upgradings to first class and free flights to passengers who log a certain number of miles. At first, many companies took the position that having paid for the tickets, they deserved to get any bonuses earned by their employees on business trips. But the structure of the programs and an overwhelming resistance by employees to give up what they saw as a new benefit quickly led most companies to abandon their efforts. 
Now, under pressure from a sluggish economy and business travel costs that rose 94 percent in the 1980's, according to the Runzheimer International Business Travel Price Index, corporate travel managers are trying a variety of ways to reclaim frequent-flier bonuses.
Some, like the Boeing Corporation, use get-tough policies ranging from monitoring the return of bonus points accumulated by employees to restating longstanding corporate policy against using the bonuses for personal use.
But others, the Unisys Corporation notable among them, have decided a share-the-fortune approach is better. They offer their employees cash or other incentives to turn the bonuses in for company use.
''As air fares go up, companies tighten budgets and corporate travel managers come under pressure to cut costs, frequent-flier programs are something that is being looked at,'' said Margie L. Crace, the president of the National Business Travel Association, an organization of corporate travel managers.
Still, it is unlikely that most companies will make stringent efforts to take the bonuses from employees, according to travel managers and people who monitor the frequent-flier programs. Because awards are registered in personal accounts - designed by the airlines to increase ''brand loyalty'' among travelers and their families - it is difficult for companies to keep track.
Ms. Crace is travel manager at Chemed/DuBois, a specialty chemical company in Cincinnati. She said her company has been taking back frequent-flier bonuses since 1984.
 
Employees Fight Back
Even though the airlines expect only 30 percent of all frequent-flier awards to be redeemed, employees still strongly resist giving them up. ''At first, it's like Vietnam, Korea, World War III,'' Ms. Crace said. ''You are against Mom, Apple Pie and America when you try to take the awards.''
One international management consultant said frequent-flier miles should not be taken from employees. The benefits represent ''the scars of business travel,'' he said, because such travel was more of ''a hassle than pleasure.''
That may explain why more than 100 companies have got in touch with Unisys, in Blue Bell, Pa., for information about a strategy it devised for prying loose frequent-flier bonuses from its workers.
Under a program started in April 1989, Unisys, the computer manufacturer, gives employees who agree to use their bonus points for business travel half the cash value of the air fare saved.
Robert W. Anderson, the company's director of corporate travel, said many employees had accumulated so many bonus points that they would never be able to use them all for personal travel. The program, he said, benefits both company and employee.
 
'Money in the Hand'
''There is more to a trip than just the air fares,'' Mr. Anderson said, ''and if you don't have the money to take a big trip - or the vacation time - then our program offers money in the hand and it certainly helps the company.''
In the first nine months of the voluntary program, Mr. Anderson said, Unisys saved about $100,000 -which he concedes is minuscule when compared with the company's air fare costs last year of about $75 million. But he said he expected more of the 25,000 eligible employees to participate this year and projected saving 10 percent of Unisys's air fare costs.
Other companies are more strict about wanting it all. In Dallas, the Halliburton Company, the diversified energy and construction concern, told its more than 60,000 employees last year that they would no longer be able to keep frequent-flier awards accumulated on business trips. ''I'm not aware of any problems that we've had with the new policy,'' said Guy Marcus, Halliburton's vice president for investor relations. ''The employees recognize that it is the company that buys the tickets.''
 
Boeing's Savings
Boeing, the Seattle-based aircraft manufacturer, has never allowed employees to use awards for personal travel. It closely scrutizes ticket reimbursements to insure that bonuses are returned to the company. A spokesman, Bob Jorgensen, said that last year the company used the bonuses to save about $1 million on an annual travel budget of $100 million.
When new employees join Boeing, Mr. Jorgensen said, many grumble about losing frequent-flier benefits. To assauge them, the company said that any money saved on air fares is credited to an employees' department. ''That way the money comes back to your organization,'' he said, ''if not to you.''
Following the airlines' lead, many hotel chains and rental car agencies have started their own frequent-traveler bonus programs. But because air travel is usually the most costly part of corporate travel over all, companies are focusing on ways to cut that expense.
Ken Heldt, managing director of Frequent Flyer Services of Colorado Springs, said that on average a company could cut total air fare costs by 7 to 10 percent. His company analyzes corporate travel budgets to help managers determine how much they can save through reclaiming bonus awards and how to track the awards.
His clients, he said, have included large international operations like the Amoco Oil Corporation and the Union Carbide Corporation as well as the small but travel-dependent scouting team for the Chicago Cubs.
While these companies are interested in seeing how much they can save by reclaiming awards, Mr. Heldt said he often advised sharing.
''It still gives employees some incentive to make sure that the numbers are put in the computers,'' he said.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
U.S. Memories: Who Is the Loser?

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
U.S. MEMORIES, R.I.P.: The joint venture formed last year to rescue the American computer industry from the clutches of a Japanese chip cartel died of financial anemia last week. The giant companies it was intended to protect just could not bring themselves to sign checks amounting to a few days' worth of the industry's annual investment budget.
To Sanford L. Kane, U.S. Memories' president, the decision was a sad example of American managerial myopia, of the computer makers' inability to look beyond the current glut in mass-produced memory chips to the day when NEC, Toshiba, Hitachi and friends would once again be in the catbird seat. But to Gary Saxonhouse, a specialist on the Japanese economy at the University of Michigan, the decision seemed more a triumph of cool business logic over chauvinist passion. 
High-tech manufacturers, he said, are happy to play the us-versus-them game on the public's nickel. But with their own money at stake they are far more likely to look to the bottom line.
The American semiconductor industry leads the world in logic chips, the electronic brains of computers and other smart machines. But it has lost its once-dominant position in solid-state memory devices, where efficient manufacturing technology rather than design prowess is key.
While some American companies remain in the forefront of this technology, Japan now makes 70 percent of the standard one-megabit dynamic random access memory chips, known as D-RAM's, and 90 percent of the more advanced four-megabit chips.
To people who think America and Japan are fated to fight it out for king of the industrial hill, that represents a dangerous vulnerability. When the market for D-RAM's again tightens, prices will skyrocket and shortages will be felt most severely by American manufacturers.
And the long-term problems created by dependence on the Japanese may be worse than the temporary supply disruptions. Japanese computer makers, which are mostly divisions of the same companies that manufacture D-RAM's, will be favored with advance knowledge and guaranteed supplies of the next generation of memory chips. That will give them a critical leg up in the fast-paced competition for world markets.
U.S. Memories was meant to blunt the threat. Mr. Kane expected to hit the ground running next year, using technology licensed from I.B.M. to make four-megabit chips, and moving on to 16-megabit designs by mid-decade.
But major domestic consumers of D-RAM's, including Apple Computer, Sun Microsystems and Hewlett-Packard, never signed on. And other heavyweights, like A.T.&T. and Compaq, would not put up enough cash or sign the long-term purchase contracts needed to finance plant construction. U.S. Memories threw in the towel. That may have surprised Federal officials, who have been persuaded in the past to subsidize research on D-RAM's. And it may have surprised the Japanese Government, which was bullied by Washington back in 1985 to reserve a niche in the world market for American-made memory chips. But it was no shock to Mr. Saxonhouse, who noted that American computer makers probably have less costly ways to assure adequate access to D-RAM's.
I.B.M. is already licensing its advanced chip-making technology to smaller domestic producers. Sun Microsystems is forging strong ties with Fujitsy, a D-RAM maker - a deal that leaves the companies mutually dependent for product technologies. Others are signing long-term contracts with Japanese, South Korean and American chip makers, paying a higher price to be protected against possible supply interruptions.
But most simply do not buy the idea that they are vulnerable to a Japanese power play, Mr. Saxonhouse said, and for good reason. Any serious attempt by the Japanese to withhold chip supplies at a critical moment of the product cycle would induce other companies in other countries to enter the business. And since each generation of chips requires new technology, there would be no insurmountable barriers to entry. ''The Japanese could gouge Sun or Motorola once,'' Mr. Saxonhouse concluded, ''but not twice.''
What if the computer makers are wrong? What if the Japanese somehow parlayed their lead in D-RAM's into a long-term edge in electronics?
Look at the extreme case, Mr. Saxonhouse suggested. Suppose that a lock on the D-RAM market permanently doubled the economic return on $100 billion worth of Japanese capital, and that the extra return came entirely at the expense of American consumers. The annual loss to Americans would be about $10 billion - nothing to sneeze at, surely, but still less than a fifth of 1 percent of national income.
The game is real enough: Strategic decisions by computer makers and their governments could make or break companies, careers and fortunes. But high stakes for corporations do not translate into high stakes for the economy. Mr. Saxonhouse's argument: For the want of a D-RAM the nation will not be lost.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Ford to Defer Merit Raises

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: DETROIT, Jan. 23

 BODY:
The Ford Motor Company said today that it would defer first-quarter merit pay increases for 55,000 salaried workers in the United States to cut costs in a soft and unpredictable auto market.
The move ''is a recognition that the future is somewhat uncertain because of weak auto industry sales and slowing economic growth, along with an increasingly competitive environment,'' a company spokeswoman, Joy Wolfe, said. 
Earlier this month, the industry leader, the General Motors Corporation, said it was planning broad cost cuts intended to save more than $1 billion.
Ford did not say how much it expected to save with the program but said it was part of an effort to cut costs and increase efficiency.
The No. 2 United States auto maker is seeking savings in other areas, like travel expenses, scheduled overtime for production and office workers, and discretionary spending not linked to product development, Ms. Wolfe said.
Ford said about 52,000 of its salaried work force were in the United States and 3,000 in Canada.

HEADLINE: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
Municipal Bond Upgradings Were Favorable in 1989

 BODY:
Upgradings in the ratings of municipal bonds in 1989 were the most favorable in recent years, according to a report released this week by the public finance department of Moody's Investors Service Inc.
The 240 issues that were upgraded exceeded the 186 that were downgraded by about 30 percent, the financial rating agency said in the annual report. In all, about $38 billion in debt was affected by changes, Moody's noted. 
The report said most changes reflected national trends, like the relative strength of the economy last year and the generally healthy financial condition and favorable debt positions of the bond issuers.
A higher rating on an issuer's bonds makes borrowing costs less expensive, because the ratings reflect the degree of risk that buyers of bonds must assume. Bonds with lower ratings generally must carry higher interest rates in order to attract buyers.
Regions with the most favorable ratios of upgradings to downgradings last year included the Southeast, the Midwest and the Great Lakes area. New Jersey had the most favorable ratio of upgradings to downgradings, followed by New York, Ohio, North Carolina and California.
The region with the least favorable ratio was the Southeast, followed by the Rocky Mountain and Great Plains regions. The poor showing for the Southeast was primarily the result of oil- and real estate-related problems in Texas, which had the most rating reductions, with 26. However, Moody's said the figure was significantly lower than the 46 ratings that were lowered in 1988.
In terms of dollars, Massachusetts had the most debt affected by rating downgradings. On two occasions, a reduction in the state's general obligation debt rating affecting $8 billion of debt.
Rating changes on general obligation and other tax-supported bonds accounted for 75 percent of all revisions, Moody's said, with the ratio of upgradings to downgradings at 5 to 4.
Among municipal revenue bond issues, water, sewer, public power and higher education bonds had more than three times as many upgradings as downgradings, while hospital and housing issues suffered more downgradings than upgradings, the report showed.
Hospital downgradings reflected the continuing financial dificulties stemming from market competition and Medicare reimbursement, Moody's said.

HEADLINE: Haste Urged in Savings-Asset Sales

BYLINE: By MARTIN TOLCHIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23

 BODY:
Congress today prodded Federal regulators charged with disposing of the assets of insolvent savings institutions to step up their pace and urged them to sell some single-family homes to low-income buyers.
The House Banking Committee also voted to supboena Michael R. Milken, the billionaire financier, as part of a new investigation into the role of high-yield ''junk bonds'' in the failures of savings and loan institutions, including Charles F. Keating Jr.'s Lincoln Savings and Loan Association of Irvine, Calif.
The committee, which conducted hearings last fall on the Lincoln failure, also voted to supboena two men involved in land deals with Lincoln, Ernest Garcia and Fernando Acosta. 
Representative Henry B. Gonzalez, the Texas Democrat who is chairman of the panel, said Mr. Milken's testimony could ''signal phase 2 of the investigation, which will concentrate on the extent to which trading in junk bonds and subordinated debt contributed to the collapse of Lincoln and other savings institutions.'' Mr. Milken, who pioneered the use of junk bonds in his years at Drexel Burnham Lambert, is now under indictment on securities fraud charges. $22 Billion Spent So Far The regulators who appeared before the House committee today, including Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, and Jack F. Kemp, Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, both members of the Government's savings oversight board, said they had so far spent $22 billion for the rescue, including $8.3 billion to pay off certificates of deposit that had come due, and had sold or merged 40 insolvent institutions with about $12 billion in deposits.
Both Democrats and Republicans on the committee criticized what they considered the slow pace of the asset sales by the Resolution Trust Corporation. The agency was created by the industry bailout in August to liquidate or find buyers for insolvent institutions, and to dispose of their assets.
At the beginning of January, the Bush Administration instructed the trust agency to sell as quickly as possible the real estate it had inherited. The savings agency has listed more than 30,000 commercial and residential properties as the first group it will put on the market.
Addressing the members of the trust agency's oversight board, Representative Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of Brooklyn, said, ''You had estimated last September that you could spend $20 billion by October'' in closing or taking over the insolvent savings and loans. ''It's now January, and you've only used $8 billion or $9 billion.''
 
The Problems in the Process
John E. Robson, Deputy Secretary of the Treasury, responded to Mr. Schumer by citing ''the problem of creating new institutions'' like Resolution Trust and ''broadening the bidding process'' for properties.
Mr. Robson suggested that the $50 billion provided by the rescue plan might prove inadequate. It is not yet known whether the figure will prove correct ''because of many variables that continue to exist,'' he said. ''These include the pattern of interest rates, the performance of local real estate markets and the general condition of regional economies.''
Representative Barney Frank, Democrat of Massachusetts, asked the Federal overseers: ''To what extent do you intend to utilize your authority to discount sales to low-income buyers?'' The Congressman cited a provision in the bailout law that authorized the trust agency to sell single-family homes to low-income families at below-market value, and to provide low-interest loans to expedite those sales.
Daniel P. Kearney, president of the trust corporation's oversight board, replied that the agency was ''exploring the possibility'' of such sales.
And Mr. Greenspan said that unless such sales were made to low-income families, the agency would violate the spirit of the law.
 
Greenspan Quizzed on Rates
Mr. Greenspan was also questioned about President Bush's comments last week on interest rates. On Friday the President told the National Association of Home Builders that ''low and stable interest rates'' were essential to a growing economy. The previous day, Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman, said the Administration hoped the inflation rate and a faltering housing industry would persuade the Fed to loosen credit.
Representative Chalmers P. Wylie of Ohio, the committee's ranking Republican, asked Mr. Greenspan if he was feeling White House pressure to reduce interest rates. Mr. Greenspan replied that he had not felt any pressure and that Mr. Bush had merely stated a fact that most people, including himself, agreed with.
Representative Jim Leach, Republican of Iowa, warned Mr. Greenspan, ''If you didn't see the smoke signals, watch out for the tom-toms.''
Mr. Kemp agreed with Mr. Greenspan concerning the President's statement. ''He wasn't putting any pressure on the chairman,'' Mr. Kemp said.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Declines on Reports Of Subsiding Soviet Unrest

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar lost value against all major foreign currencies yesterday and finished near its lowest levels of the day in United States trading.
Reports that the unrest was subsiding in Soviet Azerbaijan halted the dollar's recent advance and renewed buying of West German marks. Investor confidence in the dollar was also shaky in the aftermath of Monday's sharp selloff on Wall Street.
Robert Morrissey, a currency trader at the Bank of Boston, said the recent political turmoil in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union had spurred dollar demand and caused dealers to lighten their holdings of marks.
 
'Market Is Fairly Bearish'
But sentiment turned against the dollar again yesterday and interest reappeared in marks. Sales of dollars pushed the dollar past technical support levels and caused additional sales amid trading maneuvers intended to prevent further losses.
''The market is fairly bearish on the dollar and we could see it trade lower,'' Mr. Morrissey said.
Testimony by Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve Board chairman, before a Congressional committee had minimal effect on the foreign exchange markets, Mr. Morrissey said. Traders said Mr. Greenspan left only a vague impression that interest rates might move lower sometime in the future.
In late New York trading, the dollar was quoted at 145.94 yen, down from 146.51 late Monday. And sterling strengthened further, to $1.6535, from $1.6370 late Monday.
Selected late dollar rates, compared with Monday's late levels, included: 1.6960 West German marks, down from 1.7242; 1.5085 Swiss francs, down from 1.5350; 5.7655 French francs, down from 5.859; 1.1785 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1801, and 1,262.25 Italian lire, down from 1,283.

HEADLINE: Real Estate;
Construction Without Loan Or Tenants

BYLINE: By Shawn G. Kennedy

 BODY:
AS a cadre of dignitaries looked on, ground was broken on Monday for a new 28-story office tower in Fort Lee, N.J.
Noticeably absent from the group, however, was a banker. In an unusual move, David Poskanzer, the project's developer, has started work on his new $150 million, 800,000-square-foot building without a construction loan in place. Also not in place are tenants for the new building, and that is the key to the problem.
Mr. Poskanzer said that Chase Manhattan Bank, which provided the financing for his first two office buildings in the Fort Lee Executive Park, where the new building will go up, decided last year not to serve as lender for the final phase of development there. 
''Right now, there is very little available money for speculative ventures,'' said Mr. Poskanzer, whose complex is at the intersection of Fletcher Avenue and Route 4. ''But what surprised us about Chase's decision not to go forward was that we have proven ourselves with this office park and with 28 other projects. Both of the other buildings here are full. Fort Lee is a strong market - perhaps the strongest in the state. We are doing well, and so are our competitors.''
Although he is confident that a lender will be found, Mr. Poskanzer has not taken Chase's decision lightly. He filed suit in New Jersey Superior Court on Dec. 29 charging the bank with breach of contract and failure to deal in good faith. Officials at Chase have said there is no merit to the suit.
Mr. Poskanzer said that in the past a bank would lend the full construction cost of a project and often accept the value of the land as the builder's equity. Once the project was built and tenants found, permanent financing would be supplied by a pension fund, insurance company or investment group.
Mr. Poskanzer's reaction to tightening purse strings at Chase may be unusual, but other developers are also finding that banks that were enthusiastic lenders in the past are shying away from new projects, particularly those for which no tenants have been signed up. Lenders say this skittishness is a reflection of an overbuilt market in the New York suburbs characterized by high vacancy rates and flat or declining rents, as well as the stricter lending policies that Congress has put on the savings and loan industry.
''There is no question that the current market is making financing more difficult,'' said Stephen Spinola, president of the Real Estate Board of New York, an industry group that represents real estate professionals.
Today's tight money is in dramatic contrast to the atmosphere during most of the 1980's, when lenders often pursued developers. During much of the decade, as the region's economy grew briskly, new office centers sprouted throughout the region, tenants took space and rents rose. But the slowdown in the economy and high vacancy rates have made lenders see speculative development in a new light.
One bank, American Savings Bank, based in White Plains, which lent money for some new development projects in the 1980's, stopped financing new construction altogether a few years ago. ''There is not enough reward in the risk-reward equation,'' said H. L. Van Varick, the bank's executive vice president for real estate. ''It is rare to find a project where builders can find a sufficient number of tenants before putting a shovel in ground to put a project in a paying mode as soon as it is finished. But that is what banks are looking for these days.''
Mr. Van Varick said American Savings had not stopped financing real estate ventures but had returned to the business of refinancing completed projects. ''We look for well-located buildings with healthy income streams that do not have to achieve top-of-the-market rents,'' he said. ''In short, we are chasing the same deals as our competitors.''
Jack Shaffer, a chief executive with Sonneblick Goldman, one of the nation's largest mortgage brokerage firms, said: ''Banks are being much more discriminating when it comes to new construction. The office demand curve is flat or declining in all but a few locations. The money for new office projects has not dried up completely, but we find that lenders are requiring more up-front equity -as much as 30 or 40 cents on the dollar - and much less debt.''
Stephen L. Green, a Manhattan investor who recently secured a $20 million construction loan for redevelopment of a 450,000-square-foot office building at 333 East 38th Street, said he had noticed a sharp change in the attitude of lenders.
''Banks are administering the loans they make with a greater degree of care,'' Mr. Green said. ''You have to be able to show that you can increase profits 5 or 10 percent a year without counting on inflation to do it for you.''
Many in the industry, including some developers, see the conservative posture among lenders positively. William L. Klein, vice president of commercial development with H. Hovnanian Investment Properties Inc. in Red Bank, N.J., said: ''It is the responsibility of lenders to ask for equity or signed leases in areas where the supply is greater than the demand. In the long run, overbuilding and panic hurt everyone.''

HEADLINE: Pentagon Freezing Construction As Bush Reviews Arms Priorities

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24

 BODY:
The Pentagon today imposed a three-month freeze on military construction, and President Bush said he would submit a new budget to Congress next week that would begin to ''restructure America's defenses in the wake of the dramatic changes'' in Europe.
At a news conference, Mr. Bush also denounced a proposal by Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York to cut Social Security taxes. And the President announced that he would support a Congressional proposal to elevate the Environmental Protection Agency to a Cabinet department.
The construction freeze, ordered by Defense Secretary Dick Cheney in a memorandum to senior Pentagon officials, halts all new military construction projects and modifications to existing contracts. It is intended to give the Pentagon time to revise its future construction plans but is unlikely to save much money now. 
 
Plans to Close More Bases
In addition to the temporary freeze, a Pentagon official said, Mr. Bush will present Congress on Monday with a ''hefty'' list of bases he wants to close, most likely including some Air Force and Army bases in Germany. The list goes beyond the 86 bases already being closed or scaled back under last year's Congressional order. It is not known how many more bases the Pentagon will ask Congress to shut down.
Directed by Mr. Bush to begin cutting Pentagon spending, Mr. Cheney on Jan. 13 ordered a moratorium on hiring in the Defense Department through Oct. 1 that is expected to eliminate 50,000 jobs out of a work force of 1.05 million civilians.
Mr. Bush also plans other management changes at the Pentagon, which he has not detailed. Officials have said those changes would save $2.3 billion in the Defense Department budget in the fiscal year 1991, which begins Oct. 1. Pentagon officials have said the military budget would total $295 billion, or a decrease of 2 percent from the current fiscal year after inflation is taken into account.
 
Hopes to Head Off Congress
The President's comments, and the Pentagon's actions so far, seem largely intended to head off Congressional efforts to dictate a new military strategy and tell the Pentagon how it should restructure American forces. Administration officials hope to avoid reductions in Pentagon spending beyond cuts already incorporated into their proposed fiscal 1991 budget.
Mr. Bush opened the selling campaign for that budget at his news conference today with his comments on military strategy and by calling the Social Security tax cut proposed by Mr. Moynihan, Democrat of New York, a ''sleight of hand'' that would end up producing an increase in other taxes.
Although he said an alternative proposal was ''worthy of consideration,'' Mr. Bush stopped short of endorsing a measure by Representative John Porter, Republican of Illinois.
Mr. Moynihan has proposed reducing the Social Security tax by $62 billion over the next two years to eliminate a surplus in the retirement fund. Mr. Porter today proposed continuing to deduct the Social Security tax from paychecks but refunding the money at the end of each year in the form of a payment to a retirement savings account in the taxpayer's name.
Both the Moynihan and the Porter proposals would end the practice of using the Social Security surplus to offset the Federal budget deficit.
Mr. Bush's comments today drew immediate fire from Mr. Moynihan on the Senate floor. ''I rise for a painful purpose,'' he said, ''to state my disappointment with the remarks made by the President this morning.'' Mr. Moynihan said using the Social Security surplus to offset the budget deficit is ''embezzlement.''
Mr. Bush also endorsed making the Environmental Protection Agency a Cabinet department, saying he was convinced ''that the environmental challenges that face America and the world are so important that they must be addressed from the highest level of our Government.''
 
Foreshadows Speech and Budget
Mr. Bush's news conference foreshadowed the State of the Union Message he will deliver next Wednesday to a joint session of Congress and the budget he will submit on Monday, and was part of a new approach his Administration is taking.
Rather than use the State of the Union Message as a detailed, summary of his major pieces of proposed legislation and of the new budget, Mr. Bush will focus on broader themes, officials said.
Before he speaks, three of the most complicated portions of his new budget will be presented by top Administration officials: William J. Bennett, the Federal narcotics chief, will unveil a new anti-drug abuse program on Thursday; Mr. Cheney will present the military budget on Monday, and Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady will offer new initiatives on family savings on Tuesday.
The speech will also be shorter than average; the current draft, officials said, runs less than 30 minutes. The speech usually lasts 45 minutes to an hour.
 
Details of Freeze
In his memorandum to heads of the military departments today, Mr. Cheney froze all new military construction contracts and any options on existing contracts until April 30, 1990, unless they are required by law or international treaty or to comply with base closings ordered by Congress last year.
Mr. Cheney said the freeze would give the Pentagon time to review its spending plans ''in light of the coming changes in force structure and disposition of the U.S. armed forces.'' He also ordered top Pentagon officials to review all their building plans.
The current military budget includes $8 billion for thousands of construction projects around the world, ranging from major bases to childrens' day care centers. It is always one of the most politically ticklish parts of the military budget, since it involves the future of bases that are an important source of income in Congressional districts and the direction of United States foreign policy.
Mr. Bush said the 1991 Pentagon budget ''begins the transition to a restructured military, a new strategy that is more flexible, more geared to contingencies outside of Europe while continuing to meet our inescapable responsibility to NATO and to maintaining the global balance.''
Mr. Bush's comments drew quick criticism from Congressional Democrats.
''If there is a strategy in what we've seen of the 1991 defense budget, it's so sophisticated that we can't detect it,'' said Representative Patricia Schroeder, the Colorado Democrat who heads the House Armed Services Subcommittee on Military Installations and Facilities. ''Perhaps it's a new stealth strategy,'' she said.
Representative Les Aspin, Democrat of Wisconsin, who heads the House Armed Services Committee, said, ''President Bush is finally saying we need a new defense strategy for new times, but it still looks like the Administration is writing the budget first and drafting the strategy later.''

HEADLINE: U.S. FACES STRAINS FROM GLOBAL JUMP IN INTEREST RATES

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
Interest rates in Japan and West Germany are suddenly surging, in the process dragging up American rates at what most economists say is just the wrong moment for the nation's fragile economy.
Rarely has the global economy forced itself so vividly on the United States. West Germany and Japan, currently the engines propelling the world's economic growth, are trying to curb inflation. But their chief tool, higher long-term interest rates, is spilling over into the weak American economy and that could be a hammer blow, further slowing growth.
''This is a terribly inconvenient time to have rates pulled up,'' said Lawrence Veit, an economist at Brown Brothers Harriman & Company. 
 
Free Flow of Money
Experts say the huge Federal deficit has left the American economy hostage to a continual flow of investment funds from abroad.
In today's international economy, with so few legal or practical obstacles to the flow of money across national boundaries, borrowers in this country must match the higher interest rates being offered abroad. Otherwise, savers throughout the world will pursue higher returns by buying the bonds issued in Japan and West Germany.
Although the market's spontaneous forces, not the Federal Reserve, have pushed up long-term rates, the central bank is nevertheless on the spot. The Federal Reserve could stand pat, allowing the market flows to take their course. But the higher interest rates could well nudge the vulnerable American economy into recession.
Higher interest rates have spread throughout the money markets. In the United States, mortgage rates have rebounded in the last month, just when the housing industry is weak. Many corporations, already heavily in debt, are facing higher monthly payments, which would further cut into their profits. Car loans might be pushed up as the higher rates force a General Motors or a Beneficial Finance to pay more for the money they lend to consumers.
 
'It Makes People Nervous'
As in any market, expectations are often self-fulfilling. Lenders who expect interest rates to rise will demand a higher rate before committing funds.
''It makes people nervous,'' said Nigel Gault, senior economist at DRI-McGraw-Hill, a research organization. ''There had been an expectation that interest rates would continue to slide down, and suddenly people have woken up to the idea that maybe they won't.''
A month ago, with the rate on 30-year Treasury bonds at 7.84 percent, no mainstream American economist was predicting its rise to 8.4 percent or forecasting that 30-year mortgage rates would be back to 10 percent after being closer to 9 percent in December. But the steps taken by West Germany and Japan made that chain of events inevitable, economists now say.
This is the first time in more than a decade that American economic growth is significantly less vigorous than in West Germany and Japan. With the robust growth, prices in Germany and Japan have climbed at rates deemed alarming in those inflation-resistant nations.
The West German inflation rate almost tripled last year, to 3 percent, and the prospect for 1990 is for more strong demand. Eastern Europeans are pouring into West Germany at the rate of 2,000 a day, adding to the national demand for goods.
 
Boom Times in West Germany
What is more, a capital spending boom in Europe has drawn heavily on German products, and the country's exports are up strongly. And now the metal workers union, seeking a greater share of the profits, is demanding what amounts to a 15 percent wage increase. The union represents more than 10 percent of the nation's organized labor.
In such a situation, the Bundesbank pushed up interest rates, the classic central bank strategy for curbing an expansion that threatens to increase inflation. The higher rates are intended to raise the cost of the loans that finance spending by consumers and businesses.
Similarly, the inflation rate in Japan more than doubled last year, to 2.5 percent, and workers are seeking a 6 percent wage increase in nationwide negotiations now under way. Rising land prices also were a problem, and, inexplicably, the yen weakened a bit against the dollar, perhaps because of the uncertain outcome of the national election next month. In this situation, the Bank of Japan on Dec. 25 raised its key discount rate by half a percentage point. The move helped to push up 10-year notes to more than 6.3 percent, from 5.5 percent.
Some American economists argue that the Bundesbank and the Bank of Japan are overreacting. They contend that inflation is not all that big a problem and they predict that the two central banks will back down soon on interest rates, which are now unusually close to American rates. (Yields on 10-year government notes range from 8.3 percent in the United States to 6.3 percent in Japan.) ''Our current view is that Japan has a case of inflation jitters,'' said Nicholas Sargen, the chief of bond research at Salomon Brothers. ''We can't identify what has changed so much in Japan in recent weeks to trigger such a jump in rates.''
 
A Different Viewpoint
A few economists in this country hold that the rising rates abroad are fortuitous, coming at a time when inflation again threatens the American economy.
These economists argue that recent data - particularly an upturn in industrial production and in the Producer Price Index, an important inflation measure - indicate that the long slowdown in American economic growth ended late last year. As a result, they say, the annual inflation rate, which declined from about 5.5 percent in early 1989 to 4.5 percent by year-end, will be on the rise again by springtime. So, in their view, the higher long-term interest rates forced on the nation by the West Germans and the Japanese will help to arrest the inflation.
Some policy makers at the Federal Reserve show signs of concern that the economy might be rebounding. Two of the central bank's governors, Manuel Johnson and Wayne Angell, have said they see little likelihood of a recession ahead. And Robert L. Parry, president of the Frederal Reserve Bank of San Francisco, said yesterday that the West Germans and Japanese are only partly responsible for the rise in long-term American rates. ''It seems to me that a prime additional suspect putting pressure on rates is heightened inflationary concerns in the United States,'' he said.
 
Awaiting the G.N.P. Report
But it remains uncertain whether the economy is getting a second wind. Government data measuring developments in recent weeks are still too sparse to tell. The first major assessment will come on Friday, when the Commerce Department releases its initial estimate of what happened to the gross national product in the fourth quarter.
Most economists guess that the G.N.P., which measures the total value of the nation's goods and services, grew by less than 1 percent from September through December. Growth of 1 percent or more would feed the economic-rebound viewpoint while a growth rate of less than five-tenths of one percent would be viewed as evidence that the economy remains very weak.
Whatever the state of the economy, the mechanism through which rising interest rates abroad affect American rates is causing a problem of its own: the increased competition for funds. The United States Treasury in recent years has counted on Japanese buyers to purchase roughly one-third of the long-term securities that the Government issues periodically to finance its budget deficit.
The next major auction of these securities is scheduled for early February, and the question is whether American rates will be high enough to attract not only Japanese investors, but Americans as well. Their alternative is to purchase Japanese or European securities. Salomon, in fact, recommended to clients this week that they consider this possibility.
 
Looking Abroad to Invest
''For the first time in two years, we have told customers that the Japanese bond market may be attractive to U.S. investors,'' Mr. Sargen said. If they agree, then rates on the securities auctioned in early February will have to rise above their current levels to draw investors.
But more than just rates influence investors' decisions. Foreign investors might not purchase Treasuries, for example, if they believe that the dollar will decline in value after they make the purchases. Currently, the dollar is just beginning to fall against the yen and has been losing ground since last fall against the mark. On the other hand, the Japanese might invest here for political reasons, because their Government encourages them to do so.
Right now, neither Japanese nor American nor German investors are buying many bonds, as the selloffs in all three marketplaces in recent days indicate. Most investors are holding their funds in cash, waiting to see what will happen, Mr. Sargen said.
