HEADLINE: Azerbaijani Strife Expected to Lift Oil Prices Throughout the World

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
Western experts say the ethnic strife in Azerbaijan has begun to disrupt production of oil in the Soviet Union, the world's largest oil producer by far and a large exporter. The resulting drop, which comes on top of a decline that began in mid-1987, is expected to contribute to tighter supplies and higher prices for oil around the world at a time when production is also falling in other regions.
Lower Soviet oil production is likely to mean a drop in exports, and that could be particularly troublesome for the nations of Eastern Europe as they wrest with political upheaval. These nations have relied heavily on subsidized oil from the Soviet Union.
But because every oil-thirsty economy drinks from the same barrel, virtually all nations could be affected, market analysts say. The Soviet Union produces about 12 million barrels of oil a day, and exports almost 4 million, including about 2 million to non-Communist nations. 
While Azerbaijan, a republic bordering Iran, produces only about 3 percent of the Soviet Union's oil, it is home to two-thirds of the country's oil services industry, the factories that make the valves, pipes and more specialized equipment needed to operate wells from the Baltic to the Pacific, experts say.
Production of that equipment has suffered as the conflict between Muslim Azerbaijani and Christian Armenian workers has increased, said Thane Gustafson, a professor of government at Georgetown University and an expert on the Soviet energy industry.
''Beginning with the first strikes and demonstrations in November 1988, the Azerbaijanis would put down their tools to go off to the public square,'' he said. ''The Armenians, already in fear, would either disappear or lie low. The Russians remaining would lay down tools, because they didn't want to be left holding the bag and be responsible for the target output.''
Of the fighting in Azerbaijan in recent days, Professor Gustafson added, ''All of that is multiplied by 10 in the wake of the most recent problems,'' when the Soviet Army was sent into Baku, the Azerbaijani capital, and when nationalist sentiments intensified.
James R. Schlesinger, a former Secretary of Energy, said the disruptions in Baku mean the Soviets ''will be short of oilfield equipment at a moment that they need more equipment if they want to sustain production.'' The disruption, he said, ''is likely to have a long, lingering effect.''
 
Poor Drilling Results
The insurrection in Azerbaijan comes on top of a recent history of trouble in the Soviet energy industry. Despite growing demands for investment in other fields and shortages of capital, the country has dedicated huge amounts to drilling in recent years, with smaller and smaller results.
American officials say they expect a decline in Soviet oil production of about 2 percent to 2.5 percent a year, even without taking account of the recent violence.
Analysts say the oil industry suffers from the inefficiencies and technological backwardness that other Soviet industries face, only on a larger scale.
The Soviet oil export picture is also affected by trouble in the nation's coal mines, experts say. The Soviet Union has had to make up for coal production lost to strikes by burning more oil.
The Chernobyl nuclear-reactor accident in 1986, which led to shutdowns at other reactors for safety improvements, has had a similar effect. For years, the Soviet Union has tried to use its coal and nuclear power at home and export the oil to earn hard currency.
''We're reaching a confluence of factors that are probably going to send another price shock,'' said Nauman Barakat, first vice president of futures at Shearson Lehman Hutton. Others are predicting at least a bull market for oil.
''We are very concerned,'' Mr. Barakut said. ''This might be a blessing for the OPEC cartel,'' he said, by weakening a competitor.
The American benchmark crude, West Texas Intermediate, has been selling at $22 to $23 a barrel in recent days, up $5 from this time last year. Analysts attribute some of the recent strength to expectations of lower Soviet exports.
 
Output Falling Elsewhere
The decline in Soviet exports comes as production is falling in other non-OPEC fields, from the North Sea to Alaska, and among some members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries outside the Middle East, like Nigeria and Indonesia.
Thomas McHale, an economist at Drexel Burnham Lambert and a frequent traveler to the Soviet Union, said a variety of technical and economic problems have been threatening the level of oil production. But he added: ''When you get these political dimensions, all bets are off. This has generated some underlying fear in the United States that has supported our current price spike.''
Strife in Azerbaijan could also disrupt the market for refined products. The republic takes in crude oil from Iran and returns it as finished products, said Mehdi Varzi, an analyst with Kleinwort Grieveson Securities in London.
The condition of the Soviet energy industry and its prospects have long been a subject for groping estimates and speculation among Western experts and, by some accounts, among planners in Moscow.
In 1977, the Central Intelligence Agency forecast that the Soviet Union's oil output would peak in 1980 and then decline sharply, turning the Soviet bloc into a net importer. Professor Gustafson, in a book published by the Princeton University Press last month, said the C.I.A. forecast might have alarmed even the Soviets, who began spending heavily on energy projects soon after. The book is called ''Crisis Amid Plenty: The Politics of Soviet Energy under Brezhnev and Gorbachev.''
 
Further Decline Expected
By everyone's count, Soviet oil production was down last year, falling by 100,000 to 250,000 barrels a day, and may fall by 300,000 barrels a day more this year, which would probably reduce exports to non-Communist nations to a level below the current two million barrels a day. Some experts think the level is already below that.
That oil enters a non-Communist market of about 55 million barrels a day in which virtually all the spare capacity is in a handful of OPEC countries, a situation that makes it easier for producers to agree to reduce their pumping and raise prices.
Part of the Soviets' production problem is the natural decline of their major oilfields in western Siberia. In addition, Western experts say, the Soviets lack the technology needed to extract the harder-to-get oil, and are reluctant to spend scarce hard currency abroad to obtain it.
''Exploration is about at the limit of their capacity,'' said one United States Government expert, who added that Moscow was talking to Western oil companies about using their expertise. But Western experts on the Soviet Union said newly ascendant environmentalists and ardent nationalists in the Soviet Union would oppose exploiting Soviet natural resources for foreign markets.
 
Some Fields Damaged
In addition to a lack of technical innovation, experts say, the Soviets have damaged some oilfields by trying to meet short-term production goals. That has reduced the amount of oil that can be easily recovered.
''They worked off five-year plans, and in many cases did short-term, expedient things that in the long term are detrimental,'' said Herbert M. Ryan, a spokesman for Dresser Industries, a Dallas-based oil services company that sells about $100 million a year in equipment and services to the Soviets and is hoping to sell more. ''Well, the long term is now,'' he said. The condition of the Soviet industry has profound implications for the newly independent states of Eastern Europe. Mr. Varzi, the London analyst, who is a former Iranian diplomat, said that last year, exports to Eastern bloc allies totaled 1.5 million to 1.6 million barrels a day, but ''at the moment, they are running not much more than one million barrels a day.'' As a result, he said, those countries will buy from OPEC at a rate of 1.2 million to 1.3 million barrels a day this year, more than double the level of three years ago, assuming no increase in demand. That raises OPEC's power in the worldwide market.
 
Hard Currency Needed
What is more, the Soviet exports to Eastern Europe have been at subsidized prices, but Moscow has said it wants to raise prices.
That would help the Soviet Union maintain foreign currency earnings even if the quantity exported were to decline. Nearly half of Soviet foreign exchange comes from energy exports including natural gas, by some estimates, and the need for hard currency is increasing. The country's external debt has risen in the last five years to about $25 billion from $5 billion.
To earn that hard currency, the Soviet economy has paid a very heavy price, experts said. Mr. Gustafson calculated that of the increase in industrial investment from 1985 to 1990, 70 percent went to energy.
He and others think the high level of investment cannot be sustained.
''The oil sector has taken up an incredible amount of capital over the last 20 or 30 years,'' Mr. Varzi said. ''Some of that capital has got to be reallocated to other sectors if the needs of Soviet consumers are going to be at least partially satisfied.''
''With over-allocation, production was beginning to level out,'' he said. ''Now, with under-allocation, what's going to happen?''
If the Soviet Union makes the ruble a convertible, or ''hard,'' currency, it will find it cheaper to buy its oil from the Persian Gulf than to spend huge numbers of rubles to drill in inhospitable places inside the country, economists say.
But other experts say that such a goal is far off, and that no matter what happens to total production, the Soviets will struggle to keep exports high because of the driving need for foreign exchange.
''It's too essential for them,'' said Robert Mabro, director of the Institute for Energy Studies at Oxford University. ''They will do whatever is possible, and divert resources from other industries.''
''There has been a traditional pessimism about Soviet oil production, starting with the C.I.A. report, but they have always managed to struggle on,'' he said. The events in Azerbaijan, he added, ''could produce a hiccup for six months or a year, but I wouldn't rush to conclusions about the longer run.''

HEADLINE: U.S. Softens Its Stance on Return Of the Boat People in Hong Kong

BYLINE: By SHEILA RULE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: GENEVA, Jan. 24

 BODY:
The United States has softened its opposition to the forced repatriation of Vietnamese refugees in Hong Kong by indicating at an international meeting here that some boat people could be sent back after a one-year moratorium. But the American insistence on the moratorium effectively prevented any consensus from being achieved at the meeting.
The closed two-day meeting was of a United Nations committee formed to seek a new policy for the 44,000 boat people who have streamed into Hong Kong in the last year and a half.
As the meeting ended today, Robin McLaren, an assistant under secretary in Britain's Foreign Office and head of its delegation here, said that of the 30 countries represented on the committee, only the United States and Vietnam had failed to agree to a proposal that mandatory repatriation start on July 1. 
 
'Fully Tested' Repatriation
Mr. McLaren said the United States insisted that the deportations not begin until Jan. 1, 1991, in order to put in place guarantees on screening methods and the safety of the Vietnamese once they returned, and that Vietnam proposed Oct. 1 of this year.
The United States Embassy said the United States delegation would not comment and referred all inquiries to Washington.
The State Department spokeswoman, Margaret D. Tutwiler, told reporters today in Washington that the ''United States' position on involuntary repatriation has not changed'' and that it remained opposed to the practice ''in principle and in practice.''
Miss Tutwiler said the State Department believed that alternatives to forced repatriation could be ''fully tested'' during the moratorium and ''found to be the most effective means for addressing this problem.''
 
Britain Eager for Agreement
When asked what would happen to people who refused to go voluntarily after the moratorium ended, Miss Tutwiler said, ''We'll cross that bridge when we get there.''
The committee has been deadlocked since its establishment in June, largely because of United States opposition to forced returns. Britain, the colonial authority in Hong Kong, insists that it has no choice but to carry them out eventually.
Mr. McLaren said that it was not Britain's view that there was any need for a moratorium on deportations and that he did not know whether it would forcibly repatriate boat people before some consensus was reached on the issue.
Britain is eager to get an agreement on the repatriations before seasonal winds change in March and boat people sail northeast across the South China Sea. After international protests greeted Britain's repatriation of 51 Vietnamese boat people in December, Britain announced that it would suspend the repatriation temporarily. #12-Month Moratorium Proposed Sergio Vieira de Mello, head of the Asian section of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, said High Commissioner Thorvald Stoltenberg had been asked by the committee to consult with ''governments that still have reservations'' about the proposed date on which forced repatriations could resume. He said the United Nations hoped that Britain would refrain from further deportations until the effort to reach a consensus was given a chance to succeed.
Delegates said it appeared for a while that a consensus might be reached after the United States, which had previously steadfastly opposed any mandatory repatriation, softened its position to accept forced returns under certain conditions.
Deputy Assistant Secretary of State Robert Funseth, who led the United States delegation, reaffirmed the United States' opposition in principle to forced repatriation. But he proposed the 12-month moratorium on any forced repatriations, after which mandatory repatriation would be allowed on the condition that no one be forced to return to Vietnam as long as there were volunteers waiting to return and that there be full international monitoring of the process leading to any mandatory return. A copy of the proposal was obtained by The New York Times.
While welcoming the change in position as the starting point for more discussions, British officials said the moratorium was too long and should be reduced.
 
Vaguely Worded Proposition
At an international conference on Indochinese refugees in June, it was unanimously agreed that the Vietnamese should be screened and that those determined to be economic migrants and not legitimate political refugees should be persuaded to return ''voluntarily.'' But it left in suspension the crucial question of what to do with the Vietnamese who are likely to be denied refugee status but refuse to return to Vietnam. Participants could only agree to a vaguely worded proposition that ''alternative'' solutions should be found if voluntary repatriation did not work ''after a reasonable period of time.''
Britain hopes to eventually empty the crowded Hong Kong detention centers that now house the 44,000 boat people who have arrived since June 1988, when the colony began treating all arriving Vietnamese as illegal immigrants.

HEADLINE: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST: CZECHOSLOVAKIA;
Prague Arms Trade to End, Foreign Minister Says

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PRAGUE, Jan. 24

 BODY:
The Czechoslovak Foreign Minister has promised that the country will end its lucrative worldwide arms exports immediately.
In a wide-ranging interview at his home on Tuesday night, the Foreign Minister, Jiri Dienstbier, a 52-year-old former journalist and former dissident, also said negotiations to get Soviet troops withdrawn from Czechoslovakia were being complicated by Moscow's preoccupation with violence in Azerbaijan, and he expressed the hope that the United States would respond with a comparable gesture if they did withdraw.
He also speculated that German reunification might come before either East or West could revise what he called their already obsolete strategic conceptions of the world.
The Foreign Minister, who just two months ago was stoking coal at the menial job to which he had been assigned as a punishment, has been keeping an arduous schedule. On Tuesday, his duties did not end until well after midnight, when he traveled to the airport to greet Gianni de Michelis, the Italian Foreign Minister. 
Earlier in the week, Mr. Dienstbier (his full name is pronounced YIHR-zhee DEENST-beer) had met Polish officials, and the Israeli Finance Minister, Shimon Peres. With Mr. Peres, Mr. Dienstbier discussed a resumption of the diplomatic relations with Israel that Czechoslovakia broke 22 years ago.
 
'Arms 'Just Won't Be Sold'
Such a schedule, his wife, Vera, insisted, was impossible, but Mr. Dienstbier appeared to be thriving under it.
''Foreign policy until now was either very pragmatic, or else very ideological,'' Mr. Dienstbier said, echoing the pledge of a new approach given by the new President, Vaclav Havel, his close friend. ''It seemed that some things could not be done because they had never been done before, but they can be done if people want to do them.
''For instance,'' he declared, ''Czechoslovakia will simply end its trade in arms without taking into account what the pragmatists will say, that it will be a blow to the state coffers, that those people will get arms from somebody else anyway if we don't supply them.
''That hasn't been officially announced,'' he said, ''but it simply will be done and weapons just won't be sold anymore. We can stop that actually even without knowing how big the trade was.''
Mr. Dienstbier's assertion apparently reflected discussion with other ministers in the new Government, which has replaced the Communist regime swept away last month in the tide of change across Eastern Europe.
 
Major Weapons Exporter
Czechoslovakia has one of the world's biggest arms industries, ranking seventh in total weapons exports from 1984 through 1988, says the Stockholm International Peace Research Institute, an organization funded by the Swedish Government.
The United States Arms Control and Disarmament Agency has reported that Czechoslovakia's arms exports totalled $975 million in 1987. That is down from a peak of $1.5 billion in 1985.
Those figures do not include arms smuggled out of the country, often with the Government's tacit consent, for which no figures are available.
Mr. Dienstbier said he did not know precise figures for Czechoslovakia's arms exports. ''There are very many things we don't know about exactly, because for 40 years they were very cleverly camouflaged under various entries,'' he said. But it would not take much cleverness to stop selling submachine guns to hunt antelopes, he said.
Omnipol, an export agency rumored to be behind many arms deals, happens to be just down Nekazanka Street from the Dienstbiers' fourth-floor walkup apartment.
Britain and other countries have asserted that terrorist groups have obtained Czechoslovak-made high explosives like Semtex. The British authorities have concluded that Semtex was used in the bombing of Pan American Flight 103 over Scotland in December 1988, an attack that killed 270 people.
Mr. Dienstbier said determining how such explosives could have fallen into terrorists hands was difficult.
''Officially there was never anything ever sold to terrorist organizations,'' he said. ''I think this kind of trade is done throughout the whole world in such a sophisticated manner. It's not only Czechoslovakia; it's everywhere. You can't really prove the real origins.''
The Czechoslovak Government has demanded the withdrawal of all 70,000 to 75,000 Soviet troops stationed here by the end of this year. But Mr. Dienstbier said the negotiations that began Jan. 15 may have been complicated indirectly by civil disturbances in Soviet Azerbaijan.
''In the Soviet leadership hardly anybody has any time today to deal with anything but burning problems, in a situation when there are thousands of dead and wounded in Azerbaijan,'' he said, using a figure much higher than the one officially reported in Moscow.
 
Suggests U.S. Gesture
Asked if Czechoslovakia would formally encourage the United States to pull out troops from Western Europe if Soviet forces left the country, he answered: ''I think that when one side does something, it is possible for the other side also to do something.''
Asked how important the political survival of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union was for the process, Mr. Dienstbier replied: ''I do not think the fate of Gorbachev himself is all that important. The Soviet Union has no alternative, unless it is something even more radical.
''On the other hand,'' he continued, ''there is the danger that the Soviet Union could become a focal point of great world tension unless it manages in a peaceful manner to solve an endless series of mutually interconnected problems, of the economy, society, nationalities, religion, and even of civilization itself.''
 
Thoughts on Germany
Speaking of the relevance of military alliances as change transforms Eastern Europe, he said, ''In this new situation we still talk about whether the NATO alliance should continue to the year 2010, while at the same time the Warsaw Pact no longer exists as the other half of a bipolar security system. The NATO alliance still exists in its old form. Institutions lag behind historical developments, not only institutions, but thinking, too.''
He was asked what he, as a citizen of a country victimized by German aggression, thought of the prospect of German reunification now.
''What could easily happen is that tomorrow demonstrators in Berlin and Leipzig could decide to abolish the frontiers altogether, and suddenly there will be a country that's half in the Warsaw Pact and half in NATO, and nobody will be able to prevent it,'' he said. ''Not if a nation of 80 million simply decides to do it.
''I don't think we have to be afraid of the reunification of Germany,'' he said. ''But at the same time we shall have to proceed very quickly in all of Europe so as to knock down as quickly as possible all the artificial barriers created here over 40 years. We should probably have the courage to return to the year 1945 to the principles of the Atlantic Charter and the anti-Hitler coalition, to connect ourselves with the idea of postwar cooperation in building a free and democratic Europe, as if these 40 intervening years didn't exist.''
 
The Helsinki Process
He suggested the process begun in Helsinki in 1975 by the 35-nation Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe as the best framework.
Mr. Dienstbier, who was a radio correspondent in Washington in 1968 before he was recalled and banned from journalism by the Soviet-installed regime, said, with the evident concurrence of his wife, that he would not move to the Foreign Minister's official apartment on the third floor of Cernin Palace on Prague's Medieval castle hill.
It was from that apartment that Jan Masaryk, Czechoslovakia's previous non-Communist Foreign Minister, either jumped or was pushed to his death from his third-floor bathroom overlooking the palace's inner court.
Masaryk's rooms will be opened March 10, he said, as a museum, a memorial to a man whose death he thought could never be conclusively explained. All that is known is that Masaryk went to his death a month after agreeing to remain in the Government after the Soviet-backed Communist takeover of Klement Gottwald.
 
Likened to Kennedy Death
''It's like the problems with the assassination of President Kennedy,'' Mr. Dienstbier said. ''I don't think it's of any use to speculate about it, because it is clear that if there was something behind it, the participants and the documents have been destroyed, the participants together with the documents.
''Anyway,'' he said, ''if he jumped from the window it is an even more damning judgment of what had happened in February than if he was pushed. If he was killed, it would testify to the stupidity and cruelty of those who decided the murder. If he did it himself it was his own protest against the regime. All the files that could have been found were discovered when the historians went through the files in 1968.
''Of course,'' he acknowledged, ''they're still discovering things from the Egyptian period.''
But he said he plans to put his office where Masaryk's leather-topped table stands now, a few rooms away from the bathroom that figured in his death.

HEADLINE: Haiti About-Face: General 'Looking Like Dictator'

BYLINE: By JOSEPH B. TREASTER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, Jan. 24

 BODY:
After 16 months of tentative hope for democracy, Haiti appears to be slipping back into dictatorship.
Haitian political leaders and foreign diplomats say they now believe that legitimate elections, scheduled for this year, are unlikely and that Lieut. Gen. Prosper Avril, the military ruler, is trying to consolidate his personal power. ''He's looking like a dictator,'' one diplomat said.
In a burst of fury that began last weekend, General Avril has banished a presidential candidate and several advocates of free elections, driven independent radio news broadcasters off the air and, with dozens of beatings and arrests, intimidated most of his critics. 
Haiti's political elite was shaken, but until today there had been few other signs of tension or discontent in the teeming capital. This afternoon, however, many street vendors and shopkeepers closed their businesses in panic as soldiers circulated saying ''things are going to get hot.''
 
A Call for Firearms
This evening, Gen. Fritz Romulus, the Interior Minister, issued a call for all firearms being held without permits. Anyone not complying within 48 hours, he said, will be subject to arrest.
General Avril, who had taken some steps toward holding elections, abruptly imposed a state of siege on Saturday night, startling Washington and the six million residents of the most impoverished, disease-ridden country in the Western Hemisphere.
A colonel in the Presidential Guard had been slain in the street the night before and there had been some bitter exchanges between General Avril and civilian political leaders. But the country seemed otherwise quiet.
Encouraged by the general's initial steps toward elections and wanting to encourage him, the United States, France and the World Bank had begun discussions aimed at restoring some of the economic aid that was suspended after Haiti's first attempt at democratic elections in more than three decades ended in a massacre in November 1987.
 
Two Theories
The sudden turn of events seemed to confirm the suspicions of many Haitians that General Avril never intended to hand over power to a civilian.
Just what motivated him is not clear, but two theories are gaining adherents. One is that Haiti's democratic leaders had demonstrated their weakness by failing to gain public support for a general strike recently and he believed he could move against them without raising a general protest. So far that has proved true. He wanted to get rid of key political leaders, the theory goes, before the election process started in late April with voting for municipal councils.
The second theory, less fully formed, is that General Avril was responding to demands for more financial benefits from members of the Presidential Guard, which is his main base of power and which put down an attempt to overthrow him last April.
Enlisted men in the Presidential Guard brought General Avril to power on Sept. 17, 1988, after turning against President Henri Namphy. Until Friday night, Joseph Hebreux, a young former medic who had been promoted to sergeant major, had worked at General Avril's side and lived with his wife in a suite in the Presidential Palace. Sergeant Major Hebreux represented the interests of the enlisted men and, at least symbolically, indicated that they had a share in power of the presidency.
 
Economy Doing Badly
On Friday, Sergeant Major Hebreux quietly went from being the highest ranking enlisted man to adjutant, the lowest ranking commissioned officer, and was reassigned to an obscure post at army headquarters.
Haiti's economy has been shriveling. Economists say that it has been poorly managed under General Avril and that money from some state enterprises has been diverted to the military.
One Haitian with contacts in the military said General Avril led the Presidential Guard to believe that a trip to Taiwan this month would yield millions in aid that would benefit them. But diplomats say he apparently returned empty-handed.
While General Avril was in Taiwan, three civic leaders sent a message to the Government in Taipei saying no agreements with the general would be considered binding on the Haitian people. Diplomats say General Avril knew he was unlikely to receive financial aid from the Nationalist Chinese. But in an airport speech back in Haiti, he attributed the financial failure of his mission to the civic leaders. One of them, Dr. Louis Roy, was exiled on Sunday. Another, Antoine Izmery, was arrested on Tuesday morning.
The United States, France and Canada condemned the crackdown and Francois Benoit, Haiti's Ambassador to Washington, resigned, declaring he no longer believed that General Avril would preside over fair elections.
 
Behavior Called Indefensible
Echoing blunt criticism from Washington, Alvin P. Adams, the American Ambassador in Haiti, described General Avril's behavior as ''indefensible and outrageous.'' He indicated, however, that the United States was holding out hope that General Avril would reverse himself. ''We hope ways can be found to restore the status quo ante, meaning to restore and to enhance confidence in the electoral process,'' Mr. Adams said in an interview with several foreign reporters.
General Avril has made no public statements on the crisis, but Interior Minister Romulus suggested on television on Tuesday night that the Government would go ahead with local and legislative elections in the next few months and that after a national assembly had been formed some of the exiled political leaders might be permitted to return to take part in presidential elections in the fall.
Distrust of General Avril was widespread when he was installed as President in an enlisted men's coup on Sept. 17, 1988. He had spent almost his entire army career as an adviser and confidant to Francois Duvalier and his son, Jean-Claude, as they terrorized and plundered Haiti. The Duvalier Government was overthrown in February 1986.
General Avril, who became a millionaire, negotiated weapons and equipment purchases from abroad and had close ties to the electricity company and the national flour mills, two of the Government's most lucrative businesses. But he began to win some support by promising he would lead Haiti to ''irreversible democracy.''
Last fall, however, violence, some of it directed at political activists, began to increase. Some diplomats and Haitians following politics here say they now believe the violence was part of an overall plan to prevent or limit elections this year.

HEADLINE: Wider Search Is Seen In Mail-Bombing Case

BYLINE: By RONALD SMOTHERS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ENTERPRISE, Ala., Jan. 24

 BODY:
A Federal investigation into mail bombings that killed a judge and a civil rights lawyer appeared today to be widening, with one law-enforcement official saying new agents had been assigned to this small town that has become the center of the case.
Publicly, officials of the Federal Bureau of Investigation in Washington declined to comment on reports that Robert Wayne O'Ferrell, who operates a salvage and army surplus store here, had failed a lie-detector test. Privately, other Government officials do not dispute accounts that he failed such a test in some important areas. But these officials also emphasized that Mr. O'Ferrell, a 56-year-old lifelong resident of Enterprise, had not been singled out as the chief suspect. 
On Monday, Mr. O'Ferrell became the object of the first search warrants issued in the case when investigators poring through court files found a letter he had typed. It related to a lawsuit he had filed that ultimately involved one of the bombing victims, Federal Judge Robert S. Vance, who sat on the Court of Appeals for the 11th Circuit, in Atlanta.
Judge Vance was killed by a bomb that had been mailed to his Birmingham, Ala., home in December.
 
Fresh Reinforcements Arrive
Federal investigators here remained silent on their investigation, but Tom Moore, a spokesman for the F.B.I.'s Birmingham office, said that while some investigators had left, fresh reinforcements had come in and were likely to remain through the week.
Mr. O'Ferrell started today much as he always has, except that he was being watched by hordes of reporters and television cameramen. He strode across the cluttered yard into a red shed for buckets and food for four yapping puppies, four dogs, two horses and a pony.
''I hope today or tomorrow will wind it up,'' he said of the searches on his property and that of his relatives and the hours of questioning, lie-detector tests and taking of blood samples. ''They ain't found nothing, and you can't keep looking when you ain't found nothing.''
 
N.A.A.C.P. Was Target
In addition to the bomb that killed Judge Vance, an explosive device killed a Savannah, Ga., civil rights lawyer in December. Two other bombs were removed safely from the Atlanta offices of the 11th Circuit Court and from the offices of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People in Jacksonville, Fla.
A number of people are said to be under surveillance. Mr. O'Ferrell reportedly came to attention because he had sued his former employer, the Gulf Life Insurance Company of Jacksonville, in a case that was ultimately rejected by Judge Vance's court.
The Associated Press quoted Mr. O'Ferrell as saying, ''I have not been told I am a suspect and have not been told I failed a lie-detector test.''
 
Some Residents Are Skeptical
Many residents said they find Mr. O'Ferrell an unlikely focus in the case. He is a religious man, said Carole Green, who works at the Sessions Company peanut warehouse near Mr. O'Ferrell's own store.
Later today, Mr. O'Ferrell lost patience with the journalists surrounding his home. He threatened to call the police if onlookers did not say off his property, and he posted ''No Trespassing'' signs.
Impatience could be felt throughout this southeastern Alabama town of 20,000 residents. Many residents seemed torn between curiosity about the investigation's progress and anger at the unwelcome attention.
Lynn Sullivant, the secretary to Police Chief Tim Byrd, scowled at the ever-ringing telephone and said, as others did, that she was ''just trying to get back to normal.''
 
Tidbits of Local History
''Of course, they feel that it reflects badly on the town,'' said Wallace Goodman, publisher of the local newspaper, The Enterprise Ledger.
But Mayor Jacqueline Thompson said that the town was accustomed to taking ''disaster and turning it into a positive.'' Enterprise, she said, is the only town in the country that has a monument to a pest, the dreaded boll weevil that devastated the city's major crop and cotton-ginning industry at the turn of the century.
The event forced farmers to diversify their crops with peanuts and corn, saving the soil and, in the long run, the economy. Thus a tribute: an Italian-made fountain, featuring a robed woman holding aloft a large carapaced boll weevil was erected in the main intersection.
Enterprise is the main population center of Coffee County, an area that is jokingly called U.C.L.A. for the ''upper corner of lower Alabama.''

HEADLINE: Washington Talk;
Panama Invasion Costly In a Far Wider Theater

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24

 BODY:
The domestic political verdict is in:
President Bush's standing with the American electorate has benefited enormously from the invasion of Panama on Dec. 20. Opinion surveys demonstrate conclusively that, as usual, voters in this country have responded favorably to a decisive military stroke by a President.
But more than a month after Mr. Bush sent airborne forces into the little Central American state, other questions remain open: Will democracy take root in Panama, where it has so often withered in the past? Will the Bush Administration be able to convict Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega in a Florida court? Will his arrest have any lasting impact on international drug traffic?
And it is clear already that the operation has cost the United States a pretty penny abroad - more, perhaps, than Washington anticipated. 
In Western Europe, where the President is widely faulted for passivity in his approach to what Europeans consider the overriding issue of the day - the historic changes in the Soviet Union and its former satellite states in eastern Europe - the invasion of Panama did not strike most foreign-policy experts as evidence of a new boldness by Mr. Bush.
Instead, it seemed, as one diplomat here put it, like ''one more step in the decline of the American empire, with the United States, like the British, reduced to bashing little guys.''
The reaction in Latin America has been, if anything, worse.
While Latin leaders recognized that the ''accepted'' remedies for the Noriegas of the hemisphere had failed, with both the Organization of American States and initiatives by groups of Latin nations failing miserably, they were displeased by the clumsiness of American commanders, especially the invasion of Nicaraguan diplomatic property, and what many of them saw as mindless American self-congratulation.
A senior Latin American representative here asked the other day: ''Can't the United States deal quietly and quickly with sticky problems? Must it beat its own chest so hard?'' In other words, what had played so well at home, ample promotion of a quick victory with few American casualties over a universally disliked foe, raised others' hackles.
An early casualty of the Panama invasion was the Administration's vaunted plan to station United States warships off the Colombian coast to intercept drug runners. Colombia didn't like the idea at all. In the pre-Panama climate, it might have swallowed its objections; in the post-Panama atmosphere, the United States had to do the swallowing.
Recognizing what harm had been done, Mr. Bush announced on Jan. 5 that Vice President Dan Quayle, who had worked the phones during the hours after the invasion in an effort to assuage Latin feelings, would visit several countries in the region for some ''very, very important diplomacy.'' In fact, Mr. Quayle will begin on Friday a trip to three countries that are safely in the American camp -Jamaica, Honduras and Panama itself.
Not one is a major factor in hemispheric affairs, and not one needs any convincing about the utility of what happened in December, so the journey has lost its meaning.
Presidents Carlos Salinas de Gortari of Mexico and Carlos Andres Perez of Venezuela made it clear, after weeks of talks, that a visit from Mr. Quayle wouldn't be welcome. The White House could hardly send the Vice President anyway. A few people there remember the abuse that earlier Presidential emissaries, like Richard M. Nixon and Nelson A. Rockefeller, suffered in Latin America when they had the temerity to visit at times of hostility toward Washington.
Administration cheerleaders, ignoring Mr. Bush's earlier comments about the mission's importance, about how urgent it was for Mr. Quayle to ''personally deliver'' the President's message of good will, now say the timing of the trip and its itinerary don't matter much. More candid officials within the Government are speaking of ''serious miscalculations'' - not only in estimating the depth of Latin displeasure but also in planning to deal with it.
''As we learned,'' an American diplomat with long experience in Latin America said today, ''there wasn't any quick, clean, cost-free way to get rid of Noriega. There isn't any quick, clean, cost-free way to assuage the Latins' feelings, either. We'll have to win their confidence back the hard way: help them economically, stay out of their politics and wait.''

HEADLINE: Bush to Seek $1.2 Billion For a Bigger Drug War

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE

 BODY:
As part of an additional $1.2 billion he proposes to add to the nation's budget for the war on drugs, President Bush plans a 50 percent increase in money for the military to intensify efforts to halt international drug smuggling.
But Mr. Bush's increase for next year is not as much as the Democrats are seeking.
Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr., chairman of the Judiciary Committee, will offer today a long Democratic counter proposal calling for an increase of more than $5 billion in current spending in many new areas. In the introduction, the Delaware Democrat emphasized that his plan was not a ''wholesale rejection of the President's approach'' but would take the debate one step farther. 
Bush Administration officials said yesterday that the President's plan, which is the second phase of a new national drug policy announced last September, makes some major changes and adds more details, including specific dollar figures for the fiscal year 1991, starting Oct. 1. The current budget is $8.8 billion.
 
Dispute Over the Effect
Democratic leaders and experts in the drug field have contended that the national strategy to combat drug abuse has had little effect thus far. Administration officials say it is still too soon to see a major change but one of them, speaking on condition that he not be identified, said: ''The first strategy was the broad plan. This is how we're going to win the drug war.''
The new proposals, to be announced by the President today at a luncheon in Washington with newspaper editors and publishers, underwent at least four drafts and have been closely guarded at the White House because of President Bush's penchant for secrecy. But in interviews, Administration officials involved in writing the document disclosed several key elements:
* As part of the Pentagon's efforts to play an increased role in fighting drugs, that agency's anti-drug budget would increase to $1.2 billion from slightly more than $800 million in the current fiscal year. The military would use nearly a third of the money for the American program to help the cocaine source countries of Colombia, Peru and Bolivia, which received $261.2 million this year.
* A multi-agency drug intelligence center would be established to coordinate all intelligence information involving domestic and international drug trafficking.
* The New York, Miami, Los Angeles and Houston metropolitan areas and the Southwestern border will be designated for a special infusion of money because of their particularly serious drug problems. Federal officials said probably far less than $100 million would be divided roughly equally by the areas next year.
* The drug treatment efforts in Federal, state and local prisons would be intensified. More money would be available for Federal prisons for treatment programs, and agencies would be encouraged in some cases to shift funds from treatment programs outside the prison population to programs for prisoners. State and local governments would be encouraged to put more of their Federal block grant money into drug treatment programs at their jails and prisons.
* The Customs Service would again be allowed to open its own drug investigations and have more authority to make arrests under drug laws, as it did before the Drug Enforcement Administration was created in 1973.
* Pilot programs, including one site in New York City and another in New York State, would be selected for large drug-treatment ''campuses'' in which addicts could get in-patient and outpatient services and job training.
William J. Bennett, director of the Office of National Drug Control Policy, had requested a budget increase of about 30 percent over the current fiscal year, Administration officals said.
 
Revival of Former Plan
The multi-agency center in the plan had been proposed in the strategy announced by Mr. Bush in September, but was shelved in part because Attorney General Dick Thornburgh had complained that he had not been named chairman. In a compromise that represents a small victory for Mr. Thornburgh in his tug-of-war with Mr. Bennett, Mr. Thornburgh was named chairman but the center will be run daily by an executive director, who will be selected by all the agencies involved.
The 1988 drug law requires an updated strategy by Feb. 1 of each year. In addition to the blueprint that will be made public today, the White House next week is planning to release another document that lays out in even greater detail the Administration proposal for drug spending in fiscal 1991.
Senator Biden's plan, prepared by the Democratic staff of the Judiciary Committee and International Narcotics Control Caucus, puts a greater emphasis on helping hard core drug users rather than occasional users, and on using economics tools rather than the military to curb cocaine production in the Andean nations.

HEADLINE: Study of Teen-Agers Hints Gain for Those Having Abortions

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BALTIMORE, Jan. 23

 BODY:
A federally financed study of unmarried, sexually active teen-age girls has found that those who obtained abortions did better economically and educationally and had fewer subsequent pregnancies than those who chose to bear children. Those who had abortions even fared better than those who were not pregnant at the start of the research project.
The findings of the four-year study, conducted by the Johns Hopkins School of Hygiene and Public Health, suggests for the first time that the experience of choosing an abortion may have beneficial results for some adolescent girls. A total of 334 girls from Baltimore, 17 years old and younger, participated in the study, the first to compare teen-agers who obtain abortions with those who were never pregnant in the way they fare later, experts said. 
Dr. Laurie Schwab Zabin, the principal author, said the study did not conclude that young women were helped by having an abortion. ''I don't think it's fair to say that the abortion experience did all these glorious things for them,'' said Dr. Zabin, an associate professor at Johns Hopkins. ''I hardly think we should tout it as something that everyone should go out and do.''
There were a number of factors that complicated the task of interpreting the data. For example, those who chose to end the pregnancy had better educated parents and higher educational ambitions than those in the two other groups, so their superior achievement may not be attributable to abortion.
But Dr. Zabin said the group that had abortions came out ahead of the other two even when researchers statistically allowed for these variables.
 
Differences Held to Be Striking
And she said the differences between those who ended their pregnancies and those who did not or were not pregnant were so striking that the possiblity of benefits could not be dismissed.
''Clearly the abortion experience is not setting these kids back,'' she said. ''If anything, it's probably giving them some sense of control over their lives so that they can move on and do the things that are important.''
The study, financed by the National Institute of Child Health and Human Development, one of the National Institutes of Health, reported on black teen-agers who came in for pregnancy tests at two family planning clinics in Baltimore in 1985 and 1986. The young women were interviewed before they knew the results of their tests so researchers could establish baseline data on educational achievements and expectations, economic levels, psychological traits and other variables.
Once results were known, the young women were divided into three groups: 141 who chose to have an abortion, 93 who bore the child, and 100 who turned out not to be pregnant. The groups were then followed for two years.
The researchers found that 90 percent of the young women who had abortions had graduated from high school or were still in school. By contrast, 68 percent of those who bore children and 79 percent of those whose pregnancy test were negative completed high school or had not dropped out.
Also, those teen-agers who had abortions were more likely to find jobs, and thus were less likely to be in a household that is receiving food stamps or Medicaid payments than their counterparts in the other two groups, the study said.
The study will be published the November/December issue of Family Planning Perspectives magazine, published by the Alan Guttmacher Institute.
 
Psychological Impact
It found that 4.5 percent of those choosing abortion experienced an adverse psychological change two years after the event, as against 5.5 percent of those who bore children and 10 percent of young women with negative pregnancy tests. This indicates that while the decision to have an abortion provided few psychological benefits, it did not, as anti-abortion groups often claim, cause any emotional damage.
The research team also found those who had abortions were more likely to use contraception later than the teen-agers in the other groups, and that they were less likely to become pregnant later. The study found that 37 percent of those who had abortions became pregnant within 18 months. By comparison, 47 percent of the girls who had babies were pregnant within 18 months of the birth of their baby, and 58 percent of those who were not pregnant became pregnant within 18 months of their examinations.
Officials of anti-abortion organizations denounced the study, contending that its methodology was flawed.
Olivia Gans, president of the American Victims of Abortion, faulted the study for only following women for two years. Ms. Gans asserted that ''postabortion stress syndrome'' often does not show up until five years after the abortion.
The study weakens the argument often made by anti-abortion forces that abortions produces severe psychological trauma in women, an assertion that is generally made on the basis of anecdotal evidence.
 
Koop Letter About Review
In 1987, at a meeting with a group of anti-abortion advocates, President Ronald Reagan directed Surgeon General C. Everett Koop to prepare a comprehensive report on the health effects of abortion. Last January Dr. Koop declined to release the review. Instead, he wrote Mr. Reagan that studies on the psychological effects of the procedure had serious flaws and ''could not provide conclusive data about the health effects of abortion on women.''
In most of the studies the women were reached after they had abortions. Thus there is scant data on the subjects' personality traits, or psychological stresses before they became pregnant. Also, few studies in this area use a control group. If it does, there are often economic or social differences between the groups that distort the findings. To accurately measure psychological effects, Dr. Koop said, would require a five-year study that begins looking at some women before they conceive. Such a study would cost approximately $100 million.
The Johns Hopkins study tries to get around these flaws by interviewing their subjects before they knew the results of their pregnancy tests, and by studying a relatively uniform groups -inner-city black teen-agers. ''That's the strength of this study,'' said Brian Wilcox, director of Public Interest Legislation for the American Psychological Association. ''It's the first to have such a nice clean research design.''

HEADLINE: IN THE NATION;
The Bishop And the Chairman

BYLINE: By Tom Wicker

 BODY:
Governor Cuomo of New York is in ''serious risk of going to hell'' for his support of abortion rights - so says a Roman Catholic bishop who is serving a 10-day jail sentence for trying to block the entrance to an abortion clinic in Albany.
Bishop Austin Vaughan of Newburgh, N.Y., did not speak for the Roman Catholic Church or its hierarchy, but his ecclesiastical threat to Mr. Cuomo inevitably raises the specter of religious intervention in the politics of Catholic voters. And his remark, as well as the act that landed him in jail, suggest the extremes to which some anti-abortion activists are willing to go in order to impose their beliefs on the rest of us.
Mr. Cuomo, to his credit, defended both the bishop's right to speak out and women's ''constitutional right to abortion.'' 
Bishop Vaughan's strong views and willingness to act on them also suggests why Lee Atwater, the Republican national chairman, is having trouble trying to convince his party of one of the oldest, most necessary tenets of traditional two-party politics - that each of the two parties is and must be an ''umbrella'' under which people of varying opinions and ideology can shelter.
That's not a tradition congenial to rigid anti-abortion forces. But were it not so, in a nation of such vastly differing economic interests, ethnicity and social attitudes, the American political spectrum would be divided into dozens, perhaps hundreds, of small limited-interest or regional parties, many of them bitterly or even violently opposed to and unwilling to cooperate with others. Whatever else may be said for or against the two-party system, it usually has spared the nation that kind of dangerously fractionated politics.
Mr. Atwater would not have to be much of a student of history to understand that; nor need he reach far into the past for an apt metaphor. Only 20-odd years ago, President Lyndon Johnson was insisting that his party was a ''big tent'' covering all sorts of voters and ideas.
The Republican chairman, however, has not undertaken to teach his party an elementary lesson of American politics for purely educational reasons. Instead, he knows and wants Republicans to realize that in last year's three major elections, Democratic candidates who took a pro-choice position on abortion defeated rivals who were perceived as anti-choice.
Mr. Atwater's President, moreover, vetoed three bills last year ostensibly on anti-abortion grounds, and now maintains in the bully pulpit a pronounced personal stance against abortion and using Federal funds for that purpose. Besides, the Republican platform commits the party to a constitutional amendment that would end a woman's right to choose abortion.
For many years, Republicans were able with little political cost to oppose that right and reap anti-abortion support, because pro-choice voters believed such an amendment was unlikely to pass and that the party could do little to interfere with an established constitutional right. Last year, however, the Supreme Court made it possible for state legislatures to restrict abortion rights; the once-empty Republican anti-abortion threat became suddenly all too real to women and families everywhere.
Consequently, Mr. Atwater is trying to tell his party that to be monolithically anti-abortion has become risky politics. Instead of shunning anyone favoring choice, Republicans should welcome under their umbrella all shades of opinion, in the traditional manner of American political parties.
Even Mr. Bush, though apparently fearing to change once again his own polymorphous view, allowed his press secretary to say that ''there is room within the party for varying points of view.'' A story in Newsweek that the women in the Bush family, including the First Lady, are pro-choice makes the same political point: There's such room even in the White House, folks.
It would be a neat trick if Mr. Atwater and Mr. Bush could persuade the nation that their party is not necessarily anti-abortion - even if Mr. Bush is, and even if the party platform is too - while retaining the anti-abortion votes that have been a major element in Republican political success.
The elections next fall will provide a test. But what will happen when Republicans gather under their big tent in 1992 to write a new platform? Will they scratch the anti-abortion plank, turning their backs on a staple of their political support? Or will they stand defiantly on their position as the party of opposition to women's right of choice? That's a conundrum to challenge even the occult powers of Republican spin doctors.

HEADLINE: The Talk of the South Fork;
Baymen Find No Warmth This Winter

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SPRINGS, L.I., Jan. 24

 BODY:
The bushel of steamers that Tom Lester harvested last week is still in his cellar, and it is starting to stink. ''I can't sell them,'' said Mr. Lester, a burly 48-year-old baymen whose day's work normally fetches between $75 and $100. ''No one wants them at any price.''
The market for clams and other shellfish has collapsed here on the South Fork since last week, when the State Department of Environmental Conservation banned shellfishing in 56,000 acres in Suffolk County. Pollution isn't the problem. A shortage of state inspectors to certify the waters is. 
Winter on the South Fork - the towns of Southampton and East Hampton -brings a welcome calm to year-round residents who live in a love-hate relationship with the summer tourists and second-homeowners, whose dollars drive this region's economy. Now is also the time when local concerns, like the plight of the baymen, attract more attention.
At a court hearing today in Hauppauge, state officials promised to speed the testing in 500 acres of particularly rich clamming beds in East Hampton and Southampton. If the waters prove clean, the baymen might be able to resume harvesting there by Feb. 5.
But for the baymen, a dwindling breed who rely on $350 a week or so from clamming to tide them over until spring, this winter will be one of the leanest in recent memory. ''The damage has already been done,'' Mr. Lester said. ''People's confidence has been ruined.''
In recent years, man-made regulations and natural catastrophes have robbed the baymen of two other catches: striped bass and bay scallops. Now, with clams and oysters unjustly suspect, the baymen say, a way of life may soon be gone.
''We've been getting beaten down, peg by peg,'' said Billy Havens, 37, who has worked on the waters here since he was 7 years old. ''We can't hang on much longer.''
 
Crossed Swordfish
Grilled, broiled or blackened, a moist, meaty swordfish steak has increasingly become the fish of choice for many American diners.
That appetite has set off a boom in swordfishing - 750 licensed longline boats in East Coast waters now, compared with about 35 boats 10 years ago -and a resulting 60 percent drop in the number of mature swordfish in the same period, Federal officials say.
Alarmed by evidence of overfishing, the National Marine Fisheries Service is expected to impose emergency swordfishing restrictions in the western Atlantic within the next few weeks. The limitations - which could set a minimum size, ban night fishing and close waters with large numbers of undersized fish -would stay in effect until a permanent fishing-reduction plan is adopted later this year.
For the five dozen fishing vessels in the South Fork's oceangoing fleet, the plan is tantamount to a moratorium on their livelihood. ''I'll be out of business,'' said Bill Modica, 28, who is captain of the 58-foot Midnight Sun out of Montauk and who relies on swordfishing for 70 percent of his catch.
Any kind of fishing restrictions sends shock waves through the boat dealers, marine suppliers, bar owners and restaurateurs of Montauk, a seaside village of 3,100 people.
''Sure, there's a need for conservation, but they're talking about wiping us off the face of the map,'' said Richard Gosman, one of the largest dock operators and fish wholesalers in Montauk.
Fishermen here complain that the restrictions would cover only boats from the United States. Vessels from Spain, Canada and Japan, the other large swordfishing nations, would be free to continue their free-fishing ways and increase exports to this country.
''The fishermen have legitimate complaints,'' said David Crestin, deputy director of the Office of Fishery Conservation and Management at the Marine Fisheries Service. ''But if the United States wants to take a leadership role in conservation, we can't sit back.''
 
New Look at Ruling
Since Colonial days, New York State has recognized the Shinnecock Indians as a tribe. Now the 350 Shinnecocks who live on an 800-acre reservation in Southampton are debating whether to seek tribal status with the Federal Government.
On the surface, the issue is not cultural identity but gaining another source of money and, perhaps, assistance: The designation would make the tribe eligible for education, health and governmental administration programs under the Bureau of Indian Affairs. The Shinnecocks are already eligible for other Federal aid, like nutrition programs for the elderly.
But perhaps more important, many Shinnecocks are questioning whether their traditional form of tribal government - three male trustees elected by the men of the tribe - is fit to deal with the same complex problems that all communities face today: land preservation, family violence, drug and alcohol abuse.
''The tribal government is not up to that challenge,'' said Roberta Hunter, 38, a member of a newly formed women's group on the reservation. The group is pressing the trustees for a full public discussion of the Federal recognition issue, the right for women to vote in tribal affairs and a more active role in regaining ancient Shinnecock lands.
''There's plenty of potential here,'' said David Bunn Martine, a 29-year-old painter who has advocated a more progressive government. ''But too many people are satisfied with the status quo.''
 
The News and Then Some
Just how many articles about zoning boards and chambers of commerce can anyone really read? That's the question that people in Sag Harbor are asking these days as a battle of weekly newspapers in this old whaling village shows no signs of waning.
It started a little over a year ago when Gardner Cowles 3d, the scion of the Midwestern newspaper family, bought the 129-year-old Sag Harbor Express. The publisher of a venerable weekly in nearby East Hampton, Helen S. Rattray, jumped into the fray by starting a competing weekly, the Sag Harbor Herald. All this for a village of 2,800 people.
Add to that two other larger weeklies, the East Hampton Star and the Southampton Press, and there is a local-news glut. ''If you want to keep up, you feel overwhelmed sometimes,'' said Lorraine Dusky, an author and member of the village zoning board. She said she reads all four weeklies regularly.
Business owners complain that they cannot afford to advertise in both village papers, but most residents like the competition. ''It either makes the news twice as interesting or twice as boring,'' said Ted Conklin, owner of the American Hotel. ''There's just not that much to report.''

HEADLINE: A New Yankee Stadium Is Proposed in the Bronx

BYLINE: By DENNIS HEVESI

 BODY:
The Bronx Borough President proposed yesterday that the city and state build a new stadium for the New York Yankees at Ferry Point Park, a 414-acre site at the north end of the Bronx-Whitestone Bridge.
''We need to build the Yankees a state-of-the-art, first-class baseball stadium in the Bronx,'' said the Borough President, Fernando Ferrer. ''I think Ferry Point Park is an outstanding location because of its proximity to the bridge and major traffic arteries.''
Mr. Ferrer's proposal focuses attention on concerns that the Yankees, whose lease on the city-owned ''House that Ruth Built'' expires in 12 years, might follow other professional sports teams to New Jersey. An agreement in principle that would have kept the team in Yankee Stadium until the year 2032 was signed more than two years ago, but was never made final. 
On Tuesday night, during a broadcast of the WCBS radio program ''Ask the Mayor,'' Mayor David N. Dinkins said he hoped to meet soon with the Yankees owner, George M. Steinbrenner 3d. Mr. Dinkins said he intended ''to make it plain to him that we will do all that we are able to accommodate his concerns because we need our Yankees.''
 
'30 Years Is a Long Lease'
Mr. Steinbrenner said last night that he had spoken to Mr. Dinkins and that they would meet tomorrow. Asked about the impasse over the agreement signed in October 1987, Mr. Steinbrenner said the Yankees and former Mayor Edward I. Koch had encountered two obstacles.
Mr. Steinbrenner said the former baseball commissioner, Peter Ueberroth, ''told us that he would not approve any extraordinarily long leases, and certainly 30 years is a long lease.''
Also, Mr. Steinbrenner said, ''We have been promised many, many things from the city and, for some reason, they just didn't get done.''
Under the agreement that would have extended the Yankees' lease until 2032, the city and state were to finance jointly about $90 million in improvements in and around Yankee Stadium. These included construction of a Metro-North railroad station and a 3,200-space parking garage as well as new skyboxes and a restaurant at the stadium. Mr. Steinbrenner said he had proposed to Mr. Koch that the Yankees pay for the improvements inside the stadium, but that without a final agreement on the lease Mr. Koch had refused.
 
'A Passive Park'
Asked about Mr. Ferrer's proposal to build a 75,000-seat, domed stadium at a cost of about $200 million, Mr. Steinbrenner said, ''That's the first I've heard about it.'' The general counsel for the Yankees, David Sussman, said, ''Any proposal that the city would make is something that the Yankees would have to evaluate very seriously.''
Mr. Dinkins's press secretary, Albert Scardino, said the Mayor ''has to look at the proposal.''
''Part of the park is landfill, and without some engineering effort it could not support a permanent structure of any size,'' Mr. Scardino said. ''But it's possible.''
Under the agreement that was never made final, the New York State Urban Development Corporation would have helped pay for the improvements to Yankee Stadium. The corporation's chairman, Vincent Tese, declined to comment on Mr. Ferrer's proposal, adding, ''This is the first I've heard of it.''
 
Stadium Called a Boon
Mr. Ferrer called Ferry Point Park a ''passive park, which means that it's not anywhere being utilized to its full potential.'' A baseball stadium, he said, ''would not be intrusive to the community and would be a tremendous boon to the Bronx, the city and to the Yankees.''
The park is near two highways, the Hutchinson River Parkway and Interstate 95, but the closest subway station - Westchester Square on the IRT's No. 6 Pelham Bay Park line - is about a mile away. Asked about that problem, Mr. Ferrer's spokesman, Clint Roswell, said, ''There could be some sort of shuttle hookup by bus or, in the future, you might be able to extend the subway a little down the line.''
The city's departing Parks Commissioner, Henry J. Stern, said Ferry Point Park is largely undeveloped and lightly used. It has a ball field, a field for flying model planes and sitting areas, he said.
Marc Matsil, the Parks Department's director of natural resources, said ''a small percentage'' of the park is wetlands. ''It does have a coastline with native grasses,'' he said.
Mr. Stern said, ''We have no objection to the plan, provided our park acreage is replaced acre for acre, because we don't like a net loss.''
Asked what would happen to the old Yankee Stadium, Mr. Ferrer said: ''You turn it into a municipal stadium for intercollegiate and high school athletics, as well as for concerts. It still has tremendous economic, recreational and sports potential for the city.''
