HEADLINE: President's News Conference on Foreign and Domestic Issues

 BODY:
Following is a transcript of President Bush's news conference yesterday in Washington, as recorded by The New York Times:
 
OPENING STATEMENT
Good morning, good morning. Well, as you know, I'll soon present my budget to the Congress, and as I prepare to do so, it strikes me that our nation faces challenges on many fronts. So, let's give each the attention it deserves.
Tomorrow I'm going to announce the second phase of our strategy to fight drugs in the schools, in the streets of America. The future of this country depends on whether we can give our children a chance to grow up drug-free. And, secondly, I will soon present our plan to restructure America's defenses in the wake of the dramatic changes that are taking place abroad. And I'm proposing a defense budget that begins the transition to a restructured military - a new strategy that is more flexible, more geared to contingencies outside of Europe while continuing to meet our inescapable responsibility to NATO and to maintaining the global balance. 
And finally, Secretary Brady and Director Darman and Chairman Boskin will put the details of our budget before the American people. And as that occurs, other members of the Administration, the Cabinet, key agencies will provide an in-depth outline of their efforts to address the many challenges of caring for the afflicted and uplifting the poor, cleaning the environment, educating our kids, as well as other important issues.
All of this is preparatory to the State of the Union one week from today, in which I will speak to the broader issues that we face as a nation. Cabinet Status for E.P.A. There are two items that I want to mention here today and then take some questions.
First, I've decided that the environmental challenges that face America and the world are so important that they must be addressed from the highest level of our government. And at the beginning of this century, President Roosevelt - Theodore Roosevelt - helped pave the way for the establishment of a national park system. Twenty years ago, President Nixon established the E.P.A. -Environmental Protection Agency - and - by executive order - that is now one of the largest and most important regulatory agencies in the Government, and today I'd like to announce another step forward in this important tradition of support for conservation and environmental protection.
Many countries have environmental ministers and now in - with Cabinet status - and I'm convinced that that Cabinet status will help influence the world's environmental policy.
So, with so many difficult decisions ahead, I'll need Bill Reilly's counsel. I'll need him sitting at my side in the Cabinet and I'm pleased to endorse the elevation of the E.P.A. to Cabinet status by creating a Department of the Environment.
Senators Glenn and Bill Roth, chairmen and ranking members of the government -Senate Government Affairs Committee -have introduced legislation that would create this department. Congressmen Conyers and Horton are working on similar legislation. And I look forward to working with them and other interested members of the House and Senate to enact legislation that would bring E.P.A. to the Cabinet table where it now belongs.
 
Commitment to Chinese Students
And now I'd like to address one other issue that I know is foremost on your minds. Every American should know. I want to take this opportunity to state this as strongly as I can, that I will not break faith with the Chinese students here.
I made that very clear from the very beginning and right after Tiananmen I moved to protect the Chinese students in this country. Not one was sent back. They were safe then and they are safe now and they will be safe in the future.
And when Congress passed the Pelosi bill last fall, I was faced with a choice. If I signed the bill, the students would still be safe but China would retaliate and cut off future student exchanges. You see, I think the exchanges have brought forward the reforms that have taken place in China, if you look back over your shoulder for a starting point and compare it to the Cultural Revolution day.
Some of the reforms have taken place as steps - have been taken forward - and, regrettably, Tiananmen was a step, gigantic step, back. I want to keep contact. I do not want isolation.
If I vetoed the bill, I could take action to provide the students with even greater protection while keeping the door open for more Chinese scholars to study here. And the price of the Pelosi bill is lost opportunity for the Chinese scholars of tomorrow. And people should understand that very, very clearly.
The bill is totally unnecessary. The long-term policy consequences are potentially great and Congress, in my view, will have only itself to blame. I can understand their emotion, but we've got to look at policy and we've got to be fair in what has already been accomplished by the executive order. It's a strong message. I want it to be seen exactly that way.
And now I'd be delighted to take any questions. Terry and then Helen.
 
QUESTIONS AND ANSWERS
Gorbachev Chances of Survival
Q. Mr. President, how serious a crisis is the nationalist rebellion in Azerbaijan for President Gorbachev, and what are the chances that he'll survive this test and the challenge in the Baltics?
A. Well, I think the answer to your question unfolds every day. We don't really know, and it is serious. Gorbachev has always indicated a desire to restrain - for peaceful change inside the Soviet Union, and I refer to what he said on the Baltics. He's faced with an ethnic problem, and an internal problem of enormous dimensions. But I don't know, Terry, I can't make predictions about that. But I know that I hope that he not only survives but stays strong, because I think it is in our interest that perestroika succeed and go forward.
Q. Could I just follow up and ask you: Do you think that he's gone too far in the crackdown in Baku?
A. Anytime you have a use of force and a loss of life, we are concerned. But I don't believe I can judge that question right now.
 
Drug War and Banning Guns
Q. Mr. President, you're very concerned with drugs, and drugs are intimately connected now to guns. What is it, what do you tell your grandchildren in why you would ban semiautomatic foreign-made guns and not domestically produced? There were two students who were killed in the last 10 days, high schools students, here. Aren't you deeply concerned? I mean, what is the lethal - legal justification?
A. I am concerned, and I just don't happen to believe that banning of weapons will take them out of the hands of the criminals. And we've seen state law after state law violated by the bad guys getting the weapons. And I believe that, so I don't want to go for more Federal gun control. I'm not going to do it. We've taken some steps that I think are helpful.
Q. But we are sending weapons, though, to Colombia and so forth that are made in this country. How do you stop that?
A. To Colombia?
Q. And to other places where they're getting in.
A. If they're going to the Colombian Government, I wouldn't stop it, and if they're going to the bad guys, we would undergo every possible - follow every possible avenue to stop it. Yes?
 
Outlook on Chinese Relations
Q. Mr. President, back on China for a moment, it appears your veto will be overridden in the House today. That would require Senate action for the job to be complete. I know you met with Senate leaders this morning. Are you confident that just these remarks you've made out here today, and whatever else you may have said, will be enough? Or do you really feel that the Chinese leadership with whom you have dealt for so long kind of let you down here, and didn't give you a strong enough hand?
A. Well, what I did to try to - in talking to the Senate leaders this morning, the Republicans - is to cite certain things, steps that China has taken. They've accepted the Peace Corps volunteers, you see; I think that's good. People say, ''Well, in the face of Tiananmen, that's not good.'' I think it is good because I think cultural contacts, educational contacts will benefit in the long run democracy and reform in China. They've accredited a V.O.A. correspondent; as you know, they were kicked out. They've muted the hostile propaganda against Americans and stopped harassing the U.S. Embassy. That's good; that's important to me as President, who feels a certain responsibility for the people there. They've given some assurances on missile sales; I want to see them follow up, but I think that's positive. They're reopened the Fulbright exchanges. I think that's good and I think that's positive.
And I think if we let Congress have its head and do what is emotionally popular, these things would be changed. They've lifted martial law. I don't know a single member of Congress that if I'd have said to them, ''Look, we think by sending General Scowcroft and Larry Eagleburger over there, we can get martial law lifted. Do you think it's worth it?'' I think most would have said, ''Sure, that would be a good step.'' It happens and we see a lot of criticism of it. They've released 573 people that were detained after last June's events.
You can argue about any one of these points, but I ask the Senate and the House - I'm a little late for that one - the Senate to take a look at these things and put it in the totality of a policy. And, you see, I think there's some real reasons - Asian reasons, if you will: Cambodia and Japan - that we should retain relations with China. That doesn't mean we endorse the lack of human rights.
I tell you, one of the criticisms that gets to me a little, and I vowed - I didn't tell you my New Year's resolution was not to let it get to me - but it's the idea that I don't care about human rights. That is absolutely ridiculous. I want to see China move forward. And some think isolation, don't think so. I think we're handling it pretty well, Brit.
Q. Just to follow up, Mr. President, did you in any way convey to the Chinese leaders the idea that these steps taken so far would be enough to head off this action taken by Congress?
A. We didn't give a timetable, but we've encouraged in every way we can these and more. But I'm just asking that people look at them. I have not seen them - maybe it's my fault - one account on whatever media of these steps put together as a package. Haven't seen one. So I'd like to suggest to the Congress that are debating this to take a hard look at this and see whether it's progress, whether it adds up to anything, or, as some of our critics would say, it's pure, you know, boilerplate. Yes, Lesley?
 
Signal on Trust From Congress
Q. Mr. President, in voting, in the House particularly, you seem to be conceding that that's gone for you. Do you think that there's a problem of trust here with you? Are they saying they don't trust you to go forward on the student thing? After all, you told them you weren't going to have high-level exchanges, and while you were telling them that you were sending a high-level delegation.
A. There weren't any exchange in that. What the exchange was, Lesley, was when the Secretary of Commerce was going to go to China and be an exchange visit arranged by their Commerce Minister. That was canceled.
Q. But they obviously thought it included high-level contacts. The question is, Do you think you have a problem with them not trusting you because of that?
A. No, I don't think it's a question of trust. I think the students have done a very good job presenting their case to the Congress. I think there's some politics involved, crass politics. When you hear name-calling, when you hear people saying ''kowtow''; that is not the kindest word to say, We have an honest policy difference with this President. And so there's some politics involved in this as well, but I think there's some genuine feeling that these students have a very good case. And what I want to do is make the case that the way to continue reforms and have reform go forward is not through isolation and unilateral Congressional action, but through the kinds of contacts that I foresee, and through encouraging the kinds of steps that have already been taken.
 
View of Repression in China
Q. You talk about the lifting of martial law. What about the situation as it exists without the gesture? Are you at all disturbed that the repression goes on?
A. Yes, I'm very much concerned about the status quo, and I was terribly concerned at the time of the Cultural Revolution when we made the original contact with China. And it was a good thing we did because you began, through contacts with the West, to see China pull out of this Middle Kingdom syndrome and move forward. And I think I know enough about it that in China you get a couple of steps forward and then somebody steps back.
And I look at Deng Xiaoping's own history; I think he was out three times and in four. And some will argue, well, he's part of the problem - he's now retired - but the reforms, particularly on the economic side, that brought a new level of prosperity to the Chinese people, really were started by him. So I'm not giving up; I mean I'm not accepting the status quo at all.
And China knows my position in this. But it's - I do think there's some indignation about students, there is some feeling that -I'm talking about the Congress now - there's a lot here of empathy with the students, right here, but I think there's also a dose of political rhetoric up there that certainly has diminished the other side.
And I will readily concede maybe I could have done better, and sooner, in presenting the facts of this case. The Attorney General's doing a good job telling, you know, the differences between the Pelosi bill and what we've already accomplished. But I don't know where we'll come out. But I'm going to keep on working the policy. Yes, over here.
 
Effort to Prevent Recession
Q. Mr. President, given the weakness of the dollar, the turmoil in the financial markets and the recent poor economic indicators, what are you going to do to calm the economy - calm the markets and keep the economy from sliding into recession?
A. Well, one thing I'm not going to do is comment on levels of the market, except to say that there's been a substantial increase over the last year - and some are reading the recent couple of days as corrections, although I gather it recovered a little bit yesterday. And the market has always been an indicator and it's been one that's been read quite positively, but I don't want to get into market levels.
What I do want to do is establish sound policies, and I'm convinced that if we can get the cooperation of Congress that we need on reducing the deficit, that that will go a long way not to market prices but in terms of the fundamentals on the economy. It's slowed down a little, there's a lot of prediction that it'll be slow for a while and then have a rather robust step-up come summer. But I don't know, all I know is that we've got to not bash anybody but get out there and try to enact policies that will help keep this longest recovery in modern history going.
Q. You said that you felt that there is room for further reduction of interest rates. Given the need to attract foreign investments from overseas, their rates are high. How do you square that with your call for lower interest rates?
A. You mean to attract --
Q. Attract more investments to cover the U.S. deficit and yet so we're competing against foreign investments that are --
A. I think that people see the U.S. still, regardless of what's temporary out there, as the safest haven for investment anywhere in the world. And I want to conduct the fiscal policy of this Government so they will continue to see it that way. Yes, John.
 
Chinese Dissident's Status
Q. Going back to the vote on the Chinese student visas - you and your people have been trying to get that vote delayed. Is that because you had some indications from the Chinese they may soon release Fang Lizhi? And if this vote goes against you, will it hurt his chances?
A. No, it is not. But I don't think it'll help his chances. But I would love to see that step taken by the Chinese. But it isn't - there's not a - I think we're reconciled to the fact that the vote will go forward tomorrow in the Senate.
 
Attitude Toward China Card
Q. Have you tried to change your China policy? One thing you never do is talk about the China card. You seem to hate that expression even though when Kissinger and Nixon were doing it, it was considered a master stroke of foreign policy playing the Chinese off against the Soviets. If Gorbachev does fall from power and is succeeded by men whose role model is Joe Stalin, must you then have to play the China card too?
A. I don't think you play a card. I think that's gratuitously offensive to the Soviets and to the Chinese. But one of the reasons I want to stay engaged is that there are geopolitical reasons to have good relations or improved relations even under these unsatisfactory conditions.
And it's going to be hard to do because of the - of the human rights setback. But I want to have some contact. I want to retain contact because as you look around the world - take a look at Cambodia, take a look at Japan; take a look at a lot of countries in the Pacific - China is a key player. And I'd like to think that our representation will have them move forward on the human rights side so we can have a more normalized relationship. Charles.
 
Contacts With Gorbachev
Q. Mr. President, regarding the Soviet Union, have you in the course of these events going on in Baku or any of your senior people - I see General Scowcroft is here - been in touch with Mr. Gorbachev or his people to discuss how severe it is and --
A. Well, we had contact with him. I don't remember when my last contact was with Mr. Gorbachev, but it didn't relate specifically to the Baku.
Q. Could I then follow, sir - ask you to reconcile if you can the position that you've taken that you want Mr. Gorbachev to survive and succeed and on the other hand you have areas of the Soviet Union such as the Baltics that you do not recognize as being part of the Soviet Union and where you say you favor an independent pursuit of their own destiny. Does he succeed if they secede?
A. Well, he - that again - at this juncture the U.S. position is well known and you stated it correctly, that we have not recognized the status of the Baltics. However, what I say that we want to do is to encourage Mr. Gorbachev's stand that peaceful change is the order of the day.
And he is sorting out some very difficult internal problems in these three Baltic countries, and I don't think it helps facilitate things for us to fine-tune all that. They know our position. I talked to him about this, incidentally, at Malta, and the thing I think is that in looking at the Soviet scene there, that he is still adhering as best he can to the concept of peaceful change in the Baltics and that's got to dominate.
 
Reconfirming Poland's Borders
Q. Mr. President, President Jaruzelski of Poland recently suggested that the four big powers reconfirm - or reaffirm - the frontiers of Poland irrespective of whatever happens to West Germany. Would the United States join such a reconfirmation of the frontiers?
A. Well, we have recognized under Helsinki existing borders and I've no problem reiterating that. But whether that requires some kind of a international action on it, I just have no judgment on that. Yes.
 
Summit Meeting in Prague
Q. Mr. President, Havel of Czechoslovakia offered yesterday a summit in Prague with Mr. Gorbachev. Do you think it's a good idea?
A. Listen, I respect him so much and I don't just give him the back of my hand, but we've got a summit set and we have a - we have a very critical agenda that I want to see met -goals that I want to see met. And so I think at this time, that suggestion is not going to work out the way he suggests. But I was rather moved by the suggestion and by the conditions that make the suggestion possible. Who would have dreamed it a year ago, that the conditions inside Czechslovakia would give them less than a, you know - would give them the freedom to make this kind of suggestion. I was rather moved by it, but I don't believe it's going to work for this summit. Ann.
 
Alternative on Social Security
Q. Mr. President, you've opposed the Moynihan Social Security bill strongly. Would you endorse or work for or support a Republican alternative proposed by Congressman Porter that would take the Social Security increases for this to next year and allow people to keep those tax increases and put them in a separate account?
A. The Porter proposal has some interesting ingredients to it. I'm not prepared to endorse it. We have, don't have provision for that in our budget proposals. It's worthy, though, of consideration and some study, but I'm not prepared to endorse that. No, I'm not.
Q. Is that not the first step to privatizing Social Security?
A. Well, I don't think that he would say that it is, that that's the inevitable goal. But it has certain aspects there.
But people are concerned about Social Security, so when you have innovative thinking of that nature, I don't want to just gun it down. I'm not going to support it.
Q. Mr. President, over the last few years there's been large increases in the Social Security tax and even though it's a regressive tax, people supported it or swallowed it because they were told that that was necessary to make the system solvent for the next generation. But now everyone is finding out that in fact that money isn't there any longer and it's been used for debt reduction. Given the fact that people are now realizing that this is happening, do you think it's fair to ask them to continue to pay this increased tax for even one month longer?
The commission that reformed Social Security was well aware of what you just talked about. They considered it. I think the commission included Mr. Moynihan - I may be mistaken, but I think it did - and they considered this point, and we will have some innovative suggestions as we go along here as to how to compensate for this understandable concern on the part of some. But I would for now, for this year - we will not alter the recommendations of that bipartisan commission.
Q. Mr President --
Q. Could I just briefly - do you feel that this increase was sold to people under false premises?
A. No, 'cause I think these were intelligent people wrestling with a very, very difficult problem, and I can't accuse them of selling the commission conclusions as under false cover. Owen and then Ann.
 
Social Security Surplus
Q. Well, as you know the budget deficit has been coming down over the past few years solely because Social Security surplus has been rising and in fact your own budget projections show $200-billion-a-year deficits in the indefinite future when you remove the Social Security surplus. Given the fact that you have such a large deficit in every other program, when will you and the Congress stop bickering and counting gimmicks and deal with this problem that the American public has said for a decade --
A. Thank you for the endorsement of our approach, Owen. We would urge that we stop bickering and go forward with the proposal that we come out with that I think will begin to address itself to Maureen's question that is very sound. And nobody's trying to conceal the fact that the Social Security trust fund is operating at a surplus. There wasn't any concealment by the Speaker of the House, Tip O'Neill, and others that entered into this bipartisan agreement. Ann.
Q. Well, wait a minute. Your own budget proposal that you will unveil on Monday which shows a $64 billion deficit - in fact if you remove Social Security will be close to $450
A. But you're making the argument - the old argument of taking the Social Security trust fund off-budget, and at this juncture we're not prepared to do that. But wait till you see the detail, and I hope you'll see, the American people will see, something here that begins to address itself to these fundamentals that I think are properly being asked about. Ann and then Rita.
 
Bush Family Views on Abortion
Q. Mr. President, could you confirm this week's published reports that there are divisions within your own immediate family on the issue of abortion, and in particular could you confirm the widely held view that your own wife supports abortion?
A. No, I couldn't confirm that and I can't -and the meeting that I read about in one of the most respected publications was pure, unadulterated malarky, is the word I like to use. It just wasn't there. Rita.
Q. Follow up. As I understand your position you now say that the question of abortion is one of personal choice, one on which Republicans can have diverse views and still be good Republicans.
A. I've always said that, Ann. I campaigned for people that disagree with me on abortion.
Q. But my question is you say it's an issue of personal choice and the question of conscience, and yet you support a constitutional amendment which would remove that choice for all Americans. How do you reconcile those --
A. I reconcile that I was elected to try to fulfill the platform and the programs that I believe in and so that's my personal choice, but that doesn't mean that I have lack of respect for others and that I'm going to go out and not campaign for people that disagree with me on this issue, on foreign policy or whatever it is. And so that's how I explain it. Yeah, Rita.
 
Civilian Death Toll in Panama
Mr. President, last time you took questions here you were claiming success for the capture of Noriega, and also that you had protected American lives in Panama. What do you have to say to the Panamanians about more than 200 civilians - civilian Panamanians that were killed as a result of this invasion? And also, in your aid package to Panama, which hasn't been announced, do you plan to offer any compensation to the families of these people?
A. I'm not sure of the details on the aid package, because we haven't - I haven't signed off on it yet. But what I say to them is, Look, you lost some Panamanian lives; innocent life was lost. And yet 92 percent of the people in Panama strongly supported the action of the United States. Isn't that significant? And I mourn the loss of innocent civilians in Panama, or anywhere else, and certainly mourn the loss of the life of Americans. But you have to feel concerned about that, but you have to look at the broad picture, and then you have to - and I'm very pleased with the strong support from the Panamanian people. And then you've got to do what's right; you have to try to help repair the wounds, repair the damages.
We've got to go to the - I know most of you are very anxious to be at the arrival ceremony out there, and I have to be there. Yes?
 
Fairness of the Tax System
Q. Mr. President, another question that's been raised about the Moynihan proposal is the fairness of the tax system. Over the past decade, even as income tax has come down for high-paid people, Social Security taxes have gone up, mostly for lower- and middle-income people. Do you think that's fair?
A. Well, it's - look, if we were all starting over, I think we'd fine-tune the entire tax system. We're not starting over, and I think that system has been, in and out over the years, basically a pretty fair system. And while I'm here, don't think I've lost because of some arguments - political arguments - on the Hill that capital gains reduction is only for the rich. I support it, but the reason I do is that in my view it - it increases jobs for people.
So you have to look at what individual -somebody has an idea that it's some individual deduction that encourages, say, drilling when we are in an increasingly negative oil supply situation. And some would say, ''Hey, that favors those that go out and drill.'' And I say, ''Wait a minute, that's true and that may not be fair to some taxpayer here, but the national interest is best served by the encouragement and development of domestic resources.''
We're all fat, dumb and happy about our energy situation today, and I'm not. So there's all kinds of provisions that some will argue are fair or unfair.
Q. But, Sir, some of your favorite economists and think-tanks say that the Social Security tax acts as a great disincentive to work and to employing people.
A. Well, I think that's a legitimate complaint about some of it, and that's one of the reasons I favor holding the line on taxes. And one of the reasons I oppose Moynihan is I think it's a disguise for increased taxes around the corner. And I don't want to see the benefits of Social Security cut. It is odd that a Republican President, often accused by political opponents in an election year, is the one that is protecting the sanctity of the Social Security benefits. And I would say to those out around the country, ''Take a hard look now, don't let that rabbit be pulled out of the hat by one hand and 25 other rabbits dumped on you in another.'' This is a very complicated situation and this is, you know, a sleight-of-hand operation here.
And the very day Moynihan proposed it, or the next day, what do we get? We get the call from another prominent, respected Democratic Senator saying raise the sales tax on everybody. Before we go making a lot of changes, let's know exactly where everybody's coming from in this. And I think Mr. Moynihan of a few years back ought to go out and discuss it with Mr. Moynihan of today, because he was a part, I believe, of a Social Security compromise that didn't correct some of the injustice.
Q. Mr. President --
 
A. Hey, listen, I got to be out there looking very strict here at 10 o'clock.

HEADLINE: WAR OF NUMBERS ON BUDGET REOPENS

BYLINE: By SUSAN F. RASKY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24

 BODY:
Washington's annual war of numbers commenced officially today, with the Congressional Budget Office telling lawmakers they will have to find $74 billion in spending cuts or new tax revenue to reduce the 1991 deficit to the level required by law.
In testimony before the Senate Budget Committee, Robert D. Reischauer, director of the non-partisan budget office, also said $38 billion more would be needed to reach the deficit target if Congress approved Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan's proposal to cut Social Security taxes.
Mr. Moynihan, a New York Democrat, has said the taxes should be reduced to force a halt to the practice of using surpluses in the Social Security retirement fund to offset part of the Federal budget deficit. 
 
Sasser Criticizes Estimates
Despite the difference between the Congressional estimate of the deficit and the one expected in the budget request President Bush will send to Congress on Monday, under the terms of the balanced-budget law the Administration figure is the one that has to be used to determine the amount of spending cuts or new taxes needed to reach the deficit target.
''It has become obvious to all concerned that the Office of Management and Budget consistently underestimates the deficits by resorting to the most optimistic economic assumptions it can credibly - and now sometimes even incredibly - employ,'' said Senator Jim Sasser, the Tennessee Democrat who is chairman of the Senate Budget Committee.
Mr. Reischauer told the committee that over the last 10 years the average amount by which the deficit exceeded the amount stipulated in the budget was $40.2 billion a year. He said the use of overly optimistic economic forecasts accounted for 43 percent of the miscalculation.
The budget panel will play a crucial role in deciding how savings from the Pentagon budget should be allocated between reducing the deficit or increasing money for domestic programs.
In a preliminary study of where the military savings might come from, the budget committee's staff has calculated that $93 billion over the next four years could be made available by deferring production on the Sea Wolf submarine and the C-17 transport plane, scaling back the antimissile defense system, and cancelling programs for the B-2 bomber, the mobile basing system for the MX missile, the V-22 vertical lift plane, the Army Air Defense Antitank system and the advanced tactical fighter.
According to the staff study, these deferrals and cancellations would save from $13 billion to $18 billion in the 1991 fiscal year.

HEADLINE: Poll Finds U.S. Expects Peace Dividend

BYLINE: By MICHAEL ORESKES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24

 BODY:
Three out of four Americans say the warming of relations between the United States and the Soviet Union can open the way for cuts in military spending, and by a wide margin they want this ''peace dividend'' spent to fight problems here at home rather than to cut taxes or close the budget deficit.
That is a central finding of the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll and is consistent with an important shift in public sentiment registered in a number of recent surveys: the rebellion against government and taxes, which dominated the politics of the 1980's, is abating and the desire for government intervention at home is on the rise.
A majority wants the Federal Government to spend more to fight drugs and to protect the enviornment. Four out of 10 Americans said they would be willing to pay $100 a year more in Federal taxes if the money would go for those purposes.
 
The Mood of Americans
The poll of 1,557 adults was conducted from Jan. 13 to 15 to gauge the mood of Americans as Congress prepares to receive President Bush's budget and his State of the Union Message next week. The survey has a margin of sampling error of plus or minus three percentage points. 
The central dynamic of the new Congressional session, which opened Tuesday, will be reconciling the pressure for increased domestic spending with the continuing deficit problem and the widely expressed view in the Bush Administration that the United States should not abruptly reduce its military strength.
But pressure to cut military spending is on the rise. When Mr. Bush took office a year ago, 24 percent of the public favored a decrease in military spending. In the current survey, 36 percent said they favored such a decrease. The number who would keep military spending the same has declined over the same period, from 58 percent to 48 percent, while the 13 percent who would increase spending is essentially unchanged from a year ago.
In January 1981, when Ronald Reagan began his Presidencvy on the promise of a major military buildup, only 7 percent of the public thought military spending should be decreased, while 61 percent favored an increase.
 
Military 'Restructuring' Planned
Mr. Bush announced today that his budget proposal would include the first stages of the Administration's plan for ''restructuring'' the military in light of the economic and political changes sweeping Eastern Europe.
The latest survey asked how Americans would like to spend the savings if there is a large cut in military spending in the next few years, whether they wanted ''to reduce the Federal budget deficit, to cut taxes or to spend more to fight problems such as drugs and homelessness.'' Only 10 percent said they would cut taxes; 21 percent favored cutting the deficit and 62 percent said they would spend the money to fight domestic problems.
''There is less tax fear and more of an accumulated public agenda,'' said Paul Tully, political director of the Democratic National Committee. But he and other political analysts cautioned that there is a deep mistrust of government in the nation and a strong belief that general tax increases would be wasted.
 
Some Skeptical Comments
Indeed, when some people in the Times/CBS News Poll were asked if they would pay more taxes to fight drugs or clean up the environment, they said they would but then volunteered skeptical comments about what would really happen to the money.
''I'd pay and then hope to God the money would go to that,'' said Cynthia Olsen, the 38-year-old wife of an Army staff sergeant in Keizer, Ore., in a follow-up interview after the poll was completed.
Although she described herself as a Democrat, she said that if a politician guaranteed that the increased taxes would be spent for the purposes she supported, which include improving education, fighting drugs and cleaning the environment, ''he'd have my vote every time, whether he's a Republican or a Democrat.''
In recent years many Americans have rationalized seemingly contradictory desires to cut taxes while preserving or even increasing spending on favored programs by saying that the money should be found by curbing waste, fraud and abuse. Other surveys have shown that many Americans believe a lot of the Federal budget is wasted. But now a new alternative to raising taxes is taking shape in the public mind: the peace dividend.
 
Split Over the Cold War
Americans are still wary of the new world order. Slightly more than half of those surveyed in the Times/CBS News Poll say the cold war is not over. But even among this group, 31 percent favor a decrease in military spending.
If relations between the United States and the Soviet Union continue to improve, most Americans expect there will be a peace dividend. Asked how much the nation could save on military spending in that eventuality, 36 percent said a lot of money and 38 percent said it would save some money.
Richard G. Darman, director of the Office of Management and Budget, seemed to be well aware of this public expectation when he arrived at a television talk show Sunday with figures to quantify the peace dividend. He said that in the budget Mr. Bush is to submit next Monday the peace dividend would amount to $10 billion, and as much as $40 billion within four years.
''What the political system will actually do with that, or how much it will actually be as it works its way through the political system, you just can't predict at this point,'' Mr. Darman added. It is widely expected that Congress, which very nearly enacted deep cuts in military spending last year, will cut more deeply into the Pentagon budget than Mr. Bush will propose Monday.
The President and other members of his Adminstration have cautioned against cutting too much too soon from the military. Many conservatives in Washington, and even many moderates and some liberals, are coming to see the American military presence in Europe as an important stabilizing force in the Continent's unpredictable political situation. Indeed, current arms reduction talks are seen by many of these people as a way to fend off the pressure for military cutbacks and preserve higher levels of arms and troops than the public mood and political process would produce on its own.
But if there are cuts in spending by the Defense Department, there is broad agreement on where the money should go. Domestic spending to fight problems like drugs and homelessnes is favored over other alternatives among virtually every demographic and political category. Sixty-nine percent of Democrats want to spend the money on domestic problems, but so do 56 percent of Republicans. And among the other Republicans, the clear choice is cutting the deficit (26 percent), while cutting taxes was the third choice (8 percent).
There are other variations, too. Seven out of 10 younger Americans, the 18-to-29-year-olds that both parties view as important to their future, favor spending any peace dividend on domestic problems, while only half of those who are 65 and over do.
The 101st session, which Congress resumed this week, has been one of the most difficult in memory. The House was staggered by a corruption scandal last year and seven Senators face ethics inquiry this year.
 
Corruption Scandals in Congress
The deep veins of cynicism about Washington were tapped in a question about whether members of Congress were financially corrupt. Forty percent said they thought some members of Congress were corrupt, 22 percent said half the members were and 18 percent said most of them are.
Despite corruption scandals in both the House and the Senate, the public attitude toward Congress is not at a record low. Forty-two percent of the public approves of the job Congress is doing, while 47 percent said they disapproved. When the same question was asked in October 1982, 33 percent approved and 50 percent disapproved.
Americans continue to have a better opinion of the representative from their own Congressional district than of Congress itself. Sixty-four percent said they approve of the job their own representatives are doing, while 21 percent disapproved.
Those who said they disapproved of Congress but approved of the work their own representative was doing were asked why they felt their lawmaker was doing a better job than Congress as a whole.
The answers illustrated the crucial importance of service to individuals in the home district and attention to local questions. The two reasons cited most often by nearly half of those who rated their representative better than Congress as a whole were that the lawmaker takes care of people in his or her district and communicates with people.

HEADLINE: New Plan By Owners Rejected

 BODY:
The baseball players' union yesterday rejected a proposal by the owners under which the players could accept the owners' revenue-sharing plan, with its pay-for-performance salary scale, but still qualify for elements of the current system, such as salary arbitration.
''Management loves to have a two-tiered wage structure,'' said Donald Fehr, the executive director of the union. ''All that does is breed problems and resentment.''
The proposal was announced by the owners' chief negotiator, Charles O'Connor. After a five-hour negotiating session in Tampa, Fla., O'Connor, general counsel of the Player Relations Committee, said the owners would be willing to include a grandfather clause in a new collective-bargaining agreement.
Under such a clause, he said by phone from Tampa, players who are in their first six years in the major leagues could opt to be covered by the existing economic rules. Those rules provide for salary arbitration for players after their third, fourth and fifth years in the majors.
Under the plan, the owners would commit 48 percent of gate and broadcasting revenue to player salaries and benefits. Salaries of players in their first six years would be determined by service time in the majors and status within a statistically devised scale. The players would not have the benefits now available: salary arbitration, guaranteed contracts and multiyear contracts.
The two sides plan to meet again today in Tampa, then recess until next Wednesday in New York.

CORRECTION-DATE: January 26, 1990, Friday, Late Edition - Final

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article in Sports Pages yesterday about the baseball labor negotiations referred incorrectly to a method of making revenue-sharing acceptable to the players. The method was not offered by the owners, but was posed in a question to both sides by the reporter.

HEADLINE: For Keeping Up With the Joneses, A Dual-Career Pair

BYLINE: By PATRICIA LEIGH BROWN

DATELINE: ATLANTA, Jan. 21

 BODY:
By their houses, ye shall know them.
Houses built of the social trends of 1990, not just of bricks and mortar, were on display in all their neo-traditional glory at the 46th annual convention and exposition of the National Association of Home Builders, which ended here Monday.
From a ''house for the 'Thirtysomething' generation'' to the Busy Woman's Dream House, the shifts that have taken place within the American family are finding physical expression in the mass-production housing that is the stock in trade of the estimated 65,000 building professionals who descended upon the Georgia World Congress Center - and an exposition floor the size of nearly 17 football fields - for this yearly event.
In a year when housing starts were the lowest since the recession of the early 1980's, the economics of home building were very much on builders' minds. One seminar was titled ''If You Stay in This Business Long Enough, You'll Go Broke.'' 
''They're scrambling,'' said Barry A. Berkus, a Santa Barbara architect who designed two modular houses for the show. ''The builders are faced with a double-edged sword. They're worried about the savings and loans, their traditional source of financing, while at the same time they're looking at a lot of environmental regulations that are slowing down the building process.''
But where design ideas were concerned, there was no lack of trying. It was all here: working at home, teleconferencing, a yearning for the outdoors, a longing for tradition. Outside, classical windows, gables and other details harkened back to America's past. Inside, rather than formal spaces, there was a growing preference for family rooms and the rambling farmhouse-style kitchens that adjoin them.
Twin sinks in enlarged master bathrooms, the drip-free symbols of dual-career couples, are now standard-issue in nearly every new housing development. As Mr. Berkus put it, ''If the only time working couples see each other is between 7 and 7:30 in the morning and while cooking dinner, the bathroom and the kitchen had better become a living room.''
The much-touted media room of the 1980's seemed to yield to the living room, kitchen and family room; increasingly sophisticated technology makes it likely that images will be projected on screens that can drop down in any room.
When they were not chatting about ''power facades'' and ''big-impact looks'' or attending talks on ''Surging Slabs'' and ''90 Marketing Ideas for the 90's in 90 Minutes'' (''See how hot design ideas can make your product sizzle!'') builders engaged in an unusual form of tourism by taking bus tours to Atlanta subdivisions. They also flocked to showcase houses, most constructed for the conference on the outskirts of the city, that were meant to demonstrate the latest residential design trends.
The most talked-about of these was the 2,300-square-foot New American Home '90, sponsored by Builder magazine, Home magazine and the National Council of the Housing Industry, the manufacturers' arm of the builders' association. Designed by Claude Miquelle, a Wakefield, Mass., architect, the house, priced just under $200,000 in the Atlanta market, was meant to reflect the needs of ''Thirtysomething'' couples raising young children. According to a National Association of Home Builders profile of new home buyers, released at the conference, the median age of the new single-family home buyer has risen from 32.8 years in 1976 to 36.8 years in 1989.
An unfinished upstairs ''bonus'' space with a separate entry is intended to be used as either a home office, a ''granny flat'' or as an accessory apartment for a visiting (or returning) child. According to the architect, such flexible interior spaces have become vital. ''Today's couples may have four kids, or no kids, depending on the weekend,'' he said.
In contrast to the open plans of the 1970's, the vaulting interior spaces are informally divided by varied floor and ceiling heights, half-walls with columns, and French doors with transoms. The front entry leads directly into the family room, which is on a lower level, with an informal dining room on one side of the entry and a parlor on the other. In a break with the ''Father Knows Best'' tradition, the main staircase is in the kitchen, which is now, Mr. Berkus said, the room ''the family watches Ted Koppel in.''
''Rather than sitting around the living room in an artificially formal posture,'' said John Bloodgood, a Des Moines architect, ''we're recognizing who we are. The kitchen and the family room are becoming the reality of the house, instead of being tucked away. As the family spends less time together, they want to communicate more.''
Improbable road signs that read ''Dream House: Straight Ahead'' led to the Busy Woman's Dream House, sponsored by Family Circle magazine. The house, built and designed in accordance with a reader survey, tries yet again to answer the question, ''What do women want?'' Among its features is an entertainment center built into the kitchen island and a children's wing with a shuttered laundry chute.
Despite their professional strides, women are still the ''coffee cup fairies'' who shoulder the burden of housework, said Marilyn Turnipseed, the Georgia builder who built the house.
Designed by Jane Siris and Peter Coombs of Siris-Coombs Architects in New York, the house has an attractive pine deck and veranda that extends the interior floor plane to the outside, another trend. It combines a ranch house plan with ''a form of American architecture people like,'' Ms. Siris said.
There were two adjoining factory-built modular ''nest'' (new expanding shelter technology) houses by Mr. Berkus, one of 1,560 square feet and the other of 1,105. They addressed both the aging population and marketing to couples with children, a new concern. Three-foot-wide doorways are incorporated to accommodate wheelchairs. Privacy for children is achieved in small rooms, one with pull-down beds and another with a divider like a sliding windowshade.
The factory-built houses played to the most popular jargon at the convention: ''affordability'' and ''the family market.'' They attracted long lines as builders queued up, occasionally distracted by Vanna White look-alikes in leather minis singing about faucet warranties. The houses' vinyl shingles, pitched roofs and round clerestory windows - a mystifying architectural pastiche Mr. Berkus called ''national regionalism'' - were an attempt, he said, to blend ''old forms with new technology.''
Among the thousand or so exhibitors at the show certain trends were evident. In a nod to the influence of architects, Frank Lloyd Wright in particular, several companies were showing architect-inspired collections. At the General Electric booth there was a Prairie Kitchen. It had Stickley-esque hardware and leaded-glass cabinet doors. It also had a home canning center, a nod to canning as a ''family togetherness activity,'' said Bob Mundt, a designer of G. E. appliances.
Wright also lived on at Marvin Windows in a new insulated corner window with a 90-degree bend, and at Pella Windows and Doors in an Architect Series of insulating windows in Prairie, Palladian and Mission styles.
Spotted in the crowd the Chicago architect Stanley Tigerman confessed that after a while, his eyes ''began to glaze over like heat-seeking missiles.'' But he applauded the resurgence of Wright. ''It's reassuring to see that America is still interested in itself,'' he said.
The growing interest in home technology seemed to reach its apex in the bathroom. Kohler introduced Pillow Talk, a whirlpool bath with a squishy padded rim. A computer controls water temperature, lights under the rim of the tub, room lights and the radio; the bath costs $7,000, without faucets. For those who have everything, there was also a matching chaise longue for the bathroom in water-resistant synthetic leather.
In perhaps the ultimate manifestation of the ''smart'' house, there was the Smart Seat, a microprocessor-controlled bidet attachment for the toilet, as yet only available (for $1,000 to $1,500) in Japan. Shown at American Standard, it attracted the kind of attention that might normally greet a moon man. This ''total hygiene system'' had a ''seat-activation switch'' to control the temperature of the water, dryer and seat. America, take note: it also has a memory.
Other new unveilings included a halogen cooktop at Dacor, a handsome barrier-free shower for elderly people at Kohler, a pull-down ironing board with a built-in light at Nutone), and a spa by Jacuzzi that had a built-in deck. The salesman offered the dubious suggestion that the deck might be used for ''wine and cheese.''
The Slicer-Dicer Award for the most bizarre gadget might go the Cybiag, or Can You Believe It's A Garage Door? This garage door - disguised with a curtained window - is manufactured by a division of Ashland Engineering Inc. of Park Ridge, Ill. On Sunday, about a hundred builders attended a seminar, one of nearly 200 during the convention, called ''Marketing to Kids: The Heart of the New Family.'' Discussing the ''hippie-yuppie dichotomy,'' said Mr. Bloodgood, the architect, along with Todd Zimmerman, a housing research and strategic planner from Clinton, N.J., and Randall Lewis, an Upland, Calif., builder, discussed the ''hot buttons'' essential to catering to baby boom families.
In the future, Mr. Bloodgood predicted, there will be an additional activity room in the house ''for finger painting and growing hydroponic vegetables.'' But for now, Mr. Zimmerman suggested, builders should pay attention to children's housing preferences, including ''the Swiss Family Robinson syndrome,'' the fact that most children would rather live in a tree than a house.
Mr. Zimmerman told the crowd not to overlook ''the guilt factor'' in marketing to ''Thirtysomething'' couples with children.
''Kids are the road to higher profits,'' said Mr. Lewis. He urged the builders to be more involved in their local communities by building playgrounds, sponsoring summer pizza parties and the like. ''You'll not only be the good guy,'' he said. ''It's good for referrals.''

HEADLINE: Rewriting Auction Records

BYLINE: By RITA REIF

 BODY:
IN 1989, defying reports of a softening economy, many antiques and collectibles enthusiasts paid record prices for the rarest works, some with choice pedigrees, in the booming auction market.
Two spectacular prices fetched last year - $12.1 million for an American 18th-century desk-bookcase and $88,000 for a 1920's German teddy bear - were paid by buyers who, some dealers and collectors said, were affected by auction fever. They were determined to acquire these objects at any price. In both cases the bidders encountered stiff competition, and the sums they paid for their prizes far exceeded the auction houses' expectations. 
The Steiff teddy bear caused a sensation when it was auctioned at Sotheby's in London in September, bringing four times the $19,630 that a Steiff bear had brought in May at Christie's South Kensington in London.
The desk-bookcase, the tallest surviving example of what was a status symbol for merchants in Colonial America, was expected to bring $3 million to $5 million, a price commensurate with its pedigree and proportions. When the bidding ended at the June sale at Christie's in New York, the bonnet-topped secretary, made in the 1760's for Nicholas Brown of Providence, R.I., probably by John Goddard of Newport, had surpassed the previous auction record for furniture: $2.97 million paid at Sotheby's in London in 1988 for a Louis XVI console that once belonged to Marie Antoinette.
''Not all masterpieces hang on the wall,'' said Harold Sack of Israel Sack Inc., the New York dealer, after he bought the Newport secretary for a collector he would not name. His client was identified by trade sources as the Texas financier Robert M. Bass.
Auction fever characterized the bidding for other works, too. Some, like the secretary, had enviable pedigrees; others, like the bear, were bought out of sheer collecting enthusiasm. These were among the year's records:
* A Tang horse was sold last December at Sotheby's in London for $5.95 million, a record for Chinese art, to Keiichi Shimojo, a Japanese dealer who bid for a man whom he would identify only as 70-year-old Tokyo real-estate investor.
* A diamond-encrusted ''Pine Cone'' Easter egg by Peter Carl Faberge was sold last May for $3.1 million, a record for any 19th-century work of the decorative arts, at Christie's in Geneva to Joan Kroc, the owner of the San Diego Padres.
* A lotus-shaped lamp made about 1900 by Daum and Louis Majorelle of Nancy, France, brought $1.76 million at Sotheby's in New York in December, a record for Art Nouveau. The buyer was a Japanese bidder who was not identified.
* The $522,500 paid for a Navajo First Phase chief's blanket by David Walentas, a New York real-estate developer, rewrote the record for American Indian art. The price, four times the previous level, was reached at a November sale at Sotheby's in New York.
* In May at the same house, Anthony De Lorenzo, a New York dealer, paid $374,000 for a black lacquer screen by Eileen Gray, a record for a work by the designer.
In collectibles, sometimes emotion plays a major part in the decision to buy. The look on the Steiff teddy bear's face proved irresistible to Paul and Rosemary Volpp. Mr. Volpp, a semiretired West Coast manufacturer of parts for construction equipment, said this week that he gave two instructions to Jack Wilson, a British friend who bid for him and his wife: ''I said, 'I want complete anonymity'; I said, 'Buy the bear.' ''
The Volpps collect teddy bears, and he wanted to give this one to his wife as a 42d wedding anniversary present. ''We admit to owning a little over 5,000 teddy bears, but nobody has the will to count them,'' he said.
Although the presale estimate was $1,120 to $1,440, the Volpps thought the bear would sell for about $23,000. But the bidding was fierce. ''The problem was, there were two people with the same idea,'' Mr. Volpp said.
Rarity commanded high prices in several sales. A complex boxwood clock by Thomas Tompion, a Charles II design made in the late 17th century, brought $1.4 million at Christie's in London in July, when it was sold to Asprey of London. The price was a record for any clock.
An Art Deco wastebasket by Emile-Jacques Ruhlmann was bought by Francois de Menil, a New York architect, for $33,000, a record for a wastebasket, at Sotheby's in New York in May. A much-sought black and white celluloid of Donald Duck in the Disney cartoon ''Orphan's Benefit'' was sold in May for $286,000 to a Canadian collector. And in a November sale at Christie's East in New York, a 1950's Thunder Robot brought $9,020, a record for a toy robot.
''The market goes forward in leaps and then fills in the gaps,'' said James J. Lally, a New York dealer in Chinese art. ''The Tang horse had that tugging effect, that tractor effect.''
Navajo blankets are gaining in popularity, and when a rare one appears, collectors compete relentlessly for it. Mr. Walentas, who owns about a dozen Navajo weavings, said he never intended to spend $522,500 for his, which had been estimated to bring $100,000 to $150,000.
''I got carried away,'' he said. ''I really did not intend to spend that kind of money. I bid by telephone. I just wanted to own it. It is something that only comes along very occasionally. It is not the kind of record you want to set.'' Will these prices ever be repeated? The Faberge market is soon to be tested. In April, the ''Bonbonniere'' Easter egg is to be auctioned at Christie's in New York, with a presale estimate of more than $1 million. Like the ''Pine Cone'' egg, the ''Bonbonniere'' was made not for a Romanov but for Alexander Ferdinandovich Kelch, a gold-mining industrialist from St. Petersburg.
''The big publicity surrounding the price paid for the 'Pine Cone' inspired the client to contact us and to sell it,'' said Marie Stock, one of Christie's specialists in Russian art.
Dean Failey, who heads Christie's sales of American furniture and decorative arts, said the extraordinary price paid for the Newport secretary was no fluke, as was demonstrated last weekend in Christie's sale of American furniture.
''Everyone - collectors, dealers and auctioneers - was looking at this sale as a barometer of what the coming year holds in store in the American furniture market,'' Mr. Failey said. A Philadelphia 18th-century pier table was sold for $4.62 million - the second-highest price for a piece of furniture - to Mr. Sack. And a Philadelphia 18th-century tea table was bought for $1.2 million by Leigh Keno, another New York dealer.
High prices work ''like a magnet,'' Mr. Sack said. ''They give people support to invest in buying American furniture. As far as sellers are concerned, a lot of great pieces are attracted to the market. Money is honey. The secretary was a benchmark. That $12 million secretary makes everything else seem reasonable in price.''

CORRECTION-DATE: January 26, 1990, Friday, Late Edition - Final

 CORRECTION:
Because of a production error, a caption in The Home Section yesterday, with a picture of two cartoon characters sold at auction, was erroneous in some copies. The picture was a rare black and white celluloid from ''Orphan's Benefit,'' by Walt Disney.

HEADLINE: Business Digest

 BODY:

The Economy
Interest rates in Japan and West Germany are surging and in the process dragging up American rates at just the wrong moment for the nation's fragile economy, many economists say. West Germany and Japan are raising rates to try to curb inflation. [Page A1.] The Federal Reserve Board said in a report that the U.S. economy is expected to grow slowly in 1990, with improvements in some regions later in the year. [D8.] 
The $50 billion committed by the Government to rescue depositors at failed savings institutions will run out by mid-1991, a top Federal regulator told Congress. [D1.] The latest institution to be seized is Empire of America, which is based in Buffalo and has $8.8 billion in assets. [D21.]
Auto sales were flat in mid-January, compared with a year earlier, with Japanese companies that make cars here reporting gains and the Big 3 reporting losses. [D8.]
 
International
Ethnic strife has begun to disrupt oil production in the Soviet Union, the world's largest oil producer. Western experts said the resulting drop is expected to contribute to tighter supplies and higher prices for oil around the world. [A1.]
I.B.M. and Siemens will work together to develop advanced computer memory chips for the mid-1990's. [D1.]
 
Companies
Chevron and Exxon said profits had been reduced by a total of more than $1.7 billion in the fourth quarter, in large part to deal with their environmental problems. [D1.]
United Airlines' parent will receive a buyout proposal from the unions representing its pilots, machinists and flight attendants. The plan would give the unions a 75 percent stake in the company. [D1.]
Goldman, Sachs has a stellar reputation, yet a confidential study provides an unflinching self-portrait of an investment bank suffering internal tensions and resentments. [D1.] Five women quit as vice presidents of Goldman Sachs to form a boutique specializing in municipal finance with a sixth woman from Citibank. [D3.]
Large suppliers to Federated Stores will reduce the value on their books of the amounts owed by the retailer, which has sought bankruptcy court protection. [D4.]
Aeroflot, the Soviet airline, has purchased five A310 airliners from Airbus Industrie. It is the Soviet airline's first order for Western aircraft. [D22.]
Adobe Systems has received the first copyright registration for a computer program that generates a style of type. [D5.]
B.A.T., which is fighting off a $21 billion takeover attempt, said it would dismantle units in the U.S. and West Germany. [D4.]
 
Markets
The Dow Jones industrial average closed down by 10.82 points, at 2,604.50, after being off by 62 points in early trading. [D1.]
Treasury notes and bonds moved lower. [D18.] Yields of tax-exempt and taxable money market funds were down. [D9.]
Orange juice futures prices plummeted in the sharpest downturn since a December freeze heavily damaged the Florida crop. [D19.] The dollar finished lower. [D19.]
 
Today's Columns
Some of the nation's largest aerospace companies have decided to take a cooperative approach to building an aircraft that could take off from a runway and fly at 25 times the speed of sound directly into orbit. Talking Deals. [D2.]
''Junk bond'' interest rates will have to remain 5.3 percent above Treasury yields to reward investors fairly for the high risk of default, a recent study found. Market Place. [D10.]
The Bloom Companies wants its name added to a very short list: out-of-town advertising agencies that have made it in New York. Randall Rothenberg: Advertising. [D21.]

HEADLINE: Dow Off 10.82, A Comeback After Plunge

BYLINE: By H. J. MAIDENBERG

 BODY:
The Dow Jones industrial average plunged 62 points in the first half-hour of trading yesterday, then climbed back during the balance of the day to close at 2,604.50, down 10.82.
Analysts said changes in technical factors and fears of rising interest rates had caused the plunge. They said the rally reflected, at least in part, a strong reception in the credit markets to the Treasury's auction of two-year notes.
At the close, declining issues on the New York Stock Exchange outnumbered rising ones, 1,207 to 384. That indicated that most of the recovery was led by a few important stocks, as was the earlier decline. Volume on the Big Board soared to 207.8 million shares, from 179.3 million on Tuesday. 
The analysts said the large opening drop and the later climb was driven by computerized trading, which took advantage of an odd spread between the Standard & Poor index of 500 stocks and the nearest futures contract on the index, for March. The S.&P. index fell 1.35 yesterday, to 330.26, a premium to the March futures contract.
Normally, the futures contract, which is an agreement to buy or sell a certain amount of a financial instrument at a specified time and price, sell for more than the S.&P. 500 index.
That abnormality prompted program traders and arbitragers to sell the underlying shares in favor of buying the unusually ''cheap'' futures.
The early decline was also reinforced by falling bond prices and rising yields, which have contributed heavily in recent weeks to the large losses in the stock market.
Other negative influences included the sharp overnight drop of 599.04 points, or 1.60 percent, in the Tokyo Stock Exchange's Nikkei average of 225 issues. The fall left the average below the 37,000 mark.
Stock prices were also hurt by the surge in interest rates that followed the poor reception accorded the Treasury's auction of $5 billion in 40-year bonds on Tuesday.
 
Strong Recovery
The recovery yesterday gathered full force in the late afternoon, when the computer-program traders who had sold the blue-chip issues from the opening were instructed by their programs to buy most of them back, as those stock prices fell to more attractive levels.
''One positive technical factor undoubtedly put into the computers was the fact that most trades under 10,000 shares during the first hour were buys, not sells,'' said Laszlo Birinyi, who heads an investment consulting firm bearing his name in New York. ''Many small traders apparently expected the early decline because of the index spreads and saw it as an opportunity to buy.''
The analysts also said the opportunity to make money on the other side of the technical-trading coin combined late in the day with the unexpectedly strong demand for $10 billion worth of two-year notes at a Treasury auction yesterday.
Bond traders said the response to the note auction would take some upward pressure off short-term interest rates, which in turn would help make for a more promising climate when the stock market opens this morning.
 
Above 2,600 Level
Another positive technical factor yesterday, Mr. Birinyi said, is that the Dow closed above 2,600. Many of the analysts conceded that a close below 2,600 would have been very troublesome, to say the least.
After yesterday's close, Donald M. Selkin, the index futures and options specialist at Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. said: ''The situation is back to normal and, if anything, the 500 index futures are now dearer than the cash market. Added to this positive situation was the surprisingly good reception given the Treasury's two-year notes, which slowed the rise in Treasury yields.''
In New York, the S.&P. 500 index closed at 330.26, but the March futures contract on the index, which trades on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange for 15 minutes after the Big Board closes, finished with a gain of 2.85, at 333.10. Thus, the futures settled with a premium of 2.84 points over the cash, or actual, index.
 
Normal Premium of 2.05
Mr. Selkin said he calculated that the normal premium on the March 500 futures contract at yesterday's close should have been 2.05 points. The premium is calculated by using a formula that included the number of days to the expiration of the nearest 500 index futures, which is March 16, the interest investors would get if they put their money into 90-day Treasury bills instead of into the basket of 500 stocks and related factors.
Typical of how such computer trading can influence the price of even the bluest of the blue chips was the performance of Merck, the pharmaceutical company based in Rahway, N.J. Its shares closed up 3/4, at 72 5/8, after falling as low as 69 3/4 during the opening selloff.
But among the most-active Big Board issues, changes were fractional, except for Tucson Electric, which dropped 3 1/4, to 13 5/8, on a volume of 2.1 million shares. The Arizona utility not only omitted its quarterly dividend but was downgraded to a ''sell'' by Prudential-Bache, which says Tucson may not resume paying dividends for several years.
Citicorp was the most-active issue, off 3/4, at 24, on 6.3 million shares. Further talk had arisen about the bank holding company acquiring some of the assets of the troubled Bank of New England, which rose 1/2, to 3 3/4.
 
UAL Rises to $161.50
UAL, the parent of United Airlines, was again the subject of rumors about an offer by employees to buy the company for $190 a share. The stock closed up 6, at 161 1/2. New York Stock Exchange officials, concerned by stock's volatility, asked UAL if it had any solid developments to report. Officials of the company, based in Elk Grove Township, Ill., said their policy was not to comment on the behavior of its stock or on rumors.
On the American Stock Exchange, Texas Air was the most-active issue, dropping 1 3/8, to 7 3/8, on 6.7 million shares. Officials of the Houston-based company said they could not explain the decline or the unusually high volume. At the First Boston Corporation, the traders said they crossed a block of a million Texas Air shares at 6 1/2. The traders at other brokerages said 900,000 shares of the carrier were crossed at 6 1/4.
The Amex's market-value index dropped 5.06, at 354.67, while in the over-the-counter market, the Nasdaq composite index lost 4.76 at 425.66

HEADLINE: I.B.M. Joins Siemens In Developing Chips

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF

 BODY:
In a move to strengthen its ability to compete with Japanese semiconductor manufacturers, the International Business Machines Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to work with the West German electronics giant Siemens A.G. to develop advanced computer memory chips for the mid-1990's.
I.B.M. was also encouraged yesterday in its effort to develop ties to the computer industry in Europe when officials at Project Jessi, a European semiconductor consortium, said they would welcome the American company's participation in selected projects with the group. Project Jessi includes Siemens, Philips N.V. and Thomson CSF.
The two announcements are evidence of a growing trans-Atlantic technology cooperation, largely motivated by the fear of Japanese domination of the world's supply of semiconductors, industry executives and analysts said. Several other American companies have development agreements with Japanese manufacturers, but none have such an extensive tie to a European company. 
 
Atlantic Chip Alliance
I.B.M. executives have indicated for some months that the American computer maker has been seeking closer ties with European companies to form an Atlantic alliance. Such an alliance may insure that the United States and Europe will remain independent suppliers of advanced semiconductor chips.
''This is part of a strategy to improve the balance in a global sense,'' said Paul Bergevin, an I.B.M. spokesman. ''The effort is not directed against any particular set of suppliers. But the Japanese are also systems makers who we compete against. We are trying to strengthen the other two legs of the triangle.''
The I.B.M.-Siemens collaboration also reflects the rapidly rising cost of developing new generations of dynamic random access memory, or D-RAM, chips. The highest capacity commercial chip now holds four million bits of information.
I.B.M. and Siemens will jointly develop a chip capable of storing 64 million bits of information - or the equivalent of 10 good-sized novels -on a single fingernail-sized sliver of silicon. Chips with this capacity are expected to be commercial manufactured as early as 1995.
Currently, chips that can store 16 million bits of information are in the advanced stages of development. The 64-million-bit chip is the next step in the evolution of semiconductors.
''Even for companies the size of I.B.M. and Siemens, the costs of trying to go it alone in developing new generations of memory chips are very significant,'' said Michael Borrus, co-director of the Berkeley Roundtable on International Economics. ''If you can cut those costs in various in ways, it is a tremendous advantage.''
 
Failure of U.S. Memories
I.B.M. officials said yesterday that the agreement with Siemens was not related to the recent failure of U.S. Memories. That attempt to build an American semiconductor manufacturer of advanced memory chips fell apart on Jan. 15 because not enough American computer makers were willing to invest in it.
Analysts and industry executives said the negotiations between I.B.M. and Siemens have been going on for about a year. Although the idea behind U.S. Memories and the announcement of the I.B.M.-Siemens agreement are not directly related, they are both part of the same plan, the executives said.
''I.B.M. views the Europeans as being well ahead of most Americans in their understanding of the threat posed by the Japanese and their understanding the importance of responding in a strategically cohesive manner,'' said Charles H. Ferguson, a computer industry researcher at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.
As part of the agreement to develop new memory chip technology, the two companies will immediately begin to cooperate at I.B.M.'s new advanced semiconductor technology center in East Fishkill, N.Y., and at the Munich semiconductor laboratories of Siemens. No dollar value was assigned to the agreement.
 
X-Ray Lithography
I.B.M. executives said the work would concentrate on chip design and semiconductor-processing technology. But they said it would not include the development of X-Ray lithography technologies.
I.B.M. says it is working on using X-Rays instead of light to manufacture advanced chips because it believes that in the mid- to late 1990's semiconductors will become so dense that lightwaves will fail to resolve the ultra-thin circuit line widths of advanced chips.
The company has signed an agreement with Motorola Inc. to participate in the development of X-Ray lithography technologies.
Officials at Project Jessi, which stands for Joint European Submicron Silicon, also said yesterday that the organization considers Jessi-Sematech cooperation as an important factor in establishing a strong industry for both European and United States semiconductor manufacturers.
Sematech is a consortium financed by American computer and semiconductor companies and the United States Government to develop advanced chip-making equipment.

GRAPHIC: Photo: I.B.M. and Siemens A.G. will work together to develop advanced computer memory chips. One research site will be I.B.M.'s semiconductor technology center in East Fishkill, N.Y., where engineers worked recently on experimental semiconductor wafers. (NYT/Suzanne DeChillo)

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
British Ford Strike Averted

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: LONDON, Jan. 24

 BODY:
Workers at the Ford Motor Company Ltd. voted by nearly 3 to 2 to accept a 10.2 percent pay increase, averting a nationwide strike, union leaders said today.
Final returns showed that 59 percent of those voting went against their union leaders' recommendations and accepted the improved offer. 
They will get a 10.2 percent raise in the first year and a minimum of 8 percent, or a choice of 2.5 percent above inflation, in the second year.
The vote took place on Tuesday and today. Most of the 32,000 workers at the American company's 22 British plants earn an average of $374 a week.
Union leaders rejected the offer last week and sought agreement from the workers to start striking with the last shift on Friday.
The Ford pay negotiations are considered a standard for Britain's manufacturing industry. The Ford deal is likely to mean more double-digit pay demands. The engineering union, the country's largest, immediately said it considered 10.2 percent a benchmark for raises throughout industry.
A Ford spokesman in Britain said the vote ''has saved us the prospect of a potentially damaging strike here and at Ford's continental plants.''

HEADLINE: Earnings Drop At Du Pont

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 24

 BODY:
E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company said today that its fourth-quarter earnings dropped 3.4 percent, prompting some analysts to lower expectations of the company's 1990 results.
Du Pont, based in Wilmington, Del., had earnings of $483 million, or 71 cents a share, in the 1989 quarter, compared with $500 million, or 70 cents a share, in the corresponding period a year earlier, when more shares were outstanding. 
For the year, Du Pont posted a 13.2 percent increase in earnings, to $2.48 billion, or $3.53 a share, on revenues of $35.9 billion. In 1988, Du Pont earned $2.19 billion, or $3.04 a share, on revenues of $32.7 billion.
The company said its quarterly profits were depressed by softening in economic sectors important to the company, including automobiles, housing and electronics.
 
James Wilbur, an analyst for
Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company, said he lowered his 1990 earnings estimate to $3.85 a share, from $3.88, primarily because of anticipated weakness in the auto industry, an important market for Du Pont's polymers, which are used in plastics.

HEADLINE: BankAmerica Change Seen

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 24

 BODY:
A. W. Clausen, who led the BankAmerica Corporation back from the brink of financial ruin, is expected to retire this year as the bank's chief executive, banking industry officials said today.
The changing of the guard might take place at or after the company's annual shareholders meeting in May, they said. 
Richard Rosenberg, 59 years old, the vice chairman for retail operations, is expected to be named the new chief executive, executives said. A bank spokesman would not comment on any changes.
 
Mr. Clausen, 66, who ran
BankAmerica in the 1970's and left to head the World Bank in 1981, returned as chairman and chief executive in 1986, a time when BankAmerica was suffering from huge losses and was the target of a takeover attempt by the First Interstate Bancorp. Mr. Clausen fought off the takeover, revamped the bank's management team and engineered a recovery with steadily increasing earnings.
Two other major California banks, the Security Pacific Corporation and First Interstate, recently announced the retirements of their chief executives.
