HEADLINE: 250 Jobs to Be Cut By Perkin-Elmer

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: NORWALK, Conn., Jan. 24

 BODY:
Citing sagging sales, the Perkin-Elmer Corporation said it would cut 250 jobs within two weeks, most in its semiconductor business. Edward Bloch, a company spokesman, said most of the layoffs would be at the company's optical lithography unit in Wilton. He said skilled and unskilled jobs would be cut.
Perkin-Elmer makes measuring and analyzing equipment for high-technology laboratories. The company cut about 300 jobs at its Norwalk headquarters last April through attrition and contract buyouts. Mr. Bloch said all the job cuts would be in Connecticut. After the cuts, Perkin-Elmer will have 2,200 employees in Connecticut and 6,500 worldwide.

HEADLINE: Auto Sales Were Flat in Mid-January

BYLINE: By PAUL C. JUDGE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Jan. 24

 BODY:
Sales of the eight companies that build cars in the United States were flat in mid-January, compared with a year ago.
The Big Three auto makers sold fewer cars in the 10-day period, compared with a year earlier, while Honda, Toyota, Mazda and Mitsubishi posted increases.
The sales figures for the 10 days ended Jan. 20 translate into a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 6.8 million cars, slightly better than some analysts had been expecting. 
 
'Meaningful Inventory Reduction'
''If the industry can keep selling at this pace, inventories could get back to normal in a matter of weeks,'' said Scott Merlis, an auto analyst with Morgan Stanley & Company. He said the steady pace of sales in January have resulted in ''very meaningful inventory reduction.''
Light-truck sales rose 9.3 percent during the 10 days, led by the Chrysler Corporation, which continued to draw customers with its first rebates on mini-vans.
Analysts said rebates and a steady economy kept vehicle sales from falling below last year's level, which was a fairly strong sales period.
The eight manufacturers sold 156,333 automobiles in mid-January, up slightly from 156,284 in the period last year.
Steady sales would be good news for the auto makers, which have ordered widespread plant shutdowns and cut about 200,000 vehicles from their first-quarter production schedules in an effort to reduce inventories.
 
Ford to Idle Plants
The Ford Motor Company announced today that it planned to idle two car plants, in Edison, N.J., and Kansas City, Mo., and a truck plant in Louisville, Ky., for a week in early February. The shutdowns will result in temporary layoffs of 5,600 hourly workers.
Production slowdowns have spread to include some factories partly or wholly owned by Japanese manufacturers. Diamond-Star Motors, the Mitsubishi Motors Corporation's joint venture with Chrysler, plans to cut the output of cars it manufactures for Chrysler at its plant in Normal, Ill. And Mazda Motor Manufacturing Inc. in Flat Rock, Mich., will trim its production of the Ford Probe later this month.
''If we kept the line speed at normal levels, we'd have more cars than we could sell,'' a Mazda spokesman said.
But the Honda Motor Company, which began producing cars at its new factory in East Liberty, Ohio, last month, said it had no plans to curb production. Slight Gain at G.M. The General Motors Corporation sold 110,736 vehicles, up 1.1 percent from the comparable period last year. Light trucks led the way with a 5.9 percent gain, to 41,036 units. But sales of G.M. cars fell 1.5 percent, to 69,700 units.
Ford's sales fell 6.1 percent, to 82,899, with cars down 10.4 percent, to 47,122, and light trucks up two-tenths of 1 percent, to 35,777.
Chrysler posted a 14.1 percent increase in sales, to 52,340 vehicles. Chrysler's car sales fell 8.8 percent, to 20,196, but its light-truck sales surged by 35.6 percent, spurred by the rebates on its mini-vans.
The Toyota Motor Corporation and Mistubishi both posted sizable sales increases for the 10-day period, reflecting new United States production added since last year. Toyota sold 7,405 cars in mid-January, compared with 1,571 a year earlier. Mitsubishi sold 1,918 cars during the 10 days, compared with 311 in the 1989 period.
Honda's sales increased 14.9 percent, to 7,241 cars, while Mazda posted an increase of 55.4 percent, to 1,049 cars.
The Nissan Motor Company was the only Japanese auto maker to post lower sales on its American-made vehicles, with car sales falling 12.5 percent, to 1,702, and light-truck sales plunging by 42.1 percent, to 1,805.

HEADLINE: Fed Expects Slow Growth This Year

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24

 BODY:
The nation's economy is expected to grow slowly in 1990, with improvements in some regions later in the year, the Federal Reserve Board said today.
''Economic activity is expanding slowly in most of the nation, with conditions somewhat stronger in the West than in the East,'' the central bank said in a summary of its so-called beige book.
The report did not mention any inflationary problems - the reason the Fed slowed the economy early last year by driving up interest rates to dampen demand and cool off pressure on prices. 
The Fed switched course last June and has permitted short-term rates to drop gradually in an effort to keep the slowing economy from falling into a recession. But the central bank has not acted since mid-December and last week the White House broke its usual no-comment stance on Fed activities and said that ''lower interest rates are justified.''
 
'Soft Landing' Seen
Nevertheless, the latest report appeared to indicate that most participants in the Fed's survey, completed Jan. 18, thought the central bank had achieved its ''soft landing'' - continued sluggish growth but no recession.
''The outlook is for slow growth in all regions in 1990,'' the report said. ''Some respondents expect improvement late in the year.''
The survey is conducted eight times a year in preparation for meetings of the Federal Open Market Committee, the Fed's monetary policy-setting arm. The next meeting will be held on Feb. 6-7.
The beige book summed up trends in various sectors of the economy in recent weeks.
''Retail sales in the holiday season ranged from 'disappointing' in Boston to modest in Philadelphia and Atlanta and relatively strong in Chicago, Minneapolis and San Francisco,'' the report said. ''However, widespread discounting generally reduced store profits. Retailers expect flat sales or modest increases through the first six months of 1990. Results in the first weeks of January were said to be encouraging.''
 
Manufacturing Sluggish
The manufacturing sector also performed weakly, according to the report. ''Manufacturing activity is generally sluggish with production declines in some industries (autos, in particular) offsetting gains in others (such as commercial aircraft and oilfield equipment),'' the report said. ''Several districts reported that the steel and computer industries, among others, may be bottoming out. Most manufacturers expected slow growth in 1990, with a weak first half followed by gradual improvement.''
Weather also had an impact on various sectors of the economy, the report said, pointing out that cold weather hurt construction activity in some regions and that cold or dry weather hurt citrus, vegetable and winter wheat crops. It also said that the real estate industry held steady or improved modestly.

HEADLINE: CONSUMER RATES;
Yields' Slide Is Slowed

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Yields of tax-exempt and taxable money market funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report were down for the week ended yesterday, but the decline was not as steep as a week ago.
Analysts at Donoghue's said they still expected lower interest because of a weak United States economy. But they added that the trend toward lower interest rates had been interrupted as higher interest rates abroad affect the American economy. 
Donoghue's seven-day compounded average yield for a taxable money market mutual fund was down 5 basis points in the week, to 8 percent, while the 30-day yield fell a similar amount, to 8.14 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
 
Taxables Up $2.5 Billion
Assets of taxable funds rose $2.5 billion, to $373 billion. Donoghue's analysts said most of the increase came from consumer funds, where assets increased $1.9 billion, to $292.8 billion.
The average days to maturity of securities held in managers' portfolios increased three days, to 41. The increase may be a reflection of managers having to go further in maturities to get higher yields. Shorter maturities have not shown many increases.
Among the general-purpose money market funds with assets of more than $100 million that are surveyed by IBC/Donoghue's, the best performer was the Dreyfus World Wide Dollar Money Market fund, distributed by the Dreyfus Service Corporation in Garden City, L.I.. It had a return of 8.90 percent, or about 90 basis points better than the average yield this week.
 
Tax-Exempts Are Flat
Tax-exempt assets increased $9.3 million, essentially staying flat at $75.9 billion, as the average seven-day compounded yield decreased 7 basis points, to 5.33 percent. Taxable equivalents were 7.40 percent for investors in the 28 percent tax bracket and 7.95 percent for those in a 33 percent bracket.
Just as it has been for the last few weeks and again for the week ended yesterday, the top-performing tax-free fund was the Evergreen Tax-Free Money Market Fund, distributed by the Evergreen Asset Management Company in Purchase, N.Y. Donoghue's said the fund posted a return of 6 percent, about 67 points better than the average.
By contrast, The Bank Rate Monitor's national index showed bank money market accounts and six-month certificates of deposit unchanged, at 6.32 percent and 7.87 percent, respectively.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
'Junk' Forecast: Wide Premiums

BYLINE: By Richard D. Hylton

 BODY:
A RECENT study by a bond research organization concluded that ''junk bond'' interest rates would have to remain 5.3 percentage points above Treasury yields to reward investors fairly for the high risk of default.
''While a 2.6 percent premium was adequate for the traditional junk bond buyer, bond funds and individuals who participate in the market will not be adequately compensated at these levels,'' the study by the Bond Investors Association said.
The study, done by Richard Lehmann, president of the nonprofit research organization, offers some startling figures. But perhaps even more startling are the conclusions about the future of the junk bond market one would reach if the study's logic is extended a few years into the future. The association, which is based in Miami Lakes, Fla., is supported by members and publishes a newsletter. 
Among the findings is that in the last decade 651 junk bond issues defaulted on more than $30.5 billion. The group calculated that the junk bond market comprises 3,500 issues with a value of more than $300 billion of debt, a figure up to $100 billion higher than some previous assessments.
The study, which grouped defaults by the year of issue, demonstrated that for every year about 38 percent of the junk bond issues would eventually go into default. Based on that record of default, Mr. Lehmann predicted $40 billion in defaults in the next three years, with $15 billion of that this year.
''The high incidence of default should keep junk bond yields at current levels,'' Mr. Lehmann said. ''This means that the new issue volume in 1990 will continue its sharp decline since fewer businesses can justify paying such rates.''
An even more important point that the study tries to make is that the rates are high because this is not a good time to be in the junk bond market. Mr. Lehmann regards the present rates as a sign of what is to come, not a buying opportunity.
''The 5.3 percent premium that we came up with is interesting not only because that's where the market is now, but what it says is the differential doesn't represent a buying opportunity but indicates where the market is going to be in the future,'' he said. ''It's not going back to 2.6 percent premium that was adequate for the junk bond buyer.''
There is substantial evidence to support the contention that these kinds of differentials between Treasuries and junk are here to stay.
First, as junk bonds grow more risky, the likelihood that these high yields will be maintained and that defaults will rise is strong. According to Moody's Investors Service, in December of 1981 $22.6 billion of bonds was graded as junk, or below investment grade. That accounted for 6.5 percent of all corporate bonds rated by Moody's. At that time, approximately 42 percent were assigned a Ba rating, that is, where the least risky junk bonds are.
Today the amount of junk rated by Moody's has a face value of $226.2 billion, which accounts for 25.4 percent of all corporate bonds rated by Moody's. The least risky Ba-rated category accounts for only 25 percent of rated junk bonds. On the other hand, the B-rated and even lower-rated categories grew.
''Between 1970 and 1988, the one-year default rate on average for a Ba-rated junk was 1.6 percent,'' said John Lonski, a senior economist with Moody's. ''For B-rated, junk it was 6.7 percent. If we continue to observe the downward shift toward B-rated, then the default rates, of course, will rise.''
Mr. Lonski emphasized that the buzzword now among many junk bond buyers is ''conservative.'' And with good reason. ''You have to keep in mind that the junk bond market has been skewed toward increased risk on average,'' he said. ''If I were putting together a junk bond portfolio now, I would skew my portfolio toward the upper echelon of the junk bond universe.''
If the picture of steady defaults in a junk bond universe that is more speculative and 10 times larger than it was in December 1981 does not paint a grim picture, the specter of a recession on top it all certainly finishes the job.
''If we have a mild recession, we may find that banks and other sources will not be able to lend short-term money to make up for cash shortfalls of junk bond issuers,'' Mr. Lonski said, ''and a number of the more precarious issuers may not be able to procure short-term capital at favorable rates.''
This, of course, sharply increases the likelihood of a deluge of defaults. ''We've never had such a large and risky junk market come under the weight of a recession,'' Mr. Lonski said.
But history is not necessarily the best indicator of where the fast-moving junk market will go. Given the variables, the rate of default in the near term may prove significantly higher than the pattern developed in the last decade.
''If you extrapolate three years forward, you're looking at $40 billion in defaults,'' Mr. Lehmann estimated. ''We're looking for about $25 billion in new issues in 1990 and a 50 percent default rate in 1990 as a function of new issue volume.''

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
U.S. Notes and Bonds Fall Again

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Even as prices of Treasury notes and bonds moved lower again yesterday, some market participants and analysts said they saw the early signs of a strong technical rally.
Talk of a price rebound began to circulate after Tuesday's big selloff was followed by a further slide in prices during overnight trading in Tokyo. The bulk of those declines were made up once trading shifted to the United States.
''This is the first day we have felt constructive on the market in the past three weeks,'' said Roger A. Froelich, president of Technical Dimensions, a firm in Mount Kisco, N.Y., that provides research for institutional investors. ''We have had three weeks of declines, and expect a technically driven rally that will take yields on the 30-year bond back to around 8.25 percent.'' 
In late trading, the Treasury's closely watched 30-year bond was offered at a price of 96 30/32, down 5/32, to yield 8.40 percent. Earlier the bond had been offered at a price to yield 8.45 percent.
 
'Prices Will Correct'
One government bond trader, who asked not to be identified, said: ''The news that is coming on Friday is expected to be constructive for the market. We won't have any more supply for two weeks and we have come down a long ways in price. You can never be sure, but I would anticipate that prices will correct somewhat from here.''
Tomorrow the Government is scheduled to release reports on durable goods orders for December, as well as a preliminary estimate of how much the economy expanded in the fourth quarter. Most analysts anticipate that both reports will provide further evidence of generally weak conditions in the economy.
The sense of slow growth or no growth was underlined in the Federal Reserve's ''beige book,'' released yesterday. Compiled every six weeks or so by the Fed's regional banks, the report said that ''economic activity is expanding slowly in most regions of the country, with conditions somewhat stronger in the West than the East.''
The report had no impact on prices in the credit markets, but analysts said the Fed's comments on inflation were reassuring. The report noted that with the exception of fuel prices, both producer prices and retail prices were steady to falling, ''with discounting occurring in some industries.''
Edward J. Sawicz, president of the Discount Corporation of New York, said the ''beige book fit fairly well with what we know about the economy; and the inflation news was better than I had anticipated.''
A big drop in stock prices helped to keep short-term interest rates firm for much of the session yesterday. But the modest gains were erased as the stock market rallied from its lows.
 
Note Auction Is Strong
In marked contrast to Tuesday, when the Government struggled to sell $5 billion of 40-year bonds for the Resolution Trust Corporation, dealers said that demand was strong for $10 billion of two-year Treasury notes auctioned yesterday.
Bids on the notes produced an average yield of 8.21 percent, 50 basis points, or half a percentage point, above the average yield on securities sold on Dec. 19, the last time two-year notes were auctioned.
The sharp rise in yields attracted healthy bids from individual investors. More than $1.3 billion in non-competitive bids were placed on the securities, the highest total since the July 26 two-year note auction.
In the secondary market for Treasury issues, in late trading yesterday the 7 7/8 percent 10-year notes were offered at 96 25/32, down 2/32, to yield 8.35 percent. And the 7 3/4 percent five-year notes were offered at 97 27/32, down 1/32, to yield 8.26 percent.
Treasury bill rates eased slightly. Three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 7.65 percent late in the day, down three basis points, or hundredths of a point. Six-month bills dipped by a like amount, to a late offered rate of 7.56 percent.
 
Bell South Offering
Activity in the corporate bond market was highlighted by a public offering of $275 million of notes by BellSouth ESOP Trust. Proceeds from the sale will be used to finance the purchase of BellSouth stock in its employee stock ownership plan. A total of $825 million in securities will ultimately be sold to finance the plan.
The 9 1/8 percent notes, which mature in July 2003, were priced at par, or $100, 73 basis points over the prevailing yield on the 7 7/8 percent ten-year Treasury notes at the time of pricing.
The notes, guaranteed by the BellSouth Corporation, are rated AA-1 by Moody's Investors Service and AAA by Standard & Poor's. Morgan Stanley & Company acted as lead manager for the transaction.
Participants in the secondary market for investment-grade corporate bonds said that prices of most issues were unchanged on the day.
Prices of most actively traded municipal bonds dipped by a quarter to a half a point, traders said.

LENGTH: 940 words

HEADLINE: SENATE, BY 4 VOTES, FAILS TO OVERRIDE BUSH'S CHINA VETO;
Getting Mad, Getting Even

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25

 BODY:
In heading off what looked three days ago like a sure defeat on the China issue, President Bush proved today that a popular leader, if sufficiently aroused, can still change votes on Capitol Hill, even in this day of lax party discipline and constantly shifting coalitions.
Mr. Bush managed to keep his record intact; not one of his vetoes has been overridden by the heavily Democratic Congress. He won a fine victory for the executive branch in its decades-long struggle to keep the legislative branch from asserting control over foreign policy. And he had his way on a subject he is convinced he knows better than anyone else in Washington. 
 
Reasons for the Victory
But he did not win by much, and he needed a lot of help, however high he is flying in the opinion polls.
It helped that he needed to persuade only senators of his own party, and not all of them, to block a bill permitting Chinese students to remain in this country after their visas had expired. It helped that the Democrats made the bill a partisan question in their seeming eagerness to pin a defeat on the President within a few days of the start of the new legislative session.
It helped that not many voters were worked up over the issue. Senator John H. Chafee, Republican of Rhode Island, said he doubted that any of his colleagues had been approached by more than two or three constituents about the bill during the long holiday recess.
It helped that the President promised, through an executive order, to do essentially what the Democratic bill would have done - a step that allowed Republican lawmakers who worry deeply about civil liberties questions, like Senator Arlen Specter of Pennsyl vania, to support the White House.
 
A Passionate Argument
Most of all, it helped that George Bush, a mild man who usually finds it hard to communicate passion, got good and mad this time and showed it.
Senator Alan K. Simpson of Wyoming, the Republican whip, who made a testy, offhand remark Tuesday about only five Republican Senators' backing the President, said he had never seen the President ''as focused, as forceful and as effective'' as he was at a morning meeting with Republican senators.
''He was just offended as hell that the Democrats would accuse him of kowtowing to the Chinese leaders or of jeopardizing the Chinese students,'' Mr. Simpson said. ''He let people see his annoyance, he told people that he understood the guys in power in Beijing - rattled off their names, phonetically perfect, guys I've never even heard of - and that convinced people.''
Mr. Bush was badly beaten in the House of Representatives on Wednesday. But like most Presidents, he found it easier to influence the relatively small number of senators. He knows them better, knows how best to twist their arms and to reward them, knows what issues appeal to them and why.
In addition, the longer the issue hung fire, the more it looked like an attempt by the Democrats not only to help the students, not only to register dissatisfaction with the President's relatively mild attitude toward the massacre last June in Tiananmen Square, but also to hand him a defeat early in his second year.
Senator Specter said that, to him, ''the whole thing started to have the smell of the Congress trying to land a political punch on the President's nose, and that made a lot of us rally around our man.''
 
'Politics,' Not 'Policy'
Seeking to frame the debate that way before the vote, Senator Bob Dole, the minority leader, said, ''It's not China policy, it's American politics.''
As things turned out, the roll-call was about as close to a party-line matter as one sees these days, with all the Democrats present voting against Mr. Bush and all but 8 of the 45 Republicans voting with him.
In foreign-policy terms, most experts on Asian issues say they think the vote will have only a marginal effect. China faces problems of corruption, of economic stagnation and of institutional inadequacy so severe that this week's debate must seem minor. And Mr. Bush's executive order, plus his pledge today that ''no student, as long as I'm President, will be sent back,'' would seem to protect those who fear reprisals.
The Democrats had argued along with dissident Republicans that Mr. Bush was sending the leaders in Beijing ''a signal that they can get away with what they have done and retain their power,'' as Senator Slade Gorton, a Republican from Washington, argued this afternoon.
Some of those who voted against Mr. Bush say they think that the Chinese leadership will now be less likely to reform than it might otherwise have been.
 
A Matter of 'Face'
But Professor John K. Fairbank of Harvard University, the dean of American China scholars, said the whole issue had more to do with Chinese ''face'' - with preserving prestige -than anything else. ''They fight the face war on every front,'' he said, and that explains their vocal opposition to the bill that President Bush vetoed.
''It isn't the students as such that bother them,'' Professor Fairbank added. ''If Congress votes against them, that makes a law, something formal, something official, something permanent. But if George Bush does the same thing with an executive order, well, he's just doing what he has to, playing American politics, and they know he's their friend anyway, because he sent his people to see them when the rest of the world wouldn't talk to them. At least that's what I have to figure.'' Presumably, Mr. Bush, who spent a year and a half as United States representative in Beijing and counts himself a China expert as a result, has made some similar calculations.

HEADLINE: Upheaval in the East: Hungary;
U.S. Envoy in Hungary Quits To Handle Investment in East

BYLINE: By CELESTINE BOHLEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BUDAPEST, Jan. 25

 BODY:
R. Mark Palmer, the United States Ambassador here, is resigning from the State Department to manage a new consortium of North American financiers that today announced the purchase of half interest in a Hungarian bank, the first in what was projected as a series of ambitious investments in Eastern Europe.
The chairman of the group, the Central European Development Corporation, is Ronald S. Lauder, a former American Ambassador to Austria and a free-spending, unsuccessful candidate in last year's New York City mayoral race. Mr. Lauder said this week that tourism, communication and commercial real estate would be the main targets of investment, initially in Hungary and Czechoslovakia.
 
Venerable Institution
The announcement of the $10 million bank deal, celebrated with an official ceremony at the Ministry of Finance, will turn 50 percent of the General Banking and Trust Company, one of prewar Hungary's most venerable institutions, over to a group of high-profile businessmen, several of Hungarian descent.
The deputy chairman is Andrew Sarlos, a Toronto-based real estate developer. Other major investors include Melvin Simon, the American shopping mall magnate, and Albert Reichmann, owner of Olympia & York Real Estate Company in Canada. Mr. Lauder, whose family owns the Estee Lauder Cosmetics Company, holds 50 percent of the shares. 
The sale of General Banking and Trust Company shares, while not the first Western purchase of a Communist-held bank, is yet another high-water mark in the continually rising attraction of American businessmen to Hungary.
Foreign investment in Hungary is still limited by the nonconvertibility of the forint, the national currency. Most of the foreign business starting up now is either barter trade dependent on exports of raw materials or in trade of manufacturers' goods made inside the country.
 
Hard-Currency Projects Favored
For investors like the Central European Development Corporation, the initial attraction is to projects like tourism and commercial office space for foreign businesses where payment will be in hard currency and can be legally taken out of the country.
Mr. Palmer, a career Foreign Service officer who has headed the United States Embassy here since December 1986, said today that he did not want to comment on the business venture until he resigned from the State Department in July. He will leave Hungary after the general elections next March, it was announced today.
Lawyers for the State Department apparently reviewed the propriety of an Ambassador's doing business in a region where he has served, and ruled that Mr. Palmer may not conduct business with United States embassies or the State Department for one year after he leaves Government.
Mr. Palmer, who will be the chief executive officer of the group, has told friends that he would like to spend six months of the year in Washington and the rest in Prague, where the projected European Community bank for Eastern Europe is expected to be situated.
Mr. Palmer, 48 years old, who served as Deputy Assistant Secretary of State for Soviet and Eastern European Affairs from 1982 to 86, has been an energetic representative here, championing the cause and virtues of Americans to Hungarians and vice versa.
The Ambassador's gung-ho approach toward Hungary's economic potential was the chief attraction Wednesday night at the inaugural supper of the American Chamber of Commerce here, just formed by representatives of 57 American companies now doing business in Hungary.
''If you stand in a lobby of the Forum Hotel, you are lucky not to get knocked down,'' Mr. Palmer said. ''The gold rush is on in Hungary. Budapest is a boom town.''
He said the opportunities lay not just in the glitzy downtown, which makes Budapest look like a Western city, but in its dingier regions on the outskirts, where the city reveals its age and 40 years of Communist rule. ''There are numerous people here who are poor, which is a disgrace,'' he said. ''The city is in disastrous shape, which means the possibilities are unlimited.''
American business here, as elsewhere in Eastern Europe, pales next to its European competitors. The chamber's president, Michael J. Shade, a banking consultant, said that for every American company doing business in Hungary - he counted about 100 late last year - there were 10 from either West Germany or Austria.
Although the fall of Communism in surrounding countries has given Hungary competition in the rush for Western investment, it has also given investors reassurance that the economic and political changes begun here several years ago have taken on a life of their own.
Hungary's economic lure, however, is tarnished by its $20 billion debt, a figure that officially and suddenly grew by $2 billion late last year. But the Hungarian Government has since made enough cuts in food, housing and other subsidies to satisfy conditions set by the International Monetary Fund.
Hungary faces other major problems as it makes the transition to capitalism. It is known for having one of Europe's worst telephone systems, and only the first hint of a computerized financial infrastructure. But what it has is more than its neighbors, and for the moment, that still puts Hungary at the advantage.
 
Lobbies for Deal-Making
The best evidence of this are the lobbies of Budapest's big hotels, now bursting with businessmen making deals. Fax machines at the popular Forum Hotel are backed up for hours, while Hungarian clients patiently wait their turn to take a seat at the lounge tables.
''It is the new crossroads of Europe,'' said Alexander Tomlinson, a senior adviser to the Washington-based Center for Privatization who has been advising the Hungarian Government on its transition from a state-controlled economy.
Although the Americans do not dominate the foreign investment scene, many of their projects have captured the limelight - General Electric's $150 million investment in the Tungsram lightbulb factory, General Motors' negotiations to start a joint automobile factory. Rupert Murdoch, an Australian-born entrepreneur who has many interests in the United States, announced last week that he had spent $4 million to buy 50 percent of two Hungarian tabloids.
Businessmen here say American investment was spurred last summer by President Bush's visit here and the subsequent decision of Congress to let the Overseas Private Investment Corporation provide guarantees for a return on profits on new American investment here.
 
Business Slow and Arduous
Mr. Lauder - who last year spent $13 million on his campaign for Mayor of New York, where he failed to win the Republican nomination then ran and lost as a Conservative - said that since college he has been drawn to Eastern Europe, where his family is originally from. But he said his experience had shown him that business here is still a slow, arduous process.
''One mistake people make is they think it is Western Europe or the United States,'' he said. ''Americans come in here, see the potential, try to do something in two weeks and are disappointed. It takes years.''
Estee Lauder last year opened a luxury shop on Vaci Street in downtown Budapest. ''People ask why there are not more Western shops,'' Mr. Lauder said. ''It took us two years.''
In his speech last night, Mr. Palmer also cautioned against overenthusiasm and warned that in the next year Hungary, which is now embracing foreign capital, might go through a counterreaction.

HEADLINE: $1 Billion Package Of Aid to Panama Announced by U.S.

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25

 BODY:
President Bush announced a $1 billion package of grants, loans and other types of assistance today to help Panama rebuild its economy after the American invasion and years of corrupt government by Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega.
The proposal was worked out by White House, Treasury and State Department officials, who acknowledged that some of Panama's problems resulted from economic sanctions imposed by the United States in an effort to undermine General Noriega.
Most of the package is subject to approval by Congress, where it is likely to have broad support.
The new President of Panama, Guillermo Endara, who took office as a result of the American invasion last month, said today that while the $1 billion aid package ''does not match the total that we would wish,'' it was still an extremely generous amount that Panama intended to put to use promptly. He said it was about half of the amount requested by his Government. 
Mr. Bush said the new aid programs would give Panama instant relief, ''or as close as instant relief as we can hope for.''
The package includes grants and loans to promote economic development; new incentives for American investment in and trade with Panama; an emergency public works program; new housing to replace that damaged in the American invasion; funds to repair Panamanian businesses damaged in recent looting; funds to help Panama reduce its foreign debt, and a decree restoring the quota for American imports of Panamanian sugar.
Mr. Bush said that Vice President Dan Quayle, who is scheduled to visit Panama this weekend, would review details of the plan with Mr. Endara.
Members of Congress welcomed the proposal. But they said it would not be easy to find all the money at a time when there was a large Federal budget deficit as well as new demands for American aid from the emerging democracies of Eastern Europe.
Administration officials said they did not know where the money would come from or how much might be taken from foreign aid earmarked for other countries or other purposes.
The Bush proposal includes several million dollars to build housing for former residents of El Chorillo, an impoverished neighborhood of frame houses that was heavily damaged last month in three days of fighting around General Noriega's military headquarters.
Lawrence S. Eagleburger, the Deputy Secretary of State, said there were about 2,500 homeless families in El Chorillo and other parts of Panama City.
 
Economic Woes Listed
Mr. Endara said this month that ''Panama is in economic ruins.'' Bernard W. Aronson, the Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs, described the problems when he testified today before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee.
Panama's gross domestic product, which measures the output of goods and services, declined about 16 percent in the last two years, Mr. Aronson said. ''Unemployment, which had been at 12 percent before the crisis, now stands at 25 percent or higher,'' he reported. ''Total external public debt is projected at $4 billion, and the ratio of external debt to gross domestic product is one of the highest in the world.''
''The Noriega regime made no debt service payments for over two years,'' Mr. Aronson added. ''The Endara Government has inherited arrearages of $940 million to international financial institutions and commercial banks. The short period of civil disturbance and looting which followed the collapse of the Noriega regime caused additional damage and has particularly hurt private business.''
The Deputy Treasury Secretary, John E. Robson, said the United States was willing to put up $100 million to $150 million to help Panama reduce its debts to the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank. Administration officials said they would also encourage Japan and Western European countries to help Panama pay off such debts.
The Bush Administration is apparently undecided about where to find the money for Panama. Administration officials originally told Congressional aides that $500 million would be taken from Defense Department accounts, but they seemed to be reconsidering that idea today.
 
'Repair the Wounds'
The Administration also told Congressional aides that it would ask permission to reallocate $40 million previously appropriated for economic aid to Somalia and the Sudan. The United States was unlikely to spend that money because of human rights abuses in Somalia and the Sudan and because of their failure to repay certain loans made in the past.
Mr. Bush said the American aid would help ''repair the wounds, repair the damage'' done in the American invasion.
Under his plan, the Export-Import Bank of the United States would provide up to $400 million to finance sales of American products in Panama. In addition, the Treasury would try to negotiate an agreement with Panama allowing American businesses to take tax deductions for conventions held in Panama. The Defense Department would resume buying Panamanian goods and services for American troops there.
Several Senators expressed doubts today about whether Panama was making a sharp enough break with its past. Senator John Kerry, Democrat of Massachusetts, said he feared that Panamanian banks would not take the steps needed to curtail the laundering of money derived from illicit narcotics traffic.
Senator Christopher J. Dodd, Democrat of Connecticut, said that many of the military men who served under General Noriega were still in Panama's security forces. Mr. Dodd said he feared that ''some of the very culprits who created the problems we've seen in recent months will be back in a few years, under a different name and in different uniforms, engaging in the same practices and activities.''
Senator Claiborne Pell, the chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee, said the United States had an obligation to help Panama create a stable democracy because Washington ''nurtured the rise to power of Manuel Noriega.''

HEADLINE: Bush to Propose Savings Plan Providing Tax-Free Interest

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25

 BODY:
The Bush Administration has added the final details to a new savings plan and other programs that it hopes will address what many economists have identified as the nation's No. 1 economic problem, the lagging United States savings and investment rate.
The centerpiece is a new account that the White House hopes will increase the amount that many Americans save each year by granting them tax-free interest on money left on deposit for at least seven years.
The White House hopes the account will induce millions of middle-income Americans, particularly members of young families, to save more. President Bush had promised to push for such an account during his election campaign, and he will officially propose it when he sends his 1991 budget request to Congress on Monday, Deposits Not Deductible Deposits in these accounts would not be tax-deductible. Thus the proposal would not be immediately costly to the Treasury by enabling people to reduce their tax bills. But over the years some people, perhaps many, could deposit large amounts of money in these tax-free accounts that they might have saved in taxable accounts, costing the Treasury money. 
The White House hopes the beneficial effects of the higher savings rate would more than offset that loss in revenue.
Mr. Bush also plans to propose that Congress expand the scope of individual retirement accounts, so savings in these accounts could be used by people for the purchase of their first home, Administration officials said.
President Bush's proposals are subject to approval by Congress. Because the savings proposal gives much of the middle class a small but significant tax break, it is politically difficult for either Republicans or Democrats to oppose.
But if it is politically sound, some economists said, the proposal is economically questionable. Many people would take advantage of it to switch money from a savings account where the interest is taxable, they said, to another, and some economists characterized it as a political ploy by the Bush Administration to broaden the number of taxpayers benefiting from a break.
President Bush has also been pushing for a reduction in the capital gains tax rate, another of his campaign promises. A lower gains tax, which is assessed when assets like stocks or real estate are sold, would principally benefit richer families.
A consensus seems to have emerged in Congress that some form of capital gains reduction will be enacted this year.
 
'Shifting Ballast'
One critic of the new savings proposal, Charles L. Schultze, senior fellow at the Brookings Institution and chairman of President Carter's Council of Economic Advisers, said: ''It's a little bit like shifting ballast around in the Titanic. I do not think it is going to change savings. All we are doing is dumping the revenue loss off onto people in the future.''
Several legislators have proposed their own plans to stimulate savings, primarily by enlarging the use of the I.R.A. These plans were discussed last year, often as alternatives to Mr. Bush's proposal for a lower gains tax.
Lobbyists for financial institutions say some form of I.R.A. legislation will also pass before Congress adjourns in the fall. They note that in an election year such plans are generally popular with middle-class voters.
The Family Savings Account, as the President's proposal will be known, would permit families with adjusted gross incomes of less than $120,000 to deposit up to $5,000 a year in an account, with the interest earned tax-exempt provided the money is kept on deposit for seven years. Individuals with incomes of less than $60,000 could put as much as $2,500 into such an account each year.
 
Simple and Widely Available
Administration officials said the plan was both simple - a necessary dimension to make it appeal to a large number of people - and available to a broad range of middle- and upper-income taxpayers. This is thought to be the primary segment of the population that could significantly increase the national savings rate; such groups have in recent years shown a propensity to spend heavily, rather than save.
Family savings rates, now running at just over 5 percent a year, are roughly a third what they are in Japan, which has the highest rate of a major industrialized nation. In West Germany, Canada, France and Belgium, the savings rate in recent years has been about twice as high as in the United States.
The personal savings rate in the United States hit a 40-year low of 3.2 percent in 1987. In the early 1970's, it was above 9 percent.
 
Growing Consensus
There is a growing consensus that domestic savings and investment must be increased and that the nation's growing reliance on foreign capital for investment is an unacceptable substitute.
Economists have been stepping up warnings that low rates of savings and investment inevitably produce a weaker economy and a lower standard of living. Unless the United States stimulates its savings, many of them say, over the long run the nation could turn into a second-rate economic power.
Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, has called the nation's low savings rate ''the most important long-term issue that has to be addressed by policy makers.''
A low savings rate makes it harder for businesses to make new investments in plant and equipment; with a smaller pool of savings capital, their competition for financing drives up interest rates. As a result, businesses either try to find capital from abroad or reduce their spending, which eventually lowers their productivity and earnings potential. And their workers ultimately suffer when companies shut outmoded plants or reduce wages, lowering the standard of living.
Though the basic outline of the Bush savings account has been known for several weeks, the final details have only recently been worked out, Administration officials said today.
Under the plan, the accounts will be offered by any institution that can now offer an I.R.A. This would include banks, savings and loans, credit unions, brokerage firms and mutual funds.
Administration officials said the new family account was intended primarily to give younger families a tax-preferred account that had a shorter term than an I.R.A. The I.R.A. is mainly oriented to retirement, with a 10 percent penalty on withdrawals before the age of 59 1/2.
''We see this as a way to provide the kinds of funds you need for education or catastrophic health problems without changing the I.R.A. too much,'' one official said.
 
Broad Support Seen
The White House is certain to get broad support from the financial industry. ''We're in favor of savings,'' said Robert Dugger, chief economist at the American Bankers Association. ''There are a lot of ways of doing it. But we are never going to get a serious discussion going until we have real proposals, and this is one.''
But other economists were not as supportive.
Mr. Schultze of Brookings and other economists have said that one key to stimulating savings is to cut the budget deficits, since heavy Government spending absorbs large amounts of private savings and leaves little for private industry investment.
 
No Penalty
Under the change that the President will propose in I.R.A.'s, if a first-time home buyer uses I.R.A. funds as a down payment on a home, the 10 percent penalty for early withdrawal would not be applied, an official said.
This is likely to find some sympathy in Congress, though some legislators may propose variations. For example, Lloyd Bentsen, Democrat of Texas and chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, has proposed expanding the use of I.R.A.'s to include first-time home buyers and people needing money for educational expenses.
Lobbyists and economists said they doubted that Mr. Bentsen would support the Family Savings Account without insisting on his version of the I.R.A.

HEADLINE: Excerpts From President's News Conference on China and Other Matters

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from President Bush's news conference in Washington yesterday, as recorded through the facilities of CNN.
 
OPENING STATEMENT
No Chinese student who is in this country is going to be sent back against his or her will, and we will continue to urge the People's Republic of China to recognize the human rights of its citizens, to participate in the affairs of the world community.
And I do want to express my personal thanks to the leadership of the Republican Party in the Senate -Senator Dole, Senator Simpson -who led this effort with courage and determination. And a special thanks to all those members who voted for the values of justice and human freedom that I believe were at stake in this question.
Secondly, this morning I called President Endara of Panama to assure him of our continuing support of his efforts to establish democracy in Panama. A part of this effort involves the establishment of a healthy economy, and I am deeply impressed with his commitment to reform Panama's economy. 
And based on this commitment and the report I received from Larry Eagleburger and John Robson, with us here, I informed President Endara that we'd arrived at an economic assistance package to help assist Panama in its economic recovery.
Our plan, valued at about a billion dollars, includes $500 million in humanitarian assistance for housing, emergency public works, business assistance; loans, guarantees and export opportunities; and then a $500 million, in addition, assistance package for balance of payments support, public investment and economic restructuring. The Vice President will review the details of this plan with President Endara on his visit to Panama.
And we're going to work closely with the Congress on this package to insure its prompt implementation. The economic challenges that Panama faces are great, but we will work with the people to build a prosperous democratic nation. I've just met again with Secretaries Robson and Eagleburger and they believe, given the history in Panama, the business side, that this economic assistance can indeed result in the short-run in a very - in a vastly improved economic situation. Helen?
 
QUESTIONS AND ANSWERS
 
Lifting of Martial Law
Q. Mr. President, isn't it about time that you told the American people what were the results of two secret missions to China? Whether you got any kind of promise from the regime for loosening up and becoming a more tolerant society? And will this victory now lead you to try to lift the sanctions against China?
A. Well, I think I addressed myself to that yesterday, but let me repeat. I was very pleased at the lifting of martial law, I was very pleased at the release of 573 people from jail in a kind of an amnesty. I've said that these weren't all the steps that need to be taken.
I'm very pleased that they've stopped harassing the United States Mission there, our embassy in Beijing. I'm very pleased that they've lightened up on the areas where I think we can really move things forward, and that is the Peace Corps and the Fulbright exchanges.
So this was all part of the debate on the Hill, and I must say that I think that - the fact that they had made those moves carried some weight with some of the senators.
Q. Is that the promise that you were given? They say now that martial law is--
A. No promises. I'm looking for action, not words.
 
Chinese Students in U.S.
Q. Mr. President, of 535 members of Congress, 52 supported you on this veto. Do you view that as any kind of - do you view that as a mandate for your policies?
A. Yeah. Because you've got to give disproportionate weight to how the Executive Branch feels. We're an equal branch. So you add to that the support on the Hill - we come out more than equal.
Q. Does your commitment that no Chinese student will be sent back against his or her will - does that run absolutely, or is that something that will run until such time as you feel that China has changed its ways in some way that meets your approval?
A. Against his or her will is the controlling statement. You, Charles.
 
Aid to Panama
Q. Mr. President, on the aid to Panama - some assessments say $1 billion is only a fraction of what it will need to restore the effects down there. What is your assessment and what are people saying?
A. Well, I'm basing my judgment on what President Endara said, and on the recommendations of the economic mission that went there. And President Endara seemed very pleased with this.
I said to him, if there is additional categories where we can - in which we can be helpful - please let me know. But I think he was very pleased, and I think both Larry and John feel that it is a very good step. Whether it is the last step or not I don't know. We've got to see how that private sector responds, and how the economic recovery goes forward. But I wouldn't say that this is the end of the road in terms of what we can do to help them.
Q. Is there an assessment of what the total cost will be?
A. Well, I think they feel that this is - let's go here, see what happens, and then take another look. Some may come up with higher figures, but this is what we think is a good and full program to give them the help they need right now. Yes.
Q. Mr. President, have you been personally briefed on the exact number of people left homeless as a result of the U.S. invasion of Panama, and when, specifically, sir, can they expect to get new homes to replace those that were destroyed?
A. I think these programs will give instant, or as close as instant relief as we can hope for here. . . . I don't have the exact number there. But I would like to help as best I can with the reconstruction. . . .
 
Action on Drugs
Q. Given the fact that in your inaugural address you talked about the promise to stop the scourge of drugs, and given the fact that today you told newspaper publishers that drugs were at the top of your agenda, is this going to be the primary test of your Administration - in its first four years, at least, is the primary domestic test - assuming the economy doesn't fall apart - is it the big one?
A. I think it's the big one, and I think it's a test, not for the Administration, but for every community in the country, every state, every local government - for the people. And somebody asked me, if you had to set goals, changes in the education system or - and, but where could you most readily hope to see results, I would say in the antinarcotics fight. I think it's really that kind of priority.
 
Trips to China
Q. Going back to China - you gave us an accounting of why General Scowcroft went in December, but I wonder if I could ask you to go back to July. Could you give us an accounting of that trip - what happened? What did you learn? Why did you send him then?
A. To see - to make clear to the Chinese leadership that the relationship is important but that it could not go forward until certain changes were - had taken place. And that, in sum, is what it was about.
Q. Was it your initiative or theirs?
A. Mine. My initiative.
 
Vote on China
Q. Why was it so important to win this vote?
A. Well I said yesterday - I mean, for several reasons - One reason: I think there was a political ingredient in it. And nobody likes - nobody likes to get patted on that, on that.
And also I think from a foreign policy standpoint, I think it's better to do it this way. I think there's a trust factor that hopefully will result in changes that are satisfactory to the American people and to me, a trust factor in the Administration. And I -I hope that I can use that, having won this now, to further the kinds of things that I think will help move China forward.
I will pledge right here to work with the Congress. I love the way their debate ended with both Senator Mitchell and Dole saluting each other for the way in which the matter was discussed. And I think that's a good signal for the political fights that - that may lie ahead.
Q. Mr. President, I understand the Secretary - Transportation Secretary Skinner was among those making calls on this vote.
A. I hope so.
Q. Suggest - well that's just a little pork barrel of persuasion as well. But was there something more than just
A. Highways in China? What are you talking about?
Q. Well, was it just the pure merits of the case that won the day or was it, you know, win one for the--
A. I think there was some politics in it. I think there was politics in it.
Q. Did you make specific promises to anyone on - help on any other issue.
A. No.
Q. On the trust factor, I wonder if I can apply that to the American people, sir. What can you say to convince the people that the missions to China weren't secret simply to avoid the overwhelming public opposition to them?
A. I say I think what I'm doing is correct. And I say I think I was elected to do, in foreign policy, what I think was correct. And you have the checks and balances of the Congress. They had a shot to say that it wasn't correct in this instance. And so I - I say that I feel encouraged that the process worked out this way. And I point back to the original relationship with China, and I don't believe you'd ever had if there hadn't been some secret diplomacy.
 
Policy on China
Q. You indicated in the beginning of your statement that you feel you do have a mandate now on this China policy. A lot of people have criticized it as a secret policy. You also indicated that perhaps you might do more to keep Congress informed. Why not keep them informed of these secret missions, and what do you plan to do in terms of keeping them informed?
A. Well, I think we do. We've bent over backwards to keep people informed in the Congress. And I think once in a while there is something that is, that is done quietly and then when it is proper, while we'll, we'll give a thorough and full briefing. And I think in this one, when this matter was disclosed by us, we immediately briefed Congress on what it was we had intended to do, why we did it. And so, I don't think there's any real lack of consulation. In fact, I pride myself on the fact that we have had outstanding consultation. And I've had these leaders down here over and over again, bipartisan. And I'm going to continue to do that.
Q. Mr. President, it was six months before Congress found out about it.
A. That's right.
Q. Why not inform the people--
A. Because we were working on some initiatives and in my judgment it was better that it be quiet. And I've cited some examples in history, particulary the China trip opening to China that I think was, was best served by the way it was done.
Q. Mr. President, a lot of the emotion over your China policies had to do with the famous Scowcroft toast on videotape. It angered a lot of people to see toasting people responsible for the Tiananmen Square massacre. Would you say that at least that part of it was a mistake. That it--
A. No, because when you go to China, that's, that is, I don't know of anybody that's been there that doesn't engage in that activity. And if you read the full context of what was said, I think it was a very unfair shot. But I agree with you. Some people used that as something that was outrageous. But they ought to go over to China and just understand how it works.
 
Election in Panama
Q. The election last May is the one that never really resulted in a full count, because of General Noriega, yet that's the same election on which the Endara Government is basing its legitimacy. Is it time, sir, for another election in Panama?
A. Well, I think that, fortunately, the Endara Government has been endorsed by the Electoral Commission - they kind of were a little diverted from their normal course of business by Mr. Noriega a while back, but I think that's a matter for the Panamanians to decide. I think it would be a little bit outrageous for us to come charging in and tell them when they ought to have an election.
 
Army of El Salvador
Q. Several key Democratic Senators say they no longer - they don't believe President Cristiani has control of the military any longer. What is your response to that? They are also drafting legislation which would kill future military aid. Do you think you will be as successful in defeating that topic as you were today?
A. I hope so, because Cristiani is trying hard. And I think there is some evidence that he doesn't control all his military. The very fact that he is trying to bring some to justice who at least have been accused of wrongdoing demonstrates that. But the man was elected - certifiably free elections. He is trying very hard. He has taken some extraordinarily courageous and tough steps, and he has my full support.
 
Support in Congress
Q. Mr. President, the surprise victory to start the year, will this transfer to other issues and is this what someone once called Big Mo -momentum - starting off?
A. Listen, I learned a lesson, not to talk about that. And I learned it the hard way, took it right on the chin. And I'm coming in here in a spirit of cooperation and - excuse me if the adrenalin flowed on one or two of the questions because, you know, things didn't look too bright a little while back.
But, no, there's no point in - this is too serious a business, especially as it relates to this China policy. And so I'm not in a mode of talking about momentum or something of that nature. I do think, because of the way it worked out, it's going to be helpful in reaching accommodation in the Senate and in the House on certain of our objections.
And by that mean, I offer out that hand of cooperation, but it is a two-way street; I simply cannot accept legislation that is - that is opposed to principles I believe in. So I don't know where it'll fall out, but there is - and I promise you, I don't come in here with some sense of gloating or anything of that nature of all. It was too tough a vote for a lot of my friends, on both sides of the aisle. . . .
 
Flexibility in Aid
Q. Mr. President, in announcing $1 billion for Panama, that's an awful lot of money, so what countries are going to get less money as a result of our generosity with Panama?
A. Well there will be offsets. And we will, at the appropriate time, which is fairly soon, tell the Congress where we think those offsets should come from. But let me reiterate my philosophical approval for the Bob Dole position, which is to give the President more flexibility on this concept of earmarking. . . .
 
Racism in the U.S.
Q. Mr. President, do you agree with the N.A.A.C.P. and other organizations that there is a rising tide of racism in this country?
A. I had a long talk with some of the executives of the N.A.A.C.P. the other day and they expressed to me their concerns. And I share their concerns. But whether it - I like to think that there isn't a rising tide. I think that there are some very ugly incidents. And if I can use this platform, the White House, to speak out against that bigotry and against that ugliness, perhaps it will help. I don't, but I will tell you that several of those leaders felt that there was a growing pattern of racism and as you, your question said, a rising tide. I don't know that I agree with it, but I do agree there is some very ugly incidents lately and we all ought to do what we can to make clear that is not the American way.
